Suryavarman II built the Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia, the largest religious structure in the world.
To which Hindu god was the Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia dedicated?
The Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia was dedicated to the Hindu god Vishnu.
What events are depicted in the bas-reliefs of the Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia?
The bas-reliefs of the Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia depict events in the Indian epics Mahabharata and Ramayana, as well as Suryavarman II holding court.
What features adorn the Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia?
The Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia is adorned with hundreds of graceful statues of angelic dancers, known as apsara s.
What was the original condition of the Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia during the 12th century?
In the 12th century, the Angkor Wat temple complex in Cambodia had gilded towers and properly maintained moats.
Who succeeded Suryavarman II as ruler of Cambodia from 1160 to 1166?
Yasovarman II succeeded Suryavarman II as ruler of Cambodia from 1160 to 1166.
Who was crowned king of Cambodia in 1181 and ruled for more than 30 years?
Jayavarman VII was crowned king of Cambodia in 1181 and ruled for more than 30 years.
What was the outcome of Jayavarman VII's annexation of the Cham capital in Cambodia?
Jayavarman VII's annexation of the Cham capital resulted in Angkor controlling Champa until Jayavarman’s death.
What type of projects did Jayavarman VII increasingly devote his energies to during his reign in Cambodia?
Jayavarman VII increasingly devoted his energies to religious and religiopolitical construction projects during his reign in Cambodia.
What significant architectural projects did Jayavarman VII undertake in Cambodia?
Jayavarman VII constructed more than 100 rest houses and hospitals throughout Cambodia.
What was the estimated population of Angkor Thom in Cambodia during the beginning of the 13th century?
Angkor Thom in Cambodia was estimated to have been home to approximately 1 million people in the beginning of the 13th century.
What was Jayavarman VII's impact on Cambodia's development?
Jayavarman VII established the full greatness of the Cambodian nation and created a welfare state motivated by Buddhism.
What were the consequences of Jayavarman VII's demands on Cambodia's resources?
Jayavarman VII's overwhelming demands on Cambodia's material and human resources may have contributed to the kingdom's loss of creativity and eventual demise.
What event occurred in Cambodia after the death of Jayavarman VII around 1220?
The Khmer empire in Cambodia began to contract after the death of Jayavarman VII around 1220.
Which kingdoms in northern Thailand challenged Angkorean domination in Cambodia during the early 13th century?
The vigorous new kingdoms centering on the city of Sukhothai in northern Thailand challenged Angkorean domination in Cambodia during the early 13th century.
Who provided the longest and most-detailed extant description of the Khmer capital in Cambodia in 1296?
Zhou Daguan provided the longest and most-detailed extant description of the Khmer capital in Cambodia in 1296.
What was the status of Angkor in Cambodia for the next 200 years after the mid-13th century?
Angkor remained a glittering, crowded, and wealthy city in Cambodia for the next 200 years after the mid-13th century.
What was a key factor in the fall of the Angkorean state in Cambodia?
Competition from the rising Tai power in Ayutthaya was a key factor in the fall of the Angkorean state in Cambodia.
When was a Tai kingdom founded at Ayutthaya that modeled itself culturally on Angkor in Cambodia?
A Tai kingdom was founded at Ayutthaya in 1351 that modeled itself culturally on Angkor in Cambodia.
What was the status of Cambodia after the fall of Angkor?
Cambodia was reduced to a minor power and a Tai vassal state after the fall of Angkor.
Where did the Khmer capital move to after the fall of Angkor in Cambodia?
The Khmer capital moved to Lovek, near the modern capital of Phnom Penh, after the fall of Angkor in Cambodia.
What was the approximate population of Indigenous people in Brazil at the time of European contact in 1500?
Between two million and six million Indigenous people lived in Brazil at the time of European contact in 1500.
How were many Indigenous survivors treated under Portuguese domination in Brazil?
Many Indigenous survivors endured harsh treatment under Portuguese domination in Brazil.
What event in 1498 influenced Portugal's interest in Brazil?
Vasco da Gama's discovery of an all-water route to the Indies and the Spice Islands via Africa's Cape of Good Hope influenced Portugal's interest in Brazil.
Why was Brazil renamed from Vera Cruz?
Brazil was renamed from Vera Cruz because of the copious amounts of brazilwood found there that yielded a valuable red dye.
What motivated the Portuguese to initially trade with the Indigenous population in Brazil?
The Portuguese began a desultory trade with the Indigenous population for brazilwood in Brazil.
Which European power trespassed on Portuguese claims in Brazil and shipped dyewood to Europe?
The French trespassed on Portuguese claims in Brazil and shipped the dyewood to Europe.
What was the first systematic effort made by the Portuguese crown to establish a government in Brazil?
The Portuguese crown made the first systematic effort to establish a government in Brazil in 1533.
How did the Portuguese crown divide the colony of Brazil in 1533?
The Portuguese crown divided the colony of Brazil into 15 hereditary captaincies, or fiefs, each extending 50 leagues along the coast and an indefinite distance inland.
What were the two successful captaincies in Brazil during the initial settlement period?
São Vicente and Pernambuco were the two successful captaincies in Brazil during the initial settlement period.
Who was the donatário of the captaincy of Pernambuco in Brazil?
Duarte Coelho Pereira was the donatário of the captaincy of Pernambuco in Brazil.
What was the primary economic contribution of the captaincy of Pernambuco in Brazil?
The captaincy of Pernambuco in Brazil became a great sugar-producing region, offering the first example of a profitable agrarian export from the New World to Europe.
Who was elected president of the Czech Republic in January 1993?
Václav Havel was elected president of the Czech Republic in January 1993.
Who became prime minister of the Czech Republic after Václav Havel's election?
Václav Klaus became prime minister of the Czech Republic after Václav Havel's election.
What was the separation of the Czech Republic from Slovakia dubbed?
The separation of the Czech Republic from Slovakia was dubbed the Velvet Divorce.
What was the composition of the center-right coalition government in the Czech Republic?
The center-right coalition government in the Czech Republic was composed of the Civic Democratic Party, the Civic Democratic Alliance, and the Christian and Democratic Union–Czech People’s Party.
When did the Czech Republic hold its first general election as a separate entity?
The Czech Republic held its first general election as a separate entity on May 31–June 1, 1996.
What event led to the resignation of the prime minister of the Czech Republic in November 1997?
Major economic problems, serious rifts within the ruling coalition, and public dissatisfaction with Klaus’s leadership and economic policy forced the prime minister’s resignation in November 1997.
What was the outcome of the June 1998 elections in the Czech Republic?
The Civic Democratic Party won more than one-fourth of the votes, while the Social Democrats won nearly one-third.
What was the result of the split in the Civic Democratic Party in the Czech Republic?
Jan Ruml founded a new conservative party, the Freedom Union, to which almost half of the Civic Democrat deputies defected.
What position did Klaus regain shortly after his resignation in the Czech Republic?
Klaus was reelected party chairman of the Civic Democratic Party shortly after his resignation.
Who was installed as prime minister of the Czech Republic after initial unsuccessful attempts to form a government?
Miloš Zeman was installed as prime minister of the Czech Republic after initial unsuccessful attempts to form a government.
Who was elected to the chairmanship of the Chamber of Deputies in the Czech Republic?
Klaus was elected to the chairmanship of the Chamber of Deputies in the Czech Republic.
What was growing in the Czech Republic by the end of the 1990s?
Public dissatisfaction with the political leadership was growing in the Czech Republic by the end of the 1990s.
What declaration did prominent political writers issue in early 1999 to call for change in the Czech Republic?
Prominent political writers issued the "Impuls 99" declaration in early 1999 to call for social, moral, and political change in the Czech Republic.
When did the Czech Republic formally apply for membership in the European Union?
The Czech Republic formally applied for membership in the European Union in 1996.
What was the name of the manifesto circulated by activists in November 1999 in the Czech Republic?
Activists circulated the "Thank You! Now Leave!" manifesto in November 1999 in the Czech Republic.
What document did Germany and the Czech Republic sign in January 1997?
Germany and the Czech Republic signed a document of reconciliation in January 1997.
Who became president of the Czech Republic in 2003?
Klaus became president of the Czech Republic in 2003.
When did the Czech Republic become a member of the EU?
The Czech Republic became a member of the EU on May 1, 2004.
What event occurred in the Czech Republic in March 2009?
The center-right Czech government collapsed after losing a parliamentary vote of confidence in March 2009.
When did the Czech Republic ratify the Lisbon Treaty?
The Czech Republic ratified the Lisbon Treaty in 2009.
Who became the prime minister of the Czech Republic in July 2010?
Petr Nečas became the prime minister of the Czech Republic in July 2010.
What significant change to the Czech Republic's constitution was made in February 2012?
The Czech Republic's constitution was amended in February 2012 to introduce direct presidential elections.
What event occurred within the Public Affairs party in April 2012 that affected the Czech Republic's government?
Public Affairs disintegrated in April 2012, leaving Nečas without a formal majority in the Czech Republic.
Who won the first direct presidential election in the Czech Republic in January 2013?
Miloš Zeman won the first direct presidential election in the Czech Republic in January 2013.
What event toppled the government of the Czech Republic in June 2013?
A scandal involving Nečas toppled the government of the Czech Republic in June 2013.
What was the voter turnout in the first direct presidential election of the Czech Republic?
The voter turnout in the first direct presidential election of the Czech Republic was about 60 percent.
Which party did Miloš Zeman run at the head of in the Czech Republic's first direct presidential election?
Miloš Zeman ran at the head of the Citizens’ Rights Party (SPOZ) in the Czech Republic's first direct presidential election.
What empires have influenced Greece's heritage?
Greece is heir to the heritages of Classical Greece, the Byzantine Empire, and nearly four centuries of Ottoman Turkish rule.
What event united the city-states of ancient Greece against a common enemy?
The Persian Wars united the city-states of ancient Greece against a common enemy.
What was the time period of the Persian Wars in ancient Greece?
The Persian Wars occurred from 492 to 449 BCE in ancient Greece.
What form of government did Cleisthenes introduce in Athens, Greece in 507 BCE?
Cleisthenes introduced democracy in Athens, Greece in 507 BCE.
What governing body in ancient Greece allowed all adult male citizens to vote?
The Assembly (Ecclesia) in ancient Greece allowed all adult male citizens to vote.
What percentage of the total population in ancient Greece were eligible to vote in the Assembly?
Ten to fifteen percent of the total population in ancient Greece were eligible to vote in the Assembly.
How long did the system of democracy introduced by Cleisthenes last in Athens, Greece?
The system of democracy introduced by Cleisthenes lasted nearly two centuries in Athens, Greece.
When did ancient Greece's civilization begin and end?
Ancient Greek civilization flourished from the period following Mycenaean civilization, which ended about 1200 BCE, to the death of Alexander the Great, in 323 BCE.
What event marked the end of ancient Greece's civilization?
The death of Alexander the Great in 323 BCE marked the end of ancient Greece's civilization.
What period marked the end of Mycenaean civilization in Greece?
Mycenaean civilization in Greece ended about 1200 bce.
What period is known as Classical antiquity in Greece?
Classical antiquity in Greece spanned from the output of ancient Greek author Homer in the 8th century bce to the decline of the Roman Empire in the 5th century ce.
What were the major areas shaped by ancient Greece during Classical antiquity?
Ancient Greece shaped areas as diverse as law, architecture, art, language, poetry, rhetoric, politics, and philosophy during Classical antiquity.
What was the role of Greece in the Mediterranean sphere of influence during Classical antiquity?
Greece played a major role in the Mediterranean sphere of influence during Classical antiquity.
What was the significance of Greece in the creation of Western civilization?
Greece played a major role in the creation of Western civilization during Classical antiquity.
What period in Greece is often called a Dark Age?
The period between the catastrophic end of the Mycenaean civilization and about 900 bce is often called a Dark Age in Greece.
What does Thucydides imply about Greece during the post-Mycenaean period?
Thucydides implies that Greece was settling down after something during the post-Mycenaean period.
What does Thucydides display knowledge of regarding the post-Mycenaean period in Greece?
Thucydides displays sound knowledge of the series of migrations by which Greece was resettled in the post-Mycenaean period.
What legendary event was connected to the Dorian invasion in Greece?
The Dorian invasion was connected to the legendary return of the descendants of Heracles in Greece.
What prohibition existed against Dorians in Greece during the 5th century?
Dorians were prohibited from entering Ionian sanctuaries in Greece during the 5th century.
What 5th-century artifact from Greece provides evidence of the prohibition against Dorians?
An inscription from the island of Paros in Greece provides evidence of the prohibition against Dorians.
What period in Greece is characterized by geometric shapes painted on pottery?
The Protogeometric Period in Greece is characterized by geometric shapes painted on pottery.
When did archaeology reveal significant findings about the Protogeometric Period in Greece?
Archaeology revealed significant findings about the Protogeometric Period in Greece in 1981.
What was the approximate duration of the Protogeometric Period in Greece?
The Protogeometric Period in Greece lasted approximately from 1075 to 900 bce.
What significant archaeological discovery was made at Lefkandi in Greece around 1000 BCE?
A grave containing the remains of a man and a woman, along with a large bronze vessel from Cyprus and gold items, was discovered at Lefkandi in Greece around 1000 BCE.
What type of vessel was used to deposit the man's ashes in the Lefkandi grave in Greece?
A large bronze vessel from Cyprus was used to deposit the man's ashes in the Lefkandi grave in Greece.
What animals were buried with the deceased in the Lefkandi grave in Greece?
Horses were buried with the deceased in the Lefkandi grave in Greece, along with their snaffle bits.
What architectural feature was anticipated by the form of the collapsed house at Lefkandi in Greece?
The form of the collapsed house at Lefkandi in Greece anticipated that of the Greek temples two centuries later.
What evidence from Lefkandi in Greece challenged previous assumptions about the post-Mycenaean period?
Lefkandi in Greece provided evidence of contacts between Egypt and Cyprus between 1000 and 800 bce, challenging previous assumptions about the period's isolation and impoverishment.
What does the term colonization imply in the context of Archaic Greece?
The term colonization in Archaic Greece does not necessarily imply state-sponsored sending out of definite numbers of settlers.
What groups are involved in the conflict that began in Sudan in 2023?
The Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitary group are involved in the conflict that began in Sudan in 2023.
What was declared by the International Rescue Committee in December 2024 regarding Sudan?
The International Rescue Committee declared that the crisis in Sudan was the largest humanitarian crisis ever recorded in December 2024.
What is the estimated number of people displaced within Sudan due to the conflict?
An estimated 11.4 million people were displaced within Sudan due to the conflict.
What agreement granted southern Sudan semiautonomous status and led to the secession of South Sudan in 2011?
The 2005 Comprehensive Peace Agreement granted southern Sudan semiautonomous status and led to the secession of South Sudan in 2011.
When did South Sudan gain independence from Sudan?
South Sudan gained independence from Sudan on July 9, 2011.
What was the outcome of the 2011 referendum in southern Sudan?
The 2011 referendum resulted in South Sudan’s independence from Sudan.
What decades-long conflict did the 2005 Comprehensive Peace Agreement end in Sudan?
The 2005 Comprehensive Peace Agreement ended decades of conflict between the southern Sudan population and the Sudanese government.
When did Sudan gain independence?
Sudan became independent in 1956.
What was the main conflict in Sudan from 1955 to 1972?
Sudan experienced a costly and divisive civil war from 1955 to 1972, fought largely in the south but punctuated by violent incidents in the north.
What agreement ended the conflict in Sudan temporarily in 1972?
The Addis Ababa Agreement ended the conflict in Sudan temporarily in 1972.
What agreement granted southern Sudan semiautonomous status in 2005?
The Comprehensive Peace Agreement granted southern Sudan semiautonomous status in 2005.
When was South Sudan declared an independent country following a referendum?
South Sudan was declared an independent country on July 9, 2011.
What was the outcome of the independence referendum held in Sudan in January 2011?
The results of the vote held in January 2011 were overwhelmingly in favour of independence.
What conflict occurred in Sudan in 2023?
Sudan experienced warfare between the heads of the country's military forces and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitary in 2023.
When did Khoisan occupation at Depression Shelter in Botswana begin and end?
Depression Shelter in the Tsodilo Hills has evidence of continuous Khoisan occupation from about 17,000 bce to about 1650 ce.
What economic activity did some Khoi people in northern Botswana adopt during the final centuries of the last millennium before the Common Era?
Some of the Khoi people of northern Botswana converted to pastoralism, herding their cattle and sheep on the rich pastures revealed by the retreating lakes and wetlands.
What was the earliest dated Iron Age site in Botswana?
The earliest dated Iron Age site in Botswana was an iron-smelting furnace in the Tswapong Hills near Palapye, dated about 190 ce.
When did early Iron Age farmers occupy beehive-shaped houses in Botswana?
Early Iron Age farmers occupied beehive-shaped houses made of grass matting around Molepolole in Botswana around 420 ce.
What culture rose in southeastern Botswana around 1095 CE?
A new culture characterized by a site on Moritsane hill near Gabane rose in southeastern Botswana around 1095 CE.
What was the basis of the Toutswe state's prosperity in Botswana between the 7th and 13th centuries?
The Toutswe state's prosperity in Botswana was based on cattle herding between the 7th and 13th centuries.
What successor state to Great Zimbabwe controlled trade in salt and hunting dogs from the eastern Makgadikgadi Pans in Botswana?
The Butua state controlled trade in salt and hunting dogs from the eastern Makgadikgadi Pans in Botswana.
Who founded the Ngwaketse chiefdom in southeastern Botswana by 1795?
Kwena and Hurutshe migrants founded the Ngwaketse chiefdom in southeastern Botswana by 1795.
Where did a group of Ngwato settle farther north in Botswana by 1795?
A group of Ngwato settled farther north at Shoshong in Botswana by 1795.
Who attacked the Ngwaketse in Botswana by 1800?
Raiders from the Cape Colony attacked the Ngwaketse in Botswana by 1800.
Who defeated the Kololo in Botswana in 1864?
The Lozi subjects defeated the Kololo in Botswana in 1864.
Who was the great Ngwaketse warrior king killed by the Kololo in Botswana?
Makaba II was the great Ngwaketse warrior king killed by the Kololo in Botswana.
What Tswana states were reconstituted in Botswana in the 1840s after the wars ended?
The Ngwaketse, Kwena, Ngwato, and Tawana states were reconstituted in Botswana in the 1840s after the wars ended.
Which Tswana king of Botswana allied himself with British traders and missionaries in the 19th century?
Sechele of the Kwena state allied himself with British traders and missionaries in Botswana in the 19th century.
Who baptized Sechele, the Tswana king of Botswana, during his reign?
David Livingstone baptized Sechele, the Tswana king of Botswana, during his reign.
Who tried to seize people fleeing from the Transvaal to join Sechele's state in Botswana?
The Boers tried to seize people fleeing from the Transvaal to join Sechele's state in Botswana.
What was the impact of American Indians on the history of the United States?
American Indians exercised an important influence upon the civilization transplanted from Europe to the United States.
What were some of the contributions of American Indians to European settlers in the United States?

American Indians contributed Indian foods and herbs, articles of manufacture, methods of raising some crops, war techniques, words, a rich folklore, and ethnic infusions to European settlers in the United States.
What was the nature of the conflict between European settlers and American Indians in the United States?
The conflict between European settlers and American Indians in the United States was a protracted and brutal westward-moving conflict caused by white expansionism and Indian resistance.
What European power first promoted overseas exploration and colonization, setting the stage for later English colonization of the area that would become the United States?
The Portuguese were the first Europeans to promote overseas exploration and colonization, beginning with a voyage to Porto Santo off the coast of West Africa in 1418.

Which European power initially lagged behind the Portuguese in navigation and exploration but later made significant conquests in the Caribbean and New Spain, influencing the European expansion that would eventually reach the United States?
The Spanish initially lagged behind the Portuguese in navigation and exploration but quickly closed that gap in the decades following Columbus’s voyages to America.
What European nations successfully established colonies in the United States by the end of the 16th century?
Spain and Portugal remained the only two European nations to have established successful colonies in the United States by the end of the 16th century.
Who led the English expedition to the United States in September 1583?
Gilbert led the English expedition to the United States in September 1583 with five vessels and 260 men.
Who did the English turn to after Gilbert's voyage failed to establish a presence in the United States?
Sir Walter Raleigh was the new man the English turned to after Gilbert's voyage failed to establish a presence in the United States.
What strategy did Sir Walter Raleigh employ to advance England's fortunes in the United States?
Sir Walter Raleigh employed a southern rather than a northern route to North America to advance England's fortunes in the United States.
What was the primary reason for the Virginia colony's poor performance as an investment in the United States during its first two years?
The Virginia colony proved an extraordinarily bad investment due to the unwillingness of early colonizers to provide for themselves and a chronic shortage of capital.
What change did the 1609 charter bring to the Virginia Company's operations in the United States?
The 1609 charter significantly broadened membership in the Virginia Company, temporarily increasing the supply of capital at the disposal of its directors.
How did the early colonizers in the United States expect to sustain themselves in Virginia?
The early colonizers expected the Indians to provide for their existence, a notion that the Indians fiercely rejected.
What charter did the crown issue in 1612 to help the struggling enterprise in the United States?
The crown issued a third charter in 1612, authorizing the company to institute a lottery to raise more capital for the floundering enterprise in the United States.
Who harvested the first crop of a high-grade strain of tobacco in the United States in 1612?
John Rolfe harvested the first crop of a high-grade and therefore potentially profitable strain of tobacco in the United States in 1612.
Who arrived as governor in the United States in 1611 and brought the 'Laws Divine, Morall, and Martial'?
Sir Thomas Dale arrived as governor in the United States in 1611 and brought the 'Laws Divine, Morall, and Martial'.
What laws did Sir Thomas Dale bring to the United States in 1611 to supervise the settlers' lives?
Sir Thomas Dale brought the 'Laws Divine, Morall, and Martial' to the United States in 1611, which were intended to supervise nearly every aspect of the settlers' lives.
What system did the settlers in the United States adopt under Sir Thomas Dale's governance in 1611?

The settlers in the United States adopted a system where each person, including women and children, was given a military rank with duties spelled out in minute detail under Sir Thomas Dale's governance in 1611.
What penalties did settlers in the United States face for violating work regulations in Virginia?

Settlers in the United States faced penalties including being forced to lie with neck and heels together all night for the first offense, whipped for the second, and sent to a year’s service in English galleys for the third.
What incentive did the company offer to settlers in the United States in 1618?
The company offered 50 acres of land to those settlers who could pay their transportation to Virginia and a promise of 50 acres after seven years of service to those who could not pay their passage.
Who issued a call for the election of representatives to a House of Burgesses in the United States in 1619?
Sir George Yeardley issued a call for the election of representatives to a House of Burgesses in the United States in 1619.
What was the original form of the House of Burgesses in the United States?
The House of Burgesses was originally an agency of the governing board of the Virginia Company in the United States.
When was the House of Burgesses scheduled to convene in the United States?
The House of Burgesses was scheduled to convene in July 1619 in the United States.
Who was granted control of Maryland in the United States in 1632?
Lord Baltimore was granted control of Maryland in the United States in 1632.
Who took over the Maryland project after Lord Baltimore's death in the United States?
Cecilius Calvert took over the Maryland project after Lord Baltimore's death in the United States.
Where did Cecilius Calvert promote a settlement in the United States?
Cecilius Calvert promoted a settlement at St. Mary's on the Potomac in the United States.
What was the primary purpose of the colony in the United States as envisioned by Baltimore?
Baltimore intended the colony in the United States to serve as a haven for Catholics and a profitable venture.
What was the demographic composition of the early 17th-century settlement in the United States?
The early 17th-century settlement in the United States was composed overwhelmingly of young single males, many of whom were indentured servants.
How would you characterize Baltimore's administration of the colony in the United States?
Baltimore was for the most part a good and fair administrator of the colony in the United States.
What change occurred in the control of the Maryland colony in the United States following the accession of William III and Mary II to the English throne?

The control of the Maryland colony in the United States was taken away from the Calvert family and entrusted to the royal government following the accession of William III and Mary II to the English throne.
What religion was decreed as the established religion of the Maryland colony in the United States by the crown?
Anglicanism was decreed as the established religion of the Maryland colony in the United States by the crown.
What event led to the Maryland colony in the United States reverting back to a proprietary form of government in 1715?
The Calvert family's renunciation of Catholicism and embrace of Anglicanism led to the Maryland colony in the United States reverting back to a proprietary form of government in 1715.
What ancient kingdom is Bahrain Island widely believed to be the site of?
Bahrain Island is widely believed to be the site of the ancient kingdom of Dilmun.
Which native Arab dynasty has ruled Bahrain since the late 18th century?
The Khalīfah family has ruled Bahrain since the late 18th century.
What was the ancient kingdom of Dilmun known for in Bahrain?
The ancient kingdom of Dilmun was a commercial centre that traded with ancient Sumer.
Which tribes inhabited Bosnia and Herzegovina when the Romans extended their conquests into the territory during the 2nd and 1st centuries bce?
Illyrian tribes inhabited Bosnia and Herzegovina when the Romans extended their conquests into the territory during the 2nd and 1st centuries bce.
Into which Roman province was most of the area of modern Bosnia and Herzegovina incorporated?
Most of the area of modern Bosnia and Herzegovina was incorporated into the Roman province of Dalmatia.
Who drove the Goths out of the Balkans in the early 6th century, making Bosnia and Herzegovina part of the Byzantine Empire?
Byzantine emperor Justinian I drove the Goths out of the Balkans in the early 6th century, making Bosnia and Herzegovina part of the Byzantine Empire.
When did Slavs begin to settle in the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina?
Slavs began to settle in the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina during the 6th century.
Which two powerful Slavic tribes settled in Bosnia and Herzegovina during the 7th century?
The Croats and the Serbs were the two powerful Slavic tribes that settled in Bosnia and Herzegovina during the 7th century.
Who conquered part of northwestern Bosnia and Herzegovina during the late 8th and early 9th centuries?
Charlemagne's Franks conquered part of northwestern Bosnia and Herzegovina during the late 8th and early 9th centuries.
Under whose rule did northwestern Bosnia and Herzegovina later become part of Croatia?
King Tomislav's rule saw northwestern Bosnia and Herzegovina later become part of Croatia.
Which Serb princedom took over much of Bosnia and Herzegovina after King Tomislav's death in 928?
A Serb princedom that acknowledged the sovereignty of the Byzantine Empire took over much of Bosnia and Herzegovina after King Tomislav's death in 928.
Who first recorded the written mention of Bosnia and Herzegovina?
Byzantine emperor Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus first recorded the written mention of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Which dynasty ruled Bosnia and Herzegovina under Ban Stjepan Kotromanić?
The Kotromanić dynasty ruled Bosnia and Herzegovina under Ban Stjepan Kotromanić.
Who were the three prominent rulers of Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1180 to 1463?
Ban Kulin, Ban Stjepan Kotromanić, and King Tvrtko I were the three prominent rulers of Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1180 to 1463.
Which kingdom maintained a theoretical claim to sovereignty over Bosnia and Herzegovina during the medieval period?
The kingdom of Hungary maintained a theoretical claim to sovereignty over Bosnia and Herzegovina during the medieval period.
When did Ban Kulin rule Bosnia and Herzegovina?
Ban Kulin ruled Bosnia and Herzegovina from approximately 1180 to 1204.
Who succeeded Ban Stjepan Kotromanić as ruler of Bosnia and Herzegovina?
King Tvrtko I succeeded Ban Stjepan Kotromanić as ruler of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Who expanded Bosnia and Herzegovina southward by incorporating the principality of Hum?
Stjepan Kotromanić expanded Bosnia and Herzegovina southward by incorporating the principality of Hum.
During which century did Bosnia and Herzegovina briefly become the most powerful state in the western Balkans?
Bosnia and Herzegovina was the most powerful state in the western Balkans in the late 14th century.
What was the result of Bosnia and Herzegovina's isolation from Rome during the medieval period?
Bosnia and Herzegovina's isolation from Rome led to the Bosnian church falling into its own de facto schism.
What was the religious division that occurred in 1054 affecting Bosnia and Herzegovina?
The schism of 1054 divided Western and Eastern Christianity, with most of Bosnia and Herzegovina being Latin except for modern Herzegovina.
What led to complaints from neighboring areas about the Bosnian church in the 1190s in Bosnia and Herzegovina?
Poor theological training, lax observances, and Eastern Orthodox practices led to complaints from neighboring areas about the Bosnian church in the 1190s in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
What action was taken by Ban Kulin in response to the papal legate's investigation in 1203 in Bosnia and Herzegovina?
Ban Kulin gathered a special council at Bilino Polje where church leaders signed a declaration promising reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
What did the church leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina promise in their declaration at Bilino Polje in 1203?
The church leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina promised to correct lax religious practices and not shelter heretics in their monasteries in their declaration at Bilino Polje in 1203.
What happened to the church in Bosnia and Herzegovina over the following century after the 1203 declaration?
The church in Bosnia and Herzegovina became increasingly isolated over the following century after the 1203 declaration.
What was the official view from Rome regarding the Bosnian church by the time the Roman Catholic Franciscans began to operate in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 1340?
The Roman Catholic Church viewed the entire Bosnian church as having fallen into heresy by 1340.
What heresy did many historians in the mid-19th century argue the Bosnian church had adopted in Bosnia and Herzegovina?
Many historians argued the Bosnian church had adopted the extreme dualist heresy of the Bulgarian Bogomils.
What was the religious stance of the Bosnian church in Bosnia and Herzegovina?
The Bosnian church in Bosnia and Herzegovina was an essentially nonheretical branch of the Roman Catholic Church.
What religious order established a network of friaries in Bosnia and Herzegovina during the 14th century?
The Franciscans established a network of friaries in Bosnia and Herzegovina during the 14th century.
What event broke the back of the Bosnian church in Bosnia and Herzegovina?
The conversion of most of the clergy broke the back of the Bosnian church in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Which empire threatened invasion of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the final decades of the medieval Bosnian state?
The Turkish Ottoman Empire threatened invasion of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the final decades of the medieval Bosnian state.
Who struggled for possession of the crown against his brother Tvrtko II after King Tvrtko I's reign in Bosnia and Herzegovina?
Stjepan Ostoja struggled for possession of the crown against his brother Tvrtko II after King Tvrtko I's reign in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
What type of stone tools were found in Pakistan dating back to about 500,000 years ago?
Hand axes of the type commonly associated with Acheulean industry were found in Pakistan dating back to about 500,000 years ago.
When did human populations in Pakistan transition to the Neolithic revolution?
Human populations in Pakistan transitioned to the Neolithic revolution about 8000 bce.
What significant advancements in animal husbandry were made by the people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan from about 8000 to 5000 bce?
The people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan domesticated cattle, sheep, and goats from about 8000 to 5000 bce.
What crops were cultivated by the people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan during the Neolithic period?
The people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan cultivated wheat and barley during the Neolithic period.
What technological developments were made by the people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan during the Neolithic period?
The people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan developed pottery during the Neolithic period.
What type of houses were built by the people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan during the Neolithic period?
The people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan built permanent mud-brick houses during the Neolithic period.
What burial practices were observed by the people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan during the Neolithic period?
The people of Mehrgarh in Pakistan engaged in ritual burials during the Neolithic period.
What period of civilizational development occurred in Pakistan from approximately 5000 bce to 2600 bce?
The Early Indus period occurred in Pakistan from approximately 5000 bce to 2600 bce.
What type of communities emerged in Pakistan during the Early Indus period?
Village communities of settled agriculturalists emerged in Pakistan during the Early Indus period.
What materials were used to make tools in Pakistan during the Early Indus period?
Stone, copper, and bronze were used to make tools in Pakistan during the Early Indus period.
What developments occurred in Pakistan around 3000 bce during the Early Indus period?
Substantial walled towns developed in Pakistan around 3000 bce during the Early Indus period.
What artistic developments became common in Pakistan during the Early Indus period?
Painting and pottery with clear religious symbolism became common in Pakistan during the Early Indus period.
What isolated member of the Dravidian language group is spoken in western Pakistan?
The Brahui language, an isolated member of the Dravidian language group, is spoken in western Pakistan.
What was the historical term for the Indo-Aryan migration into Pakistan?
The Indo-Aryan migration into Pakistan was historically termed the Aryan invasion.
What was the result of the interaction between Indo-Aryan and Indigenous peoples in Pakistan?
The interaction between Indo-Aryan and Indigenous peoples in Pakistan led to significant cultural and genetic integration over the millennia.
What cultures contributed to the diversity of later South Asian societies in Pakistan?
The diversity of later South Asian societies in Pakistan arose from the interaction between Indo-Aryan and Dravidian cultures.
What empire incorporated the Gandhara region of Pakistan as a satrapy around the 6th century BCE?
The Achaemenid empire incorporated the Gandhara region of Pakistan as a satrapy around the 6th century BCE.
Who conquered the Achaemenid empire and entered the Gandhara region of Pakistan by 327 BCE?
Alexander the Great conquered the Achaemenid empire and entered the Gandhara region of Pakistan by 327 BCE.
What was the outcome of Alexander the Great's push eastward in Pakistan?
Alexander the Great's troops refused to fight onward after reaching the Beas River in Pakistan.
What empire emerged as the dominant power in Pakistan after Alexander's representatives left South Asia?
The Mauryan empire emerged as the dominant power in Pakistan after Alexander's representatives left South Asia.
Who established Buddhism as the dominant religion in Pakistan during the Mauryan period?
Ashoka established Buddhism as the dominant religion in Pakistan during the Mauryan period.
What cultural elements blended to create the distinctive Gandhara art style in Pakistan?
Buddhist art blended with Greek and Persian cultural elements to create the distinctive Gandhara art style in Pakistan.
Where in Pakistan are Ashoka's famous Buddhist rock edicts located?
Ashoka's famous Buddhist rock edicts are located at Shahbazgarhi, near Mardan, and at Mansehra in Pakistan.
What empire declined following Ashoka's death in Pakistan?
The Mauryan empire declined following Ashoka's death in Pakistan.
Which city in Pakistan was sacked by the Hephthalites in the 5th century CE?
Taxila was sacked by the Hephthalites in the 5th century CE in Pakistan.
Which rulers controlled Taxila in Pakistan from 185 BCE to the 5th century CE?
Taxila in Pakistan was controlled by the native Gandharans, the Achaemenids, Alexander, the Bactrian Greeks, the Scythians, the Parthians, and the Sasanians from 185 BCE to the 5th century CE.
What ancient texts mention the city of Taxila in Pakistan?
The Ramayana, the Mahabharata, Buddhist literature, and Achaemenian inscriptions mention the city of Taxila in Pakistan.
Who established the first permanent Islamic foothold in Pakistan in 711 ce?
Muḥammad ibn al-Qāsim established the first permanent Islamic foothold in Pakistan in 711 ce.
Who led the second wave of Muslim incursions into Pakistan in the 11th century?
Sultan Maḥmūd of Ghazna led the second wave of Muslim incursions into Pakistan in the 11th century.
What was the primary objective of Maḥmūd’s raids in Pakistan?
Maḥmūd’s raids in Pakistan primarily had as their object taking plunder rather than conquering territory.
Which language became the language of governance in Muslim Pakistan from the era of the Ghaznavids onward?
Persian became the language of governance in Muslim Pakistan from the era of the Ghaznavids onward.
Who led the Ghūrids in their ambitious campaigns into Pakistan by the mid-12th century?
Muḥammad of Ghūr led the Ghūrids in their ambitious campaigns into Pakistan by the mid-12th century.
Who did Muḥammad of Ghūr appoint to oversee the region in Pakistan after taking Delhi in 1193?
Muḥammad of Ghūr appointed Quṭb al-Dīn Aibak to oversee the region in Pakistan after taking Delhi in 1193.
What dynasty founded by Quṭb al-Dīn Aibak ruled Pakistan during the early consolidation of Muslim rule?
The Mamluk dynasty founded by Quṭb al-Dīn Aibak ruled Pakistan during the early consolidation of Muslim rule.
Which five dynasties ruled over Pakistan before the beginning of Mughal rule in 1526?
The Mamluk, Khaljī, Tughluq, Sayyid, and Lodī dynasties ruled over Pakistan before the beginning of Mughal rule in 1526.
What dynasty succeeded the Khaljīs in 1320 and initially experienced prosperity in Pakistan?
The Tughluq dynasty succeeded the Khaljīs in 1320 and initially experienced prosperity in Pakistan.
What external threats did the Tughluq dynasty face during its period of decline in Pakistan?
The Tughluq dynasty faced external threats such as the Mongols during its period of decline in Pakistan.
Who founded the Mughal dynasty in Pakistan after defeating Ibrāhīm Lodī at the First Battle of Panipat in 1526?
Bābur founded the Mughal dynasty in Pakistan after defeating Ibrāhīm Lodī at the First Battle of Panipat in 1526.
Which Mughal emperor ruled Pakistan from 1556 to 1605 and is celebrated as one of the greatest rulers in the history of the Indian subcontinent?
Akbar ruled Pakistan from 1556 to 1605 and is celebrated as one of the greatest rulers in the history of the Indian subcontinent.
What syncretic religion did Akbar attempt to create in Pakistan, blending elements of various faiths?
Dīn-i Ilāhī was the syncretic religion Akbar attempted to create in Pakistan, blending elements of various faiths.
Who succeeded Akbar as rulers of Pakistan and generally upheld his legacy of cultural integration and administrative prowess?
Jahāngīr and Shah Jahān succeeded Akbar as rulers of Pakistan and generally upheld his legacy of cultural integration and administrative prowess.
What was the consequence of Jahāngīr granting the British East India Company permission to establish a trading post in Surat in 1613 for Pakistan?
Jahāngīr's decision to grant the British East India Company permission to establish a trading post in Surat in 1613 had far-reaching consequences for the Indian subcontinent, including Pakistan.
Which architectural structures exemplified the Mughal period in Pakistan?
The Lahore Fort, the Bādshāhī Mosque, and the tomb of Jahāngīr exemplified the architecture of the Mughal period in Pakistan.
What challenges did Aurangzeb face during his reign over Pakistan from 1658 to 1707?
Aurangzeb faced rebellion and enforced a religious orthodoxy that subjugated non-Muslims, agitating Rajputs, Sikhs, and the nascent Maratha kingdom in Pakistan.
What event in 1739 further weakened the Mughal Empire in Pakistan?
Nādir Shah's invasion in 1739 further weakened the Mughal Empire in Pakistan.
Who established the Sikh empire in Pakistan in 1799?
Maharaja Ranjit Singh established the Sikh empire in Pakistan in 1799 with the capture of Lahore from its Durrani ruler.
What event marked the collapse of the Sikh empire in Pakistan?
The Second Sikh War (1848–49) marked the collapse of the Sikh empire in Pakistan.
Which empire annexed Pakistan following the collapse of the Sikh empire?
The British Empire annexed Pakistan following the collapse of the Sikh empire.
When did the British East India Company establish its initial factory in Surat, marking the beginning of its expansion in the subcontinent that would eventually lead to the conquest of Pakistan?
The British East India Company established its initial factory in Surat in 1613, marking the beginning of its expansion in the subcontinent that would eventually lead to the conquest of Pakistan.
What battle in 1757 solidified the British East India Company's status as a military power in the subcontinent, paving the way for its conquest of Pakistan?
The Battle of Plassey in 1757 solidified the British East India Company's status as a military power in the subcontinent, paving the way for its conquest of Pakistan.
Who conquered Sindh in 1843, marking a significant step in the British conquest of Pakistan?
Charles James Napier conquered Sindh in 1843, marking a significant step in the British conquest of Pakistan.
What event in 1849 led to the British annexation of the Punjab, further expanding their control over the territory that is now Pakistan?
The conclusion of the Second Sikh War in 1849 led to the British annexation of the Punjab, further expanding their control over the territory that is now Pakistan.
In what year was the British Balochistan agency established, marking the culmination of British control over Balochistan, a region that is now part of Pakistan?
The British Balochistan agency was established in 1877, marking the culmination of British control over Balochistan, a region that is now part of Pakistan.
What profound influence did Islam have on the peoples and societies of South Asia prior to the emergence of Pakistan?
Islam exercised a profound influence upon the peoples and societies of South Asia, reshaping its cultural landscape and sowing the seeds for the eventual emergence of Pakistan as a separate country.
What language developed since the 12th century and eventually became Pakistan's national language?
Urdu developed since the 12th century and eventually became Pakistan's national language.
What event in 1857 led to increased British wrath against Muslims in Pakistan?
The Indian Rebellion of 1857 led to increased British wrath against Muslims in Pakistan.
What happened to the Mughal Empire in 1858 in Pakistan?
The Mughal Empire was formally dissolved in 1858 in Pakistan.
Who were the leaders laying the groundwork for an independent Islamic state in Pakistan in the 18th century?
Shah Walī Allāh and Sayyed Ahmad Barelvi were the leaders laying the groundwork for an independent Islamic state in Pakistan in the 18th century.
What was the attitude of Muslims in Pakistan towards British ways and English education after the Mughal Empire's dissolution?
Muslims in Pakistan were reluctant to adopt British ways or take advantage of English educational opportunities after the Mughal Empire's dissolution.
What was the impact of British rule on Hindus and Muslims in Pakistan?
Hindus advanced under British rule at the expense of their Muslim counterparts in Pakistan.
Who encouraged Muslims to seek European education in Pakistan?
Sayyid Ahmad Khan encouraged Muslims to seek European education in Pakistan.
What was the outcome of Muslims trying to catch up to Hindus in Pakistan?
Catching up to the more progressive and advantaged Hindus was an impossible task in Pakistan.
What organization was formed in 1906 to give Muslims a voice in Pakistan under British rule?
The All India Muslim League was formed in 1906 to give Muslims a voice in Pakistan under British rule.
Who delivered a 1930 speech calling for an independent Islamic state on the Indian subcontinent, which would later become Pakistan?
Muhammad Iqbal delivered a 1930 speech calling for an independent Islamic state on the Indian subcontinent, which would later become Pakistan.
What event occurred less than three decades before the formation of the Indian National Congress in Pakistan?
The Rebellion of 1857 occurred less than three decades before the formation of the Indian National Congress in Pakistan.
Who coined the name Pakistan for the proposed South Asian country?
Choudhary Rahmat Ali coined the name Pakistan for the proposed South Asian country.
Which Muslim leaders were less than enthused with Iqbal's proposal for Pakistan?
Abul Kalam Azad, Abdul Ghaffar Khan, and Khizar Hayat Khan Tiwana were less than enthused with Iqbal's proposal for Pakistan.
Who coined the name Pakistan in a 1933 pamphlet?
Rahmat Ali and three Cambridge colleagues coined the name Pakistan in a 1933 pamphlet.
What theory did Mohammed Ali Jinnah and the Muslim League propose for the creation of Pakistan?
Mohammed Ali Jinnah and the Muslim League posited a two-nation theory that argued Indian Muslims were entitled to a separate, self-governing state in a reconstituted subcontinent.
When did Mohammed Ali Jinnah assume leadership of the Muslim League in Pakistan's history?
Mohammed Ali Jinnah assumed leadership of the Muslim League in the late 1930s following his break with Congress Party leader Mohandas K. Gandhi.
What was Mohammed Ali Jinnah's concern regarding the Muslim minority in India that led to the demand for Pakistan?
Mohammed Ali Jinnah questioned the security of the Muslim minority in an India dominated by essentially Hindu authority.
What was the stance of British authority towards the Muslim League under Mohammed Ali Jinnah's leadership in Pakistan's history?
The Muslim League, with Mohammed Ali Jinnah as its spokesman, was also the preferred organization from the standpoint of British authority.
What was Mohammed Ali Jinnah's approach to seeking separation from imperial rule in Pakistan?
Mohammed Ali Jinnah promoted the rule of law in seeking separation from imperial rule in Pakistan.
What was the significance of the Lahore Resolution of 1940 in Pakistan's history?
The Lahore Resolution of 1940 called for an independent Muslim state or states in India, which later became relevant to Pakistan.
What event during World War II influenced the political power shift in Pakistan?
World War II weakened the British, forcing them to consider abandoning India, which impacted Pakistan's political landscape.
Which political party's movements pressured the British to abandon India, affecting Pakistan's independence?
The Congress Party, led by Gandhi, organized popular national movements that pressured the British to abandon India, affecting Pakistan's independence.
What mission was sent to New Delhi in early 1942 in response to the Congress Party's campaign for Britain to quit India, affecting Pakistan's path to independence?
The Cripps Mission was sent to New Delhi in early 1942 in response to the Congress Party's campaign for Britain to quit India, affecting Pakistan's path to independence.
What was the outcome of the Cripps Mission's negotiations with the Congress Party leaders regarding Britain's transfer of power during the war, impacting Pakistan's future?
The Cripps Mission's negotiations with the Congress Party leaders regarding Britain's transfer of power during the war ended in failure due to an impasse.
Who conquered Albania in the 2nd century bce?
The Romans conquered Albania in the 2nd century bce.
Who ruled Albania from the end of the 4th century ce?
The Byzantine Empire ruled Albania from the end of the 4th century ce.
Who conquered Albania in the 15th century?
The Ottoman Turks conquered Albania in the 15th century.
What empire ruled Albania for more than four centuries?
The Ottoman Empire ruled Albania for more than four centuries.
In what year was Albania declared independent?
Albania was declared independent in 1912.
What type of state did Albania emerge as after World War II?
Albania emerged from World War II as a communist state.
What event in 1989 led to the emergence of new social forces and democratic political parties in Albania?
The collapse of other communist regimes beginning in 1989 led to the emergence of new social forces and democratic political parties in Albania.
What period marked the earliest evidence of human habitation in Lebanon?
The Paleolithic Period marked the earliest evidence of human habitation in Lebanon.
When did the Neolithic Revolution occur in Lebanon?
The Neolithic Revolution occurred in Lebanon after about 10,000 bce.
What metals were first used in Lebanon during the 4th millennium bce?
Copper and bronze were the first metals used in Lebanon during the 4th millennium bce.
What was the approximate date of the first urban settlement in Lebanon?
The first urban settlement in Lebanon was dated to about 3050–2850 bce.
What event occurred in Byblos, Lebanon around 1630 bce?
The Hyksos destroyed Amorite rule in Byblos, Lebanon around 1630 bce.
What Egyptian pharaoh is mentioned as having officers oversee the felling of cedars in Lebanon?
Seti I had officers overseeing the felling of cedars in Lebanon, as depicted in a temple relief at Karnak.
What type of diplomatic texts from the 14th century bce provide information about Phoenicia in Lebanon?
The Amarna letters, written in cuneiform, provide information about Phoenicia in Lebanon during the 14th century bce.
What language and script were used to write the tablets that reveal the political state of affairs in Lebanon during the time of Egyptian governance?
The tablets that reveal the political state of affairs in Lebanon were written in the Akkadian language and cuneiform script of Babylonia.
Which dominant power had close relations with the Canaanite towns in Lebanon during the period described in the archives?
Egypt was the dominant power that had close relations with the Canaanite towns in Lebanon during the period described in the archives.
What was the administrative division of the land of Retenu, which included Lebanon, under Egyptian rule?
The land of Retenu, which included Lebanon, was divided into three administrative districts, each under an Egyptian governor.
Which Egyptian dynasty no longer intervened in the affairs of Syria in Lebanon after the reign of Ramses III?
The 21st dynasty no longer intervened in the affairs of Syria in Lebanon.
Who attempted to assert Egypt's ancient supremacy in Lebanon around 928 bce?
Sheshonk I attempted to assert Egypt's ancient supremacy in Lebanon around 928 bce.
What event around 1100 bce demonstrated the decline of Egypt's authority in Phoenicia, Lebanon?
The inhospitable reception of Wen-Amon in Byblos demonstrated the decline of Egypt's authority in Phoenicia, Lebanon.
What battle did Ethiopia win against colonial Italy in 1896?
Ethiopia won the Battle of Adwa against colonial Italy in 1896.
When was Ethiopia invaded and occupied by fascist Italy?
Ethiopia was invaded and occupied by fascist Italy in 1935–36.
Who liberated Ethiopia during World War II?
The Allied powers liberated Ethiopia during World War II.
What international organization did Ethiopia help establish in Africa?
Ethiopia helped establish the Organization of African Unity, which later became the African Union.
What United Nations body was established with Ethiopia's support?
Ethiopia supported the establishment of the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa.
What significant UN document did Ethiopia sign as an independent nation?
Ethiopia signed the Charter of the United Nations as one of the first independent nations.
What civilization flourished in North Macedonia between 7000 and 3500 bce?
The Old European (Neolithic) civilization flourished in North Macedonia between 7000 and 3500 bce.
What was the pattern of politics in North Macedonia until the arrival of the Romans?
The pattern of politics in North Macedonia until the arrival of the Romans was a shifting succession of contending city-states and chiefdoms that occasionally integrated into ephemeral empires.
What groups probed the defenses of the Roman Empire in North Macedonia beginning in the 3rd century?
Goths, Huns, Bulgars, Avars, and other seminomadic peoples probed the defenses of the Roman Empire in North Macedonia beginning in the 3rd century.
What was the nature of control from Constantinople over North Macedonia by the mid-6th century?
Control from Constantinople over North Macedonia became more and more intermittent by the mid-6th century.
When did Slavic tribes begin to settle in North Macedonia?
Slavic tribes began to settle in North Macedonia by the mid-6th century.
How was North Macedonia governed from the 7th to the 13th century?
North Macedonia was governed as a system of military marches by the Byzantine state through alliances with local princes from the 7th to the 13th century.
What significant cultural achievement was associated with Saints Cyril and Methodius in North Macedonia during the 9th century?
Saints Cyril and Methodius devised an alphabet based on Greek letters adapted to the phonetic peculiarities of the Slavonic tongue in North Macedonia.
What later development emerged from the alphabet created by Saints Cyril and Methodius in North Macedonia?
The Cyrillic alphabet emerged as a distinctive cultural feature uniting several of the Slavic peoples in North Macedonia.
What was the central purpose of the missionaries led by Saints Cyril and Methodius in North Macedonia?
The central purpose of the missionaries was to preach the Gospel to the Slavs in the vernacular in North Macedonia.
What ecclesiastical connection remained influential during the struggle for North Macedonia in the 19th century?
The ecclesiastical connection with the Greek culture of Constantinople remained a powerful lever during the struggle for North Macedonia in the 19th century.
When did the Slavic tribes begin living in North Macedonia?
The Slavic tribes began living in North Macedonia in the 6th century.
What was the basis of Greece's claim to North Macedonia?

Greece's claim to North Macedonia was based on the area's long association with the Greek-speaking Byzantine state and the Greek claim to continuity with the ancient Macedonian empire of Alexander the Great.
What did Greece attempt to block after North Macedonia's independence in 1991?
Greece attempted to block the international recognition of the Republic of North Macedonia by its constitutional name after its independence in 1991.
What right did Greece deny to Macedonians in North Macedonia and Greece?
Greece denied the Macedonians of the Republic of North Macedonia and Greece the right to identify themselves as Macedonians.
Who reestablished Bulgarian control in North Macedonia after a revolt of the western provinces?
Samuel reestablished Bulgarian control in North Macedonia after a revolt of the western provinces, reigning from 976 to 1014.
Where did Samuel establish his capital and a patriarchate during his reign over North Macedonia?
Samuel established his capital and a patriarchate in Ohrid during his reign over North Macedonia.
What empire included northern and central North Macedonia from 1185 until the mid-14th century?
The second Bulgarian empire included northern and central North Macedonia from 1185 until the mid-14th century.
When did Uganda obtain formal independence?
Uganda obtained formal independence on October 9, 1962.
What groups of people occupied the territory of Russia since the 2nd millennium bce?
Indo-European, Ural-Altaic, and diverse other peoples occupied the territory of Russia since the 2nd millennium bce.
Which groups passed briefly over the territory of Russia between the 4th and 9th centuries ce?
The Huns, Avars, Goths, and Magyars passed briefly over the territory of Russia between the 4th and 9th centuries ce.
What archaeological evidence indicates the development stages of the East Slavs in Russia?
Middle Eastern coins found in eastern Europe indicate the development stages of the East Slavs in Russia.
What period saw commercial explorers penetrate the Volga region in Russia?
Commercial explorers penetrated the Volga region in Russia from about 770 to about 830.
What products did Germanic commercial-military bands find in the territory of Russia?
Germanic commercial-military bands found amber, furs, honey, wax, and timber products in the territory of Russia.
What was the nature of local authority in Russia during Germanic incursions?
There was no significant local authority in Russia to negotiate the balance between trade, tribute, and plunder during Germanic incursions.
What trading organizations from northern Iran and North Africa were active in Russia's lower Volga, Don, and Dnieper regions?
Trading organizations from northern Iran and North Africa were active in Russia's lower Volga, Don, and Dnieper regions, seeking products and slaves.
When did commerce decline in Russia's Don and Dnieper regions?
Commerce declined in Russia's Don and Dnieper regions about 830.
What may be considered the first direct political antecedent of the Kievan state in Russia?
The Volga Rus khagan state may be considered the first direct political antecedent of the Kievan state in Russia.
Who is considered the progenitor of the dynasty that ruled in various portions of East Slavic territory in Russia until 1598?
Rurik is considered the progenitor of the dynasty that ruled in various portions of East Slavic territory in Russia until 1598.
What group of Scandinavians extended their raiding activities down the main river routes toward Baghdad and Constantinople in Russia?
The Varangians extended their raiding activities down the main river routes toward Baghdad and Constantinople in Russia.
What dynasty ruled in various portions of East Slavic territory in Russia until 1598?
The Rurik dynasty ruled in various portions of East Slavic territory in Russia until 1598.
What indicates a flourishing trade in Russia during the period of 900–930?
The number of Middle Eastern coins reaching northern regions indicates a flourishing trade in Russia during the period of 900–930.
What were the Varangians in Russia?
The Varangians were adventurers of diverse origins, often led by princes of warring dynastic clans in Russia.
Who controlled the region of Russia from about 930 to 1000?
Varangians from Novgorod controlled the region of Russia from about 930 to 1000.
What trade route developed during the period of Varangian control in Russia?
The trade route from the Baltic to the Black Sea developed during the period of Varangian control in Russia.
What was the basis of the economic life of the Kievan principality in Russia?
The trade route from the Baltic to the Black Sea was the basis of the economic life of the Kievan principality in Russia.
What determined the political and cultural development of the Kievan principality in Russia?
The trade route from the Baltic to the Black Sea determined the political and cultural development of the Kievan principality in Russia.
Who organized the commerce that was the lifeblood of the Kievan organism in Russia?
The princes organized the commerce that was the lifeblood of the Kievan organism in Russia.
Who established the dynastic seniority system of his clan as the political structure for ruling the scattered territories of Russia?
Vladimir established the dynastic seniority system of his clan as the political structure for ruling the scattered territories of Russia.
What significant religious action did Vladimir take in Russia?
Vladimir invited or permitted the patriarch of Constantinople to establish an episcopal see in Russia.
Who ruled Russia from 1019 to 1054?
Yaroslav ruled Russia from 1019 to 1054.
Who ruled Russia from 1015 to 1019?
Svyatopolk ruled Russia from 1015 to 1019.
What dynasty ruled Russia during the 11th century?
The Rurikid dynasty ruled Russia during the 11th century.
When did the Ryukyu Kingdom become an integral part of Japan?
The Ryukyu Kingdom became an integral part of Japan in 1879.
Who took control of the Ryukyu Kingdom after Japan's defeat in World War II?
The United States took control of the Ryukyu Kingdom after Japan's defeat in World War II.
What replaced the military government of the Ryukyu Kingdom in 1951?
A civil administration based in Naha replaced the military government of the Ryukyu Kingdom in 1951.
What significant developments occurred in South Africa during its prehistory?
South Africa experienced the wandering of small bands of hominins through the savanna, the inception of herding and farming as ways of life, and the construction of large urban centers.
What was the first australopithecine specimen found in South Africa?
The first australopithecine specimen found in South Africa was the skull of a child from a quarry site at Taung.
What are the primary phases of South Africa's prehistory based on technology?
South Africa's prehistory has been divided into the Stone Age and the Iron Age based on technology.
What is the significance of the sites Sterkfontein, Swartkrans, and Kromdraai in South Africa?
Sterkfontein, Swartkrans, and Kromdraai were designated a World Heritage site in 1999 for their australopithecine fossils.
What were the three periods of the Stone Age in South Africa?
The Stone Age in South Africa was divided into the Early Stone Age, Middle Stone Age, and Late Stone Age.
When did the Early Stone Age occur in South Africa?
The Early Stone Age in South Africa occurred from about 2,500,000–150,000 years ago.
What type of tools were found with australopithecine fossil bones in South Africa?
Simple stone tools were found with australopithecine fossil bones in South Africa.
When did the Late Stone Age occur in South Africa?
The Late Stone Age in South Africa occurred from about 30,000–2,000 years ago.
What ancient Roman provinces formed parts of Hungary's territory in antiquity?
The ancient Roman provinces of Pannonia and Dacia formed parts of Hungary's territory in antiquity.
According to the double-conquest theory, who merged with the Magyars arriving in Hungary under Árpád's leadership?
Many of the Late Avars/Early Magyars survived the 9th century to merge with the Magyars arriving in Hungary under Árpád's leadership.
Which neighboring region made itself fully independent in 869 in the area that includes Hungary?
Croatia made itself fully independent in 869 in the area that includes Hungary.
Which neighboring region openly defied its Carolingian overlord in the area that includes Hungary?
Moravia openly defied its Carolingian overlord in the area that includes Hungary.
Who called in the help of the Magyars in 892 to assert authority over the Moravian duke Svatopluk in Hungary?
Carolingian emperor Arnulf called in the help of the Magyars in 892 to assert authority over the Moravian duke Svatopluk in Hungary.
What was the social structure of the Magyar federation in Hungary?
The Magyar federation in Hungary comprised seven tribes, each under a hereditary chieftain and composed of clans with real or imagined blood kinship, including free members and slaves.
Which Turkic tribes were part of the Magyar federation in Hungary?
Three tribes of Turkic Khazars, known as the Kavars, were part of the Magyar federation in Hungary.
What event in 889 affected the Magyars and their confederates in Hungary?
Attacks by the Pechenegs in 889 drove the Magyars and their confederates to the western extremities of the steppes in Hungary.
What name was given to the federation of tribes that would eventually become Hungary?
The federation was known to its neighbours as the On-Ogur, meaning Ten Arrows or Ten Tribes.
What positions of power existed among the Magyars prior to the conquest of Hungary?
The Magyars lived under a dual kingship that included a sacred ruler with minimal powers called the kende and a de facto leader called the gyula.
Who united the positions of kende and gyula into the office of a duke or prince in Hungary?
Árpád united the positions of kende and gyula into the office of a duke or prince in Hungary following the death of the last kende in 904.
What state did the Magyars destroy in 906 during their conquest of Hungary?
The Magyars destroyed the Moravian state in 906 during their conquest of Hungary.
What German force did the Magyars defeat in 907 during their conquest of Hungary?
The Magyars defeated a German force sent against them in 907 during their conquest of Hungary.
Who were the first inhabitants of Tonga?
Austronesian-speaking people of the Lapita culture were the first inhabitants of Tonga.
What dynasty ruled Tonga from at least the 10th century CE?
The Tu'i Tonga ruled Tonga from at least the 10th century CE.
When did the Tu'i Tonga transfer his temporal powers to his brother?
The Tu'i Tonga transferred his temporal powers to his brother about 1470.
Who were the first Europeans to visit Tonga?
Dutch navigators Jakob Le Maire and Abel Janszoon Tasman were the first Europeans to visit Tonga.
When did effective European contact with Tonga begin?
Effective European contact with Tonga began with Capt. James Cook's visits between 1773 and 1777.
Who converted to Christianity in 1831 and later became King George Tupou I of Tonga?
Taufa‘ahau converted to Christianity in 1831 and later became King George Tupou I of Tonga.
What was the period of war and disorder in Tonga that ended with Taufa‘ahau's rule?
Tonga experienced a period of war and disorder from 1799 to 1852 that ended with Taufa‘ahau's rule.
When did King George Tupou I establish a modern constitution for Tonga?
