What principle was unknown in Poland that led to internal strife during every succession?
The principle of primogeniture was unknown in Poland, leading to internal strife during every succession.
Which neighboring regions did Poland alternately compete and cooperate with?
Poland alternately competed and cooperated with Bohemia, Hungary, and the principality of Kievan Rus.
What recognition did Poland receive from Holy Roman Emperor Otto III in 1000?
Holy Roman Emperor Otto III recognized the sovereign status of the Polish duke in 1000.
What ecclesiastical organization did Otto III agree to establish in Poland?
Otto III agreed to an independent Polish ecclesiastical organization that added an archbishopric in Gniezno and bishoprics in Kraków, Wrocław, and Kołobrzeg to the already extant bishopric in Poznań.
What was the objective of the missionary activities coordinated by the rulers of Poland and the Holy Roman Empire?
The rulers sought to coordinate their missionary activities in the pagan Slav lands between the Elbe and Oder rivers, home of the so-called Polabian Slavs.
What year did Bolesław assume the royal crown in Poland?
Bolesław assumed the royal crown in Poland in 1025.
What was the outcome of Bolesław assuming the royal crown in Poland?
Bolesław's assumption of the royal crown made him the equal of other European monarchs.
What event led to Mieszko II renouncing his kingly status in Poland?
Mieszko II was obliged to renounce his kingly status due to the virtual collapse of the state in Poland.
What was the result of Casimir I's efforts in Poland?
Casimir I succeeded in bringing most of the Polish lands under his sway, reviving the ecclesiastical organization, and making Kraków his capital.
Who was the king of Poland that gained the royal crown in 1076 by siding with Rome during the Investiture Controversy?
Bolesław II the Bold was the king of Poland that gained the royal crown in 1076 by siding with Rome during the Investiture Controversy.
When was Stanislaus, the bishop of Kraków, canonized as a saint in Poland?
Stanislaus, the bishop of Kraków, was canonized as a saint in Poland in 1253.
Who succeeded Bolesław II as the ruler of Poland and abandoned claims to the royal crown?
Władysław I Herman succeeded Bolesław II as the ruler of Poland and abandoned claims to the royal crown.
Who emerged as the sole ruler of Poland in 1102 after a period of internal conflict?
Bolesław III (the Wry-Mouthed) emerged as the sole ruler of Poland in 1102 after a period of internal conflict.
What was the outcome of Emperor Henry V's invasion of Poland during Bolesław III's reign?
Emperor Henry V's invasion of Poland was repelled during Bolesław III's reign.
What was the result of the conflict between Poland and Bohemia over Silesia during Bolesław III's reign?
Bohemia renounced its claims to Silesia during Bolesław III's reign.
What system did Bolesław III establish in his 1138 testament to ensure greater stability in Poland?
Bolesław III established a system in his 1138 testament that divided Poland among his sons, with the oldest becoming the senior duke.
What was the role of the senior duke in Poland according to Bolesław III's system?
The senior duke in Poland had general powers over military, foreign, and ecclesiastical matters and controlled the capital in Kraków.
How long did the period of divisions in Poland last before the rule of Casimir III?
The period of divisions in Poland lasted almost 200 years before the rule of Casimir III.
What characterized the system established by Bolesław III in Poland by the early 13th century?
The system established by Bolesław III in Poland was characterized by disputes, subdivisions, and fratricidal strife by the early 13th century.
What system did the early Piast monarchy in Poland use to govern its territories?
The early Piast monarchy in Poland used a system of fortified settlements governed by castellans who acted as administrators, military commanders, judges, and tax collectors.
What social structure emerged in Poland during the early Piast period?
The emerging social pyramid in Poland positioned the duke and his officials and leading warriors on top, with various categories of freemen, part-freemen, and slaves at the bottom.
What agricultural innovation contributed to the breakdown of the governing system in Poland between the 10th and 12th centuries?
Improved cultivation methods, notably the three-field system, enhanced the value of the land in Poland.
How did the ruler of Poland compensate his nobles, warriors, and officials during the early Piast period?
The ruler of Poland compensated his nobles, warriors, and officials with land and estates cultivated by a semiserf population.
Which religious orders arrived in Poland during the 11th to 13th centuries?
The Benedictines arrived in Poland in the 11th century, the Cistercians in the 12th century, and the Dominicans and the first nuns in the 13th century.
Who compiled the first historical chronicle in Poland in the early 12th century?
Gallus Anonymous, a Benedictine monk, compiled the first historical chronicle in Poland in the early 12th century.
Who completed the second historical chronicle in Poland at the beginning of the 13th century?
Wincenty Kadłubek completed the second historical chronicle in Poland at the beginning of the 13th century.
What economic developments marked a turning point in medieval Poland during the 13th century?
The agricultural boom and development of salt mining in Little Poland and silver and gold mining in Silesia marked a turning point in medieval Poland during the 13th century.
How did Poland participate in European trade during the 13th century?
Poland participated in the west-east trade as well as in that of the Baltic region in the north and that along the Danube River in the south during the 13th century.
What change occurred in Poland's agricultural labor system during the 13th century?
The growth of large landed estates in Poland led to the use of free tenant farmers rather than serfs to cultivate the land during the 13th century.
Where did settlers come from to work on Poland's agricultural lands during the 13th century?
Large groups of settlers from the Rhineland and the Low Countries came to work on Poland's agricultural lands during the 13th century.
What law influenced the autonomy and self-government of towns in Poland during the 13th century?
The Magdeburg Law influenced the autonomy and self-government of towns in Poland during the 13th century.
What privileges were assured to settlers in Poland during this colonization?
Settlers in Poland were assured of personal freedom, fixed rents, and some measure of self-administration during this colonization.
What was the significance of the charters granted to towns like Wrocław, Poznań, and Kraków in Poland?
The charters granted to towns like Wrocław, Poznań, and Kraków in Poland provided for autonomy and self-government modeled on that of the German city of Magdeburg.
What system of governance did not prevail in Poland?
A system based on contractual personal arrangements between superiors and inferiors with land as reward for services did not prevail in Poland.
Which institution in Poland functioned as the only structure that transcended divisions during the feudal period?
The church functioned as the only structure that transcended the divisions in Poland.
What exemptions did landowners in Poland obtain during the feudal period?
Landowners in Poland obtained immunities, which were exemptions from taxes, services, and the legal jurisdiction of the state.
Which groups in Poland obtained immunities during the feudal period?
Ecclesiastical landowners in the 12th century and lay nobility in the 13th century obtained immunities in Poland.
Who were the explorers that continued Norway's great tradition of exploration into modern times?
Fridtjof Nansen, Roald Amundsen, and Thor Heyerdahl continued Norway's great tradition of exploration into modern times.
What year did Norway gain its independence?
Norway gained its independence in 1905.
What industry became major for Norway in the 1970s?
The exploitation of offshore oil and natural gas became the major maritime industry for Norway in the 1970s.
What dynasty ruled India from about 321 to 185 bce?
The Mauryan dynasty ruled India from about 321 to 185 bce.
Who founded the Mauryan dynasty in India?
Chandragupta Maurya founded the Mauryan dynasty in India.
What event in 323 bce led to Chandragupta's conquest of the Punjab region in India?
The death of Alexander the Great in 323 bce led to Chandragupta's conquest of the Punjab region in India.
Which dynasty attempted to advance into India in 305 bce and was defeated?
The Seleucids attempted to advance into India in 305 bce and were defeated.
What was the outcome of the treaty between the Seleucids and the Mauryans in India?
The Seleucids and the Mauryans maintained friendly relations after the conclusion of the treaty in India.
Who was the Mauryan emperor of India who extended the empire across northern India?
Chandragupta extended the empire across northern India by the end of his reign.
Which Mauryan emperor of India added Kalinga to the empire and later abandoned military conquest?
Ashoka added Kalinga to the empire and later abandoned military conquest.
What state ideology did Ashoka institute in India after embracing Buddhism?
Ashoka instituted dharma as the state ideology in India after embracing Buddhism.
What historical texts from India were inscribed on stone pillars erected by Ashoka?
The edicts inscribed on stone pillars erected by Ashoka constitute some of the oldest deciphered original texts of India.
Who founded the Shunga dynasty in India?
Pushyamitra founded the Shunga dynasty in India.
What dynasty ruled northern and parts of central and western India from the early 4th to the late 6th century CE?
The Gupta dynasty ruled northern and parts of central and western India from the early 4th to the late 6th century CE.
What aspects of Indian culture were established during the Gupta period?
The Gupta period established the norms of Indian literature, art, architecture, and philosophy.
Who was the first ruler of the Gupta empire in India?
Chandra Gupta I was the first ruler of the Gupta empire in India.
Who expanded the Gupta empire through conquest in India?
Samudra Gupta expanded the Gupta empire through conquest in India.
How was the Gupta kingdom in India administratively divided?
The Gupta kingdom in India was administratively divided into provinces, which were further divided into smaller units called pradesha s or vishaya s.
Who governed the provinces in the Gupta kingdom of India?
The provinces in the Gupta kingdom of India were governed by high imperial officers or members of the royal family.
What system of authority is indicated by the composition of Gupta-era municipal boards in India?
A decentralized system of authority is indicated by the composition of Gupta-era municipal boards in India.
When did Sultan Iltutmish establish his permanent capital at Delhi in India?
Sultan Iltutmish established his permanent capital at Delhi in India in 1211.
Who ruled India for nearly 40 years of stability after Iltutmish's death?
Ghiyāth al-Dīn Balban ruled India for nearly 40 years of stability after Iltutmish's death.
Who conquered Gujarat in India during the Khaljī dynasty?
ʿAlāʾ al-Dīn conquered Gujarat in India during the Khaljī dynasty.
Who defeated serious Mongol onslaughts by the Chagatais of Transoxania in India between 1297 and 1306?
Muhammad ibn Tughluq's predecessor defeated serious Mongol onslaughts by the Chagatais of Transoxania in India between 1297 and 1306.
What was the outcome of the Turkic conqueror Timur's invasion of India in 1398-99?
The power of the Delhi sultanate in north India was shattered by the invasion of Turkic conqueror Timur in 1398-99.
Who established a second capital at Daulatabad in India during his reign from 1325-51?
Muhammad ibn Tughluq established a second capital at Daulatabad in India during his reign from 1325-51.
What was the result of Muhammad ibn Tughluq's attempt to set up a Muslim military, administrative, and cultural elite in the Deccan in India?
The Deccan Muslim aristocracy threw off the overlordship of Delhi and set up the Bahmanī sultanate in India in 1347.
Who made no attempt to reconquer the Deccan in India during his reign from 1351-88?
Fīrūz Shah Tughluq made no attempt to reconquer the Deccan in India during his reign from 1351-88.
What dynasty ruled India from 1451 to 1526?
The Lodī dynasty ruled India from 1451 to 1526, partly recovering the Delhi sultanate's hegemony.
How did the Delhi sultans in India manage their local governance?
The Delhi sultans in India left a large discretion to their local governors and officials.
What culture arrived in Jamaica around 600 CE?
The Redware people arrived in Jamaica around 600 CE.
Who settled throughout Jamaica around 800 CE?
The Arawakan-speaking Taino settled throughout Jamaica around 800 CE.
Who founded the first permanent European settlement in Jamaica in 1509?
Juan de Esquivel founded the first permanent European settlement in Jamaica in 1509.
When did Christopher Columbus first reach Jamaica?
Christopher Columbus first reached Jamaica in 1494.
What was the capital of Jamaica moved to in 1534?
The capital of Jamaica was moved to Villa de la Vega in 1534.
What happened to the Taino people in Jamaica under Spanish rule?
The Spanish enslaved many of the Taino in Jamaica, with most dying from European diseases and overwork.
When were the Solomon Islands initially settled?
The Solomon Islands were initially settled by at least 2000 bce.
Who was the first European to reach the Solomon Islands in 1568?
Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira was the first European to reach the Solomon Islands in 1568.
What led to the Solomon Islands being named Islas de Solomón?

Unjustified rumors that Álvaro de Mendaña de Neira had found gold and discovered where the biblical king Solomon obtained gold for his temple in Jerusalem led to the Solomon Islands being named Islas de Solomón.
When did French and English navigators make further sightings of the Solomon Islands?
French and English navigators made further sightings of the Solomon Islands in the late 18th century.
What event in 1788 led to increased naval and commercial shipping through the Solomon Islands’ waters?
The settlement of Sydney by the English in 1788 led to increased naval and commercial shipping through the Solomon Islands’ waters.
When did Roman Catholic missionaries first establish a settlement in the Solomon Islands?
Roman Catholic missionaries established a settlement in the Solomon Islands in 1898.
What was the primary reason for the declaration of the British Solomon Islands Protectorate in 1893?

The British Solomon Islands Protectorate was declared in 1893 partly in response to abuses associated with labor recruitment and partly to regulate contacts between islanders and European settlers but mainly to forestall a threat of annexation by France.
What was the outcome of the 1899 agreement between Germany and Britain regarding the Solomon Islands?
Germany transferred the northern islands, except for Buka and Bougainville, to Britain in 1899 in return for recognition of German claims in Western Samoa and parts of Africa.
When did colonial rule begin in the Solomon Islands?
Colonial rule began in the Solomon Islands in 1896.
What was the approximate number of laborers recruited from the Solomon Islands between 1870 and 1910?
About 30,000 laborers were recruited from the Solomon Islands between 1870 and 1910.
Why did Germany and Britain divide the Solomon Islands between them in 1886?
Germany and Britain divided the Solomon Islands between them in 1886 to protect their own interests.
What was the fate of Basiana, the leader of the tax collectors' killers, in the Solomon Islands?
Basiana, the leader of the tax collectors' killers, was hanged in the Solomon Islands.
What happened to Basiana's young sons during his execution in the Solomon Islands?
Basiana's young sons were forced to witness his execution in the Solomon Islands.
When did Japanese forces begin occupying the Solomon Islands during World War II?
Japanese forces began occupying the Solomon Islands early in 1942.
What was the outcome of the Japanese advance southward in the Solomon Islands during World War II?
The Japanese advance southward in the Solomon Islands was stopped by U.S. forces.
What was the role of the islanders during the campaign in the Solomon Islands?
The islanders strongly supported the U.S. forces and their allies during the campaign.
Why was Honiara on Guadalcanal chosen as the new capital of the Solomon Islands after the war?
Honiara on Guadalcanal became the new capital because of the proximity of an airfield and the availability of flat land and military buildings.
What nationalist movement emerged in the Solomon Islands from 1944 to 1952?
Maasina Rule was the nationalist movement that emerged in the Solomon Islands from 1944 to 1952.
When did the Solomon Islands attain independence?
Solomon Islands attained independence on July 7, 1978.
Who became the first prime minister of the Solomon Islands in 1978?
Peter Kenilorea became the first prime minister of the Solomon Islands in 1978.
What event occurred in Solomon Islands in June 2000 during the period known as the Tensions?
Ulufa’alu was deposed in a coup in June 2000.
Who succeeded Ulufa’alu as leader of Solomon Islands after the June 2000 coup?
Manasseh Sogavare succeeded Ulufa’alu as leader of Solomon Islands after the June 2000 coup.
Who became prime minister of Solomon Islands in December 2001?
Sir Allen Kemakeza became prime minister of Solomon Islands in December 2001.
What international forces arrived in Solomon Islands in 2000 to address the civil disorder?
New Zealand and Australian forces arrived in Solomon Islands in 2000 to address the civil disorder.
What was the outcome of the general election held in Solomon Islands in December 2001?
Sir Allen Kemakeza became prime minister after the general election held in Solomon Islands in December 2001.
What multinational mission was formed to assist Solomon Islands in mid-2003?
The Regional Assistance Mission to the Solomon Islands (RAMSI) was formed to assist Solomon Islands in mid-2003.
Who requested assistance from the Pacific Islands Forum for Solomon Islands in mid-2003?
Kemakeza requested assistance from the Pacific Islands Forum for Solomon Islands in mid-2003.
Who became the prime minister of the Solomon Islands after Snyder Rini's resignation in 2006?
Sogavare became the prime minister of the Solomon Islands after Snyder Rini's resignation in 2006.
Who replaced Sogavare as prime minister of the Solomon Islands after he lost a confidence vote in 2007?
Derek Sikua replaced Sogavare as prime minister of the Solomon Islands after he lost a confidence vote in 2007.
What was the main purpose of the proposed new constitution for the Solomon Islands?
The proposed new constitution for the Solomon Islands aimed to address provincial and ethnic tensions by changing the governmental structure to that of a federation of states.
Which countries and organizations provided foreign aid to support the Solomon Islands' recovery?
Japan, New Zealand, Australia, and the European Union provided foreign aid to support the Solomon Islands' recovery.
What event occurred in Honiara after the 2006 general election in the Solomon Islands?
Antigovernment riots broke out in Honiara after the 2006 general election in the Solomon Islands, resulting in parts of the city being burned and looted.
Who became prime minister of the Solomon Islands after the August 2010 general election?
Danny Philip became prime minister of the Solomon Islands after the August 2010 general election.
What was a stated priority of Danny Philip's administration in the Solomon Islands?
Constitutional reform was a stated priority of Danny Philip's administration in the Solomon Islands.
Why did Danny Philip resign as prime minister of the Solomon Islands?
Danny Philip resigned as prime minister of the Solomon Islands in the face of corruption allegations.
Who succeeded Danny Philip as prime minister of the Solomon Islands?
Gordon Darcy Lilo succeeded Danny Philip as prime minister of the Solomon Islands.
When did RAMSI formally end its mission in the Solomon Islands?
RAMSI formally ended its mission in the Solomon Islands in June 2017.
Who succeeded Lilo as the leader of the Solomon Islands after the 2014 general election?
Sogavare succeeded Lilo as the leader of the Solomon Islands after the 2014 general election.
What initiative was completed in time for the 2014 general election in the Solomon Islands?
A biometric voter registration initiative was completed in time for the 2014 general election in the Solomon Islands.
When did RAMSI end its military operations in the Solomon Islands?
RAMSI ended its military operations in the Solomon Islands in July 2013.
Who succeeded Sogavare as prime minister of Solomon Islands after Sogavare lost a vote of confidence in 2017?
Rick (“Hou”) Houenipwela succeeded Sogavare as prime minister of Solomon Islands after Sogavare lost a vote of confidence in 2017.
When did Solomon Islands hold its first general election since the departure of RAMSI?
Solomon Islands held its first general election since the departure of RAMSI in April 2019.
Who returned to the post of prime minister of Solomon Islands after the April 2019 general election?
Sogavare returned to the post of prime minister of Solomon Islands after the April 2019 general election.
What significant diplomatic change did Solomon Islands make in 2019?

What event in late November 2021 led to protests in the Solomon Islands?
Protesters in the Solomon Islands demonstrated in Honiara in late November 2021, calling for Sogavare's resignation due to economic conditions and marginalization.
What decision from 2019 contributed to the 2021 unrest in the Solomon Islands?
The Solomon Islands' decision to drop ties with Taiwan in favor of Beijing in 2019 contributed to the 2021 unrest.
How did the Solomon Islands government respond to the 2021 riots?
The Solomon Islands government requested security forces from other Pacific countries to help maintain order during the 2021 riots.
What political challenge did Sogavare face in early December 2021 in the Solomon Islands?
Sogavare faced a confidence vote in early December 2021 in the Solomon Islands and survived it.
What proposal did Suidani announce for Malaita in the Solomon Islands?
Suidani announced his intent to poll Malaitans to determine support for independence for the province in the Solomon Islands.
What security pact was signed by Solomon Islands in April 2022?
Solomon Islands signed a security pact with China in April 2022.
Why did Sogavare propose delaying the 2023 general election in Solomon Islands?
Sogavare proposed delaying the 2023 general election in Solomon Islands because the country was scheduled to host the Pacific Games in November 2023.
When was the delayed general election held in Solomon Islands?
The delayed general election was held in Solomon Islands in April 2024.
What was the outcome of the 2024 general election in the Solomon Islands?
The 2024 general election in the Solomon Islands resulted in Jeremiah Manele being elected as prime minister.
Who was elected as prime minister of the Solomon Islands after the 2024 general election?
Jeremiah Manele was elected as prime minister of the Solomon Islands after the 2024 general election.
What was the impact of the 2024 general election on Sogavare's political career in the Solomon Islands?
Sogavare retained his seat in Parliament but stated he would not run for prime minister again after the 2024 general election in the Solomon Islands.
What was a key issue in the 2024 general election in the Solomon Islands?
The 2024 general election in the Solomon Islands was also seen as a referendum on Sogavare's decision to pivot toward China.
Who was involved in strengthening the Solomon Islands' relationship with China?
Jeremiah Manele was involved in strengthening the Solomon Islands' relationship with China.
Who attacked Singapore Island in 1025?
Rajendra Chola I, ruler of the southern Indian Chola kingdom, attacked Singapore Island in 1025.
What event occurred in Singapore in 1068?
There was another Chola raid in Singapore in 1068.
What happened to Singapore at the end of the 14th century?
Singapore fell into decay and was supplanted by Malacca at the end of the 14th century.
What was the outcome of the 70 Tai war boats' siege of Singapore in 1349?
The 70 Tai war boats besieged Singapore for a month but had to withdraw in 1349.
Who is credited with founding the city of Singapore according to the Sejarah Melayu?
Sri Tri Buana, a Srīvijayan prince, is credited with founding the city of Singapore.
What event led to the naming of Singapore according to the Sejarah Melayu?
Sri Tri Buana glimpsed a tiger, mistaken it for a lion, leading to the naming of Singapore.
Who did Sir Stamford Raffles install to validate the purchase of land in Singapore?
Hussein, Abdul Rahman's elder brother, was installed by Sir Stamford Raffles to validate the purchase of land in Singapore.
Who was the hereditary chief that Sir Stamford Raffles met in Singapore?
The temenggong, a direct ancestor of the sultans of present-day Johor, Malaysia, was the hereditary chief that Sir Stamford Raffles met in Singapore.
Who was the sultan of Riau-Johor under Dutch surveillance when Sir Stamford Raffles arrived in Singapore?
Abdul Rahman, a younger son and not a sultan de jure, was the sultan of Riau-Johor under Dutch surveillance when Sir Stamford Raffles arrived in Singapore.
What action did Sir Stamford Raffles take regarding Abdul Rahman's suzerainty over Singapore?
Sir Stamford Raffles withdrew his recognition of Abdul Rahman's suzerainty over Singapore.
What treaty in 1824 placed Singapore in the British sphere of influence?
The Anglo-Dutch treaty of 1824 placed Singapore in the British sphere of influence.
When was Singapore ceded to the British for a monetary payment?
Singapore Island was ceded to the British for a monetary payment in August 1824.
What administrative change occurred in Singapore in 1830?
Singapore was reduced to a residency under Bengal in 1830.
When did Singapore become the capital of the Straits Settlements?
Singapore became the capital of the Straits Settlements in 1832.
When were the Straits Settlements, including Singapore, transferred to the direct control of the governor-general of India?
The Straits Settlements, including Singapore, were transferred to the direct control of the governor-general of India in 1851.
What event in 1869 marked the beginning of an era of prosperity for Singapore?
The opening of the Suez Canal in 1869 marked the beginning of an era of prosperity for Singapore.
What was constructed at Tanjong Pagar as a result of Singapore's economic growth?
Three miles of wharves were constructed at Tanjong Pagar as a result of Singapore's economic growth.
What was established in Singapore in 1921?
A naval base was established in Singapore in 1921.
What factors contributed to Singapore becoming one of the greatest ports in the world?
The demand of the industrial West for tin and rubber contributed to Singapore becoming one of the greatest ports in the world.
Singapore remained under Japanese control until what month and year?
Singapore remained in Japanese hands until September 1945.
Why was Singapore excluded from the proposed Malayan Union and Federation of Malaya?

Singapore was excluded from the proposed Malayan Union and Federation of Malaya mainly because it was thought that Singapore’s predominantly Chinese population would be an ethnic obstacle to common citizenship.
What year did Singapore become a separate crown colony?
Singapore became a separate crown colony in 1946.
What year did Singapore become self-governing?
Singapore became self-governing in 1959.
What matters did Britain still retain control of after Singapore became self-governing?
Britain still retained control of defense and foreign policy after Singapore became self-governing.
When did Singapore join the Federation of Malaysia?
Singapore joined the Federation of Malaysia in September 1963.
Who led the People’s Action Party in Singapore in 1959?
Lee Kuan Yew led the People’s Action Party in Singapore in 1959.
What was the Socialist Front accused of being in Singapore?
The Socialist Front was accused of being a communist front organization in Singapore.
When did Singapore secede from Malaysia?
Singapore seceded from Malaysia in 1965.
What was the reason for Singapore's secession from Malaysia?
Singapore seceded from Malaysia due to political friction between the state and central governments.
When did the British government announce the withdrawal of its defense forces from Singapore?
The British government announced the withdrawal of its defense forces from Singapore in January 1968.
What was the outcome of the election in Singapore in April 1968?
The ruling PAP swept all parliamentary seats in the election in Singapore in April 1968.
When did the British military presence in Singapore come to an end?
The British military presence in Singapore came to an end at the end of October 1971.
What defense arrangement replaced the Anglo-Malayan treaty for Singapore in the 1970s?
A five-power defense arrangement involving Britain, Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia, and Singapore as equal partners replaced the Anglo-Malayan treaty for Singapore.
When did Singapore become a founding member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations?
Singapore became a founding member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in 1967.
What was the outcome of opposition parties in Singapore's Parliament between 1981 and 1991?
Opposition parties in Singapore's Parliament increased their number of seats from one to four between 1981 and 1991.
Who continued to dominate Singaporean politics after Lee stepped down as prime minister in 1990?
The PAP continued to dominate Singaporean politics after Lee stepped down as prime minister in 1990.
What is the earliest estimated time period when early humans may have resided in Mexico?
Early humans may have resided in Mexico some 30,000 to 40,000 years ago, according to some archaeologists and linguists.
What is the more generally accepted time period for early settlers in Mexico?
The more generally accepted claims for early settlers in Mexico pertain to a somewhat later period.
What primitive cultigens were cultivated in Mexico during the Abejas phase?
Avocados, chili peppers, amaranth, zapotes, tepary beans, and squashes were primitive cultigens cultivated in Mexico during the Abejas phase.
What new plants were introduced in Mexico toward the end of the Abejas phase?
Pumpkins and the common bean were introduced in Mexico toward the end of the Abejas phase.
What was the primary economic activity of village communities in Mexico by 2000 bc?
Agriculture was the primary economic activity of village communities in Mexico by 2000 bc.
What agricultural advancements occurred in Mexico during the Early Formative Period?
Numerous edible plants were improved by hybridization and more-sophisticated cultivation techniques in Mexico during the Early Formative Period.
What type of societies emerged in Mexico during the Middle Formative Period?
More-complex societies organized around politico-religious capitals emerged in Mexico during the Middle Formative Period.
What materials were used to build structures in Mexico during the Formative Periods?
Structures in Mexico during the Formative Periods were built with wood, reeds, and thatch.
What period in Mexico saw the emergence of the first large stone-built ceremonial centres and monumental stone sculpture?
The Middle Formative Period in Mexico saw the emergence of the first large stone-built ceremonial centres and monumental stone sculpture around 1000 bc.
Which two sites in Mexico evolved from small farming villages to impressive urban centres during the Middle Formative Period?
San Lorenzo and La Venta in Mexico evolved from small farming villages to impressive urban centres during the Middle Formative Period.
What materials did Olmec artists in Mexico work with to create their sculptures and objects?
Olmec artists in Mexico worked with stone, jade, and other materials to create their sculptures and objects.
What distinctive features did Olmec artists in Mexico often depict in their human faces?
Olmec artists in Mexico often depicted human faces with jaguar mouths and nostrils.
What period in Mexico saw the emergence of complex societies and the development of hieroglyphics?
The Late Formative Period in Mexico saw the emergence of complex societies and the development of hieroglyphics.
Which city in Mexico became one of the earliest manifestations of densely settled city life during the Late Formative Period?
Teotihuacán in Mexico became one of the earliest manifestations of densely settled city life during the Late Formative Period.
What notable architectural features were built in Teotihuacán, Mexico during the Late Formative Period?
The Pyramid of the Sun and the Avenue of the Dead were notable architectural features built in Teotihuacán, Mexico during the Late Formative Period.
What architectural innovation was evident in temple construction in Mexico by the end of the Late Formative Period?
The corbeled vault was evident in temple construction in Mexico by the end of the Late Formative Period.
What calendrical system was evident in the Maya Lowlands by the end of the Late Formative Period in Mexico?
The Initial Series calendrical system was evident in the Maya Lowlands by the end of the Late Formative Period in Mexico.
What significant development occurred in ceremonial centres in the Maya Lowlands during the Late Classic subperiod in Mexico?
Ceremonial centres in the Maya Lowlands proliferated during the Late Classic subperiod in Mexico.
What achievement did Maya astronomers and mathematicians complete in Mexico during the Classic Period?
Maya astronomers and mathematicians finished work on what was perhaps the world’s most accurate calendar in Mexico during the Classic Period.
What city became the dominant force in Middle America during the Post-Classic Period in Mexico?
Tenochtitlán became the dominant force in Middle America during the Post-Classic Period in Mexico.
When did Chichén Itzá lose its position of leadership in Mexico?
Chichén Itzá lost its position of leadership about 1200 ce in Mexico.
What city eventually became the Yucatecan capital in Mexico during the Post-Classic Period?
Mayapán eventually became the Yucatecan capital in Mexico during the Post-Classic Period.
What was the probable origin of the first settlers of the eastern Caroline Islands in Micronesia?
The eastern Caroline Islands in Micronesia were probably first settled from the area of the New Hebrides (now Vanuatu) and Fiji sometime before 1000 bce.
What type of artifacts have been found in Chuuk, Micronesia, and what is their approximate age?
Pottery dating to about the 1st century ce has been found in Chuuk, Micronesia.
What is the probable origin of the settlers of the high island of Yap in Micronesia?
The high island of Yap in Micronesia appears to have been settled from the west, probably from the Philippines or Indonesia.
What type of social upheaval occurred in the eastern islands of Micronesia seven centuries ago?
A major social upheaval occurred in the eastern islands of Micronesia seven centuries ago, possibly under the impact of invasion from the south.
What was the Yapese stone money quarried from in Micronesia?
The Yapese stone money was quarried in nearby Palau and the Marianas in Micronesia.
What system evolved in Micronesia in later centuries with the surrounding coral atolls?
A reciprocal tribute and trade system evolved in Micronesia in later centuries with the surrounding coral atolls, sometimes termed the Yap empire, or Yapese empire.
What type of settlements were built in the eastern islands of Micronesia after the social upheaval?
Fortified settlements were built of huge basaltic logs in the eastern islands of Micronesia after the social upheaval.
Who named the islands of Micronesia after the Spanish king Charles II?
Spanish navigators named the islands of Micronesia after the Spanish king Charles II.
In what year did Spain colonize the Carolines, which are part of Micronesia?
Spain colonized the Carolines in 1886.
To whom did Spain sell the islands of Micronesia in 1899?
Spain sold the islands of Micronesia to Germany in 1899.
When did Japan gain formal title to the islands of Micronesia as a League of Nations mandate?
Japan gained formal title to the islands of Micronesia as a League of Nations mandate in 1920.
What was Japan's final use of the islands of Micronesia before World War II?
Japan fortified the islands of Micronesia just before World War II.
When did Micronesia become the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands?
The Carolines, including Micronesia, became the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands in July 1947.
Who administered Micronesia after it became the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands?
The United States administered Micronesia after it became the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.
When did Micronesian leaders begin negotiations with the United States for full self-government?
Micronesian leaders began negotiations with the United States for full self-government in 1969.
What year did the constitution drafted for Micronesia become the basis for its federated government?
The constitution drafted in 1975 became the basis for Micronesia's federated government.
When did Micronesia's federated government go into effect?
Micronesia's federated government went into effect in 1979.
What political entity was formed by the inner states of Yap, Truk, Kosrae, and Ponape in Micronesia?
The Federated States of Micronesia was formed by the inner states of Yap, Truk, Kosrae, and Ponape.
When did voters in Micronesia approve the Compact of Free Association with the United States?
Voters in Micronesia approved the Compact of Free Association with the United States in a 1983 plebiscite.
When did the Compact of Free Association between Micronesia and the United States become effective?
The Compact of Free Association between Micronesia and the United States became effective on November 3, 1986.
What conditions must be met for Micronesia to alter its relationship with the United States under the Compact of Free Association?

When did Micronesia become a member of the UN?
The Federated States of Micronesia became a member of the UN on September 17, 1991.
What event occurred in Micronesia in 1996 that affected President Bailey Olter?
President Bailey Olter suffered an incapacitating stroke in July 1996.
What health crisis led to a national vaccination program in Micronesia?

When was the compact renewed for Micronesia?
The compact was renewed by mutual consent in 2003 for 20 more years.
When did the renewed compact come into force for Micronesia?
The renewed compact came into force in 2004.
Which Indian emperor left a column inscribed at Lumbini in Nepal?
Ashoka, emperor of India, left a column inscribed at Lumbini in Nepal.
What was the claimed status of the Kirati dynasty in Nepal?
The Kirati dynasty claimed the status of the Kshatriya caste of rulers and warriors in Nepal.
What dynasty ruled Nepal from 500 to 700 ce?
The Licchavi dynasty ruled Nepal from 500 to 700 ce, establishing a powerful, unified kingdom.
When did Nepal's contacts with China begin?
Nepal's contacts with China began in the mid-7th century with the exchange of several missions.
What interrupted Nepal's relationship with China?
Intermittent warfare between Tibet and China terminated Nepal's relationship with China.
When were Nepal's contacts with China reestablished on a continuing basis?
Nepal's contacts with China were reestablished on a continuing basis only in the late 18th century.
Which dynasty ruled Nepal from the 10th to the 18th century?
The Malla dynasty ruled Nepal from the 10th to the 18th century.
Who introduced the first legal and social code influenced by Hindu principles in Nepal?
Jaya Sthiti introduced the first legal and social code strongly influenced by contemporary Hindu principles in Nepal.
Who divided Nepal into the independent principalities of Kathmandu, Patan, and Bhaktapur?
Yaksha Malla divided his kingdom into the independent principalities of Kathmandu, Patan, and Bhaktapur.
What was the religious policy of the Licchavi kings towards their non-Hindu subjects in Nepal?
The Licchavi kings did not impose Brahmanic social codes or values on their non-Hindu subjects in Nepal.
What dynasty ruled Gorkha and began to assert a predominant role in the hills of Nepal in the early 18th century?
The Shah family ruled Gorkha and began to assert a predominant role in the hills of Nepal in the early 18th century.
What event in the 16th century led to the establishment of dynasties claiming high-caste Indian origin in Nepal?
The Muslim invasions of northern India in the 16th century led to the establishment of dynasties claiming high-caste Indian origin in Nepal.
Which family's rule in Gorkha provided the foundation for the modern state of Nepal?
The Shah family's rule in Gorkha provided the foundation for the modern state of Nepal.
What weakened the Mallas in Nepal before their defeat by the Gorkha ruler Prithvi Narayan Shah?
Familial dissension and widespread social and economic discontent weakened the Mallas in Nepal before their defeat by the Gorkha ruler Prithvi Narayan Shah.
What challenges did the Shah rulers face in Nepal?
The Shah rulers faced tremendous and persistent problems in trying to centralize an area long characterized by extreme diversity and ethnic and regional parochialism in Nepal.
How did the Shah rulers establish a centralized political system in Nepal?
The Shah rulers established a centralized political system by absorbing dominant regional and local elites into the central administration at Kathmandu in Nepal.
What was the result of the Shah rulers' compromise division of responsibilities in Nepal?
The Shah rulers' compromise division of responsibilities between the local elites and the central administration severely limited the center’s authority in outlying areas in Nepal.
What characterized Nepalese politics from 1775 to 1951?
Nepalese politics was characterized by confrontations between the royal family and several noble families from 1775 to 1951.
What dynasty ruled Nepal from 1777 to 1832?
The Shah dynasty ruled Nepal from 1777 to 1832, with the position weakened by minor kings.
Which family dominated Nepal's politics from 1806 to 1837?
The Thapa family dominated Nepal's politics from 1806 to 1837.
Which family held effective authority in Nepal from 1846 to 1951?
The Rana family held effective authority in Nepal from 1846 to 1951.
What was the status of the Shah ruler during the Rana family's dominance in Nepal?
The Shah ruler was relegated to an honorary position without power during the Rana family's dominance in Nepal.
What characterized Nepalese politics until 1950?
Nepalese politics was basically conspiratorial in character until 1950.
What alternatives did excluded noble families have in Nepal?
Excluded noble families had only two alternatives—to accept inferior posts in the administration and army or to conspire for the overthrow of the dominant family.
Who established a unified state in Nepal and launched an expansion program from 1742 to 1775?
Prithvi Narayan Shah established a unified state in Nepal and launched an expansion program from 1742 to 1775.
What were the outcomes of Nepal's wars with China and Tibet from 1788 to 1792?
Nepal's wars with China and Tibet from 1788 to 1792 resulted in successive setbacks.
What was the outcome of Nepal's war with the Sikh kingdom in the Punjab in 1809?
Nepal's war with the Sikh kingdom in the Punjab in 1809 resulted in a setback.
What was the outcome of Nepal's war with British India from 1814 to 1816?
Nepal's war with British India from 1814 to 1816 resulted in a setback.
What was the outcome of Nepal's war with Tibet from 1854 to 1856?
Nepal's war with Tibet from 1854 to 1856 resulted in a setback.
What was Nepal's response to the British conquest of India in the 19th century?
Nepal sought an accommodation with the British to preserve its independence in response to the British conquest of India in the 19th century.
What terms did Nepal accept from the British in exchange for recruiting Nepalese for the Gurkha units in the British Indian Army?
Nepal accepted British guidance on foreign policy in exchange for recruiting Nepalese for the Gurkha units in the British Indian Army.
What event in 1947 affected Nepal's relationship with the Rana regime?
The British withdrawal from India in 1947 deprived the Ranas of a vital external source of support and exposed the regime to new dangers.
Why did Nepal maintain friendly relations with China and Tibet?
Nepal maintained friendly relations with China and Tibet for economic reasons and to counterbalance British predominance in South Asia.
What regime ruled Nepal after 1860 and established a de facto alliance with the British?
The Rana family regime ruled Nepal after 1860 and established a de facto alliance with the British.
Who led the Nepalese royal family during the 1950 revolution in Nepal?
King Tribhuvan led the Nepalese royal family during the 1950 revolution in Nepal.
Which party led the revolutionary forces in Nepal during the 1950 revolution?

What was the outcome of the 1950 revolution in Nepal regarding the Ranas?
The 1950 revolution in Nepal resulted in a settlement with the Ranas under which the sovereignty of the crown was restored.
Who provided strong diplomatic support to the rebels in Nepal during the 1950 revolution?

What event in December 2014 held promise for the removal of the United States' economic embargo against Cuba?

When did Qatar's modern history begin and what event marked its start?

Estonia's Parliament, the Riigikogu, was established as a single-chamber body of 100 members elected for three years.
How many coalition governments did Estonia have from May 1919 to May 1933?
Estonia had 20 coalition governments from May 1919 to May 1933.
How many statesmen headed Estonia's coalition governments from May 1919 to May 1933?
Ten statesmen headed Estonia's coalition governments from May 1919 to May 1933.
What event occurred in Estonia on December 1, 1924?
On December 1, 1924, 300 conspirators, mostly Russians, tried to seize communications and call in Soviet troops but failed ignominiously in Estonia.
What happened to the Communist Party in Estonia after the failed coup attempt in 1924?
The Communist Party was outlawed in Estonia after the failed coup attempt in 1924.
What significant change occurred in Estonia's government structure in 1933?
A new constitution in 1933 gave sweeping powers to the president in Estonia.
What action did Päts take in Estonia on March 12, 1934?
Päts proclaimed a state of emergency in Estonia on March 12, 1934.
What was the outcome of the state of emergency declared by Päts in Estonia in 1934?
Opposition leaders were arrested, political activities of all parties were forbidden, and Päts assumed dictatorial powers in Estonia.
What significant political event occurred in Estonia in December 1936?
A new constituent assembly was elected in Estonia in December 1936.
What type of election system was used in Estonia's legislative election in February 1938?
Estonia's legislative election in February 1938 used the majority system.
What was the composition of Estonia's national council according to the third constitution?
Estonia's national council consisted of 40 members according to the third constitution.
What dynasty ruled the Mamluk Sultanate from 1250 to 1517?
The Mamluk dynasty ruled the Mamluk Sultanate from 1250 to 1517.
When did the Ottoman occupation of the Mamluk Sultanate occur?
The Ottoman occupation of the Mamluk Sultanate occurred from 1517 to 1798.
What was the significance of Egypt during the Mamluk period in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Egypt became the unrivaled political, economic, and cultural centre of the eastern Arabic-speaking zone of the Muslim world during the Mamluk period in the Mamluk Sultanate.
What event occurred in 1261 under the Mamluk rulers of the Mamluk Sultanate?
The reestablishment of a significant institution occurred in 1261 under the Mamluk rulers of the Mamluk Sultanate.
Which dynasty did the Mamluk slaves serve in before forming the Mamluk Sultanate?
The Mamluk slaves served in the Ayyūbid dynasty’s armies before forming the Mamluk Sultanate.
Until which century did the remnants of the Mamluk Sultanate survive?
The remnants of the Mamluk Sultanate survived until the 19th century.
What event in 1250 marked the Mamluk accession to power in the Mamluk Sultanate?
The battle at Al-Manṣūrah in 1250 marked the Mamluk accession to power in the Mamluk Sultanate.
Until what year did remnants of the Mamluk state survive in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Remnants of the Mamluk state survived in the Mamluk Sultanate until the 19th century.
In which Syrian city did Ayyubid governance persist at least nominally in the first half of the 14th century in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Ayyubid governance persisted at least nominally in Ḥamāh in the first half of the 14th century in the Mamluk Sultanate.
Until what year did the Ayyubid dynasty persist in some areas of Syria in the Mamluk Sultanate?
The Ayyubid dynasty persisted in some areas of Syria until 1260 in the Mamluk Sultanate.
What empire did the Mamluk Sultanate seek to expand into during Mehmed II's reign?
The Mamluk Sultanate sought to expand into southeastern Anatolia during Mehmed II's reign.
What conflict did the Mamluk Sultanate engage in with Bayezid II?
The Mamluk Sultanate came into conflict with Bayezid II over border zones and control of small principalities.
Who conquered the Mamluk Sultanate in a single yearlong campaign from 1516 to 1517?
Selim I conquered the Mamluk Sultanate in a single yearlong campaign from 1516 to 1517.
What factors contributed to the Ottoman conquest of the Mamluk Sultanate in 1516-1517?

The Ottoman conquest of the Mamluk Sultanate was aided by the support of many Mamluk officials who betrayed their masters in return for important positions and the well-organized and disciplined Ottoman infantry and cavalry supported by artillery.
What event led to the fall of the Mamluk Sultanate in 1516-17?
The Mamluk Sultanate fell to the Ottoman Empire in a single, yearlong campaign from 1516 to 1517.
How did the Mamluk Sultanate's officials contribute to its downfall?
Many Mamluk officials betrayed their masters in return for important positions, aiding the Ottoman conquest of the Mamluk Sultanate.
What was the role of Al-Azhar University during the Mamluk Sultanate period?
Al-Azhar University was revived under the Mamluk Sultanate, becoming one of the most revered centers of Sunni scholarship in the world.
What significant event damaged Al-Azhar University in the early 1300s during the Mamluk Sultanate?
An earthquake damaged Al-Azhar University in the early 1300s during the Mamluk Sultanate.
What was the status of Al-Azhar University under the Mamluk Sultanate?
Al-Azhar University was elevated to be one of the most revered centers of Sunni scholarship in the world under the Mamluk Sultanate.
What significant military victory did the Mamluk Sultanate achieve in 1260?
The Mamluk Sultanate defeated the Mongols at ʿAyn Jālūt in Syria in 1260, halting their southward advance.
What was the origin of the Mamluk Sultanate's ruling dynasty?
The Mamluk Sultanate's ruling dynasty arose from the leaders of former slave bodyguards of the sultan.
Who concluded a peace with Abū Saʿīd in 1323 in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Sultan al-Malik al-Nāṣir concluded a peace with Abū Saʿīd in 1323.
What event occurred in the Mamluk Sultanate in 1323 regarding the il-khans?
A peace was concluded between the Mamluk Sultanate and the il-khans in 1323.
Who was the last effective il-khan that the Mamluk Sultanate made peace with in 1323?
Abū Saʿīd was the last effective il-khan that the Mamluk Sultanate made peace with in 1323.
When did the Mamluk Sultanate establish control over Egypt?
The Mamluk Sultanate established control over Egypt in 1250.
What was the primary purpose of the Mamluk Sultanate's military expeditions against Maqurrah in the late 13th and early 14th centuries?
The Mamluk Sultanate's military expeditions against Maqurrah aimed to rid Egypt of uncontrollable Arab Bedouin and capture Nubia.
What was one of the reasons the Mamluk Sultanate sent military expeditions against Maqurrah in the late 13th and early 14th centuries?
The Mamluk Sultanate sent military expeditions against Maqurrah to rid Egypt of uncontrollable Arab Bedouin.
Who was the first Mamlūk sultan of the Mamluk Sultanate in the Turkish, or Baḥrī, line?
Aybak was the first Mamlūk sultan of the Mamluk Sultanate in the Turkish, or Baḥrī, line, ruling from 1250 to 1257.
Who ruled the Mamluk Sultanate from 1260 to 1277 and led military campaigns against Mongols and crusaders?
Baybars I ruled the Mamluk Sultanate from 1260 to 1277 and led military campaigns against Mongols and crusaders.
What were Baybars I's notable achievements during his rule of the Mamluk Sultanate?
Baybars I was noted for his military campaigns against Mongols and crusaders and for his internal administrative reforms during his rule of the Mamluk Sultanate.
Who was the most eminent Mamlūk sultan of the Mamluk Sultanate from 1260 to 1277?
Baybars was the most eminent Mamlūk sultan of the Mamluk Sultanate from 1260 to 1277.
Who was the 26th Mamlūk ruler of the Mamluk Sultanate and what characterized his reign?
Faraj was the 26th Mamlūk ruler of the Mamluk Sultanate and his reign was marked by a loss of internal control of the Mamlūk kingdom.
What were the challenges faced by Faraj during his rule of the Mamluk Sultanate?
Faraj was the victim of forces—including foreign invasion and domestic feuds—that he did not create and could not control during his rule of the Mamluk Sultanate.
What event occurred in 1299-1300 involving the Mamluk Sultanate?
Ghāzān invaded Syria, defeated the Egyptian army at Homs, and made a triumphal entry into Damascus.
What was the hereditary quarrel of Ghāzān's family with the Mamluk Sultanate?
Ghāzān's family had a hereditary quarrel with the Mamluk Sultanate, whom they viewed as champions of Islām.
Who led the invasion of Syria in 1299-1300 against the Mamluk Sultanate?
Ghāzān led the invasion of Syria in 1299-1300 against the Mamluk Sultanate.
What was the role of the ḥājib in the Mamluk Sultanate?
The ḥājib was a high government official in the Mamluk Sultanate, originally designated as a chamberlain.
How did the ḥājib function under the Spanish Umayyads in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Under the Spanish Umayyads, the ḥājib functioned as a chief minister in the Mamluk Sultanate, paralleling the position of vizier in the eastern caliphates.
Who eliminated the Mamlūks, the former ruling oligarchy of the Mamluk Sultanate?
Muḥammad ʿAlī eliminated the Mamlūks, the former ruling oligarchy of the Mamluk Sultanate.
How did Muḥammad ʿAlī affect the religious class of the Mamluk Sultanate?
Muḥammad ʿAlī turned the religious class of the Mamluk Sultanate into pensioners of the government.
What restrictions did Muḥammad ʿAlī impose on the native merchant and artisan groups of the Mamluk Sultanate?
Muḥammad ʿAlī restricted the activities of the native merchant and artisan groups of the Mamluk Sultanate.
What did Muḥammad ʿAlī do to the peasant rebellions in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Muḥammad ʿAlī crushed all movements of rebellion among the peasants of the Mamluk Sultanate.
What was the duration of Qalāʾūn's rule as Mamluk sultan of the Mamluk Sultanate?
Qalāʾūn ruled the Mamluk Sultanate as Mamluk sultan from 1279 to 1290.
When did the Mamluk Sultanate drive the Crusaders out of Beirut?
The Mamlūks drove the Crusaders out of Beirut in 1291.
What was Beirut's role under Mamluk Sultanate rule?
Beirut became the chief port of call in Syria for the spice merchants from Venice under Mamluk Sultanate rule.
What was the nature of Mamluk Sultanate rule in Lebanon?
Mamluk Sultanate rule allowed limited local autonomy to regional leaders in Lebanon.
Who emerged as a champion of Muslim resurgence in the Mamluk Sultanate in 1260?
Baybars I emerged as a champion of Muslim resurgence in the Mamluk Sultanate in 1260.
When did Jerusalem fall to the Mamluk Sultanate?
Jerusalem fell to the Mamluk Sultanate in 1247.
When did the Mamluk Sultanate regain control of Jerusalem?
The Mamluk Sultanate regained control of Jerusalem in 1247.
Which Christian sects remained in Jerusalem under Mamluk Sultanate rule?
The Greek Orthodox and other Eastern sects remained in Jerusalem under Mamluk Sultanate rule.
What military corps did the Mamluk Sultanate establish to expel the Crusaders from Syria?
The Mamluk Sultanate established the Mamlūks, their own slave-soldier corps, to expel the remaining Crusaders from Syria.
What was the outcome of the Mamluk Sultanate's consolidation of Ayyūbid holdings in Syria?
The Mamluk Sultanate consolidated Ayyūbid holdings into a centralized state in Syria.
What military power replaced the Ayyubids as rulers of Egypt in 1250 in the Mamluk Sultanate?
The Mamluks, a self-perpetuating elite of slaves and freedmen, mainly of Turkish and Circassian origin, replaced the Ayyubids as rulers of Egypt in 1250.
Who was the victorious Mamluk general at the Battle of ʿAyn Jālūt in Palestine in 1260 in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Baybars I was the victorious Mamluk general at the Battle of ʿAyn Jālūt in Palestine in 1260.
What battle did the Mamluks win against the Mongols in Palestine in 1260 in the Mamluk Sultanate?
The Mamluks won the Battle of ʿAyn Jālūt against the Mongols in Palestine in 1260.
What event in 1260 contributed to the economic recovery of the Mamluk Sultanate?
The Mongol withdrawal in 1260 contributed to the economic recovery of the Mamluk Sultanate.
When did the economy of the Mamluk Sultanate begin to boom in Syria?
The economy of the Mamluk Sultanate began to boom in Syria by the beginning of the 14th century.
What was the administrative structure of the Mamluk Sultanate in Damascus?
Damascus was the seat of the sultan’s deputy in Syria, with a miniature court fashioned after that of Cairo.

In what year did Egyptians and Meccans attack al-Mujāhid the Rasūlid on a pilgrimage in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Egyptians and Meccans attacked al-Mujāhid the Rasūlid on a pilgrimage in 1350 in the Mamluk Sultanate.
Who was the Rasūlid ruler that was held prisoner in Egypt by the Mamluk Sultanate in 1350?
Al-Mujāhid the Rasūlid was the ruler that was held prisoner in Egypt by the Mamluk Sultanate in 1350.
What was the outcome of the Mamluk Sultanate's dispute with the Yemeni Rasūlids over the overlordship of the Holy Cities?
The Mamluk Sultanate generally prevailed in the dispute with the Yemeni Rasūlids over the overlordship of the Holy Cities.
What significant event occurred in the Mamluk Sultanate when Baybars I defeated the Mongols?
Baybars I invited a member of the ʿAbbāsid house to invest him and live in Cairo as spiritual head of all Muslims after his defeat of the Mongols.
How did Marjān divide the government of the kingdom in the Mamluk Sultanate?
Marjān divided the government of the kingdom between two other Mamlūks, Najāḥ and another Mamlūk, in the Mamluk Sultanate.
What type of tools were found in high river terraces of Ghana during the Pleistocene Epoch?
Pebble tools were found in high river terraces of Ghana during the Pleistocene Epoch.
What culture is lacking in Ghana during the succeeding pluvial era except for the extreme north?
The Acheulean culture is lacking in Ghana during the succeeding pluvial era except for the extreme north.

The Kintampo culture was found in the Accra plains of Ghana, characterized by clay houses, Saharan chert microliths, shale arm rings, and scored terra-cottas.

Fine pottery, stone axes, and quartz and shell beads were discovered at the Sekondi village and cemetery in Ghana.

The empire of Ghana flourished until the 13th century and is the namesake of modern Ghana.
When did Muslim contacts with the empire of Ghana begin?

What is the relationship between the oral traditions and the empire of Ghana?

What challenges do the early traditions of Ghana present?

What is the current state of linking traditions with archaeological evidence in Ghana?
Little progress has so far been made in linking the surviving traditions with the available archaeological evidence in Ghana.
Which states developed around the easterly termini near Ghana?
Songhai, the Hausa states, and Bornu developed around the easterly termini near Ghana.
What traders reached parts of modern Ghana by the 14th century?
Mande traders reached parts of modern Ghana by the 14th century.
What merchants reached parts of modern Ghana by the 16th century?
Hausa merchants reached parts of modern Ghana by the 16th century.
What influenced the inhabitants of what is now Ghana following the development of Islamic civilization in northern Africa?
The new wealth and cross-fertilization of ideas from the great empires of the western Sudan influenced the inhabitants of what is now Ghana.
Who founded the first states of the Akan-speaking peoples in Ghana?
Migrants coming from the direction of Mande founded the first states of the Akan-speaking peoples in Ghana about the 13th century.

Who founded the Ga and Ewe states of the southeast in Ghana?

What event occurred to the Toltec civilization in the 12th century CE that may have influenced the Aztec Empire's migration?
Tula, the capital of the Toltec civilization, was attacked and destroyed in the 12th century CE, along with other important Toltec centers.
What was the state of the Toltec civilization before the Aztec Empire's appearance in Mesoamerica?
The Toltec civilization was highly developed with a spectacular urban center featuring pyramids, temples, public buildings, and statuary before the Aztec Empire's appearance in Mesoamerica.

What dynasty succeeded the Qin dynasty in China?
The Han dynasty succeeded the Qin dynasty in China.
Which dynasty ruled China from 206 BCE to 220 CE?
The Han dynasty ruled China from 206 BCE to 220 CE.
Who temporarily usurped the throne and established the Xin dynasty in China?
Wang Mang temporarily usurped the throne and established the Xin dynasty in China.

When did the Qian (Former), or Xi (Western) Han period occur in China?
The Qian (Former), or Xi (Western) Han period occurred in China from 206 bce to 25 ce.

The Hou (Later), or Dong (Eastern) Han period occurred in China from 25 to 220 ce.
What system of local administration did Li Yuan adopt for China?
Li Yuan adopted the same pattern of local administration as the first Sui emperor for China.
What land-distribution system did Li Yuan implement in China?
Li Yuan adopted the Sui land-distribution system to give every taxable male a plot and minimize large estates in China.
Who succeeded to the throne of China in 626 by murdering two brothers and forcing the abdication of his father?
Li Shimin, known by the temple name Taizong, succeeded to the throne of China in 626 by murdering two brothers and forcing the abdication of his father.
What significant administrative reforms did Taizong implement in China?

Taizong adjusted the balance of the court aristocracy to equalize regional influences and expanded both the Sui use of examinations in literature and culture for hiring civil servants and the Sui system of high-quality schools at the capital.
Who was the empress who intrigued her way into the role during the reign of the Gaozong emperor in China?
Wu Zhao, known by Wuhou, her posthumous name, intrigued her way into the role of empress during the reign of the Gaozong emperor in China.
What military achievement did Taizong accomplish in China?
Taizong defeated his eastern Turkish enemies and spread disunity among those in the west, expanding China farther westward than ever before.
Who ruled China during the early 8th century golden age of arts?
Empress Wuhou ruled China during the early 8th century golden age of arts.
What event forced Emperor Xuanzong to flee west to Sichuan in China?
The rebellion in the northeast forced Emperor Xuanzong to flee west to Sichuan in China.
Who restored the authority of the empire throughout most of China by 818?
Emperor Xianzong restored the authority of the empire throughout most of China by 818.
What was the result of the rebellion that broke out in the northeast of China in the second half of the 8th century?

What instruments were played by musicians in China during the Tang period?
Musicians in China played bells, stone chimes, flutes, zithers, and drums during the Tang period.

Prose stylists in China during the Tang period were concerned with lyrical expression and rhetorical devices for artistic effect.
What types of instruments were used in imperial entertainments in China during the Tang period?

Who was the Tang minister of state in China better known as a painter than as a statesman?

What was Zhao Kuangyin's position before founding the Bei Song period in China?

Which dynasty did the Juchen establish in northern China after overthrowing the Liao kingdom?

Which dynasty did Gaozong of China emulate in managing civil service?

Who led the Mongol assault on the Jin state in northern China in 1211?
Genghis Khan led the Mongol assault on the Jin state in northern China in 1211.
When did the Mongols, under Genghis Khan’s grandsons, advance on the Song forces in China?
The Mongols, under Genghis Khan’s grandsons, advanced on the Song forces in China in 1250.
What dynasty ruled China from 960 to 1279?
The Song dynasty ruled China from 960 to 1279, establishing great artistic achievements.
When did the Song forces' capital fall in China?

What was the last of the Northern Song emperors known for in China?

What architectural feature was noted in the Song era in China?
The architecture of the Song era was noted for its tall structures and curved eave lines of roofs upward at the corners in China.
What was the name of the encyclopedia that appeared in 1267 in China?
An encyclopedia that appeared in 1267 in China has 10 of 200 chapters on the subject of music.
What dynasty ruled China from the early 13th century to 1368?
The Yuan dynasty ruled China from the early 13th century to 1368.
How much control did the Yuan emperors have over their distant possessions while ruling China?
The Yuan emperors were rarely able to exercise much control over their more distant possessions while ruling China.
When did Genghis Khan begin encroaching on the Jin dynasty in northern China?
Genghis Khan began encroaching on the Jin dynasty in northern China in 1211.
In what year did the Mongols complete their conquest of southern China by defeating the Nan Song dynasty?
The Mongols completed their conquest of southern China by defeating the Nan Song dynasty in 1279.

What was the first dynasty to make Beijing its capital in China?

What dynasty ruled China from 1368 to 1644?
The Ming dynasty ruled China from 1368 to 1644.
What dynasty ruled China from 1644 to 1911/12?
The Qing dynasty ruled China from 1644 to 1911/12.
Which dynasty succeeded the Yuan in China?
The Ming dynasty succeeded the Yuan in China.
What dynasty ruled China from 618 to 907?
The Tang dynasty ruled China from 618 to 907.
When was the First Republic of South Korea established?
The First Republic of South Korea was established in August 1948.
What law did South Korea adopt to prohibit opposition groups?
South Korea adopted a National Security Law to prohibit groups that opposed the state or expressed support for North Korea.
When was Syngman Rhee reelected as president of South Korea?
Syngman Rhee was reelected as president of South Korea in August 1952.
What was the main dispute between Syngman Rhee and the National Assembly of South Korea?

What event in South Korea on April 19, 1960, led to the resignation of President Rhee?
The massive student demonstrations in South Korea on April 19, 1960, led to the resignation of President Rhee.
When did President Rhee of South Korea force the National Assembly to pass an amendment exempting him from the two-term limit on the presidency?
President Rhee of South Korea forced the National Assembly to pass an amendment exempting him from the two-term limit on the presidency in 1954.
In what year did President Rhee of South Korea run for his fourth term of office?
President Rhee of South Korea ran for his fourth term of office in 1960.
When did President Rhee of South Korea die in exile?
President Rhee of South Korea died in exile in 1965.
Who was elected as the Prime Minister of South Korea during the Second Republic?
Prime Minister Chang Myon was elected by the lower house of the legislature in South Korea during the Second Republic.
What was the outcome of the Chang government's efforts to initiate reforms in South Korea?
The Chang government failed to cope with the unstable situation created by a violent political change in South Korea.
What was the source of authority in South Korea during the Second Republic?
The ultimate source of authority was vested in the office of the prime minister in South Korea during the Second Republic.
Who led the military junta that seized power in South Korea on May 16, 1961?
Gen. Park Chung-Hee led the military junta that seized power in South Korea on May 16, 1961.
What body, headed by Park Chung-Hee, took control of the government in South Korea after the 1961 coup?
The Supreme Council for National Reconstruction, headed by Park Chung-Hee, took control of the government in South Korea after the 1961 coup.
What significant change to South Korea's political structure was proposed by the Supreme Council for National Reconstruction in November 1962?
The Supreme Council for National Reconstruction proposed a constitutional amendment bill providing for a strong president and a weak, single-chamber National Assembly in South Korea in November 1962.
How was the constitutional amendment bill approved in South Korea in December 1962?
The constitutional amendment bill was approved by a national referendum in South Korea in December 1962.
What was Park's initial stance on participating in South Korea's civilian government in February?
Park announced that he would not take part in the civilian government to be formed later in the year if civilian political leaders chose to uphold a nine-point political stabilization proposal.
What was the outcome of the pressure on Park regarding elections in South Korea?
Park announced a plan for holding elections toward the end of the year under considerable domestic and international pressure.
What political party named Park as its presidential candidate in South Korea in late May?
The newly formed Democratic Republican Party (DRP) named Park as its presidential candidate.
Who was the opposition candidate in the 1963 presidential election of South Korea?
Yun Po-Sun was the opposition candidate in the 1963 presidential election of South Korea.
What was the outcome of the 1967 election in South Korea?
Park was elected to his second term of office in the 1967 election in South Korea.
Which party won a large majority in the National Assembly in 1967 in South Korea?
The DRP won a large majority in the National Assembly in 1967 in South Korea.
What was the response of the New Democratic Party to the 1967 election results in South Korea?

What constitutional amendment was passed in South Korea in October 1969?

Who won the presidential election in South Korea in April 1971?
President Park won the presidential election in South Korea in April 1971.
How many seats did the NDP secure in the National Assembly election in South Korea in 1971?

When did Ireland's economic problems begin to abate at the start of the 21st century?
Ireland's long-standing economic problems began to abate at the beginning of the 21st century.
What event occurred in Ireland in 2008?
A financial and economic crisis befell Ireland in 2008.
Who provided a costly bailout to Ireland's economy?

Ireland was formally incorporated into the United Kingdom in 1801.

The southern state of Ireland formally left the Commonwealth in 1949.
What economic community did Ireland join in 1973?
Ireland joined the European Economic Community in 1973.

What institution in Papua New Guinea was designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2008?
The Kuk Early Agricultural Site was designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2008.

What institute in Papua New Guinea promotes activities associated with traditional cultures?
The Institute of Papua New Guinea Studies promotes activities associated with traditional cultures.
What staple crop was introduced to Papua New Guinea from the Americas around 300 to 400 years ago?

When did Egypt regain its independence under Amyrtaeus of Sais in the Achaemenid Empire?

The Inca Empire's relay service carried messages at a rate of 150 miles a day.
When did the Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire occur?
The Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire occurred in 1532.

A well-organized relay service carried messages in the form of knotted cords called quipu in the Inca Empire.

Inti, the sun god, Viracocha, a creator god and culture hero, and Apu Illapu, the rain god, were the main deities in the Inca Empire's pantheon.

What major wars was Paraguay involved in during the 19th and 20th centuries?
Paraguay was involved in the War of the Triple Alliance (1864/65–70) and the Chaco War (1932–35).

Alfredo Stroessner ruled Paraguay from 1954 to 1989.

The Kyrgyzstan government granted U.S. in 2001.

Who was the revolutionary leader whose controversial rule affected Venezuela's position in the world?

Who were the first settlers of Tuvalu?
The first settlers of Tuvalu were from Samoa and probably arrived in the 14th century ad.
When did Tuvalu become a British protectorate?
Tuvalu became a British protectorate in 1892.
When did Tuvalu become part of the Gilbert and Ellice Islands Colony?
Tuvalu became part of the Gilbert and Ellice Islands Colony in 1916.
What was the primary religion established in Tuvalu by 1900?
Protestant Christianity was firmly established in Tuvalu by 1900.

When did Tuvalu gain independence?
Tuvalu gained independence in 1978.
What were the main priorities for Tuvalu after independence?
The main priorities for Tuvalu after independence were to establish the infrastructure for a separate nation and to seek foreign assistance for economic viability.
What two ethnic groups have been major influences on Sri Lanka's civilization?
The Sinhalese and the Tamils have been major influences on Sri Lanka's civilization.
What was the significance of Sri Lanka to European powers after the discovery of an oceanic route to India in the 15th century?
Sri Lanka's strategic importance increased with the coming of Europeans, leading Western maritime powers to fight for control of its shores.
What was the outcome of European influence on Sri Lanka and India in terms of their relationship?
European influence and colonial rule tightened the long-standing links between Sri Lanka and India.
When did Sri Lanka attain independence and what was the impact on its social institutions and ideologies?
Sri Lanka attained independence in the mid-20th century, leading its social institutions and ideologies to resonate more closely with India's.
When did people in Sri Lanka begin to experiment with food production and irrigation?
People in Sri Lanka began to experiment with food production and irrigation about the 9th century bce.
What type of tools became visible in the archaeological record of Sri Lanka about 28,000 years ago?
Finer tools made of quartz and occasionally of chert became visible in the archaeological record of Sri Lanka about 28,000 years ago.
When did human inhabitants first appear in Sri Lanka?
Human inhabitants first appeared in Sri Lanka some 75,000 to 125,000 years ago.
What type of tools did people in Sri Lanka gain access to from the continent by about the 9th century bce?
People in Sri Lanka gained access to some of the iron tools produced on the continent by about the 9th century bce.
What type of human inhabitants were the earliest in Sri Lanka with direct fossil evidence?

When did urban settlements first appear in Sri Lanka?

What chronicles constitute a literary record of the establishment and growth of Sinhalese political power and of Sri Lankan Buddhism?

Who were the first Indian settlers to arrive in Sri Lanka according to the Sinhalese tradition?

Who founded a dynasty in Sri Lanka after a ceremonial enthronement and marriage?

What period did the Anuradhapura culture span in Sri Lanka?
The Anuradhapura culture in Sri Lanka spanned the 3rd century bce to the 10th century ce.
What features were present in Sri Lanka before the Indo-Aryan migrations?
Settled agriculture, tank irrigation, use of iron, and pottery were features present in Sri Lanka before the Indo-Aryan migrations.
Who founded the kingdom of Anuradhapura in Sri Lanka?
Pandukkabhaya, the third king of the Vijaya dynasty, founded the kingdom of Anuradhapura.
When did Indo-Aryan settlements begin to grow in Sri Lanka?
Indo-Aryan settlements grew in different parts of Sri Lanka from about the 5th century bce.
Which group of settlers eventually gave their name to the descendants of the various groups in Sri Lanka?
The Sinhalese, the most powerful of the Indo-Aryan settlers, eventually gave their name to the descendants of the various groups.
What event in 1918 led to Austria experiencing social and economic turbulence?
The collapse of Austria-Hungary in 1918 led to Austria experiencing social and economic turbulence.
What political system did Austria join in 1995?
Austria joined the supranational European Union in 1995.
What event in 1955 enabled Austria to develop into a stable and socially progressive nation?
The establishment of permanent neutrality in 1955 enabled Austria to develop into a stable and socially progressive nation.
What occupation ended in Austria with the establishment of permanent neutrality in 1955?
The occupation by Allied troops that had occupied Austria since the end of World War II ended with the establishment of permanent neutrality in 1955.
What former empire had its seat in Vienna, the capital of Austria?
The Holy Roman Empire had its seat in Vienna, the capital of Austria.
Which state conquered and destroyed the Sao kingdom in Cameroon?
Kotoko state conquered and destroyed the Sao kingdom in Cameroon.
When did the Sao kingdom reach its height in Cameroon?
Sao kingdom reached its height from the 9th to the 15th century in Cameroon.
Which empire incorporated the Kotoko state in Cameroon during the late 19th century?
Bornu empire incorporated the Kotoko state in Cameroon during the late 19th century.
Who was the ruler during which the Kotoko state was incorporated into the Bornu empire in Cameroon?
Rābiḥ al-Zubayr was the ruler during which the Kotoko state was incorporated into the Bornu empire in Cameroon.
What faith became a powerful force in northern and central Cameroon through conquest, immigration, and commerce from north and northwestern Africa?
Islam became a powerful force in northern and central Cameroon through conquest, immigration, and commerce from north and northwestern Africa.
What trade replaced the slave trade in Cameroon in the early 1800s?
Trade in rubber, palm oil, and other items replaced the slave trade in Cameroon in the early 1800s.
