Which kingdoms provided a supply of enslaved people for the Atlantic slave trade in Cameroon?
The Bamileke, Bamoum, and other kingdoms provided a supply of enslaved people for the Atlantic slave trade in Cameroon.
What European powers replaced earlier Portuguese and Dutch influences in Cameroon?
The British and Germans replaced earlier Portuguese and Dutch influences in Cameroon.
Who established a Baptist station in Akwa Town in 1845 in Cameroon?
Alfred Saker and Joseph Merrick established a Baptist station in Akwa Town in 1845 in Cameroon.
When did the American Presbyterian mission open a station in Cameroon?
The American Presbyterian mission opened a station in 1871 in Cameroon.
Which Christian denominations have been the most prominent in Cameroon?
The Presbyterians, Baptists, and Roman Catholics have been the most prominent denominations in Cameroon.
Which empire had suzerainty over the Kha communities in what is now Laos since the 5th century?
The Khmer empire of Cambodia had suzerainty over the Kha communities in what is now Laos since the 5th century.
What principality did the Tai establish in what is now Laos during the 12th and 13th centuries?
The Tai established the principality of Muong Swa in what is now Laos during the 12th and 13th centuries.
What period of time did Fa Ngum conquer territories that included all of present-day Laos and much of what is today northern and eastern Thailand?
Fa Ngum conquered territories that included all of present-day Laos and much of what is today northern and eastern Thailand between 1353 and 1371.
What event broke the long period of calm in Laos after Oun Hueun's death in 1416?
A Vietnamese invasion in 1479 broke the long period of calm in Laos after Oun Hueun's death in 1416.
Who ruled Laos from 1520 to 1548 and involved the country in a struggle against Myanmar and Ayutthaya?
Photisarath ruled Laos from 1520 to 1548 and involved the country in a struggle against Myanmar and Ayutthaya.
Who succeeded Photisarath as ruler of Laos and transferred the capital from Luang Prabang to Vientiane?
Setthathirath I succeeded Photisarath as ruler of Laos and transferred the capital from Luang Prabang to Vientiane.
Which kingdom took control of Chiang Mai from Laos during Setthathirath I's reign?
The kingdom of Myanmar took control of Chiang Mai from Laos during Setthathirath I's reign.
What significant military events occurred in Laos around 1565 and 1570 during Setthathirath I's rule?
Laos repelled two invasions around 1565 and 1570 during Setthathirath I's rule.
Who did Photisarath place on the throne of Chiang Mai, marking Laos' maximum territorial expansion?
Photisarath placed his son Setthathirath on the throne of Chiang Mai, marking Laos' maximum territorial expansion.
Who restored order in Laos after a period of anarchy following Setthathirath's death in 1571?
Souligna Vongsa restored order in Laos after a period of anarchy following Setthathirath's death in 1571.
What event occurred in Laos in 1574 after Setthathirath's death?
Myanmar seized Vien Chan in Laos in 1574 after Setthathirath's death.
Who led two victorious expeditions against the principality of Chieng Khouang in southern Laos?
Souligna Vongsa led two victorious expeditions against the principality of Chieng Khouang in southern Laos.
What was the outcome of Souligna Vongsa's death in 1694 for Laos?
Souligna Vongsa's death in 1694 led to one of his nephews seizing the throne with Vietnamese help, placing Laos under Vietnamese rule.
How did members of the royal family in northern Laos respond to Vietnamese vassalage after Souligna Vongsa's death?
Members of the royal family in northern Laos refused to accept Vietnamese vassalage after Souligna Vongsa's death.
What year did Lan Xang cease to exist as a unified kingdom in Laos?
Lan Xang ceased to exist as a unified kingdom in Laos in 1713.
What year did the kingdom of Champassak secede from Lan Xang in Laos?
The kingdom of Champassak seceded from Lan Xang in Laos in 1713.
What year did Luang Prabang and Vien Chan declare independence from Lan Xang in Laos?
Luang Prabang and Vien Chan declared independence from Lan Xang in Laos in 1707.
What were the three separate kingdoms that Lan Xang split into in Laos?
Lan Xang split into the separate kingdoms of Luang Prabang, Vien Chan, and Champassak in Laos.
What branch of the Indo-European people created a state entity in premodern times in Lithuania?
Lithuanians, belonging to the Baltic group, created a state entity in premodern times in Lithuania.
What became of the Prussians in Lithuania by the 18th century?
The Prussians became extinct by the 18th century in Lithuania.
Which lands were already in the hands of the German Crusading knights near Lithuania?
Prussia and Livonia were already in the hands of the German Crusading knights near Lithuania.
What was the particular object of German expansion between Prussia and Livonia in Lithuania?
Samogitia was the particular object of German expansion between Prussia and Livonia in Lithuania.
Who united the Lithuanian tribes in the middle of the 13th century?
Mindaugas united the Lithuanian tribes in the middle of the 13th century.
When was Mindaugas crowned king of Lithuania?
Mindaugas was crowned king of Lithuania in 1253 by authority of Pope Innocent IV.
Who was the ruler of Lithuania from 1270 to 1282?
Traidenis was the ruler of Lithuania from 1270 to 1282.
When did Gediminas begin to rule Lithuania?
Gediminas began to rule Lithuania about 1315.
Who systematically carved out the empire that was historic Lithuania?
Gediminas systematically carved out the empire that was historic Lithuania.
What was the capital of Lithuania by 1323?
Vilnius was the capital of Lithuania by 1323.
What was a notable practice of the Lithuanian warrior caste?
The Lithuanian warrior caste intermarried extensively with the ruling princely families of the subject East Slav principalities.
Who ruled Lithuania as Great Prince after Algirdas's death in 1377?
Jogaila ruled Lithuania as Great Prince after Algirdas's death in 1377.
Who drove Jogaila from Vilnius in 1381 and assumed the title of Great Prince of Lithuania?
Kęstutis drove Jogaila from Vilnius in 1381 and assumed the title of Great Prince of Lithuania.
Who captured Kęstutis and his eldest son Vytautas in 1382 in Lithuania?
Jogaila captured Kęstutis and his eldest son Vytautas in 1382 in Lithuania.
What significant event occurred in Lithuania in 1362 under Algirdas's rule?
In 1362, Algirdas expanded his empire in the east to include Kiev in Lithuania.
What was the division within Lithuania's ruling family regarding alliances in 1382?
Lithuania's ruling family was split between those favoring alliance with Moscow and Orthodox Christianity and those preferring alliance with Poland and Roman Christianity.
What agreement did Jogaila conclude on August 14, 1385, regarding Lithuania?
Jogaila concluded an agreement to join his realm with Poland in return for marriage to the 12-year-old Polish queen Jadwiga and assumption of the Polish throne as king.
When did Jogaila formally introduce Roman Christianity among his Lithuanian-speaking subjects?
Jogaila formally introduced Roman Christianity among his Lithuanian-speaking subjects in 1387.
What was the consequence of the baptism of the Lithuanians for the Teutonic Order?
The baptism of the Lithuanians removed the basis for the existence of the Teutonic Order.
What battle in 1410 marked a decisive defeat for the German threat to Lithuania?
The Battle of Grünwald on July 15, 1410, marked a decisive defeat for the German threat to Lithuania.
Who ruled Lithuania during its apogee and died in 1430?
Vytautas, called the Great, ruled Lithuania during its apogee and died in 1430.
What title did Ivan III, Grand Prince of Moscow, assume in 1480 that posed a threat to Lithuania?
Ivan III, Grand Prince of Moscow, assumed the title of sovereign of all the Russes in 1480 that posed a threat to Lithuania.
What was the nature of the union between Lithuania and Poland until 1569?
The union between Lithuania and Poland remained a loose alliance by virtue of a common ruler until 1569.
What political transformation occurred in Lithuania on July 1, 1569?
The common Polish-Lithuanian parliament transformed the loose personal union into a Commonwealth of Two Peoples on July 1, 1569.
What administrative structure did Lithuania maintain after the formation of the Commonwealth?
Lithuania continued to be administered separately with its own law codes and armed forces after the formation of the Commonwealth.
What cultural impact did the Commonwealth have on the Lithuanian nobility by the end of the 17th century?
The Commonwealth led to the cultural Polonization of the Lithuanian nobility, making it virtually indistinguishable from its Polish counterpart by the end of the 17th century.
Which social class in Lithuania retained the old language despite the Commonwealth's cultural influence?
The peasantry in Lithuania retained the old language despite the Commonwealth's cultural influence.
Who founded the Pala Empire in the mid-8th century?
Gopala founded the Pala Empire in the mid-8th century.
Which Pala Empire ruler expanded the kingdom and controlled Kannauj?
Dharmapala expanded the kingdom and controlled Kannauj.
Which ruler restored Pala Empire strength and reached Varanasi?
Mahipala I restored Pala Empire strength and reached Varanasi.
Who penetrated northern Bengal during the Pala Empire's decline?
Mahendrapala penetrated northern Bengal during the Pala Empire's decline.
Who was the last important king of the Pala Empire and what were his achievements?
Ramapala, the last important Pala king, strengthened the dynasty in Bengal and expanded its power in Assam and Orissa.
What was the outcome of Ramapala's death for the Pala Empire?
The Pala dynasty was virtually eclipsed by the rising power of the Senas after Ramapala's death.
What was the main capital of the Pala Empire?
Mudgagiri, now Munger, was the main capital of the Pala Empire.
What was the religious influence of the Pala Empire?
The Pala Empire supported Buddhism and helped establish it in Tibet through missionaries from their kingdom.
What was the cultural contribution of the Pala Empire?
The Pala Empire patronized a distinctive school of art, resulting in many noteworthy sculptures in stone and metal.
Who was the first permanent settler of Iceland according to The Book of Settlements?
Ingólfr Arnarson was the first permanent settler of Iceland according to The Book of Settlements.
What year did Ingólfr Arnarson settle in Iceland?
Ingólfr Arnarson settled in Iceland in the year 874.
What was the approximate period of settlement in Iceland according to Íslendingabók?
Íslendingabók sets the period of settlement in Iceland at about 870–930 ce.
What evidence supports the earliest human habitation in Iceland?
A layer of tephra dated to about 870 supports the earliest human habitation in Iceland.
When did Irish hermits begin sailing to Iceland?
Irish hermits began sailing to Iceland in the 8th century.
When did the Viking Age settlements in Iceland occur?
Iceland was among Norse Viking Age settlements of the late 9th or early 10th century.
What was the name of the general Icelandic assembly established by the end of the settlement period?
The Althing was the general Icelandic assembly established by the end of the settlement period.
Who nominated the judges for the courts of justice in Iceland during the Commonwealth period?
The godar nominated the judges for the courts of justice in Iceland during the Commonwealth period.
What was the name of the chieftaincy system in Iceland during the Commonwealth period?
The godord was the chieftaincy system in Iceland during the Commonwealth period.
Was there a central authority with executive power over Iceland during the Commonwealth period?
No central authority was vested with executive power over Iceland during the Commonwealth period.
When were the bishoprics at Skálholt and Hólar established in Iceland?
The bishoprics at Skálholt and Hólar were established in 1056 and 1106 respectively.
When did the codification of the law begin in Iceland?
The codification of the law began in 1117–18 in Iceland.
What was the impact of Norway's royal power on Iceland in the early 13th century?
Norway's royal power gained strength in the early 13th century, aiming to unite all Norwegian Viking Age settlements, including Iceland, under its reign.
What event occurred in Iceland between 1262 and 1264?
Icelandic chieftains and representatives of the farmers swore allegiance to the king of Norway between 1262 and 1264.
Who held almost all the chieftaincies in Iceland by mid-century?
About 10 powerful godar, belonging to some five families, held almost all the chieftaincies in Iceland by mid-century.
What war did Australia participate in from 1899 to 1902?
Australia participated in the Boer War from 1899 to 1902.
What war did Australia participate in from 1914 to 1918?
Australia participated in the First World War from 1914 to 1918.
When did European explorers first arrive in Australia?
European explorers first arrived in Australia in the 16th century.
What Chinese historical period may have seen control of South Asian waters extending to a landing in Australia?
China's control of South Asian waters could have extended to a landing in Australia in the early 15th century.
Which Muslim voyagers came within 300 miles of Australia?
Muslim voyagers who visited and settled in Southeast Asia came within 300 miles of Australia.
What was the Latin term used by Europeans to describe the unknown southern land that included Australia?
Terra australis incognita was the Latin term used by Europeans to describe the unknown southern land that included Australia.
What maps are cited as evidence of a possible Portuguese discovery of Australia?
The Dieppe maps are cited as evidence of a possible Portuguese discovery of Australia.
What was the purpose of Pedro Fernández de Quirós' expedition to Australia del Espirítu Santo in 1605?
Pedro Fernández de Quirós' expedition aimed to establish Roman Catholicism in the southern land.
When did Pedro Fernández de Quirós' expedition to Australia del Espirítu Santo depart from Callao, Peru?
Pedro Fernández de Quirós' expedition departed from Callao, Peru, in December 1605.
Who was the first Dutch explorer to land in Australia?
Willem Jansz was the first Dutch explorer to land in Australia in 1605.
What was the name of the Dutch ship that first landed in Australia in 1616?
The Eendracht was the Dutch ship that first landed in Australia in 1616.
Who published Voyages and persuaded the Admiralty to back another venture in Australia?
The explorer published Voyages and persuaded the Admiralty to back another venture in Australia.
Which government showed interest in Australia by backing several voyages in the 18th century?
The British government showed interest in Australia by backing several voyages in the 18th century.
What was the British government's hope for Australia in the eastern seas?
The British government hoped for a mighty empire of commerce in the eastern seas in Australia.
What was the purpose of Captain James Cook's three voyages on behalf of the British Admiralty in relation to Australia?
Captain James Cook's three voyages on behalf of the British Admiralty were to explore and strengthen British interest in the eastern seas, including Australia.
When did Captain James Cook's first voyage to Australia take place?
Captain James Cook's first voyage to Australia took place from August 1768 to April 20, 1770.
Who were the most famous post-settlement explorers of Australia?
George Bass and Matthew Flinders were the most famous post-settlement explorers of Australia.
Who traversed and described the southern shores of Australia discovered by Pieter Nuyts?
George Vancouver traversed and described the southern shores of Australia discovered by Pieter Nuyts in 1791.
Who commanded the expedition that circumnavigated Australia and virtually completed the charting of the continent?
Flinders commanded the expedition that circumnavigated Australia and virtually completed the charting of the continent.
When did the name change from New Holland to Australia receive official backing?
The name change from New Holland to Australia received official backing from 1817.
Who led the Admiralty expeditions to Australia from 1817 to 1822 and from 1838 to 1839?
Phillip Parker King and John Clements Wickham led the Admiralty expeditions to Australia from 1817 to 1822 and from 1838 to 1839 respectively.
What was the primary purpose of the British government in settling Australia in 1788?
The British government primarily intended to relieve pressure on its prisons by transporting convicts to Australia.
When did the British government decide to settle New South Wales in Australia?
The British government determined on settling New South Wales in Australia in 1786.
What event intensified the pressure on Britain's prisons prior to settling Australia?
The loss of its American colonies intensified the pressure on Britain's prisons prior to settling Australia.
When did colonization of Australia begin?
Colonization of Australia began early in 1788.
Who was the commander of the expedition to Australia in 1787?
Arthur Phillip was the commander of the expedition to Australia in 1787.
What was the composition of the First Fleet that sailed to Australia on May 13, 1787?
The First Fleet that sailed to Australia on May 13, 1787, consisted of 11 vessels, including 6 transports, carrying about 730 convicts and more than 250 free persons.
What was the British government's plan for developing Australia's economy?
The British government planned to develop Australia's economy by employing convict labour on government farms, while former convicts would subsist on their own small plots.
Who was the guiding authority for the plans to settle Australia?
Lord Sydney (Thomas Townshend), secretary of state for home affairs, was the guiding authority for the plans to settle Australia.
When did Phillip establish an outstation at Norfolk Island in Australia?
Phillip established an outstation at Norfolk Island in Australia immediately after settling in Port Jackson.
What was the purpose of Norfolk Island in Australia from 1825?
Norfolk Island in Australia was revived in 1825 to provide a jail for convicts who misbehaved in Australia.
What new purpose did Norfolk Island in Australia serve from 1856?
Norfolk Island in Australia served as a home for the descendants of the mutineers of the HMS Bounty from 1856.
When did Phillip's governorship of New South Wales in Australia end?
Phillip's governorship of New South Wales in Australia ended in December 1792.
What challenges did European settlers face in Australia during the early settlement period?
European settlers in Australia faced challenges including indifferent land, disease, pests, and hostile Aboriginal people.
What event marked the nadir of European settlement in Australia in autumn 1790?
The nadir of European settlement in Australia in autumn 1790 was marked by shrinking supplies.
What impact did the arrival of the second fleet have on European settlement in Australia?
The arrival of the second fleet in Australia brought hundreds of sickly convicts but also the means of survival.
When did Guatemala transition from authoritarian rule to democratic governance?
Guatemala transitioned from authoritarian rule to democratic governance in 1985.
What sparked the 36-year civil war in Guatemala starting in 1954?
Guerrilla opposition sparked the 36-year civil war in Guatemala starting in 1954.
When were peace accords signed to end the civil war in Guatemala?
Peace accords were signed to end the civil war in Guatemala in 1996.
Since what year have elections been held regularly in Guatemala?
Elections have been held regularly in Guatemala since 1996.
When was the Republic of Somalia formed?
The Republic of Somalia was formed in 1960 by the federation of a former Italian colony and a British protectorate.
Who held dictatorial rule over Somalia from October 1969 until January 1991?
Mohamed Siad Barre held dictatorial rule over Somalia from October 1969 until January 1991.
What event led to the overthrow of Mohamed Siad Barre in Somalia in 1991?
Mohamed Siad Barre was overthrown in a bloody civil war waged by clan-based guerrillas in 1991.
What autonomous region was self-proclaimed in the northeast of Somalia in 1998?
The autonomous region of Puntland was self-proclaimed in the northeast of Somalia in 1998.
What type of administration did Somalia have before 2012?
Somalia had a tenuous transitional administration before 2012.
What was established in Somalia in 2012?
The Federal Republic of Somalia was established in 2012.
What was the hope for Somalia after the establishment of the new government in 2012?
The hope was that the new government would usher in a new era of peace and rebuilding in Somalia.
What is the approximate date of the oldest fossil remains found in Nigeria?
The oldest fossil remains found in Nigeria have been dated to about 9000 bce.
What type of evidence from the Stone Age has been found in Nigeria?
Isolated collections of ancient tools and artifacts from different periods of the Stone Age have been found in Nigeria.
What is the significance of the Nok culture in Nigeria's history?
The Nok culture represents the oldest recognizable evidence of an organized society in Nigeria.
When were the Nok culture's terra-cotta figurines accidentally discovered in Nigeria?
The Nok culture's terra-cotta figurines were accidentally discovered by tin miners in Nigeria in the 1930s.
What artistic features characterized the Nok culture's art in Nigeria?

The Nok culture's art in Nigeria was characterized by naturalism, stylized treatment of the mouth and eyes, relative proportions of the human head, body, and feet, distortions of the human facial features, and treatment of animal forms.
Which Nigerian locations later developed art influenced by the Nok culture?
Igbo Ukwu, Ife, Esie, and Benin City in Nigeria later developed art influenced by the Nok culture.
What periods did the Nok culture in Nigeria transition through?
The Nok culture in Nigeria transitioned from the Neolithic period to the Iron Age.
What was discovered in Nigeria in the 1930s and '40s at Igbo Ukwu?
Bronzes, which have been dated to about the 9th century ce, were discovered in Nigeria in the 1930s and '40s at Igbo Ukwu.
What do the bronzes discovered in Nigeria reveal about the society at Igbo Ukwu?
The bronzes discovered in Nigeria reveal a high artistic tradition and a well-structured society with wide-ranging economic relationships.
What was the role of the eze nri in Nigeria?
The eze nri, a priest-king, held religious but not political power over large parts of the Igbo-inhabited region in Nigeria well into the 20th century.
What were some of the large and developed systems in northern Nigeria before British control?

The Hausa states of Kano, Katsina, Zaria, and Gobir, Kanem-Borno, and the Jukun states of Kwararafa, Kona, Pinduga, and Wukari were large and developed systems in northern Nigeria before British control.
Which smaller kingdoms existed in Nigeria before the late 19th century?
The Igala, Nupe, and Ebira kingdoms were smaller kingdoms that existed in Nigeria before the late 19th century.
What were some of the notable states in southern Nigeria before British control?

The Yoruba states of Ife and Oyo, the Edo state of Benin, the Itsekiri state of Warri, the Efik state of Calabar, and the Ijo city-states of Nembe, Elem Kalabari, Bonny, and Okrika were notable states in southern Nigeria before British control.
What was the dominant power in central Sudan, including much of Hausaland, for a long time in Nigeria?
Borno was the dominant power in central Sudan, including much of Hausaland, for a long time in Nigeria.
What legend concerning a mythical Middle Eastern ancestor of the Hausa suggests influence on the rise of a centralized political system in Hausaland in Nigeria?
The Bayajidda legend concerning a mythical Middle Eastern ancestor of the Hausa suggests influence on the rise of a centralized political system in Hausaland in Nigeria.
What was the structure of the monarchy in Borno in Nigeria despite the rulers embracing Islam?
The structure of the monarchy in Borno in Nigeria remained traditional, with the queen mother and other female officials exercising considerable power despite the rulers embracing Islam.
What were the bases of royal authority in Borno in Nigeria?
The selection of the monarch, the coronation rites, and other bases of royal authority in Borno in Nigeria were dictated by pre-Islamic beliefs.
Who were granted fiefs and posted away from the capital to govern frontier zones in Borno in Nigeria?
The princes and other members of the royal family in Borno in Nigeria were granted fiefs and posted away from the capital to govern frontier zones.
Who were preferred for the royal guard and palace officials in Borno in Nigeria?
People of slave origin were preferred for the royal guard and palace officials in Borno in Nigeria.
What centralized states developed in Nigeria with walled cities and monarchical systems of government?
Daura, Katsina, Kano, Zaria, Gobir, and Kebbi developed as centralized states in Nigeria with walled cities and monarchical systems of government.
From which empire was Islam introduced to Nigeria in the 14th century?
Islam was introduced to Nigeria from the Mali empire in the 14th century.
When did Islam begin to spread beyond urban areas in Nigeria?
Islam remained predominantly an urban religion in Nigeria until the beginning of the 19th century.
What cultural features emerged in Nigeria during the time of Yoruba city-states?
A monarchical system, a pantheon of gods, and divination centred on the deity Ifa emerged in Nigeria during the time of Yoruba city-states.
What is Ife known for in Nigeria?
Ife is known for its potsherd pavements and the great artistry of its terra-cottas and bronzes in Nigeria.
How did Yoruba states in Nigeria establish legitimacy?
Yoruba states in Nigeria established legitimacy by claiming descent from Ife and sometimes borrowing regalia from Ife for coronation rites.
What practice did Yoruba states in Nigeria follow regarding deceased rulers?
Yoruba states in Nigeria sometimes sent remains of deceased rulers to Ife for burial.
What kingdom in Nigeria gradually supplanted the older kingdom of Ife in the 14th century?
Oyo gradually supplanted the older kingdom of Ife in the 14th century.
What goods were exchanged in Nigeria between the north and south through the Oyo kingdom?
Rock salt, copper, textiles, leather goods, and horses from the north were exchanged with kola nuts, indigo, parrots, and cowries from the south in Nigeria.
When did the Portuguese arrive in the kingdom of Benin in Nigeria?
The Portuguese arrived in the kingdom of Benin in Nigeria in the 15th century.
What type of structure did the kingdom of Benin in Nigeria have when the Portuguese arrived?
The kingdom of Benin in Nigeria had a monarchy with a complex structure of chiefs and palace officials when the Portuguese arrived.
Who founded the Tutsi monarchy in Burundi in the 16th century?
Ntare Rushatsi (Ntare I) founded the Tutsi monarchy in Burundi in the 16th century.
When did Hutu farmers begin arriving in Burundi?
Hutu farmers began arriving in Burundi around 1000 ce.
What was the original population of Burundi before the arrival of Hutu and Tutsi groups?
The Twa, a Pygmy hunter-gatherer population, were the original inhabitants of Burundi.
Who established the original kingdom in the Nkoma region of Burundi?
Ntare I established the original kingdom in the Nkoma region of Burundi.
Who were the first Europeans to visit Burundi in 1858?
Richard Burton and John Hanning Speke were the first Europeans to visit Burundi in 1858.
What German territory did Burundi become part of in 1890?
Burundi became part of the German Protectorate of East Africa in 1890.
Which country was awarded control of Burundi after World War I?
Belgium was awarded control of Burundi after World War I.
What administrative change occurred in Burundi in the late 1920s under Belgian rule?
Most chiefs and subchiefs were eliminated in Burundi in the late 1920s under Belgian rule.
What system did Germany and Belgium create in Burundi based on physical characteristics?
Germany and Belgium created a system in Burundi whereby the categories of Hutu and Tutsi were no longer fluid based on physical characteristics.
Which group was considered superior in Burundi due to European bias?
The Tutsi were considered superior in Burundi due to European bias toward their generally lighter skin and greater height.
When did Burundians begin to press for independence?
Burundians began to press for independence after World War II (1939–45).
What political party was established in Burundi in 1958?
Unity for National Progress (Unité pour le Progrès National; UPRONA) was established in Burundi in 1958.
What was the outcome of the legislative elections held in Burundi in 1961?
UPRONA won 58 out of 64 legislative seats in Burundi in 1961, with 22 seats held by Hutu members.
Who became prime minister of Burundi after the 1961 legislative elections?
Prince Rwagasore became prime minister of Burundi after the 1961 legislative elections.
When did Burundi gain independence?
Burundi became independent on July 1, 1962.
What event occurred on October 13, 1961, in Burundi?
Prince Rwagasore was assassinated on October 13, 1961, in Burundi.
What change occurred in the role of the mwami in Burundi in 1959?
The mwami was made a constitutional monarch in Burundi in 1959.
Who was assassinated in Burundi on January 15, 1965?
Pierre Ngendandumwe was assassinated in Burundi on January 15, 1965.
Who served as prime minister in Burundi after Pierre Ngendandumwe's assassination?
Joseph Bamina served as prime minister in Burundi after Pierre Ngendandumwe's assassination.
Who was appointed prime minister by Mwambutsa in Burundi despite the Hutu majority in the National Assembly?
Léopold Biha was appointed prime minister by Mwambutsa in Burundi despite the Hutu majority in the National Assembly.
Who was the constitutional monarch of Burundi who requested Pierre Ngendandumwe to take office as prime minister for the second time?
Mwambutsa was the constitutional monarch of Burundi who requested Pierre Ngendandumwe to take office as prime minister for the second time.
Who was appointed prime minister of Burundi in July 1966?
Michel Micombero was appointed prime minister of Burundi in July 1966.
Who deposed Mwambutsa in Burundi in July 1966?
Prince Charles Ndizeyeto deposed Mwambutsa in Burundi in July 1966.
Who deposed Prince Charles Ndizeyeto in Burundi in November 1966?
Tutsi politicians deposed Prince Charles Ndizeyeto in Burundi in November 1966.
What event led to the execution of 34 Hutu officers in Burundi?
The abortive coup led to the execution of 34 Hutu officers in Burundi.
What event in Burundi in 1972 led to the deaths of an estimated 100,000 to 200,000 Hutu?
The genocidal killings perpetrated against the Hutu community in April and May 1972 led to the deaths of an estimated 100,000 to 200,000 Hutu.
What percentage of Burundi's population was killed during the 1972 genocidal killings?
The 1972 genocidal killings took the lives of approximately 5 percent of Burundi's population.
How many Hutu fled Burundi as a result of the 1972 genocidal killings?
More than 100,000 Hutu fled Burundi as a result of the 1972 genocidal killings.
What was the outcome for educated Hutu in Burundi following the 1972 genocidal killings?
The 1972 genocidal killings virtually eliminated all educated Hutu in Burundi.
Who overthrew Micombero in Burundi in 1976?
Jean-Baptiste Bagaza overthrew Micombero in Burundi in 1976.
What was the process of Slavicization in Serbia during the late 7th century?
The Slavicization of Serbia was a long and erratic process during the late 7th century.
What were the names used to refer to Serbia during the period of cultural assimilation under Roman rule?
Serbia was referred to as Vlachia and Sclavinia during the period of cultural assimilation under Roman rule.
Who created the first state to which Serbs attach a political identity in Serbia around 850?
Vlastimir created the first state to which Serbs attach a political identity in Serbia around 850.
What was the basis of the Serbs' social organization in Serbia?
The zadruga, or extended family, was the basis of the Serbs' social organization in Serbia.
What title did a veliki župan occasionally declare himself in Serbia?
A veliki župan occasionally declared himself king or emperor in Serbia.
What was the relationship between the early Serb state in Serbia and Constantinople?
The early Serb state in Serbia initially accepted the supremacy of Constantinople.
Who were the main rivals for control over the region of Serbia during the early Slav states period?
Simeon I, ruler of the first Bulgarian empire, and the veliki župan Česlav, leader of a rival Serb kingdom known as Zeta, were the main rivals for control over the region of Serbia.
What religious tradition was established in Serbia during the early Slav states period?
The early Serb protostates established an enduring link between the Serb people and the Slavonic liturgical tradition of Orthodox Christianity in Serbia.
When was Christianity first introduced to the region that includes Serbia?
Christianity was introduced into the Balkans, including the region of Serbia, during the Roman period.
What script was invented by Cyril and Methodius to facilitate preaching in Serbia?
Cyril and Methodius invented the Glagolitic script to facilitate preaching in Serbia.
Who commissioned Cyril and Methodius to evangelize the Slavs in Serbia?
Byzantine emperor Michael III commissioned Cyril and Methodius to evangelize the Slavs in Serbia.
Who secured the title of 'king of Serbia, Dalmatia, and Bosnia' from Pope Honorius III in 1217?
Stefan Prvovenčani secured the title of 'king of Serbia, Dalmatia, and Bosnia' from Pope Honorius III in 1217.
What dynasty facilitated the rise of Serbia after the defeat of the Byzantine Empire in 1204?
The Nemanjić dynasty facilitated the rise of Serbia after the defeat of the Byzantine Empire in 1204.
Under whose reign did the Nemanjić state reach its greatest extent in Serbia?
The Nemanjić state reached its greatest extent in Serbia under the reign of Stefan Dušan.
What territories did Serbia incorporate under Stefan Dušan's reign from 1331 to 1355?
Serbia incorporated Thessaly, Epirus, Macedonia, all of modern Albania and Montenegro, a substantial part of eastern Bosnia, and modern Serbia as far north as the Danube under Stefan Dušan's reign.
What was the Golden Age of Serbia?
The empire of Dušan Silni was considered the Golden Age of Serbia.
What was the relationship between the Serbian state and Byzantium during the Middle Ages?
The Serbian state modeled itself on Byzantium and saw itself as a supplanter of Byzantium during the Middle Ages.
When was an autocephalous church declared in Serbia?
An autocephalous church was declared in Serbia in 1219.
Who was named archbishop of Serbia in 1219?
Sava, the youngest son of Stefan Nemanja, was named archbishop of Serbia in 1219.
When was the archbishop of Peć raised to the status of patriarch in Serbia?
The archbishop of Peć was raised to the status of patriarch in Serbia in 1375.
What significant event occurred in Serbia in 1219 regarding the Serbian church?
The Serbian church separated from the Bulgarian-influenced archbishopric of Ohrid in Serbia in 1219.
What crops became more widespread in Serbia during the Nemanjić period?
Hemp, flax, grapes, and oil-yielding plants became more widespread in Serbia during the Nemanjić period.
Who prepared the biography of Stefan Nemanja in Serbia?
St. Sava and his brother Stefan Prvovenčani prepared the biography of Stefan Nemanja in Serbia.
What type of league was formed in Switzerland during the medieval period?
Switzerland formed a medieval defensive league during a time lacking imperial authority.
What was the primary reason for the cantons in Switzerland to remain united?
The cantons in Switzerland remained united through the shared defense of liberty.
What significant historical event in the 16th century caused internal strife in Switzerland?
The Reformation in the 16th century caused endemic internal strife in Switzerland.
What political structure did Switzerland develop during the early modern period?
Switzerland developed political structures on the level of the 13 cantons that the Swiss Confederation comprised by the time of the Reformation.
What significant political document did Switzerland adopt in 1848?
Switzerland adopted its 1848 constitution, which enshrined liberal principles such as individual rights, separation of powers, and parliamentary bicameralism.
What period of crisis led to the integration of French- and Italian-speaking cantons into Switzerland?
The period of crisis from the end of the 18th century to the mid-19th century led to the integration of French- and Italian-speaking cantons into Switzerland.
When was Switzerland attacked during the European balance of power period?
Switzerland was attacked in 1798 during the European balance of power period.
What concept did Switzerland develop to maintain peace during the 20th century?
Switzerland developed the concept of armed neutrality to maintain peace during the 20th century.
What historical period did Switzerland adapt well to economically?
Switzerland adapted well to the Industrial Revolution economically.
What global conflicts did Switzerland avoid participating in during the 20th century?
Switzerland was spared from participating in two world wars during the 20th century.
What is the age of the first stone implements discovered in Switzerland?
The first stone implements discovered in Switzerland are more than 250,000 years old.
When did early human Neanderthal hunting settlements exist in Switzerland?
Early human Neanderthal hunting settlements in Switzerland date from about 50,000 bce.
What type of artifacts were found in Kesslerloch in Switzerland?
Animal figures carved on antlers and bones were found in Kesslerloch in Switzerland.
When were the animal figures carved on antlers and bones in Kesslerloch in Switzerland dated to?
The animal figures carved on antlers and bones in Kesslerloch in Switzerland date from about 10,000 bce.
When did Homo sapiens first appear in Switzerland?
Homo sapiens appeared in Switzerland toward the end of the Würm, about 12,000 bce.
What agricultural practices did Neolithic cultures establish in Switzerland around 5000 bce?
Neolithic cultures established corn growing and animal breeding in Switzerland around 5000 bce.
When did Bronze Age settlements begin to appear in Switzerland?
Bronze Age settlements began to appear in Switzerland from about 1800 bce.
What tribe controlled much of the area between the Jura and the Alps in Switzerland?
The Helvetii controlled much of the area between the Jura and the Alps in Switzerland.
What were the Celts in Switzerland known for during the Iron Age?
The Celts in Switzerland were noted for their metalwork, original ceramics, and superb jewelry crafted from gold.
What was the approximate population of Celtic villages in Switzerland according to Caesar?
The Celtic villages in Switzerland had about 400 inhabitants according to Caesar.
What event in 58 BCE led the Helvetii to attempt migration from Switzerland?
The Helvetii attempted to migrate from Switzerland to southwestern Gaul in 58 BCE due to pressures from Germanic tribes.
What three empires were the most famous and largest in Yemen prior to the arrival of Islam?
The Minaean, Sabaean, and Ḥimyarite empires were the most famous and largest in Yemen prior to the arrival of Islam.
What were the primary sources of prosperity for the city-states and empires in Yemen before Islam?

The primary sources of prosperity for the city-states and empires in Yemen before Islam were their control over frankincense and myrrh production and their exclusive access to luxury commodities from southern Asia and eastern Africa.
What time period did the ascendancy of the Minaean, Sabaean, and Ḥimyarite empires in Yemen roughly span?
The ascendancy of the Minaean, Sabaean, and Ḥimyarite empires in Yemen roughly spanned from 1200 bce to 525 ce.
What was the result of Yemen's inability to compete against imperial Rome?
Yemen went into economic decline and lost revenue, making it impossible to maintain its extensive cities and facilities.
What famous engineering marvel in Yemen failed to be maintained due to economic decline?
The Great Dam at Maʾrib, the heart of a monumental irrigation project, failed to be maintained due to economic decline.
Who was the last Ḥimyarite king of Yemen in the 6th century ce?
Dhū Nuwās was the last Ḥimyarite king of Yemen in the 6th century ce.
Who led the Aksumite campaign to invade Yemen in the 6th century ce?
Abraha led the Aksumite campaign to invade Yemen in the 6th century ce.
Which dynasty added Yemen to their domains after expelling the Aksumites?
The Sāsānian dynasty of Persia added Yemen to their domains after expelling the Aksumites.
What was the outcome of the Aksumite invasion of Yemen under Abraha?
The Aksumite invasion of Yemen under Abraha resulted in the overthrow of Dhū Nuwās and a massacre of Jews.
What was the Ḥimyarites' response to Aksumite rule in Yemen?
The Ḥimyarites grew resentful of the Aksumites and sought the support of the Sāsānian dynasty of Persia to expel them.
What was the outcome of the caliph sending representatives to Yemen to address rebellions?
The representatives would establish their own dynasty in Yemen.
What were two of Yemen's most famous mosques that are among the earliest examples of Islamic architecture?
The mosques in Janadiyyah and the Great Mosque in Sanaa were two of Yemen's most famous mosques that are among the earliest examples of Islamic architecture.
Who founded the city of Zabīd in Yemen in the 9th century?
Muḥammad ibn Ziyād founded the city of Zabīd in Yemen in the 9th century.
What Shiʿi Muslim sect was introduced to Yemen in the 9th century?
The Zaydī sect was introduced to Yemen in the 9th century.
Who was accepted as the last legitimate successor to the Prophet by the Zaydī sect in Yemen?
Zayd ibn ʿAlī was accepted as the last legitimate successor to the Prophet by the Zaydī sect in Yemen.
What was the impact of Zaydī Islam on Yemeni culture and civilization for the next 1,000 years?
Zaydī Islam left a lasting impact on Yemeni culture and civilization for the next 1,000 years.
What kind of rulers contested for control of Yemen during the same 1,000-year period?
Factional, dynastic, local, and imperial rulers contested for control of Yemen during the same 1,000-year period.
Which dynasties ruled Yemen during the 13th to 15th century?
The Rasulids ruled Yemen during the 13th to 15th century, firmly establishing Sunni Islam in southern and western Yemen.
What was the impact of the redirection of trade on cities in Yemen by the 18th century?
The redirection of trade caused cities such as Aden and Mocha in Yemen to shrink from populations in excess of 10,000 to villages of a few hundred.
What significant cultural practice became prominent in Myanmar by the 11th century?
Theravada Buddhist practice became prominent in Myanmar by the 11th century.
What was Myanmar's relationship with Indian cultural influences?
Myanmar retained important components of its local ways in synthesis with Indian culture.
When did Myanmar become a center of Theravada Buddhist practice?
Myanmar became the center of the Theravada Buddhist practice by the 11th century.
What discovery in 1969 revealed evidence of Paleolithic and Neolithic settlements in Myanmar?
Workers from the government’s Department of Archaeology discovered cave paintings and stone tools in the eastern part of Shan state in 1969.
What culture did the Paleolithic and Neolithic settlements in Myanmar bear similarities to?
The Paleolithic and Neolithic settlements in Myanmar bore similarities to the Hoabinhian culture.
What type of tools were crude shards and ring stones found in Myanmar used for?
Crude shards and ring stones found in Myanmar were attached to stonecutting tools to make them more suitable for digging.
What evidence confirms human habitation in Malaysia about 40,000 years ago?
Bone and artifact discoveries at the Niah Cave site confirm human habitation in Malaysia about 40,000 years ago.
When did Neolithic culture become established in Malaysia?
Neolithic culture was apparently well established in Malaysia by 2500 to 1500 bce.
What type of civilizations have been unearthed in Peninsular Malaysia?
Archaeologists have unearthed evidence of Stone Age and early Bronze Age civilizations in Peninsular Malaysia.
How long has Peninsular Malaysia been inhabited?
Peninsular Malaysia has been inhabited for at least 6,000 years.
What chronicles the evolution of stone tools in Malaysia?
The Niah Cave site chronicles the evolution of stone tools in Malaysia until some 1,300 years ago.
What cultural influences shaped the political and cultural patterns in Malaysia during the early historical period?
Indian concepts of religion, government, and the arts, including Hinduism and Mahayana Buddhism, shaped the political and cultural patterns in Malaysia.
When did small Malay kingdoms first appear in Malaysia?
Small Malay kingdoms appeared in Malaysia in the 2nd or 3rd century ce.
Who brought Indian concepts of religion, government, and the arts to Malaysia?
Indian traders and priests brought Indian concepts of religion, government, and the arts to Malaysia.
What was the result of the synthesis of Indian and indigenous ideas in Malaysia?
The synthesis of Indian and indigenous ideas in Malaysia led to the creation of new ethnic fusions and cultural patterns.
What Indianized empire based in Sumatra exerted loose control over Malaysia's maritime trading states between the 7th and 13th centuries?
Srivijaya exerted loose control over Malaysia's maritime trading states between the 7th and 13th centuries.
Which Southeast Asian empires claimed suzerainty in Malaysia at various times?
The Khmer empire, the Tai kingdom of Ayutthaya, and the Majapahit empire claimed suzerainty in Malaysia at various times.
What legacy did early cultural forces leave in Malaysia?
Early cultural forces left a living legacy in Malaysia, evident in political ideas, social structures, rituals, language, arts, and other traditions of Malay Muslims.
Who was the ancestor after whom the Sassanian Empire's ruling dynasty was named?
Sāsān was the ancestor after whom the Sassanian Empire's ruling dynasty was named.
Who led the Sassanian Empire in overthrowing the Parthians and establishing the empire?
Ardashīr I led the Sassanian Empire in overthrowing the Parthians and establishing the empire.
What was Ardashīr's title during his reign over the Sassanian Empire?
Ardashīr reigned as 'king of kings' over the Sassanian Empire.
Who destroyed the Sassanian Empire during the years 637–651?
The Arabs destroyed the Sassanian Empire during the years 637–651.
What was the state religion of the Sassanian Empire during its rule?
Zoroastrianism was the state religion of the Sassanian Empire during its rule.
What was the government structure of the Sassanian Empire?
The government of the Sassanian Empire was centralized, with provincial officials directly responsible to the throne.
What cultural developments occurred in the Sassanian Empire?
Iranian art experienced a general renaissance in the Sassanian Empire, with architecture often taking on grandiose proportions.
What was the impact of the Sassanian Empire on Iranian nationalism?
A revival of Iranian nationalism took place under Sasanian rule in the Sassanian Empire.
What was the fate of followers of other faiths in the Sassanian Empire?
Followers of other faiths suffered official persecution at various times in the Sassanian Empire.
When did Stockholm become the permanent capital of Sweden?
Stockholm became the permanent capital of Sweden in 1523.
When did Sweden's parliamentary democracy begin?
Sweden's parliamentary democracy began in 1917.
How long has Sweden existed as a sovereign state?
Sweden has a 1,000-year-long continuous history as a sovereign state.
When did Sweden last engage in military conflict?
Sweden has been at peace since 1814.
What foreign policy doctrine has Sweden followed since World War II?
Sweden has followed the doctrine of nonalignment in peace aiming at neutrality in war.
What role has Sweden chosen to play among the world's conflicting ideological and political systems?
Sweden has chosen to play a balancing role among the world's conflicting ideological and political systems.
What event led to the demise of the Rwandan kingship before the country became independent in 1962?
A grassroots Hutu-led upheaval led to the demise of the Rwandan kingship before the country became independent in 1962.
What significant event occurred in Rwanda in 1994?
Civil war and genocide occurred in Rwanda in 1994.
What characterized the years following the 1994 genocide in Rwanda?
Reconstruction and ethnic reconciliation characterized the years following the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.
What event in Rwanda that began in late 1959 led to the forced departure of 150,000 to 300,000 Tutsi?
The Hutu revolution in Rwanda that began in late 1959 led to the forced departure of 150,000 to 300,000 Tutsi.
What happened to many Tutsi in Rwanda after the end of the 1994 genocide?
Many Tutsi returned to Rwanda to reclaim their heritage after the end of the 1994 genocide.
What agricultural cultures developed in Angola from about 1000 to 500 bce?
Agricultural cultures developed in Angola from about 1000 to 500 bce, which by the first centuries ce were also working iron.
Which kingdoms occupied the territory of Angola by 1500?
Ndongo, Bailundu, Ciyaka, and Kwanhama were among the kingdoms that occupied the territory of Angola by 1500.
What was the significance of the Chokwe in northeastern Angola?
The Chokwe established an important cultural centre in the northeastern part of Angola.
What kingdom emerged in the 14th century in northern Angola?
The Kongo kingdom emerged in the 14th century in northern Angola.
When did Portuguese navigators first reach the Kongo kingdom in Angola?
Portuguese navigators reached the Kongo kingdom in Angola in 1483.
What was the name of the Kongo king who converted to Christianity and established the religion in Angola?
Mvemba a Nzinga, who took the Christian name Afonso I, established Christianity in Angola.
What led the Portuguese to seek new allies in Angola, particularly the Ndongo kingdom?
Disputes over control of trade, particularly regarding enslaved people from Kongo and its neighbours, led the Portuguese to seek new allies in Angola.
When did the Portuguese establish a colony at Luanda in Angola?
The Portuguese established a colony at Luanda in Angola in 1575.
What was Angola's major export during the Portuguese colonial period?
Enslaved people were Angola's major export during the Portuguese colonial period.
Who resisted Portuguese expansion in Angola after 1617?
Queen Nzinga Mbande of Ndongo and Matamba resisted Portuguese expansion in Angola after 1617.
What was the outcome of the civil wars in Kongo after 1665 in Angola?
The civil wars in Kongo after 1665 led to the enslavement of people in Angola.
When did Portuguese expansion in Angola largely come to an end?
Portuguese expansion in Angola was largely over by 1670.
What was the impact of the rise of the great Lunda empire after 1750 in Angola?
The rise of the great Lunda empire after 1750 led to conflicts that resulted in the enslavement of people in Angola.
What kingdom in Angola reached its height in the late 16th century?
The Ndongo kingdom in Angola reached its height in the late 16th century.
What kingdom replaced the Ndongo kingdom in Angola after its destruction?
The Kasanje kingdom replaced the Ndongo kingdom in Angola after its destruction.
What event led to the decline of the Kongo kingdom in Angola in the 17th century?
Civil wars led to the decline of the Kongo kingdom in Angola in the 17th century.
What kingdom in Angola was decentralized by the late 18th century?
The Loango kingdom in Angola was decentralized by the late 18th century.
Who destroyed the Ndongo kingdom in Angola in the 17th century?
The Portuguese destroyed the Ndongo kingdom in Angola in the 17th century.
When was the export of enslaved people banned in Angola?
The export of enslaved people was banned in Angola in 1836.
When was slavery legally abolished in the Portuguese empire, which included Angola?
Slavery was legally abolished in the Portuguese empire in 1875.
What products dominated exports from Angola from the 1850s onward?
Products hunted or collected by Africans, first ivory and wax and later wild rubber, dominated exports from Angola from the 1850s onward.
When did the trade in enslaved people effectively end in Angola?
The trade in enslaved people effectively ended in Angola in the early 1850s when the Brazilian market was closed.
What economic changes occurred in Angola during the industrial revolution?
Angola experienced a shift from local production to commodity exports of peanuts, honey, animal skins, ivory, and rubber in response to cheaper imported goods.
What were the consequences of Angola's increasing involvement in the international economy?
Angola's increasing wealth and involvement in the international economy led to many problems for both indigenous and colonial governments.
What empire was overthrown by the Chokwe in Angola in the 1880s?
The Lunda empire was overthrown by the Chokwe in Angola in the 1880s.
What factor contributed to the collapse of the Kasanje kingdom in Angola?
Illicit slave trading undermined the king’s central slave market and newly enriched commoners demanded a stronger voice in government, contributing to the collapse of the Kasanje kingdom in Angola.
When did the Portuguese begin constructing the Benguela Railway in Angola?
The Portuguese began constructing the Benguela Railway in Angola in 1902.
What was the intended purpose of the Benguela Railway in Angola?
The Benguela Railway was intended to serve the Katanga mines in the Belgian Congo in Angola.
When did the Portuguese begin settling small farmers in the Huíla highlands of Angola?
The Portuguese began settling small farmers in the Huíla highlands of Angola in the 1880s.
When did the Portuguese introduce systematic taxation of Africans in Angola?
The Portuguese introduced systematic taxation of Africans in Angola in 1906.
What type of missions were subsidized by the government in Angola from the 1870s?
French Roman Catholic missions were subsidized by the government in Angola from the 1870s.
Who held many positions in the colonial administration of Angola?
Angolan Creoles held many positions in the colonial administration of Angola.
What event in Lisbon in 1910 marked the beginning of modern Portuguese colonialism in Angola?
The proclamation of the Republic of Portugal in Lisbon in late 1910 marked the advent of modern Portuguese colonialism in Angola.
What was established in 1926 that further solidified Portuguese control over Angola?
The authoritarian New State (Estado Novo) was established in 1926, marking the advent of modern Portuguese colonialism in Angola.
What was the approximate number of Christians in Angola by 1940?
There were about a million Christians in Angola by 1940, some three-fourths of them Roman Catholics.
What policies were imposed on Angolan natives by the Portuguese authorities?
Angolan natives were taxed and subjected to forced labour and forced cultivation under Portuguese rule.
What economic changes occurred in Angola from 1910 to 1975?
Angola's economy was modernized and bound to Portugal's by protective tariffs, with lorries and fixed stores replacing trading caravans.
What major revolt occurred in northern Angola in 1961?
A major revolt rocked northern Angola in 1961 following the independence of the Belgian Congo.
What type of mining dominated the northeast of Angola from 1912?
Alluvial diamond mining dominated the northeast of Angola from 1912.
What followed the 1961 revolt in northern Angola?
A long guerrilla war followed the 1961 revolt in northern Angola.
What measures did the Portuguese take to contain the revolt in Angola after the attack on the prison in Luanda?
The Portuguese deployed large numbers of troops, set up strategic hamlets, and encouraged Portuguese peasants to immigrate to Angola.
What reforms did the Portuguese implement in Angola to improve relations with Africans?
The Portuguese abolished forced cultivation, forced labour, and stringent tests to gain assimilated status, and improved education, health, and social welfare services.
What was the impact of the reforms on the economy of Angola?
The economy entered into a period of sustained boom, marked by rapid industrialization and the growth of oil production, and the standard of living rose for both urban workers and rural producers.
Who led the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola from 1962?
Agostinho Neto led the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola from 1962.
What foreign support did the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola receive?
The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola received foreign support from the Soviet Union.
Who founded the National Front for the Liberation of Angola in 1957?
Holden Roberto founded the National Front for the Liberation of Angola in 1957.
What foreign aid did the National Front for the Liberation of Angola obtain?
The National Front for the Liberation of Angola obtained aid from the United States and China.
What movement did Jonas Savimbi establish in 1966 to fight for Angola's independence?
Jonas Savimbi established the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) in 1966.
Which country provided some aid to UNITA in its fight for Angola's independence?
China provided some aid to UNITA in its fight for Angola's independence.
What event in Portugal in April 1974 affected the guerrilla movements in Angola?
A military coup in Portugal overthrew that country’s dictatorship in April 1974, affecting the guerrilla movements in Angola.
What was the state of the three guerrilla movements in Angola by the early 1970s?
The three guerrilla movements in Angola had been almost entirely expelled from Angolan soil by the early 1970s.
When did Vietnam achieve independence from China?
Vietnam achieved independence from China in 938 ce.
What relationship did Vietnam maintain with China after gaining independence?
Vietnam maintained a tributary relationship with China, exchanging goods for Chinese philosophical, administrative, and literary influence.
Which empire did Vietnam conquer in 1471?
Vietnam conquered Champa in 1471.
What parts of the Khmer empire did Vietnam later conquer?
Vietnam later conquered parts of the Khmer empire, including the Mekong River delta.
When did Vietnam largely reach its present size?
Vietnam had largely reached its present size by 1757.
When was Soc Trang annexed by Vietnam?
Soc Trang was annexed by Vietnam in 1840.
What was the outcome of the Battle of Dien Bien Phu for Vietnam?
The Battle of Dien Bien Phu resulted in Vietnam's victory over the French in 1954.
What international agreement reaffirmed Vietnam's independence after the Battle of Dien Bien Phu?
The Geneva Accords reaffirmed Vietnam's independence after the Battle of Dien Bien Phu.
What two major conflicts contributed to Vietnam's national identity?
Vietnam's victory against the French at the Battle of Dien Bien Phu and its victory against the United States in the Vietnam War contributed to Vietnam's national identity.
What was the primary goal of North Vietnam during the Vietnam War?
North Vietnam sought unification under communism during the Vietnam War.
What economic policy hindered Vietnam's growth after reunification in 1976?
Vietnam's communist economic policy hindered growth after reunification in 1976.
What reforms, beginning in 1986, spurred Vietnam's economic recovery?
The market-oriented doi moi reforms, beginning in 1986, spurred Vietnam's economic recovery.
When did Vietnam throw off Chinese rule?
Vietnam threw off Chinese rule in 938 ce.
What products did Vietnam send to the Chinese emperor as a tribute-paying state?
Vietnam sent lacquerware, animal skins, ivory, and tropical products to the Chinese emperor.
What did Vietnam receive from China in return for its tribute?
Vietnam received scrolls on philosophy, administration, and literature from China.
Which social classes in Vietnam were most shaped by Sinic culture?
Sinic culture shaped the aristocracy and mandarinal families in Vietnam more than the peasantry.
What aspects of culture did the peasantry in Vietnam preserve despite Sinic influence?
The peasantry in Vietnam preserved distinctive customs, beliefs, vocabulary, lifeways, and gender relations.
How did Vietnam's kings model themselves in their rule?
Vietnam's kings modeled themselves on Chinese emperors, exacting tribute from ethnic minorities on the periphery of the Vietnamese state.
What title did Vietnam's kings use when not addressing the Chinese court?
Vietnam's kings called themselves emperors when not addressing the Chinese court.
What was the extent of the Vietnamese state's capacity to rule?
The Vietnamese state's capacity to rule diminished with distance from the capital.
What pattern of cultural adaptation did Vietnam exhibit historically?
Vietnam has a long history of affiliating with a dominant civilization and adapting that civilization's ideas, institutions, and technology to Vietnamese purposes.
How did descendants of mandarins in Vietnam respond to the challenge of the West?
Descendants of mandarins in Vietnam responded to the challenge of the West by rejecting tradition and becoming communists to combat colonialism.
What has been the driving force behind the Vietnam Communist Party’s actions since the 1980s?
Strategic absorption and adaptation have been the driving force behind the Vietnam Communist Party’s embrace of economic liberalization and integration into the world economy since the 1980s.
What two states emerged in Vietnam after the partitioning in 1954?
The Democratic Republic of Vietnam and the Republic of Vietnam emerged in Vietnam after the partitioning in 1954.
When was Vietnam reunified?
Vietnam was reunified in April 1975.
What political entity was established in Vietnam in July 1976?
The Socialist Republic of Vietnam was established in Vietnam in July 1976.
What ancient artifacts have been discovered near Dakar in Senegal?
Paleolithic and Neolithic axes and arrows have been discovered near Dakar in Senegal.
What historical structures in central Senegal were designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2006?
The stone circles in central Senegal were designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2006.
Which Berber group established a Muslim ribāṭ in Senegal around 1040?
The Zenaga Berbers established a Muslim ribāṭ in Senegal around 1040.
Who founded the Jolof kingdom in Senegal between 1150 and 1350?
Njajan Njay founded the Jolof kingdom in Senegal between 1150 and 1350.
What Wolof states emerged from the Jolof kingdom in Senegal in the 16th century?
The Wolof states of Walo, Kajor, Baol, Sine, and Salum emerged from the Jolof kingdom in Senegal in the 16th century.
Who established a theocratic confederacy in Fouta, Senegal after 1776?
Tukulor Muslims established a theocratic confederacy in Fouta, Senegal after 1776.
Which European powers established trading factories in Senegal in the 15th and 17th centuries?
Portuguese, Dutch, and French powers established trading factories in Senegal in the 15th and 17th centuries.
When did France take over Gorée from the Dutch in Senegal?
France took over Gorée from the Dutch in 1677.
What year did the Second Republic outlaw slavery on French soil in Senegal?
The Second Republic outlawed slavery on French soil in 1848.
Who was appointed governor of Senegal by Napoleon III in 1854?
Commandant Louis-Léon-César Faidherbe was appointed governor of Senegal by Napoleon III in 1854.
In what year were Saint-Louis and Gorée returned to France after British occupation in Senegal?
Saint-Louis and Gorée were returned to France in 1816 after British occupation.
Who conquered the Bambara kingdom of Kaarta and the states of Segu and Macina during the French period in Senegal?
Al-Ḥājj ʿUmar Tal, a Tukulor, conquered the Bambara kingdom of Kaarta and the states of Segu and Macina during the French period in Senegal.
What was the outcome of the military stalemate between the French and al-Ḥājj ʿUmar Tal's forces in Senegal after 1857?
A truce of coexistence was established between the French and al-Ḥājj ʿUmar Tal's forces in Senegal after 1857.
When did the French government approve a large program of railway construction in Senegal?
The French government approved a large program of railway construction in Senegal in 1879.
What was the economic benefit of peanut cultivation and export for the colonists in Senegal during the French period?
Peanut cultivation and export reaped great economic benefits for the colonists in Senegal during the French period.
Who was unable to control his home territory of Fouta in Senegal due to French occupation?
Al-Ḥājj ʿUmar Tal was unable to control his home territory of Fouta in Senegal due to French occupation.
What privileges did Diagne obtain for Senegal's urban minority during World War I?
Diagne obtained confirmation of full French citizenship rights for Senegal's urban minority during World War I.
When were French citizenship rights lost for Senegal's urban minority during World War II?
French citizenship rights were lost for Senegal's urban minority between 1940 and 1942 during World War II.
Who were the two socialist deputies elected in Senegal in 1946?
Lamine Guèye and Léopold Senghor were the two socialist deputies elected in Senegal in 1946.
What was the initial focus of Lamine Guèye and Léopold Senghor after their election in Senegal?
Lamine Guèye and Léopold Senghor initially concentrated on restoring the original French citizenship rights in Senegal.
When were French citizenship rights restored in Senegal after World War II?
French citizenship rights were restored in Senegal under the Fourth Republic between 1947 and 1958.
What event in 1947-48 revealed strong internal tensions in Senegal?
A sustained railway strike in 1947-48 revealed strong internal tensions in Senegal.
Who did Senghor build a political partnership with in Senegal?
Senghor built a strong political position on partnership with the leaders of the Mourides and other socially conservative Muslim orders.
What decision did the Senegalese electorate make in 1958 regarding the French Community?
The Senegalese electorate accepted Senghor's advice to vote in favour of membership in Charles de Gaulle’s proposed French Community.
When did Senegal claim and receive independence?
Senegal claimed and received independence in 1960, initially within the short-lived Mali Federation.
What type of pottery did Fiji's first settlers bring with them when they arrived from Melanesia?
Fiji's first settlers brought Lapita ware pottery with them when they arrived from Melanesia.
What skills were associated with the Lapita culture in Fiji?
The Lapita culture in Fiji was associated with well-developed skills in navigation and canoe building.
What evolved in Tonga and Samoa after the Lapita culture spread there from Fiji?
The first distinctively Polynesian cultures evolved in Tonga and Samoa after the Lapita culture spread there from Fiji.
How were leaders chosen in traditional Fijian society?
Leaders in traditional Fijian society were chosen according to rank, which was based on descent as well as personal achievement.
Who were the first Europeans to sight the Fiji islands?
Dutch explorer Abel Janzsoon Tasman and Capt. James Cook were the first Europeans to sight the Fiji islands.
What was the basis of Fijian society's organization?
Fijian society was organized through residence and kinship, including mataqali or clans and residential subclans.
Who traveled through Fiji in his open longboat after the mutiny on the HMS Bounty in 1789?
William Bligh traveled through Fiji in his open longboat after the mutiny on the HMS Bounty in 1789.
What significant event occurred in Fiji in 1854?
Cakobau became a Christian in 1854, bringing most Fijians under the influence of Methodist missionaries.
What economic factor attracted European settlers to Fiji in the 1860s?
A boom in cotton prices caused by the American Civil War attracted European settlers to Fiji in the 1860s.
What problems arose in Fiji due to the introduction of labourers from other Pacific islands?
The introduction of labourers from other Pacific islands led to violent confrontations and exacerbated the instability of Fijian society.
What prevented Fijian chiefs from imposing rule over the whole group?
Disputes over land and political power, along with the introduction of labourers from other Pacific islands, prevented Fijian chiefs from imposing rule over the whole group.
When did Fiji become a British crown colony?
Fiji became a British crown colony on October 10, 1874.
What was the basis of the system of indirect rule implemented by Sir Arthur Gordon in Fiji?
Sir Arthur Gordon implemented a system of indirect rule in Fiji based on the traditional political structure.
How were the Fijians taxed under Sir Arthur Gordon's policies?
The Fijians were taxed in agricultural produce, not cash, under Sir Arthur Gordon's policies.
What company was involved in establishing sugar plantations and processing mills in Fiji?
The Colonial Sugar Refining Company was involved in establishing sugar plantations and processing mills in Fiji.
When did the indenture system terminate in Fiji?
The indenture system terminated in Fiji in 1920.
What role did Fijians play in the Solomon Islands campaign during World War II?
Fijians served as scouts in the campaign for the Solomon Islands during World War II.
What was the composition of the army in Fiji after the war?
The army in Fiji remained exclusively Fijian except for a handful of European officers after the war.
Why did Indians in Fiji refuse to serve in the army?
Indians in Fiji refused to serve in the army due to unequal treatment, including lesser wages and conditions than Europeans.
What was the outcome of the colonial authorities restructuring the Fijian administration after the war?
The colonial authorities' restructuring of the Fijian administration reinforced chiefly leadership and consolidated the conservatism of Fijian society.
What event in 1874 guaranteed Fijian land rights?
The Deed of Cession in 1874 guaranteed Fijian land rights.
What was the significance of the 1966 constitution in Fiji?
The 1966 constitution in Fiji represented a compromise between parliamentary democracy and ethnic divisions within the country.
Who was previously excluded from the franchise in Fiji before the 1966 constitution?
Fijians were previously excluded from the franchise in Fiji before the 1966 constitution.
What power was given to Fijian chiefs in the 1966 constitution?
Fijian chiefs were given an effective veto in all important matters affecting the status of Fijians and in changes to the constitution itself.
What electoral system was implemented in Fiji in the 1930s?
Fiji implemented an electoral system using a common roll of voters in the 1930s.
How were voters classified in Fiji's electoral system?
Voters in Fiji were classified according to ethnicity: Fijian, Indian, or General.
What type of rolls were used to elect legislative representatives in Fiji?
Legislative representatives in Fiji were elected from Indian and Fijian rolls and from cross-voting rolls.
What was the effect of the constitution on power distribution in Fiji?
The constitution gave power to Fijian politicians in Fiji so long as they remained in partnership with the General voters and the Fijian vote remained unified.
When did Fiji achieve independence?
Fiji achieved independence on October 10, 1970.
Which party governed Fiji from 1970 to 1987?
The Alliance Party governed Fiji from 1970 to 1987.
What was the outcome of the 1987 elections in Fiji?
The Indian-dominated National Federation Party and the Labour Party formed a successful coalition in the 1987 elections in Fiji.
Who led the Labour Party in Fiji during the 1987 elections?
Timoci Bavadra led the Labour Party in Fiji during the 1987 elections.
What event occurred in Fiji after only a few weeks of the new government with a majority of Indian members in the legislature?
Lieut. Col. Sitiveni Rabuka led a coup d’état in Fiji, arresting and deposing the new government’s leaders.
What action did the governor-general take in Fiji after the first coup?
The governor-general declared a state of emergency and assumed control of the government in Fiji.
What did Rabuka do in Fiji in September after being dissatisfied with the progress of negotiations?
Rabuka led a second coup in Fiji and reimposed military rule.
What significant changes did Rabuka make to Fiji's government and constitution in 1987?
Rabuka declared Fiji a republic and revoked the 1970 constitution in 1987.
What event occurred in Fiji on July 25, 1990?
A new constitution was promulgated in Fiji on July 25, 1990.
Who became prime minister of Fiji in 1992?
Rabuka became prime minister of Fiji in 1992.
When was a Constitutional Review Commission established in Fiji?
A Constitutional Review Commission was established in Fiji in 1994.
When was Fiji readmitted to the Commonwealth?
Fiji was readmitted to the Commonwealth in 1997.
When did the proposed constitutional changes take effect in Fiji?
The proposed constitutional changes took effect in Fiji in 1998.
Who became Fiji’s first prime minister of Indian ancestry in May 1999?
Mahendra Chaudhry became Fiji’s first prime minister of Indian ancestry in May 1999.
What event occurred on May 19, 2000, in Fiji?
George Speight led a group that took Mahendra Chaudhry and his government hostage and deposed them on May 19, 2000.
Who backed George Speight in the 2000 coup in Fiji?
Rebel members of the army’s counterrevolutionary warfare unit backed George Speight in the 2000 coup in Fiji.
What was the outcome of the no-confidence motion against Mahendra Chaudhry in August 1999 in Fiji?
Mahendra Chaudhry easily survived the no-confidence motion by nationalist legislators in August 1999 in Fiji.
Who declared a state of emergency in Fiji after the coup?
Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara declared a state of emergency in Fiji after the coup.
Who appointed Ratu Josefa Iloilo as interim president of Fiji?
The Bose Levu Vakaturaga appointed Ratu Josefa Iloilo as interim president of Fiji.
What event occurred in Fiji after 56 days of captivity in the parliamentary complex?
The rebels released the hostages after 56 days of captivity in the parliamentary complex in Fiji.
Who took over governing powers of Fiji after declaring a state of emergency?
Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara took over governing powers of Fiji after declaring a state of emergency.
Who appointed a Fijian-dominated interim civilian administration to lead Fiji back to democracy?
The military commander appointed a Fijian-dominated interim civilian administration to lead Fiji back to democracy.
What was the outcome of Fiji's High Court ruling in November regarding the military-installed government?
Fiji's High Court declared the military-installed government illegitimate and decreed that the parliament ousted in May remained the country's governing authority.
Who was confirmed as prime minister of Fiji in September 2001?
Laisenia Qarase of the nationalist Fiji United Party was confirmed as prime minister in September 2001.
What significant event occurred in Fiji's sugar industry in 2002?
Plans were introduced for the privatization of Fiji's sugar industry in 2002, which was in danger of collapse after the withdrawal of subsidies from the European Union.
Who won the May 2006 elections in Fiji and began a second term?
Qarase's party narrowly won the May 2006 elections, and he began his second term.
Who seized power in Fiji in December 2006?
Voreque Bainimarama seized power in Fiji in December 2006.
Who was named interim prime minister of Fiji in January 2007?
Bainimarama was named interim prime minister of Fiji in January 2007.
What event occurred in Fiji in April 2009?
The Fiji Court of Appeal ruled that the Bainimarama government had been put in place illegally after the 2006 coup.
Who abrogated the 1997 constitution of Fiji?
President Iloilo abrogated the 1997 constitution of Fiji.
Who was appointed as prime minister of Fiji's new interim government in 2009?
Bainimarama was appointed as prime minister of Fiji's new interim government in 2009.
Who was formally installed as president of Fiji in November 2009?
Epeli Nailatikau was formally installed as president of Fiji in November 2009.
What body did Bainimarama abolish in March 2012 in Fiji?
Bainimarama abolished the Bose Levu Vakaturaga in Fiji in March 2012.
What was Bainimarama's plan for Fiji announced in March 2012?
Bainimarama announced a plan to create a new constitution for Fiji by the following year.
What was the Bainimarama regime's response to the new constitution draft in late 2012 in Fiji?
The Bainimarama regime rejected the new constitution draft in Fiji in late 2012.
What date did Fiji's new constitution come into effect?
Fiji's new constitution came into effect on September 7, 2013.
What was a major criticism of Fiji's 2013 constitution?
Fiji's 2013 constitution was criticized for granting legal immunity to coup participants and curtailing certain rights.
What type of legislature was created under Fiji's 2013 constitution?
Fiji's 2013 constitution created a 50-member popularly elected legislature.
What provision was emphasized by Bainimarama in Fiji's 2013 constitution?
Bainimarama emphasized Fiji's 2013 constitution's provision of an independent judiciary.
What event occurred in Fiji on September 17, 2014?
Parliamentary elections took place in Fiji on September 17, 2014.
Which party won the parliamentary elections in Fiji in 2014?
Bainimarama’s FijiFirst party won the parliamentary elections in Fiji in 2014.
When did Bainimarama resign as head of the military in Fiji?
Bainimarama resigned as head of the military in Fiji in March 2014.
What position did Bainimarama assume in Fiji following the 2014 elections?
Bainimarama was sworn in as prime minister as a civilian in Fiji following the 2014 elections.
What economic activities did the people of Mozambique engage in before the arrival of Portuguese settlers?
The people of Mozambique developed complex communities based on agriculture, cattle raising, mining, crafts, and trade before the arrival of Portuguese settlers.
When did archaeological and historical research begin to reintegrate Mozambique's past with that of East, Central, and Southern Africa?
Archaeological and historical research began to reintegrate Mozambique's past with that of East, Central, and Southern Africa since 1950.
In which century did the first small groups of Portuguese settlers arrive in Mozambique?
The first small groups of Portuguese settlers arrived in Mozambique in the 16th century.
What social unit emerged in south-central Mozambique toward the end of the 1st millennium CE?
Nyika groups of households emerged in south-central Mozambique toward the end of the 1st millennium CE as social units under the authority of a chief and chiefly household.
What architectural feature characterized the earliest settlements like Mapungubwe in Mozambique?
