Stone enclosures, or zimbabwes, characterized the earliest settlements like Mapungubwe in Mozambique.
What empire gained hegemony over the Greek colonies in Ukraine?
The Roman Empire gained hegemony over the Greek colonies in Ukraine.
Which group displaced the Sarmatians in Ukraine around 200 ce?
The Goths displaced the Sarmatians in Ukraine around 200 ce.
Who broke the power of the Goths in Ukraine around 375?
The Huns broke the power of the Goths in Ukraine around 375.
Which groups succeeded the Huns in Ukraine during the 5th–6th centuries?
The Bulgars and Avars succeeded the Huns in Ukraine during the 5th–6th centuries.
Who dominated much of southern Ukraine in the 10th and 11th centuries?
The Pechenegs dominated much of southern Ukraine in the 10th and 11th centuries.
What group of merchant-warriors controlled trade along the Dnieper route in Ukraine during the formation of the Kyivan state?
Varangian merchant-warriors controlled trade along the Dnieper route in Ukraine during the formation of the Kyivan state.
What name was given to the Kyivan region and later to the entire territory ruled by the Kyivan dynasty in Ukraine?
Rus was the name given to the Kyivan region and later to the entire territory ruled by the Kyivan dynasty in Ukraine.
What process was connected to the formation of the Kyivan state in Ukraine in the mid-9th century?
Developments in international trade and the new prominence of the Dnieper route from the Baltic to Byzantium were connected to the formation of the Kyivan state in Ukraine.
What religion did Volodymyr the Great adopt for Ukraine in 988?
Volodymyr the Great adopted Christianity as the religion of Ukraine in 988.
Who was appointed by the patriarch of Constantinople to head the church hierarchy in Ukraine since 1037?
The metropolitan of Kyiv was appointed by the patriarch of Constantinople to head the church hierarchy in Ukraine since 1037.
What cultural developments were introduced to Ukraine with the adoption of Christianity?
The adoption of Christianity introduced new forms of architecture, art, music, a written language, and the beginnings of a literary culture to Ukraine.
What event in 1240 marked a significant decline in Kyiv's political power in Ukraine?
The Mongol-Tatar sack of Kyiv in 1240 marked a significant decline in Kyiv's political power in Ukraine.
Who briefly stemmed Kyiv's decline in the 12th century in Ukraine?
Volodymyr II Monomakh briefly stemmed Kyiv's decline in the 12th century in Ukraine.
What began in the 1220s and contributed to Kyiv's decline in Ukraine?
The Mongol-Tatar invasions that began in the 1220s contributed to Kyiv's decline in Ukraine.
What significant event occurred in Ukraine in 1253 during Danylo's reign?
Danylo accepted the royal crown from Pope Innocent IV and recognized him as head of the church in Ukraine in 1253.
What major invasion affected Ukraine between 1240 and 1241?
The Mongol invasion of 1240–41 affected Ukraine.
When did the Roman dynasty in Ukraine come to an end?
Roman's dynasty in Ukraine came to an end in 1340.
What were some of the challenges Ukraine faced during Danylo's reign?
Danylo's reign in Ukraine witnessed the rise of boyar-magnate unrest, debilitating dynastic involvements with Poland and Hungary, and the Mongol invasion.
What was the impact of the Mongol invasion on Ukraine's Galicia-Volhynia region?
The Mongol invasion marked the onset of Galicia-Volhynia's decline in Ukraine, which continued until the extinction of Roman's dynasty in 1340.
When were the Marshall Islands first settled by Micronesians?
The Marshall Islands were settled initially around the beginning of the Christian era by Micronesians who may have been influenced by early Polynesian (Lapita) culture.
Who first sighted the Marshall Islands in 1529?
The Spanish navigator Álvaro Saavedra sighted the Marshall Islands in 1529.
Who partially explored the Marshall Islands in 1788?
British naval captains John Marshall and Thomas Gilbert partially explored the Marshall Islands in 1788.
Who led Russian expeditions to map the Marshall Islands in 1803?
Adam Johann Krusenstern led Russian expeditions to map the Marshall Islands in 1803.
When did Germany establish a protectorate over the Marshall Islands?
Germany established a protectorate over the Marshall Islands in 1886.
Who seized the Marshall Islands in 1914?
Japan seized the Marshall Islands in 1914.
What type of mandate did Japan administer the Marshall Islands under after 1919?
Japan administered the Marshall Islands as a League of Nations mandate after 1919.
What event led to the United States occupying the Marshall Islands during World War II?
Heavy fighting at Kwajalein and Enewetak led to the United States occupying the Marshall Islands during World War II.
When were the Marshall Islands made part of the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands under United States jurisdiction?
The Marshall Islands were made part of the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands under United States jurisdiction in 1947.
When did the Marshall Islands vote to separate from the other entities of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands?
The Marshall Islands voted to separate from the other entities of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands in 1978.
What document did voters in the Marshall Islands approve in 1979?
Voters in the Marshall Islands approved a constitution in 1979.
What agreement did the government of the Marshall Islands sign with the United States in 1982?
The government of the Marshall Islands signed the Compact of Free Association with the United States in 1982.
What agreement did the United States and the Marshall Islands approve in 1983?

The United States and the Marshall Islands approved an agreement in 1983 that required the United States to remain responsible for defense and external security and provide financial assistance for the republic.
What did the United States agree to set up for the people of the four atolls affected by nuclear tests in the Marshall Islands?
The United States agreed to set up a separate fund for the people of the four atolls and established an open-ended fund to cover personal injury claims among the islanders.
What tribunal did the United States and the Marshall Islands agree to set up in 1983?
The United States and the Marshall Islands agreed to set up a joint U.S.-Marshallese claims tribunal.
What fund did the United States agree to set up to improve living conditions on Ebeye island in the Marshall Islands?
The United States agreed to set up a fund to improve living conditions on Ebeye island, where all Micronesians working on the Kwajalein missile range and base resided.
Who was the great chief that arrived in central Vanuatu around 1200 and developed a highly stratified society?
Roy Mata developed a highly stratified society in central Vanuatu around 1200.
What culture settled the northern islands of Vanuatu by 1300 bce?
The Lapita culture settled the northern islands of Vanuatu by 1300 bce.
What ritual was performed to mark the death of Roy Mata in Vanuatu?
The death of Roy Mata was marked by an elaborate ritual that included the burying alive of one man and one woman from each of the clans under his influence.
Who was the first European explorer to make contact with Vanuatu in 1606?
Pedro Fernández de Quirós was the first European explorer to make contact with Vanuatu in 1606.
Who mapped the island group of Vanuatu and named it the New Hebrides in 1774?
James Cook mapped the island group of Vanuatu and named it the New Hebrides in 1774.
What significant cultural change occurred in Vanuatu after the 1860s?

The return of thousands of ni-Vanuatu men and women who had been indentured to work on plantations in Fiji, New Caledonia, and Queensland, Australia, led to significant cultural change in Vanuatu after the 1860s.
What new forms of political influence did returning ni-Vanuatu establish in Vanuatu after the 1860s?
Returning ni-Vanuatu established new forms of political influence within the network of Protestant missions in Vanuatu after the 1860s.
What administrative arrangement was established in Vanuatu in 1906?
The Anglo-French condominium was established in Vanuatu in 1906, under which resident commissioners jointly ruled the indigenous people.
What was the Joint Naval Commission established in Vanuatu in 1887?
The Joint Naval Commission was established in Vanuatu in 1887 to protect the interests of British missionaries and French planters.
What significant event occurred in Vanuatu during World War II?
Vanuatu became a major Allied base during World War II, inspiring the transformation of the Jon Frum cargo cult into an anti-European political movement.
What was the outcome of the 1977 conference in Paris regarding Vanuatu's independence?
The 1977 conference in Paris resulted in an agreement on independence for Vanuatu.
When did Vanuatu gain independence and what was its new name?
Vanuatu gained independence on July 30, 1980, as the Republic of Vanuatu.
Who led the unsuccessful attempt to establish the independence of Espiritu Santo from Vanuatu in 1980?
Jimmy Stevens, the Na-Griamel Party leader, led the unsuccessful attempt to establish the independence of Espiritu Santo from Vanuatu in 1980.
What defense pact did Vanuatu enter into in August 1980?
Vanuatu entered into a defense pact with Papua New Guinea in August 1980 to replace the British and French forces.
What islands did Vanuatu claim in 1982 to expand its exclusive economic zone?
Vanuatu claimed the uninhabited islands of Matthew and Hunter in 1982 to expand its exclusive economic zone.
Who headed the Vanua’aku Pati party that formed the first parliamentary majority in Vanuatu?
Father Walter Lini headed the Vanua’aku Pati party that formed the first parliamentary majority in Vanuatu.
Who succeeded Lini as party leader and prime minister of Vanuatu in 1991?
Donald Kalpokas succeeded Lini as party leader and prime minister of Vanuatu in 1991.
Who formed the National United Party in Vanuatu for the December 1991 general election?
Lini and his supporters formed the National United Party in Vanuatu for the December 1991 general election.
Who was the francophone prime minister of Vanuatu who retained the post through a series of coalition governments until the 1995 general election?
Maxime Carlot Korman was the francophone prime minister of Vanuatu who retained the post through a series of coalition governments until the 1995 general election.
How many changes of prime minister occurred in Vanuatu during the six years of unstable parliamentary coalitions following the 1995 general election?
Six changes of prime minister occurred in Vanuatu during the six years of unstable parliamentary coalitions following the 1995 general election.
Who were the former premiers that served additional terms during the six years of unstable parliamentary coalitions in Vanuatu?
Carlot Korman and Kalpokas were the former premiers that served additional terms during the six years of unstable parliamentary coalitions in Vanuatu.
Who served two brief terms as prime minister of Vanuatu during the six years of unstable parliamentary coalitions?
Rialuth Serge Vohor of the UMP served two brief terms as prime minister of Vanuatu during the six years of unstable parliamentary coalitions.
What were the charges that led to the collapse of several administrations in Vanuatu, including those headed by Carlot Korman and Barak Sope?
Several administrations in Vanuatu, including those headed by Carlot Korman and Barak Sope, came apart amid charges of official corruption and criminal activity.
Who first fully examined the Paleolithic Period in Palestine?
Dorothy Garrod first fully examined the Paleolithic Period in Palestine in her excavations of caves on the slopes of Mount Carmel in 1929–34.
What culture is best represented in the Mesolithic Period in Palestine?
The Natufian culture is best represented in the Mesolithic Period in Palestine, known from excavations at ʿAin Mallāha and Jericho.
What evidence suggests the Natufians in Palestine may have experimented in agriculture?
The artistic care the Natufians in Palestine lavished on the carving of the hafts of their sickles and the provision of utensils for grinding grain suggests they may have experimented in agriculture.
What significant developments occurred in Palestine during the Neolithic Period?
Palestine saw the domestication of animals, cultivation of crops, production of pottery, and building of towns during the Neolithic Period.
When was the town of Jericho established in Palestine?
Jericho was established in Palestine by 7000 bce.
What transition occurred in Palestine during the 5th–4th millennium bce?
The transition from the Stone Age to the Copper Age took place in Palestine during the 5th–4th millennium bce.
What period is also known as the Copper Age in Palestine?
The Aeneolithic or Chalcolithic Period is also known as the Copper Age in Palestine.
What German Egyptologist's work is referenced for interpreting Egyptian dates in Palestine?
Rolf Krauss's Sothis- und Monddaten is referenced for interpreting Egyptian dates in Palestine.
What Egyptian dynasty was contemporaneous with Early Bronze II in Palestine?
The 1st dynasty of Egypt was contemporaneous with Early Bronze II in Palestine, around 2925 bce.
Which sites in Palestine provided evidence of the early phases of the Early Bronze Age?
Megiddo, Jericho, Tall al-Farʿah, Tel Beit Sheʾan, Khirbat al-Karak, and Ai provided evidence of the early phases of the Early Bronze Age in Palestine.
When were the towns of southern Palestine, such as Tel Lakhish, established?
The towns of southern Palestine, such as Tel Lakhish, were established in Early Bronze III.
Did Palestine's towns unify under a single leadership during the Early Bronze Age?
Palestine's towns did not unify under a single leadership during the Early Bronze Age.
What level of political control did Egypt exercise over Palestine's towns during the Early Bronze Age?
Egypt exercised loose political control over Palestine's towns during the Early Bronze Age.
When did the urban civilization in Palestine cease to exist?
The urban civilization in Palestine ceased to exist by about the 23rd century BCE.
What empire's creation in Mesopotamia may be related to events in Palestine during the Early Bronze Age?
The Akkadian empire's creation under Sargon of Akkad and his grandson Naram-Sin may be related to events in Palestine during the Early Bronze Age.
What event in Egypt is associated with the incursion of nomads from the east into Palestine during the Early Bronze Age?
The invasions of Egypt by people from Asia that brought the Old Kingdom to an end is associated with the incursion of nomads from the east into Palestine during the Early Bronze Age.
What is the probable initial date for the incursion of nomads from the east into Palestine during the Early Bronze Age?
The probable initial date for the incursion of nomads from the east into Palestine during the Early Bronze Age is the 23rd–22nd century bce.
What period in Palestine introduced the Canaanite culture as found by the Israelites on their entry into the region?
The Middle Bronze Age introduced the Canaanite culture as found by the Israelites on their entry into Palestine.
What time frame is associated with the Middle Bronze Age in Palestine?
The Middle Bronze Age in Palestine occurred from approximately 2000 to 1550 bce.
What types of archaeological evidence are associated with the Middle Bronze Age in Palestine?
The Middle Bronze Age in Palestine is characterized by new types of pottery, weapons, and burial practices.
What type of civilization was established in Palestine during the Middle Bronze Age?
An urban civilization based on agriculture was established in Palestine during the Middle Bronze Age.
What Egyptian dynasty showed significant interest and influence in Palestine from c. 1939–c. 1760 bce?
The Egyptian 12th dynasty showed significant interest and influence in Palestine from c. 1939–c. 1760 bce.
Which literary work details a hero’s exile in the Palestine region during the Middle Bronze Age?
The Story of Sinuhe details a hero’s exile in the Palestine region during the Middle Bronze Age.
When did the Israelites move into Palestine and encounter the culture introduced during the Middle Bronze Age?
The Israelites moved into Palestine in the 14th and 13th centuries bce and encountered the culture introduced during the Middle Bronze Age.
What technological innovation in pottery production first appeared in Palestine during the Middle Bronze Age?
The clay was turned entirely on a fast wheel for the first time in Palestine during the Middle Bronze Age.
What type of fortification was introduced to Palestine during the Middle Bronze Age?
Plaster-faced ramparts were introduced to Palestine during the Middle Bronze Age.
What group established a military aristocracy in Palestine during the Middle Bronze Age?
The Habiru established a military aristocracy in Palestine during the Middle Bronze Age.
What cultural elements did the Habiru bring to the towns in Palestine?
The Habiru brought new defenses, new prosperity, and many Egyptian cultural elements to the towns in Palestine.
What event occurred in Palestine at the end of the Middle Bronze Age around 1550?
The Egyptians expelled the Hyksos into Palestine at the end of the Middle Bronze Age around 1550.
Which cities were destroyed in Palestine following the Egyptians' expulsion of the Hyksos?
Megiddo, Jericho, and Kiriath-sepher were destroyed in Palestine following the Egyptians' expulsion of the Hyksos.
Who replaced the weak rule of the last pharaohs of the 18th dynasty in Palestine around 1292 BCE?
Seti I and Ramses II of the 19th dynasty replaced the weak rule of the last pharaohs of the 18th dynasty in Palestine around 1292 BCE.
What weakened the Canaanite vassal princes of Palestine?
The exactions of foreign bureaucrats and internal decay weakened the Canaanite vassal princes of Palestine.
What did archaeological evidence suggest about the Israelite settlement in Palestine?
Archaeological evidence suggests that the Israelite settlement in Palestine was much more complex and disconnected than the biblical accounts indicate.
What Egyptian dynasty's weak kings preceded the period of anarchy in Palestine?
The 19th dynasty's weak kings preceded the period of anarchy in Palestine.
Which Egyptian ruler achieved ephemeral victories in Palestine during the early 12th century?
Ramses III achieved ephemeral victories in Palestine during the early 12th century.
What has been the major source of historical information about Palestine for some periods?
Biblical narrative has been the major source of historical information about Palestine for some periods.
What has augmented the biblical narrative of Palestine's history?
Modern archaeological excavations and outside written sources have augmented the biblical narrative of Palestine's history.
What has often been disputed regarding the biblical narrative of Palestine's history?
The validity of the biblical narrative of Palestine's history has often been disputed.
What dynasty ruled Iran from 1501 to 1736?
The Safavid dynasty ruled Iran from 1501 to 1736.
What was the original religious orientation of the Ṣafavī order in Iran?
The Ṣafavī order was originally Sunni in Iran, following the jurisprudence of the Shāfiʿī school.
What event in the 13th century drastically reconfigured the Islamic world in Iran?
The Mongol invasions that began in the 13th century drastically reconfigured the Islamic world in Iran.
What was the impact of the Mongol invasions on the Abbasid empire in Iran?
The Mongol invasions brought about the end of the Abbasid empire in Iran.
Who was enthroned as shah of Iran in July 1501?
Ismāʿīl I was enthroned as shah of Iran in July 1501.
Who was the ruler of Iran from 1524 to 1576?
Shah Ṭahmāsp I ruled Iran from 1524 to 1576.
Who became the ruler of Iran in 1588?
ʿAbbās I became the ruler of Iran in 1588.
What major military reform did ʿAbbās I implement in Iran?
ʿAbbās I implemented a major army reform in Iran, reducing the strength of the Kizilbash and expanding the use of firearms.
What military units did Shah ʿAbbās form in Iran?
Shah ʿAbbās formed the ghulām s, tofangchī s, and topchī s in Iran.
Which power did Shah ʿAbbās defeat in 1603 to reclaim territory in Iran?
Shah ʿAbbās defeated the Turks in 1603 to reclaim territory in Iran.
What significant city did Shah ʿAbbās capture in his military campaigns in Iran?
Shah ʿAbbās captured Baghdad in his military campaigns in Iran.
Who did Shah ʿAbbās expel from the island of Hormuz in Iran?
Shah ʿAbbās expelled the Portuguese traders from the island of Hormuz in Iran.
What was the result of Shah ʿAbbās's reign for Iran's status?
Shah ʿAbbās's reign raised Iran to the status of a great power.
Who moved the capital of Iran to Eṣfahān and made it the centre of Safavid architectural achievement?
Shah ʿAbbās I moved the capital of Iran to Eṣfahān and made it the centre of Safavid architectural achievement.
Who recovered Eṣfahān in 1729 and ascended the throne of Iran?
Shah Ṭahmāsp II recovered Eṣfahān in 1729 and ascended the throne of Iran.
What empire ruled Algeria from the 16th century until the French conquest?
The Ottoman Empire ruled Algeria from the 16th century until the French conquest.
When did France launch its war of conquest in Algeria?
France launched its war of conquest in Algeria in 1830.
What status did France grant Algeria in 1848?
France made Algeria a département of France in 1848.
Who ruled Algeria from the 8th through the 16th century?
Various Arab-Amazigh dynasties ruled Algeria from the 8th through the 16th century.
What event occurred in Algeria from 1954 to 1962?
A war of independence occurred in Algeria from 1954 to 1962.
Who noted the cycle of violence in Algeria during the war of independence?
Frantz Fanon noted the cycle of violence in Algeria during the war of independence.
What was the outcome of the negotiations that ended the conflict in Algeria?
The negotiations ended the conflict and led to Algerian independence.
What cultural influence remained strong in Algeria after independence?
The influence of the French language and culture remained strong in Algeria after independence.
What heritage has Algeria sought to regain since independence?
Algeria has sought to regain its Arab and Islamic heritage since independence.
Who was Genghis Khan and why is he important in Mongolian history?
Genghis Khan was important in Mongolian history as the founder of the Mongol Empire.
Who formed a united Mongolian state of nomadic tribes in the early 13th century CE?
Genghis Khan formed a united Mongolian state of nomadic tribes in the early 13th century CE.
What event occurred in 1691 in northern Mongolia?
Northern Mongolia was colonized by Qing (Manchu) China in 1691.
Who was proclaimed Bogd Khan after the collapse of Qing rule in Mongolia in 1911/12?
The Bogd Gegeen (or Javzandamba), Mongolia’s religious leader, was proclaimed Bogd Khan after the collapse of Qing rule in Mongolia in 1911/12.
What significant event occurred on July 11, 1921, in Mongolia?
July 11, 1921, became celebrated as the anniversary of the revolution in Mongolia.
When was the Mongolian People’s Republic proclaimed in Mongolia?
The Mongolian People’s Republic was proclaimed in November 1924 in Mongolia.
What was the political system of Mongolia from 1921 until the end of the 1980s?
Mongolia was a one-party state from 1921 until the end of the 1980s.
What type of assistance did Mongolia receive from the Soviet Union?
Mongolia received technical, economic, and military assistance from the Soviet Union.
What changes occurred in Mongolia beginning in 1990?

Mongolia ended the monopoly of political power by the communists in favour of free multiparty elections, coalition government, a new constitution, greater cultural and religious freedom, a neutral position in international relations, and a transition to a market economy beginning in 1990.
What type of social structure did Nauru have when Europeans first arrived in the early 18th century?
Nauruan society consisted of 12 matrilineal kinship groups, each having a chief.
What year did an English sailing vessel first sight Nauru?
An English sailing vessel first sighted Nauru in 1798.
What event in the 1880s led to Germany incorporating Nauru into its Marshall Islands protectorate?
Intraisland warfare among competing districts in the 1880s led to Germany incorporating Nauru into its Marshall Islands protectorate in late 1888.
Which company negotiated an agreement with the German administration to mine Nauru’s phosphate deposits in 1906?
The Pacific Phosphate Company, a British concern, negotiated an agreement with the German administration to mine Nauru’s phosphate deposits in 1906.
What happened to Nauru during World War I?
A small Australian force occupied Nauru and removed most German nationals during World War I.
What status did Nauru gain in 1920?
Nauru became a mandated territory within the framework of the League of Nations in 1920.
Who were the responsible authorities for Nauru's administration?
Australia, Britain, and New Zealand were named as the responsible authorities for Nauru's administration.
What was the role of the British Phosphate Commission in Nauru?
The British Phosphate Commission took over the phosphate industry in Nauru as a joint Australian, British, and New Zealand enterprise.
When did Japanese forces occupy Nauru?
Japanese forces arrived in Nauru in August 1942.
What happened to 1,200 Nauruans during the Japanese occupation?
1,200 Nauruans were taken to Truk to serve as forced laborers on Japanese military installations.
When did Australian troops regain possession of Nauru after World War II?
Australian troops again took possession of Nauru in September 1945.
How many Nauruans were returned home on January 31, 1946?
737 Nauruans were returned home on January 31, 1946.
What status did Nauru attain in November 1947?
Nauru became a United Nations trust territory in November 1947.
Who provided the actual administration of Nauru as a United Nations trust territory?
Australia provided the actual administration of Nauru as a United Nations trust territory.
When was the agreement granting Nauruan independence concluded?
The agreement granting Nauruan independence was concluded in October 1967.
What date was chosen as Independence Day for the Republic of Nauru?
January 31, 1968, was chosen as Independence Day for the Republic of Nauru.
What was the significance of January 31, 1968, in Nauru's history?
January 31, 1968, marked the 22nd anniversary of the return of Nauruans from Truk.
Who dominated the political scene in Nauru for the first two decades of the republic?
Hammer DeRoburt dominated the political scene in Nauru for the first two decades of the republic.
When was Hammer DeRoburt voted out of office in Nauru?
Hammer DeRoburt was voted out of office in Nauru in 1989.
What was the projected outcome for Nauru’s primary phosphate deposits by the early years of the 21st century?
Nauru’s primary phosphate deposits were projected to be exhausted by the early years of the 21st century.
Where was a major portion of the earnings from phosphate mining in Nauru invested?
A major portion of the earnings from phosphate mining in Nauru was invested abroad.
What was the financial agreement between Australia and Nauru in 2002?
Australia paid an additional $14 million to Nauru to cover another 1,500 people in December 2002.
When did the last refugees leave Nauru?
The last refugees left Nauru in February 2008.
What action did Australia take regarding Nauru in 2012?
Australia reestablished a detention center on Nauru in 2012.
What was Croatia's position in relation to the Roman Empire?
Croatia lay near the division between the two halves of the Roman Empire.
What was Croatia's status after World War II?
Croatia emerged from World War II as a separate republic in the communist federation.
What was Croatia's position in relation to the Soviet and Western blocs?
Croatia navigated between the Soviet and Western blocs as a separate republic in the communist federation.
When did Croatia develop as an independent state?
Croatia developed as an independent state in the 9th century.
Who was the king that turned Croatia into a powerful military force?
King Tomislav turned Croatia into a powerful military force during his reign from c. 910–928.
In what year did Croatia's crown pass into the hands of the Hungarian dynasty?
Croatia's crown passed into the hands of the Hungarian dynasty in 1102.
What institutions maintained Croatian statehood during the dynastic union with Hungary?
The Sabor and the ban maintained Croatian statehood during the dynastic union with Hungary.
What territories did Croatia lose to Venice by 1420?
Croatia lost Dalmatia to Venice by 1420.
What were the Croatian nobility's hopes regarding lands occupied by the Ottomans?
The Croatian nobility hoped to repossess lands occupied by the Ottomans once liberated.
Where did a Croatian national tradition survive during the Ottoman conquests?
A Croatian national tradition survived within territories under Ottoman and Venetian rule.
Who was elected to the throne of Croatia in 1527?
The Austrian Habsburgs were elected to the throne of Croatia in 1527.
What event led to the Austrian Habsburgs being elected to the throne of Croatia?
The death of King Louis II of Hungary at the Battle of Mohács led to the Austrian Habsburgs being elected to the throne of Croatia.
What was the impact of the Military Frontier on Croatian nobles, the Sabor, and the ban?
The Military Frontier further reduced the amount of land under the control of Croatian nobles, the Sabor, and the ban.
What event in 1573 reflected the deteriorating position of the Croatian peasantry in Croatia?
A rebellion in 1573 reflected the deteriorating position of the Croatian peasantry in Croatia.
Who led the unsuccessful anti-Habsburg conspiracy of Croatian and Hungarian nobles in Croatia?
Petar Zrinski, ban of Croatia, led the unsuccessful anti-Habsburg conspiracy of Croatian and Hungarian nobles in Croatia.
What was the fate of Petar Zrinski and other leaders of the anti-Habsburg conspiracy in Croatia?
Petar Zrinski and other leaders of the anti-Habsburg conspiracy in Croatia were executed in 1671.
What happened to the properties of Petar Zrinski and other leaders of the anti-Habsburg conspiracy in Croatia?
The properties of Petar Zrinski and other leaders of the anti-Habsburg conspiracy in Croatia were confiscated by the Habsburg crown.
What form of government did the constitution of Palau establish in 1981?
The constitution of Palau established a presidential form of government in 1981.
What are the two separately elected offices in Palau's executive branch?
The president and vice president are the two separately elected offices in Palau's executive branch.
What colonial powers influenced Palauan society over a century?
Spanish, German, Japanese, and American colonial powers influenced Palauan society over a century.
What customs characterize Palauan society?
Pragmatic adaptation, persistence of wealth-exchange customs, and competition characterize Palauan society.
What traditional tasks do men continue in rural areas of Palau?
Men continue their traditional tasks as fishermen and warriors in rural areas of Palau.
What event in 1783 marked the first extensive contact between Palauans and Westerners?
The shipwreck of the East India Company’s packet Antelope in 1783 marked the first extensive contact between Palauans and Westerners.
What was the impact of firearms introduced by European visitors on Palau?
Firearms introduced by European visitors were prized for intervillage warfare in Palau.
Who ended intervillage warfare in Palau in 1883?
Capt. Cyprian Bridge of HMS Espiegle ended intervillage warfare in Palau in 1883.
Who expelled the Germans from Palau at the beginning of World War I?
The Japanese navy expelled the Germans from Palau at the beginning of World War I.
What was the status of Palauans by 1936 under Japanese rule?
Palauans were a marginal minority by 1936 under Japanese rule.
What happened to Palau after Japan lost it in World War II?
Palau was administered by the U.S. Navy for a short period after Japan lost it in World War II.
When did Palau become part of the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands under U.S. administration?
Palau became part of the United Nations Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands under U.S. administration in 1947.
When did Palau adopt its constitution and become internally self-governing?
Palau adopted its constitution and became internally self-governing in 1981.
What agreement did Palau sign with the United States in 1982?
Palau signed a Compact of Free Association with the United States in 1982.
When did Palau finally pass the referendum for the Compact of Free Association?
Palau passed the referendum for the Compact of Free Association in 1993.
What responsibility did the United States retain under the Compact of Free Association with Palau?
The United States remained responsible for external security and defense under the Compact of Free Association with Palau.
What constitutional prohibition in Palau caused conflict with the United States?
Palau's constitutional prohibition on the operation of U.S. nuclear-powered or nuclear-armed vessels and aircraft caused conflict with the United States.
When did the United States dissolve the trusteeship over Palau?
The United States dissolved the trusteeship over Palau in 1986.
What event occurred in Palau in October 1994?
Palau became independent in October 1994.
What significant event happened to Palau's first president Haruo I. Remeliik in 1985?
Haruo I. Remeliik was assassinated in 1985.
When did Palau join the United Nations?
Palau joined the United Nations in December 1994.
What was the outcome of the 1992 constitutional amendment vote in Palau?
The 1992 amendment reduced the popular vote required to override the antinuclear provision from three-fourths to a simple majority.
What was the cause of Lazarus E. Salii's term as president of Palau being cut short?
Lazarus E. Salii committed suicide in August 1988.
What ancient group of peoples did the Latvians constitute a prominent division of?
The Latvians constituted a prominent division of the ancient group of peoples known as the Balts.
Who founded the Order of the Brothers of the Sword in Latvia in 1202?
Albert of Buxhoevden founded the Order of the Brothers of the Sword in Latvia in 1202.
What event occurred in Latvia in 1237?
The Order of the Brothers of the Sword merged with the Teutonic Order in Latvia in 1237.
What was formed in Latvia after the German conquest of the tribal kingdoms?
The Germans formed the Livonian confederation in Latvia after the conquest of the tribal kingdoms.
Who was named bishop of Ikškile in Latvia in 1186?
Meinhard was named bishop of Ikškile in Latvia in 1186.
What three components were in constant dispute within the Livonian confederation in Latvia?
The Teutonic Order, the archbishopric of Riga, and the free city of Riga were in constant dispute within the Livonian confederation in Latvia.
What economic organization did Riga join in 1282 that brought prosperity to Latvia?
Riga’s joining the Hanseatic League in 1282 brought prosperity to Latvia.
What was the situation of the indigenous nobility in Latvia under German rule?
The indigenous nobility in Latvia was extinguished under German rule, apart from a few members who changed their allegiance.
What obligations did the rural population in Latvia have to their German conquerors?
The rural population in Latvia was forced to pay tithes and taxes to their German conquerors and to provide corvée, or statute labour.
When was Riga incorporated into the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth in Latvia?
Riga was incorporated into the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth in Latvia in 1581.
Who took Riga from the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth in Latvia in 1621?
Gustav II Adolf took Riga from the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth in Latvia in 1621.
What treaty ceded Vidzeme to Sweden in Latvia in 1629?
The Truce of Altmark ceded Vidzeme to Sweden in Latvia in 1629.
Who took Riga from the Swedes in Latvia in 1710?
Alexis took Riga from the Swedes in Latvia in 1710.
What treaty secured Vidzeme for Russia in Latvia in 1721?
The Peace of Nystad secured Vidzeme for Russia in Latvia in 1721.
By the end of the 18th century, which power ruled the whole Latvian nation?
Russia ruled the whole Latvian nation by the end of the 18th century.
What significant event in 1905 led to open discussions about an independent Latvian state in Latvia?
The Russian Revolution of 1905 led to open discussions about an independent Latvian state in Latvia.
During which period did a national revival surge throughout Latvia?
A national revival surged throughout Latvia during the last quarter of the 19th century.
What types of institutions were established in Latvia during the national revival?
Universities and other national institutions were established in Latvia during the national revival.
What event in 1917 led to the Latvian National Political Conference of Riga asking for complete political autonomy in Latvia?
The Russian Revolution of 1917 led to the Latvian National Political Conference of Riga asking for complete political autonomy in Latvia.
Who proclaimed independence for Latvia on November 18, 1918?
The Latvian People’s Council, led by Kārlis Ulmanis, proclaimed independence for Latvia on November 18, 1918.
What government did the Soviet government establish for Latvia at Valmiera?
The Soviet government established a communist government for Latvia at Valmiera, headed by Pēteris Stučka.
When did the Red Army capture Riga in Latvia?
The Red Army captured Riga in Latvia on January 3, 1919.
Where did the Ulmanis government move to after the Red Army captured Riga in Latvia?
The Ulmanis government moved to Liepāja, where it was protected by a British naval squadron.
What was Gen. Rüdiger von der Goltz's intention for Latvia in 1919?
Gen. Rüdiger von der Goltz intended to build a German-controlled Latvia and make it a German base of operation in the war against the Soviets.
Who led the West Russian army that fought against Latvia in 1919?
Pavel Bermondt-Avalov led the West Russian army that fought against Latvia in 1919.
Which naval squadron aided Latvia in defeating Goltz's and Bermondt-Avalov's troops on November 10?
An Anglo-French naval squadron aided Latvia in defeating Goltz's and Bermondt-Avalov's troops on November 10.
By what date had all German troops abandoned Latvia and Lithuania?
By December 1919 all German troops had abandoned Latvia and Lithuania.
What type of government did Latvia establish with its constitution of February 15, 1922?
Latvia's constitution of February 15, 1922, established a republic with a president and a unicameral parliament, the Saeima, of 100 members elected for three years.
What significant agrarian reform did Latvia implement during its period of economic growth?
Latvia's agrarian reform bill granted land to about 145,000 peasants.
Who dissolved the Saeima and all political parties in Latvia in May 1934?
Ulmanis, prime minister for the fourth time since 1918, dissolved the Saeima and all political parties and established authoritarian rule.
What was the outcome of the Latvian-Soviet peace treaty signed in Riga on August 11, 1920?
The Latvian-Soviet peace treaty signed in Riga on August 11, 1920, resulted in the Soviet government renouncing all claims to Latvia.
What event led to the formation of modern Turkey?
The Ottoman defeat in World War I led to the formation of modern Turkey.
When was modern Turkey formed?
Modern Turkey was formed in the aftermath of World War I.
Who replaced Damad Ferid Pasha as grand vizier in Turkey after the latter's resignation?
Ali Riza Pasha replaced Damad Ferid Pasha as grand vizier in Turkey after the latter's resignation.
What significant document was passed by the new parliament in Turkey in January 1920?
The National Pact was passed by the new parliament in Turkey in January 1920.
When did the Allies extend the occupied area of Istanbul in Turkey?
The Allies extended the occupied area of Istanbul in Turkey on March 16, 1920.
Who became grand vizier again in Turkey on April 5, 1920?
Damad Ferid became grand vizier again in Turkey on April 5, 1920.
What was the significance of the Fundamental Law of January 20, 1921, in Turkey?
The Fundamental Law of January 20, 1921, declared that sovereignty belonged to the nation in Turkey.
Who headed the executive council in Turkey after the Fundamental Law was established?
Mustafa Kemal headed the executive council in Turkey after the Fundamental Law was established.
What was the Grand National Assembly's assertion about the sultan's government in Turkey?
The Grand National Assembly asserted that the sultan's government was under infidel control in Turkey.
What was the outcome of the Battle of the Sakarya River for Turkey in 1921?
The Battle of the Sakarya River resulted in a defeat for the Greeks and marked the beginning of their long retreat from Turkey.
What treaty restored the cities of Kars and Ardahan to Turkey in 1921?
The Soviet-Turkish Treaty of March 16, 1921, restored the cities of Kars and Ardahan to Turkey.
What armistice allowed Turkey to reoccupy Istanbul and eastern Thrace?
The Armistice of Mudanya allowed Turkey to reoccupy Istanbul and eastern Thrace.
What treaty provided a comprehensive settlement for Turkey in 1923?
The Treaty of Lausanne provided a comprehensive settlement for Turkey in 1923.
What was the outcome of the population exchange between Turkey and Greece following the Treaty of Lausanne?
The Treaty of Lausanne resulted in 1,300,000 Greeks leaving Turkey and 400,000 Turks being repatriated.
When did Turkey regain tariff autonomy under the Treaty of Lausanne?
Turkey regained tariff autonomy in 1929 under the Treaty of Lausanne.
What international agreement finally gave Turkey complete control of the straits in 1936?
The 1936 Montreux Convention gave Turkey complete control of the straits.
What event led to the creation of a state in Turkey where the majority spoke Turkish?
The war and subsequent peace settlement led to the creation of a state in Turkey where the majority spoke Turkish.
What was the focus of the religious ceremony preceding the opening of the Grand National Assembly in Turkey?
The religious ceremony preceding the opening of the Grand National Assembly in Turkey focused on the need to save 'religion's last country'.
What was the outcome of the long effort to create a sense of Turkish nationhood in Turkey?
The outcome of the long effort to create a sense of Turkish nationhood in Turkey was the construction of a new political system.
What was the first step in constructing a new political system in Turkey?
The abolition of the sultanate and the declaration of a republic was the first step in constructing a new political system in Turkey.
What event occurred in Turkey on November 1, 1922?
The assembly abolished the sultanate in Turkey on November 1, 1922.
Who was installed as the first and last Ottoman caliph who was not also sultan in Turkey?
Abdülmecid II was installed as the first and last Ottoman caliph who was not also sultan in Turkey.
What weakened Mehmed VI's support among Kemalists in Turkey?
Mehmed VI's identification with the Allies weakened his support among Kemalists in Turkey.
What role did the Allied invitation to the sultan play in Turkey's political situation?
The Allied invitation to the sultan to nominate representatives to Lausanne aided Mustafa Kemal in Turkey's political situation.
What dynasty declined in Anatolia, Turkey, enabling Ottoman expansion?
The Seljuq dynasty declined in Anatolia, Turkey, enabling Ottoman expansion.
What external factor contributed to the decline of the Seljuq dynasty in Turkey?
The Mongol invasion contributed to the decline of the Seljuq dynasty in Turkey.
Which dynasty was weakened by Mongol invasions, allowing Osman I to expand in Turkey?
The Seljuq dynasty was weakened by Mongol invasions, allowing Osman I to expand in Turkey.
Who continued the institutionalization of the Ottoman state in Turkey after Murad I?
Bayezid I continued the institutionalization of the Ottoman state in Turkey after Murad I.
Who founded the Ottoman dynasty and empire in Turkey around 1300?
Osman I founded the Ottoman dynasty and empire in Turkey around 1300.
How long did the Ottoman period last in Turkey?
The Ottoman period lasted more than 600 years in Turkey.
What characterized the first period of Ottoman history in Turkey?
The first period of Ottoman history in Turkey was characterized by almost continuous territorial expansion.
What institutions were amalgamated during the Ottoman expansion in Turkey?
The political, economic, and social institutions of the classical Islamic empires were amalgamated with those inherited from Byzantium and the great Turkish empires of Central Asia in Turkey.
What title was given to the Ottoman leaders during their initial expansion in Turkey?
The Ottoman leaders were given the honorific title ghāzī, meaning "raider", during their initial expansion in Turkey.
What was the name given to the city by Emperor Constantine I when he refounded it in 330 in Turkey?
Constantinople was the name given to the city by Emperor Constantine I when he refounded it in 330 in Turkey.
In what year did the city of Constantinople in Turkey fall after its last and unsuccessful defense under the 11th (or 12th) Constantine?
The city of Constantinople in Turkey fell in 1453 after its last and unsuccessful defense under the 11th (or 12th) Constantine.
What type of technology contributed to the Ottoman conquest of Turkey in 1453?
Modern artillery, in which European technicians had instructed the Ottoman Turks, contributed to the Ottoman conquest of Turkey in 1453.
What was a major factor that weakened Turkey in the face of new enemies from east and west?
Bitter ethnic and religious hostility marked the history of Turkey's later centuries, weakening it in the face of new enemies descending upon it from east and west.
What was the ultimate cause of Turkey's collapse?
Turkey finally collapsed when its administrative structures could no longer support the burden of leadership thrust upon it by military conquests.
What economic activity did the Roman emperors hope would develop between provinces including those that would become Turkey?
The Roman emperors hoped that a lively and spontaneous trade would develop between the several provinces including those that would become Turkey.
What role did the emperor play in maintaining unity in Turkey during the late Roman Empire?
The emperor alone could provide protection and unity in Turkey, embodying all virtues and possessing qualities displayed imperfectly by individual subjects.
How did conquest affect the regions under Roman rule in Turkey?
Conquest brought regions of diverse background under Roman rule in Turkey, including ancient and populous Eastern provinces and Western provinces undergoing urban development.
What was the state of urban development in the Western provinces of Turkey under Roman rule?
The Western provinces of Turkey had only lately entered upon their own course of urban development under the not-always-tender ministrations of their Roman masters.
What was a challenge to unity in Turkey during the late Roman Empire?
Not everyone understood or spoke Latin in Turkey, presenting a challenge to unity during the late Roman Empire.
What did warrior emperors in Turkey devote their energies to during the late Roman Empire?
Warrior emperors in Turkey devoted their energies to protecting the frontier against barbarians and reasserting control over provinces.
What challenges did Turkey face during the late Roman Empire period?
Turkey faced warfare, widespread disease, and rapid turnover among imperial throne occupants during the late Roman Empire period.
What was preserved in Turkey despite the challenges of the late Roman Empire period?
The traditional fabric of Greco-Roman society and the bureaucratic structure were preserved in Turkey despite the challenges.
What was the state of the economy and society in Turkey during the late Roman Empire period?
The economy and society of Turkey during the late Roman Empire period was the most diverse it had ever been.
How did emperors in Turkey influence the development of towns and provinces during the late Roman Empire period?
Emperors in Turkey favoured certain towns and provinces at the expense of others for personal and dynastic reasons.
What was the impact of succession to the throne on administrative officials in Turkey during the late Roman Empire period?
The erratic course of succession to the throne in Turkey resulted in constant change among the top administrative officials.
How did social disorder affect opportunities for advancement in Turkey during the late Roman Empire period?
Social disorder in Turkey opened avenues to eminence and wealth that the more-stable order of an earlier age had closed to the talented and the ambitious.
What event in the 1st century CE led to the centuries-long Diaspora for Jews before the establishment of Israel?
The demise of the Herodian kingdom in the 1st century CE led to the centuries-long Diaspora for Jews before the establishment of Israel.
What does the nation of Israel represent for Jews after two millennia?
The nation of Israel represents for Jews the restoration of their homeland after two millennia.
What historical event in Judaea against the Romans led to a 19-century Jewish exile that influenced the formation of Israel?
The failed revolts in Judaea against the Romans early in the Common Era led to a 19-century Jewish exile that influenced the formation of Israel.
What factors in the 1800s inspired a new wave of Jewish emigration to the region that would become Israel?
A rise in European antisemitism and revived Jewish national pride inspired a new wave of Jewish emigration to the region that would become Israel.
Who financed the agricultural colonies in Palestine during the 1880s that contributed to the development of Israel?
The Rothschilds and other wealthy families financed the agricultural colonies in Palestine during the 1880s that contributed to the development of Israel.
Who advocated for a Jewish state as a political solution for antisemitism and a Jewish secular identity in Israel?
Theodor Herzl advocated for a Jewish state as a political solution for antisemitism and a Jewish secular identity in Israel.
What event did Theodor Herzl cover that influenced his advocacy for a Jewish state in Israel?
Theodor Herzl covered the Dreyfus affair in France, which influenced his advocacy for a Jewish state in Israel.
Who led the Zionist organization after Theodor Herzl's death in 1904 in Israel?
Chaim Weizmann led the Zionist organization after Theodor Herzl's death in 1904 in Israel.
What was the name given to Judaea by the Romans that Europeans used to refer to Palestine in Israel?
Palaestina, meaning 'Land of the Philistines,' was the name given to Judaea by the Romans that Europeans used to refer to Palestine in Israel.
Who ruled what Europeans called Palestine in Israel during the early Zionist efforts?
The Ottoman Turks ruled what Europeans called Palestine in Israel during the early Zionist efforts.
What declaration did the British government issue in 1917 regarding Israel?
The Balfour Declaration committed Britain to facilitate the establishment of a Jewish homeland in Palestine.
Which international organization endorsed the Balfour Declaration concerning Israel?
The League of Nations endorsed the Balfour Declaration and placed Palestine under British mandate.
What role did Panama serve in the 1530s for the Spanish conquest of the Inca empire?
Panama served as the staging point for the Spanish conquest of the Inca empire in the 1530s.
What was Panama's function until the 19th century in terms of Spanish trade?
Panama was a transshipment point for gold and silver destined for Spain until the 19th century.
What role did Panama play after Colombia's independence from Spain?
Panama served as a staging point for oceangoing migrants to the gold fields of California after Colombia's independence from Spain.
Which Native American peoples were among the original inhabitants of Panama?
The Guaymí, Kuna, and Chocó were among the Native American peoples who originally inhabited Panama.
When did the United States relinquish jurisdiction of the Panama Canal to Panama?
The United States relinquished jurisdiction of the Panama Canal on December 31, 1999.
What significant event occurred in Panama on December 31, 1999?
Panama gained control of the entirety of its national territory on December 31, 1999.
What year did Samoa gain independence?
Samoa gained independence in 1962.
When did Polynesians first arrive in Samoa?
Polynesians arrived in Samoa about 1000 bce.
What evidence indicates Polynesians arrived in Samoa around 1000 bce?
Lapita pottery shards found in Mulifanua Lagoon on Upolu indicate Polynesians arrived in Samoa around 1000 bce.
When did local pottery manufacturing cease in Samoa?
Local pottery manufacturing ceased in Samoa by about 200 ce.
Who established a Christian mission in Samoa in 1830?
John Williams established a Christian mission in Samoa in 1830.
Who was converted by John Williams and had recently conquered all of Samoa?
Malietoa Vainu‘upo was converted by John Williams and had recently conquered all of Samoa.
Which foreign powers tried to persuade their governments to annex Samoa?
The United States, Great Britain, and Germany tried to persuade their governments to annex Samoa.
What treaty did the United States, Great Britain, and Germany sign in 1879 regarding Samoa?
The United States, Great Britain, and Germany signed the Berlin Act in 1879 to provide for the neutrality of the islands and to avoid further conflict in Samoa.
Which movement led by Lauaki Namulau‘ulu began the drive for political independence in Western Samoa in 1908?
The Mau a Pule movement led by Lauaki Namulau‘ulu began the drive for political independence in Western Samoa in 1908.
What was the result of the division of Samoa between the United States and Germany in 1899?
The United States annexed eastern Samoa, whereas Germany annexed the western part of the islands—Western Samoa in 1899.
What was the main reason for the matai's dissatisfaction with the German governor in Western Samoa?
The matai were dissatisfied with the German governor’s attempts to change the fa‘a Samoa and centralize all authority in his hands.
What event led to the exile of Lauaki and his supporters in Samoa?
Lauaki and nine of his leading supporters surrendered after the governor called in warships and were subsequently tried and exiled to Saipan in the Mariana Islands.

New Zealand troops shot and killed the matai Tupua Tamasese Lealofi III and other unarmed Mau supporters during a demonstration in December 1929 in Samoa.

What political institutions did New Zealand allow to be established in Samoa in the late 1940s?

When did a constitutional convention meet in Samoa?
A constitutional convention met in Samoa in 1954.
What was the outcome of the government reforms carried out in Samoa during the next few years?

When did Western Samoa regain its political independence?
Western Samoa regained its political independence in 1962.
Who became the cohead of state of Samoa in 1962?
Susuga Malietoa Tanumafili II became the cohead of state of Samoa in 1962.

Fiame Faumuina Mataafa served as prime minister of Samoa from 1962 to 1970 and again from 1973 to 1975.
Who was prime minister of Samoa during 1976-1982?
Tupuola Taisi Efi was prime minister of Samoa during 1976-1982.
Who served as prime minister of Samoa from 1985 to 1998?

What name change did the legislature of Samoa make in 1997?
The legislature of Samoa changed the country's name from Western Samoa to Samoa in 1997.

What unusual political crisis occurred in Samoa in 2021?
An unusual political crisis took place in Samoa in 2021, after elections held in April produced controversial results.
Who appeared poised to become Samoa's first woman prime minister in 2021?
Fiame Naomi Mataafa, daughter of Fiame Faumuina Mataafa, appeared set to become Samoa's first woman prime minister in 2021.

Who was the Prime Minister of Samoa since 1998?
Tuilaepa Sailele Malielegaoi was the Prime Minister of Samoa since 1998.
What did the Supreme Court of Samoa order in late June?

What did the Court of Appeal of Samoa declare in July?
The Court of Appeal of Samoa declared that Mataafa’s oath of office had been legitimate in July.
Who was the first emperor of the Incas in Peru?
Manco Capac was the first emperor of the Incas in Peru.
What was the nature of the first seven emperors of the Incas in Peru?
The first seven emperors of the Incas in Peru were legendary, local, and of slight importance.
What was the relationship between the Incas and neighboring tribes in Peru?
The Incas were almost constantly at war with neighboring tribes in Peru.
Who began the rapid expansion of the Inca empire in Peru in 1438?
Pachacuti began the rapid expansion of the Inca empire in Peru in 1438.

Pachacuti ruled Peru from 1438 to 1532, establishing the Inca Empire.
When was New Zealand annexed by Great Britain?
New Zealand was annexed by Great Britain in 1840.
In what year did New Zealand become fully independent?
New Zealand became fully independent in 1947.
When did Polynesians from eastern Polynesia first reach New Zealand?
Polynesians from eastern Polynesia reached New Zealand in the early 13th century.

The Archaic phase of New Zealand's Polynesian period was characterized by primarily coastal settlements and an economy based on hunting, especially of moas, fishing, and limited crop cultivation.
What marked the transitional phase of New Zealand's Polynesian period?

The transitional phase of New Zealand's Polynesian period was marked by a growth in population, a shift to a fish, shellfish, and plant diet, the emergence of food-storage pits, and changing art forms.
When did the colonization phase of New Zealand's Polynesian period end?
The colonization phase of New Zealand's Polynesian period ended around 1400.
What was the approximate duration of the transitional phase in New Zealand's Polynesian period?
The transitional phase in New Zealand's Polynesian period lasted until about 1600.
What was the major food supply for the first Polynesian settlers in New Zealand?
Moas served as the major food supply for the first Polynesian settlers in New Zealand.
When did the moas become extinct in New Zealand?
Moas became extinct in New Zealand by the 15th century.
Who completed Tasman’s work by circumnavigating the two major islands of New Zealand in 1769–70?
James Cook completed Tasman’s work by circumnavigating the two major islands of New Zealand in 1769–70.
Who made the first systematic observations of Māori life and culture in New Zealand?
Cook, with the explorer and naturalist Joseph Banks, made the first systematic observations of Māori life and culture in New Zealand.

Cook’s journal, published as A Voyage Towards the South Pole, and Round the World (1777), brought the knowledge of New Zealand to Europeans.
What were the primary economic activities of early European settlers in New Zealand?
Early European settlers in New Zealand engaged in the trade of sealskins, timber, New Zealand flax, and whaling.

Hongi Hika acquired muskets by exchanging presents obtained in England for muskets in Australia.

Hongi Hika's acquisition of muskets led to devastating wars against traditional enemies in New Zealand.
Who followed the traders to New Zealand after the establishment of early European settlements?
Missionaries followed the traders to New Zealand after the establishment of early European settlements.
What religious groups established mission stations in New Zealand between 1814 and 1838?
Anglicans, Wesleyan Methodists, and Roman Catholics established mission stations in New Zealand between 1814 and 1838.
What impact did Christianity have on Māori social cohesion in New Zealand?
Christianity cut across the sanctions and prohibitions that had supplied Māori social cohesion in New Zealand.
What economic system was introduced to Māori in New Zealand by traders and missionaries?
A capitalist economy was introduced to Māori in New Zealand by traders and missionaries.
What were Australian graziers doing in New Zealand during the late 1830s?
Australian graziers were buying land from the Māori in New Zealand during the late 1830s.
What was happening in Great Britain regarding New Zealand in the late 1830s?
Colonization schemes were afoot in Great Britain regarding New Zealand in the late 1830s.
What year did the British government decide on partial annexation of New Zealand?
The British government decided on partial annexation of New Zealand in 1838.
In what year did New Zealand become a separate crown colony?
New Zealand became a separate crown colony in 1841.
What treaty emerged from discussions between Hobson and the northern chiefs before the annexation of New Zealand?
The Treaty of Waitangi emerged from discussions between Hobson and the northern chiefs before the annexation of New Zealand.
Who was named governor of New Zealand after it became a separate crown colony?
Hobson was named governor of New Zealand after it became a separate crown colony.
What was the New Zealand Company founded to do in 1839?
The New Zealand Company was founded in 1839 to colonize New Zealand on the principles laid down by Edward Gibbon Wakefield.
What ship did the New Zealand Company send to New Zealand in May 1839?
The New Zealand Company sent the survey ship Tory to New Zealand in May 1839.
What was the British government's moral obligation to the Māori under the treaty in New Zealand?
The British government had a strong moral obligation to act as guardian of the Māori in New Zealand.
What was the consequence of British annexation on land sales in New Zealand?
British annexation would entail a crown monopoly of land sales and a consequent increase in price in New Zealand.
Who died in 1842 while serving as a key figure in New Zealand's early settlement?
Hobson died in 1842 while serving as a key figure in New Zealand's early settlement.
What were the names of the settlements established in New Zealand's North Island in the 1840s?
New Plymouth, Wanganui, and Wellington were the settlements established in New Zealand's North Island in the 1840s.
Who succeeded Hobson in New Zealand after his death in 1842?
Robert FitzRoy succeeded Hobson in New Zealand after his death in 1842.
What was the result of the company's actions in New Zealand during the 1840s?
The company's actions in New Zealand during the 1840s resulted in the founding of New Plymouth, Wanganui, Wellington, Nelson, Otago, and Canterbury.
Who became governor of New Zealand in 1845?
George Grey became governor of New Zealand in 1845.
What event in the 1850s helped improve New Zealand's economy?
The Australian gold rushes of the 1850s offered a market for foodstuffs to the New Zealand farmer, settler and Māori alike.
What did the leading settlements in New Zealand begin to campaign for by the end of the 1840s?
The leading settlements in New Zealand began to campaign for representative government in place of Grey’s personal rule by the end of the 1840s.
What act was drafted in 1852 to meet the demands of settlers in New Zealand?
The New Zealand Constitution Act of 1852 was drafted to meet the demands of settlers in New Zealand.
What were Grey's goals for the Māori in New Zealand by the end of 1853?
Grey's goals for the Māori in New Zealand by the end of 1853 were to begin their rapid assimilation to British social and cultural patterns.
What land policy did Grey want to introduce in New Zealand?
Grey wanted to introduce a land policy in New Zealand that would safeguard the small farmer against the large landowner.
When did Grey depart from New Zealand?
Grey departed from New Zealand at the end of 1853.
What system of government was achieved in New Zealand after a quarrel with the acting governor?
New Zealand achieved full responsible government, a system under which the governor could act in domestic matters only upon the advice of ministers enjoying the confidence of the elected chamber.
What was the composition of the central government in New Zealand after the Constitution Act came into force in 1853?

The central government of New Zealand consisted of a governor and a two-chamber legislature, comprising a Legislative Council nominated by the crown and a House of Representatives elected upon a low property franchise for a five-year term.
Who was the acting governor of New Zealand involved in a quarrel with the General Assembly?
Col. Robert Henry Wynyard was the acting governor of New Zealand involved in a quarrel with the General Assembly.
When did the General Assembly of New Zealand first meet after the Constitution Act came into force?
The General Assembly of New Zealand first met in 1854.
What was the basis of election for the House of Representatives in New Zealand after the Constitution Act came into force?
The House of Representatives in New Zealand was elected upon a low property franchise for a five-year term.
Who led the opposition against responsible government in New Zealand?
Edward Gibbon Wakefield led the opposition against responsible government in New Zealand.
When did the Colonial Office concede responsible government to New Zealand?
The Colonial Office conceded responsible government to New Zealand in 1856.
Who reserved Māori affairs to the control of the governor alone in New Zealand?
Thomas Gore Browne reserved Māori affairs to the control of the governor alone in New Zealand.
How many provincial institutions administered New Zealand by the time of their abolition in 1876?
Ten provincial institutions administered New Zealand by the time of their abolition in 1876.
What powers did the provincial institutions have in New Zealand during the 1850s?
The provincial institutions in New Zealand had the power to administer land, control immigration, and oversee public works during the 1850s.
How did provinces in New Zealand use revenue from land sales?
Provinces in New Zealand used revenue from land sales to settle land, regulate immigration, and build roads and bridges.
What was the status of the central legislature in New Zealand until the wars of the 1860s?
The central legislature in New Zealand was less important until the wars of the 1860s, though its ultimate authority remained.
Which provinces in New Zealand cultivated prosperity by spending revenue on communications, immigration, and education?
Canterbury and Otago in New Zealand cultivated prosperity by spending revenue on communications, immigration, and education.
What was the situation with land availability in the North Island of New Zealand by the end of the 1850s?

In the North Island of New Zealand, most of the land available for settlement had been taken up by the end of the 1850s, a good deal of it by speculators, and some of it was given away to attract immigrants.
What movement emerged in New Zealand in 1858 under the leadership of Te Wherowhero?
The Māori King Movement emerged in New Zealand in 1858 under the leadership of Te Wherowhero, who reigned as King Pōtatau I.
Who led the opposition to land sales in the Taranaki province of New Zealand in the 1850s?
Wiremu Kīngi, chief of Te Ātiawa, led the opposition to land sales in the Taranaki province of New Zealand in the 1850s.
What was the main cause of deteriorating relations between settlers and Māori in New Zealand in the 1850s?
The increasing settler population and demand for pastoral land caused deteriorating relations between settlers and Māori in New Zealand in the 1850s.
What treaty promised protection to the Māori in New Zealand?
The Treaty of Waitangi promised protection to the Māori in New Zealand.
Who was the member of the cabinet in charge of Māori affairs in New Zealand?
Christopher Richmond was the member of the cabinet in charge of Māori affairs in New Zealand.
What department was Donald McLean the head of in New Zealand?
Donald McLean was the head of the Native Land Purchase Department in New Zealand.
What event in 1859 led to the outbreak of civil strife in New Zealand?
Gore Browne's acceptance of Te Teira's offer to sell the Waitara block, ignoring Wiremu Kīngi's veto, led to the outbreak of civil strife in New Zealand.
Who was sent back as governor of New Zealand in 1861 to act as a peacemaker?
Grey was sent back as governor of New Zealand in 1861 to act as a peacemaker.
What was the result of Grey's defensive measures in New Zealand?
Grey's defensive measures in New Zealand accelerated the extension of conflict and the fighting spread from Taranaki to the Waikato.
What was the outcome of Māori resistance in the Taranaki and Waikato regions of New Zealand by the mid-1860s?
Māori resistance in the Taranaki and Waikato regions of New Zealand had ended by the mid-1860s.

The victors adopted a punitive policy of land confiscation towards the Māori tribes in New Zealand following their defeat.
What was the impact of the land confiscation policy on the Māori tribes in New Zealand?
The land confiscation policy deepened resentment among the Māori tribes in New Zealand and led to a period of withdrawal from settler society.
When did an uneasy peace settle on New Zealand following the Māori resistance?
An uneasy peace settled on New Zealand in 1870 following the Māori resistance.
What act in New Zealand legalized private land transactions between settlers and Māori in 1862?
The Native Land Act of 1862 legalized private land transactions between settlers and Māori in New Zealand.
How many seats in the General Assembly were created for Māori members in New Zealand in 1867?
Four seats in the General Assembly were created for Māori members in New Zealand in 1867.
What right did Māori men gain in New Zealand in 1867?
Māori men gained the vote in New Zealand in 1867.
What event in New Zealand during the 1860s led to a significant increase in the South Island's European population?
The gold rush in New Zealand during the 1860s led to a significant increase in the South Island's European population.
What action did the central government of New Zealand take in 1867 to preserve the colony's reputation?
The central government of New Zealand banned further provincial overseas borrowing in 1867 to preserve the colony's reputation.
Which regions of New Zealand experienced economic prosperity during the 1860s due to the gold rush?
Canterbury and Otago in New Zealand experienced economic prosperity during the 1860s due to the gold rush.
What was the impact of the gold rush on the economy of New Zealand's North Island?
The gold rush had a limited impact on the economy of New Zealand's North Island, which did not recover its previous lead until the 20th century.
Who provided a development policy for New Zealand in 1870?
Julius Vogel provided a development policy for New Zealand in 1870.
What position did Julius Vogel hold when he provided the development policy for New Zealand in 1870?

What was the population of New Zealand at the end of the 1870s?
New Zealand's population doubled to about 500,000 by the end of the 1870s.
What infrastructure developments occurred in New Zealand during the 1870s?
New Zealand saw the construction of roads, bridges, railways, and telegraph systems during the 1870s.

How did the government of New Zealand support immigration during the 1870s?

New Zealand faced falling overseas prices for farm products, declining gold output, government retrenchment, and widespread unemployment in the 1880s.

What period marked economic growth in New Zealand before the depression?
The 1870s marked economic growth in New Zealand before the depression that lasted until 1895.
Who were the leaders of New Zealand's government in the 1880s?

What was the time-honoured remedy for economic issues in New Zealand until 1887?

What battle did Canada participate in from 22 April to 25 May 1915?

In which war did Canada invade Sicily?
Canada invaded Sicily during the Second World War.
What war did Canada participate in that is also known as the Boer War?
