What significant event occurred in Brunei in 1929?
Petroleum production began in Brunei in 1929.
Who occupied Brunei from 1941 to 1945?
The Japanese occupied Brunei from 1941 to 1945.
What change occurred in Brunei's administration in 1959?
Brunei achieved self-government in 1959 and the British resident was replaced by a high commissioner.
What political institution was installed in Brunei in 1962?
A partly elected Legislative Council with limited authority was installed in Brunei in 1962.
What event interrupted Brunei's conversion to a representative government later that year?
A revolt interrupted Brunei's conversion to a representative government later that year.
Who suppressed the revolt in Brunei with the help of British forces?
The sultan suppressed the revolt in Brunei with the help of British forces.
Who abdicated in favour of his eldest son in 1967 in Brunei?
Sultan Omar Ali Saifuddien abdicated in favour of his eldest son in 1967 in Brunei.
Who did Sultan Omar Ali Saifuddien abdicate in favour of in 1967 in Brunei?
Sultan Omar Ali Saifuddien abdicated in favour of his eldest son, Hassanal Bolkiah Muʿizzaddin Waddaulah, in 1967 in Brunei.
What treaty did the United Kingdom and Brunei sign in 1979?
The United Kingdom and Brunei signed a treaty in 1979 whereby Brunei would become fully independent in 1984.
When did Brunei gain independence?
Brunei gained independence on January 1, 1984.
What form of government was introduced in Brunei after independence?
A ministerial form of government was introduced in Brunei after independence.
What ideology did the sultan of Brunei encourage Bruneians to adopt in 1990?
The sultan of Brunei encouraged Bruneians to adopt Melayu Islam Beraja (MIB; “Malay Islamic Monarchy”) in 1990.
Who was appointed as defense minister in Brunei in 1970?
The sultan's father was appointed as defense minister in Brunei in 1970.
What happened to the Legislative Council in Brunei after independence?
The Legislative Council was suspended in Brunei after independence.
What political parties were legalized in Brunei in the mid-1980s?
The Brunei National Democratic Party and the Brunei National United Party were legalized in Brunei in the mid-1980s.
When was the Brunei National United Party allowed to operate again in Brunei?
The Brunei National United Party was allowed to operate again in Brunei beginning in 1995.
What two new parties joined the Brunei National United Party in the early 21st century in Brunei?
The People’s Awareness Party and the National Development Party joined the Brunei National United Party in Brunei in the early 21st century.
When did the sultan reconvene the Legislative Council in Brunei to discuss constitutional amendments?
The sultan reconvened the Legislative Council in Brunei in 2004 to discuss constitutional amendments.
How did the sultan reform the Legislative Council in Brunei in 2005?
The sultan reformed the Legislative Council in Brunei in 2005 with an entirely appointed membership.
What measures did Brunei initially implement toward stricter Islamic practices?
Brunei initially implemented measures such as banning the sale of alcoholic beverages and requiring that Muslim children receive religious instruction.
When did Brunei announce the expansion of Syariah to include criminal offenses by Muslims?
Brunei announced the expansion of Syariah to include criminal offenses by Muslims in October 2013.
What was the first phase of Brunei's Syariah Penal Code implementation in May 2014?

The first phase of Brunei's Syariah Penal Code implementation in May 2014 covered crimes with lesser punishments, such as fines and prison sentences for offenses such as failing to observe the fast during Ramadan.
What was the second phase of Brunei's Syariah Penal Code implementation?
The second phase of Brunei's Syariah Penal Code implementation covered crimes penalized by corporal punishments, such as whipping or amputation for theft.
What was the status of Brunei's relations with Malaysia at independence in 1984?
Brunei's relations with Malaysia were strained over boundary and territorial disputes in Sarawak at independence in 1984.
What agreement did Brunei and Malaysia reach in 2009 regarding territorial claims?
Brunei and Malaysia reached an agreement in 2009 by which Brunei would drop its claim on Limbang and Malaysia would forgo its claim to oil-rich areas in the South China Sea.
When did regular voyages between Indonesia and China begin?
Regular voyages between Indonesia and China began in the 5th century ce.
What was the significance of Palembang in Indonesia during the 7th century?
Palembang in Indonesia was commercially prominent in the 7th century, indicating active involvement in the Persian trade with southern China.
What economic opportunity did Indonesian shippers exploit in southern China during the 5th and 6th centuries?
Indonesian shippers exploited southern China's economic difficulties, which resulted from being cut off from the ancient trade route of Central Asia.
What event in 1292 led to Mongol troops arriving in Indonesia?
Mongol troops arrived in Indonesia in 1292 to avenge an insult to Kublai Khan by Kertanagara, the king of Singhasari.
Who was the ruler of Kaḍiri that seized the palace from Kertanagara in Indonesia?
Jayakatwang, the ruler of Kaḍiri, seized the palace from Kertanagara in Indonesia.
What kingdom successfully controlled Bali, Madura, Malayu, and Tanjungpura in Indonesia?
Majapahit successfully controlled Bali, Madura, Malayu, and Tanjungpura in Indonesia.
Who led Indonesia to its height of power in the mid-14th century?
King Hayam Wuruk and his prime minister, Gajah Mada, led Indonesia to its height of power in the mid-14th century.
When did the decline of Majapahit in Indonesia begin?
The decline of Majapahit in Indonesia began after the death of Gajah Mada in 1364.
What further weakened Majapahit in Indonesia?
The death of Hayam Wuruk in 1389 further weakened Majapahit in Indonesia.
Which countries did Majapahit in Indonesia maintain regular relations with?
Majapahit in Indonesia maintained regular relations with China, Champa, Cambodia, Annam, and Siam.
What empire flourished in Indonesia between the 7th and 13th centuries?
Srivijaya empire flourished in Indonesia between the 7th and 13th centuries.
Where did the kings of Srivijaya in Indonesia establish monasteries?
The kings of Srivijaya in Indonesia established monasteries at Negapattam in southeastern India.
What event occurred in Indonesia in 1025?
Chola seized Palembang, captured the king and carried off his treasures in Indonesia in 1025.
Which kingdom dominated Indonesia by the end of the 12th century?
Malayu, a vassal of Java, dominated Indonesia by the end of the 12th century.
Which Javanese kingdom came to dominate the Indonesian political scene?
Majapahit, a Javanese kingdom, came to dominate the Indonesian political scene.
What dynasty overthrew the Umayyad caliphate in Iraq in 750 CE?
The Abbasid caliphate overthrew the Umayyad caliphate in Iraq in 750 CE.
Who led the open revolt in 747 that resulted in the defeat of Marwān II, the last Umayyad caliph, in Iraq?
Abū Muslim led the open revolt in 747 that resulted in the defeat of Marwān II, the last Umayyad caliph, in Iraq.
What was the outcome of the Battle of the Great Zab River in 750 in Iraq?
The Battle of the Great Zab River in 750 in Iraq resulted in the defeat of Marwān II, the last Umayyad caliph, and the proclamation of the first Abbasid caliph, Abū al-ʿAbbās al-Saffāḥ.
Who was proclaimed the first Abbasid caliph after the defeat of Marwān II in Iraq?
Abū al-ʿAbbās al-Saffāḥ was proclaimed the first Abbasid caliph after the defeat of Marwān II in Iraq.
What was the shift in focus of the caliphate under the Abbasids in Iraq?
Under the Abbasids, the caliphate in Iraq shifted its focus from the West to the East.
What was the significance of the Abbasid support from Persian converts in Iraq?
The support from Persian converts led the Abbasids to take over much of the Persian tradition of government in Iraq.
What was the result of the Abbasid support from pious Muslims in Iraq?
The support from pious Muslims led the Abbasids to acknowledge publicly the embryonic Islamic law in Iraq.
What dynasty ruled Iraq from 750 to 833?
The Abbasids ruled Iraq from 750 to 833, promoting commerce, industry, arts, and science.
Who were the notable rulers of Iraq during the Abbasid period?
Al-Manṣūr, Hārūn al-Rashīd, and al-Maʾmūn were notable rulers of Iraq during the Abbasid period.
What event in 945 marked a significant change in Iraq's power structure?
The Iranian Būyids entered Baghdad in 945, demanding recognition as sole rulers of their controlled territory.
Who was the caliph of Iraq when the Būyids entered Baghdad in 945?
Al-Mustakfī was the caliph of Iraq when the Būyids entered Baghdad in 945.
What was the impact of al-Muʿtaṣim's introduction of non-Muslim mercenaries on Iraq's imperial unity?
Al-Muʿtaṣim's introduction of non-Muslim mercenaries into Iraq's army weakened the base of imperial unity through religion.
What dynasty overpowered the Abbasids in Iraq in 1055?
The Seljuqs overpowered the Abbasids in Iraq in 1055.
Who were the caliphs that restored the authority of the caliphate in Iraq during the Seljuq period?
Al-Mustarshid, al-Muqtafī, and al-Nāṣir were the caliphs that restored the authority of the caliphate in Iraq during the Seljuq period.
What event led to the fall of the Abbasid dynasty in Iraq in 1258?
A Mongol siege of Baghdad led to the fall of the Abbasid dynasty in Iraq in 1258.
What style of government did the islanders of Kiribati adopt after the influx of Samoans in the 14th century?
The islanders of Kiribati adopted a gerontocratic style of government based on rule by elders after the influx of Samoans in the 14th century.
Who were the first settlers to arrive in the Gilbert Islands and Banaba, which are now part of Kiribati?
The first settlers in the Gilbert Islands and Banaba, which are now part of Kiribati, came from Southeast Asia by way of Micronesia.
When did Spanish explorers first sight some of the islands that are now part of Kiribati?
Spanish explorers first sighted some of the islands that are now part of Kiribati in the 16th century.
When did the Gilbert Islands become a British protectorate, which later became part of Kiribati?
The Gilbert Islands became a British protectorate in 1892, which later became part of Kiribati.
What event occurred in Banaba in 1900 that led to its annexation as part of Kiribati?
Banaba was annexed in 1900 after the discovery of its rich phosphate deposits as part of Kiribati.
What was the name of the colony formed in 1916 that included the Gilbert Islands, Ellice Islands, and later other island groups that are now part of Kiribati?
The Gilbert and Ellice Islands Colony was formed in 1916, which included the Gilbert Islands, Ellice Islands, and later other island groups that are now part of Kiribati.
Which country occupied the islands that are now Kiribati during World War II?
Japan occupied the islands that are now Kiribati during World War II.
In what year was an elected House of Representatives established in the colony that is now Kiribati?
An elected House of Representatives was established in 1967 in the colony that is now Kiribati.
What event occurred in 1979 regarding Kiribati?
The Gilbert Islands achieved independence under the name Kiribati in 1979.
When did Lan Xang reach the height of its glory?
Lan Xang was at the height of its glory when the Dutch merchant Gerrit van Wusthof visited Vientiane in 1641.
What event forced Lan Xang's rulers to transfer the capital from Luang Prabang to Vientiane?
Conflict with Myanmar and Thai neighbours forced Lan Xang's rulers to transfer the capital from Luang Prabang to Vientiane in 1563.
What two kingdoms did Lan Xang split into in the 18th century?
Lan Xang split into two separate kingdoms, Vien Chang and Luang Prabang, in the 18th century.
In which century did Lan Xang begin to flourish?
Lan Xang flourished from the 14th century until it was split into two separate kingdoms.
Who established the Joseon kingdom in Korea?
Yi Seong-Gye established the Joseon kingdom in Korea.
What Chinese dynasty did Korea have close relationships with during the Joseon period?
Korea had close relationships with the Ming dynasty of China during the Joseon period.
What ideology was adopted as the state and society ideology in Korea during the Joseon period?
Neo-Confucianism was adopted as the ideology of the state and society in Korea during the Joseon period.
What was the Joseon regime also frequently referred to as in Korea?
The Joseon regime was also frequently referred to as the Yi dynasty in Korea.
Who established a new aristocracy of scholar-officials called the yangban in Korea?
Yi Seong-Gye established a new aristocracy of scholar-officials called the yangban in Korea.
What significant invention occurred in Korea during the reign of King Sejong in 1443?
The Korean phonetic alphabet, Hangul, was invented in Korea during the reign of King Sejong in 1443.
What event devastated Korea in 1592?
An invasion from Japan devastated Korea in 1592.
Who helped repel the Japanese invaders from Korea in 1592?
Chinese troops helped repel the Japanese invaders from Korea in 1592.
During whose reign was a bureaucratic system for government administration established in Korea?
A bureaucratic system for government administration was established in Korea during the reign of King Seongjong.
Who invaded northwestern Korea in 1627?
The Manchu tribes of Manchuria invaded northwestern Korea in 1627.
Which two kings oversaw Korea's recovery from war destruction?
King Yeongjo and King Jeongjo oversaw Korea's recovery from war destruction.
What school of learning emerged in Korea to address administrative problems?
Silhak, or Practical Learning, emerged in Korea to address administrative problems.
What treaty in 1876 defined Korea as an independent state?
The Treaty of Ganghwa defined Korea as an independent state in 1876.
Which two wars did Japan win to gain predominant influence in Korea?
Japan won the Sino-Japanese War and the Russo-Japanese War to gain predominant influence in Korea.
When did Japan formally annex Korea?
Japan formally annexed Korea in 1910.
When was the first known settlement in Cyprus established?
The first known settlement in Cyprus was established as early as 9,000 years ago.
What type of rock found in Cyprus indicates contact with other cultures?
Obsidian, a type of volcanic rock not native to Cyprus, indicates contact with other cultures.
How long was Cyprus uninhabited after the disappearance of Khirokitia?
Cyprus was uninhabited for nearly 2,000 years after the disappearance of Khirokitia.
What styles of pottery were characteristic of the Middle Bronze Age in Cyprus?
Well-made decorative pottery styles were characteristic of the Middle Bronze Age in Cyprus.
Which regions traded with Cyprus during the Middle Bronze Age?
Crete, Anatolia, Syria, and Egypt traded with Cyprus during the Middle Bronze Age.
What was the significance of the Late Bronze Age in Cyprus?
The Late Bronze Age was one of the most formative periods of the life of ancient Cyprus.
Who claimed Cyprus as one of his conquests about 1500 bce?
Thutmose III of Egypt claimed Cyprus as one of his conquests about 1500 bce.
What type of pottery was imported from mainland Greece to Cyprus around 1400 bce?
Mycenaean pottery was imported from mainland Greece to Cyprus around 1400 bce.
When did Greek immigration from the Peloponnese to Cyprus occur?
Greek immigration from the Peloponnese to Cyprus occurred after 1200 bce.
What language became predominant in Cyprus since the start of the 1st millennium bce?
The Greek language became predominant in Cyprus since the start of the 1st millennium bce.
Which six ancient Greek kingdoms were founded on Cyprus?
The six ancient Greek kingdoms founded on Cyprus were Curium, Paphos, Marion, Soli, Lapithos, and Salamis.
What was the origin of the Greek immigrants who settled in Cyprus?
The Greek immigrants who settled in Cyprus were of Peloponnesian origin, specifically from Arcadia.
What kingdom in Cyprus remained under the control of the earlier indigenous inhabitants?
Amathus remained under the control of the earlier indigenous inhabitants in Cyprus.
What type of burials of the royal family of Salamis in Cyprus are evidence of an advancing civilization in the late Iron Age?
Spectacular chariot burials of the royal family of Salamis in Cyprus are evidence of an advancing civilization in the late Iron Age.
What ancient empire was Bolivia the center of before the 15th century?
The Tiwanaku empire was the center of Bolivia before the 15th century.
Which empire ruled Bolivia from the 15th to the early 16th century?
The Inca empire ruled Bolivia from the 15th to the early 16th century.
What Spanish administrative division did Bolivia become part of after the arrival of the conquistadores?
The Viceroyalty of Peru was the Spanish administrative division Bolivia became part of after the arrival of the conquistadores.
What valuable resource did Bolivia provide to Spain during the colonial period?
Bolivia provided Spain with immense wealth in silver during the colonial period.
When did Uruguay become an independent country?
Uruguay became an independent country in 1828.
Which European countries had strong ties with Uruguay?
Uruguay had strong ties with the United Kingdom, France, and Italy.
What period of repressive military rule occurred in Uruguay?
Uruguay experienced a period of repressive military rule from 1973 to 1985.
When was civilian democratic rule restored in Uruguay?
Civilian democratic rule was restored in Uruguay in 1985.
What were the two major precolonial societies in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
The Kongo kingdom and the Luba-Lunda states were the two major precolonial societies in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
How did power emanate from the capital to outlying areas in the Democratic Republic of the Congo's precolonial societies?
Power emanated from the capital to outlying areas through appointed chiefs or local clan heads in the Democratic Republic of the Congo's precolonial societies.
What often led to civil strife in the Democratic Republic of the Congo's precolonial societies?
Competition for the kingship often led to civil strife in the Democratic Republic of the Congo's precolonial societies.
What group attacked the kingdom in the Democratic Republic of the Congo by the late 16th century?
The Imbangala, referred to as Jaga in contemporary sources, attacked the kingdom in the Democratic Republic of the Congo by the late 16th century.
Which two groups experienced fragmentation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo two centuries after the Imbangala attacks?
The Lunda and the Luba experienced fragmentation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo two centuries after the Imbangala attacks.
What factors undermined resistance to colonial forces in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?

Internecine raids and wars, increased devastation from sophisticated firearms, and divisions between collaborators and resisters undermined resistance to colonial forces in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Who initiated the conquest of the territory that became the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
King Leopold II of the Belgians initiated the conquest of the territory that became the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
What event in 1874-77 drew King Leopold II's attention to the region of the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
Henry Morton Stanley's exploration of the Congo River in 1874-77 drew King Leopold II's attention to the region of the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
What was the name of the entity established by Leopold in the Democratic Republic of the Congo from 1885-1908?
The Congo Free State was established by Leopold in the Democratic Republic of the Congo from 1885-1908.
What was the stated humanitarian mission of Leopold's African International Association in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?

Leopold's African International Association had a stated humanitarian mission of ending slavery and bringing religion and the benefits of modern life to the Congolese in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Who owned the Congo Free State before it was annexed by Belgium in 1908 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
King Leopold owned the Congo Free State before it was annexed by Belgium in 1908 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
What event occurred in 1908 regarding the Congo Free State in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
The Belgian Parliament voted to annex the Congo Free State in 1908 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
What was the result of the Belgian Parliament's vote in 1908 for the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
The Belgian Parliament's vote in 1908 placed the Congo Free State under Belgian rule in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
What legacy did the Congo Free State leave in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
The Congo Free State left a legacy of anti-Western sentiment in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
When was the Kingdom of the Netherlands founded?
The Kingdom of the Netherlands was founded in 1579.
What agreement formed a closer union within the Low Countries in the Netherlands on January 23, 1579?
The Union of Utrecht formed a closer union within the Low Countries in the Netherlands on January 23, 1579.
Which provinces and cities were the first signatories to the Union of Utrecht in the Netherlands?
Holland, Zeeland, Utrecht, Gelderland, and Zutphen were the first signatories to the Union of Utrecht in the Netherlands.
What was the ultimate goal of the Union of Utrecht in the Netherlands?
The Union of Utrecht was ultimately designed to strengthen the central government in Brussels in the Netherlands.
What became the actual outcome of the Union of Utrecht in the Netherlands?
The Union of Utrecht became the foundation of a separate state and a distinct country in the northern Netherlands.
What was the new state named after the Union of Utrecht in the Netherlands?
The United Provinces of the Netherlands, or the Dutch Republic, was the new state name after the Union of Utrecht.
What was the government of the Netherlands known as in the international community?
The States General was the government of the Netherlands known in the international community.
What term did the English apply exclusively to the Hollanders in the Netherlands?
The English applied the term Dutch exclusively to the Hollanders in the Netherlands.
What was the basis of the new northern union in the Netherlands?
The treaty formed the basis of the new northern union in the Netherlands, establishing a military league to resist the Spaniards on a perpetual basis.
How did the provinces in the Netherlands unite according to the treaty?
The provinces in the Netherlands united for all time as if they were a single province, each remaining sovereign in its internal affairs but acting as a body in foreign policy.
What was the requirement for decisions on war and peace in the Netherlands?
Decisions on war and peace in the Netherlands required unanimous agreement.
Who retained formal sovereignty over the Netherlands during the Union of Utrecht?
The king of Spain retained formal sovereignty over the Netherlands during the Union of Utrecht.
What was the religious outcome in the key provinces of the Netherlands after the Union of Utrecht?
The Calvinists gained predominance and a monopoly on public religious practice in the key provinces of Holland and Zeeland in the Netherlands.
What was the Pacification of Ghent's significance in the Netherlands?
The Pacification of Ghent was a religious settlement that the Union of Utrecht moved away from in the Netherlands.
Who was named governor-general by the States General in 1577 in the Netherlands?
Archduke Matthias of Habsburg was named governor-general by the States General in 1577 in the Netherlands.
What document did the States General issue in 1581 in the Netherlands?
The States General issued the Act of Abjuration in 1581 in the Netherlands.
What was declared by the States General in 1581 in the Netherlands?
The States General declared that Philip had forfeited his sovereignty over the provinces in 1581 in the Netherlands.
What was the outcome of the Act of Abjuration in the Netherlands?
The Act of Abjuration resulted in a declaration of independence for the whole of the Low Countries in the Netherlands.
What was the result of the military and political events of the next decade in the Netherlands?
The military and political events of the next decade limited the permanent effect of the declaration of independence to the northern provinces under the closer union of Utrecht in the Netherlands.
Who assassinated William in the Netherlands on July 10, 1584?
Balthasar Gérard, a fanatical young Roman Catholic from Franche-Comté, assassinated William in the Netherlands on July 10, 1584.
What was the result of William's death in the Netherlands?
William's death resulted in the almost unnoticed disappearance of the central government in Brussels in the Netherlands.
Where did the States General meet after William's death in the Netherlands?
The States General met at The Hague in Holland after William's death in the Netherlands.
Which provinces did the States General represent after William's death in the Netherlands?
The States General represented only the provinces in the Union of Utrecht after William's death in the Netherlands.
What form of government did Thailand have until the revolution in 1932?
Thailand was ruled by an absolute monarchy until the revolution in 1932.
What type of government did Thailand adopt after the 1932 revolution?
Thailand became a constitutional monarchy after the 1932 revolution.
What was Thailand officially called until 1939?
Thailand was officially called Siam until 1939.
What type of parliament has Thailand had since the 1932 revolution?
Thailand has had an elected parliament since the 1932 revolution.
What event occurred in Thailand in 2006?
The military, aligned with the monarchy, overthrew an elected government in Thailand in 2006.
When were new parliamentary elections held in Thailand after the 2006 crisis?
New parliamentary elections were held in Thailand in 2007.
When did Haiti win independence from France?
Haiti won independence from France in 1804.
What was the significance of Haiti's independence in the Americas?
Haiti became the second country in the Americas to free itself from colonial rule after the United States.
What policy did Bhutan's rulers implement to maintain isolation from the outside world?
Bhutan's rulers banned foreigners until well into the 20th century to maintain isolation.
What changes did Bhutan begin to make under pressure from neighboring countries?
Bhutan began to commit to policies of social and administrative reform coupled with economic development under pressure from neighboring countries.
What was the result of Bhutan's policy changes under pressure from neighboring countries?
Bhutan began to cultivate its international contacts as a result of its policy changes under pressure from neighboring countries.
Who became the king of Bhutan and acquired the title of dharma raja four to five centuries ago?
Sheptoon La-Pha became the king of Bhutan and acquired the title of dharma raja four to five centuries ago.
Who succeeded Sheptoon La-Pha and consolidated Bhutan's administrative organization?
Doopgein Sheptoon succeeded Sheptoon La-Pha and consolidated Bhutan's administrative organization through the appointment of regional penlops and jungpens.
What title did the minister acquire when appointed to exercise temporal power in Bhutan?
The minister acquired the title of deb raja when appointed to exercise temporal power in Bhutan.
What positions were established by Doopgein Sheptoon to consolidate Bhutan's administrative organization?
Doopgein Sheptoon established the positions of regional penlops and jungpens to consolidate Bhutan's administrative organization.
What dual system of governance existed in Bhutan until the early 20th century?
Bhutan had a system of two supreme authorities—a dharma raja for spiritual affairs and a deb raja for temporal matters—until the early 20th century.
How was succession to the spiritual office of dharma raja determined in Bhutan?
Succession to the spiritual office of dharma raja in Bhutan was dependent on what was considered a verifiable reincarnation of the deceased dharma raja.
What event led to the cessation of the dharma raja office in Bhutan?
The dharma raja office in Bhutan ceased to exist when no reincarnation was found after the death of the last dharma raja in the 1930s.
What characterized much of the 19th century in Bhutan?
Much of the 19th century in Bhutan was plagued by a series of civil wars as the governors of the various territories contended for power and influence.
Who was elected as the hereditary king of Bhutan in 1907?
Ugyen Wangchuk of Tongsa was elected as the hereditary king of Bhutan in 1907.
What position was Ugyen Wangchuk of Tongsa holding before becoming the hereditary king of Bhutan?
Ugyen Wangchuk of Tongsa was the penlop of Tongsa before becoming the hereditary king of Bhutan.
Who elected Ugyen Wangchuk as the hereditary king of Bhutan in 1907?
A council of lamas, abbots, councillors, and laymen elected Ugyen Wangchuk as the hereditary king of Bhutan in 1907.
What event preceded the election of Ugyen Wangchuk as the hereditary king of Bhutan in 1907?
The dharma raja had died and the deb raja had withdrawn into a life of contemplation before the election of Ugyen Wangchuk as the hereditary king of Bhutan in 1907.
Who became Bhutan's druk gyalpo in 1907 with British approval?
Ugyen Wangchuk became Bhutan's druk gyalpo in 1907 with British approval.
What treaty did Bhutan conclude with India in August 1949?
Bhutan concluded a treaty with India in August 1949, whereby India assumed Britain's former role toward Bhutan.
What was the result of the 1910 treaty between Bhutan and Great Britain?

The 1910 treaty between Bhutan and Great Britain resulted in Bhutan agreeing to be guided by Great Britain in external affairs in return for an increased annual subsidy and the promise of noninterference in Bhutan's internal affairs.
What was transferred to Bhutan as part of the 1949 treaty with India?
A strip of land in the Duars of Assam, known as the Dewangiri, was transferred to Bhutan as part of the 1949 treaty with India.
What event in 1950 prompted Bhutan to strengthen its ties with India?
The People’s Republic of China taking control of Tibet in 1950 prompted Bhutan to strengthen its ties with India.
What measures did India take in the 1950s to address the Chinese threat to Bhutan?
India strengthened its defensive garrisons along Bhutan’s northern border with Tibet in the 1950s.
What significant step toward ending Bhutan’s isolation was taken with the arrival of the first automobiles?
The arrival of the first automobiles in Bhutan was a significant step toward ending Bhutan’s geographical isolation.
What event terminated the early Bronze Age culture in Jordan?
A nomadic invasion terminated the early Bronze Age culture in Jordan, destroying principal towns and villages.
When did the Egyptians arrive in Jordan to reestablish security?
The Egyptians arrived in Jordan after 1580 bce to reestablish security.
What discovery confirmed that Jordan had a settled population from 1900 to 1300 bce?
The discovery of a small temple at Amman with Egyptian, Mycenaean, and Cypriot imported objects confirmed that Jordan had a settled population from 1900 to 1300 bce.
What kingdoms were mentioned in biblical accounts of Jordan from the Middle Bronze Age onward?
Gilead, Moab, and Midian were kingdoms mentioned in biblical accounts of Jordan from the Middle Bronze Age onward.
Which tribes settled in the conquered territory of the Ammonites, Amorites, and Bashan in Jordan?
The Israelite tribes of Gad, Reuben, and half of the Manasseh group settled in the conquered territory of the Ammonites, Amorites, and Bashan in Jordan.
What characterized the period from 1300–1000 bce in Jordan?
The period from 1300–1000 bce in Jordan was marked by constant raiding from both sides of the Jordan River.
What happened to Ammon with its capital, Rabbath Ammon (modern Amman), after the death of David in Jordan?
Ammon with its capital, Rabbath Ammon (modern Amman), regained independence on the death of David in Jordan.
Who captured Sela (Petra), the capital, in Jordan?
Amaziah, a Hebrew king, captured Sela (Petra), the capital, in Jordan.
Who overran the eastern part of Jordan as far as Edom?
Adadnirari III, the Assyrian ruler, overran the eastern part of Jordan as far as Edom.
Who retaken Jordan in 734–733 and devastated Israel?
Tiglath-pileser III, the Assyrian ruler, retaken Jordan in 734–733 and devastated Israel.
When did the Assyrian empire fall in Jordan?
The Assyrian empire fell in Jordan in 612 bce.
Who conquered the kingdom of Nabataea in 64–63 bce and established the Decapolis in Jordan?
Pompey conquered the kingdom of Nabataea in 64–63 bce and established the Decapolis in Jordan.
What was the name of the Roman province that Jordan was absorbed into in 106 ce?
Nabataea was absorbed into the Roman Empire as the province of Palaestina Tertia in 106 ce.
Who led an ill-starred expedition from Jordan in 25–24 bce in search of Arabia Felix?
Aelius Gallus led an ill-starred expedition from Jordan in 25–24 bce in search of Arabia Felix.
What was the name of the new Roman province that included most of Jordan, with its capital first at Petra?
Arabia Petraea was the new Roman province that included most of Jordan, with its capital first at Petra.
What event in 636 led to Muslim rule over Jordan?
The Battle of the Yarmouk River led to Muslim rule over Jordan.

Early Qing (1644 CE–1796 CE) — North China: What event marked the beginning of the Early Qing period in North China?

The Early Qing period began in 1644 CE when Qing forces captured the Ming capital at Beijing from rebels and held a funeral for the last Ming emperor to symbolize Qing inheritance of the Mandate of Heaven, marking the start of the Early Qing period in North China.
Early Qing (1644 CE–1796 CE) — North China: What was the administrative structure of the central government during the Early Qing period in North China?

The central government of the Early Qing period was headed by the emperor and included a 'Grand Council', created by the Yongzheng emperor and expanded by the Qianlong emperor, which ruled over the central ministries and provided a way for the emperor to circumvent the official bureaucracy for many decisions in North China.
Early Qing (1644 CE–1796 CE) — North China: Who were some of the notable rulers of the Early Qing period in North China?
The Early Qing period had three notable rulers - Kangxi, Yongzheng, and Qianlong - who are historically known as great rulers and during whose reigns China was extremely prosperous in North China.
Early Qing (1644 CE–1796 CE) — North China: What was the population of China during the Early Qing period?

According to Chinese census and registration counts, the population of China in 1749 CE was about 177.5 million during the Early Qing period, and by 1851 the population had reached 431.9 million people.
Early Qing (1644 CE–1796 CE) — North China: What were some of the cultural developments that flourished during the Early Qing period in North China?

During the Early Qing period, print journalism, theatre, and novels flourished under the Qing emperors in North China, although the period is not well known for poetry, painting, and porcelain like previous periods.
Early Qing (1644 CE–1796 CE) — North China: How did the Qing provincial government function during the Early Qing period in the Middle Yellow River Valley?

The Qing provincial government consisted of governors who controlled a hierarchical system of officials, prefects, county chiefs, country magistrates, and clerks, with high-ranking officials typically of Manchu descent, in the Middle Yellow River Valley during the Early Qing period.
Late Qing (1796 CE–1912 CE) — North China: What was the Qing Dynasty and when did the Late Qing period occur in North China?

The Qing Dynasty was China's last imperial dynasty, and the Late Qing period occurred from 1796 to 1912 in North China, marked by internal turmoil and foreign incursions into its territory and economic sphere, affecting the Middle Yellow River Valley.
Late Qing (1796 CE–1912 CE) — North China: What significant event occurred in 1839 CE during the Late Qing period in North China?

The First Opium War broke out in 1839 CE when a Chinese commissioner attempted to block opium trade in Guangzhou harbour, highlighting the economic problems faced by the Qing emperors in North China during the Late Qing period.
Late Qing (1796 CE–1912 CE) — North China: What was the impact of the Opium Wars on the Late Qing economy in North China?

The Opium Wars led to a large trade imbalance, drained China's economy of silver, and depreciated the value of copper coins, significantly affecting the economy of North China during the Late Qing period.
Late Qing (1796 CE–1912 CE) — North China: How did foreign powers exploit China during the Late Qing period in North China?

Foreign powers, including Great Britain, Japan, Germany, and France, exploited their tax-free status, established concessions in China, and claimed colonial territories, to the detriment of local Chinese producers in North China during the Late Qing period.
Late Qing (1796 CE–1912 CE) — North China: What was the outcome of the Boxer Rebellion in 1900 CE during the Late Qing period in North China?

The Boxer Rebellion was a peasant uprising that targeted foreigners in 1900 CE, but ultimately failed to overthrow the Qing rulers in North China, who were already facing significant internal and external challenges during the Late Qing period.
Late Qing (1796 CE–1912 CE) — North China: What was the political organization of the Late Qing government in North China?

The Late Qing maintained a traditional imperial-style Chinese government headed by an emperor and central bureaucracy, with provincial government consisting of governors who controlled a hierarchical system of officials in North China.
Late Qing (1796 CE–1912 CE) — North China: How did the population of Late Qing China change during the 19th century in North China?

The population of Late Qing China experienced extremely rapid growth, reaching 431.9 million people by 1851, but subsequent censuses were disrupted by rebellions in North China during the Late Qing period.
Archaic Basin of Mexico (6000 BCE–2001 BCE) — Mexico: What characterized the Archaic Basin of Mexico period in terms of lifestyle transition?
The Archaic Basin of Mexico period was characterized by a long, gradual transition from a lifestyle centred on big-game hunting to a sedentary, agricultural lifestyle.
Archaic Basin of Mexico (6000 BCE–2001 BCE) — Mexico: What defines Archaic sites in the Basin of Mexico?
Archaic Basin of Mexico sites are defined by their lack of both large animal remains and ceramics.
Archaic Basin of Mexico (6000 BCE–2001 BCE) — Mexico: What preceded the Archaic Basin of Mexico period?
The Archaic Basin of Mexico period was preceded by the Paleo-Indian period, which had a lifestyle centred on big-game hunting.
Archaic Basin of Mexico (6000 BCE–2001 BCE) — Mexico: What period succeeded the Archaic Basin of Mexico period?
The Archaic Basin of Mexico period was succeeded by the Formative period, which had a sedentary, agricultural lifestyle.
Archaic Basin of Mexico (6000 BCE–2001 BCE) — Mexico: What information is lacking about the Archaic Basin of Mexico period?
The Archaic Basin of Mexico period lacks population estimates and information on the political organisation of settlements at the time.
Initial Formative Basin of Mexico (2000 BCE–1201 BCE) — Mexico: What was the Initial Formative Basin of Mexico period in the region of Mexico?
The Initial Formative Basin of Mexico period was a phase of prehistory in the Basin of Mexico, roughly corresponding to modern-day Mexico City, that occurred from 2000 to 1201 BCE.
Initial Formative Basin of Mexico (2000 BCE–1201 BCE) — Mexico: What significant developments occurred at the start of the Initial Formative Basin of Mexico period?
At the start of the Initial Formative Basin of Mexico period, maize, squash, and other food crops had been domesticated, laying the groundwork for further developments in the region during this time.
Initial Formative Basin of Mexico (2000 BCE–1201 BCE) — Mexico: When did the earliest known pottery and settled villages emerge in the Initial Formative Basin of Mexico?
The Initial Formative Basin of Mexico saw the emergence of the earliest known pottery and settled villages between 1600 and 1400 BCE, a few centuries after the period began.
Initial Formative Basin of Mexico (2000 BCE–1201 BCE) — Mexico: What can be estimated about the population size of the site of Tlatilco during the Initial Formative Basin of?
The Initial Formative Basin of Mexico period includes the settlement of Tlatilco, which may have had a population of between 3,000 and 13,000 people, based on its size of about 65 hectares.
Initial Formative Basin of Mexico (2000 BCE–1201 BCE) — Mexico: What changes occurred in the Basin's settlement system around 1500 BCE during the Initial Formative Basin of?

The Initial Formative Basin of Mexico period saw the development of a two-tiered settlement system in the Basin around 1500 BCE, suggesting a hierarchical relationship between larger and smaller settlements.
Initial Formative Basin of Mexico (2000 BCE–1201 BCE) — Mexico: How did access to food impact the social structure during the Initial Formative Basin of Mexico period?

The Initial Formative Basin of Mexico period likely saw the emergence of social inequalities and political hierarchies due to the ability of certain segments of the population to intensify and control access to staples and ceremonial foods.
Early Formative Basin of Mexico (1200 BCE–801 BCE) — Mexico: What geographical region in Mexico is associated with the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period?
The Early Formative Basin of Mexico period is associated with the Basin of Mexico, a highlands plateau in central Mexico, roughly corresponding to modern-day Mexico City.
Early Formative Basin of Mexico (1200 BCE–801 BCE) — Mexico: What significant developments occurred during the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period in Mesoamerica?

During the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period, sociopolitical hierarchies emerged and expanded, and craft specialisation developed, such as the manufacture of obsidian blades, characterising the Early Formative period.
Early Formative Basin of Mexico (1200 BCE–801 BCE) — Mexico: What is notable about the settlement system that emerged during the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period?
The Early Formative Basin of Mexico period saw the establishment of a two-tiered settlement system, a significant development in the region's sociopolitical hierarchy.
Early Formative Basin of Mexico (1200 BCE–801 BCE) — Mexico: What was a distinctive feature of the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period in terms of ceramics?

The Early Formative Basin of Mexico period is characterised by the earliest shared style in Mesoamerica, featuring a standardized set of symbols typically carved or incised on black, black-and-white, and white or white-slipped ceramics, distinctive of the Early Formative period.
Early Formative Basin of Mexico (1200 BCE–801 BCE) — Mexico: What can be said about the population of the Basin of Mexico during the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period?

The Early Formative Basin of Mexico period had an estimated population of approximately 5,000 people in the Basin of Mexico around 1150 BC, with the largest known settlement, Tlatilco, possibly having between 1,000 and 4,000 inhabitants, characteristic of the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period.
Early Formative Basin of Mexico (1200 BCE–801 BCE) — Mexico: How large was the settlement of Tlatilco during the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period?

The Early Formative Basin of Mexico period saw Tlatilco, the largest known settlement, spanning over 40 hectares, with a possible population of between 1,000 and 4,000 inhabitants, during the Early Formative Basin of Mexico period.
Middle Formative Basin of Mexico (800 BCE–401 BCE) — Mexico: What characterised the Middle Formative Basin of Mexico period in the Basin of Mexico region of Mexico?

The Middle Formative Basin of Mexico period was characterised by increasingly widespread and elaborate public architecture, more distinctive regional pottery styles, more extensive greenstone trade, and an increased use of stone for symbolic expression.
Middle Formative Basin of Mexico (800 BCE–401 BCE) — Mexico: What was the estimated population of the Basin of Mexico around 650 BC during the Middle Formative Basin of Mexico?
The Middle Formative Basin of Mexico period saw an estimated population of approximately 25,000 people in the Basin of Mexico around 650 BC.
Middle Formative Basin of Mexico (800 BCE–401 BCE) — Mexico: What was the population of the largest known settlement, Chalcatzingo, during the Middle Formative Basin of Mexico?
The Middle Formative Basin of Mexico period had the largest known settlement, Chalcatzingo, with a population of between 3,000 and 5,000 people.
Middle Formative Basin of Mexico (800 BCE–401 BCE) — Mexico: How did settlement hierarchies change during the Middle Formative Basin of Mexico in the Mexico region?
During the Middle Formative Basin of Mexico, settlement hierarchies either maintained or increased the number of levels in the Basin of Mexico region of Mexico.
Late Formative Basin of Mexico (400 BCE–101 BCE) — Mexico: What was the geographical location of the Late Formative Basin of Mexico period?
The Late Formative Basin of Mexico period was located in the Basin of Mexico, a highlands plateau in central Mexico, roughly corresponding to modern-day Mexico City, in the Mexico region.
Late Formative Basin of Mexico (400 BCE–101 BCE) — Mexico: What characterized the polities in Mesoamerica during the Late Formative Basin of Mexico period?

During the Late Formative Basin of Mexico period, polities throughout Mesoamerica experienced increases in wealth, influence, and hierarchical complexity, which was also evident in the Basin of Mexico.
Late Formative Basin of Mexico (400 BCE–101 BCE) — Mexico: Which cities became major regional centers in the Basin of Mexico during the Late Formative Basin of Mexico period?
The Late Formative Basin of Mexico period saw Cuicuilco, Tlapacoya, and Cholula become major regional centers with monumental architecture in the Basin of Mexico.
Late Formative Basin of Mexico (400 BCE–101 BCE) — Mexico: What was the estimated population of the largest known settlement, Cuicuilco, during the Late Formative Basin of?
The Late Formative Basin of Mexico period had Cuicuilco as its largest known settlement, which may have had a population of at least 20,000 across 400 ha.
Late Formative Basin of Mexico (400 BCE–101 BCE) — Mexico: What was the nature of political power during the Late Formative Basin of Mexico period?

The Late Formative Basin of Mexico period was characterized by political power that was inherently theocratic, although the exact administrative mechanisms prevalent at the time remain unclear in the context of the Late Formative Basin of Mexico.
Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico (100 BCE–99 CE) — Mexico: What geographical region in Mexico is associated with the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period?
The Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period is associated with the Basin of Mexico, a highlands plateau in central Mexico roughly corresponding to modern-day Mexico City.
Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico (100 BCE–99 CE) — Mexico: What notable city emerged during the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period?

During the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period, Teotihuacan emerged as the largest and most populous city in the New World, with the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period marking a significant time in its development.
Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico (100 BCE–99 CE) — Mexico: What was the estimated population of Teotihuacan by 150 CE during the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period?

The Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period saw Teotihuacan grow to have a population ranging between 60,000 to 80,000 inhabitants by 150 CE, highlighting the significance of the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period in the city's expansion.
Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico (100 BCE–99 CE) — Mexico: What was the nature of political power during the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period?

The Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period was characterized by political power that was inherently theocratic, with the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period marked by this distinct form of governance.
Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico (100 BCE–99 CE) — Mexico: How clear are the administrative mechanisms of the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period?

The Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period remains unclear in terms of its exact administrative mechanisms, beyond the fact that political power was theocratic during this time in the Terminal Formative Basin of Mexico period.
Classic Basin of Mexico (100 CE–649 CE) — Mexico: What characterised the Classic Basin of Mexico period in Mexico?

The Classic Basin of Mexico period was characterised by sophisticated forms of artistic expression and high levels of craft specialisation, pronounced differences between the material culture of the wealthier classes and that of the poorer ones, and trade networks extending farther and farther across the wider region.
Classic Basin of Mexico (100 CE–649 CE) — Mexico: What was the dominant centre in the Basin of Mexico during the Classic Basin of Mexico period?

The Classic Basin of Mexico period had Teotihuacan as the dominant centre in the Basin of Mexico, with the presence of Teotihuacano artefacts outside of the Basin testifying to its far-ranging influence.
Classic Basin of Mexico (100 CE–649 CE) — Mexico: How large was the city of Teotihuacan during the Classic Basin of Mexico period?
During the Classic Basin of Mexico period, Teotihuacan was the largest city in the world, with a population of about 100,000 or 125,000.
Classic Basin of Mexico (100 CE–649 CE) — Mexico: What is known about the political organisation of Teotihuacan during the Classic Basin of Mexico period?

Relatively little is known regarding Teotihuacan's political organisation during the Classic Basin of Mexico period, with no consensus on the existence of a ruler's palace at the site, nor have royal burials or depictions of individual rulers been found.
Classic Basin of Mexico (100 CE–649 CE) — Mexico: How was power possibly distributed in Teotihuacan during the Classic Basin of Mexico period?

The Classic Basin of Mexico period's Teotihuacan possibly had power shared or distributed, perhaps governed by a committee of representatives from different interest groups, and/or spokespeople for some or each of the city's thousands of apartment compounds, as suggested by representations of elite personages shown in groups and partaking in processions.
Epiclassic Basin of Mexico (650 CE–899 CE) — Mexico: What was the Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period in the region of Mexico?

The Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period, also known as the Late Classic period, was a phase of prehistory in the Basin of Mexico, roughly corresponding to modern-day Mexico City, that occurred from approximately 650 to 899 CE.
Epiclassic Basin of Mexico (650 CE–899 CE) — Mexico: What happened to Teotihuacan during the Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period?
During the Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period, Teotihuacan had diminished in size and lost its hold over the region.
Epiclassic Basin of Mexico (650 CE–899 CE) — Mexico: How did the population of major centres compare to Teotihuacan during the Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period?
The Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period saw none of the major centres, such as Cantona, Xochicalco, and Cacaxtla, match Teotihuacan, with their populations likely not surpassing 25-30,000.
Epiclassic Basin of Mexico (650 CE–899 CE) — Mexico: What cultural practice became widespread during the Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period?

The Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period saw the worship of the feathered snake become widespread throughout Mesoamerica, as indicated by the broad distribution of artistic representations of this deity or culture hero.
Epiclassic Basin of Mexico (650 CE–899 CE) — Mexico: What was a notable aspect of ritual practice and artistic expression during the Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period?
The Epiclassic Basin of Mexico period was marked by a renewed emphasis on human sacrifice in both ritual practice and artistic expression.
Toltecs (900 CE–1199 CE) — Mexico: What region in Mexico was under the control of the city of Tula during the Toltecs period?
The Toltecs were based in the Basin of Mexico, a highlands plateau in central Mexico, during their period of control, roughly corresponding to modern-day Mexico City.
Toltecs (900 CE–1199 CE) — Mexico: What was the significance of Tula in relation to the Toltecs?
The Toltecs had a city known as Tula, which some scholars argue corresponded to Tollan, the capital of the Toltecs, according to the Aztecs and other Mesoamerican sources.
Toltecs (900 CE–1199 CE) — Mexico: How did the Toltecs' influence extend beyond the Basin of Mexico?
The Toltecs' influence extended beyond the confines of the Basin of Mexico, and they extracted food and other revenue from their surrounding region, indicating their power and control.
Toltecs (900 CE–1199 CE) — Mexico: What can be inferred about the administrative system of the Toltecs based on the city of Tula?

The Toltecs, like the city of Tula, may have relied on an administrative system wherein power was distributed among different sectors of society, as suggested by the city's many buildings with large halls and evidence for feasts and other types of large gatherings.
Toltecs (900 CE–1199 CE) — Mexico: What was the population size of the city of Tula during the Toltecs period?
The city of Tula, which was associated with the Toltecs, had up to 60,000 inhabitants during their period.
Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico (1200 CE–1426 CE) — Mexico: What was the Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico period in the region of Mexico?
The Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico was a phase of prehistory in the Basin of Mexico, roughly corresponding to modern-day Mexico City, that occurred from approximately 1200 to 1426 CE.
Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico (1200 CE–1426 CE) — Mexico: What replaced Tula's control over the Basin of Mexico during the Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico period?
The Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico saw the replacement of Tula's control with several city-states, known as altepetl, which ruled the region.
Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico (1200 CE–1426 CE) — Mexico: How did the city-states in the Basin of Mexico during the Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico period eventually?
Toward the end of the Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico, the city-states came to form growing confederations, paving the way for the Aztec empire.
Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico (1200 CE–1426 CE) — Mexico: What was the population size of major centers like Azcapotzalco, Texcoco, or Cholula during the Middle?
The Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico saw major centres such as Azcapotzalco, Texcoco, or Cholula likely having between 20,000 and 30,000 inhabitants.
Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico (1200 CE–1426 CE) — Mexico: How were the altepetl city-states in the Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico governed?
Each altepetl in the Middle Postclassic Basin of Mexico was ruled by a king, known as a tlatoani, and a council of nobles.
Aztec Empire (1427 CE–1526 CE) — Mexico: What was the geographical location where the Aztec Empire rose to power?
The Aztec Empire rose to power in the Basin of Mexico, a highlands plateau in central Mexico, during the Late Postclassic period.
Aztec Empire (1427 CE–1526 CE) — Mexico: What alliance led to the formation of the Aztec Empire?

The Aztec Empire was born from the Triple Alliance between the city-states of Tenochtitlan, Texcoco, and Tlacopan, who agreed to collaborate on a campaign of territorial expansion and share the resulting tribute and tax payments.
Aztec Empire (1427 CE–1526 CE) — Mexico: How did the power of the Aztec Empire expand in Northern Mesoamerica?

The Aztec Empire came to control a significant portion of Northern Mesoamerica, with the main exception being the West, which largely remained under the control of the Tarascans, despite some military successes by the Triple Alliance.
Aztec Empire (1427 CE–1526 CE) — Mexico: What was the role of Tenochtitlan in the Aztec Empire?
Tenochtitlan became the de-facto administrative capital of the Aztec Empire, with its ruler holding the title huey tlatoani, and its power was strongest over the empire's central provinces.
Aztec Empire (1427 CE–1526 CE) — Mexico: What was the population of Tenochtitlan by the time of the Spanish conquest?
By the time of the Spanish conquest in the 1520s, the Aztec Empire's capital, Tenochtitlan, likely housed between 150,000 and 250,000 people, perhaps even more.
Hawaii I (1000 CE–1200 CE) — Polynesia: What is the estimated time period of the initial settlement of the Hawaiian archipelago by Polynesian voyagers during the Hawaii I?

The Hawaii I period, which spans from around 1000 to 1200, is believed to have started with the initial settlement of the Hawaiian archipelago by Polynesian voyagers, with estimates suggesting that the archipelago was first colonized between 1000 and 1100.
Hawaii I (1000 CE–1200 CE) — Polynesia: What was the likely size of the founding population of Hawaii I in Polynesia?

The Hawaii I period, which occurred in Polynesia, had a founding population that was probably about 100 people, due to the limited capacity of the canoes the first settlers likely used to reach the islands.
Hawaii I (1000 CE–1200 CE) — Polynesia: How did the population of Hawaii I in the Big Island of Polynesia change between 1000 and 1200?

The Hawaii I period, which took place in the Big Island of Polynesia, saw a population that probably grew somewhat between 1000 and 1200, although no up-to-date estimates could be found in the literature for this specific time period.
Hawaii I (1000 CE–1200 CE) — Polynesia: What was the political organization of the ancient Polynesians during the Hawaii I period?

The Hawaii I period, which occurred in Polynesia, was characterized by a political organization where ancient Polynesians recognized the authority of the *ariki, that is, the head of a lineage, who had both secular and sacred authority and was in charge of most, if not all, rituals.
Hawaii I (1000 CE–1200 CE) — Polynesia: When did the earliest island-wide unitary kingdom on the Big Island of Hawaii I emerge?

The Hawaii I period, which spanned from around 1000 to 1200 in the Big Island of Polynesia, was followed by the emergence of the earliest island-wide unitary kingdom on the Big Island, which occurred around 1580.
Hawaii II (1200 CE–1580 CE) — Polynesia: What time period does Hawaii II refer to in the context of the Hawaiian archipelago in Polynesia?
Hawaii II refers to the period from 1200 to 1580 CE, marking a significant time in the history of the Big Island in Polynesia, specifically within the Hawaiian archipelago.
Hawaii II (1200 CE–1580 CE) — Polynesia: What significant event occurred around 1580 in the Big Island of Hawaii during the Hawaii II period?
The Hawaii II period saw the emergence of the first island-wide unitary kingdom on the Big Island around 1580, which was a notable development in the political organization of Hawaii II in Polynesia.
Hawaii II (1200 CE–1580 CE) — Polynesia: How was the Big Island of Hawaii organized before the emergence of the first island-wide unitary kingdom during the Hawaii II period?
Before the emergence of the first island-wide unitary kingdom around 1580, the Big Island was probably divided into several small, independent polities during the Hawaii II period in Polynesia.
Hawaii II (1200 CE–1580 CE) — Polynesia: What happened to the population of Hawaii II from 1200 to 1400 CE in the context of Polynesia?

During the Hawaii II period, from 1200 to 1400 CE, Hawaiians experienced significant population growth and adapted their technology and subsistence economy to local conditions in Polynesia while maintaining long-distance contact with Eastern Polynesia.
Hawaii II (1200 CE–1580 CE) — Polynesia: What changes occurred in the population and contact with Eastern Polynesia from 1400 to 1580 CE in Hawaii II?

From 1400 to 1580 CE, the Hawaii II period saw population growth peak and begin to stabilize, contact with Eastern Polynesia ceased, and large-scale dryland field systems were established across the Big Island in Polynesia.
Hawaii III (1580 CE–1778 CE) — Polynesia: What significant event occurred in Hawaii III period in 1580 in Polynesia?

Hawaii III period, which refers to the time from 1580 to 1778 CE in Polynesia, began with the approximate date of the formation of the first island-wide unitary kingdom on the Big Island of Hawaii during Hawaii III.
Hawaii III (1580 CE–1778 CE) — Polynesia: Who became the first true 'king' of the entire Big Island in Hawaii III period around 1580?

During Hawaii III, 'Umi had become the first true 'king' (ali'i nui) of the entire Big Island by about 1580, exerting greater control over land tenure and instituting a system of territorial administration based on ahupua'a land parcels.
Hawaii III (1580 CE–1778 CE) — Polynesia: What was the political organization of the Big Island during the Hawaii III period?

Hawaii III was characterized by the island alternating between being split into two or more smaller polities and being united under one ruler, with the kingdom divided into districts (moku) controlled by major chiefs called ali'i-'ai-moku during times of greater integration.
Hawaii III (1580 CE–1778 CE) — Polynesia: How was the population of the Big Island organized during the Hawaii III period?

During Hawaii III, the population of the Big Island was settled in all ecological zones, with a high-density but stable population, and commoner farmers, known as maka'āinana, paid tribute to konohiki land managers, who were often junior relatives of the ahupua'a chiefs.
Hawaii III (1580 CE–1778 CE) — Polynesia: What was the estimated population of the entire Hawaiian archipelago by the end of the Hawaii III period?
By the end of Hawaii III, the population of the entire Hawaiian archipelago was certainly very large, with estimates ranging between 250,000 and 800,000 when Captain Cook arrived in 1778.
Hawaii III (1580 CE–1778 CE) — Polynesia: What significant event marked the end of the Hawaii III period in 1778?
Hawaii III ended with the arrival of Captain Cook in 1778, which marked the first European contact with the Hawaiian archipelago.
Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period (1778 CE–1819 CE) — Polynesia: What significant event occurred in 1778 in the Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period in Polynesia?
The Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period began in 1778 with the arrival of Captain Cook, marking the first European contact in the region of Polynesia, specifically on the Big Island of Hawaii.
Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period (1778 CE–1819 CE) — Polynesia: Who rose to power over the Kohala and Kona districts of the Big Island in 1782 during the Kingdom of?

Kamehameha, a war chief and keeper of the war god Kūka'ilimoku, rose against King Kīwala'ō and seized power over the Kohala and Kona districts of the Big Island during the Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period.
Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period (1778 CE–1819 CE) — Polynesia: What was the outcome of Kamehameha's military campaigns during the Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period?

The Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period saw Kamehameha wage several military campaigns, eventually unifying the entire archipelago, minus Kaua'i and Ni'ihau, in 1804, under the Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period.
Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period (1778 CE–1819 CE) — Polynesia: How was the political hierarchy organized during the Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period?

The Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period had Kamehameha I at the top of the political hierarchy, advised by the kālaimoku on secular affairs and the kahuna nui on sacred duties, with governors and high-ranking chiefs overseeing the islands and districts.
Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period (1778 CE–1819 CE) — Polynesia: What was the impact of European contact on the population of the Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period in?

The Kingdom of Hawaii - Kamehameha Period saw a drastic decline in the kanaka maoli population after Europeans introduced diseases such as smallpox, syphilis, and measles, to which they had no immunity, in the region of Polynesia.
Cahokia - Early Woodland (600 BCE–150 BCE) — Mississippi Basin: What significant event occurred in the diets of people in the Mississippi Basin during the Cahokia - Early?

Cahokia - Early Woodland (600 BCE–150 BCE) — Mississippi Basin: What was the primary weapon used during the Cahokia - Early Woodland period?
The Cahokia - Early Woodland period used the atlatl as the contemporary weapon, before the introduction of the bow.
Cahokia - Early Woodland (600 BCE–150 BCE) — Mississippi Basin: How did groups in the Cahokia - Early Woodland period ensure access to needed resources?
During the Cahokia - Early Woodland period, groups ensured access to needed resources through the maintenance of alliance-exchange relationships and periodic rituals at ceremonial mound centers.
Cahokia - Early Woodland (600 BCE–150 BCE) — Mississippi Basin: What impact did the introduction of the bow have on the social complexity of the Mississippian region during?

The introduction of the bow in the Mississippi region during the Cahokia - Early Woodland period decreased social complexity, causing the collapse of the Hopewell system, the abandonment of mound centers, and the end of alliance-exchange relationships.
Cahokia - Early Woodland (600 BCE–150 BCE) — Mississippi Basin: How did the introduction of the bow affect the settlement patterns in the Mississippi Basin during the Cahokia?

Cahokia - Early Woodland (600 BCE–150 BCE) — Mississippi Basin: When did maize appear in the archaeological record during the Cahokia - Early Woodland period?

Cahokia - Early Woodland (600 BCE–150 BCE) — Mississippi Basin: What replaced the atlatl as the primary weapon in most regions during the Cahokia - Early Woodland period?

Cahokia - Late Woodland I (300 CE–450 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What was the greatest environmental hazard faced by the people of Cahokia during the Cahokia - Late Woodland I?

The greatest environmental hazard faced by the people of Cahokia during the Cahokia - Late Woodland I period was a late summer Mississippi River flood, which could drown crops, prevent easy fishing, and ruin food stored in underground pits.
Cahokia - Late Woodland I (300 CE–450 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What made Cahokia an advantageous location for settlement during the Cahokia - Late Woodland I period?

Cahokia was located in the widest expanse of land suitable for settlement in the American Bottom, with high ground bordered by large tracts of low-lying land, making it an advantageous location for settlement during the Cahokia - Late Woodland I period.
Cahokia - Late Woodland II (450 CE–600 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What was the significance of the introduction of the bow in the Mississippian region during the Cahokia - Late?

The introduction of the bow in the Mississippian region during the Cahokia - Late Woodland II period decreased social complexity because it caused the collapse of the Hopewell system, the abandonment of mound centers and alliance-exchange relationships, and led to a new subsistence strategy and household autonomy, as seen in the Cahokia - Late Woodland II period in the Mississippi Basin.
Cahokia - Late Woodland II (450 CE–600 CE) — Mississippi Basin: How did the transition from atlatl to bow affect the Cahokia - Late Woodland II period in the Mississippi Basin?

The transition from atlatl to bow during the Cahokia - Late Woodland II period in the Mississippi Basin was relatively rapid, leading to the disappearance of dart points from the archaeological record, and enabled a new subsistence strategy based on the bow and native crops, which resulted in the effective exploitation of previously marginal lands and household autonomy in the Cahokia - Late Woodland II period.
Cahokia - Late Woodland II (450 CE–600 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What was the impact of population growth on the Cahokia - Late Woodland II period in the Mississippi Basin?

Cahokia - Late Woodland II (450 CE–600 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What evidence of intergroup violence appears in the archaeological record during the Cahokia - Late Woodland?

Cahokia - Late Woodland II (450 CE–600 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What was the strategic importance of Cahokia's location during the Cahokia - Late Woodland II period?

Cahokia - Late Woodland III (600 CE–750 CE) — Mississippi Basin: How did the introduction of the bow affect the Cahokia - Late Woodland III period in the Mississippi Basin?

Cahokia - Late Woodland III (600 CE–750 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What was the impact of population growth on the Cahokia - Late Woodland III period in the Mississippi Basin?

Cahokia - Late Woodland III (600 CE–750 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What evidence of intergroup violence appears in the archaeological record during the Cahokia - Late Woodland?

During the Cahokia - Late Woodland III period, evidence of intergroup violence, such as arrow points embedded in skeletons in individual and group burials, appears in the archaeological record, indicating the bow as the primary weapon of intergroup violence.
Cahokia - Late Woodland III (600 CE–750 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What was the significance of maize farming during the Cahokia - Late Woodland III period in the Mississippi?

The Cahokia - Late Woodland III period in the Mississippi Basin saw the intensification of maize farming, which enabled higher yields and more food to be extracted from a smaller territory, leading to increased social complexity and the establishment of civic-ceremonial centers with large earthen mounds.
Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I (750 CE–900 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What significant developments occurred during the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period in the?

The Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period saw the first signs of warfare, an increase in social complexity, and more widespread consumption of farmed crops like maize. Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I (750 CE–900 CE) — Mississippi Basin: How did settlements change during the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period in the Mississippi?

During the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period, settlements changed with houses clustered into court-yard groups, and some settlements even gained palisades and ditches, although they were present at only a tiny fraction of all sites. The Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period saw the emergence of these more complex settlements.
Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I (750 CE–900 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What evidence of warfare exists from the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period in the Mississippi?

The Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period has evidence of inter-group violence, with human bones recovered with arrow points embedded into them in individual and group burials. This evidence suggests that warfare was present during the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period.
Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I (750 CE–900 CE) — Mississippi Basin: How did food production change during the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period in the Mississippi?

The Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period saw a dramatic intensification of food production, particularly of maize farming, which brought higher yields and enabled more food to be extracted from a smaller territory. This change in food production would lead to population growth during the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period.
Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I (750 CE–900 CE) — Mississippi Basin: What was the population size of the largest settlement during the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I?

The population of the largest settlement during the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period was probably in the region of 500 people. Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I (750 CE–900 CE) — Mississippi Basin: How did social roles change during the Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period in the Mississippi?

The Cahokia - Emergent Mississippian I period saw increased differentiation of social roles, with individuals dedicated to community defense, organization of labor, and communal storage of maize in secure central places.
