Abbasid Caliphate I (750 CE–946 CE) — Mesopotamia: What event marked the beginning of the Abbasid Caliphate I in Mesopotamia?
The Abbasid Caliphate I began in 750 CE, following a revolt where Abbasid rulers took power from the Umayyad Dynasty under Abu al-'Abbas al-Saffah in Mesopotamia.
Abbasid Caliphate I (750 CE–946 CE) — Mesopotamia: How did the Abbasid Caliphate I treat the Umayyad family after taking power in Mesopotamia?
The Abbasid Caliphate I, under Abu al-'Abbass al-Saffah, sought to destroy the male line descending from Fatima and Ali, and had about 300 members of the Umayyad family killed in Mesopotamia.
Abbasid Caliphate I (750 CE–946 CE) — Mesopotamia: What was the outcome of the Abbasid Caliphate I period in Mesopotamia by 946 CE?
The Abbasid Caliphate I period ended in 946 CE when the Daylamite Buyids from northwestern Iran reduced the caliph to a nominal figurehead in Mesopotamia.
Abbasid Caliphate I (750 CE–946 CE) — Mesopotamia: Who is considered to have ruled during the zenith of the Abbasid Caliphate I period in Mesopotamia?
The zenith of the Abbasid Caliphate I period is considered to be the reign of Harun al Rashid, who ruled from 763-809 CE in Mesopotamia.
Abbasid Caliphate I (750 CE–946 CE) — Mesopotamia: What was the administrative structure of the Abbasid Caliphate I in Mesopotamia?

The Abbasid Caliphate I had a complex bureaucracy, with the caliph as the spiritual leader and commander-in-chief, leaving day-to-day administration to his vizier and heads of the diwans in Mesopotamia.
Abbasid Caliphate I (750 CE–946 CE) — Mesopotamia: How did the territory of the Abbasid Caliphate I change over time in Mesopotamia?

The territory possessed by the Abbasid Caliphate I shrunk dramatically, from 11.1 million square kilometres in 750 CE, to 4.6 million around 850 CE, to just 1 million square kilometres half a century later, losing Egypt, Afghanistan, and Central Asia, but still maintaining a substantial population in Mesopotamia.
Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period (854 CE–1193 CE) — Pakistan: What geographical feature borders two sides of the Kachi Plain in the Sind region of Pakistan?

The Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period region, located in the Kachi Plain of Pakistan, is bordered by the mountains of Baluchistan on two of its three sides, while its southeastern side opens up to the Indus Valley, during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period.
Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period (854 CE–1193 CE) — Pakistan: What was the status of Sind in relation to the Arab empire during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period?

The Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period region, in Pakistan, was a vital tribute paying territory of the Arab empire, first under the Ummayad and then the Abbasid Caliphates, during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period.
Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period (854 CE–1193 CE) — Pakistan: What event occurred in Sind in 836 CE, according to historical records of the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period?

The Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period region, in Pakistan, plunged into a civil war after the Abbasid Caliphate lost control of its western territories in 836 CE, during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period.
Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period (854 CE–1193 CE) — Pakistan: Who became the rulers of an independent Sind in the middle of the ninth century, during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid?
The Habari lineage became the rulers of an independent Sind, in Pakistan, in the middle of the ninth century, during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period.
Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period (854 CE–1193 CE) — Pakistan: What was the estimated population of Sind during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period?
The Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period region, in Pakistan, had a population that is unlikely to have exceeded one million, according to Panwhar, during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period.
Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period (854 CE–1193 CE) — Pakistan: How was the polity of Sind organized during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period?

The Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period region, in Pakistan, was ruled by an emir, who delegated power over regions and districts to specially appointed governors, who were closely related to the emir himself, during the Sind - Abbasid-Fatimid Period.
Ghur Principality (1025 CE–1215 CE) — Afghanistan: What was the relationship between the Ghurid rulers and the Ghaznavids and Seljuk Turks in the Ghur Principality?

The Ghurid rulers of the Ghur Principality were in a state of vassalage of the Ghaznavids and the sultans of the Seljuk Turks, to whom they sent tribute, until their successful rebellion against the Ghaznavids in 1186 CE.
Ghur Principality (1025 CE–1215 CE) — Afghanistan: What was the result of the Ghurid rebellion against the Ghaznavids in the Ghur Principality?

The successful rebellion of the Ghur Principality against the Ghaznavids resulted in a legacy of at least a degree of cooperation among the Ghurid rulers, and led to the peak of their power in 1186 CE.
Ghur Principality (1025 CE–1215 CE) — Afghanistan: What was the system of government in the Ghur Principality?

The Ghur Principality was based on the Persian model with a professional vizier who oversaw civil affairs, and included officials such as a treasurer, an overseer of public morality, and qadis who enforced the Shari'a law.
Ghur Principality (1025 CE–1215 CE) — Afghanistan: What were some of the cultural achievements of the Ghur Principality?

The Ghur Principality had significant cultural achievements, including literary and artistic activities in the Persian style, and the building of the double-helical Minaret of Jam around 1190 CE, sponsored by Ghurid sultans.
Delhi Sultanate (1206 CE–1526 CE) — North India: When and how was the Delhi Sultanate created in North India?

The Delhi Sultanate was created in 1206 CE when Muhammad Qutb-ud-din declared his independence from the Ghurids, following the defeat of the last Hindu ruler of Delhi in 1192 CE. The Delhi Sultanate was established in North India, specifically in the Kachi Plain region.
Delhi Sultanate (1206 CE–1526 CE) — North India: What were the main dynasties that ruled the Delhi Sultanate in North India?

The Delhi Sultanate was ruled by five successive Turko-Afghan dynasties, including the Mamluk Dynasty, Khalji Dynasty, Tughlaq Dynasty, Sayyid Dynasty, and Lodi Dynasty, which spread Islam and the Persian language of administration in northern India.
Delhi Sultanate (1206 CE–1526 CE) — North India: What was the nature of the central administration of the Delhi Sultanate?

The Delhi Sultanate had a highly complex central administration but was not a centralized state, with much of its power devolved to local Hindu rulers and landholders in the provinces, while the area around Delhi was ruled directly by the Sultan.
Delhi Sultanate (1206 CE–1526 CE) — North India: How did Ala al-Din contribute to the Delhi Sultanate's administration in North India?

Ala al-Din reorganized the revenue and administrative systems of the Delhi Sultanate in order to support a large standing army, which was crucial for maintaining the personal authority of the Delhi Sultan in India and for expanding or defending territory.
Delhi Sultanate (1206 CE–1526 CE) — North India: What changes occurred in the role of the vizier in the Delhi Sultanate over time?

The vizier of the Delhi Sultanate became more powerful over time, with their duties extending from solely military affairs to also include revenue affairs, such as fiscal administration, income and expenditure, appointment of officials, and the collection of taxes.
Delhi Sultanate (1206 CE–1526 CE) — North India: How did the Delhi Sultanate end in North India?
The Delhi Sultanate ended in 1526 CE when Ibrahim was defeated by Babur, the Mongol ruler, marking the end of the Delhi Sultanate's 320-year rule in North India.
Sind - Samma Dynasty (1335 CE–1521 CE) — Pakistan: What geographical feature borders two sides of the Kachi Plain in the Sind region of Pakistan?

The Sind - Samma Dynasty region, located in the Kachi Plain of Pakistan, is bordered by the mountains of Baluchistan on two of its three sides, while its southeastern side opens up to the Indus Valley, during the rule of the Samma dynasty.
Sind - Samma Dynasty (1335 CE–1521 CE) — Pakistan: Which dynasty ruled the Sind region between the mid-fourteenth century and the 1520s?
The Sind - Samma Dynasty ruled the region of Sindh, also known as Sind, in modern-day Pakistan, between the mid-fourteenth century and the 1520s.
Sind - Samma Dynasty (1335 CE–1521 CE) — Pakistan: What was the geopolitical position of the Samma dynasty in the fourteenth century?

The Sind - Samma Dynasty faced a precarious geopolitical position in the fourteenth century, courting friendship with the Mongols as a counterbalance to the more immediate threat presented by the Delhi Sultanate.
Sind - Samma Dynasty (1335 CE–1521 CE) — Pakistan: Who conquered the Sind region in 1520?
The Sind - Samma Dynasty region was conquered by Shah Begh Argun, followed swiftly by Babur, founder of the Mughal dynasty, in 1520, marking the end of the Samma dynasty's rule over Sind.
Sind - Samma Dynasty (1335 CE–1521 CE) — Pakistan: How was the polity of the Sind - Samma Dynasty organized?

The Sind - Samma Dynasty was ruled by a jam, who delegated power over regions and districts to specially appointed governors, who were closely related to the emir himself, during the rule of the Samma dynasty in the Sind region.
Sind - Samma Dynasty (1335 CE–1521 CE) — Pakistan: What were the estimated population numbers of Sind during the Sind - Samma Dynasty?

The population of Sind during the Sind - Samma Dynasty is unlikely to have exceeded one million, according to Panwhar, though Lakho provides an estimate of 2,200,000, giving varying estimates of the population during the rule of the Samma dynasty.
Durrani Empire (1747 CE–1826 CE) — Afghanistan: Who founded the Durrani Empire and how did he come to power?
The Durrani Empire was founded by Ahmad Shah Durrani, a former soldier of the Afsharid Kingdom, who was elected to the monarchy by an inter-tribal assembly called the Loya Jirga.
Durrani Empire (1747 CE–1826 CE) — Afghanistan: How was the Durrani state governed and sustained?

Durrani Empire: The Durrani state was an empire sustained and governed through the maintenance of a large number of armed horsemen primarily recruited from the Pashtun peoples, as well as other tribes such as the Turkmen, Uzbek, Tajik, and Hazara.
Durrani Empire (1747 CE–1826 CE) — Afghanistan: What was the administrative structure of the Durrani Empire?

The Durrani Empire was a loose confederation of tribes with not much in the way of an administration, except for that possessed by conquered elites, who were largely left alone if they made their tribute payments. The Durrani Empire had short-term central administrative posts given to members of the governing tribes.
Durrani Empire (1747 CE–1826 CE) — Afghanistan: How did the Durrani Empire's army expand and how were soldiers compensated?

The Durrani Empire's army expanded rapidly from 16,000 in 1747 to about 120,000 in 1761. Soldiers received almost all the money, paid through generous land grants called Jegeirs, while the remaining revenue was spent on meeting the costs of the large army.
Japan - Incipient Jomon (13600 BCE–9200 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What characterized the subsistence system of the Japan - Incipient Jomon phase?
The Japan - Incipient Jomon phase had a subsistence system that was Paleolithic-style hunting, with people using tools such as bone fishhooks, arrowheads, and adzlike tools to gather food.
Japan - Incipient Jomon (13600 BCE–9200 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What types of tools were used by the people of the Japan - Incipient Jomon phase?

The Japan - Incipient Jomon people used tools such as bone fishhooks, usually not barbed, arrowheads, and large, adzlike tools made of sandstone, slate, or other soft stone to dig plant bulbs and starchy roots.
Japan - Incipient Jomon (13600 BCE–9200 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What was the size and structure of the earliest recognizable Japan - Incipient Jomon community site?

The Hanawadai site in Ibaragi Prefecture, which is the first recognizable Japan - Incipient Jomon community site, had five house pits lying about 10 meters apart, with one pit measuring 4.6 by 3.8 meters and having twelve holes for posts.
Japan - Incipient Jomon (13600 BCE–9200 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What was the estimated population of the Japan - Incipient Jomon phase?

The estimated population of the Japan - Incipient Jomon phase was around 21,900, with over half of the population strung out along the banks of Kanto streams, according to Koyama Shuzo's calculations.
Japan - Incipient Jomon (13600 BCE–9200 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What was the life expectancy of the people of the Japan - Incipient Jomon phase?
The life expectancy of the Japan - Incipient Jomon people was estimated to be about thirty years, with virtually unused wisdom teeth providing partial evidence for this estimate.
Japan - Incipient Jomon (13600 BCE–9200 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What were the living conditions like for the people of the Japan - Incipient Jomon phase?

The Japan - Incipient Jomon people faced severe conditions, with evidence of malnutrition and early aging, as seen in the human skeletons excavated from sites of this phase, which were often found intentionally buried among shells in flexed positions.
Japan - Initial Jomon (9200 BCE–5300 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What characterized the subsistence system of the Japan - Initial Jomon phase?

The Japan - Initial Jomon phase had a subsistence system that was Paleolithic-style hunting, with people using tools such as bone fishhooks, arrowheads, and adzlike tools to gather food. The Japan - Initial Jomon people also dug plant bulbs and starchy roots, and pulverized nuts and seeds with grinding stones.
Japan - Initial Jomon (9200 BCE–5300 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What were the living conditions like for the people of the Japan - Initial Jomon phase?

The people of the Japan - Initial Jomon phase lived in small bands, with no more than ten or fifteen people, in house pits that were about 10 meters apart. The Japan - Initial Jomon people faced severe conditions, with evidence of malnutrition and early aging, and had a life expectancy of about thirty years.
Japan - Initial Jomon (9200 BCE–5300 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What were the characteristics of the human skeletons found from the Japan - Initial Jomon phase?

The human skeletons found from the Japan - Initial Jomon phase were intentionally buried among shells, lying on their backs in flexed positions. The skeletons, such as the earliest known Japan - Initial Jomon man, showed signs of malnutrition, early aging, and worn-down teeth, with an estimated life expectancy of about thirty years.
Japan - Initial Jomon (9200 BCE–5300 BCE) — Northeast Asia: How did the population of the Japan - Initial Jomon phase distribute themselves?

The population of the Japan - Initial Jomon phase, estimated to be around 21,900, was concentrated in higher land in the valleys of the lower-central mountains, with over half of the population living along the banks of Kanto streams, where they had access to water supplies and a variety of plant, mammal, and sea life.
Japan - Initial Jomon (9200 BCE–5300 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What was the significance of the Kanto region to the Japan - Initial Jomon phase?

The Kanto region was significant to the Japan - Initial Jomon phase because it provided a variety and abundance of plant, mammal, and sea life, where northern and southern environmental zones overlap in central Japan, making it an ideal place for the Japan - Initial Jomon people to establish communities.
Japan - Initial Jomon (9200 BCE–5300 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What type of dogs were kept by the people of the Japan - Initial Jomon phase?

The people of the Japan - Initial Jomon phase kept dogs around their houses, specifically the Canis familiaris japonica, which were small, short-haired, Spitz-like dogs that were perhaps ancestors of the present-day Shiba.
Japan - Early Jomon (5300 BCE–3500 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What happened to the coastal population of Japan during the Early Jomon period in Northeast Asia?

Japan - Early Jomon: The Early Jomon period in Northeast Asia saw the coastal population pushed farther inland due to consistent warming and a rising sea level, with the temperature peaking several degrees higher than today toward the end of this stage. Water flooded low valleys, and some Kanto sites are as much as fifty kilometers from the present shore, affecting the Early Jomon population.
Japan - Early Jomon (5300 BCE–3500 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What types of animal bones were found in the shell mounds of the Early Jomon period in Japan?

Japan - Early Jomon: The shell mounds of the Early Jomon period in Japan contain chiefly bones of deer, boars, flying squirrels, and Siberian mountain lions, with investigations indicating that mainly older deer were hunted, and that mountain lions were dying out during the Early Jomon.
Japan - Early Jomon (5300 BCE–3500 BCE) — Northeast Asia: How did the warmer temperature of the Early Jomon period in Japan affect the growth of forests?

Japan - Early Jomon: The warmer temperature of the Early Jomon period in Japan encouraged the growth of the evergreen oak forests that covered much of west Japan, which is a characteristic of the Early Jomon period in Northeast Asia.
Japan - Early Jomon (5300 BCE–3500 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What was the impact of the warmer temperature on the population of the Early Jomon period in Japan?

Japan - Early Jomon: The warmer temperature and reliable food sources of the Early Jomon period in Japan produced a dramatic increase in population, with the Early Jomon population numbering around 106,000, or five times that of the Earliest Jomon, during the Early Jomon period in Northeast Asia.
Japan - Early Jomon (5300 BCE–3500 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What were the characteristics of the villages developed during the Early Jomon period in Japan?

Japan - Early Jomon: The Early Jomon period in Japan saw the development of small villages on bluffs, with pit houses grouped in the form of a horseshoe, and the presence of pottery of several successive types at a single site indicates continuous habitation during the Early Jomon.
Japan - Early Jomon (5300 BCE–3500 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What types of innovations were found in the Torihama shell mound of the Early Jomon period in Japan?

Japan - Early Jomon: The Torihama shell mound of the Early Jomon period in Japan revealed innovations such as polished stone axes, bone needles, and thimblelike bone rings, as well as the presence of cultivated plants like bottle gourds and green beans, which are characteristic of the Early Jomon period in Northeast Asia.
Japan - Early Jomon (5300 BCE–3500 BCE) — Northeast Asia: What was the significance of the discovery of ropes, reed baskets, and wooden objects in the Torihama shell mound of?

Japan - Early Jomon: The discovery of ropes, reed baskets, and many wooden objects, including oars, boards, adzes, bows, and carved bowls and a comb, in the Torihama shell mound of the Early Jomon period in Japan is significant because they are well-preserved and show the technological advancements of the Early Jomon period in Northeast Asia.
Japan - Early Jomon (5300 BCE–3500 BCE) — Northeast Asia: How did the house construction change during the Early Jomon period in Japan?

Japan - Early Jomon: The house construction during the Early Jomon period in Japan saw advances with the introduction of substantial inner posts strong enough to hold a roof over a rectanguloid floor, and the use of kaya as roofing grass, which kept the interior dry during the Early Jomon period in Northeast Asia.
Kansai - Yayoi Period (300 BCE–250 CE) — Northeast Asia: What characterized the beginning of the Kansai - Yayoi Period in Northeast Asia?

The Kansai - Yayoi Period was characterized by substantial changes and the introduction of new cultural features in daily life, including the introduction of rice farming, metalworking, cloth making, and new forms of pottery from continental Asia.
Kansai - Yayoi Period (300 BCE–250 CE) — Northeast Asia: What type of houses emerged during the early Kansai - Yayoi Period?
The Kansai - Yayoi Period saw the emergence of a new type of house, consisting of rectangular or round sub-types, which spread throughout western Japan by the end of the Early Kansai - Yayoi Period.
Kansai - Yayoi Period (300 BCE–250 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the introduction of rice paddy field agriculture impact the social structure of the Japanese Kansai - Yayoi?

Kansai - Yayoi Period: The introduction of rice paddy field agriculture had a big impact on the social structure of the Japanese Kansai - Yayoi communities, requiring an unprecedented scale of collaboration and social organization, and leading to the emergence of a ranked society.
Kansai - Yayoi Period (300 BCE–250 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the significance of the Middle Kansai - Yayoi Period in terms of population and settlement hierarchy?

The Middle Kansai - Yayoi Period saw a significant increase in population, resulting in the emergence of large central-type settlements, and a two-tiered settlement hierarchy characterized by larger villages acting as regional centres and smaller satellite settlements.
Kansai - Yayoi Period (300 BCE–250 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the nature of the elite status in the Late Kansai - Yayoi Period?

In the Late Kansai - Yayoi Period, the elite status was no longer achieved during one's lifetime but was inherited at birth, as suggested by the burial of children and infants in rectangular burial compounds.
Kansai - Yayoi Period (300 BCE–250 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the Kansai - Yayoi Period see the emergence of a polity in western Japan?
The Kansai - Yayoi Period saw the emergence of the polity of Yamatai, ruled by the queen Himiko, in western Japan, although the exact location of Yamatai is a matter of debate among scholars.
Kansai - Yayoi Period (300 BCE–250 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the impact of trade contacts with the Chinese Lelang commandery on the Kansai - Yayoi Period?

The trade contacts with the Chinese Lelang commandery led to the spread of bronze mirrors and metal objects in the Kansai - Yayoi Period, and the acquisition of the title of wang (king) by Japanese chiefs as a consequence of the tribute they submitted to the Chinese Han dynasty.
Kansai - Kofun Period (250 CE–537 CE) — Northeast Asia: What characterized the Kansai - Kofun Period in Northeast Asia?

The Kansai - Kofun Period is commonly defined by the emergence and spread of mounded tombs, from which derive the word Kofun meaning 'old tumulus'. The Kansai - Kofun Period saw the spread of monumental keyhole shaped tombs, which have been interpreted as the burials of regional leaders.
Kansai - Kofun Period (250 CE–537 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the significance of the keyhole shaped tombs in the Kansai region during the Kansai - Kofun Period?

The large-sized keyhole shaped tombs in the Kansai region, particularly in the Nara basin and Osaka plain, have been interpreted as the burials of regional leaders, suggesting that the Kansai region played a prominent political role in Japan during the Kansai - Kofun Period.
Kansai - Kofun Period (250 CE–537 CE) — Northeast Asia: How is the Kansai - Kofun Period sub-divided?

The Kansai - Kofun Period is sub-divided into three sub-periods: Early Kansai - Kofun (250-400 CE), Middle Kansai - Kofun (400-475 CE), and Late Kansai - Kofun (475-710 CE), based on changes in tomb structures and their assemblages, in settlement patterns and in ruling dynasties.
Kansai - Kofun Period (250 CE–537 CE) — Northeast Asia: What characterized the Early Kansai - Kofun period?

The Early Kansai - Kofun period was characterized by the spatial distribution of many contemporaneous large keyhole shaped tumuli, representing the presence of several different polities and regional leaders, with the political centre at Miwa in the south-eastern Nara basin, and power held by the Sujin dynasty.
Kansai - Kofun Period (250 CE–537 CE) — Northeast Asia: What changes occurred in the grave assemblage during the Middle Kansai - Kofun period?

During the Middle Kansai - Kofun period, the grave assemblage underwent substantial changes, with bronze mirrors and fine beadstone objects no longer deposited, and an increase in the amount of iron deposited in the tombs in the form of weapons and/or tools, and the introduction of horse trappings, gilt-bronze ornaments, and gold jewellery.
Kansai - Kofun Period (250 CE–537 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the estimated population of Kansai during the Kansai - Kofun Period?

The estimated population of Kansai during the Kansai - Kofun Period was between 150,000 and 200,000 people in 300 CE, and between 1.5 million and 2 million by 500 CE, with approximately 16.8% of the Japanese population living in Kansai from 250-599 CE.
Asuka (538 CE–710 CE) — Northeast Asia: What event in 538 CE led historians to designate the last segment of the Kofun period as the Asuka period in Northeast Asia?

The Asuka period began with the introduction of the Buddhism religion in 538 CE, which led historians to designate the last segment of the Kofun period as the Asuka period in Northeast Asia, specifically in the Kansai region.
Asuka (538 CE–710 CE) — Northeast Asia: How does the Asuka period overlap with the archaeological period Kofun in Northeast Asia?

The Asuka period overlaps with the archaeological period Kofun until 710 CE in Northeast Asia, specifically in the Kansai region, as the Asuka period can be considered a part of the broader Kofun period.
Asuka (538 CE–710 CE) — Northeast Asia: What were the two main phases of the Asuka period in Northeast Asia?

The Asuka period can be divided into two main phases: the first phase from 572-645 CE, when the Soga clan led, and the second phase from 645-692 CE, dominated by Tenchi Tenno, Temmu Tenno, and Jito Tenno, all of which occurred in Northeast Asia, specifically in the Kansai region, during the Asuka period.
Asuka (538 CE–710 CE) — Northeast Asia: What significant event marked the end of the Asuka period in Northeast Asia?

The Asuka period ended with the abdication of Jito Tenno in favor of her son Mommu and the move of the capital to the Heijō Palace of Nara, marking the conclusion of the Asuka period in Northeast Asia, specifically in the Kansai region.
Asuka (538 CE–710 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the impact of the introduction of Buddhism on the Asuka period in Northeast Asia?

The introduction of Buddhism in Japan during the Asuka period, which occurred in Northeast Asia, specifically in the Kansai region, led to the establishment of a central administrative control and the introduction of the Ritsuryo law system, and was favored by the Soga clan, a Japanese court family, during the Asuka period.
Asuka (538 CE–710 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the estimated population of the Kansai region during the Asuka period?

The estimated population of the Kansai region during the Asuka period was between 1.5 million and 2 million people in 600 CE, and between 2 million and 3 million by 700 CE, indicating growth during the Asuka period in Northeast Asia.
Asuka (538 CE–710 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the significance of the Taika reform during the Asuka period in Northeast Asia?

The Taika reform during the Asuka period in Northeast Asia, specifically in the Kansai region, led to a significant decrease in the size of large burial tumuli, which coincided with the emergence of a marked pyramidal hierarchy, as seen during the Asuka period.
Asuka (538 CE–710 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the burial practices change during the Asuka period in Northeast Asia?

During the Asuka period in Northeast Asia, specifically in the Kansai region, burial practices changed, with the disappearance of large tumuli and the emergence of individual, small round tumuli, which were much smaller than the preceding monumental mounded tombs, characteristic of the Asuka period.
Heian (794 CE–1185 CE) — Northeast Asia: What event marked the beginning of the Heian period in Northeast Asia's Kansai region?
The Heian period began when the Emperor Kammu moved the capital from Nara to Heian (Kyoto) in 794 CE, marking the start of the Heian period in Northeast Asia's Kansai region.
Heian (794 CE–1185 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the nature of the imperial court's administration during the Heian period?

The Heian period's imperial court maintained centralized control over the main islands of Japan and was the centre of a vast, highly bureaucratic administration system, characteristic of the Heian period.
Heian (794 CE–1185 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the imperial court's isolation affect the central government during the Heian period?

The imperial court's isolation from the realities of government, elaborate internal power dynamics and court intrigues eventually weakened the central government during the Heian period, contributing to the rise of the provincial warrior class.
Heian (794 CE–1185 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the impact of the Fujiwara family's dominance on the Heian government?

The dominance of the Fujiwara family led to an increasingly narrow focus on factional concerns, with the government's functions being carried out by other means and increased competition for offices, characteristic of the Heian period's administration.
Heian (794 CE–1185 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the Heian period end?
The Heian period ended with the establishment of the Kamakura Shogunate, marking a significant shift in Japan's governance, and the Heian period came to a close.
Heian (794 CE–1185 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the population range of the polity during the Heian period?
The polity population during the Heian period ranged from roughly four million in 800 CE to five or six million by 1100 CE, with Kyoto being the largest settlement, a key aspect of the Heian period.
Heian (794 CE–1185 CE) — Northeast Asia: What contributed to the emergence of feudalism in Japan during the Heian period?

The changing patterns of land ownership, including the proliferation of private land ownership exempt from taxation, and the nobles' absence from their lands, contributed to the emergence of feudalism in Japan during the Heian period, a significant development in the Heian period.
Kamakura Shogunate (1185 CE–1333 CE) — Northeast Asia: What event marked the beginning of the Kamakura Shogunate in Northeast Asia?

The Kamakura Shogunate begins with the victory of the Minamoto family over the Taira clan in the Gempei War, marking the start of the Kamakura period in Northeast Asia, specifically in the Kansai region.
Kamakura Shogunate (1185 CE–1333 CE) — Northeast Asia: Who was appointed shogun by the emperor in 1192 CE during the Kamakura Shogunate?

Minamoto no Yoritomo was appointed shogun by the emperor in 1192 CE, becoming the first shogun of the Kamakura Shogunate, and managed to avoid court influence by locating his base of operations in Kamakura.
Kamakura Shogunate (1185 CE–1333 CE) — Northeast Asia: What characterized the Kamakura Shogunate's system of governance in Northeast Asia?

The Kamakura Shogunate marks the beginning of Japan's medieval era, characterized by the rise of warrior rule combined with a feudal system of landholding and administration, which defined the period of the Kamakura Shogunate in Northeast Asia.
Kamakura Shogunate (1185 CE–1333 CE) — Northeast Asia: Who is considered to have been responsible for institutionalizing the way the bakufu mediated disputes and governed?

The Hōjō regent Hōjō Yasutoki is considered to have been responsible for institutionalizing the way the bakufu mediated disputes and governed during the Kamakura Shogunate, and his reign is often seen as the 'peak' of the Kamakura Shogunate.
Kamakura Shogunate (1185 CE–1333 CE) — Northeast Asia: What event marked the end of the Kamakura Shogunate in 1333 CE?
The Kamakura Shogunate ended in 1333 CE with the overthrow of the shogunate and the restoration of the Emperor Go-Daigo, bringing an end to the period of the Kamakura Shogunate in Northeast Asia.
Kamakura Shogunate (1185 CE–1333 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the shogun reward loyalty during the Kamakura Shogunate?

The shogun of the Kamakura Shogunate rewarded loyalty with grants of estates and offices, which formed the basis of governance during this period, with the central political relationship being between the lord and his vassals.
Kamakura Shogunate (1185 CE–1333 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the estimated population of the Kamakura Shogunate?
The estimated population of the Kamakura Shogunate was between five and six million, according to historian estimates, during the period of the Kamakura Shogunate in Northeast Asia.
Ashikaga Shogunate (1336 CE–1467 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the base of the Ashikaga Shogunate's power in Northeast Asia during the Muromachi Ashikaga period?

The Ashikaga Shogunate's power was based in Muromachi, a district of Kyoto, in Northeast Asia during the Muromachi Ashikaga period. Muromachi Ashikaga refers to the combination of the district and the name of the family who served as shoguns throughout the period.
Ashikaga Shogunate (1336 CE–1467 CE) — Northeast Asia: Who initiated the divide between the Northern and Southern Courts in the Ashikaga Shogunate period?

The divide between the Northern and Southern Courts in the Ashikaga Shogunate period was initiated by the appointment of Ashikaga Takauji as shogun by another branch of the imperial line with the support of other disillusioned lords, following the disintegration of Emperor Go-Daigo's brief 'Kenmu Restoration'.
Ashikaga Shogunate (1336 CE–1467 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the significance of Shogun Yoshimitsu's reign in the Ashikaga period?

Ashikaga Shogunate: The peak of the Ashikaga period corresponds to the reign of Shogun Yoshimitsu, who helped to broker the unification of the Northern and Southern Courts, with imperial succession reinstated through the Northern line, and was an able statesman who advanced many aspects of government and policy, and was an active patron of the arts.
Ashikaga Shogunate (1336 CE–1467 CE) — Northeast Asia: What event effectively brought an end to the Ashikaga Shogunate period in Northeast Asia?

The Onin War, which started in 1467, effectively brought an end to the Ashikaga Shogunate period in Northeast Asia, although the Ashikaga shogunate remained in power nominally until the overthrow of their last shogun by Oda Nobunaga in 1573.
Ashikaga Shogunate (1336 CE–1467 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the power of the Ashikaga Shogunate change over time in Northeast Asia?

Initially, the power of the Ashikaga Shogunate had theoretically extended throughout the main islands of Japan, but by the time of the Onin War, the area under its direct control had shrunk to Kyoto and its hinterland, despite the 'idea' of a larger unified culture remaining.
Ashikaga Shogunate (1336 CE–1467 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the population estimate during the Ashikaga Shogunate period in Northeast Asia?

The Ashikaga Shogunate period saw a population growth, with estimates ranging from roughly 10 million around 1300 CE to approximately 17 million in 1500 CE, during the time of the Muromachi Ashikaga period.
Warring States Japan (1467 CE–1568 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the nature of control in Warring States Japan during the 15th to 16th centuries in Northeast Asia?

In Warring States Japan, the shogun became a prize to control, and the capital at Kyoto was devastated by war, with no central government in place. The daimyo, supported by their close kinsmen and vassals, often had an inner council to decide on matters of administration and military policy.
Warring States Japan (1467 CE–1568 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the role of bugyo in Warring States Japan?
In Warring States Japan, military administrators known as bugyo were employed in a non-fighting capacity, supporting the daimyo in their administration and military policy decisions.
Warring States Japan (1467 CE–1568 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the population change during the Warring States Japan period?
Despite the turmoil, the population in Warring States Japan probably increased by five million over 100 years to about 20 million in 1568 CE, indicating significant growth during this time.
Warring States Japan (1467 CE–1568 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was another name for Warring States Japan known as Warring States Japan?

Warring States Japan is also known as the Onin War and the Age of the Warring States, which translated into Japanese becomes the Sengoku jidai or Sengoku Period, highlighting the intense conflict and power struggles that characterized this era.
Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama (1568 CE–1603 CE) — Northeast Asia: What event marked the beginning of the Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period in Northeast Asia?

The Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period marked the beginning of a process of national unification after the disorder of the Warring States period, starting with the rise to power of the military commander and regional lord Oda Nobunaga in 1568.
Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama (1568 CE–1603 CE) — Northeast Asia: Who were the key warrior rulers that the Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period is named after?
The Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period is named for the castles built by the warrior rulers Oda Nobunaga and Toyotomi Hideyoshi.
Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama (1568 CE–1603 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the outcome of Oda Nobunaga's defeat of the shogun Ashikaga Yoshiaki in the Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period?

With his defeat of the shogun Ashikaga Yoshiaki, Oda Nobunaga set about bringing the lesser daimyō under the control of a single military command, and in 1568 he marched on, and occupied, the imperial capital of Kyoto, gaining effective control of the government during the Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period.
Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama (1568 CE–1603 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the result of Toyotomi Hideyoshi's attempts to expand Japan's territory overseas during the Japan -?
Toyotomi Hideyoshi led two unsuccessful invasions of Korea in 1592 and 1597 during the Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period, in an attempt to expand Japan's territory overseas.
Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama (1568 CE–1603 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the social hierarchy change during the Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period in Northeast Asia's Kansai region?

Toyotomi Hideyoshi was instrumental in creating a strict and finely graded social hierarchy of warriors, farmers, artisans, and merchants during the Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama period, a structure that would be institutionalized in the succeeding Tokugawa period.
Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama (1568 CE–1603 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the population estimate for the area under Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama control by 1600 CE?

Population estimates for the area under Japan - Azuchi-Momoyama control range from roughly 17 million in 1500 CE to 22 million in 1600 CE, with the imperial capital, Kyoto, remaining the largest settlement with approximately 300,000 inhabitants.
Tokugawa Shogunate (1603 CE–1868 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the duration of the Tokugawa Shogunate in Northeast Asia?
The Tokugawa Shogunate lasted from 1603 to 1868, marking a period of 268 years during which the Tokugawa family ruled Japan.
Tokugawa Shogunate (1603 CE–1868 CE) — Northeast Asia: Who was the leader that marked the official beginning of the Tokugawa Shogunate?

Tokugawa Ieyasu marked the official beginning of the Tokugawa Shogunate with his appointment as shogun in 1603, although his decisive victory at the Battle of Sekigahara in 1600 is sometimes considered the starting point of the Tokugawa period.
Tokugawa Shogunate (1603 CE–1868 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the impact of the Tokugawa Shogunate on internal strife and warfare in Japan?
The rise to power of the Tokugawa Shogunate marked an end to the internal strife and warfare that had characterized the preceding century, bringing stability to Japan under the Tokugawa Shogunate.
Tokugawa Shogunate (1603 CE–1868 CE) — Northeast Asia: What characterized the 'peak' of the Tokugawa period?

The 'peak' of the Tokugawa period, known as the Genroku period from 1688 to 1704 CE, was characterized by the development of a distinct urban culture and the proliferation of art, theatre, and fiction under the Tokugawa Shogunate.
Tokugawa Shogunate (1603 CE–1868 CE) — Northeast Asia: What factors contributed to the end of the Tokugawa Shogunate?

The Tokugawa Shogunate came to an end due to economic difficulties and the threat of Western encroachment, leading to the resignation of the last Tokugawa shogun in 1867 and the imperial restoration in 1868.
Tokugawa Shogunate (1603 CE–1868 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the Tokugawa Shogunate organize the Japanese polity?

The Tokugawa Shogunate built on the work of earlier generals, uniting all the daimyō under the command of a military leader into a 'national confederation', with the daimyō maintaining administrative authority in their own territories but expected to follow the guidance of the shogunate.
Tokugawa Shogunate (1603 CE–1868 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the social hierarchy like during the Tokugawa period?

The Tokugawa period was characterized by a formalized social order known as shi-nō-kō-shō, 'warrior-peasant-artisan-merchant', with class determined by birth and social mobility theoretically prohibited, under the rule of the Tokugawa Shogunate.
Tokugawa Shogunate (1603 CE–1868 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the population of Japan change during the Tokugawa period?

The population of Japan rose from estimates ranging from 15 to 22 million at the beginning of the Tokugawa period to around 30 million by the end of the period, with the Tokugawa Shogunate overseeing this growth.
Iban - Pre-Brooke (1650 CE–1841 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: What region did the Iban people inhabit during the Iban - Pre-Brooke period in Maritime Southeast Asia?
The Iban - Pre-Brooke people inhabited the Kapuasi basin, located in Western Kalimantan, in Borneo, in Maritime Southeast Asia.
Iban - Pre-Brooke (1650 CE–1841 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: What were the key cultural values of the Iban people during the Iban - Pre-Brooke period?
The Iban - Pre-Brooke people emphasized individual resourcefulness, egalitarianism, personal mobility, and opening new land for settlement in their culture.
Iban - Pre-Brooke (1650 CE–1841 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: What event checked the expansion of the Iban people in 1841?
The Iban - Pre-Brooke expansion was checked by British adventurer James Brooke, of the so-called Brooke Raj, in 1841.
Iban - Pre-Brooke (1650 CE–1841 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: How were Iban communities governed before the establishment of the Brooke Raj?

Before the establishment of the Brooke Raj, the Iban - Pre-Brooke communities were directed by groups of family leaders, with no permanent leaders, and warriors, bards, augurs, and other specialists could become men of influence.
Iban - Pre-Brooke (1650 CE–1841 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: What changes occurred in Iban political organization with the creation of the Brooke Raj?

The Iban - Pre-Brooke political organization changed profoundly with the creation of permanent political positions, such as headman, regional chief, and paramount chief, by James Brooke, as Rajah of Sarawak, to better control Iban society.
Iban - Pre-Brooke (1650 CE–1841 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: What was the approximate population of the Iban people in Sarawak according to the 1985 census?
The Iban - Pre-Brooke people had a population of around 439,000 people in Sarawak, according to the 1985 census.
Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial (1841 CE–1987 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: What was the culture of the Iban people in Maritime Southeast Asia during the Iban - Brooke Raj?

The Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial period was characterized by the Iban people's culture, which emphasized individual resourcefulness, egalitarianism, personal mobility, and opening new land for settlement. The Iban people were a river people whose culture played a significant role in shaping their society. During this period, the Iban culture continued to influence their way of life.
Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial (1841 CE–1987 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: What was the impact of the Brooke Raj on the Iban communities in Maritime Southeast Asia during?

The Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial period saw the governed Iban communities being relatively autonomous in the regulation of local matters, although a colonial administrative structure was superimposed onto the Iban system. The White Rajahs sought to suppress infighting and mobilize Iban communities for their own military interests, which had a significant impact on the Iban people during this period.
Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial (1841 CE–1987 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: How did the political organization of the Iban people change during the Iban - Brooke Raj and?

The Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial period saw a significant change in the political organization of the Iban people, with the creation of permanent political positions, such as headman, regional chief, and paramount chief, by James Brooke. The establishment of political parties in the early 1960s also profoundly changed the Iban political organization, which was a key aspect of the Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial period.
Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial (1841 CE–1987 CE) — Maritime Southeast Asia: What was the population of the Iban people in Sarawak during the Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial?

The Iban - Brooke Raj and Colonial period saw the Iban people living in autonomous longhouse communities, with the 1985 census for Sarawak estimating the number of Iban at around 439,000 people. This gives an insight into the population of the Iban people during this period.
Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age (3000 BCE–2000 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What characterized the pottery of the Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age in Anatolia-Caucasus?
The Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age was characterized by distinctive red monochrome wares in its pottery, which was a notable feature of the period in Anatolia-Caucasus.
Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age (3000 BCE–2000 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What types of materials were used in the grave goods found in the Royal Tombs at Alaca Höyük during?
The Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age grave goods found in the Royal Tombs at Alaca Höyük included a multiplicity of materials such as metals, stones, frit, faience, pottery, bone, and textiles.
Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age (3000 BCE–2000 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was notable about the anthropomorphic figurines found in the Royal Tombs at Alaca Höyük during?

The Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age anthropomorphic figurines found in the Royal Tombs at Alaca Höyük were made by combining more than one metal in a single object, making them a spectacular finding of the period.
Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age (3000 BCE–2000 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: How were the sites of the Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age typically fortified?

The Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age sites were well fortified, with proof of wooden palisades and stone walls found in sites such as Karataş-Semayük, and complex fortifications like stronghold walls and rectangular-shaped bastions found at Alişar Hüyük.
Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age (3000 BCE–2000 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What were the dominant animals in the animal economy of the Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age?

The Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age had an agropastoral economy with pastoral dominating, where sheep and goats were the dominant component, representing 63-68 percent of the faunal remains, followed by cattle and pigs.
Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age (3000 BCE–2000 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What types of handheld weapons were found in the Central Anatolia Plateau during the Konya Plain -?
The Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age handheld weapons found in the Central Anatolia Plateau included swords, daggers, pikes, halberds, spears, battle axes, and warclubs.
Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age (3000 BCE–2000 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the orientation of the bodies in the extramural Early Bronze Age cemeteries found at?
The Konya Plain - Early Bronze Age bodies in the extramural cemeteries found at Demircihöyük and Karataş-Semayük were mostly facing Southeast, with around 900 pithoi burials discovered.
Hatti - Old Kingdom (1650 BCE–1500 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What is known as the Old Kingdom in the context of the Hittite Kingdom in Anatolia-Caucasus?

The Hatti - Old Kingdom is known as the early period of the Hittite Kingdom, which lasted from about 1650 to 1500 BCE and emerged after a group of Indo-European speakers migrated and settled on a high plateau in western Anatolia known as Hatti.
Hatti - Old Kingdom (1650 BCE–1500 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: How did the Hatti - Old Kingdom polity emerge in the Anatolia-Caucasus region?

The Hatti - Old Kingdom polity emerged after a group of Indo-European speakers migrated from either the Caucasus or the Bosphorus and Dardanelles and settled on a high plateau in western Anatolia known as Hatti, where they mingled with the indigenous people of Hatti and adopted many of their beliefs and customs.
Hatti - Old Kingdom (1650 BCE–1500 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the political organization of the central Anatolian region before the mid-1st millennium BCE during the?

During the Hatti - Old Kingdom period, the central Anatolian region was divided into many city-states before the Hittites began to conquer the neighbouring cities and founding a strong state around 1650 BCE.
Hatti - Old Kingdom (1650 BCE–1500 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: Who was the first known king of the Hittites during the Hatti - Old Kingdom period?
Labarna I, who lived in the 17th century BCE, was the first known Hittite king during the Hatti - Old Kingdom period.
Hatti - Old Kingdom (1650 BCE–1500 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What were the roles of the king in Hittite society during the Hatti - Old Kingdom period?

The king of the Hatti - Old Kingdom was the supreme ruler and military commander, a chief judge and a priest in Hittite society, and he entrusted the management of major cities and provinces to officials who were often directly answerable to him.
Hatti - Old Kingdom (1650 BCE–1500 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What obligations did vassal rulers have to the king of the Hatti - Old Kingdom?
Vassal rulers of the Hatti - Old Kingdom were obliged to pay tribute to the king and take an oath of allegiance.
Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II (1500 BCE–1400 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II period also referred to as for the Hittite people?
The Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II period was sometimes referred to as the Middle Kingdom for the Hittite people, which existed before the Empire period of the New Kingdom.
Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II (1500 BCE–1400 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the approximate population of the area corresponding to Hittite control during the Konya?
The Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II period had an approximate population of less than a million Hittites, possibly much less, in the area corresponding to Hittite control.
Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II (1500 BCE–1400 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What is known about the Middle Kingdom of the Hittites during the Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II?
The Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II period was a time of troubles, and not much is known about the Middle Kingdom of the Hittites.
Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II (1500 BCE–1400 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: Who is noted for building achievements during the Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II period?
Hantili II is noted for building achievements, being responsible for the first extensive fortification of the capital Hattusa, during the Konya Plain - Late Bronze Age II period.
Hatti - New Kingdom (1400 BCE–1180 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the time period of the Hatti - New Kingdom in Anatolia-Caucasus?

The Hatti - New Kingdom lasted from about 1400-1180 BCE, although the dynasty that created it came to power in the mid-fifteenth century BCE, and during this time, the Hatti - New Kingdom was a major power in the region.
Hatti - New Kingdom (1400 BCE–1180 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What areas did the Hittite king control during the Hatti - New Kingdom period?

During the period of its greatest splendor, the Hittite king of the Hatti - New Kingdom controlled up to 400,000 squared kilometers of land, including the areas of Northern Mesopotamia, Syria, and Palestine, which were all part of the Hatti - New Kingdom's territories.
Hatti - New Kingdom (1400 BCE–1180 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the administrative structure of the Hatti - New Kingdom?

The Hatti - New Kingdom had a relatively sophisticated central bureaucracy, with a Chief of the Scribes, a hazannu, Keepers of the Royal Storehouses, and District governors known as Lord of the Watchtower, all of which were important officials in the Hatti - New Kingdom's administration.
Hatti - New Kingdom (1400 BCE–1180 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the result of the war between the Hatti - New Kingdom and Egypt?

The war between the Hatti - New Kingdom and Egypt, which took place during the reign of Muwattalli and Ramses II, resulted in the first written international treaty, known as the Kadesh Treaty, which was a significant achievement for the Hatti - New Kingdom.
Hatti - New Kingdom (1400 BCE–1180 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What led to the decline of the Hatti - New Kingdom?

The Hatti - New Kingdom probably fell under the pressure of the Sea Peoples around 1200 BCE, although a few Hittite city-states in Northern Syria survived until 708 BC, marking the end of the Hatti - New Kingdom's power in the region.
Neo-Hittite Kingdoms (1180 BCE–900 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What happened to the Hittite civilization after Hattusa was destroyed by fire in the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms period?

The Neo-Hittite Kingdoms period saw elements of the Hittite civilization lingering in peripheral areas of the former kingdom, including the Konya Plain region, after Hattusa was destroyed by fire ending the New Kingdom period of the Hittites.
Neo-Hittite Kingdoms (1180 BCE–900 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: Where were the primary regions of the Syro-Hittite kingdoms located during the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms period?

The primary region of the Syro-Hittite kingdoms during the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms period was in Syria, although the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms themselves were located in Anatolia-Caucasus, including the Konya Plain region.
Neo-Hittite Kingdoms (1180 BCE–900 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What cultural links existed between the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms and the Late Bronze Age Hittite Empire in?
The Neo-Hittite Kingdoms had cultural links with the Late Bronze Age Hittite Empire, which can be seen in the iconography and architecture of the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms in Anatolia-Caucasus.
Neo-Hittite Kingdoms (1180 BCE–900 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the organization of the region during the 1180-900 BCE post-Empire period of the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms in?

During the 1180-900 BCE post-Empire period of the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms, the region reorganized into city-states, with each city-state having its own autonomous ruler in the Konya Plain and surrounding areas.
Neo-Hittite Kingdoms (1180 BCE–900 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: Which states were present in the area around or on the Konya Plain during the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms period?

The states present in the area around or on the Konya Plain during the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms period were Pisidia, Pamphylia, Lycaonia, Tabal, and Cilicia, which were part of the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms in Anatolia-Caucasus.
Neo-Hittite Kingdoms (1180 BCE–900 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What language is believed to have been used by the society of the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms era in the Konya Plain?
The society of the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms era in the Konya Plain region is believed to have used the Hieroglyphic Luwian language, as the Hittite cuneiform disappeared entirely during this period.
Neo-Hittite Kingdoms (1180 BCE–900 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What titles did many Neo-Hittite rulers take and what kind of administrative centre likely existed in the central?
Many Neo-Hittite rulers took the titles 'Great King' and 'Hero', and it is likely that an administrative centre existed in the central town of the Neo-Hittite Kingdoms in Anatolia-Caucasus.
Phrygian Kingdom (900 BCE–695 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What event led to the formation of the Phrygian Kingdom in Anatolia?
The Phrygian Kingdom came into existence after the migration of a people to Anatolia in the early Iron Age, after the fall of the Hittite Empire, marking the beginning of the Phrygian Kingdom.
Phrygian Kingdom (900 BCE–695 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the most developed phase of the Phrygian Kingdom?
The Phrygian Kingdom's most developed phase occurred under king Midas who ruled from the city of Gordium in the late 8th century, during the Phrygian Kingdom period.
Phrygian Kingdom (900 BCE–695 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: How did the Phrygian Kingdom come to an end?
The Phrygian Kingdom came to an end when it was conquered by the Lydian Kingdom, which marked the end of the Phrygian period, ending the Phrygian Kingdom's existence.
Phrygian Kingdom (900 BCE–695 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What is known about the autonomy of cities within the Phrygian Kingdom?
The Phrygian Kingdom had other cities with their own governments and a great deal of autonomy, with the biggest cities having governors, during the time of the Phrygian Kingdom.
Phrygian Kingdom (900 BCE–695 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What is known about the language of the Phrygian Kingdom?
The Phrygian language is not known, and its similarity to Greek languages has only allowed for fragments of texts to be understood, leaving much about the Phrygian Kingdom's language unclear.
Phrygian Kingdom (900 BCE–695 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What is the significance of king Midas in the Phrygian Kingdom?
King Midas ruled the Phrygian Kingdom from the city of Gordium in the late 8th century, marking the kingdom's most developed phase, with Midas being a key figure in the Phrygian Kingdom's history.
Tabal Kingdoms (900 BCE–730 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What occupied the Konya Plain region during the 900-730 BCE period in Anatolia-Caucasus?
The Tabal Kingdoms occupied the Konya Plain region during the 900-730 BCE period in Anatolia-Caucasus, consisting of small independent states that likely first evolved during the Neo-Hittite period.
Tabal Kingdoms (900 BCE–730 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: How did the Tabal Kingdoms interact with the Mesopotamian Empire after the Assyrian invasion?

The Tabal Kingdoms became tribute-sending states to the Mesopotamian Empire after the Assyrian invasion, but were otherwise free to rule their states in whatever manner they wished, without interference from the Assyrian king, during the Tabal Kingdoms period.
Tabal Kingdoms (900 BCE–730 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the term 'Tabal' in the context of the Assyrian administrative designation?
The term 'Tabal' was an Assyrian administrative designation rather than a political one, used to refer to the kingdoms of Tabal in the region of Anatolia-Caucasus during the Tabal Kingdoms period.
Tabal Kingdoms (900 BCE–730 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: How many kingdoms of Tabal existed in the mid-9th century BCE according to Assyrian records?
According to Assyrian records, there were 24 kingdoms of Tabal in the mid-9th century BCE during the Tabal Kingdoms period.
Tabal Kingdoms (900 BCE–730 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: Which kingdoms of Tabal were listed as tributaries by Assyrian king Tiglath-pileser III?
Assyrian king Tiglath-pileser III listed five tributaries he possessed in Tabal: Tabal, Atuna, Tuhana, Ishtu(a)nda, and Hupishna, during the Tabal Kingdoms period.
Kingdom of Lydia (670 BCE–546 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the Kingdom of Lydia's significance in the history of Anatolia?

The Kingdom of Lydia, under the Mermnad dynasty, came to dominate Anatolia after the conquest of Phrygia, and is most famous for being the likely birthplace of coinage, blessed with a rich supply of minable electrum, a natural alloy of silver and gold.
Kingdom of Lydia (670 BCE–546 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the nature of the Kingdom of Lydia's relations with other states?

The Kingdom of Lydia's relations with other states were characterized by pragmatic deal-making to preserve the economic system of the integrated Mediterranean trading zone, and the Lydian kings often utilized marriages to secure alliances with many foreign powers, including the Persian Medians, Greek Ionians, and Carians.
Kingdom of Lydia (670 BCE–546 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What were the major threats to the Kingdom of Lydia's power?

The Kingdom of Lydia faced major threats from the nomadic Cimmerians, who were initially expelled, and later from Assyria, which led to an alliance with Egypt, and also from the Persian Medians, with whom the Lydian kings formed alliances through marriages.
Lysimachus Kingdom (323 BCE–281 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the Lysimachus Kingdom's duration in the history of the Anatolia-Caucasus area?
The Lysimachus Kingdom constituted only a short period in the history of the area, specifically from 323 BCE to 281 BCE, with Lysimachus declaring himself king in 306 BCE.
Lysimachus Kingdom (323 BCE–281 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: Who conquered the Odrysian Kingdom before the Lysimachus Kingdom was established in the Anatolia-Caucasus region?
The Odrysian Kingdom was present in Thrace before it was conquered by Philip II, and then ruled by Alexander the Great until his death in 323 BCE, after which the Lysimachus Kingdom was established.
Lysimachus Kingdom (323 BCE–281 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was Lysimachus' policy during his reign in the Lysimachus Kingdom in Anatolia-Caucasus?
Lysimachus ruled with an expansionist policy in the Lysimachus Kingdom, and extended the kingdom to its furthest reaches by around 300 BCE, including the Konya Plain.
Lysimachus Kingdom (323 BCE–281 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the outcome of the Battle of Corupedium for the Lysimachus Kingdom in the Anatolia-Caucasus region?

Lysimachus was defeated at the Battle of Corupedium by Seleucus, the ruler of the Seleucid Empire, in 281 BCE, and his territories became part of the Seleucid Empire, marking the end of the Lysimachus Kingdom.
Lysimachus Kingdom (323 BCE–281 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What is known about the administration of the Lysimachus Kingdom in the Anatolia-Caucasus area?

The Lysimachus Kingdom's administration is very limited, with almost no direct information as to Lysimachus' administration, although there is some continuity with the Odrysian Kingdom before the Macedonian conquest.
Lysimachus Kingdom (323 BCE–281 BCE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: How did the boundaries of the Lysimachus Kingdom in the Anatolia-Caucasus region change during Lysimachus' reign?
The Lysimachus Kingdom's boundaries were extended to include the Konya Plain, and the kingdom reached its furthest reaches by around 300 BCE under Lysimachus' expansionist policy.
Late Cappadocia (330 BCE–16 CE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the fate of the Cappadocian kingdom in the hands of other powerful polities in Asia Minor during the Late?

The Late Cappadocia kingdom began and ended in the hands of other more powerful polities in Asia Minor, growing out of suzerainty to the Achaemenid Empire and eventually returning to being a province under Rome in the early first century CE, with the Late Cappadocia kingdom being fought over and used by neighbouring polities to strengthen their positions of power.
Late Cappadocia (330 BCE–16 CE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: How did the kingdom of Late Cappadocia in the Konya Plain region come under the influence of Rome?
