Egypt - Thebes-Libyan Period: The most powerful pharaoh of the Thebes-Libyan Period was Shoshenq I, the first Libyan ruler and founder of the Twenty-second Dynasty, who embarked on an 'ambitious royal building programme' and attempted to regain control of the entirety of Egypt.
Egypt - Thebes-Libyan Period (1069 BCE–747 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the outcome of the division of the state into the Twenty-second and Twenty-third Dynasties during?

Egypt - Thebes-Libyan Period: The division of the state into the Twenty-second and Twenty-third Dynasties during the Thebes-Libyan Period in Egypt did not work, as the Twenty-second Dynasty pharaohs could barely control the north by the time of Shoshenq III, and numerous local rulers became virtually autonomous.
Egypt - Thebes-Libyan Period (1069 BCE–747 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the impact of the Thebes-Libyan Period on the political organization of Egypt in Northeast Africa?

Egypt - Thebes-Libyan Period: The Thebes-Libyan Period in Egypt represented another time of decentralization, with the governments at Memphis and Thebes following the traditional 'intermediate period' pattern of rulers, and the state eventually dividing into the Twenty-second and Twenty-third Dynasties.
Egypt - Saite Period (664 BCE–525 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the significance of the Saite Period in Egypt's history?

Egypt - Saite Period: The Saite Period, also known as the 'Saite Renaissance', was a time of centralized rule in Egypt, during which the Saite kings constructed a more centralized state than that of the preceding period, with the high point of Saite power being the reign of Amasis II, who ruled Egypt during the Twenty-sixth Dynasty.
Egypt - Saite Period (664 BCE–525 BCE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Saite kings manage to construct a more centralized state in Egypt?

Egypt - Saite Period: The Saite kings, from their palace at Memphis, gradually managed to construct a more centralized state than that of the preceding period, with the Saite Period being characterized as the 'Saite Renaissance'.
Egypt - Saite Period (664 BCE–525 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the role of the Demotic script during the Saite Period in Egypt?

Egypt - Saite Period: The Demotic script, which originated in the delta but spread throughout Lower and Upper Egypt under Psamtik I and his successors, was an important phenomenon of the Saite Period, and was useful in everyday contexts such as accounting, letter-writing, and non-religious literature.
Egypt - Saite Period (664 BCE–525 BCE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Saite kings initially exert influence over Upper Egypt?

Egypt - Saite Period: The Saite kings initially exerted influence over Upper Egypt through the priestly position of the God's Wife of Amun, which was held by a Saite priestess at the Amun temple, and an observer based in Thebes who was often called 'governor', during the Saite Period.
Egypt - Saite Period (664 BCE–525 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What changes did Psamtik II's campaign bring to the Saite authority in Upper Egypt?

Egypt - Saite Period: Psamtik II's campaign against the Kingdom of Napata brought the Theban Egypt under the effective control of the Memphite kings, ending the 'period of compromise' in Upper Egypt, and allowing the Saite Dynasty to portray the Nubian kings as usurpers, during the Saite Period.
Egypt - Saite Period (664 BCE–525 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the approximate population of Egypt during the Saite Period?
Egypt - Saite Period: The total population of Egypt during the Saite Period remained fairly steady at roughly three million people, with reliable population estimates being difficult to find.
Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period (404 BCE–342 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What characterized the Inter-Occupation Period in Egypt's history in Northeast Africa?

Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period: The Inter-Occupation Period in Egypt, which occurred in Northeast Africa, was characterized by indigenous rulers governing the region, with external relationships with Greeks and Persians overshadowing attempts to maintain internal political stability. This period, also known as the Inter-Occupation Dynasties, refers to the last time Egypt was governed by native rulers before phases of Persian domination.
Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period (404 BCE–342 BCE) — Northeast Africa: Who established the Twenty-eighth Dynasty during the Inter-Occupation Period in Upper Egypt?

Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period: The Twenty-eighth Dynasty during the Inter-Occupation Period in Upper Egypt was established by Amyrtaeus II, who ruled from Memphis and may have adopted the regnal name of Psamtik to lend his rule legitimacy. Amyrtaeus II succeeded in extending his control as far south as Aswan in 400 BCE.
Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period (404 BCE–342 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What led to the end of Amyrtaeus II's reign during the Inter-Occupation Period in Egypt?

Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period: Amyrtaeus II's reign during the Inter-Occupation Period in Egypt was challenged and overthrown by one of his generals, Nepherites I, who captured Amyrtaeus and executed him at Memphis, as described in an Aramaic papyrus. This event marked the end of Amyrtaeus II's rule and the beginning of the Twenty-ninth Dynasty.
Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period (404 BCE–342 BCE) — Northeast Africa: Who founded the Thirtieth and final native Egyptian pharaonic Dynasty during the Inter-Occupation Period?

Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period: The Thirtieth and final native Egyptian pharaonic Dynasty during the Inter-Occupation Period was founded by Nectanebo I, who overthrew the last ruler of the Twenty-ninth Dynasty with the assistance of a Greek general called Chabrias. Nectanebo I's dynasty was the last native Egyptian pharaonic dynasty during the Inter-Occupation Period in Northeast Africa.
Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period (404 BCE–342 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What were the most powerful elements in Egyptian society during the Inter-Occupation Period?

Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period: The most powerful elements in Egyptian society during the Inter-Occupation Period were members of the warrior class and priesthood. The men who established the Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Dynasties, such as Nepherites I and Nectanebo I, were both generals, highlighting the importance of the warrior class during this time in Egypt's history.
Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period (404 BCE–342 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the impact of foreign mercenary forces on Egypt during the Inter-Occupation Period?

Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period: The presence of garrisoned Greeks, Carians, Phoenicians, Cypriots, Aramaeans, and Jews in Egypt during the Inter-Occupation Period brought great ethnic and cultural diversity, as these groups retained the languages and culture of their home communities. This diversity contributed to Egypt being a diverse, cosmopolitan state during this time in Northeast Africa.
Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period (404 BCE–342 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What significant innovation was adopted in Egypt during the Inter-Occupation Period?

Egypt - Inter-Occupation Period: A significant innovation adopted in Egypt during the Inter-Occupation Period was the widespread adoption of the qanat water supply technology, brought in by the occupying Persians in the 5th century BCE. Qanats provided a reliable supply of water for drinking, bathing, and irrigation, impacting the daily lives of Egyptians during this period.
Ptolemaic Kingdom II (217 BCE–30 BCE) — Northeast Africa: Who founded the Ptolemaic Kingdom II and when did he declare himself king of Egypt?
The Ptolemaic Kingdom II was founded by Ptolemy I Soter, who declared himself king of Egypt in 305 BCE, becoming the founder of a powerful dynasty that ruled Egypt for almost three centuries.
Ptolemaic Kingdom II (217 BCE–30 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What were the expansionist ambitions of Ptolemy I and his successors in the Ptolemaic Kingdom II?

Ptolemy I and his successors in the Ptolemaic Kingdom II had expansionist ambitions, seeking to carve out more territory for their kingdom, often at the expense of other kingdoms that had splintered from Alexander's empire, especially the Seleucid Kingdom of the Middle East.
Ptolemaic Kingdom II (217 BCE–30 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the extent of the Ptolemaic Empire during the Ptolemaic Kingdom II period?

The Ptolemaic Empire during the Ptolemaic Kingdom II period reached as far south as Lower Nubia, west to Cyrenaica, east to Cyprus, Syria, Phoenicia, and Asia Minor, and north into the Aegean, making Egypt a true 'Mediterranean power' under its new Macedonian rulers.
Ptolemaic Kingdom II (217 BCE–30 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the population of Egypt during the Ptolemaic Kingdom II period?

The population of Egypt during the Ptolemaic Kingdom II period has been estimated at around 4 million people in the 3rd century BCE, with between 5 and 10 percent being Greeks, while the total population of the entire Ptolemaic Empire may have reached 7 million.
Ptolemaic Kingdom II (217 BCE–30 BCE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Ptolemies in the Ptolemaic Kingdom II portray themselves to the resident Greeks and the native Egyptian?

The Ptolemies in the Ptolemaic Kingdom II portrayed themselves as Graeco-Macedonian kings to the resident Greeks and as divine pharaohs to the native Egyptian population, presiding over a 'double society'.
Ptolemaic Kingdom II (217 BCE–30 BCE) — Northeast Africa: What was the chief aim of the government in the Ptolemaic Kingdom II?

The chief aim of the government in the Ptolemaic Kingdom II was to draw as much revenue as possible from the population, resulting in a heavy burden of taxation, with the Ptolemies using state functionaries and tax farmers to divert wealth from temples, estates, and farmers to the royal coffers.
Axum I (149 BCE–349 CE) — East Africa: What characterized the Axum I empire in East Africa?
The Axum I empire was characterised by a combination of indigenous Ethiopian and South Arabian culture.
Axum I (149 BCE–349 CE) — East Africa: How was the Axum I empire governed?

The Axum I empire was governed by a single ruler, known as the negus, and his retinue, with provinces ruled indirectly through regional rulers who sent tribute, which was part of the Axum I empire's administrative system.
Axum I (149 BCE–349 CE) — East Africa: What was the estimated population of the Axum I empire without Arabian and Nubian territories?
The population of the Axum I empire without Arabian and Nubian territories has been estimated as at the outside half a million, giving an idea of the Axum I empire's size.
Axum I (149 BCE–349 CE) — East Africa: What was the size of the core area of Aksum during the first four centuries CE?
The core area of Aksum, which was the capital of the Axum I empire, covered between 80 and 100 hectares during the first four centuries CE, providing insight into the Axum I empire's core area.
Middle Wagadu Empire (700 CE–1077 CE) — West Africa: How was the Middle Wagadu Empire's society organized?

The Middle Wagadu Empire society was highly hierarchical, with the Middle Wagadu Empire distinguishing between the elite warrior class and the rest of the population, including professional artisans, farmers, herders, and slaves, with these groups further subdivided along clan lines.
Middle Wagadu Empire (700 CE–1077 CE) — West Africa: What were the main crops produced in the Sudanese region during the Middle Wagadu Empire period?

The Sudanese region produced millet, maize, yam, groundnuts, cotton, indigo, and other crops during the Middle Wagadu Empire period, with the Middle Wagadu Empire being a prosperous period for the region.
Middle Wagadu Empire (700 CE–1077 CE) — West Africa: What was the role of the king in the Middle Wagadu Empire?

The king of the Middle Wagadu Empire exerted direct authority over his kingdom and was also the head of the traditional religion, revered as a god, with the Middle Wagadu Empire having a central government that administered four provinces.
Middle Wagadu Empire (700 CE–1077 CE) — West Africa: What were the main exports and imports of the Middle Wagadu Empire?

The Middle Wagadu Empire exported gold, slaves, hides, and ivory, and imported copper, silver beads, dried fruit, and cloth, with all exports and imports being taxed by the centralized state of the Middle Wagadu Empire.
Middle Wagadu Empire (700 CE–1077 CE) — West Africa: What can be said about the capital city of the Middle Wagadu Empire?

The capital city of the Middle Wagadu Empire, Kumbi Saleh, was a thriving trading city that covered 250 hectares and had a population of 15,000-20,000 people at its peak, with the Middle Wagadu Empire having a well-developed urban center.
Fatimid Caliphate (909 CE–1171 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the duration of the Fatimid Caliphate in Northeast Africa?
The Fatimid Caliphate lasted from 909 to 1171 CE. During this time, the Fatimid Caliphate extended its rule into Egypt and much of North Africa.
Fatimid Caliphate (909 CE–1171 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the impact of the Fatimid viziers on the Fatimid Caliphate in the 11th century?

The Fatimid viziers increased their control of the military and turned the imam-caliph into a nominal figurehead, marking the effective end of the Fatimid Caliphate at the end of the 11th century. The Fatimid Caliphate remained nominally intact for nearly another century, but experienced a long decline marked by incompetent viziers.
Fatimid Caliphate (909 CE–1171 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did the population of the Fatimid Caliphate change over time?

The population of the Fatimid Caliphate peaked at about 12-13 million in 1000 CE, but subsequently declined as territory was lost to about 4 million in 1100 CE. By the end of the 10th century, the population of the caliphate was roughly equivalent to that of Egypt. The Fatimid Caliphate experienced a significant decline in population over the centuries.
Fatimid Caliphate (909 CE–1171 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the significance of the city of al-Qahira in the Fatimid Caliphate?

The city of al-Qahira, also known as Cairo, was the capital of the Fatimid Caliphate and remained so until the fall of the dynasty in 1171. Al-Qahira was a major commercial center, with a famous market called the Market of the Lamps, and was described by the 10th-century geographer al-Muqaddasi as 'the storehouse of the Occident, the entrepot of the Orient'. The Fatimid Caliphate invested heavily in public works in al-Qahira, including the construction of public baths and a caravanserai for foreign merchants.
Later Wagadu Empire (1078 CE–1203 CE) — West Africa: What was the name of the empire referred to by the Soninke people in West Africa during the Later Wagadu Empire period?
The Later Wagadu Empire, also known as the Kingdom of Ghana, was referred to as 'Wagadu' by its dominant people, a northern Mande group known as the Soninke, in West Africa.
Later Wagadu Empire (1078 CE–1203 CE) — West Africa: What factors contributed to the decline of the Ghana Empire in the late 11th century CE?
The Ghana Empire, also known as the Later Wagadu Empire, began to decline due to a combination of environmental, social, and political factors in the late 11th century CE.
Later Wagadu Empire (1078 CE–1203 CE) — West Africa: What was the significance of the city of Walata during the Later Wagadu Empire period?

The city of Walata grew in influence and took over as the main southern terminus of the trans-Saharan trade during the Later Wagadu Empire period, as the Sosso people took control of a large region above the Upper Niger River.
Later Wagadu Empire (1078 CE–1203 CE) — West Africa: What was the social organization of the Later Wagadu Empire like?

The Later Wagadu Empire society was highly hierarchical, distinguishing between the elite warrior class and the rest of the population, including professional artisans, farmers, herders, and slaves, which were further subdivided along clan lines.
Later Wagadu Empire (1078 CE–1203 CE) — West Africa: What were some of the key exports and imports of the Sudanese region during the Later Wagadu Empire period?

The Sudanese region, which included the Later Wagadu Empire, exported gold, slaves, hides, and ivory, and imported copper, silver beads, dried fruit, and cloth, with all exports and imports being taxed by the centralized state.
Mali Empire (1230 CE–1410 CE) — West Africa: What filled the power vacuum left in the Sudanese region after the decline of the Ghana Empire in West Africa?

The power vacuum left in the Sudanese region after the decline of the Ghana Empire in West Africa was filled with several smaller successor states, including the Sosso Kingdom, which was later united against by several Malinke chiefdoms that formed the Mali Empire.
Mali Empire (1230 CE–1410 CE) — West Africa: Who was the mansa that reigned over the Mali Empire from 1312 to 1337 and what were his achievements?

Musa I of the Keita dynasty was the mansa who reigned over the Mali Empire from 1312 to 1337, and his empire extended from the Atlantic to Gao and the Niger Inland Delta, and from the southern Sahara to the tropical forest belt, and he was also famed for his patronage of Islam in the Mali Empire and for his lavish distribution of gold.
Mali Empire (1230 CE–1410 CE) — West Africa: How was the Mali Empire organized politically and what was the role of the mansa?

The Mali Empire was a confederation incorporating smaller kingdoms, with the kings of the Keita dynasty at the apex, and the mansa was a 'chief of chiefs', assuming the mantle of a supreme patriarch, who could dispense justice personally and received advice from the griot.
Mali Empire (1230 CE–1410 CE) — West Africa: What was the composition of the aristocracy in the Mali Empire and what was the role of the merchant class?

The aristocracy in the Mali Empire was formed around the Malinke warrior class, including an elite corps of cavalry, and the merchant class, known as Dyula or Wangara, formed settlements at the margins of the forest regions and participated in Trans-Saharan trade networks.
Mali Empire (1230 CE–1410 CE) — West Africa: What was the characteristic architecture of the cities in the Mali Empire and what was the empire's legacy in West Africa?

The cities of the Mali Empire had a characteristic mudbrick architecture, known as banco, and the empire's legacy in West Africa can be seen in the spread of its language, laws, and customs throughout the region.
Mali Empire (1230 CE–1410 CE) — West Africa: What led to the decline of the Mali Empire in the 15th century?

The Mali Empire began to decline in the 15th century due to internal political struggles, which made it difficult for the emperors to maintain control over the large region, and the capture of Timbuktu by the Tuareg in 1433, leading to the contraction of the empire's territory.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I (1260 CE–1348 CE) — Northeast Africa: What were the two possible start dates for the Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt?

The Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt had two possible start dates: 1250 CE, when the last Ayyubid ruler in Egypt was deposed, or 1260 CE, once a period of disorder that included an attack from the Mongols had ended, marking the beginning of the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I period.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I (1260 CE–1348 CE) — Northeast Africa: Who is considered the real founder of the Mamluk state in Egypt?

Baybars, sultan from 1260 to 1277 CE, is considered the real founder of the Mamluk state in Egypt during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I period, as he was a skilled statesman and organizer who killed the first two Mamluk sultans after victories on the battlefield.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I (1260 CE–1348 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the peak of sociopolitical development, wealth, and splendor in Egypt during the Egypt - Mamluk?

The peak of sociopolitical development, wealth, and splendor in Egypt during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I period occurred under the reign of Sultan Nasiri, before the plague arrived in Alexandria in 1347 CE, marking a significant event in the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I period.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I (1260 CE–1348 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the role of the na'ib al-saltana in the Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt?

The na'ib al-saltana, or viceroy, governed Egypt in the absence of the Mamluk sultan, who ruled from Cairo, during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I period, and was responsible for overseeing the administration of the country.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I (1260 CE–1348 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt generate revenue during the 14th century CE?

The Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt, during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I period, generated revenue through various means, including the annual revenue of 9.5 million dinars, which was higher than at almost any other time since the Arab conquest, and paid for the Al-Barid postal system initiated by Baybars.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I (1260 CE–1348 CE) — Northeast Africa: What public works projects did the Mamluk rulers in Egypt undertake during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I?

The Mamluk rulers in Egypt, during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I period, undertook various public works projects, including the construction of mosques, madrasas, tombs, and hospitals, such as the hospital established by Sultan Qalaun, which included a library and a permanent medical staff.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I (1260 CE–1348 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the population of Cairo and the Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt during the mid-14th century?

The population of Cairo was probably under 200,000 in the mid-14th century, while the Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt, during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate I period, had a population of around 6-7 million people, although this fluctuated due to severe bouts of famine.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate II (1348 CE–1412 CE) — Northeast Africa: What significant event occurred in Egypt in 1348 CE during the Mamluk Sultanate II period in Northeast Africa?

Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate II: The Mamluk Sultanate II period in Northeast Africa, specifically in Egypt, experienced a 'great crisis' that included the plague of 1348 CE, which brought an end to a period of spectacular prosperity for many Egyptians and had a significant impact on the region.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate II (1348 CE–1412 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the impact of the Black Death on the population of Egypt during the Mamluk Sultanate II period?

Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate II: The Mamluk Sultanate II period in Northeast Africa, specifically in Egypt, experienced a significant decline in population due to the Black Death, with the Egyptian population possibly declining by about one-quarter to one-third by the mid- to late 14th century, and the total population of the sultanate falling from perhaps 6-7 million to 4.8 million during this period.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate II (1348 CE–1412 CE) — Northeast Africa: What notable construction projects were carried out by the Mamluk ruling class in Northeast Africa,?

Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate II: The Mamluk Sultanate II period in Northeast Africa, specifically in Cairo, saw the construction of 49 mosques between 1341 and 1412 CE, including the 'gigantic' Sultan Hasan Mosque, which cost 20 million dirhams and is considered one of the most remarkable monuments of the Islamic world.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III (1412 CE–1517 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the origin of the rulers of the Mamluk Sultanate during the Burji period in Northeast Africa?
The Mamluk Sultanate, specifically the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III, was ruled by an elite 'slave' military caste of Circassian origin during the Burji period in Northeast Africa.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III (1412 CE–1517 CE) — Northeast Africa: Who were the most renowned rulers of the Mamluk Sultanate during Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III in Upper Egypt?
The most renowned of the rulers of the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III were the Sultans Barsbay and Qaytbay in Upper Egypt.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III (1412 CE–1517 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Mamluk Sultanate's population change during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III period in?
The population of the Mamluk Sultanate, specifically the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III, perhaps recovered slightly during this period, reaching about 6 million in 1500 CE in Northeast Africa.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III (1412 CE–1517 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the system of government in the Mamluk Sultanate during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III period?

The Mamluk Sultanate, specifically the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III, was ruled by a foreign 'slave-elite' that had to be constantly replaced by new 'slave' recruits, and the sultan performed a ritual manumission at his inaugural ceremony in Northeast Africa.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III (1412 CE–1517 CE) — Northeast Africa: What public works projects were undertaken by the Burji Sultans of the Mamluk Sultanate in Northeast Africa?

The Burji Sultans of the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III expended considerable resources on public works projects, including building and restoring schools, hostels, bathhouses, and mosques, such as the El Muayyad Mosque and the Mosque of Barsbay in Northeast Africa.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III (1412 CE–1517 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Mamluk Sultanate's economy change during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III period in Northeast?

The Mamluk Sultanate, specifically the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III, experienced economic collapse and disorder that preceded the Ottoman takeover in Northeast Africa, despite the continued financing of elaborate construction projects.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III (1412 CE–1517 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the role of the na'ib al-saltana in the Mamluk Sultanate during the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III?
The na'ib al-saltana, or viceroy, governed Egypt during the absence of the Mamluk sultan from the capital, Cairo, in the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III period.
Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III (1412 CE–1517 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Mamluk elite control the appointment of officials in the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III period?

The Mamluk elite controlled the appointment of judges, legal administrators, professors, Sufi shaykhs, prayer leaders, and other Muslim officials in the Egypt - Mamluk Sultanate III period, and paid the salaries of religious personnel, endowed their schools, and brought the religious establishment into a state bureaucracy.
Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty (1493 CE–1591 CE) — West Africa: How did the Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty operate as a state?

The Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty operated as a centralized unitary state, with the king being a revered figure but his authority tempered by the precepts of Islam, and the imperial council coordinating the activities of the central government.
Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty (1493 CE–1591 CE) — West Africa: What was the significance of the city of Timbuktu during the Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty?

The city of Timbuktu was a major centre of learning during the Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty, famed for its university, holy men, doctors, and teachers, who contributed to the spread of Islamic humanism among the urban elite in the region.
Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty (1493 CE–1591 CE) — West Africa: What was the estimated population of the city of Timbuktu during the Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty?
The Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty had an estimated population of 70,000 people living in the city of Timbuktu by 1580 under Askiya Daoud.
Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty (1493 CE–1591 CE) — West Africa: What led to the end of the Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty?
The Songhai Empire - Askiya Dynasty was brought to an abrupt end in the late 16th century after a succession crisis sparked a civil war, and the Sultan of Morocco invaded in 1591.
Late Shang (1250 BCE–1045 BCE) — North China: What characterized the Late Shang Dynasty in North China?

The Late Shang Dynasty was characterized by a fully formed writing system, which included pictograms, ideograms, and phonograms, and was found at Late Shang sites, such as Yinxu, near modern Anyang, during the Late Shang period.
Late Shang (1250 BCE–1045 BCE) — North China: What was the significance of Yinxu in the Late Shang Dynasty?

The civilization at Yinxu, in the Middle Yellow River Valley of North China, is considered to represent the golden age of the Late Shang Dynasty, with 11 major royal tombs uncovered there by archaeologists during the Late Shang period.
Late Shang (1250 BCE–1045 BCE) — North China: What were some of the notable artistic achievements of the Late Shang period in North China?
During the Late Shang period, pottery, bronze, and jade work flourished, showcasing the artistic advancements of the Late Shang Dynasty in North China.
Late Shang (1250 BCE–1045 BCE) — North China: What was the calendar system like during the Late Shang period?
The Late Shang Dynasty had a developed calendar system, which consisted of 30 days in a month and 12 months, totaling 360 days in a year, used by the Late Shang in North China.
Late Shang (1250 BCE–1045 BCE) — North China: How was the Late Shang Dynasty governed in North China?

The Late Shang Dynasty was governed by a feudal system, in which the king and a class of military nobility ruled over the masses, who were mainly farmers, with the Shang kings also serving as high priests in the Late Shang Dynasty in North China.
Late Shang (1250 BCE–1045 BCE) — North China: What was the population of the Late Shang Dynasty in 1045 BCE?
The population of the Late Shang Dynasty was around 5 million in 1045 BCE, during the Late Shang period in North China.
Western Zhou (1122 BCE–771 BCE) — North China: What was the significance of the Western Zhou Dynasty in Chinese history?

The Western Zhou Dynasty was the first Chinese state to claim the Mandate of Heaven, the divinely bestowed right to rule, and it introduced the Mandate of Heaven, a kinship-based feudal system, and lineage law to North China, specifically the Middle Yellow River Valley.
Western Zhou (1122 BCE–771 BCE) — North China: What was the estimated territory controlled by the Western Zhou Dynasty in 957 BCE?

In 957 BCE, the Western Zhou controlled territory covering an estimated 850,000 square kilometres based in the central plains of China, which was a significant portion of the Western Zhou territory in North China.
Western Zhou (1122 BCE–771 BCE) — North China: What led to the end of the Western Zhou Dynasty in 771 BCE?

The Western Zhou Dynasty ended in 771 BCE when the Marquess of Shen sacked Haojing and killed the 12th Zhou king over a succession dispute, leading to the founding of the Eastern Zhou dynasty by the crown prince, marking the end of the Western Zhou period in North China.
Western Zhou (1122 BCE–771 BCE) — North China: What were some of the key features of the Western Zhou state's political organization?

The Western Zhou state was a proto-feudal monarchy with a kinship-based feudal system, where feudal lords were supported by an extended family network, and individual fiefdoms had their own taxes, legal systems, and currencies, but paid dues to the king and provided soldiers in times of need, characteristic of the Western Zhou period.
Jin (780 BCE–404 BCE) — North China: What was the role of the Jin state in the Spring and Autumn period in North China?

The Jin state dominated the Spring and Autumn period from 636 to 628 BCE in North China, and was one of the four major states, along with Qi, Qin, and Chu, that dominated the region by the mid-7th century BCE. The Jin state was located in modern Shanxi, and extended east and north from the Yellow River. During this time, the Jin state played a significant role in the constant warfare between different states in the Spring and Autumn period.
Jin (780 BCE–404 BCE) — North China: Who was Duke Xian of Jin and what did he achieve in the Jin state?

Duke Xian of Jin, who ruled from 676 to 651 BCE, conquered 16 small states in modern Shanxi, contributing to the expansion of the Jin state. The Jin state, under the leadership of Duke Xian and later his son Duke Wen, became a major power in the Spring and Autumn period.
Jin (780 BCE–404 BCE) — North China: What was the significance of the Jin state's location in North China?

The Jin state was located in modern Shanxi, and extended east and north from the Yellow River, covering an estimated 160,000 square kilometres in North China. This location played a crucial role in the Jin state's dominance of the Spring and Autumn period in North China.
Jin (780 BCE–404 BCE) — North China: How did the Jin state fit into the political organization of the Spring and Autumn period in North China?

The Jin state was part of the multi-state Spring and Autumn system, which changed the feudal structure of China in North China. In this system, the Jin state, along with other vassal states, held significant governmental authority, while the weak Eastern Zhou state was responsible for diplomacy and rituals in North China.
Jin (780 BCE–404 BCE) — North China: What was the role of Duke Wen of Jin in the Jin state's relationship with the Zhou king?

Duke Wen of Jin was given the title of ba by the Zhou king after defeating the encroaching state of Chu in 632 BCE, solidifying the Jin state's position as a major power in the Spring and Autumn period in North China. The Jin state, under Duke Wen's leadership, represented the Zhou court in war and played a key role in the ba system of political organization.
Western Han Empire (202 BCE–9 CE) — North China: What was the Western Han Empire's significance in Chinese history?

The Western Han dynasty was the first lasting imperial dynasty in China, and its first emperor Liu Bang was the first commoner to become the emperor of China, marking the Western Han Empire as a pivotal period in Chinese history.
Western Han Empire (202 BCE–9 CE) — North China: What economic and technological innovations occurred during the Western Han Empire?

The Western Han dynasty is known for its economic, technological, and artistic innovations, including the opening of the Silk Road, state-controlled production of salt, iron, and coins, and the development of waterways and irrigation, as well as the widespread use of the iron plough and other iron agricultural tools, which characterized the Western Han Empire.
Western Han Empire (202 BCE–9 CE) — North China: What was the administrative structure of the Western Han Empire?

The Western Han dynasty was marked by a strong imperial government and a combination of centrally-controlled commandaries and semi-autonomous kingdoms, with the central government promoting Confucianism as a state doctrine, which defined the Western Han Empire's administrative structure.
Western Han Empire (202 BCE–9 CE) — North China: How did the Western Han Empire's population change over time?

The population of the Western Han empire was 57.6 million in 2 CE, and 60 million at its peak, with its capital Chang’an being home to between 250,000 and 400,000 people, indicating a significant population growth during the Western Han Empire period.
Western Han Empire (202 BCE–9 CE) — North China: What led to the downfall of the Western Han Empire?
The Western Han dynasty was overthrown by Wang Mang, who ruled as the emperor of the Xin dynasty from 9-23 CE, marking the end of the Western Han Empire.
Western Han Empire (202 BCE–9 CE) — North China: What was the significance of the imperial academy established during the Western Han Empire?

An imperial academy was established in 124 BCE during the Western Han Empire, and qualification through Confucian examinations slowly replaced hereditary assignment of government positions, which had a significant impact on the Western Han Empire's administrative structure.
Eastern Han Empire (25 CE–220 CE) — North China: What was the duration of the Eastern Han Empire in North China?

The Eastern Han Empire, which was located in North China, specifically in the Middle Yellow River Valley, lasted from 25 to 220 CE. During this time, the Eastern Han Empire was a major power in the region. The Eastern Han Empire was a continuation of the Han dynasty, which was reinstated after the interregnum ruled by Wang Mang.
Eastern Han Empire (25 CE–220 CE) — North China: How did the Eastern Han Empire in North China come into being?

The Eastern Han Empire in North China was reinstated when military troops revolted against Wang Mang and attacked the capital of Chang’an in 23 CE. The first recognized Eastern Han emperor, Emperor Guangwudi, moved the capital to Luoyang in 25 CE, marking the beginning of the Eastern Han Empire in the region.
Eastern Han Empire (25 CE–220 CE) — North China: What significant cultural development occurred during the Eastern Han period in North China?

Eastern Han Empire: During the Eastern Han period in North China, Buddhism spread into the region and soon began to influence Chinese morals and ethics. The Eastern Han period also saw significant innovations, including the invention of paper made from mulberry bark by the eunuch Cai Lun in 105 CE.
Eastern Han Empire (25 CE–220 CE) — North China: What were the major challenges faced by the Eastern Han Empire in North China?

The Eastern Han Empire in North China faced a series of natural disasters, including floods and plagues, beginning in 168 CE. The empire also faced constant rebellions from Qiang ethnic minorities and two large peasant uprisings: the Yellow Turban Rebellion and the Five Pecks of Rice rebellion. Additionally, the Eastern Han Empire was marked by bloody political infighting and the rise of strong provincial rulers with independent armies.
Eastern Han Empire (25 CE–220 CE) — North China: What was the administrative structure of the Eastern Han Empire in North China?

The Eastern Han Empire in North China continued many of the administrative practices of the Western Han. However, the dynasty was marked by the influence of eunuchs, who competed with Confucian officials and the imperial clan. The decline of the Eastern Han Empire was marked by the rise of strong provincial rulers with independent armies, or warlords, and a weakening of the corrupt central government.
Western Jin (265 CE–317 CE) — North China: What significant event occurred in 265 CE during the Western Jin dynasty in North China?

The Western Jin dynasty briefly reunified China after the Three Kingdoms period, and Sima Yan overthrew Cao Wei emperor Cao Huan in 265 CE and declared himself the Western Jin emperor, marking the beginning of the Western Jin dynasty.
Western Jin (265 CE–317 CE) — North China: What was the outcome of the Western Jin dynasty's conquest of Eastern Wu in 280 CE?
The Western Jin dynasty ended the Three Kingdoms period and reunified China with its 280 CE conquest of Eastern Wu, achieving a significant milestone for the Western Jin dynasty.
Western Jin (265 CE–317 CE) — North China: What internal conflicts affected the Western Jin dynasty in North China?

The Western Jin dynasty was marked by political turmoil and internal rebellion, including a series of rebellions of princes against imperial authority known as the Revolts of the Imperial Princes, which weakened the central government of the Western Jin dynasty.
Western Jin (265 CE–317 CE) — North China: How did the Disorder of the Five Tribes impact the Western Jin dynasty?

The Disorder of the Five Tribes, a large uprising of northern nomadic tribes from 304-316 CE, further weakened the central government of the Western Jin dynasty, leading to significant instability in the region of North China.
Western Jin (265 CE–317 CE) — North China: What was the outcome for the Western Jin dynasty after the Xiongnu chief's attack on Luoyang in 316 CE?

An imperial Jin prince fled south when a Xiongnu chief attacked the Western Jin capital of Luoyang, and the prince went on to found the Eastern Jin dynasty, marking the end of the Western Jin dynasty in North China.
Western Jin (265 CE–317 CE) — North China: What were some notable advancements made during the Western Jin dynasty in North China?

Despite the political turmoil of the Western Jin dynasty, advancements were made in agriculture, craftsmanship, architecture, medicine, astronomy, and mathematics, and Buddhism continued to spread throughout China, with the Western Jin dynasty seeing significant cultural and scientific developments.
Western Jin (265 CE–317 CE) — North China: What was the estimated territory size of the Western Jin empire in 300 CE?

The territory of the Western Jin empire was estimated to cover 4.5 million square kilometers in 300 CE, making it close to the size of the Han empire, with the Western Jin dynasty controlling a vast territory in North China.
Western Jin (265 CE–317 CE) — North China: What was the population of the Western Jin empire according to the 280 CE census?
The population of the Western Jin empire was recorded as 16.16 million in a 280 CE census, providing insight into the demographics of the Western Jin dynasty during that time.
Northern Wei (386 CE–534 CE) — North China: What was the outcome of the Northern Wei dynasty's unification of northern China during the Northern and Southern dynasties period?

The Northern Wei dynasty unified northern China during the Northern and Southern dynasties period, conquering Northern Yan and Northern Liang to unify the north, and by 439 CE, the dynasty controlled Henan, Hebei, and parts of Shaanxi, Manchuria, Gansu, and Sichuan, with the Northern Wei territory expanding from the Tarim Basin to the Yellow Sea.
Northern Wei (386 CE–534 CE) — North China: What was the origin and background of the rulers of the Northern Wei dynasty?

The rulers of the Northern Wei dynasty belonged to the Tuoba tribe of the Xianbei northern steppe federation, with the Tuoba language being close to Turkish, and the non-Han Chinese rulers initially being seen as foreign invaders, but later Sinicizing their customs, language, and government in the late 400s.
Northern Wei (386 CE–534 CE) — North China: What was the significance of Buddhism during the Northern Wei dynasty?

The Northern Wei dynasty upheld Buddhism as a state religion for most of its duration, with the construction of the Buddhist caves of Yungang and Longmen during this period, and by the early 500s, Luoyang had over one thousand monasteries.
Northern Wei (386 CE–534 CE) — North China: What led to the fall of the Northern Wei dynasty?
The Northern Wei dynasty fell due to a civil war caused by rebellions in garrisons in the northern frontier, which split the dynasty into Eastern and Western Wei in 535 CE.
Northern Wei (386 CE–534 CE) — North China: What was the social and economic organization of the Northern Wei dynasty?

The Northern Wei dynasty had a system where nobles and landowners often had vesting holdings with dependent servants and slaves who did not pay taxes, but the government attempted to break up these large holdings, and instituted an equal-fields system in which the state owned all land and individuals were given certain allotments for life.
Sui Dynasty (581 CE–618 CE) — North China: What event occurred in China after the Northern and Southern dynasties period?

The Sui Dynasty reunified China after the Northern and Southern dynasties period, ruling from 581 to 618 CE. The Sui dynasty was able to unify China but did not create a stable, lasting imperial house. The Sui Dynasty's reunification was led by the first Sui emperor Yang Jian.
Sui Dynasty (581 CE–618 CE) — North China: Who was the first emperor of the Sui Dynasty and what did he accomplish?
The first Sui emperor was Yang Jian, who dethroned the Northern Zhou emperor and conquered the southern Chen dynasty, thus beginning the Sui Dynasty's rule in North China.
Sui Dynasty (581 CE–618 CE) — North China: What were some of the notable projects undertaken by the second Sui emperor Yangdi?

The second Sui emperor Yangdi undertook massive infrastructure projects, including the fortification of the Great Wall, the construction of a third capital at Jiangdu, and the Grand Canal, which were significant achievements of the Sui Dynasty.
Sui Dynasty (581 CE–618 CE) — North China: What were the consequences of Yangdi's military campaigns and use of conscripted labor?

The Sui Dynasty's use of conscripted corvee labor, coupled with natural disasters and endless military campaigns, led to famine, and the dynasty was eventually overthrown by massive peasant rebellions and revolts by nobles after only 37 years of rule.
Sui Dynasty (581 CE–618 CE) — North China: What was the significance of the Sui Dynasty's construction of infrastructure and government reforms?

The Sui Dynasty's construction of infrastructure, such as the Grand Canal, and government reforms paved the way for the lasting rule of the Tang Dynasty, and had a lasting impact on the region of North China.
Sui Dynasty (581 CE–618 CE) — North China: What were some of the key administrative reforms implemented by the Sui Dynasty?

The Sui Dynasty's administrative reforms abolished all fiefdoms and set up a prefecture system, reformed the examination and military system, and reestablished Han Confucian government rituals, which were important reforms in the Sui Dynasty's rule of North China.
Sui Dynasty (581 CE–618 CE) — North China: What was the recorded population of the Sui Dynasty in 609 CE?

The Sui Dynasty's population was recorded as 46 million in a 609 CE census, although some modern scholars believe that this number may be too low, and this population was primarily located in the Sui Dynasty's territory in North China.
Tang Dynasty I (617 CE–763 CE) — North China: What is considered the cultural and political high point of imperial China in North China during the Tang Dynasty I period?

The Tang Dynasty I is widely considered a cultural and political high point of imperial China. The Tang Dynasty I was founded by Li Yuan, the Duke of Tang, and was characterized by a cultural and economic golden age during Emperor Xuanzong's 44-year reign.
Tang Dynasty I (617 CE–763 CE) — North China: Who founded the Tang Dynasty I in North China and when did he seize the abandoned capital of Luoyang?

The Tang Dynasty I was founded by Li Yuan, the Duke of Tang, who marched to Luoyang and seized the abandoned capital in 618 CE. Li Yuan became the first emperor of the Tang Dynasty I and is posthumously known as Gaozu.
Tang Dynasty I (617 CE–763 CE) — North China: What were some of the key characteristics of the Early Tang Dynasty I in North China?

The Early Tang Dynasty I was characterized by a cultural and economic golden age, increased trade, and general cosmopolitanism. The dynasty was also famous for its poetry and literature, and was marked by the expanding use of merit examinations in the government bureaucracy.
Tang Dynasty I (617 CE–763 CE) — North China: How did the territory of China change under the Early Tang Dynasty I leadership in North China?

Under Early Tang Dynasty I leadership, China's territory expanded considerably, with conquered territories including large areas of Central Asia and northern Korea. However, in later years, China pursued a defensive, non-expansionist policy towards groups on the steppe and frontier.
Tang Dynasty I (617 CE–763 CE) — North China: What was the 'equal fields' system instituted by the Tang Dynasty I in North China?

The Tang Dynasty I instituted the 'equal fields' system, in which land owned by the state was parcelled out in equal allotments to citizens in return for taxation. This system was part of the efforts of Emperor Gaozu to restore control of the imperial government.
Tang Dynasty I (617 CE–763 CE) — North China: What was the role of the emperor in the Early Tang Dynasty I imperial government in North China?

The Early Tang Dynasty I imperial government was characterized by an emperor who theoretically had absolute power, but was often in practice overruled by ministers or regents. The central government was headed by three chief ministers who ran the Imperial Chancellery, Imperial Secretariat, and the Department for State Affairs.
Tang Dynasty I (617 CE–763 CE) — North China: Who was the first woman to rule China during the Tang Dynasty I period in North China?

Empress Wu became the first woman to rule China during the Tang Dynasty I period, first governing as a regent to her young son and later ruling as empress dowager and regent until her death in 705 CE.
Nara Kingdom (710 CE–794 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the Nara Kingdom's relationship with T'ang China during the Nara period in Northeast Asia?
The Nara Kingdom was engaged in a vassalage relationship with T'ang China, which influenced many aspects of Japanese culture, from city planning to the ideal of imperial rule, during the Nara period.
Nara Kingdom (710 CE–794 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the geography of Japan impact the Nara Kingdom's control over external political relationships in Northeast Asia?

The Nara Kingdom's geography provided some insulation from unwanted incursions from the continent, and allowed the court to exert some control over external political relationships during the Nara period.
Nara Kingdom (710 CE–794 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the outcome of the Nara Kingdom's military efforts during the Nara period in Northeast Asia?

The Nara Kingdom used its military prowess to exert control over much of the territory of the archipelago, although the northern and southern extremes remained beyond centralized control during the Nara period.
Nara Kingdom (710 CE–794 CE) — Northeast Asia: What characterized the imperial rule of the Nara Kingdom during the Nara period in Northeast Asia?
The Nara Kingdom's imperial rule was direct and legitimised by divine descent during the Nara period.
Nara Kingdom (710 CE–794 CE) — Northeast Asia: How did the Nara Kingdom's government change during the Nara period in Northeast Asia?
The Nara Kingdom's government continued to strengthen and centralize its rule with administration and legal reforms inspired by the Chinese ritsuryo system during the Nara period.
Nara Kingdom (710 CE–794 CE) — Northeast Asia: What was the estimated population of the Nara Kingdom during the Nara period in Northeast Asia?
The estimated population of the Nara Kingdom during the Nara period ranged from roughly 5 to 7 million.
Tang Dynasty II (763 CE–907 CE) — North China: What is considered the cultural and political high point of imperial China during the Tang Dynasty II period in North China?
The Tang Dynasty II is widely considered a cultural and political high point of imperial China. The Tang Dynasty II, which ruled North China, was a significant period in Chinese history.
Tang Dynasty II (763 CE–907 CE) — North China: What event marked the end of the Early period and the beginning of the Late period of the Tang Dynasty II in the Middle Yellow?

The Tang Dynasty II, which ruled the Middle Yellow River Valley, was divided into an Early period and a Late period, separated by the decline in imperial authority and instability experienced by the Tang in the 750s, culminating in the An Lushan rebellion to close out the Early period.
Tang Dynasty II (763 CE–907 CE) — North China: What was the result of Emperor Wuzong's persecution of Buddhists and non-indigenous religions during the Tang Dynasty II period?

The Tang Dynasty II, which ruled North China, saw Emperor Wuzong persecute Buddhists and adherents of other non-indigenous religions, with his movement reaching its height in 845 CE and most monasteries being destroyed, but his successors reversed his anti-Buddhist policies.
Tang Dynasty II (763 CE–907 CE) — North China: What was the population of Late Tang China during the Tang Dynasty II period?

The Tang Dynasty II, which ruled North China, had a population that is difficult to estimate due to constant conflict, but in 766 CE there were between 40 million and 55 million citizens, and in 900 CE there were between 60 million and 80 million.
Tang Dynasty II (763 CE–907 CE) — North China: What system of taxation did the Tang Dynasty II government in North China implement in 780 CE?

The Tang Dynasty II government in North China implemented the two-tax system in 780 CE, which replaced the 'equal land' distribution system of the Early Tang and represented an attempt to weaken military garrison governments and to divert taxation income to the central government.
Tang Dynasty II (763 CE–907 CE) — North China: What was the role of eunuchs in the Late Tang Dynasty II central government in the Middle Yellow River Valley?

The Tang Dynasty II, which ruled the Middle Yellow River Valley, saw the rise of eunuchs in the central government, with the Department of the Inner Palace, staffed by eunuchs, becoming a powerful governmental authority, more powerful than the emperor's chief ministers.
Jin Dynasty (1115 CE–1234 CE) — North China: What was the duration of the Jin Dynasty in North China?

The Jin Dynasty ruled north China from 1115 to 1234 CE, and during this period, the Jin Dynasty was marked by conflict with the Southern Song and the Mongols, ultimately being conquered by Mongol forces in 1233 CE, which led to the end of the Jin Dynasty.
Jin Dynasty (1115 CE–1234 CE) — North China: What was the impact of the Jin Dynasty on the population of North China?

The Jin Dynasty was the first period in Chinese history in which large populations of ethnic Han citizens were ruled by an outsider government, with the population of the Jin dynasty being between 45 million and 54 million people in 1200 CE, and the Jurchen people making up about 10 percent of the population of Jin Dynasty China.
Jin Dynasty (1115 CE–1234 CE) — North China: What was the significance of the Jin Dynasty's capital move in 1153 CE?

In 1153 CE, the Jurchen government moved its capital from Manchuria to modern-day Beijing, which was a significant event during the Jin Dynasty, marking a shift in the center of power for the Jin Dynasty.
Jin Dynasty (1115 CE–1234 CE) — North China: How did the Jin Dynasty interact with neighboring territories?

The Jin Dynasty included part of Korea in northeast Asia, and Uighur and Tibetan land in western China, and the Jin Dynasty was marked by conflict with the Southern Song and the Mongols, ultimately being conquered by Mongol forces in 1233 CE, which led to the end of the Jin Dynasty.
Mongol Empire (1206 CE–1270 CE) — Mongolia: Where did the Mongol Empire originate from?

The Mongol Empire began as one of a group of nomadic tribes living on the Central Asian Steppe in Mongolia, specifically in the Orkhon Valley region, and was led by Temujin, later called Chinggis Khan, who united the different Mongol families and incorporated other tribes into the 'Mongols'.
Mongol Empire (1206 CE–1270 CE) — Mongolia: Who led the Mongols and when was he acknowledged as the leader of all Central Asian tribes?

The Mongol Empire was led by Temujin, or Temuchin, later called Chinggis Khan, who was acknowledged as the leader of all the Central Asian tribes in 1206 CE, marking the beginning of the Mongol Empire.
Mongol Empire (1206 CE–1270 CE) — Mongolia: What was the extent of the Mongol Empire's expansion?

The Mongol Empire expanded into northern China, Iran, southern Russia, and the German lands, before turning its attention back to China and the Middle East, with Khubilai Khan moving into southern China and Hulegu capturing Baghdad, representing the height of the Mongol Empire's territory and achievement.
Great Yuan (1271 CE–1368 CE) — North China: Where was the core territory of the Great Yuan located?

The Great Yuan's core territory covered North China, Manchuria, and the Inner Mongolian steppe. The Great Yuan eventually expanded over most of China, Tibet, and into Korea during its military campaigns.
Great Yuan (1271 CE–1368 CE) — North China: What was the administrative structure of the Great Yuan Empire?

The Great Yuan Empire was administratively modelled on its Jin predecessor and ruled through a variety of entities such as the Secretariat, the Military Affairs Bureau, and the Censorate. The Great Yuan also retained Mongolian institutions, such as the keshig and the ordos, which acted as separate vassal states under nominal imperial control.
Great Yuan (1271 CE–1368 CE) — North China: What was the population of the Great Yuan China?

The population of the Great Yuan China may have been between 60 and 85 million people. The Great Yuan encompassed a territory that fluctuated between roughly 11 and 24 million square kilometres, supporting this large population.
Great Yuan (1271 CE–1368 CE) — North China: What was the significance of the city of Dadu during the Great Yuan period?

The city of Dadu, also known as Khanbalik or Daidu, was the new capital constructed by Kublai Khan during the Great Yuan period. Dadu was located on the site of modern Beijing and may have had 600,000 inhabitants at its height, serving as a symbol of the Great Yuan's syncretism of Mongolian and Chinese influences.
Great Ming (1368 CE–1644 CE) — North China: What event marked the beginning of the Great Ming period in North China?

The Great Ming period began when the Ming capital was founded in Nanjing in 1368 CE by Emperor Taizu, also known as the Hongwu Emperor, after he destroyed the Yuan capital in Beijing and forced the Mongols to retreat to Mongolia, thus restoring Chinese rule to the region during the Great Ming.
Great Ming (1368 CE–1644 CE) — North China: What led to the end of the Great Ming Dynasty in North China?

The Great Ming Dynasty came to an end in 1644 CE, when the region was re-captured by descendants of Jin Dynasty's Jurchen rulers from Manchuria known as Qing, marking the end of the Great Ming period.
Great Ming (1368 CE–1644 CE) — North China: What was the style of rule of the Great Ming emperors in North China?

The Great Ming emperors were not consistent in their style of rule, with Emperor Taizu ruling as an autocrat, while some Great Ming emperors left the governance of the nation in the hands of officials and eunuchs, characteristic of the Great Ming period.
Great Ming (1368 CE–1644 CE) — North China: How did the Great Ming period impact intellectual culture in North China?

The Great Ming period was marked by increasing openness to non-Confucian ideas and an increase in literacy among the lower levels of society, with intellectual culture flourishing among the elites, and the publishing industry expanding greatly in the Lower Yangtze region during the Great Ming.
Great Ming (1368 CE–1644 CE) — North China: What was the population of the Great Ming in North China during the 15th and 17th centuries?
The Great Ming population was between 60 million and 66.5 million in 1400 CE and 90 million and 110 million in 1600 CE, reflecting the growth of the Great Ming period.
Great Ming (1368 CE–1644 CE) — North China: How did foreign trade impact the Great Ming economy in North China?

The rapid growth of the international trading system led to large increases in foreign trade and an influx of silver into the Great Ming economy, but trade conflicts later impacted China's foreign silver supply, leading to massive deflation during the Great Ming period.
Xiongnu Imperial Confederation (209 BCE–60 BCE) — Mongolia: What region in Mongolia was under the control of the Xiongnu Imperial Confederation between 200 BCE and 100 CE?
The Xiongnu Imperial Confederation controlled the Orkhon Valley in north-central Mongolia between 200 BCE and 100 CE. The Orkhon Valley lies either side of the Orkhon River.
Xiongnu Imperial Confederation (209 BCE–60 BCE) — Mongolia: What was the composition of the Xiongnu Imperial Confederation?
The Xiongnu Imperial Confederation comprised several nomadic peoples from the Mongolian Steppe.
Xiongnu Imperial Confederation (209 BCE–60 BCE) — Mongolia: How did the Xiongnu Imperial Confederation initially interact with northern China?

The Xiongnu Imperial Confederation began raiding northern China by the 4th century BCE, where their mounted archery overwhelmed the heavily armed but relatively immobile Chinese infantry. The Xiongnu were held at bay by a combination of tribute and China's numerical superiority.
Xiongnu Imperial Confederation (209 BCE–60 BCE) — Mongolia: What led to the breakup of the Xiongnu Imperial Confederation?

The Xiongnu Imperial Confederation broke up due to several Chinese victories against them in the 1st century BCE and factional conflict within the confederacy. The breakup led to a new group, the Xianbei, taking control of the region.
Xiongnu Imperial Confederation (209 BCE–60 BCE) — Mongolia: How was the Xiongnu Imperial Confederation divided?

The Xiongnu Imperial Confederation was divided into three kingships: a central one, directly ruled by the paramount leader, and a 'left' one and a 'right' one, to the east and west, respectively, distributed among twenty-four regional leaders known as the 'ten thousand horsemen'.
Late Xiongnu (60 BCE–100 CE) — Mongolia: What region did the Late Xiongnu control between 200 BCE and 100 CE?

The Late Xiongnu controlled the Orkhon Valley, which lies either side of the Orkhon River, in north-central Mongolia, during this period. The Late Xiongnu comprised several nomadic peoples from the Mongolian Steppe. The Orkhon Valley was a key area under the control of the Xiongnu Imperial Confederation.
Late Xiongnu (60 BCE–100 CE) — Mongolia: How did the Chinese infantry fare against the Xiongnu's mounted archery?

The Late Xiongnu's mounted archery overwhelmed the heavily armed but relatively immobile Chinese infantry. The Chinese were able to hold the Late Xiongnu at bay through a combination of tribute and numerical superiority.
Late Xiongnu (60 BCE–100 CE) — Mongolia: What led to the breakup of the Xiongnu Imperial Confederation?

The Late Xiongnu confederacy's breakup was caused by several Chinese victories against the Late Xiongnu in the 1st century BCE and factional conflict within the confederacy. This led to a new group, the Xianbei, taking control of the region.
Late Xiongnu (60 BCE–100 CE) — Mongolia: How was the Late Xiongnu empire divided?

The Late Xiongnu empire was divided into three kingships: a central one, directly ruled by the paramount leader, and a 'left' one and a 'right' one, to the east and west, respectively, distributed among twenty-four regional leaders known as the 'ten thousand horsemen'. The Late Xiongnu had a complex system of governance.
Rouran Khaganate (300 CE–555 CE) — Mongolia: Where was the Rouran Khaganate located?
The Rouran Khaganate was located in the Orkhon Valley, in north-central Mongolia, with the Orkhon River running through it, and was established by the Rouran people.
Rouran Khaganate (300 CE–555 CE) — Mongolia: What was the lifestyle of the Rouran people during the Rouran Khaganate period?

The Rouran people, who established the Rouran Khaganate, began as nomadic pastoralists but transitioned to a settled, agricultural way of life by the sixth century CE, during the Rouran Khaganate period.
Rouran Khaganate (300 CE–555 CE) — Mongolia: What religious changes occurred among the Rouran people during the Rouran Khaganate?
During the Rouran Khaganate, the Rouran people transitioned from shamanism to Buddhism, marking a significant religious change within the Rouran Khaganate.
Rouran Khaganate (300 CE–555 CE) — Mongolia: How was the Rouran Khaganate empire organized?
The Rouran Khaganate empire was divided into an eastern and a western wing, each ruled by a silifa, who were subordinate to the paramount ruler or khagan of the Rouran Khaganate.
Rouran Khaganate (300 CE–555 CE) — Mongolia: How were the population and army of the Rouran Khaganate organized?
For ease of organisation, both the population and the army of the Rouran Khaganate were divided into groups of hundreds and thousands.
Kingdom of the Huns (376 CE–469 CE) — Central Europe: What event in 376 marked the expansion of the Kingdom of the Huns' horizons?

The Kingdom of the Huns' horizons were expanded after the fugitive Goths, who were forced to leave their homes by the Huns, inflicted a massive defeat on the Roman army at Adrianople in 376, allowing the Huns to raid the Balkans and attack the rich provinces of the east.
Kingdom of the Huns (376 CE–469 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Huns in Gaul act during the time of the Kingdom of the Huns?
The Kingdom of the Huns saw the Huns in Gaul acting as mercenary soldiers, with no territorial or political ambitions in the region, until Attila's rise to power.
Kingdom of the Huns (376 CE–469 CE) — Central Europe: What impact did Attila's rise to power have on the Kingdom of the Huns?
Attila's rise to power gave the Kingdom of the Huns a clear identity and made them, briefly, into a major political power, marking a significant change in their actions and ambitions.
Kingdom of the Huns (376 CE–469 CE) — Central Europe: What happened to the Kingdom of the Huns after Attila's death?

After Attila's death, his sons divided up the subject nations equally among themselves, but they soon began to quarrel, fighting several great battles as a result, and the Kingdom of the Huns disintegrated with remarkable speed.
Kingdom of the Huns (376 CE–469 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Kingdom of the Huns initially begin to expand in Central Europe?

The Kingdom of the Huns began to expand when the Huns, a Turkic people from the Central Asian steppes, moved west around 370 and attacked the Ostrogothic kingdom in the area of modern Ukraine, forcing the Ostrogoths to leave their homes and farms in panic.
Kidarite Kingdom (388 CE–477 CE) — Afghanistan: What was the duration of the Kidarite Kingdom in Central Asia?
The Kidarite Kingdom may have lasted less than 100 years, from approximately 388 to 477 CE, in the region of Afghanistan, specifically in Sogdiana, during the Kidarite Kingdom period.
Kidarite Kingdom (388 CE–477 CE) — Afghanistan: Who was the most influential ruler of the Kidarite Kingdom?

The most influential ruler of the Kidarites was perhaps king Kidara, who ruled during the Kidarite Kingdom period, with narrative sources placing him in the 420s CE and numismatists agreeing his rule began around 390 CE, in the Kidarite Kingdom.
Kidarite Kingdom (388 CE–477 CE) — Afghanistan: What territories did Kidara hold during the Kidarite Kingdom?

Khitan I (907 CE–1125 CE) — Mongolia: Where did the Khitan people first appear in documentary sources?

Kara-Khanids (950 CE–1212 CE) — Turkestan: What was the significance of the Karakhanid period in Central Asia's history?

Oirats (1368 CE–1630 CE) — Turkestan: How did the Oirat ruler Esen expand the Oirat territory?

Oirats (1368 CE–1630 CE) — Turkestan: What was the administrative division of Mongolian lands during the Oirat period?

Oirats (1368 CE–1630 CE) — Turkestan: How did the Oirats try to unite all the Mongols?

Lombard Kingdom (568 CE–774 CE) — Southern Europe: What was the origin of the Lombard Kingdom in Southern Europe?

French Kingdom - Early Valois (1328 CE–1450 CE) — Western Europe: What reforms were instituted by the crown in response to the decline in population and production during the?

Kassite Babylonia (1595 BCE–1150 BCE) — Mesopotamia: What changes did the Kassites make to Babylonian culture in Kassite Babylonia?
