Kassite Babylonia (1595 BCE–1150 BCE) — Mesopotamia: What was the impact of the Kassite period on the population and administration of Kassite Babylonia?

The Kassite period in Kassite Babylonia was characterized by an overall population decline, with border towns and villages being abandoned, and irrigation becoming less successful, while much of the administration was undertaken by or in the temples, which effectively owned most of the land in Kassite Babylonia.
Neo-Babylonian Empire (626 BCE–539 BCE) — Mesopotamia: What happened to Babylon during the Neo-Babylonian Empire period in Mesopotamia?

The Neo-Babylonian Empire saw Babylon being re-populated by the Chaldean people, and the rulers reclaimed the title of King of Babylon, with the city becoming the centre of the known world for culture, learning, and religion at the height of the Neo-Babylonian Empire's power.
Neo-Babylonian Empire (626 BCE–539 BCE) — Mesopotamia: Who played a key role in creating the Neo-Babylonian Empire in Southern Mesopotamia?

Nebachudrezzar played a key role in creating the Neo-Babylonian Empire, having gone on campaigns to defeat the Assyrian and Egyptian armies, and later undertaking a period of building, creating some of the most iconic Babylonian architecture during the Neo-Babylonian Empire period.
Neo-Babylonian Empire (626 BCE–539 BCE) — Mesopotamia: What led to the end of the Neo-Babylonian Empire in Mesopotamia?

The Neo-Babylonian Empire came to an end when Cyrus of the Achaemenid empire took over Babylon, either by being welcomed to depose the unpopular Nabonidus or by destroying the city, marking the end of the Neo-Babylonian Empire.
Neo-Babylonian Empire (626 BCE–539 BCE) — Mesopotamia: What was the cultural significance of Babylon during the Neo-Babylonian Empire period?

At the height of the Neo-Babylonian Empire's power, Babylon was given resources to become the centre of the known world for culture, learning, and religion, with the city's material culture showing continuity in form and style even through the Achaemenian transition during the Neo-Babylonian Empire period.
Neo-Babylonian Empire (626 BCE–539 BCE) — Mesopotamia: What is notable about the military literature of the Neo-Babylonian Empire in Mesopotamia?

The Neo-Babylonian Empire did not have the threatening military literature that pervaded the Neo-Assyrian empire, as it had reached its natural limit, surrounded by the Medians, Egyptians, and desert, resulting in less being known about the military capabilities of the Neo-Babylonian Empire.
Greco-Bactrian Kingdom (256 BCE–125 BCE) — Afghanistan: What type of monarchy was the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom?

The Greco-Bactrian Kingdom was a hereditary monarchy founded in the mid-3rd century BCE, probably by the Seleucid satrap Diodotus I, as a successor kingdom of the Seleucid Empire, and is known as the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom.
Greco-Bactrian Kingdom (256 BCE–125 BCE) — Afghanistan: How did the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom come to an end in Afghanistan?

The Greco-Bactrian Kingdom came to an end when it was conquered by nomadic peoples who were being pushed further west by the rising power of a unified Chinese empire, marking the end of the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom.
Greco-Bactrian Kingdom (256 BCE–125 BCE) — Afghanistan: What was the character of the cities that sprang up in Central Asia under the Greco-Bactrian rulers?
Under the Greco-Bactrian rulers, new cities based on the Greek street plan, such as Sirkap, sprang up in Central Asia, characteristic of the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom's influence in the region.
Greco-Bactrian Kingdom (256 BCE–125 BCE) — Afghanistan: What was notable about the administrative centre at Ai Khanoum in the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom?

The administrative centre at Ai Khanoum in the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom was Persian in style, likely organized into different departments and scribes, reflecting the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom's administrative structure.
Greco-Bactrian Kingdom (256 BCE–125 BCE) — Afghanistan: How was the Greco-Bactrian army organized and equipped?

The Greco-Bactrian army was based on the same model as that of the Macedonian-Seleucids, with innovations in tactics based on exposure to nomadic horsemen, and the Bactrian Greeks were equipped in the Macedonian style adopted by their Seleucid forebears, characteristic of the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom's military.
Greco-Bactrian Kingdom (256 BCE–125 BCE) — Afghanistan: What was the impact of the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom on the culture of Central Asia?

The Greco-Bactrian Kingdom had a profound influence on the culture of central Asia for centuries to come, producing distinctly Hellenistic artwork, statuary, and coinage, and leaving a lasting legacy of the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom in the region.
Armenian Kingdom (188 BCE–6 CE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: Who was the founder of the Armenian Kingdom dynasty?
The Armenian Kingdom was founded by Artaxias I, who ascended as King of Greater Armenia in 188 BCE. Artaxias I was the beginning of the Artaxiad dynasty that ruled the Armenian Kingdom.
Armenian Kingdom (188 BCE–6 CE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What cultures influenced the Armenian Kingdom?

The Armenian Kingdom was greatly influenced by Hellenistic Greek culture and religion, as well as having a strong Iranian culture, particularly with religion. The Armenian Kingdom was one of the regions that had not been conquered by the Hellenistic Greeks, but was still influenced by them.
Armenian Kingdom (188 BCE–6 CE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: Who was the king that unified the autonomous regions of the Armenian Kingdom?

The Armenian Kingdom was unified by Tigranes the Great, who was able to bring central control to the kingdom and unify the various autonomous regions governed by the nakharars. Tigranes the Great ruled the Armenian Kingdom from 95-55 BCE.
Armenian Kingdom (188 BCE–6 CE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the outcome of the wars between the Roman and Parthian Empires for the Armenian Kingdom?

The ongoing wars between the Roman and Parthian Empires led to the demise of the Artaxiad dynasty of the Armenian Kingdom. The Romans eventually forced Tigranes the Great to surrender, and the Armenian Kingdom became a buffer between the Roman and Parthian Empires.
Armenian Kingdom (188 BCE–6 CE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the relationship between the Armenian Kingdom and the Roman Empire under Tigranes' successor, Artavasdes II?

The Armenian Kingdom remained an ally to the Romans under Artavasdes II, who was the son and successor of Tigranes the Great. However, the Romans eventually invaded Armenia and captured Artavasdes II, executing him and placing Alexander Helios on the throne.
Armenian Kingdom (188 BCE–6 CE) — Anatolia-Caucasus: What was the eventual fate of the Artaxiad dynasty of the Armenian Kingdom?

The Artaxiad dynasty of the Armenian Kingdom eventually died out completely with the final Roman overthrow in 12 CE. The region became a Roman protectorate under emperor Augustus, and the Armenian Kingdom ceased to exist as an independent entity.
Himyar I (270 CE–340 CE) — Arabia: What was the geographical origin of the Himyarites in 115 BCE?
The Himyarites were a tribe from the southwestern highlands of Yemen, and during the period of Himyar I, which started in 270 CE, they were still associated with this region in Arabia.
Himyar I (270 CE–340 CE) — Arabia: How did the Roman discovery of the Indian Ocean trade winds around 100 CE affect the Himyarite state during the Himyar I period?

The Himyarite state was initially an exception to the decline of many great civilizations in South Arabia that used overland trade routes, and during the Himyar I period, which lasted from 270 to 340 CE, the Himyarites prospered from trading overseas routes in Arabia.
Himyar I (270 CE–340 CE) — Arabia: What was the significance of the Himyar-Abyssinian alliance or vassalage during the Himyar I period?

The Himyar-Abyssinian alliance or vassalage ended around 298 CE, and during the Himyar I period, which spanned from 270 to 340 CE, Himyar reached the peak of its power in the third century as a result of successful wars against local heathen tribes and the African realm of Ethiopia in Arabia.
Himyar I (270 CE–340 CE) — Arabia: How did the rise of Christianity in the west affect the incense trade during the Himyar I period?
The rise of Christianity in the west reduced demand for incense, which was most commonly used in pagan rituals, and by 395 CE, the trade ceased entirely, impacting the Himyar I period in Arabia.
Himyar I (270 CE–340 CE) — Arabia: Who were some of the known Jewish kings of the Himyarites during and after the Himyar I period?

Some of the known Jewish kings of the Himyarites included Yassirum Yohre'am, who ruled from 270 CE, and 'Amr-Shlomo ben David, who ruled from 325-330 CE, both of whom ruled during or after the Himyar I period in Arabia.
Himyar II (378 CE–525 CE) — Arabia: What was the significance of the Roman discovery of the Indian Ocean trade winds around 100 CE for the Himyarite state in Arabia?

The Himyarite state was initially an exception to the end of many great civilizations in South Arabia that used overland trade routes, and prospered after the Roman discovery of the Indian Ocean trade winds around 100 CE, as they used overseas trade routes to acquire wealth from the trade of incense and spices, characteristic of the Himyar II period in Arabia.
Himyar II (378 CE–525 CE) — Arabia: How did the Himyarites benefit from the decline of overland trade routes in the third century CE in Arabia?

The Himyarites benefited immensely at the expense of their rival kingdoms as the overland routes became increasingly less efficient and disrupted by warfare, especially in the third century CE, which involved Himyar, Saba, Hadramawt, and Aksum, during the Himyar II period in Arabia.
Himyar II (378 CE–525 CE) — Arabia: What was the outcome of the Abyssinian invasion and occupation of the tihama in the 2nd century CE for the Himyarites in Arabia?

The Abyssinians invaded and occupied the tihama from the 2nd century CE, and conquered the Himyarite capital in 240 CE, but later agreed to an alliance with Himyar and withdrew from the Arabian peninsula around 270 CE, marking a significant event in the Himyar II period in Arabia.
Himyar II (378 CE–525 CE) — Arabia: What was the impact of the rise of Christianity in the west on the incense trade in the Himyarite state in Arabia?

The rise of Christianity in the west reduced demand for incense, which was most commonly used in pagan rituals, leading to a progressive decline in profits from the incense trade for the Himyarites during the Himyar II period in Arabia, and the trade eventually ceased entirely when the Roman emperor Theodosius declared Christianity the official state religion of the Roman Empire in 395 CE.
Himyar II (378 CE–525 CE) — Arabia: What was the significance of the conversion of the Himyarites to monotheistic religious doctrines in the late 4th century CE in Arabia?

The Himyarites rapidly converted from their pagan polytheistic belief system to monotheistic religious doctrines, with many adopting Judaism, and the Jewish faith became the dominant religion in South Arabia during the Himyar II period, with the Himyarite kings either being full members or sympathizers of Judaism.
Himyar II (378 CE–525 CE) — Arabia: Who were some of the known Jewish kings of the Himyarite dynasty during the Himyar II period in Arabia?

Some of the known Jewish kings of the Himyarite dynasty during the Himyar II period include Yassirum Yohre'am, 'Amr-Shlomo ben David, Malki Kariba Juha'min, Abu Kariba As'as, Shurihbi'il Yakkuf, Martad Ilan, and Yusuf Ash'ar Dhu Nuwas, who ruled the Himyarite kingdom in Arabia.
Himyar II (378 CE–525 CE) — Arabia: What led to the foreign intervention in the Himyarite kingdom in the 6th century CE in Arabia?

The increasing persecution and massacre of Christians by king Dhu Nuwas led to a foreign intervention, with the Byzantine Empire in alliance with the Aksumite Kingdom invading the Himyarite kingdom and removing Dhu Nuwas, after which the Himyarite kingdom was ruled directly by the Christian Ethiopians until the Persian conquest in 570 CE, during the late Himyar II period in Arabia.
Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty (822 CE–1037 CE) — Arabia: What region did the Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty rule in Arabia?
The Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty occupied and ruled southern Tihama coastal plains in Arabia, with their city of power in Zabid in the Red Sea coastal desert.
Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty (822 CE–1037 CE) — Arabia: When and where did Al-Hadi ila al-Haqq found the Zaydi imamate?

Al-Hadi ila al-Haqq founded the Zaydi imamate in 893 CE, based on the Zaydi Shii teachings, which would popularize throughout at least part of North Yemen until the 1962 Revolution, during the time of the Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty.
Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty (822 CE–1037 CE) — Arabia: Who ruled Sanaa in 1007 CE and what did he achieve?
Yu’frid prince ‘Abdullah ibn Qahtan ruled Sanaa in 1007 CE and made a successful foray against the stronghold of Sunnism, a notable event during the Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty.
Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty (822 CE–1037 CE) — Arabia: What was the estimated territory of the Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty polity?
The polity territory of the Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty is estimated to be around 100,000 square kilometers, covering parts of the Yemeni Coastal Plain in Arabia.
Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty (822 CE–1037 CE) — Arabia: How was the Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty politically organized?

The Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty had a loose political organization under the control of a sultan at Aden, who held less authority over the highlands, characteristic of the Yemen Ziyadid Dynasty's rule in Arabia.
Saffarid Caliphate (861 CE–1003 CE) — Iran: Who founded the Saffarid Caliphate in Iran?

The Saffarid Caliphate was founded by Ya'qub bin Laith as-Saffar, a commoner from Sīstān, who first worked as a coppersmith, then became a warlord, before leading the conquest of Iran and Afghanistan and becoming the dynasty’s first Emir of the Saffarid Caliphate.
Saffarid Caliphate (861 CE–1003 CE) — Iran: What happened to the Saffarid Caliphate after Ya'qub's death?
After Ya'qub's death, the Saffarid Caliphate lasted only 124 years, during which time it slowly reduced in territory, ultimately leading to the end of the Saffarid Caliphate.
Saffarid Caliphate (861 CE–1003 CE) — Iran: Who was the last amir of the Saffarid Caliphate and what happened to him?

The last amir of the Saffarid Caliphate, Khalaf, was forced to abdicate in 1003 after a coup d’etat by the Sīstān military leaders who invited the Ghaznavids to invade, and Khalaf was exiled to Gardīz where he spent two years before he died, marking the end of the Saffarid Caliphate.
Saffarid Caliphate (861 CE–1003 CE) — Iran: What became of Sīstān after the fall of the Saffarid Caliphate?
After the fall of the Saffarid Caliphate, Sīstān became a province of the Ghaznavid Empire, following the invasion by the Ghaznavids in the former territory of the Saffarid Caliphate.
Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period (868 CE–969 CE) — Northeast Africa: What characterized the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period in Northeast Africa?

The Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period was notable for frequent changes in rulers, including three separate regimes in just over a century: the Tulunid Dynasty, the Abbasid Restoration Period, and the Ikshidid Dynasty, which eventually gave way to the Fatimid Caliphate.
Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period (868 CE–969 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the origin of the Tulunid Dynasty that ruled Egypt during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period?

Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period: The Tulunids were a Turkic Dynasty who established an independent rule over Egypt and parts of Syria during a time of instability caused by infighting in the Abbasid court in Damascus.
Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period (868 CE–969 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did the reign of Khumarawayh impact Egypt during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period?

Egypt saw 'peace and prosperity' under Khumarawayh's rule, but his extravagant lifestyle and 'lavish' spending on building projects and the maintenance of a large standing army 'overtaxed the state's resources' during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period.
Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period (868 CE–969 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the nature of Egypt's autonomy during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period?
Egypt during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period has been described as 'an autonomous state, albeit under Abbasid suzerainty', with Ahmad ibn Tulun never formally repudiating Abbasid authority.
Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period (868 CE–969 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did Ahmad ibn Tulun establish his rule in Egypt during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period?

Ahmad ibn Tulun, who was of Turkish ancestry, was recruited from the military and took advantage of a revolt in Palestine and Syria to build up a new Egyptian army of Turkish, Nubian, and Greek mercenaries and slaves, which he paid for by seizing control of the revenue of Egypt from the Abbasid-appointed financial director in 871 CE, during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period.
Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period (868 CE–969 CE) — Northeast Africa: What significant architectural projects were undertaken by the rulers of the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid?

The rulers of the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period undertook significant architectural projects, including the construction of an aqueduct, a maristan (hospital) by Ibn Tulun, which cost 60,000 dinars, and Kafur's palace near the Birkat Qarun, which cost a monumental 100,000 dinars.
Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period (868 CE–969 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the estimated population of Egypt and the Levant during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period?

The population of Egypt and the Levant at this time may have totalled 6.5 million, with the largest city, Fustat in Egypt, having perhaps 150,000 residents, during the Egypt - Tulunid-Ikhshidid Period.
Buyid Confederation (932 CE–1062 CE) — Iran: Where did the Buyid dynasty originate from in Iran?
The Buyid dynasty originated from Shahrud Valley in northwestern Iran, and by 934 CE, the Buyid Confederation had reached Fars, establishing a presence in the region.
Buyid Confederation (932 CE–1062 CE) — Iran: What was the structure of the Buyid army during the Buyid Confederation period?
The Buyid Confederation had an army composed partly of Daylamite infantry and slave Turkish cavalry, reflecting the military organization of the time.
Buyid Confederation (932 CE–1062 CE) — Iran: What was the role of the Abbasid caliph in the Buyid Confederation?

The Buyid Confederation amirs were governors under the Abbasid caliph, who remained in Baghdad with powers to appoint religious officials and continued to be symbolically important, particularly in Iraq, during the Buyid Confederation period.
Buyid Confederation (932 CE–1062 CE) — Iran: What was the significance of Fars in the Buyid Confederation?
Fars was the heartland of the Buyid Confederation empire, with all civil servants being drawn from there, highlighting the importance of the region to the Buyid Confederation.
Seljuk Sultanate (1037 CE–1157 CE) — Iran: What was the geographical extent of the Seljuk Sultanate's rule?

The Seljuk Sultanate ruled a relatively decentralized empire across Central Asia, Persia, and Mesopotamia, with territories including the Sultanate of Iraq, and its home region was Iran, specifically Susiana.
Seljuk Sultanate (1037 CE–1157 CE) — Iran: How was the Seljuk Empire administratively divided?

The Seljuk Empire was divided into western and eastern halves, with the east having connotations of seniority in Turkic culture, and the western territories were known as the Sultanate of Iraq, all part of the Seljuk Sultanate.
Seljuk Sultanate (1037 CE–1157 CE) — Iran: What were Nizam al-Mulk's goals for the Seljuk Sultanate?

Nizam al-Mulk strove to suppress abuses, introduce reforms, and initiate the Seljuk Sultanate's masters into the arts of Perso-Islamic statecraft, and to provide competent and reliable theologians, judges, and secretaries for the state religion and administration of the Seljuk Sultanate.
Seljuk Sultanate (1037 CE–1157 CE) — Iran: What were some of Nizam al-Mulk's key policies in the Seljuk Sultanate?

Nizam al-Mulk was particularly concerned with the construction and maintenance of trade routes, caravanserais, and bridges, and the appointment of trustworthy market inspectors and tax collectors, all crucial policies for the Seljuk Sultanate to root out corruption and foster confidence in local and long-distance trade.
Seljuk Sultanate (1037 CE–1157 CE) — Iran: What was the system of rule like in the Seljuk Sultanate?

Within the Seljuk Sultanate's system of rule, the caliph was the ultimate religious authority, and the sultan was the head of secular power supported by a vizier of the diwan-i a'la, with Seljuk maliks ruling provinces with an atabeg and a small court bureaucracy overseen by a vizier.
Seljuk Sultanate (1037 CE–1157 CE) — Iran: What led to the end of the Seljuk Sultanate as an independent state?

The Seljuk Sultanate came to an end as an independent state when it was defeated by the Mongols, and the Sultan had to pay them tribute, marking the end of the Seljuk Sultanate's independence in Iran and its other territories.
Yemen - Era of Warlords (1038 CE–1174 CE) — Arabia: What characterized the Yemen - Era of Warlords in the Tihama coastal plains?
The Yemen - Era of Warlords was primarily characterized by a two-power tension between the Najahid dynasty and the Sulayhid dynasty in the Tihama coastal plains of Arabia during its time.
Yemen - Era of Warlords (1038 CE–1174 CE) — Arabia: Which dynasties were involved in the two-power tension during the Yemen - Era of Warlords?

The Yemen - Era of Warlords involved a two-power tension between the Najahid dynasty and the Sulayhid dynasty, with the Najahid dynasty being founded by two former slaves of the predated Ziyadid dynasty.
Yemen - Era of Warlords (1038 CE–1174 CE) — Arabia: What significant event occurred in 1086 CE during the Yemen - Era of Warlords?
During the Yemen - Era of Warlords, in 1086 CE, Mukarram of the Sulayhids instituted a new coinage called 'Maliki Dinars'.
Yemen - Era of Warlords (1038 CE–1174 CE) — Arabia: What was the outcome for the Najahid rulers during the Yemen - Era of Warlords?

The Najahid rulers were driven out into refuge during the Yemen - Era of Warlords, and although many plotted their return to take back their territory in Tihama, they were ultimately defeated at the end.
Yemen - Era of Warlords (1038 CE–1174 CE) — Arabia: What was the estimated territory size of the Yemen - Era of Warlords polity?
The Yemen - Era of Warlords polity territory was estimated to be between 250,000 and 350,000 square kilometers in the Yemeni Coastal Plain of Arabia.
Yemen - Era of Warlords (1038 CE–1174 CE) — Arabia: How was the settlement hierarchy organized during the Yemen - Era of Warlords?
The Yemen - Era of Warlords had a settlement hierarchy that was between three- and five-tiered, with a capital followed by towns and villages in the region of Arabia.
Yemen - Era of Warlords (1038 CE–1174 CE) — Arabia: What was the structure of the administrative levels during the Yemen - Era of Warlords?

The Yemen - Era of Warlords had administrative levels that were between four and five, with the political organization headed by a king and queen and followed by court and provincial governments in the region of Arabia.
Ayyubid Sultanate (1171 CE–1250 CE) — Northeast Africa: Who established the Ayyubid Sultanate in Northeast Africa's Upper Egypt?

The Ayyubid Sultanate was established in Egypt by Saladin, a member of the Kurdish Ayyubid family. Saladin rose to prominence in Syria in the service of the Zangids and was appointed vizier of Egypt by the Fatimid caliph when his uncle Shirkuh died in 1169. The Ayyubid Sultanate began in 1171, when the last Fatimid caliph, Al-Adid, died and Saladin progressed from vizier to sultan in Egypt.
Ayyubid Sultanate (1171 CE–1250 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the Ayyubid Sultanate's relationship with the Abbasid caliph in Baghdad?

The Ayyubid Sultanate, under Saladin's leadership, was theoretically loyal to the Abbasid caliph in Baghdad, as Saladin sought to establish a new Sunni order in Egypt, replacing the Ismaili Islam professed by the Fatimid elite. The Ayyubid Sultanate promoted Sunni Islam in the empire by sponsoring law schools to serve as centres for the teaching of Sunni law.
Ayyubid Sultanate (1171 CE–1250 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Ayyubid Sultanate administer Egypt?

The Ayyubid Sultanate made use of the pre-existing Fatimid bureaucratic system to administer Egypt, and ruled via a Turkish and Kurdish 'military aristocracy', including some slave regiments. The Ayyubid Sultanate was funded by the distribution of iqta's, rights to tax revenue from estates of land, in exchange for military and administrative services. The Ayyubid Sultanate was never particularly centralized, with male members of the ruling dynasty given principalities across the realm and allowed to govern them with substantial political autonomy.
Ayyubid Sultanate (1171 CE–1250 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the population of Egypt under Saladin's rule in the Ayyubid Sultanate?

There were about 2.4 million people in Egypt under Saladin's rule in the Ayyubid Sultanate. However, it is difficult to find substantiated estimates for the population of the entire Ayyubid Sultanate.
Ayyubid Sultanate (1171 CE–1250 CE) — Northeast Africa: How did the Ayyubid Sultanate eventually come to an end?

The Ayyubid Sultanate came to an end when the Mamluks, a faction of high-ranking slave soldiers, assassinated Turanshah, the last Ayyubid sultan of Egypt, and seized the throne. The Mamluks had been increasingly powerful in the Ayyubid Sultanate, particularly under the rule of As-Salih Ayyub, who purchased many Turkish Mamluks to serve as a military and governmental elite. The Ayyubid dynasty hung onto power in Syria until 1260, when the Mamluks defeated the invading Mongols at 'Ayn Jalut and gained popular recognition of their right to rule as 'saviours of Islam'.
Ayyubid Sultanate (1171 CE–1250 CE) — Northeast Africa: What was the role of the sultan of Egypt in the Ayyubid Sultanate?

The sultan of Egypt in the Ayyubid Sultanate was usually successful in asserting his suzerainty over the other kingdoms. The Ayyubid Sultanate was described as a 'family confederation', with male members of the ruling dynasty given principalities across the realm and allowed to govern them with substantial political autonomy. However, the sultan of Egypt had more authority over his sons than over his brothers, who ruled different regions with less authority over each other.
Rasulid Dynasty (1229 CE–1453 CE) — Arabia: What region of Arabia was ruled by the Rasulid Dynasty during the thirteenth to fifteenth centuries CE?
The Rasulid Dynasty ruled the north-western region of modern Yemen, specifically the Yemeni Coastal Plain, along with the eastern portion of southern Arabia, during its period of power.
Rasulid Dynasty (1229 CE–1453 CE) — Arabia: What preceded the Rasulid Dynasty's rule in Yemen?
The Rasulid Dynasty's rule in Yemen was preceded by the Ayyūbid Sultanate, which was centered in Egypt, and Yemen had formed part of this sultanate before the Rasulids took control.
Rasulid Dynasty (1229 CE–1453 CE) — Arabia: How did the Rasulid Dynasty initially gain control of Yemen?

The Rasulid Dynasty gained de facto control of Yemen when the last Ayyūbid ruler of Yemen, al-Mas‘ūd Yūsuf, was summoned to govern Syria, and control passed to his trusted second-in-command, the Rasulid Nūr al-Dīn ‘Umar.
Rasulid Dynasty (1229 CE–1453 CE) — Arabia: What was the nature of the Rasulid Dynasty's rule in Yemen?

The Rasulid Dynasty, a Sunnī Muslim dynasty, presided over a prosperous and largely stable period in Yemeni history, characterized by the development of a centralized bureaucracy and the patronage of scholarly and religious institutions.
Rasulid Dynasty (1229 CE–1453 CE) — Arabia: What was the population of Aden, the capital of the Rasulid Dynasty?
The Rasulid Dynasty's capital, Aden, likely had a population of around 50,000 under the Rasulids.
Timurid Empire (1370 CE–1526 CE) — Turkestan: What was the origin of the Timurid Empire in Turkestan?

The Timurid Empire was begun by Timur, who was initially an amir within the Chagatai Khanate in Turkestan, and after taking power at Balkh in 1370, he maintained a nominal allegiance to the Chagatai khan while effectively ruling as an independent state, establishing the Timurid Empire.
Timurid Empire (1370 CE–1526 CE) — Turkestan: How did Timur expand the Timurid Empire in Persia and the sub-continent?

The Timurid Empire expanded through Timur's brutal conquests over Persia and the sub-continent, creating a large empire covering about 5,500,000 square kilometers with a population of perhaps 49 million in 1400 CE, during the Timurid Empire period.
Timurid Empire (1370 CE–1526 CE) — Turkestan: What was notable about the craftsmen in the Timurid Empire?

The Timurid Empire had an astonishingly rich assemblage of masters in virtually every field of the arts and crafts, as Timur rounded up craftspeople in all fields and sent them off to his capital at Samarkand, showcasing the Timurid Empire's cultural achievements.
Timurid Empire (1370 CE–1526 CE) — Turkestan: What was the structure of the Timurid government in Turkestan?

The Timurid government was a complex Persian-model professional bureaucracy which functionally distinguished between civilian and military branches of government, with the ruler assisted by a vizier, characteristic of the Timurid Empire in Turkestan.
Timurid Empire (1370 CE–1526 CE) — Turkestan: What eventually happened to the Timurid Empire in Central Asia?
The Timurid Empire was eventually conquered by Uzbek nomads, who took over the feuding provinces of the empire, marking the end of the Timurid Empire in Central Asia.
Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty (1454 CE–1517 CE) — Arabia: What was the time period during which the Tahirid dynasty ruled modern-day Yemen?
The Tahirid dynasty ruled modern-day Yemen between 1454 and 1517 CE, establishing itself as a prominent force in the region during this time, known as the Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty period.
Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty (1454 CE–1517 CE) — Arabia: What were some of the notable achievements of the Tahirid dynasty in terms of infrastructure development?
The Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty was characterized by the creation of schools, mosques, massive irrigation systems, roads, and bridges by the Tahirids, who were prominent builders.
Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty (1454 CE–1517 CE) — Arabia: What was the nature of the relationship between the Tahirids and the Zaydis during the Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty period?

The Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty period was marked by several battles, skirmishes, and seizures between the Zaydis and Tahirids, with tensions culminating in 1501 when Tahirid sultan Amir commenced his four-year-long campaign to conquer the northern territories held by the Zaydi dynasty.
Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty (1454 CE–1517 CE) — Arabia: How was the political organization of the Yemen - Tahirid Dynasty structured?

Safavid Empire (1501 CE–1722 CE) — Iran: Who began the conquest of Iran and declared the state religion during the Safavid Empire?

Yangshao (5000 BCE–3000 BCE) — North China: Where did the Yangshao culture first develop?
The Yangshao culture first developed in the Loess plateau in the Holocene period, specifically in the Middle Yellow River Valley in North China.
Yangshao (5000 BCE–3000 BCE) — North China: What was the primary source of food for the Yangshao people?

Yangshao (5000 BCE–3000 BCE) — North China: What characterized the architecture of Yangshao villages?

Yangshao (5000 BCE–3000 BCE) — North China: What types of artifacts have been excavated from Yangshao period graves?

Yangshao (5000 BCE–3000 BCE) — North China: How did the population and settlement organization of Yangshao change over time?

Yangshao (5000 BCE–3000 BCE) — North China: What was the size of Yangshao settlements?

Yangshao (5000 BCE–3000 BCE) — North China: What does the presence of grave goods in Yangshao burials suggest about the society?

Longshan (3000 BCE–1900 BCE) — North China: What characterized the Longshan culture in North China?

The Longshan culture was characterized by the presence of dark grey and black polished pottery. Longshan culture evolved from the Yangshao culture and the Majiabang culture, and is also known as Chalcolithic China, Jade Age, or Lungshanoid horizon.
Longshan (3000 BCE–1900 BCE) — North China: What tools did the Longshan people use for agriculture and carving in the Middle Yellow River Valley?

Longshan (3000 BCE–1900 BCE) — North China: What was the main agricultural staple of the Longshan people in North China?

Longshan (3000 BCE–1900 BCE) — North China: What was the Longshan culture the precursor of in Shaanxi and Shandong?

Longshan (3000 BCE–1900 BCE) — North China: What may have been a sign of competition for power during the Longshan period?

Erlitou (1850 BCE–1600 BCE) — North China: What characterized the Erlitou culture in North China?

Erlitou (1850 BCE–1600 BCE) — North China: What was the economy of Erlitou based on in North China?

The economy of Erlitou was based on agriculture, with the people of Erlitou farming wheat, millet, rice, and vegetables and raising domestic animals, and the state controlled areas as far as 500 km from the center of Erlitou.
Erlitou (1850 BCE–1600 BCE) — North China: How did the population of Erlitou change over time in North China?

Erligang (1650 BCE–1250 BCE) — North China: How do scholars typically place the Erligang culture in the traditional chronology of ancient China?

Erligang (1650 BCE–1250 BCE) — North China: What characterized the early Shang kings during the Erligang period?

Erligang (1650 BCE–1250 BCE) — North China: What were the primary centers of the Erligang culture?

Erligang (1650 BCE–1250 BCE) — North China: What was the structure of the political hierarchy in the Erligang culture?

Early Wei Dynasty (445 BCE–225 BCE) — North China: What were some key developments during the time of the Early Wei Dynasty in North China?

Early Wei Dynasty (445 BCE–225 BCE) — North China: What significant event marked the decline of the Early Wei Dynasty?

Early Wei Dynasty (445 BCE–225 BCE) — North China: What was the ultimate fate of the Early Wei Dynasty?

Northern Song (960 CE–1127 CE) — North China: What was the significance of the civil service examination during the Northern Song period in North China?

Northern Song (960 CE–1127 CE) — North China: How did the Northern Song dynasty impact the economy of North China?

Northern Song (960 CE–1127 CE) — North China: What were some of the key industries that flourished during the Northern Song period in North China?

Northern Song (960 CE–1127 CE) — North China: What was the impact of the Northern Song dynasty on population growth and urbanization in North China?

Jenne-jeno IV (900 CE–1300 CE) — West Africa: What type of architecture was absent in Jenne-jeno IV?

Jenne-jeno IV had no palaces, rich tombs, temples, public buildings, or monumental architecture, with the city's layout being an assemblage of dispersed clusters, indicating a resistance to centralization during the Jenne-jeno IV period.
Saadi Sultanate (1554 CE–1659 CE) — Maghreb: What was the extent of the Saadi Sultanate's boundaries between 1554 and 1591?
Between 1554 and 1591, the boundaries of the Saadi Sultanate coincided with those of modern-day Morocco, during which the Saadi Sultanate ruled over this territory.
Saadi Sultanate (1554 CE–1659 CE) — Maghreb: What additional territory did the Saadi Sultanate rule over between 1591 and 1618?
The Saadi Sultanate also ruled over the Niger Inland Delta between 1591 and 1618, though their control over this area seems to have been nominal, as part of the Saadi Sultanate's expansion.
Saadi Sultanate (1554 CE–1659 CE) — Maghreb: What event in 1603 marked the beginning of a period of instability for the Saadi Sultanate?

The death of Sultan Ahmad Al-Mansur in 1603 marked the beginning of a period of instability for the Saadi Sultanate, which ultimately led to the loss of their Niger colony, affecting the Saadi Sultanate's rule.
Saadi Sultanate (1554 CE–1659 CE) — Maghreb: How was the Saadi Sultanate organized politically during the 16th and 17th centuries?

The Saadi Sultanate was ruled through an Ottoman-style hierarchical regime, with the sultan at the top, followed by the wazir or vizier, and then the sultan's council, during the time of the Saadi Sultanate.
Segou Kingdom (1650 CE–1712 CE) — West Africa: What is known about the Segou Kingdom in West Africa's Niger Inland Delta?

The Segou Kingdom, occupying the Niger Inland Delta from the mid-17th century CE to 1712, is not well-documented, with almost nothing known about it, and its existence is not suggested by oral traditions or regional histories compiled in Timbuktu, but it is known that the Segou Kingdom was the polity that preceded the Bamana Kingdom.
Segou Kingdom (1650 CE–1712 CE) — West Africa: Who is credited with becoming the ruler of the first Bamana state within the Segou Kingdom?

The Segou Kingdom saw a hunter and warrior called Kaladian Kulibali become the ruler of the first Bamana state in around 1650, drawing on the indigenous male age-grade associations known as tòn, and his rule briefly included Timbuktu within the Segou Kingdom.
Segou Kingdom (1650 CE–1712 CE) — West Africa: What was the nature of the Bamana society before the mid-17th century within the Segou Kingdom?

The Bamana before the mid-17th century, during the time of the Segou Kingdom, were probably a 'stateless society', divided into independent villages that only banded together in response to a threat, within the context of the Segou Kingdom in West Africa's Niger Inland Delta.
Segou Kingdom (1650 CE–1712 CE) — West Africa: How did the Segou Kingdom's political organization change after Kaladian Kulibali's death?

After Kaladian Kulibali's death, the Segou Kingdom saw centralized power weaken, and an oligarchy of regional rulership by his sons and their successors held sway for some time, before the rise of Biton Kulibali and the founding of the Bamana Kingdom in 1712, marking the end of the Segou Kingdom.
Segou Kingdom (1650 CE–1712 CE) — West Africa: What was the state of the Bamana region by the time the Segou Kingdom ended?

By the time the Segou Kingdom ended and the Bamana Kingdom was founded in 1712, the Bamana region was divided into small communities, each ruled by a gerontocracy, although the relationship between this system and the preceding oligarchy of Kaladian's successors within the Segou Kingdom is not very clear.
Bamana kingdom (1712 CE–1861 CE) — West Africa: When and by whom was the Bamana Kingdom founded in West Africa?
The Bamana Kingdom was founded in 1712 by Biton Kulibali in West Africa, specifically in the Niger Inland Delta region.
Bamana kingdom (1712 CE–1861 CE) — West Africa: What event marked the end of the Bamana Kingdom's independence in West Africa?
The Bamana Kingdom became part of the Tukulor empire in 1861, when El Hajj Umar Tall seized the capital, Segu, marking the end of its independence in West Africa.
Bamana kingdom (1712 CE–1861 CE) — West Africa: What is the origin of the name of the Bamana Kingdom in West Africa?
The Bamana Kingdom derives its name from its dominant ethnic group, also known as the Bambara, in West Africa.
Bamana kingdom (1712 CE–1861 CE) — West Africa: What was the extent of the Bamana Kingdom's territory under Monson Diarra's rule in West Africa?
The Bamana Kingdom reached its greatest size under the rule of Monson Diarra, extending Segu power from San to Timbuktu, and from the Land of the Dogons to Kaarta in West Africa.
Bamana kingdom (1712 CE–1861 CE) — West Africa: How was the Bamana Kingdom ruled in West Africa?
The Bamana Kingdom was ruled by a single leader, known as the faama, who also led the army and was advised by an assembly of 40 men, including warriors and holy men, in West Africa.
Bamana kingdom (1712 CE–1861 CE) — West Africa: What was the significance of slavery in the Bamana Kingdom in West Africa?

Slavery was an important institution in the Bamana Kingdom, with the trade in slaves for guns and horses laying at the heart of the power of this nascent 'warrior-state' in West Africa, specifically in the Bamana Kingdom.
Bamana kingdom (1712 CE–1861 CE) — West Africa: What was the approximate population of the Bamana Kingdom in 1800 in West Africa?
The population of the Bamana Kingdom in 1800 may have numbered three or four million people, covering about half the territory of modern Mali, Guinea, and Senegal in West Africa.
Neguanje (250 CE–1050 CE) — Caribbean: What was the time period of the Neguanje phase in Colombian prehistory?

Neguanje (250 CE–1050 CE) — Caribbean: Where have most Nahuange artefacts and sites been found?

Neguanje (250 CE–1050 CE) — Caribbean: What is known about Neguanje social hierarchies and population numbers?
Little is known about Neguanje social hierarchies or population numbers during the Neguanje phase.
Tairona (1050 CE–1524 CE) — Caribbean: What does the name Tairona refer to in the context of the Caribbean region?

The name Tairona is generally used in reference to the indigenous groups of the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta that came in contact with the Spanish in the sixteenth century, as well as the prehistoric societies that inhabited the same area, known as the Tairona.
Tairona (1050 CE–1524 CE) — Caribbean: When did the prehistoric Tairona phase start and end in the Caribbean coast of North Colombia?

The prehistoric Tairona phase started around 1050 and ended early in the sixteenth century, as estimated by researchers based on radiocarbon-dated goldwork and complete dated contexts, which is associated with the Tairona.
Tairona (1050 CE–1524 CE) — Caribbean: How were the Tairona organized at the time of the Spanish Conquest in the Caribbean region?
At the time of the Spanish Conquest, the Tairona were organized into independent polities governed by a priestly class and a hierarchy of chiefs, characteristic of the Tairona.
Tairona (1050 CE–1524 CE) — Caribbean: What was the estimated population of a typical Tairona polity in the Caribbean region?
The population of a typical Tairona polity likely numbered in the hundreds of thousands, with conservative estimates of as much as 500,000 inhabitants, which is a notable feature of the Tairona.
Tairona (1050 CE–1524 CE) — Caribbean: How did the population of the largest Tairona settlements change over time in the Caribbean coast of North Colombia?

Early Xiongnu (1400 BCE–300 BCE) — Mongolia: Where was the Early Xiongnu period primarily located?
The Early Xiongnu period was primarily located in the Orkhon Valley, in north-central Mongolia, on either side of the Orkhon River, during the time span of 1400-300 BCE.
Early Xiongnu (1400 BCE–300 BCE) — Mongolia: What is known about the population of the Orkhon Valley during the Early Xiongnu period?

Early Xiongnu (1400 BCE–300 BCE) — Mongolia: What was the significance of the Xiongnu during the Early Xiongnu period in Mongolia?

Early Xiongnu (1400 BCE–300 BCE) — Mongolia: What information is available about the political organization of the Early Xiongnu period?
The Early Xiongnu period lacks information on political organization at this time, with no available details found.
Xianbei Confederation (100 CE–250 CE) — Mongolia: What was the Xianbei Confederation's primary economic activities in the Orkhon Valley of Mongolia?
The Xianbei Confederation was a pastoralist society that also relied on hunting and, to a lesser extent, the cultivation of wheat, barley, and millet.
Xianbei Confederation (100 CE–250 CE) — Mongolia: Who was the most powerful ruler of the Xianbei Confederation and what reforms did he implement?

Xianbei Confederation (100 CE–250 CE) — Mongolia: What was the estimated population of the Xianbei Confederation during Tanshihuai's rule?

Xianbei Confederation (100 CE–250 CE) — Mongolia: What was the structure of the Xianbei Confederation's rule under Tanshihuai?

The Xianbei Confederation was ruled by Tanshihuai, with the nomadic peoples of the middle, eastern, and western parts of the empire being ruled by the elders of the largest sites, who were in turn subordinate to Tanshihuai.
Shiwei (600 CE–1000 CE) — Mongolia: What were the primary economic activities of the Shiwei people in Mongolia?
The Shiwei people lived on agriculture and pastoralism, and they also traded sable skins during the Shiwei period in the Orkhon Valley region of Mongolia.
Shiwei (600 CE–1000 CE) — Mongolia: What is known about the political organization of the Shiwei people?

Shiwei (600 CE–1000 CE) — Mongolia: What were the Shiwei people divided into?
The Shiwei people were divided into between five and twenty tribes during the Shiwei period in the Orkhon Valley region of Mongolia.
Shiwei (600 CE–1000 CE) — Mongolia: Are there any theories about the ancestry of the Mongols in relation to the Shiwei?
The Shiwei may have been the ancestors to the Mongols, according to historical records of the Shiwei period in Mongolia.

Second Turk Khaganate (682 CE–744 CE) — Mongolia: What was the location of the Second Turk Khaganate?

The Second Turk Khaganate was located in the Orkhon Valley, in north-central Mongolia, with the Orkhon River running through it. The Second Turk Khaganate was established in this region. The Orkhon Valley was the home region of the Second Turk Khaganate.
Second Turk Khaganate (682 CE–744 CE) — Mongolia: How did the Second Turk Khaganate initially form?

The Second Turk Khaganate was established in the 680s, after the previous Turkic khaganate had collapsed due to internal rebellions and an invasion from Tang China. Second Turk Khaganate (682 CE–744 CE) — Mongolia: What was the administrative structure of the Second Turk Khaganate?

The Second Turk Khaganate had a four-tiered administrative hierarchy, with the khagan and his kinsmen at the top, followed by the khagan's counsellors, who were responsible for military, administrative, diplomatic, and legal operations. Second Turk Khaganate (682 CE–744 CE) — Mongolia: How was the Second Turk Khaganate divided?

Second Turk Khaganate (682 CE–744 CE) — Mongolia: What was the outcome of the assassination of the khagan Bilgee for the Second Turk Khaganate?

The assassination of the khagan Bilgee led to a decade of in-fighting, which ultimately resulted in the collapse of the Second Turk Khaganate by 744. The Second Turk Khaganate collapsed following this event.
Early Mongols (1000 CE–1206 CE) — Mongolia: What might be the earliest known reference to the Early Mongols?
The Early Mongols might be referred to in Chinese records from the Tang dynasty as the Mengwu, which is one of the nomadic Shiwei tribe.
Early Mongols (1000 CE–1206 CE) — Mongolia: How did the Early Mongols in Mongolia live in the eleventh century?
The Early Mongols in Mongolia lived on a mixture of hunting and pastoralism, and their technology was largely made out of wood and bone because of the Khitans' ban on the exportation of iron.
Early Mongols (1000 CE–1206 CE) — Mongolia: How did the Niru'un and Dürlükin clans interact in terms of marriage among the Early Mongols?
The Early Mongols had traditional rules of exogamy, which meant that the Niru'un had to marry among the Dürlükin and vice versa.
Early Mongols (1000 CE–1206 CE) — Mongolia: Which tribes did the Early Mongols inhabit the region alongside in Mongolia?
The Early Mongols inhabited the region alongside similarly sized peoples, such as the Naimans, Kereids, Tatars, and Merkids.
Late Mongols (1368 CE–1690 CE) — Mongolia: What event in 1368 led to the establishment of a new state in Mongolia by Toghon Temur?

The Late Mongols period began after the Yuan dynasty collapsed in 1368, and Toghon Temur, its last emperor, retired with his army to Mongolia, where he established a new state, with Karakorum as its capital, that extended from Manchuria to Kyrgyzstan between the Great Wall of China and Lake Baikal, marking the start of the Late Mongols.
Late Mongols (1368 CE–1690 CE) — Mongolia: What was the nature of the new Mongolian polity established by Toghon Temur during the Late Mongols period?
The new Mongolian polity during the Late Mongols period was actually a loose alliance of six tribal confederations or tümens united under a common Khan.
Late Mongols (1368 CE–1690 CE) — Mongolia: Which confederations were part of the new Mongolian polity during the Late Mongols period in Mongolia?
The Late Mongols period in Mongolia saw the emergence of a new Mongolian polity that included the Khalkhas as one of the six tribal confederations or tümens united under a common Khan.
Late Mongols (1368 CE–1690 CE) — Mongolia: What was the relationship like between the Khalkhas and the Oirat confederation during the Late Mongols period?

Late Mongols (1368 CE–1690 CE) — Mongolia: What led to the fall of the Khalkha confederacy during the Late Mongols period?

Late Mongols (1368 CE–1690 CE) — Mongolia: How was the Khalkha confederacy organised during the Late Mongols period?
The Late Mongols period saw the Khalkhas organised in a confederacy ruled by its own ruler, who however deferred to the overarching khan, characteristic of the Late Mongols' political structure.
Late Mongols (1368 CE–1690 CE) — Mongolia: What was the estimated population of the Khalkhas during the Late Mongols period in the 1630s?

Zungharian Empire (1670 CE–1757 CE) — Mongolia: What was the Zungharian Empire's status in the steppe according to historical descriptions?

The Zungharian Empire was the last great independent power of the steppe, with the tribal name 'Zunghar' first appearing in the seventeenth century as part of the Oirat confederation of steppe tribes, and the Zungharian polity rose to dominance within this confederation.
Zungharian Empire (1670 CE–1757 CE) — Mongolia: When did the Zungharians officially become the leading tribe of the Oirat confederation?

Zungharian Empire (1670 CE–1757 CE) — Mongolia: How did the Qing empire annex the Zungharians?

The Qing empire annexed the Zungharians following a relatively quick and bloodless military campaign in 1755, which was likely facilitated by the conflict between the successors of the last great Zungharian ruler, Galdan-Tseren, and marked the end of the Zungharian Empire.
Zungharian Empire (1670 CE–1757 CE) — Mongolia: What was the structure of the Zungharian ruler's support office?

The Zungharian ruler, known as Khung-Taiji, was supported by an office composed of four chief officials, known as ministers, judges, or grand councillors, and Galdan-Tseren added six additional councillors to this structure, which was a key part of the Zungharian Empire's political organization.
Zungharian Empire (1670 CE–1757 CE) — Mongolia: How was the Zungharian-led confederacy organized?

The Zungharian-led confederacy was made up of tribes, each with its own ruler supported by councillors, as well as minor functionaries, and each tribe was subdivided into otogs, which were further subdivided into smaller units governed by local commoner officials, characteristic of the Zungharian Empire's administrative system.
Zungharian Empire (1670 CE–1757 CE) — Mongolia: What was the estimated population of the Zungharian Empire?

Orokaiva - Pre-Colonial (1734 CE–1883 CE) — New Guinea: How did the Orokaiva people become part of a wider polity?

Beaker Culture (3200 BCE–2000 BCE) — Western Europe: What characterized the Beaker Culture in Western Europe during the late 3rd millennium BCE?

Beaker Culture (3200 BCE–2000 BCE) — Western Europe: Where did the Beaker phenomenon initially start and later expand to in Western Europe?

Atlantic Complex (2200 BCE–1000 BCE) — Western Europe: What characterized the Atlantic Complex period in Western Europe in terms of technological advancements?

Atlantic Complex (2200 BCE–1000 BCE) — Western Europe: What type of settlements were constructed during the Atlantic Complex period in Western Europe?

Atlantic Complex (2200 BCE–1000 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the geographical scope of the Atlantic Complex period in Western Europe?

Atlantic Complex (2200 BCE–1000 BCE) — Western Europe: How did trade operate during the Atlantic Complex period in Western Europe?

Hallstatt A-B1 (1000 BCE–900 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the main cultural complex in Western Europe during the Late Bronze Age and Early Iron Age?

Hallstatt B2-3 (900 BCE–700 BCE) — Western Europe: What changes occurred in the settlement hierarchy during the Hallstatt B period in Western Europe?

Hallstatt B2-3 (900 BCE–700 BCE) — Western Europe: What features became more noticeable in the Hallstatt B landscape in Western Europe?

Hallstatt C (700 BCE–600 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the main cultural complex in Western Europe during the Late Bronze Age and Early Iron Age?

Hallstatt C (700 BCE–600 BCE) — Western Europe: What characterized the settlement pattern of the Hallstatt C period in Western Europe?

Hallstatt C (700 BCE–600 BCE) — Western Europe: What developments occurred in material culture during the Hallstatt C period?

Hallstatt C (700 BCE–600 BCE) — Western Europe: What may have developed during the Hallstatt C period in terms of administrative hierarchy?

Hallstatt C (700 BCE–600 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the approximate size of the princely territories that may have been created during the Hallstatt C period?

Hallstatt D (600 BCE–475 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the main cultural complex in Western Europe during the Late Bronze Age and Early Iron Age?

Hallstatt D (600 BCE–475 BCE) — Western Europe: What changes occurred in hillforts during the Hallstatt D period in Western Europe?

Hallstatt D (600 BCE–475 BCE) — Western Europe: How did chiefs control the economy during the Hallstatt D period?

Hallstatt D (600 BCE–475 BCE) — Western Europe: What is an example of extreme social differentiation during the Hallstatt D period?

Hallstatt D (600 BCE–475 BCE) — Western Europe: What type of centres rose to prominence during the Hallstatt D period?

Hallstatt D (600 BCE–475 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the estimated population of the Heuneburg hillfort during the Hallstatt D period?

La Tene A-B1 (475 BCE–325 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the La Tene A-B1 culture in Western Europe?

La Tene B2-C1 (325 BCE–175 BCE) — Western Europe: What types of settlements existed during the La Tene B2-C1 period in Western Europe?

La Tene B2-C1 (325 BCE–175 BCE) — Western Europe: How did the tribes in the La Tene B2-C1 culture organize themselves in Western Europe?

La Tene B2-C1 (325 BCE–175 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the estimated population of the La Tene B2-C1 culture in Western Europe?

La Tene C2-D (175 BCE–27 BCE) — Western Europe: What was the La Tene C2-D culture in Western Europe?

La Tene C2-D (175 BCE–27 BCE) — Western Europe: What were the main types of settlements during the La Tene C2-D period in the Paris Basin and Western Europe?

La Tene C2-D (175 BCE–27 BCE) — Western Europe: How did the tribes of the La Tene C2-D period in Western Europe organize themselves?

La Tene C2-D (175 BCE–27 BCE) — Western Europe: What types of goods were produced at the larger La Tene C2-D sites in Western Europe?

La Tene C2-D (175 BCE–27 BCE) — Western Europe: What is estimated to be the population of the La Tene C2-D culture in Western Europe?

Proto-Carolingian (687 CE–751 CE) — Western Europe: What was the nature of the Merovingian Kingdom during the Proto-Carolingian period in Western Europe?

The Proto-Carolingian period, representing the late Merovingian Kingdom from 687 to 751 CE, was a largely decentralized kingdom based on the pre-existing Roman administrative system, with cities as the basic units.
Proto-Carolingian (687 CE–751 CE) — Western Europe: How did the city rulers contribute to the Merovingian Kingdom during the Proto-Carolingian period?

During the Proto-Carolingian period, the city rulers, known as counts or grafio, sent the king his tax revenue and carried out judicial and administrative functions, and had access to both administrative officials and city archives, contributing to the Merovingian Kingdom's organization.
Proto-Carolingian (687 CE–751 CE) — Western Europe: What was the role of the mayor of the palace in the Merovingian Kingdom during the Proto-Carolingian period?

Proto-Carolingian (687 CE–751 CE) — Western Europe: What were the basic territorial divisions of the Merovingian Kingdom during the Proto-Carolingian period?

The Proto-Carolingian period saw the Merovingian Kingdom divided into basic territorial divisions, including Neustria, Burgundy, Austrasia, and Aquitaine, each with its own distinct characteristics and levels of control, shaping the kingdom's geography and administration.
Proto-French Kingdom (987 CE–1150 CE) — Western Europe: What event marked the beginning of the Proto-French Kingdom in Western Europe?

Proto-French Kingdom (987 CE–1150 CE) — Western Europe: What was the source of legitimacy for the Capetian dynasty during the Proto-French Kingdom period in the Paris Basin?

The Capetians, during the Proto-French Kingdom period, drew their legitimacy from their stronger links to the Catholic church, which played a significant role in the Paris Basin region of Western Europe.
Proto-French Kingdom (987 CE–1150 CE) — Western Europe: What was the structure of the French king's government during the Proto-French Kingdom period in Western Europe?

At the core of the French king's government, during the Proto-French Kingdom period, were a few major officials with household titles, such as chancellor, seneschal, butler, chamberlain, and constable, which were the preserve of the aristocracy, particularly in the Paris Basin region of Western Europe.
Proto-French Kingdom (987 CE–1150 CE) — Western Europe: How did innovations in agriculture impact the population during the Proto-French Kingdom period in Western Europe?

Innovations in agriculture resulted in population increases during the Proto-French Kingdom period, especially in northern and western France, laying the groundwork for demographic expansion, which would occur later in the Capetian era, specifically within the Western Europe region.
Proto-French Kingdom (987 CE–1150 CE) — Western Europe: What role did the clergy play in the government and administration of the Proto-French Kingdom in Western Europe?

The clergy of the Church provided a pool of educated, literate, and numerate subjects, and were a vital resource for the government and administration of the Proto-French Kingdom, particularly in the Paris Basin region of Western Europe.
French Kingdom - Late Capetian (1150 CE–1328 CE) — Western Europe: What characterized the French Kingdom - Late Capetian period in Western Europe?
The French Kingdom - Late Capetian period was a character-defining period of administrative centralization and demographic expansion.
French Kingdom - Late Capetian (1150 CE–1328 CE) — Western Europe: How was the government of the French king organized before Philip II in the Paris Basin?

Before Philip II, the government of the French Kingdom - Late Capetian was very simple and closely linked to the king's court, which was still itinerant, moving wherever the king went, with a few major officials with household titles at its core.
French Kingdom - Late Capetian (1150 CE–1328 CE) — Western Europe: What changes did Philip II introduce to the administrative system of the French Kingdom - Late Capetian?

Philip II laid some of the foundations of a more formal administrative system, with government activity being recorded in writing, and registers and government records for finance and justice being placed in a dedicated archive, marking the beginning of the French Kingdom - Late Capetian's more organized administration.
French Kingdom - Late Capetian (1150 CE–1328 CE) — Western Europe: What role did the clergy and the Knights Templar play in the government of the French Kingdom - Late?

The clergy of the Christian Church continued to be a vital resource for the government and administration of the French Kingdom - Late Capetian, while the Knights Templar military order advised and controlled the treasury from the Paris Temple.
French Kingdom - Late Capetian (1150 CE–1328 CE) — Western Europe: How did the power of the royal centre change during the French Kingdom - Late Capetian period in Western?

The power of the royal centre over the regions steadily increased during the French Kingdom - Late Capetian period, with the French king gaining the power to make laws binding across the whole of his territory, and seneschals becoming royal appointees.
French Kingdom - Late Capetian (1150 CE–1328 CE) — Western Europe: What was the impact of the French Kingdom - Late Capetian period on the population of France and Paris?

The French Kingdom - Late Capetian period saw a significant demographic expansion, with the French population almost quadrupling from about 4 to 15 million, and the population of Paris growing from about 25,000 people in 1200 CE to 210,000 in 1328 CE, during the French Kingdom - Late Capetian period.
French Kingdom - Late Valois (1450 CE–1589 CE) — Western Europe: What significant cultural movement impacted the French Kingdom during the Late Valois period?

The French Kingdom - Late Valois was greatly impacted by the French Renaissance, which hit its cultural peak during the rule of Frances I and Henry II, transforming urban life and having an immense impact on architecture, culture, and art.
French Kingdom - Late Valois (1450 CE–1589 CE) — Western Europe: Who was the first Late Valois king and what did he achieve?

The French Kingdom - Late Valois period began with Louis XI, who continued to modernize the royal government and implemented the first royal postal service, building on the work of early Valois king Charles VII.
French Kingdom - Late Valois (1450 CE–1589 CE) — Western Europe: What was the outcome of the Italian Wars for the French Kingdom - Late Valois?

The French Kingdom - Late Valois fought the Italian Wars from 1494-1559 CE, but ultimately gave up all claims in Italy in 1559 CE, marking the start of a lasting rivalry between the Habsburgs and Valois.
French Kingdom - Late Valois (1450 CE–1589 CE) — Western Europe: What was the impact of the Wars of Religion on the French Kingdom - Late Valois?

The French Kingdom - Late Valois was weakened by the Wars of Religion, which lasted from 1562-1598 CE and resulted in the deaths of 3 million people, either from conflict, famine, or disease, and pitted Roman Catholics against Reformed Protestants.
French Kingdom - Late Valois (1450 CE–1589 CE) — Western Europe: How did the population of the French Kingdom - Late Valois change during French Kingdom - Late Valois?

The French Kingdom - Late Valois experienced significant population growth, recovering from the disasters of the late 14th and 15th centuries, with the population estimated to be between 10 million and 12 million in 1470 CE and reaching 20 million by 1560 CE.
French Kingdom - Late Valois (1450 CE–1589 CE) — Western Europe: What changes occurred in the government of the French Kingdom - Late Valois during French Kingdom - Late?

The French Kingdom - Late Valois saw the royal council become less feudal and more bureaucratic, with the king advised by professional lawyers rather than feudal vassals, and the financial and judicial functions of government were separated, continuing the work of early Valois king Charles VII.
French Kingdom - Early Bourbon (1589 CE–1660 CE) — Western Europe: What event marked the beginning of the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period in Western Europe?

The French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period began with the inheritance of the monarchy by Henry IV in 1589, following the death of the childless Late Valois king Henry III, and this marked the start of the House of Bourbon rule in Western Europe, specifically in the Paris Basin region, during the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period.
French Kingdom - Early Bourbon (1589 CE–1660 CE) — Western Europe: How did the reign of Henry IV impact the French monarchy during the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period?

The reign of Henry IV, during the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period, restored the French monarchy to full power in Western Europe, and his superintendent of finance Sully was able to double state revenues, which had a significant impact on the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period.
French Kingdom - Early Bourbon (1589 CE–1660 CE) — Western Europe: What role did Cardinal Richelieu play in the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period?

The French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period saw Cardinal Richelieu, the cardinal minister of King Louis XIII, modernize the French army, which led to the large-scale expansion of the French bureaucracy in Western Europe, specifically in the Paris Basin region, during the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period.
French Kingdom - Early Bourbon (1589 CE–1660 CE) — Western Europe: What was the outcome of the Fronde revolts during the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period?

The Fronde, a series of revolts in the 1640s against cardinal minister Mazarin, led the crown to consolidate its power even further during the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period in Western Europe, paving the way for the absolute rule of King Louis XIV in the Late Bourbon period, which followed the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period.
French Kingdom - Early Bourbon (1589 CE–1660 CE) — Western Europe: What were some of the institutional and military reforms instituted during the French Kingdom - Early?

The French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period saw important institutional and military reforms, including the institution of a tax on holders of government and judicial offices by King Henry IV, and the expansion and modernization of the French army under Richelieu, which led to the large-scale expansion of the French bureaucracy in Western Europe, specifically in the Paris Basin region, during the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period.
French Kingdom - Early Bourbon (1589 CE–1660 CE) — Western Europe: What was the population growth within the boundaries of present-day France during the French Kingdom -?

The population within the boundaries of present-day France grew from 18.5 million in 1600 to 21 million in 1650 during the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period in Western Europe, specifically in the Paris Basin region, reflecting the growth and development of the French Kingdom - Early Bourbon period.
French Kingdom - Late Bourbon (1660 CE–1815 CE) — Western Europe: What significant event marked the beginning of the French Kingdom - Late Bourbon period in Western Europe?
The French Kingdom - Late Bourbon period began as King Louis XIV consolidated monarchical power in 1661 CE, earning him the nickname the 'Sun King'.
French Kingdom - Late Bourbon (1660 CE–1815 CE) — Western Europe: How did King Louis XIV support the arts in the French Kingdom during the Late Bourbon period?

The French Kingdom - Late Bourbon period saw King Louis XIV, also known as the 'Sun King', come into full power and become an avid patron of the arts, creating academies for dance, science, music, and architecture, supporting French writers, and expanding the Louvre.
French Kingdom - Late Bourbon (1660 CE–1815 CE) — Western Europe: What was the outcome of the Edict of Fontainebleau issued by King Louis XIV in 1685 CE in the French Kingdom?
The French Kingdom - Late Bourbon period saw King Louis XIV nullify the Edict of Nantes that gave rights of worship to the Huguenot Protestants with the 1685 CE Edict of Fontainebleau.
French Kingdom - Late Bourbon (1660 CE–1815 CE) — Western Europe: What challenges did France face during the third period of Louis XIV's reign in the French Kingdom - Late?

The French Kingdom - Late Bourbon period saw the third period of Louis XIV's reign, from 1689 to 1715 CE, end in frustration, with France involved in a succession of wars, increased public debt, and suffering from famine from 1693 to 1694 CE.
French Kingdom - Late Bourbon (1660 CE–1815 CE) — Western Europe: How did the Enlightenment impact the French Kingdom during the Late Bourbon period?

The French Kingdom - Late Bourbon period saw the Enlightenment begin to dominate the public sphere in the 18th century, becoming a catalyst for the French Revolution which overthrew King Louis XVI in 1789 CE.
French Kingdom - Late Bourbon (1660 CE–1815 CE) — Western Europe: How did King Louis XVI's rule differ from that of King Louis XIV in terms of the Estates General in the?

The French Kingdom - Late Bourbon period saw King Louis XIV rule as his own prime minister, with the Estates General and the Assembly of Notables not meeting, whereas King Louis XVI was forced to reconvene the Estates General as the National Assembly during the French Revolution.
French Kingdom - Late Bourbon (1660 CE–1815 CE) — Western Europe: What was the result of the National Assembly's actions on King Louis XVI's rule in the French Kingdom - Late?

Sarazm (3500 BCE–2000 BCE) — Turkestan: What was the significance of the Sarazm period in Sogdiana?

Andronovo (1800 BCE–1200 BCE) — Turkestan: What subsistence strategies were employed by the Andronovo people in Turkestan?

Andronovo (1800 BCE–1200 BCE) — Turkestan: How were Andronovo communities organized in terms of settlement size in the Kazakh steppe?

Koktepe I (1400 BCE–1000 BCE) — Turkestan: What was the first urban phase in Sogdiana during the Koktepe I period?

Koktepe I (1400 BCE–1000 BCE) — Turkestan: What characterized the economy of Koktepe I in Turkestan?

Koktepe I (1400 BCE–1000 BCE) — Turkestan: What type of houses were built during the Koktepe I period in Sogdiana?

Koktepe I (1400 BCE–1000 BCE) — Turkestan: What was the significance of the Bulungur canal to Koktepe I in Turkestan?

Koktepe I (1400 BCE–1000 BCE) — Turkestan: How did the arrival of Iranian-speaking populations affect Koktepe I in Sogdiana?

Ancient Khwarazm (1000 BCE–521 BCE) — Turkestan: What was the most interesting Early Iron Age culture of Ancient Khwarazm in Turkestan?

Ancient Khwarazm (1000 BCE–521 BCE) — Turkestan: What were the key features of the Yakka-Parsan II settlement in Ancient Khwarazm?

Ancient Khwarazm (1000 BCE–521 BCE) — Turkestan: What was the significance of the Achaemenids in Sogdiana during the Ancient Khwarazm period?

Ancient Khwarazm (1000 BCE–521 BCE) — Turkestan: What was the nature of the settlements in Chorasmia during the 6th and 5th centuries BC in Ancient Khwarazm?

Ancient Khwarazm (1000 BCE–521 BCE) — Turkestan: What were the key features of the city of Kyuzeli-gir in Ancient Khwarazm?

Ancient Khwarazm (1000 BCE–521 BCE) — Turkestan: What nomadic groups infiltrated the region of Ancient Khwarazm in Turkestan?

Koktepe II (750 BCE–550 BCE) — Turkestan: What type of structure developed at Koktepe in the 7th or 6th century BCE during the Koktepe II period in Turkestan's Sogdiana region?

Koktepe II (750 BCE–550 BCE) — Turkestan: How does the cultural context of Koktepe during the Koktepe II period differ from that of eastern Central Asia?

Koktepe II (750 BCE–550 BCE) — Turkestan: What type of masonry characterizes the very first phase of urban construction at Koktepe and other sites in the Sogdian plain during?

Koktepe II (750 BCE–550 BCE) — Turkestan: What can be inferred about the population at Koktepe during the transition between the Koktepe I and Koktepe II periods in?

Koktepe II (750 BCE–550 BCE) — Turkestan: What is the significance of the fortified courtyards at Koktepe during the Koktepe II period in Turkestan's Sogdiana region?

The fortified courtyards at Koktepe during the Koktepe II period in Turkestan's Sogdiana region may have been a manifestation of the tension between the sedentary population and nomads, as well as a response to the increased danger from the Steppe, characteristic of the Koktepe II period.

The inhabitants within the courtyards at Koktepe during the Koktepe II period in Turkestan's Sogdiana region may have been Scythians, who probably invaded and settled around 750 BCE, and built fortifications to reflect the increased danger from the Steppe, typical of the Koktepe II period.
Tocharians (129 BCE–29 CE) — Afghanistan: What was the time period of the Tocharians in Afghanistan and Sogdiana?

The Tocharians were present in Afghanistan and Sogdiana between the disintegration of the Greco-Bactrian kingdom in the late 2nd century BCE and the rise of the Kushan Empire in the 1st century CE, specifically from 129 BCE to the early 1st century CE, during which the Tocharians, also referred to as Yuezhi, played a significant role.
Tocharians (129 BCE–29 CE) — Afghanistan: Who were the Tocharians also known as?

The Tocharians were also known as Yuezhi, a group of pastoralists and traders, and sometimes referred to as 'Tochari' by scholars who believe they spoke a Tocharian language, which is part of an extinct Indo-European language group, characteristic of the Tocharians.
Tocharians (129 BCE–29 CE) — Afghanistan: What was the original location of the Yuezhi, also known as Tocharians, before migrating to Sogdiana?

The Yuezhi, or Tocharians, were originally living on the steppes to the north of China in the mid-1st millennium BCE and perhaps even earlier, before migrating to Sogdiana, which became a key region for the Tocharians.
Tocharians (129 BCE–29 CE) — Afghanistan: How were the Tocharians, or Yuezhi, organized in Bactria and Sogdiana?

The Tocharians, or Yuezhi, in Bactria and Sogdiana seem to have been organized into a federation of five tribes that competed for political supremacy in the new territory, characteristic of the Tocharians' political structure during that time.
Tocharians (129 BCE–29 CE) — Afghanistan: What marked the end of the Tocharian period in Sogdiana?

The Tocharian period in Sogdiana ended with the rise of the Kushan Empire in the 1st century CE, specifically when the first Kushan king, Kujula Kadphises, seized power and began ruling over south-eastern Sogdiana, marking the end of the Tocharians' rule.
Tocharians (129 BCE–29 CE) — Afghanistan: What was the nature of Tocharian control over the sedentary population of northern Bactria and Sogdia?

The Tocharians, or Yuezhi, exercised control over the sedentary population of northern Bactria and Sogdia as a militarily superior ruling dynasty of nomads, with their 'nominal sovereignty' acknowledged by the locals because they feared violence if they refused to submit, which was a key aspect of the Tocharians' rule.
Sogdiana - City-States Period (604 CE–711 CE) — Turkestan: What was the time period of the Sogdiana - City-States Period in Turkestan?
The Sogdiana - City-States Period occurred between 604 and 711CE, and during this time, the region was characterized by the rise of city-states such as Bukhara and Samarkand.
Sogdiana - City-States Period (604 CE–711 CE) — Turkestan: How did the Sogdiana - City-States Period come to an end in the region of Turkestan?

Sogdiana - City-States Period (604 CE–711 CE) — Turkestan: Which city-state was the most prominent during the Sogdiana - City-States Period in Turkestan?

The Sogdiana - City-States Period saw Samarkand as the chief city-state, which extended across the plateau of Afrasiab in the seventh century and was at the peak of its economic and cultural production.
Sogdiana - City-States Period (604 CE–711 CE) — Turkestan: What characterized the height of the Sogdiana - City-States Period in Turkestan?

Sogdiana - City-States Period (604 CE–711 CE) — Turkestan: How were the city-states during the Sogdiana - City-States Period related to the Chinese T’ang dynasty in Turkestan?

The Sogdiana - City-States Period city-states were nominally allied to the Chinese T’ang dynasty, although the dynasty did not meaningfully hinder the Arab incursions, and the city-states had achieved de facto independence after the fall of the Western Kaghanate.
Sogdiana - City-States Period (604 CE–711 CE) — Turkestan: What was the system of government in each city-state during the Sogdiana - City-States Period in Turkestan?

The Sogdiana - City-States Period saw each city-state ruled by a king, conceived of as ‘first among equals’, who headed the administrative system that ran the state, with a strong merchant class present, although their relationship to the ruling elite remains unclear.
Khanate of Bukhara (1599 CE–1747 CE) — Turkestan: Who was a notable khan of the Khanate of Bukhara in Turkestan?
The Khanate of Bukhara had a notable khan, Abdalaziz, who ruled from 1645-81 and was a devout Muslim who favored the religious establishment and adorned Bukhara with still more mosques and madrasas.
Khanate of Bukhara (1599 CE–1747 CE) — Turkestan: What was the religious inclination of most khans of the Khanate of Bukhara in Sogdiana?
Most khans of the Khanate of Bukhara, especially in Sogdiana, were devout Muslims who favored the religious establishment.
Khanate of Bukhara (1599 CE–1747 CE) — Turkestan: What architectural additions were made to Bukhara during the Khanate of Bukhara?
The Khanate of Bukhara adorned Bukhara with still more mosques and madrasas, especially during the rule of Abdalaziz.
Hmong - Late Qing (1701 CE–1895 CE) — South China: What is another term used to refer to the Hmong people in South China during the Hmong - Late Qing period?

Hmong - Late Qing (1701 CE–1895 CE) — South China: How did the Chinese government control the Hmong people in South China during the Hmong - Late Qing period?

Hmong - Late Qing (1701 CE–1895 CE) — South China: What were some of the key events that occurred during the Hmong - Late Qing period in South China?

Hmong - Late Qing (1701 CE–1895 CE) — South China: What was the estimated population of the Hmong people in 1954?
The Hmong - Late Qing people had an estimated population of 150,000 in 1954.
Hmong - Late Qing (1701 CE–1895 CE) — South China: What was the approximate population of the Hmong people during the Qing Dynasty?

Hmong - Early Chinese (1895 CE–1941 CE) — South China: How long have the Hmong people inhabited southern China?

Hmong - Early Chinese (1895 CE–1941 CE) — South China: How did the Chinese government treat the Hmong during the Republican period in South China?

Hmong - Early Chinese (1895 CE–1941 CE) — South China: What was the estimated population of the Hmong in 1954 in South China?
