The Anurādhapura IV period marked the end of the Moriya grip on the Anurādhapura throne in Sri Lanka. The Anurādhapura IV period was characterized by the rise of the Lambakaṇṇas in Sri Lanka.
Polonnaruwa (1070 CE–1255 CE) — Sri Lanka: What has been revealed about the religious landscape of Polonnaruva in Sri Lanka?
Polonnaruwa: The remains of Polonnaruva have revealed Buddhist monasteries and Hindu temples with bronze sculptures of Hindu deities, indicating religious plurality and harmony in Polonnaruva.
Polonnaruwa (1070 CE–1255 CE) — Sri Lanka: What archaeological findings have been made at the Alahana Pirivena in Polonnaruva?
Polonnaruwa: Excavations within the Alahana Pirivena in Polonnaruva uncovered quantities of pottery with appliqué designs, including swastika, śrīvasta and vajra or triśūla, in Polonnaruva.
Polonnaruwa (1070 CE–1255 CE) — Sri Lanka: What do bronze figurines excavated at Polonnaruva represent?
Polonnaruwa: Bronze figurines excavated at Polonnaruva represent deities such as Śiva and Parvati, which have been put forward as evidence of the presence of Hinduism in Polonnaruva.
Polonnaruwa (1070 CE–1255 CE) — Sri Lanka: How do the archaeological findings in Polonnaruva contribute to our understanding of the city?

Polonnaruwa: The archaeological findings in Polonnaruva, including Buddhist monasteries and Hindu temples, contribute to our understanding of Polonnaruva as a cosmopolitan urban centre with religious plurality and harmony.
Anurādhapura III (428 CE–614 CE) — Sri Lanka: What event occurred in 614 during the Anurādhapura III period in Sri Lanka?
The last Moriya king was overthrown in 614, and the dominance of the Lambakannas was re-established during the Anurādhapura III period.
Anurādhapura III (428 CE–614 CE) — Sri Lanka: What followed the Moriyas' ascension to the throne in the fifth century in Sri Lanka during the Anurādhapura III period?
Two hundred years of open conflict between the Moriyas and the Lambakannas followed the Moriyas' ascension to the throne in the fifth century during the Anurādhapura III period in Sri Lanka.
Anurādhapura III (428 CE–614 CE) — Sri Lanka: How did the Lambakannas' reign stabilise later in the fifth century during the Anurādhapura III period?

The reign of the Lambakannas stabilised later in the fifth century during the Anurādhapura III period thanks to a new law of succession to the throne which helped to monopolise the power of the Lambakannas.
Anurādhapura I (300 BCE–70 CE) — Sri Lanka: What characterized the region where the city of Anuradhapura is located during the Anurādhapura I period in Sri Lanka?

The Anurādhapura I period in Sri Lanka was situated in a semi-arid zone, characterized by low level plains, punctuated with low granitic outcrops, and human occupation in the region was almost entirely dependent upon large-scale irrigation works.
Anurādhapura I (300 BCE–70 CE) — Sri Lanka: What was the significance of Anuradhapura during the Anurādhapura I period in Sri Lanka?

Anuradhapura was the first Buddhist city in Sri Lanka during the Anurādhapura I period, and the great architectural edifices in this city are invaluable sources to understand Buddhist sacred architecture and landscape, reflecting the importance of the Anurādhapura I period.
Anurādhapura I (300 BCE–70 CE) — Sri Lanka: What role did agriculture and irrigation landscape play in the Anurādhapura I period in Sri Lanka?

Agriculture and irrigation landscape played a vital role throughout the history of the Anurādhapura I period in Sri Lanka, emphasizing traditional land occupation and encircling the city, with the Anurādhapura I period being a significant part of this history.
Anurādhapura I (300 BCE–70 CE) — Sri Lanka: When was the city of Anuradhapura nominated under the world heritage list?

The city of Anuradhapura, which was a key location during the Anurādhapura I period in Sri Lanka, was nominated under the world heritage list in 1982, recognizing its importance and the significance of the Anurādhapura I period.
Anurādhapura I (300 BCE–70 CE) — Sri Lanka: What was the primary factor that enabled human occupation in the region of Anuradhapura during the Anurādhapura I period in Sri?

The primary factor that enabled human occupation in the region of Anuradhapura during the Anurādhapura I period in Sri Lanka was the large-scale irrigation works, first constructed in the third and fourth centuries BCE, which supported the Anurādhapura I period.
Anurādhapura II (70 CE–428 CE) — Sri Lanka: What happened to the dynasty of Devānampiya Tissa during the Anurādhapura II period in Sri Lanka?
The dynasty of Devānampiya Tissa became extinct in the first century AD during the Anurādhapura II period in Sri Lanka.
Anurādhapura II (70 CE–428 CE) — Sri Lanka: Which two powerful clans vied for the throne in Sri Lanka during the Anurādhapura II period?
The Anurādhapura II period in Sri Lanka saw the Lambakannas and the Moriyas as the two powerful clans that vied for the throne.
Anurādhapura II (70 CE–428 CE) — Sri Lanka: Who were the chief rivals of the Lambakannas for power in Sri Lanka during the Anurādhapura II period?
The Moriyas were the chief rivals of the Lambakannas for power in Sri Lanka during the Anurādhapura II period.
Anurādhapura II (70 CE–428 CE) — Sri Lanka: How long did the first Lambakanna dynasty rule at Anurādhapura during the Anurādhapura II period?
The first Lambakanna dynasty, established by Vasabha, ruled at Anurādhapura from AD 67-111 and retained hold on the throne until the death of Mahānāma in AD 428 during the Anurādhapura II period.
Anurādhapura II (70 CE–428 CE) — Sri Lanka: What was the nature of the rule of the Lambakanna dynasty during the Anurādhapura II period in Sri Lanka?
The Lambakanna dynasty ruled in comparative peace during the Anurādhapura II period in Sri Lanka, which spanned between the first and fourth centuries CE.
Kingdom of Jimma (1790 CE–1932 CE) — East Africa: When and how did the Kingdom of Jimma form in East Africa?

The Kingdom of Jimma is said to have formed in the late 18th century by members of the Diggo clan, a sub-group of the Oromo people, in East Africa, and this marked the beginning of the Kingdom of Jimma.
Kingdom of Jimma (1790 CE–1932 CE) — East Africa: What significant event occurred in the Kingdom of Jimma around the turn of the 19th century?
Around the turn of the 19th century, the Diggo captured the southern Ethiopian town of Jiren, along with its great market, Hirmata, and made this the capital of the Kingdom of Jimma.
Kingdom of Jimma (1790 CE–1932 CE) — East Africa: Who became the first monarch of the Jimma Abba Jifar Kingdom in 1830?
In 1830, Abba Jifar became the first monarch of the new established Jimma Abba Jifar Kingdom, which was part of the Kingdom of Jimma.
Kingdom of Jimma (1790 CE–1932 CE) — East Africa: What law governed the Jimma Abba Jifar Kingdom?
The Jimma Abba Jifar Kingdom, part of the Kingdom of Jimma, was an Islamic Kingdom governed by Shari’a Law.
Kingdom of Jimma (1790 CE–1932 CE) — East Africa: What threat did the Kingdom of Jimma face by the late 19th century?
By the late 19th century, the Kingdom of Jimma came under threat by the expanding Abyssinian Kingdom, which posed a risk to the Kingdom of Jimma's autonomy.
Kingdom of Jimma (1790 CE–1932 CE) — East Africa: How did the last ruler of the Kingdom of Jimma, Abba Jifar II, protect the kingdom's independence?
In order to protect the autonomy of the Kingdom of Jimma, its last ruler Abba Jifar II had to pay tribute to the Abyssinian rulers in exchange for the Kingdom of Jimma's independence.
Kingdom of Jimma (1790 CE–1932 CE) — East Africa: What event marked the end of the Kingdom of Jimma in 1932?
In 1932, Emperor Halie Selassie took control of the Kingdom of Jimma and incorporated the region into the Ethiopian Empire, marking the end of the Kingdom of Jimma.
Adal Sultanate (1375 CE–1543 CE) — East Africa: What was the Adal Sultanate in the Somali region?

The Adal Sultanate was one of the earliest Islamic Sultanates in the Somali region, originally established in the late 9th or early 10th centuries based at the coastal port city of Zelia on the Gulf of Aden, and part of the Walasma Dynasty, which later became known as the Adal Sultanate.
Adal Sultanate (1375 CE–1543 CE) — East Africa: When did the Adal Sultanate become a powerful Sultanate in East Africa?

The Adal Sultanate became a powerful Sultanate that controlled vast swaths of territory from the Harar region to the Gulf of Aden up through present-day Eritrea in the last quarter of the 14th century, during the Adal Sultanate period.
Adal Sultanate (1375 CE–1543 CE) — East Africa: Who was the most powerful leader of the Adal Sultanate in East Africa?

The most powerful leader of the Adal Sultanate was Ahmād Ibrāhīm al Ghāzī, also known as Ahmad Gurey, who ruled from 1506-1543 and led the Adal Sultanate in its conquests, including declaring jihad on Christian Ethiopia during the Adal Sultanate period.
Adal Sultanate (1375 CE–1543 CE) — East Africa: What was the outcome of the Adal Sultanate's conflict with Christian Ethiopia?

The Adal Sultanate, under the leadership of Ahmad Gurey, was able to conquer over three-quarters of Ethiopia during the Adal Sultanate period, but was ultimately defeated by Ethiopian and Portuguese forces at Lake Tana in 1543, leading to the death of Ahmad Gurey and the disintegration of the Adal Sultanate.
Adal Sultanate (1375 CE–1543 CE) — East Africa: How did the Ottoman Empire support the Adal Sultanate?
The Adal Sultanate was supplied with military supplies from the Ottoman Empire, which helped its army conquer over three-quarters of Ethiopia during the Adal Sultanate period.
Tunni Sultanate (800 CE–1200 CE) — East Africa: Where did the Tunni Sultanate originate?
The Tunni Sultanate originated on the Benadir Coast in East Africa, specifically in what is now Somalia, and was known as the Tunni Sultanate.
Tunni Sultanate (800 CE–1200 CE) — East Africa: What was the capital of the Tunni Sultanate?
The Tunni Sultanate had established its capital at Qoryooley, during the time of the Tunni Sultanate.
Tunni Sultanate (800 CE–1200 CE) — East Africa: What was one of the first notable actions of the Tunni Sultanate in Somalia?
The Tunni Sultanate was one of the first groups in Somalia to embrace Islam, as part of the Tunni Sultanate's history.
Tunni Sultanate (800 CE–1200 CE) — East Africa: What language was primarily spoken within the Tunni Sultanate?
The language spoken within the Tunni Sultanate was a local language called Af-Maay, which was used by the people of the Tunni Sultanate.
Tunni Sultanate (800 CE–1200 CE) — East Africa: What other language did some people in the Tunni Sultanate know?
Inscriptions from the twelfth century CE suggest that some within the Tunni Sultanate knew the Arabic language, during the time of the Tunni Sultanate.
Tunni Sultanate (800 CE–1200 CE) — East Africa: When did the Tunni Sultanate end?
The Tunni Sultanate ended sometime within the thirteenth century CE, marking the end of the Tunni Sultanate.
Ajuran Sultanate (1250 CE–1700 CE) — East Africa: When did the Ajuran Sultanate originate in East Africa?

The Ajuran Sultanate originated in the mid-sixteenth century as a leading clan of confederated states in East Africa, which included the Muzzafar Dynasty of Mogadishu, and was part of the Ajuran Sultanate.
Ajuran Sultanate (1250 CE–1700 CE) — East Africa: What region did the Ajuran Sultanate control in East Africa?
The Ajuran Sultanate controlled the Shabelle valley in southern Somalia all the way to the Kenyan border, which was a key area of the Ajuran Sultanate in East Africa.
Ajuran Sultanate (1250 CE–1700 CE) — East Africa: What was the capital of the Ajuran Sultanate?

The Ajuran Sultanate's capital was the Indian Ocean port city of Marka, allowing the Ajuran Sultanate to have lucrative trade connections with other parts of Africa, the Arabian Peninsula, India, and China.
Ajuran Sultanate (1250 CE–1700 CE) — East Africa: What was the title of the Ajuran leader?
The Ajuran leader was known as the imam or emir of the Ajuran Sultanate.
Ajuran Sultanate (1250 CE–1700 CE) — East Africa: How was the Ajuran Sultanate governed?
The Ajuran Sultanate was governed by the imam or emir, and below the imam were a number of governors and viceroys that helped maintain the Ajuran Sultanate.
Ajuran Sultanate (1250 CE–1700 CE) — East Africa: What led to the decline of the Ajuran Sultanate?

The Ajuran Sultanate declined due to internal resistance to Ajuran rule by various clan alliances, which ultimately allowed for other kingdoms to rise in its place, marking the end of the Ajuran Sultanate.
Ajuran Sultanate (1250 CE–1700 CE) — East Africa: What is known about the population of the Ajuran Sultanate?
The Ajuran Sultanate has no recorded population numbers within the consulted literature, providing limited information about the size of the Ajuran Sultanate.
Habr Yunis (1300 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: When did the Habr Yunis Sultanate originate from the Isaaq Sultanate?

The Habr Yunis Sultanate was originally part of the Isaaq Sultanate that began roughly around the fourteenth century, and by the mid-nineteenth century, Habr Yunis broke away from the Isaaq to create its own sultanate, known as Habr Yunis.
Habr Yunis (1300 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: What ports did the Habr Yunis control trade around?
The Habr Yunis controlled trade around the Zeila and Berbera ports on the northwest Somali coast, during the time of the Habr Yunis Sultanate.
Habr Yunis (1300 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: What happened to the Habr Yunis Sultanate by the late nineteenth century?
By the late nineteenth century, Habr Yunis was absorbed into British Somaliland, officially ending the Habr Yunis Sultanate.
Habr Yunis (1300 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: Who founded the Isaaq Somali people, from which the Habr Yunis Sultanate originated?

The Habr Yunis Sultanate originated from the Isaaq Sultanate, which was founded by Sheikh Isaq, the founder of the Isaaq Somali people, who arrived from the Arabian Peninsula roughly around the fourteenth century, leading to the establishment of the Habr Yunis Sultanate.
Kingdom of Gomma (1780 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: Where was the Kingdom of Gomma located?
The Kingdom of Gomma was located in Western Ethiopia, which is part of East Africa. The Kingdom of Gomma was one of the five Oromo kingdoms in this region.
Kingdom of Gomma (1780 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: When did the Kingdom of Gomma originate?
The Kingdom of Gomma originated in the late eighteenth century CE. This was the starting point for the Kingdom of Gomma, which lasted until its annexation.
Kingdom of Gomma (1780 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: What was the capital of the Kingdom of Gomma?
The capital of the Kingdom of Gomma was located at Haggaro. The Kingdom of Gomma had its center of power in Haggaro during its existence.
Kingdom of Gomma (1780 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: What religion did the Kingdom of Gomma embrace?
The Kingdom of Gomma was one of the first Oromo kingdoms to embrace Islam. The Kingdom of Gomma's adoption of Islam was a significant aspect of its history.
Kingdom of Gomma (1780 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: What happened to the Kingdom of Gomma by 1886 CE?
By 1886 CE, the Kingdom of Gomma was annexed into the Ethiopian Empire under Menelik II. The Kingdom of Gomma came to an end as it became part of the Ethiopian Empire.
Sultanate of Geledi (1750 CE–1911 CE) — East Africa: What dynasty was the Sultanate of Geledi part of?

The Sultanate of Geledi was part of the Gobroon Dynasty that was established in the seventeenth or the first half of the eighteenth centuries. The Sultanate of Geledi played a significant role in this dynasty.
Sultanate of Geledi (1750 CE–1911 CE) — East Africa: Where was the capital of the Sultanate of Geledi located?
The capital of the Sultanate of Geledi was the town of Afgoy, located on the lower Shebelle River, twenty km from Mogadishu, in the region of East Africa, during the Sultanate of Geledi period.
Sultanate of Geledi (1750 CE–1911 CE) — East Africa: What was the outcome of the conflict between the Sultanate of Geledi and the Baardheere Jamaaca jihadists in 1843?

The Sultanate of Geledi defeated the fundamentalist Baardheere Jamaaca jihadists in 1843, who wanted to bring ultra-religious ideals into the region of East Africa, during the Sultanate of Geledi period.
Sultanate of Geledi (1750 CE–1911 CE) — East Africa: What contributed to the decline of the Sultanate of Geledi's influence by the end of the nineteenth century?
The Sultanate of Geledi's influence waned due to regional fighting and interference from European colonists, marking a significant decline for the Sultanate of Geledi in East Africa.
Sultanate of Geledi (1750 CE–1911 CE) — East Africa: What happened to the territory of the Sultanate of Geledi in 1911?
The territory of the Sultanate of Geledi was annexed by Italy in 1911, as part of their creation of Italian Somaliland, bringing an end to the Sultanate of Geledi in East Africa.
Shoa Sultanate (1108 CE–1285 CE) — East Africa: What was the Shoa Sultanate in the region of Ethiopia?

The Shoa Sultanate was the first and earliest known Muslim political kingdom in the region of Ethiopia, with its rulers being either Muhzumite sultans or princes of the Muhzumite Dynasty, specifically the Shoa Sultanate.
Shoa Sultanate (1108 CE–1285 CE) — East Africa: Where was the Shoa Sultanate located in East Africa?

The Shoa Sultanate was located in the eastern part of the Shoan plateau and extended east along the Awash River in East Africa, with the Shoa Sultanate being an important commercial kingdom in this region.
Shoa Sultanate (1108 CE–1285 CE) — East Africa: What was the significance of the Shoa Sultanate in terms of trade?
The Shoa Sultanate was an important commercial kingdom, well situated along vital trade routes from the sea to the interior of Ethiopia, with the Shoa Sultanate playing a crucial role in this trade.
Shoa Sultanate (1108 CE–1285 CE) — East Africa: What led to the annexation of the Shoa Sultanate by the Ifat Sultanate?

The continuous infighting among the Muslim principalities of the Shoa Sultanate, as well as conflicts with other Muslim states, particularly the rulers of Ifat, led to the complete annexation of the Shoa Sultanate by the newly formed Ifat Sultanate in 1285, marking the end of the Shoa Sultanate.
Shoa Sultanate (1108 CE–1285 CE) — East Africa: Who annexed the Shoa Sultanate in 1285?
The Shoa Sultanate was annexed by the Ifat Sultanate, specifically by ‘Umar Walasma, in 1285, bringing an end to the Shoa Sultanate's existence.
Hadiya Sultanate (1300 CE–1680 CE) — East Africa: Where was the Hadiya Sultanate located?
The Hadiya Sultanate was located in the southwestern part of Ethiopia, in the East Africa region, and was also known as the Hadeya Kingdom.
Hadiya Sultanate (1300 CE–1680 CE) — East Africa: When was the Hadiya Sultanate first mentioned in historical records?
The Hadiya Sultanate was first mentioned in the Ethiopian historical epic, Kebra Nast, in the early fourteenth century, during the time of its existence.
Hadiya Sultanate (1300 CE–1680 CE) — East Africa: Who did the Hadiya Sultanate pay tribute to in the early 1300s?
The Hadiya Sultanate paid tribute to the Ethiopian Empire under the reign of Amda Tseyon in the early 1300s.
Hadiya Sultanate (1300 CE–1680 CE) — East Africa: What alliance did the Hadiya leaders form in 1531?
The Hadiya leaders formed an alliance with the Muslim forces of Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al Ghazi of the Adal Sultanate in 1531, going against the Ethiopian Kingdom, during the Hadiya Sultanate period.
Hadiya Sultanate (1300 CE–1680 CE) — East Africa: What was the outcome of the Hadiya Sultanate's rebellion against the Ethiopian Empire?
Despite being under Ethiopian control, the Hadiya Sultanate still rebelled and led insurrections, but by the 17th century, the Hadiya Sultanate finally submitted allegiance to the Ethiopian Emperor.
Hadiya Sultanate (1300 CE–1680 CE) — East Africa: Who helped the Ethiopian Empire bring the Hadiya Sultanate back under control?
The Ethiopian Empire, with the help of the Portuguese, brought the Hadiya Sultanate back into Ethiopian domination after a major victory over the Adal Sultanate.
Ifat Sultanate (1280 CE–1375 CE) — East Africa: When and by whom was the Ifat Sultanate founded in the Shoan region of present-day Ethiopia?
The Ifat Sultanate was founded by Umar Walasma in 1280, marking the beginning of the Walasma Dynasty in the region, with the Ifat Sultanate becoming a significant power in East Africa.
Ifat Sultanate (1280 CE–1375 CE) — East Africa: What contributed to the prosperity of the Ifat Sultanate in East Africa?

The Ifat Sultanate was prosperous due to extensive caravan routes and the important port city of Zeila on the Gulf of Aden, which facilitated trade and commerce in the region during the Ifat Sultanate period.
Ifat Sultanate (1280 CE–1375 CE) — East Africa: How did the Ifat Sultanate interact with the Ethiopian Christian kingdom in the early fourteenth century?

The Ifat Sultanate came into conflict with the Ethiopian Christian king Amda Siyon, who launched attacks into Muslim territory, and by 1329, the Ifat Sultanate was defeated and controlled by the Christian King, with the Ifat Sultanate still maintained under the suzerainty of the Ethiopian Christian kingdom.
Ifat Sultanate (1280 CE–1375 CE) — East Africa: What significant event occurred in the late fourteenth century regarding the Ifat Sultanate's relationship with the Ethiopian?
The Ifat leader Haqadin II led a revolt against the Christian Ethiopian Kingdom and declared Ifat's independence, marking a significant turning point for the Ifat Sultanate in East Africa.
Ifat Sultanate (1280 CE–1375 CE) — East Africa: What was the outcome of Haqadin II's revolt and the subsequent movement of the Ifat Sultanate's capital?

After Haqadin II's revolt, the Ifat Sultanate's capital was moved to the Adal region in 1374/5, and while the Walasma Dynasty continued, the Ifat Sultanate became eclipsed by the new Adal Sultanate, signaling a shift in power in the region for the Ifat Sultanate.
Medri Bahri (1310 CE–1889 CE) — East Africa: When was the Medri Bahri Kingdom established in East Africa?
Medri Bahri was established in the early fourteenth century, specifically around 1310 in East Africa.
Medri Bahri (1310 CE–1889 CE) — East Africa: What was the capital of the Medri Bahri Kingdom?
The capital of Medri Bahri was Deba-ruba, also known as Dibarwa, during its existence in East Africa.
Medri Bahri (1310 CE–1889 CE) — East Africa: How was the ruler of Medri Bahri selected?
Medri Bahri was ruled by the Bahri Negassi who was elected by the people of Medri Bahri in East Africa.
Medri Bahri (1310 CE–1889 CE) — East Africa: What was the relationship between Medri Bahri and the Ethiopian Kingdom?
Medri Bahri was a vassal state to the larger Ethiopian Kingdom, indicating a subordinate relationship between Medri Bahri and the Ethiopian Kingdom in East Africa.
Medri Bahri (1310 CE–1889 CE) — East Africa: Which country occupied Medri Bahri in the late 19th century?
Medri Bahri was occupied by Italy in the late 19th century, marking the end of Medri Bahri's independence in East Africa.
Majeerteen Sultanate (1750 CE–1926 CE) — East Africa: When did the Majeerteen Sultan, Isman Mahamud, enter into a British trade agreement?

The Majeerteen Sultan, Isman Mahamud, entered into a British trade agreement in 1839, which also guaranteed safe passage for British ships and crew members who sometimes shipwrecked in the Majeerteen Sultanate's waters.
Majeerteen Sultanate (1750 CE–1926 CE) — East Africa: What led to the decline of the Majeerteen Sultanate?

The decline of the Majeerteen Sultanate centred on a civil war between Majeerteen Sultan Isman Mahamud and his cousin Yusuf Ali, which resulted in Yusuf Ali taking control of some Majeerteen territory and creating a new Sultanate called Hobyo.
Majeerteen Sultanate (1750 CE–1926 CE) — East Africa: What happened to the Majeerteen Sultanate in the late 19th and early 20th centuries?

During the final years of the 19th and early 20th centuries, the Majeerteen Sultanate became under pressure by European colonial powers, particularly Italy, and in 1926, Italian colonial forces occupied the kingdom, creating Italian Somaliland.
Majeerteen Sultanate (1750 CE–1926 CE) — East Africa: What was the relationship between the Majeerteen Sultanate and European colonial powers?

The Majeerteen Sultanate was under pressure by European colonial powers, particularly Italy, and due to the Sultanate's subordination to the British crown, the Sultan was able to maintain his kingdom's freedom up until the later part of the 19th century.
Funj Sultanate (1504 CE–1820 CE) — East Africa: Where was the Funj Sultanate located?
The Funj Sultanate was a kingdom in modern-day Sudan, Ethiopia, and Eritrea, in the East Africa region. The Funj Sultanate had its capital at Sinnar in Sudan.
Funj Sultanate (1504 CE–1820 CE) — East Africa: When was the Funj Sultanate founded and by whom?
The Funj Sultanate was founded in 1504 after its first ruler, Amara Dunquas, defeated the Christian Alwa Kingdom. The Funj Sultanate began its reign in East Africa during this time.
Funj Sultanate (1504 CE–1820 CE) — East Africa: How did Islam spread in the Funj Sultanate?

The Funj Sultanate saw the early spread of Islam as it was originally accepted by the nobles and sultans. Islam grew in the Funj Sultanate due to Muslim immigrants and scholars that arrived in the sultanate.
Funj Sultanate (1504 CE–1820 CE) — East Africa: What was the significance of Islamic scholars in the Funj Sultanate?
In the Funj Sultanate, Islamic scholars and holy men created Quranic schools, established local saint veneration cults, and established Maliki law, contributing to the growth of Islam in the kingdom.
Funj Sultanate (1504 CE–1820 CE) — East Africa: What was the official language of the Funj Sultanate?

As Islam became the state religion of the Funj Sultanate, Arabic became the official language of the sultanate. The Funj Sultanate adopted Arabic as its official language during its reign in East Africa.
Funj Sultanate (1504 CE–1820 CE) — East Africa: What were the main trades that the Funj Sultanate depended on?
The Funj Sultanate relied heavily on caravan trade and the gold trade. The Funj Sultanate's economy in East Africa was significantly dependent on these trades.
Funj Sultanate (1504 CE–1820 CE) — East Africa: What led to the end of the Funj Sultanate?
The Funj Sultanate formally ended with Egyptian occupation in 1820-21. The Funj Sultanate in East Africa came to an end due to the Egyptian occupation.
Kingdom of Kaffa (1390 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: When was the Kingdom of Kaffa formed in southwest Ethiopia?
The Kingdom of Kaffa was formed in 1390 CE when the Minjo kings of Kaffa took over the throne of the Mato Dynasty and established the kingdom.
Kingdom of Kaffa (1390 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: What was the capital of the Kingdom of Kaffa?
The Kingdom of Kaffa had its capital at Bonga, and later acquired a second capital at Anderacha.
Kingdom of Kaffa (1390 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: What religions were practiced by the people of the Kingdom of Kaffa?
The Kingdom of Kaffa was home to a diverse range of people who practiced Islam, Christianity, and indigenous religions.
Kingdom of Kaffa (1390 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: How was the Kingdom of Kaffa administratively organized?
The Kingdom of Kaffa was divided into eighteen districts which were organized under minor administrative figures.
Kingdom of Kaffa (1390 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: What led to the collapse of the Kingdom of Kaffa in 1897?
The Kingdom of Kaffa finally collapsed in 1897 when the Ethiopian Emperor Menelik II conquered Kaffa territory.
Kingdom of Kaffa (1390 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: What trade networks did the Kingdom of Kaffa establish during the mid-nineteenth century?
The Kingdom of Kaffa established trade networks as far as Gondar in the north of Ethiopia during the mid-nineteenth century.
Kingdom of Gumma (1800 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: Where was the Kingdom of Gumma located?
The Kingdom of Gumma was one of the five Oromo kingdoms located in Western Ethiopia, in the East Africa region.
Kingdom of Gumma (1800 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: What was the capital of the Kingdom of Gumma?
The Kingdom of Gumma had its capital located in Chora.
Kingdom of Gumma (1800 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: What was the nature of the Kingdom of Gumma's political and administrative systems?
The Kingdom of Gumma seemed to be politically and administratively similar to the Kingdom of Jimma, like its neighbouring Oromo kingdoms.
Kingdom of Gumma (1800 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: What religion was predominant in the Kingdom of Gumma?
The Kingdom of Gumma was an Islamic kingdom and was particularly active in Jihadis movements in the second half of the nineteenth century, during the Kingdom of Gumma period.
Kingdom of Gumma (1800 CE–1897 CE) — East Africa: What was the eventual fate of the Kingdom of Gumma?
The Kingdom of Gumma was eventually annexed into the Ethiopian Empire by Menelik II at the turn of the twentieth century, marking the end of the Kingdom of Gumma.
Emirate of Harar (1650 CE–1875 CE) — East Africa: What was the Emirate of Harar the successor of?
The Emirate of Harar was the successor of the Imamate of Aussa. The Emirate of Harar itself was founded by Ali B. Dawud.
Emirate of Harar (1650 CE–1875 CE) — East Africa: Where was the capital of the Emirate of Harar located?
The capital of the Emirate of Harar was Harar, which is one of the holiest cities in the Islamic world and located in East Africa.
Emirate of Harar (1650 CE–1875 CE) — East Africa: What was Harar known for during the time of the Emirate of Harar?
During the time of the Emirate of Harar, Harar was an important Islamic centre for Quranic studies and learning with large numbers of mosques, schools and saint shrines in the city.
Emirate of Harar (1650 CE–1875 CE) — East Africa: What role did the Emirate of Harar play in trade?
The Emirate of Harar was also a pivotal trade centre of Ethiopia, linking the Red Sea and the interior of Ethiopia.
Emirate of Harar (1650 CE–1875 CE) — East Africa: What event officially ended the Emirate of Harar's rule?
The Emirate of Harar was occupied by the Khedivate of Egypt in 1875, officially ending the Emirate of Harar's rule.
Early Sultanate of Aussa (1734 CE–1895 CE) — East Africa: When was the Early Sultanate of Aussa established in East Africa?

The Early Sultanate of Aussa was established during the first half of the eighteenth century in East Africa, succeeding the Imamate of Aussa. The Aussa Sultanate was established by the Mudaito Dynasty of the Asaimara branch of the Danakil clan. The Early Sultanate of Aussa began in 1734.
Early Sultanate of Aussa (1734 CE–1895 CE) — East Africa: What was the peak phase of the Early Sultanate of Aussa in East Africa?

The Early Sultanate of Aussa's peak phase was during the eighteenth century in East Africa, with a decline in the first year of the nineteenth century. The Early Sultanate of Aussa experienced its peak during this time.
Early Sultanate of Aussa (1734 CE–1895 CE) — East Africa: How did the Early Sultanate of Aussa interact with foreign invaders in East Africa?

The Early Sultanate of Aussa fought off foreign invasions in the nineteenth century in East Africa, particularly against the Egyptian invading army in 1875 when the Sultan of Aussa killed Werner Munzinger in battle. The Early Sultanate of Aussa also made pacts with the Italian colonists as Italy expanded its territory in the Horn of Africa.
Early Sultanate of Aussa (1734 CE–1895 CE) — East Africa: What was the result of the agreements between the Early Sultanate of Aussa and Italy in East Africa?

The agreements between the Early Sultanate of Aussa and Italy in East Africa brought mistrust as the Ethiopian government was suspicious of the sultanate, especially during the First Italo-Ethiopian War. The Early Sultanate of Aussa's interactions with Italy led to tension with Ethiopia.
Early Sultanate of Aussa (1734 CE–1895 CE) — East Africa: What is the current status of the Sultanate of Aussa in East Africa?

To this day, there is a Sultan of Aussa, and after World War II, the Sultanate still controlled a moderate amount of influence in the Awash Valley of the Afar region in East Africa. The Early Sultanate of Aussa has continued to the present day.
Isaaq Sultanate (1300 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: Where did the Isaaq Sultanate originate from in the fourteenth century?

The Isaaq Sultanate originated from the Arabian Peninsula with the arrival of Sheikh Isaq, the founder of the Isaaq Somali people, who settled in the northeast coast of Somalia at the town of Mait during the Isaaq Sultanate period in East Africa.
Isaaq Sultanate (1300 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: Who founded the Isaaq Somali people and when did the Isaaq Sultanate roughly begin?
The Isaaq Sultanate roughly began around the fourteenth century with the arrival of Sheikh Isaq, the founder of the Isaaq Somali people, in East Africa during the Isaaq Sultanate period.
Isaaq Sultanate (1300 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: What is still venerated today in the town of Mait in East Africa related to the Isaaq Sultanate?
Sheikh Isaq's domed tomb is still venerated today in the town of Mait in East Africa, which is associated with the Isaaq Sultanate period.
Isaaq Sultanate (1300 CE–1886 CE) — East Africa: In which region did the Isaaq Sultanate primarily exist?
The Isaaq Sultanate primarily existed in East Africa, where Sheikh Isaq settled and founded the Isaaq Somali people during the Isaaq Sultanate period.
Late Formative Yoruba (650 CE–1049 CE) — West Africa: What social configuration emerged during the Late Formative Yoruba period in West Africa?

The Late Formative Yoruba period saw the emergence of a new social configuration featuring formalized association and integration of multiple households under a single leadership, which became the House, or ilé, in Yorùbá terminology, forming the primary basis of Yorùbá social organization.
Late Formative Yoruba (650 CE–1049 CE) — West Africa: How did the social organization of the Late Formative Yoruba period differ from preceding centuries?

The Late Formative Yoruba period marked a departure from the two- to three-generation households and hamlets that had been the preferred unit of social organization in the preceding centuries, with the new configuration being the House, or ilé, under a single leadership.
Late Formative Yoruba (650 CE–1049 CE) — West Africa: What were the key characteristics of an ilé during the Late Formative Yoruba period?

During the Late Formative Yoruba period, an ilé, or House, was characterized by a hierarchy of leadership, shared access to land and other means of production, a common narrative of origin, and shared ritual practices, deities, ancestors, taboos, and metaphysics among its members and units.
Late Formative Yoruba (650 CE–1049 CE) — West Africa: How did the ilé contribute to the organization and safeguarding of land and labor during the Late Formative Yoruba period?

The ilé, or House, contributed to the organization and safeguarding of land and labor during the Late Formative Yoruba period by providing a formalized association and integration of multiple households under a single leadership, allowing for shared access to land and other means of production.
Proto-Yoruboid (300 BCE–300 CE) — West Africa: What characterized the Proto-Yoruboid era in West Africa?

The Proto-Yoruboid era was marked by climatic change and ecological crisis, innovation in technology and social organization, and an unprecedented scale of migration. This period also saw the beginning of the splitting of Proto-Yoruboid into new daughter languages and dialects.
Proto-Yoruboid (300 BCE–300 CE) — West Africa: How did the ecological crisis affect the Proto-Yoruboid people in West Africa?

The ecological crisis of the Archaic period instigated processes of cultural change that launched the Proto-Yoruboid people on the path of sociopolitical and demographic differentiation from several of their proto-Benue-Kwa peers in the confluence area. The Proto-Yoruboid people had to adapt to the new normal of a nine-month dry season in the guinea savanna and the drying up of several water sources.
Proto-Yoruboid (300 BCE–300 CE) — West Africa: What changes occurred in the Proto-Yoruboid community structure during Proto-Yoruboid?

As the ecological crisis worsened, it became more frequent for Proto-Yoruboid communities, households, and individuals to branch off from the older units in search of better living conditions. The Proto-Yoruboid were initially undifferentiated from other confluence language communities in terms of group size, modes of subsistence, and technology.
Proto-Yoruboid (300 BCE–300 CE) — West Africa: What triggered the sociopolitical and demographic differentiation of the Proto-Yoruboid people?

The adjustment to and consequences of the ecological crisis of the Archaic period triggered the sociopolitical and demographic differentiation of the Proto-Yoruboid people from several of their proto-Benue-Kwa peers in the confluence area, marking a significant turning point for the Proto-Yoruboid.
Kingdom of Cayor (1549 CE–1864 CE) — West Africa: When did the Kingdom of Cayor become an independent kingdom in West Africa?
The Kingdom of Cayor became an independent kingdom around 1549 CE, after breaking the confederation with the Jolof Empire, marking the start of its rule as an independent kingdom.
Kingdom of Cayor (1549 CE–1864 CE) — West Africa: What were the main trades that the Kingdom of Cayor was involved in?
The Kingdom of Cayor was largely involved in the slave and horse trades for the Atlantic and Saharan markets, similar to its Wolof neighbours of Waalo.
Kingdom of Cayor (1549 CE–1864 CE) — West Africa: What was the system of government in the Kingdom of Cayor?
The Kingdom of Cayor was monarchical and was ruled by the Damel or king, with the last Damel of Cayor being Lat Dior.
Kingdom of Cayor (1549 CE–1864 CE) — West Africa: What event marked the official end of the Kingdom of Cayor's rule in West Africa?

The Kingdom of Cayor's rule officially ended when the last Damel of Cayor, Lat Dior, led a rebellion against the French and was defeated and exiled in 1864, after which Senegal became a French colony.
Kingdom of Saloum (1490 CE–1863 CE) — West Africa: When did the Kingdom of Saloum originate in West Africa?
The Kingdom of Saloum originated in 1490 CE in West Africa as a Sereer Kingdom.
Kingdom of Saloum (1490 CE–1863 CE) — West Africa: What was the status of the Kingdom of Saloum in relation to the Jolof Empire?
The Kingdom of Saloum was part of the confederation of the Jolof Empire until the mid-sixteenth century when it became an independent kingdom after the breakup of the Jolof Empire.
Kingdom of Saloum (1490 CE–1863 CE) — West Africa: What trade did the Kingdom of Saloum heavily participate in with European powers?
The Kingdom of Saloum heavily participated in the peanut trade with the Dutch, French, and the British.
Kingdom of Saloum (1490 CE–1863 CE) — West Africa: What event led to the end of the traditional rule of the Kingdom of Saloum in 1863?
The Kingdom of Saloum was conquered by the forces of Maba Jakhu Ba who led a jihad, officially ending its traditional rule in 1863.
Kingdom of Sine (1350 CE–1887 CE) — West Africa: When did the Kingdom of Sine originate in West Africa?
The Kingdom of Sine originated in the 1350s CE in West Africa as a Sereer kingdom.
Kingdom of Sine (1350 CE–1887 CE) — West Africa: What was the status of the Kingdom of Sine in relation to the Jolof Empire?
The Kingdom of Sine had been a part of the confederation of the Jolof Empire but became independent in the mid-sixteenth century after the breakup of the Jolof Empire.
Kingdom of Sine (1350 CE–1887 CE) — West Africa: What type of society did the Kingdom of Sine rule over?
The Kingdom of Sine was a monarchy ruling over a complex stratified society.
Kingdom of Sine (1350 CE–1887 CE) — West Africa: Which European countries did the Kingdom of Sine participate in the food trade with?
The Kingdom of Sine participated in the food trade with the Dutch, French, and the British, similar to its Sereer neighbours, the Kingdom of Saloum.
Kingdom of Sine (1350 CE–1887 CE) — West Africa: What was the status of the Kingdom of Sine in 1887 CE?
In 1887 CE, the Kingdom of Sine officially became a French protectorate, ending the Kingdom of Sine's reign.
Kingdom of Waalo (1287 CE–1855 CE) — West Africa: Where did the Kingdom of Waalo originate in 1287 CE?
The Kingdom of Waalo originated on the Senegal River in northern Senegal in West Africa. The Kingdom of Waalo was a subgroup of the Wolof people.
Kingdom of Waalo (1287 CE–1855 CE) — West Africa: What language did the people of the Kingdom of Waalo speak?
The people of the Kingdom of Waalo spoke the Wolof language, as they were a subgroup of the Wolof people.
Kingdom of Waalo (1287 CE–1855 CE) — West Africa: What was the status of the Kingdom of Waalo within the Jolof Empire in the fourteenth century?

The Kingdom of Waalo became a vassal state within the larger Jolof Empire in the fourteenth century, but later broke free from Jolof hegemony in the sixteenth century. The Kingdom of Waalo was then an independent entity.
Kingdom of Waalo (1287 CE–1855 CE) — West Africa: What type of society was the Kingdom of Waalo?

The Kingdom of Waalo was a monarchical society, but it was matrilineal in descent, meaning the children of the king's sister inherited the throne, not the offspring of the ruler, in the Kingdom of Waalo.
Kingdom of Waalo (1287 CE–1855 CE) — West Africa: What was the Kingdom of Waalo's role in the trade market?

The Kingdom of Waalo was a major trade kingdom, particularly in the slave trade, as the Kingdom of Waalo exported many slaves to the French for the Atlantic market, as well as to the western Sahara trade routes linking to north Africa.
Kingdom of Waalo (1287 CE–1855 CE) — West Africa: What led to the collapse of the Kingdom of Waalo in 1855 CE?
The Kingdom of Waalo collapsed in 1855 CE as the French took control over the region in West Africa, marking the end of the Kingdom of Waalo.
Jolof Empire (1360 CE–1549 CE) — West Africa: When did the Jolof Empire grow in influence in West Africa?

The Jolof Empire grew in influence around 1360 CE in West Africa, out of the decline of the Mali Empire, and was a Wolof Kingdom that originated as early as the thirteenth century by the leader Ndiadiane N’Diaye, who founded the Jolof Empire.
Jolof Empire (1360 CE–1549 CE) — West Africa: What was the composition of the Jolof Empire in West Africa?

The Jolof Empire in West Africa created a confederation of five kingdoms which included Waalo, Cayor, Baol, Sine, and Saloum, and all five kingdoms paid tribute and contributed to defensive matters, with the Jolof Empire at the helm.
Jolof Empire (1360 CE–1549 CE) — West Africa: How did the Jolof Empire interact with European traders in West Africa?

The Jolof Empire in West Africa established important trade relations with the Portuguese in the fifteenth century, but competition between European traders and their trading interests caused the Jolof Empire to decline, ultimately leading to its downfall.
Jolof Empire (1360 CE–1549 CE) — West Africa: What led to the decline of the Jolof Empire in West Africa?

The Jolof Empire in West Africa declined due to competition between European traders and their trading interests, which ultimately caused the Empire to break down and split into five independent kingdoms in 1549, after the ruler of Cayor led a rebellion against the Jolof Empire.
Jolof Empire (1360 CE–1549 CE) — West Africa: What was the outcome of the rebellion against the Jolof Empire in West Africa?

The rebellion against the Jolof Empire in West Africa, led by the ruler of Cayor, resulted in the Empire breaking down and splitting into five independent kingdoms in 1549, marking the end of the Jolof Empire.
Imamate of Futa Toro (1776 CE–1860 CE) — West Africa: Where was the Imamate of Futa Toro situated?
The Imamate of Futa Toro was situated along the Senegal River in present-day northern Senegal and southern Mauritania, in the West Africa region, specifically south of the Sahara Desert.
Imamate of Futa Toro (1776 CE–1860 CE) — West Africa: When was the Imamate of Futa Toro first established?

The Imamate of Futa Toro was first established in 1776 CE, when Muslim clerics, also known as torodbe, overthrew the rulers of the Empire of Great Fulo, marking the beginning of the Imamate of Futa Toro.
Imamate of Futa Toro (1776 CE–1860 CE) — West Africa: What type of ruler did the Muslim clerics establish in the Imamate of Futa Toro?
The Muslim clerics established an Imamate with an Almamy or Imam as ruler in the Imamate of Futa Toro.
Imamate of Futa Toro (1776 CE–1860 CE) — West Africa: What happened to the power of the Almamy in the Imamate of Futa Toro during the nineteenth century?
During the beginning of the nineteenth century, the Almamy of the Imamate of Futa Toro began to lose power to elite local aristocracy or chieftains who controlled most of the land in the region.
Imamate of Futa Toro (1776 CE–1860 CE) — West Africa: What event led to the end of the Imamate of Futa Toro in 1860 CE?

The Imamate of Futa Toro ended in 1860 CE when the French took control over the Futa Toro region during the Senegambian Jihad of al-Hajj Umar, as the region was crucial for trade along the Senegal River.
Denyanke Kingdom (1490 CE–1776 CE) — West Africa: When and by whom was the Empire of Great Fulo established in West Africa?
The Empire of Great Fulo was established in 1490 CE by the Fula leader Tengella in West Africa, which later led to the formation of the Denyanke Kingdom.
Denyanke Kingdom (1490 CE–1776 CE) — West Africa: What was the significance of Koli Tengella in the Denyanke Kingdom?

Koli Tengella was significant in the Denyanke Kingdom as all the other Fulo kings were descended from him, and his legacy led to the formation of the Denyanke Dynasty, also known as the Denianke Dynasty, within the Denyanke Kingdom.
Denyanke Kingdom (1490 CE–1776 CE) — West Africa: What role did the Empire of the Great Fulo play in trade in West Africa?
The Empire of the Great Fulo, which included the Denyanke Kingdom, played an important role in the trans-Sahara trade and the slave trade with Europeans in West Africa.
Denyanke Kingdom (1490 CE–1776 CE) — West Africa: What event marked the end of the Denyanke Dynasty in 1776?
The Denyanke Dynasty, part of the Denyanke Kingdom, ended in 1776 when the Empire of the Great Fulo was taken over by the Imamate of Fuuta Tooro.
Denyanke Kingdom (1490 CE–1776 CE) — West Africa: How did the Denyanke Kingdom originate from the Empire of Great Fulo?
The Denyanke Kingdom originated from the Empire of Great Fulo through Koli Tengella's legacy, which formed the Denyanke Dynasty, an essential part of the Denyanke Kingdom in West Africa.
Kingdom of Jolof (1549 CE–1865 CE) — West Africa: What event led to the origin of the Kingdom of Jolof in West Africa?
The Kingdom of Jolof originated after the breakup of the Jolof Empire in 1549, marking the beginning of this Wolof kingdom in West Africa.
Kingdom of Jolof (1549 CE–1865 CE) — West Africa: What was the capital of the Kingdom of Jolof?
The capital of the Kingdom of Jolof was Yangyang, serving as the central location for this West African kingdom.
Kingdom of Jolof (1549 CE–1865 CE) — West Africa: What factor contributed to the decline of the Kingdom of Jolof's importance?

The increase of the Atlantic slave trade led to the decline of the Kingdom of Jolof's importance, as trade became centered around the coastal kingdoms of Waalo, Cayor, Baol, Sine, and Saloum, rather than the landlocked Kingdom of Jolof.
Kingdom of Jolof (1549 CE–1865 CE) — West Africa: What event officially ended the traditional Kingdom of Jolof in the mid-1860s?
The traditional Kingdom of Jolof was officially ended by the Jihadist forces of Maba Jakhu Ba, which ruled the kingdom by the mid-1860s, marking the end of the Kingdom of Jolof.
Pandya Dynasty (590 CE–915 CE) — Southern India: What was the capital of the Pandya Dynasty in Southern India?
The Pandya Dynasty established its capital in Madurai, with its main ports at Kanyakumari, Kottalam, and Sunchindram, during its reign in Southern India.
Pandya Dynasty (590 CE–915 CE) — Southern India: What were some of the key areas supported by the Pandya Dynasty?
The Pandya Dynasty continued its support of education and the building of schools and knowledge centres, and was also a supporter of Shaivist Hindu religion and patrons of different temples.
Pandya Dynasty (590 CE–915 CE) — Southern India: What was the Pandya Dynasty's status as a naval power in Southern India?
The Pandya Dynasty was a naval superpower in the region and made many campaigns against Ceylon, demonstrating its significant maritime influence in Southern India.
Pandya Dynasty (590 CE–915 CE) — Southern India: What event marked the end of the Pandya Dynasty's rule in Southern India?

The Pandya Dynasty's rule in Southern India ended when the Cholas invaded the Pandya region in 915 CE, ruling over the territory for the next thirty years, thus bringing an end to the Pandya Dynasty's reign.
Early Cholas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What were the Early Cholas in Southern India?

The Early Cholas were a northern kingdom in Tamil Nadu and part of the three ruling kingdoms of Early Cholas, Chera and Pandya who ruled over Tamilakam in the late last millennium BCE and early first millennium CE. The Early Cholas had their capital at Uraiyur and their main trading port at Kaveripumpattinam.
Early Cholas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What was the main religion practiced by the Early Cholas in Southern India?
The Early Cholas practiced Hinduism and the Chola king Kochchenganan built 70 temples in honour of Shiva, showcasing the significance of Hinduism during the Early Cholas period.
Early Cholas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What were the trade connections like during the Early Cholas period in Southern India?

The Early Cholas had important trade connections that linked through all of Tamil Nadu and coins from this period also reveal trade links with the Romans, indicating a strong trade network during the Early Cholas period.
Early Cholas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What happened to the Early Cholas kingdom in Southern India in the 3rd century CE?

The Early Cholas kingdom declined sometime in the 3rd century CE, and was succeeded by the Kalabhra dynasty, marking the end of the Early Cholas period along with the decline of the Chera and Pandya kingdoms.
Early Cholas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: Where was the capital and main trading port of the Early Cholas located?
The Early Cholas had their capital at Uraiyur and their main trading port at Kaveripumpattinam, which were significant locations during the Early Cholas period in Southern India.
Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom (1675 CE–1799 CE) — Southern India: When was the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom established in Southern India?

The Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom was established in 1675 CE when the Maratha general Ekoji Bhonsle took control of Thanjavur and crowned himself Raja of the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom, marking the beginning of the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom in Southern India.
Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom (1675 CE–1799 CE) — Southern India: What was the capital of the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom?
The capital of the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom was the city of Thanjavur, serving as the central location of the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom in Southern India.
Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom (1675 CE–1799 CE) — Southern India: What were the religious beliefs of the Thanjavur Maratha kings?
The Thanjavur Maratha kings were devout Shaivist Hindus, and as such, the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom was influenced by these religious beliefs.
Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom (1675 CE–1799 CE) — Southern India: How did the Thanjavur Maratha kings contribute to the cultural landscape?
The Thanjavur Maratha kings contributed greatly to literature and philosophic thought, and also patronized temple projects, showcasing the cultural significance of the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom.
Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom (1675 CE–1799 CE) — Southern India: What was the fate of the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom by the end of the 18th century?
In 1799 CE, the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom came under the Madras Presidency under the British East India Company, marking the end of the Thanjavur Maratha Kingdom's independence in Southern India.
Early Pandyas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: Where was the Early Pandyas kingdom located?
The Early Pandyas kingdom was located in Southern India, specifically in Tamil Nadu, as part of the region of Tamilakam.
Early Pandyas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What were the main cities of the Early Pandyas kingdom?
The Early Pandyas had their capital at Madurai and their main port at Korkai.
Early Pandyas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What was the significance of the Early Pandyas in Tamil literature and education?

The Early Pandyas were founders and supporters of the great Tamil literary and educational academies called ‘Sangam’, which is where the Sangam Age or Period originates from, during the Early Pandyas period.
Early Pandyas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What were the dominant religions in the Early Pandyas kingdom?
The Early Pandyas were Hindu Shiavists, but Jainism and Buddhism were also present within the Early Pandyas kingdom.
Early Pandyas (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What happened to the Early Pandyas kingdom by the 3rd century CE?
By the 3rd century CE, the Early Pandyas, along with the other two ruling Sangam kingdoms, became feudatories to the Kalabhra Dynasty.
Carnatic Sultanate (1710 CE–1801 CE) — Southern India: When and how did the Carnatic Sultanate originate in Southern India?

The Carnatic Sultanate originated in 1710 CE as a vassal state of the Mughal Empire in Southern India, with the Navaiyat dynasty under Saadutullah Khan becoming the first nawab of the Carnatic Sultanate.
Carnatic Sultanate (1710 CE–1801 CE) — Southern India: What was the capital of the Carnatic Sultanate?
The Carnatic Sultanate had its capital at Arcot.
Carnatic Sultanate (1710 CE–1801 CE) — Southern India: What was the primary religion practiced by the Carnatic nawabs?
The Carnatic nawabs practiced Sufi Islam, and their court language was Persian, during the Carnatic Sultanate period.
Carnatic Sultanate (1710 CE–1801 CE) — Southern India: What were some of the contributions of the Carnatic Sultanate?
The Carnatic Sultanate contributed to the building of mosques, Hindu temples, and educational centres, showcasing the diverse contributions of the Carnatic Sultanate.
Carnatic Sultanate (1710 CE–1801 CE) — Southern India: What was the fate of the Carnatic Sultanate by the nineteenth century?

By the turn of the nineteenth century, the British East India Company took control of the entire Carnatic region, and the Carnatic Sultanate continued to survive until 1855 CE as dependents of the British rule, with the Carnatic Sultanate nawabs remaining in place.
Late Pallava Empire (300 CE–890 CE) — Southern India: Where did the Late Pallava Empire originate in Southern India?
The Late Pallava Empire originated in the northern Tamil Nadu region in Southern India. The Pallavan capital was at Kanchi, modern-day Kanchipuram, during this time.
Late Pallava Empire (300 CE–890 CE) — Southern India: What were the Pallava rulers known for in the Late Pallava Empire?
The Pallava rulers of the Late Pallava Empire were major benefactors of education and gave land grants for schools.
Late Pallava Empire (300 CE–890 CE) — Southern India: How did the Late Pallava Empire contribute to art and architecture in Southern India?
The Late Pallava Empire contributed to art and architecture by commissioning temples and shrines, particularly in the port city of Mamallapuram.
Late Pallava Empire (300 CE–890 CE) — Southern India: What happened to the Late Pallava Empire in the late 9th century?
In the late 9th century, the Late Pallava Empire was succeeded by the Chola Empire.
Kalabhra Dynasty (200 CE–600 CE) — Southern India: When did the Kalabhra Dynasty rule in Southern India?
The Kalabhra Dynasty ruled from the 3rd century CE to the late 6th or early 7th centuries CE in the Tamil Nadu region of southern India, which is the home region of the Kalabhra Dynasty.
Kalabhra Dynasty (200 CE–600 CE) — Southern India: What is the Kalabhra Dynasty period also known as in Tamil history?
The period of Kalabhra Dynasty rule is also known as the Kalabhra Interregnum and is considered the ‘Dark Age’ of Tamil history, which occurred during the Kalabhra Dynasty.
Kalabhra Dynasty (200 CE–600 CE) — Southern India: Where were the capitals of the Kalabhra Dynasty located?
The Kalabhra Dynasty had its first capital in Kaveripumpattinam and its final capital in Madurai, both of which were part of the Kalabhra Dynasty's territory in Southern India.
Kalabhra Dynasty (200 CE–600 CE) — Southern India: Which religions did the Kalabhra Dynasty promote?
The Kalabhra Dynasty promoted the Buddhist and Jain religions, and the Kalabhra Dynasty may have been less favourable to the Brahmanical religion during its rule.
Kalabhra Dynasty (200 CE–600 CE) — Southern India: Who took over the Kalabhra Dynasty by the end of the 6th or early 7th centuries?
The Kalabhra Dynasty was taken over by the kingdoms of Pandyas and Pallavas of south and north Tamil by the end of the 6th or early 7th centuries, marking the end of the Kalabhra Dynasty's rule.
Nayaks of Thanjavur (1532 CE–1676 CE) — Southern India: Who did the Nayaks of Thanjavur originally rule on behalf of in the Tamil Nadu region of Thanjavur?

The Nayaks of Thanjavur originally ruled the Tamil Nadu region of Thanjavur on behalf of the Vijayanagara kings. The Nayaks of Thanjavur became independent rulers sometime in the 1530s CE after the decline of the Vijayanagara.
Nayaks of Thanjavur (1532 CE–1676 CE) — Southern India: What was the capital city of the Nayaks of Thanjavur?
The Nayaks of Thanjavur had their capital in the city of Thanjavur. The Nayaks of Thanjavur also had a major commercial port at Nagaputtinam.
Nayaks of Thanjavur (1532 CE–1676 CE) — Southern India: With which foreign powers did the Nayaks of Thanjavur have trade connections?

The Nayaks of Thanjavur had valuable trade connections with the Dutch and the British. The Nayaks of Thanjavur imposed taxes on the import and export of foreign goods as part of these trade connections.
Nayaks of Thanjavur (1532 CE–1676 CE) — Southern India: How were trade agreements between the Nayaks of Thanjavur and foreign powers recorded?

Trade agreements between the Nayaks of Thanjavur and the Dutch and British were recorded on various inscriptions, giving insight into the particulars of these arrangements. The Nayaks of Thanjavur had these trade agreements in place during their rule.
Nayaks of Thanjavur (1532 CE–1676 CE) — Southern India: What event marked the end of the rule of the Nayaks of Thanjavur in the 1670s?

The rule of the Nayaks of Thanjavur lasted until the 1670s when the Nayaks of Maduri overthrew the last Thanjavur nayak, ending the Nayaks of Thanjavur rule. The Nayaks of Thanjavur were eventually succeeded by the Maratha rulers after a brief period of rule by the Nayaks of Maduri.
Nayaks of Madurai (1529 CE–1736 CE) — Southern India: When did the Nayaks of Madurai become independent rulers under Visvanatha Nayaka?
The Nayaks of Madurai became independent rulers under Visvanatha Nayaka around 1529 CE. This marked the beginning of the Nayaks of Madurai as a distinct ruling power in Southern India.
Nayaks of Madurai (1529 CE–1736 CE) — Southern India: What was the initial capital of the Nayaks of Madurai?
The Nayaks of Madurai had their initial capital at Madurai. The Nayaks of Madurai were rulers of South Tamil Nadu, with Madurai as their primary seat of power.
Nayaks of Madurai (1529 CE–1736 CE) — Southern India: Who was responsible for the expansion of the Minaksi-Sundaresvara temple in the capital?

The Nayaks of Madurai, particularly under Tirumala Nayaka, were responsible for the expansion of the Minaksi-Sundaresvara temple in the capital. The Nayaks of Madurai were patrons of temple constructions and celebrated many religious festivals within their temple complexes.
Nayaks of Madurai (1529 CE–1736 CE) — Southern India: What was the religious affiliation of the Nayaks of Madurai?
The Nayaks of Madurai were Shaivist Hindus. As Shaivist Hindus, the Nayaks of Madurai celebrated many religious festivals within their temple complexes, showcasing their strong religious roots.
Nayaks of Madurai (1529 CE–1736 CE) — Southern India: What trade connections did the Nayaks of Madurai have?

The Nayaks of Madurai were lucrative in trade, connecting with the Dutch East Indian Company and the Portuguese. This highlights the Nayaks of Madurai's significant involvement in international trade and commerce.
Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty (919 CE–1125 CE) — Central Europe: What united the countries of the Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty in Central Europe?
The Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty was united by the Catholic faith, under the twin leadership of the papacy and an emperor, the ‘Defender of the Roman Catholic Faith’.
Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty (919 CE–1125 CE) — Central Europe: What was the nature of the Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty's governance in Central?
The Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty did not have centralized governance, but was a confederation of constituent polities, with no common laws, language, or customs.
Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty (919 CE–1125 CE) — Central Europe: Which region emerged as the core of the Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty?
The Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty had Germany and its kings as its core region, with German kings consistently crowned as the Holy Roman Emperor by 1030.
Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty (919 CE–1125 CE) — Central Europe: What characterized the Ottonian period of the Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty?

The Ottonian period of the Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty was generally characterized by internal peace and territorial expansion, and is considered one of the three medieval renaissances.
Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty (919 CE–1125 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty transition from the Ottonian to the?

The Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty passed from the Ottonian to the Salian dynasty when the last Ottonian emperor, Henry II, died childless, and the imperial princes elected Conrad II as emperor.
Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty (919 CE–1125 CE) — Central Europe: What marked the end of the Salian rule in the Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty?
The Salian rule in the Holy Roman Empire - Ottonian-Salian Dynasty ended with the death of the last Salian emperor, Henry V, in 1125, after which the empire passed to the Hohenstaufen dynasty.
East Francia (842 CE–919 CE) — Central Europe: What event in 843 marked the beginning of East Francia as a distinct entity in Central Europe?
The Treaty of Verdun in 843 marked the beginning of East Francia as a distinct entity, comprising the lands that are now Germany, along with parts of Austria and Italy, in Central Europe.
East Francia (842 CE–919 CE) — Central Europe: Who became the first ruler of East Francia after the Treaty of Verdun?
East Francia's first ruler was Louis the German, one of Charlemagne's grandsons, who played a crucial role in shaping the kingdom.
East Francia (842 CE–919 CE) — Central Europe: What challenges did the Carolingian legacy of centralized rule face in East Francia?

The Carolingian legacy of centralized rule in East Francia faced challenges due to the strong local powers of the dukes and the ongoing threat of external invasions, particularly from the Vikings and Slavic tribes, during the East Francia period.
East Francia (842 CE–919 CE) — Central Europe: What cultural institutions were inherited by East Francia from the unified Carolingian Empire?

East Francia inherited administrative and cultural institutions from the unified Carolingian Empire, including the use of the Carolingian minuscule in writing, the promotion of Christian monasticism, and the Carolingian Renaissance's intellectual and artistic endeavors.
East Francia (842 CE–919 CE) — Central Europe: What event in 911 marked the end of Carolingian rule in East Francia?

The death of Louis the Child in 911, the last Carolingian ruler of East Francia, marked the end of Carolingian rule in the region, leading to the election of Conrad I of the Franconian dynasty as king and signaling a shift in the political landscape of East Francia.
Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties (1126 CE–1254 CE) — Central Europe: What characterized the Holy Roman Empire during the Hohenstaufen and Welf dynasties in?

The Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties was characterized by significant internal strife and expansion, with an ongoing competition between the House of Welf and the Hohenstaufen dynasty influencing the Empire's internal dynamics.
Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties (1126 CE–1254 CE) — Central Europe: What was the cause of the intra-elite conflict that followed the death of Henry V in?

The Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties began after the death of the last Salian emperor, Henry V, in 1125, who had no heirs, leading to a period of intra-elite conflict with rival factions supporting the Saxon noble Lothair III and Conrad III, of the Hohenstaufen dynasty.
Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties (1126 CE–1254 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Hohenstaufen dynasty's control over the Empire's territories differ from?

The Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties faced challenges in asserting their control over the Empire's semi-autonomous territories, unlike the Ottonian and Salian rulers who preceded them, with the lack of a central capital and unified legal system continuing to characterize the Empire.
Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties (1126 CE–1254 CE) — Central Europe: What role did the House of Welf play in the Holy Roman Empire during the Hohenstaufen?

The Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties saw the House of Welf emerge as formidable contenders to Hohenstaufen authority, wielding significant influence and territorial control, particularly in Saxony and Bavaria.
Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties (1126 CE–1254 CE) — Central Europe: What were some notable events and achievements during the reign of Frederick I?

The Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties included the reign of Frederick I Barbarossa, who made efforts to assert imperial authority in Italy, leading to prolonged conflicts with the Lombard League and the Papacy, and also participated in the Crusades to expand Christendom and enhance imperial prestige.
Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties (1126 CE–1254 CE) — Central Europe: What were some notable characteristics of Frederick II's reign in the Holy Roman Empire?

Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties (1126 CE–1254 CE) — Central Europe: What was the outcome of the death of Frederick II and the subsequent demise of his?

The Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen and Welf Dynasties came to an end with the death of Frederick II and the subsequent demise of his heirs, leading to the Interregnum, a period of significant political fragmentation and decline in imperial power, with the rise of princely states and the increasing irrelevance of the imperial title.
Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period (1255 CE–1453 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period begin in Central Europe?

Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period (1255 CE–1453 CE) — Central Europe: What was the impact of the election of Rudolf I of Habsburg in 1273 on the Holy Roman Empire -?

Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period (1255 CE–1453 CE) — Central Europe: What was the nature of the struggle between the Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period and the Papacy?

Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period (1255 CE–1453 CE) — Central Europe: What significant event occurred in 1356 during the Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period?

Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period (1255 CE–1453 CE) — Central Europe: What external pressure did the Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period face in the late medieval period?

Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period (1255 CE–1453 CE) — Central Europe: What was the impact of the rise of the Hanseatic League on the Holy Roman Empire - Fragmented Period?

Electorate of Brandenburg (1415 CE–1618 CE) — Central Europe: What significant developments occurred in the Electorate of Brandenburg from 1415 to 1618 in Central Europe?

Electorate of Brandenburg (1415 CE–1618 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Hohenzollern era in the Electorate of Brandenburg begin?

Electorate of Brandenburg (1415 CE–1618 CE) — Central Europe: What were the key achievements of Frederick II Elector of the Electorate of Brandenburg?

Electorate of Brandenburg (1415 CE–1618 CE) — Central Europe: What significant religious shift occurred in the Electorate of Brandenburg under Elector Joachim II?

Electorate of Brandenburg (1415 CE–1618 CE) — Central Europe: What marked the beginning of the Electorate of Brandenburg's expansion into the Duchy of Prussia?

Brandenburg-Prussia (1618 CE–1870 CE) — Central Europe: What marked the beginning of the Brandenburg-Prussia period in Central Europe?

Brandenburg-Prussia (1618 CE–1870 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Peace of Westphalia impact Brandenburg-Prussia in Central Europe?

Brandenburg-Prussia (1618 CE–1870 CE) — Central Europe: What reforms did the 'Great Elector' Frederick William implement in Brandenburg-Prussia?

Brandenburg-Prussia (1618 CE–1870 CE) — Central Europe: What was the significance of Frederick III's coronation as King Frederick I in Prussia for Brandenburg-Prussia?

Brandenburg-Prussia (1618 CE–1870 CE) — Central Europe: How did the leadership of Frederick William I and Frederick the Great impact Brandenburg-Prussia?

Brandenburg-Prussia (1618 CE–1870 CE) — Central Europe: What were the key outcomes of the Napoleonic Wars and the Congress of Vienna for Brandenburg-Prussia?

Brandenburg-Prussia (1618 CE–1870 CE) — Central Europe: How did the revolutions of 1848 impact Brandenburg-Prussia?

Brandenburg-Prussia (1618 CE–1870 CE) — Central Europe: What was the culmination of Brandenburg-Prussia's rise to power in Central Europe?

Electorate of Bavaria (1623 CE–1806 CE) — Central Europe: Who held substantial autonomous power within the Electorate of Bavaria?

The Elector, a title granted by the Emperor, held substantial autonomous power within the Electorate of Bavaria, managing internal affairs, laws, and customs, distinct from the broader imperial structure. The Electorate of Bavaria was under the rule of the Wittelsbach dynasty during this period.
Electorate of Bavaria (1623 CE–1806 CE) — Central Europe: What role did the Catholic faith play in the Electorate of Bavaria?

Electorate of Bavaria (1623 CE–1806 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Thirty Years' War impact the status of the Electorate of Bavaria?

Electorate of Bavaria (1623 CE–1806 CE) — Central Europe: What led to the end of the Electorate of Bavaria?

Electorate of Bavaria (1623 CE–1806 CE) — Central Europe: In which war did the Electorate of Bavaria participate under Karl Albrecht's leadership?

The Electorate of Bavaria took part in the War of the Austrian Succession, with Karl Albrecht, Elector of Bavaria, making demands on behalf of his wife Maria Amalie, the youngest daughter of Joseph I, although they withdrew from the war in 1745 after suffering defeats at the hand of the Habsburgs.
Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction (1198 CE–1215 CE) — Central Europe: What event in 1197 led to a succession crisis in the Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction in?

Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction (1198 CE–1215 CE) — Central Europe: Who were the two individuals elected in 1198 to lead the Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction?

Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction (1198 CE–1215 CE) — Central Europe: What symbols of legitimate imperial authority did Philip of Swabia possess to bolster his claim?

Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction (1198 CE–1215 CE) — Central Europe: Which regions and groups supported the Hohenstaufen Faction under Philip's leadership in the Holy?

Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction (1198 CE–1215 CE) — Central Europe: What event in 1208 marked a critical point for the Hohenstaufen Faction in the Holy Roman Empire?

Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction (1198 CE–1215 CE) — Central Europe: Who eventually rose to lead the Hohenstaufen Faction after Philip's assassination in the Holy?

Holy Roman Empire - Hohenstaufen Faction (1198 CE–1215 CE) — Central Europe: What event in 1215 symbolically concluded the factional dispute in the Holy Roman Empire -?

Polish Kingdom - Piast Dynasty Fragmented Period (1139 CE–1382 CE) — Central Europe: What happened to the Polish Kingdom after Bolesław III Wrymouth's death in 1138?

Polish Kingdom - Piast Dynasty Fragmented Period (1139 CE–1382 CE) — Central Europe: What was the Senioral Principle established by Bolesław III Wrymouth's will?

The Polish Kingdom - Piast Dynasty Fragmented Period was initially guided by the Senioral Principle, which established that the eldest member of the dynasty, holding the Seniorate Province with Kraków as its capital, would have a primacy over the other dukes and the right to be called the High Duke of Poland, thus attempting to maintain unity within the Polish Kingdom - Piast Dynasty Fragmented Period.
Polish Kingdom - Piast Dynasty Fragmented Period (1139 CE–1382 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Polish Kingdom - Piast Dynasty Fragmented Period end?

Polish Kingdom - Piast Dynasty Fragmented Period (1139 CE–1382 CE) — Central Europe: What significant internal development occurred during Casimir III the Great's reign in?

Polish Kingdom - Piast Dynasty Fragmented Period (1139 CE–1382 CE) — Central Europe: What happened to the Piast dynasty after Casimir III's death in 1370?

Hungary Kingdom - Árpád Dynasty (1000 CE–1301 CE) — Central Europe: What role did the Árpád dynasty play in the Kingdom of Hungary during the Hungary Kingdom - Árpád Dynasty?

Hungary Kingdom - Árpád Dynasty (1000 CE–1301 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Kingdom of Hungary transform during the Hungary Kingdom - Árpád Dynasty period in Central?

Hungary Kingdom - Árpád Dynasty (1000 CE–1301 CE) — Central Europe: What was the significance of the coronation of Saint Stephen I during the Hungary Kingdom - Árpád Dynasty?

Hungary Kingdom - Árpád Dynasty (1000 CE–1301 CE) — Central Europe: What was the impact of the alliance with the Roman Catholic Church on the Kingdom of Hungary during the?

Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties (1302 CE–1526 CE) — Central Europe: What marked the beginning of the Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties period in Central?

Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties (1302 CE–1526 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Angevin kings impact Hungary's influence in Central Europe during the Hungary?

Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties (1302 CE–1526 CE) — Central Europe: What was the significance of Sigismund of Luxembourg's rule during the Hungary Kingdom - Anjou?

Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties (1302 CE–1526 CE) — Central Europe: What challenges did the Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties face in Central Europe?

The Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties in Central Europe faced challenges such as internal strife and the looming threat of Ottoman conquest, which significantly impacted the kingdom's stability and security.
Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties (1302 CE–1526 CE) — Central Europe: How did the Hungary Kingdom - Anjou and Later Dynasties period conclude in Central Europe?

Brythonic Kingdoms (410 CE–1283 CE) — Western Europe: What were the Brythonic Kingdoms?

The Brythonic Kingdoms were Brythonic-speaking kingdoms that emerged in western Britain and Brittany after the withdrawal of the Roman Empire in the early fifth century. The Brythonic Kingdoms persisted in some form until the final conquest of Wales by Edward I of England in 1283.
Brythonic Kingdoms (410 CE–1283 CE) — Western Europe: When did the Brythonic Kingdoms emerge?
The Brythonic Kingdoms emerged in western Britain and Brittany after the withdrawal of the Roman Empire in the early fifth century, referring to the Brythonic Kingdoms period.

The Brythonic Kingdoms were located in western Britain and Brittany, referring to the Brythonic Kingdoms in Western Europe.
Brythonic Kingdoms (410 CE–1283 CE) — Western Europe: How long did the Brythonic Kingdoms persist?

Viking settlements (793 CE–1000 CE) — Northern Europe: What geographic areas did the Viking settlements cover in Northern Europe?

The Viking settlements covered Norse settlements in Scandinavia, Iceland, Greenland, Newfoundland, the Baltic, Russia, Scotland, Ireland, and northern France, referring to the Viking settlements period.

Early Cheras (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: Where did the Early Cheras rule?
The Early Cheras ruled over the western coast of southern India, specifically in the region of modern-day Kerala, during their period.
Early Cheras (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: What kingdoms co-ruled with the Early Cheras in Tamilakam?

The Early Cheras were one of the three ruling kingdoms, along with the Early Cholas and Pandyas, who ruled over Tamilakam in the late last millennium BCE and early first millennium CE, during the time of the Early Cheras.
Early Cheras (300 BCE–300 CE) — Southern India: When did the Early Cheras, Early Cholas, and Pandyas rule over Tamilakam?

Which empires and dynasties ruled Algeria before French colonization?

Algeria was ruled by many empires and dynasties, including the Numidians, Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Romans, Vandals, Byzantines, numerous Arab and Amazigh dynasties, Spaniards, and the Ottoman Turks.
How did the French conquest of Algeria unfold?
France captured Algiers in 1830 and expanded its control over Algeria throughout the 19th century, with the conquest marked by widespread violence and atrocities.
When did Algeria gain independence and what role did the National Liberation Front play?
Algeria gained independence in 1962 after an eight-year war, and the National Liberation Front, founded in 1954, emerged as the country’s dominant political force.
Why did the Algerian military intervene in the 1991 legislative elections?
The Algerian military intervened after the Islamic Salvation Front achieved unexpected success in the first round of the 1991 elections, fearing the establishment of an extremist-led government.
What was the outcome of the insurgency and violence in Algeria during the 1990s?
Violence between 1992 and 1998 resulted in more than 100,000 deaths, and by the late 1990s the government regained control as the Islamic Salvation Army disbanded in 2000.
Who led Algeria from 1999 to 2019?
