Abdelaziz Bouteflika became president in 1999 with military backing and remained in office until his resignation in 2019.
What led to Abdelaziz Bouteflika’s resignation in 2019?
Widespread protests erupted after Abdelaziz Bouteflika announced plans to seek a fifth term, leading to his resignation in April 2019.
Who was elected president of Algeria in December 2019?
Algerians elected former prime minister Abdelmadjid Tebboune as president in December 2019.
What reforms were introduced under President Abdelmadjid Tebboune?
President Abdelmadjid Tebboune enacted constitutional and electoral reforms in 2021, including open-list voting and the removal of gender quotas in parliament.
Which peoples first settled the area of modern Angola?
Bantu-speaking peoples settled the area now known as Angola beginning in the 6th century A.D.
What were the major precolonial kingdoms in Angola?
By the 10th century, several Bantu kingdoms had formed in Angola, including the powerful Kingdom of Kongo and its rival, the Kingdom of Ndongo.
How did Portugal establish influence in Angola?
Portugal began establishing coastal colonies and trading posts in Angola in the 16th century and introduced Christianity to the region.
What role did Angola play in the Atlantic slave trade?
Angola became a major hub of the transatlantic slave trade, resulting in the loss of millions of people from the region.
Who was Queen Nzingha Mbande and why was she significant?
Queen Nzingha Mbande was a 17th-century ruler of Ndongo who resisted Portuguese expansion and ruled for nearly four decades.
How did Portuguese colonial control expand in Angola?
Portugal consolidated control over Angola in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, abolishing the Kingdom of Kongo after a revolt in 1914.
When did Angola gain independence from Portugal?
Angola gained independence in 1975 following the collapse of Portugal’s dictatorship.
What caused Angola’s civil war after independence?
After independence, rival movements including the MPLA and UNITA fought for power, leading to a prolonged civil war.
How did the Cold War affect Angola’s civil war?
Angola’s civil war became a Cold War proxy conflict, with the Soviet Union and Cuba supporting the MPLA and the United States and South Africa supporting UNITA.
How did Angola’s civil war end?
The civil war ended in 2002 after the death of UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi, solidifying MPLA control.
What political changes affected Botswana in the early 19th century?
In the early 1800s, conflicts and population movements disrupted political entities in the region that is now Botswana.
Which ethnic group became dominant in Botswana during this period?
The Tswana ethnic group became the most prominent group in Botswana by the mid-19th century.
How did Botswana resist Afrikaner expansion?
In 1852, Tswana forces halted the northward expansion of Afrikaner settlers into what is now Botswana.
When did Britain establish control over Botswana?
Great Britain established the Bechuanaland Protectorate in 1885 over territory corresponding to modern Botswana.
When did Botswana gain independence?
Botswana gained independence in 1966 and adopted its current name, meaning land of the Tswana.
How has Botswana’s political system developed since independence?
Botswana has experienced uninterrupted civilian rule and regular elections since independence, forming a stable democracy.
Which party has governed Botswana since independence?
The Botswana Democratic Party has won every national election since Botswana gained independence.
Who became president of Botswana in 2018?
Mokgweetsi Masisi became president of Botswana in 2018 and won election in his own right in 2019.
What ethnic diversity characterizes modern Benin?
Benin is home to about 42 ethnic groups, including the Yoruba, Fon, Bariba, Dendi, and several others who migrated to the region over centuries.
What was the Kingdom of Dahomey?
The Kingdom of Dahomey emerged in the 17th century in southern Benin and became a major regional power.
How was Dahomey connected to the Atlantic slave trade?
The Kingdom of Dahomey became a major source of enslaved people during the Atlantic slave trade.
How did France colonize Benin?
France gradually took control of Dahomey in the late 19th century and completed its conquest by 1894.
When did Benin gain independence?
French Dahomey gained independence in 1960 and was later renamed the Republic of Benin in 1975.
What political system did Benin adopt in the 1970s?
In 1972, Mathieu Kerekou established a Marxist-Leninist government in Benin after a military takeover.
When did Benin begin democratic reforms?
Benin began transitioning to representative government in 1989, leading to free elections in 1991.
Why was the 1991 election in Benin historically important?
The 1991 election marked Africa’s first peaceful transfer of power from a dictatorship to a democracy.
How has Benin’s political environment changed since 2016?
Since 2016, Benin has seen a narrowing of political pluralism and free expression under President Patrice Talon.
What were the two major ethnic groups in pre-colonial Burundi?

Burundi had two major ethnic groups, the majority Hutu and minority Tutsi, who shared a common language and culture and largely lived in peaceful cohabitation under Tutsi monarchs in pre-colonial Burundi.
How did German and Belgian colonial rule affect the monarchy in Burundi?

German colonial rule in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and Belgian rule after World War I preserved Burundi’s monarchy, with Belgian colonial officials reducing the number of chiefdoms and eliminating most Hutu chiefs from positions of power in Burundi.
What event triggered increased political competition in Burundi in 1961?

The murder of the Burundian Tutsi king’s oldest son, Louis Rwagasore, by a competing political faction shortly before he was set to become prime minister triggered increased political competition in Burundi.
How did Burundi gain Burundi's independence from Belgium?
Burundi gained its independence from Belgium in 1962 as the Kingdom of Burundi.
What was the outcome of the Hutu rebellion in 1972 in Burundi?

The Hutu rebellion in 1972 in Burundi resulted in the deaths of several thousand Tutsi civilians and sparked brutal Tutsi-led military reprisals against Hutu civilians which ultimately killed 100,000-200,000 people in Burundi.
What led to a new constitution and democratic elections in Burundi in 1992 and 1993?
International pressure led to a new constitution in 1992 and democratic elections in 1993 in Burundi.
What event sparked a civil war in Burundi in 1993?

Tutsi military officers feared Hutu domination and assassinated Burundi's first democratically elected president, Hutu Melchior Ndadaye, in 1993 after only 100 days in office, sparking a civil war in Burundi.
How did the Arusha Agreement affect the civil war in Burundi?
The internationally brokered Arusha Agreement, signed in 2000, and subsequent cease-fire agreements with armed movements ended the 1993-2005 civil war in Burundi.
What was the main focus of the powerful states that controlled the Sahelian belt in Chad starting around the 9th century?

The powerful states that controlled the Sahelian belt in Chad focused on controlling trans-Saharan trade routes and profited mostly from the slave trade, with the Kanem-Bornu Empire being a prominent example in Chad.
What was the extent of the Kanem-Bornu Empire's territory in Chad and surrounding regions?

The Kanem-Bornu Empire in Chad controlled territory stretching from southern Chad to southern Libya and included portions of modern-day Algeria, Cameroon, Niger, Nigeria, and Sudan, with its center around the Lake Chad Basin in Chad.
How did France establish control over Chad?

France began moving into the region of Chad in the late 1880s and defeated the Bagirmi kingdom in 1897, Rabih Az-Zubayr in 1900, and the Ouddai kingdom in 1909, eventually incorporating Chad into French Equatorial Africa by 1910, which included the northern arid region, the Lake Chad Basin, and southeastern Chad.
What significant event occurred in Chad in 1960?
Chad achieved its independence in 1960, marking a significant turning point in the country's history, after being part of French Equatorial Africa, which included Chad.
How did Chad expel Libyan forces during the 'Toyota War'?

Chadian leaders, with the help of the French military and several African countries, expelled Libyan forces during the 1987 'Toyota War' in Chad, so named for the use of Toyota pickup trucks as fighting vehicles, which took place in Chad.
What has been the impact of terrorist-led insurgencies on Chad?

Chad has faced widespread poverty, an economy severely weakened by volatile international oil prices, and terrorist-led insurgencies in the Lake Chad Basin, with groups like Boko Haram, now known as ISIS-West Africa, conducting attacks in Chad, including bombings in N'Djamena, and the army suffering heavy losses in Chad.
What steps has the transitional government in Chad taken towards holding democratic elections?

The transitional authorities in Chad, led by Mahamat Idriss Deby, have announced plans to hold elections by October 2024, following a national dialogue in August-October 2022, and have held a constitutional referendum in December 2023, in which 86 percent of votes were in favor of the new constitution in Chad.
What challenges has the Chadian government faced in recent years?

The Chadian government has faced challenges such as widespread poverty, a weakened economy, terrorist-led insurgencies in the Lake Chad Basin, and several waves of rebellions in northern and eastern Chad, prompting the declaration of states of emergency in various regions of Chad.
What was the name of the Republic of the Congo from 1968 to 1992 in Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)?

The Republic of the Congo was named the People’s Republic of the Congo from 1968 to 1992, after which the country reverted to its original name, the Republic of the Congo. (Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)).
When did the Republic of the Congo abandon Marxism in Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)?

The Republic of the Congo abandoned a quarter-century of experimentation with Marxism in 1990, and a democratically elected government took office in 1992 in the Republic of the Congo. (Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)).
What event restored former President Denis SASSOU-Nguesso to power in the Republic of the Congo in Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)?

A two-year civil war that ended in 1999 restored to power former President Denis Sassou-Nguesso in the Republic of the Congo, who had previously ruled the Republic of the Congo from 1979 to 1992. (Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)).
When did the Republic of the Congo adopt a new constitution providing for a multi-party system in Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)?

The Republic of the Congo adopted a new constitution providing for a multi-party system and a seven-year presidential term three years after the end of the civil war in the Republic of the Congo. (Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)).
What is a notable economic feature of the Republic of the Congo in Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)?
The Republic of the Congo is one of Africa's largest petroleum producers, with the Republic of the Congo having significant oil resources. (Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)).
When was President Denis SASSOU-Nguesso reelected in the Republic of the Congo for the third and fourth times in Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)?

President Denis Sassou-Nguesso was reelected in the Republic of the Congo in 2009, 2016, and 2021, after passing a constitutional referendum allowing him to run for additional terms in the Republic of the Congo. (Republic of the Congo (Brazzaville)).
What was the demographic makeup of the territory that is now the Democratic Republic of the Congo before European invasion?

The Democratic Republic of the Congo has more than 200 ethnic groups that trace their histories to many communal organizations and kingdoms, including the Kingdom of Kongo, the Kingdoms of Luba and Lunda, and other notable political groupings in the territory.
How did European prospectors affect the kingdoms in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the late 1800s?

European prospectors in the Democratic Republic of the Congo invaded and splintered the kingdoms in the late 1800’s, sponsored by King Leopold II of Belgium, and the kingdoms were eventually forced to grant Leopold the rights to the Democratic Republic of the Congo territory as his private property.
What was the result of the Congo Free State period for the people of the Democratic Republic of the Congo?
From 1885 to 1908, millions of people in the Democratic Republic of the Congo died as a result of disease and inhumane treatment during the period known as the Congo Free State.
How did the Democratic Republic of the Congo gain independence from Belgium?
The Republic of the Congo, now the Democratic Republic of the Congo, gained its independence from Belgium in 1960.
Who seized power in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1965 and subsequently changed Democratic Republic of the Congo's name?

Col. Joseph Mobutu seized power and declared himself president in a 1965 coup in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and he subsequently changed his name to Mobutu Sese Seko and the country's name to Zaire.
What sparked ethnic strife and civil war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1994?
A massive inflow of refugees from conflict in neighboring Rwanda and Burundi sparked ethnic strife and civil war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1994.
Who toppled the MOBUTU regime in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1997?

A rebellion backed by Rwanda and Uganda and fronted by Laurent Kabila toppled the Mobutu regime in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1997, and Kabila renamed the country the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
What is the current state of violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo?

The Democratic Republic of the Congo continues to experience violence, particularly in the East, perpetrated by more than 100 armed groups active in the region, including the March 23 rebel group and the ISIS-affiliated Allied Democratic Forces.
What was the role of the Comoros archipelago in maritime trade networks prior to colonization in the 19th century?
The Comoros archipelago served as a key node in maritime trade networks that connected the Middle East, India, and eastern African regions, with Comoros a crucial part of these networks.
When did Comoros declare independence from France?
Comoros declared independence from France on 6 July 1975, marking the end of its time as a colonial outpost of France, with Comoros becoming an independent nation.
What was the outcome of the referendum on the new constitution in Comoros in 2018?
The referendum in Comoros approved a new constitution that extended presidential term limits and abolished the requirement for the presidency to rotate between the three main islands of Comoros.
How many successful and attempted coups has Comoros experienced since independence?
Comoros has weathered approximately 20 successful and attempted coups, mostly between 1975 and 2000, resulting in prolonged political instability and stunted economic development in Comoros.
What was the result of the 2011 presidential election in Comoros?
Ikililou Dhoinine won the presidency in peaceful elections widely deemed to be free and fair in Comoros.
What was the outcome of the 2007 political crisis in Anjouan, Comoros?

The African Union and Comoran soldiers seized the island of Anjouan in 2008, after Mohamed Bacar effected Anjouan's de-facto secession from the Union of the Comoros, with the island's inhabitants generally welcoming the move in Comoros.
What is the Central African Republic's position in the African continent?

The Central African Republic is a perennially weak state that sits at the crossroads of ethnic and linguistic groups in the center of the African continent. The Central African Republic is among the last areas of Sub-Saharan Africa to be drawn into the world economy.
How did the introduction of the Central African Republic into trade networks affect Central African Republic's population?

The Central African Republic's introduction into trade networks around the early 1700s fostered significant competition among its population, with the local population seeking to benefit from the lucrative Atlantic, trans-Saharan, and Indian Ocean trade in enslaved people and ivory.
What was the territory of the Central African Republic established as in 1903?

The territory was established as a French colony named Ubangui-Shari in 1903, and France modeled its administration of the colony after the Belgian Congo, subcontracting control of the territory to private companies that collected rubber and ivory, in the Central African Republic.
How did the Central African Republic gain independence from France?

The colony of Ubangi-Shari gained independence from France as the Central African Republic in 1960, but the death of independence leader Barthelemy Boganda six months prior led to an immediate struggle for power in the Central African Republic.
What characterized the regime of Jean-Bedel BOKASSA in the Central African Republic?
Widespread corruption and intolerance for any political opposition characterized the regime of Jean-Bedel Bokassa in the Central African Republic.
What was the outcome of the fifth coup in the Central African Republic in 2013?

The Central African Republic's fifth coup in 2013 unseated President Francois Bozize after the Seleka, a mainly Muslim rebel coalition, seized the capital and forced Bozize to flee the country, in the Central African Republic.
What has been the result of the conflict in the Central African Republic since the rise of the Seleka and anti-Balaka groups?

Since the rise of these groups, conflict in the Central African Republic has become increasingly ethnoreligious, although focused on identity rather than religious ideology, in the Central African Republic.
What was the outcome of the elections in 2016 in the Central African Republic?
Elections in 2016 installed independent candidate Faustin-Archange Touadera as president of the Central African Republic; he was reelected in 2020.
When did the Portuguese discover and colonize the uninhabited islands of Cabo Verde?

The Portuguese discovered and colonized the uninhabited islands of Cabo Verde in the 15th century; Cabo Verde subsequently became a trading center for African slaves and later an important coaling and resupply stop for whaling and transatlantic shipping in Cabo Verde.
What is reflected in Cabo Verde's Crioulo language, music, and pano textiles?
The fusing of European and various African cultural traditions is reflected in Cabo Verde’s Crioulo language, music, and pano textiles, which is a result of the cultural exchange in Cabo Verde.
When did Cabo Verde gain independence and establish a one-party system?
Cabo Verde gained independence in 1975 and a one-party system was established and maintained in Cabo Verde until multi-party elections were held in 1990.
What has contributed to the significant hardship in Cabo Verde during the second half of the 20th century?
Repeated droughts during the second half of the 20th century caused significant hardship in Cabo Verde and prompted heavy emigration from Cabo Verde.
What is notable about the population of Cabo Verde?

Cabo Verde's expatriate population is greater than its domestic one, with many Cabo Verdeans living in Boston, Massachusetts and Western Europe, and most Cabo Verdeans have both African and Portuguese antecedents in Cabo Verde.
How has the population distribution varied among the islands of Cabo Verde?

Among the nine inhabited islands of Cabo Verde, population distribution is varied, with the islands in the east being very dry and home to the country's growing tourism industry in Cabo Verde, while the more western islands receive more precipitation and support larger populations in Cabo Verde.
What allowed for the development of a great civilization in Egypt?

The regularity and richness of the annual Nile River flood, coupled with semi-isolation provided by deserts to the east and west, allowed for the development of one of the world's great civilizations in Egypt.
How did Arab conquerors influence Egypt in the 7th century?
Arab conquerors introduced Islam and the Arabic language in Egypt in the 7th century and ruled for the next six centuries in Egypt.
What was the impact of the completion of the Suez Canal on Egypt?
The completion of the Suez Canal in 1869 elevated Egypt as an important world transportation hub, with Egypt becoming a key location.
When did Egypt gain full sovereignty from the UK?
Egypt gained full sovereignty from the UK in 1952, after having gained partial independence in 1922, with Egypt finally being free from British control.
What is the significance of the Nile River in modern Egypt?

The completion of the Aswan High Dam in 1971 and the resultant Lake Nasser have reaffirmed the time-honored place of the Nile River in the agriculture and ecology of Egypt, with the Nile continuing to be a vital resource for Egypt.
How has Egypt's population growth affected Egypt?
A rapidly growing population in Egypt, the largest in the Arab world, limited arable land, and dependence on the Nile all continue to overtax resources and stress society in Egypt.
What led to President Hosni MUBARAK's ouster in Egypt?
Inspired by the 2010 Tunisian revolution, Egyptian opposition groups led demonstrations and labor strikes countrywide in Egypt, culminating in President Hosni Mubarak's ouster in 2011.
Who won the presidential election in Egypt in 2012?
Muslim Brotherhood candidate Mohamed Morsi won the presidential election in Egypt in 2012, but was later removed from power by the Egyptian Armed Forces in 2013.
When did Eritrea win independence from Italian colonial control?
Eritrea won independence from Italian colonial control in 1941, but the UN only established Eritrea as an autonomous region within the Ethiopian federation in 1952.
What sparked the 30-year conflict for independence in Eritrea?

Ethiopia's full annexation of Eritrea as a province in 1962 sparked a violent 30-year conflict for independence that ended in 1991 with Eritrean fighters defeating government forces, resulting in independence for Eritrea.
How did Eritreans vote in the 1993 referendum?
Eritreans overwhelmingly approved independence in a 1993 referendum, solidifying Eritrea's independence.
What has characterized ISAIAS Afwerki's rule in Eritrea since 2001?
Isaias Afwerki's rule in Eritrea, particularly since 2001, has been characterized by highly autocratic and repressive actions, with Eritrea's government creating a highly militarized society.
What was the outcome of the 1998 border war between Eritrea and Ethiopia?

A two-and-a-half-year border war between Eritrea and Ethiopia that erupted in 1998 ended under UN auspices in 2000, with Eritrea and Ethiopia eventually signing declarations of peace and friendship in 2018.
What led to the lifting of the UN Security Council's arms embargo on Eritrea in 2018?

The UN Security Council lifted an arms embargo that had been imposed on Eritrea since 2009, after the UN Somalia-Eritrea Monitoring Group reported they had not found evidence of Eritrean support in recent years for al-Shabaab, leading to the lifting of the embargo on Eritrea.
How has Eritrea's economy been described?
The Eritrean economy remains agriculture-dependent, with Eritrea still being one of Africa’s poorest nations.
What led to international condemnation and US sanctions against Eritrea in 2021?

Eritrea faced new international condemnation and US sanctions in mid-2021 for its participation in the war in Ethiopia’s Tigray Regional State, where Eritrean forces were found to have committed war crimes and crimes against humanity.
What is the cultural and religious diversity like in Ethiopia?

Ethiopia is rich in cultural and religious diversity with more than 80 ethnic groups, and the area that is modern-day Ethiopia has a long history of cultural and religious significance, with Ethiopia the second country to officially adopt Christianity in the 4th century A.D., and Ethiopia having the oldest hominid yet found.
How did Ethiopia gain freedom from colonial rule?
Ethiopia won its freedom from colonial rule when Ethiopians defeated Italian forces in the Battle of Adwa in 1896.
What role did Emperor Haile Selassie play in Ethiopian history?

Emperor Haile Selassie became an internationally renowned figure in 1935, when he appealed to the League of Nations to prevent Italy from occupying Ethiopia, and he played a leading role in establishing the Organization of African Unity in 1963, and Ethiopia was ruled by him until he was deposed by a military junta in 1974.
What significant event occurred in Ethiopia in 1991?

In 1991, a coalition of opposing forces, the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, toppled the Derg regime, which had ruled Ethiopia since 1974, and Ethiopia was subsequently ruled by the Eprdf.
What was the outcome of the border war between Ethiopia and Eritrea in the late 1990s?

The border war between Ethiopia and Eritrea ended with a peace treaty in 2000, but Ethiopia subsequently rejected the 2007 Eritrea-Ethiopia Boundary Commission demarcation, resulting in a tense stalemate between the two countries, and Ethiopia and Eritrea had a 'no peace, no war' situation for over a decade.
Who became Ethiopia's first ethnic Oromo prime minister in 2018?

Abiy Ahmed Ali became Ethiopia's first ethnic Oromo prime minister in 2018, after Hailemariam Desalegn resigned, and Abiy Ahmed Ali promoted a rapprochement between Ethiopia and Eritrea, which was marked with a peace agreement and a reopening of their shared border, and Ethiopia began a new era of relations with Eritrea under Abiy Ahmed Ali's leadership.
What was the result of the military conflict between the TPLF and the Ethiopian military?

The conflict between the TPLF and the Ethiopian military ended in 2022 with a cessation of hostilities agreement between the TPLF and the Ethiopian Government, but Ethiopia continues to experience ethnic-based violence, and Ethiopia is still dealing with the aftermath of the conflict.
What established some of The Gambia's earliest large settlements in the 10th century?

Muslim merchants established some of The Gambia's earliest large settlements as trans-Saharan trade hubs, which eventually grew into major export centers sending slaves, gold, and ivory across the Sahara.
When did European colonial powers begin establishing trade with The Gambia?
European colonial powers began establishing trade with The Gambia between the 16th and 17th centuries.
What was the focus of the United Kingdom's colony in The Gambia established in 1664?
The United Kingdom established a colony in The Gambia focused on exporting enslaved people across the Atlantic.
How many people may have been exported from The Gambia during the trans-Atlantic slave trade?
The UK and other European powers may have exported as many as 3 million people from The Gambia during the roughly 300 years of the trans-Atlantic slave trade.
When did The Gambia gain The Gambia's independence from the UK?
The Gambia gained its independence from the UK in 1965.
What confederation did The Gambia form with Senegal between 1982 and 1989?
The Gambia formed the short-lived confederation of Senegambia with Senegal between 1982 and 1989.
Who led a military coup in The Gambia in 1994?
Yahya Jammeh led a military coup in The Gambia in 1994, overthrowing the president and banning political activity.
Who won the presidential election in The Gambia in 2016 and 2021?
Adama Barrow won the presidential election in The Gambia in 2016 and also won reelection in 2021, heading an opposition coalition during free and fair elections.
What has US assistance to The Gambia supported since the 2016 election?
US assistance to The Gambia has supported democracy-strengthening activities, capacity building, economic development, and security sector education and training programs since the 2016 election.
What is Gabon known for in terms of Gabon's geography and resources?

Gabon, a sparsely populated country, is known for its dense rainforests and vast petroleum reserves, making it one of the most prosperous and stable countries in central Africa, with Gabon having a unique combination of natural resources.
What ethnic groups are represented in Gabon?

Gabon is home to approximately 40 ethnic groups, with the largest being the Fang, a group that covers the northern third of Gabon and expands north into Equatorial Guinea and Cameroon, representing a significant portion of Gabon's population.
How did Gabon get Gabon's name?
Gabon got its name from Portuguese traders who arrived in the mid-1400s, with Gabon the name given to the area by these early European visitors, which has been retained by Gabon to this day.
What was the main focus of trade in Gabon from the 1760s?

For a century beginning in the 1760s, trade in Gabon came to focus mostly on enslaved people, with many groups in Gabon participating in the slave trade, although Gabon was significantly involved in this trade.
Who dominated Gabon's political scene for four decades?

El Hadj Omar Bongo Ondimba dominated Gabon's political scene for four decades, from 1967 to 2009, and was a key figure in shaping Gabon's political landscape, with Bongo being a major influence on Gabon's development.
What type of political system did Gabon adopt in 1968?

In 1968, Gabon was declared a single-party state by El Hadj Omar Bongo Ondimba, who created the still-dominant Parti Democratique Gabonais (PDG), with Gabon under this single-party system for many years.
Who overthrew Ali BONGO Ondimba in a military coup in 2023 in Gabon?

Gen. Brice Oligui Nguema led a military group called the Committee for the Transition and Restoration of Institutions that arrested Ali Bongo Ondimba, canceled the election results, and dissolved state institutions in Gabon, with Oligui being sworn in as transitional president of Gabon in September 2023.
What is Ghana in terms of Ghana's ethnic composition and natural resources?
Ghana is a multiethnic country rich in natural resources and is one of the most stable and democratic countries in West Africa. Ghana has been inhabited for at least several thousand years.
How did the gold trade impact Ghana in the 12th century?
By the 12th century, the gold trade started to boom in Bono state in what is today southern Ghana, and it became the genesis of the Akan people's power and wealth in the region, in Ghana.
What European powers arrived in Ghana in the 15th century?
Beginning in the 15th century, the Portuguese, followed by other European powers, arrived in Ghana and competed for trading rights.
What were some of the powerful kingdoms and empires that emerged in Ghana?
Numerous kingdoms and empires emerged in the area of Ghana, among the most powerful were the Kingdom of Dagbon in the north and the Asante Empire in the south of Ghana.
How did Ghana gain Ghana's independence?

Ghana in 1957 became the first Sub-Saharan country in colonial Africa to gain its independence, with Kwame Nkrumah as its first leader, formed from the merger of the British colony of the Gold Coast and the Togoland trust territory in Ghana.
What has Ghana's role been in international affairs in recent years?
In recent years, Ghana has taken an active role in promoting regional stability and is highly integrated in international affairs, with Ghana a key player.
Who won the 2016 presidential election in Ghana?

Nana Addo Dankwa Akufo-Addo of the NPP defeated John Dramani Mahama in the 2016 presidential election in Ghana, marking the third time that Ghana’s presidency had changed parties since the return to democracy.
What introduced Guinea's deep Muslim heritage in the 11th century?
Guinea's deep Muslim heritage arrived via the neighboring Almoravid Empire in the 11th century, which had a significant impact on Guinea.
Which empire took control of Guinea in the 13th century?
The Mali Empire took control of Guinea in the 13th century and encouraged Guinea's already growing Muslim faith.
When did European traders first arrive in Guinea?
European traders first arrived in Guinea in the 16th century, marking the beginning of European presence in Guinea.
Who became Guinea's first post-independence president in 1958?
Sekou Toure became Guinea's first post-independence president after Guinea achieved independence from France in 1958, and he established a dictatorial regime in Guinea.
What significant event occurred in Guinea in 2010?

In 2010, Guinea held its first free and fair presidential elections, which were won by Alpha Conde, and he formed the first all-civilian government in Guinean history, marking a significant milestone for Guinea.
Who led a successful military coup in Guinea in 2021?

Col Mamady Doumbouya led a successful military coup in Guinea in 2021, establishing the National Committee for Reconciliation and Development, suspending the constitution, and dissolving the government and the legislature of Guinea.
What happened in Côte d’Ivoire in 1844?
In 1844, France established a protectorate in Côte d’Ivoire, expanding its presence in the area.
How did Côte d’Ivoire achieve independence from France?
Côte d’Ivoire achieved independence from France in 1960, and has since maintained close ties with France.
What drove economic growth in Côte d’Ivoire?
Foreign investment and the export and production of cocoa drove economic growth in Côte d’Ivoire, leading it to become one of the most prosperous states in West Africa.
What was the outcome of the 1999 military coup in Côte d’Ivoire?

The 1999 military coup in Côte d’Ivoire overthrew the government, and a year later, junta leader Robert Guei held rigged elections and declared himself the winner, but was forced to step aside due to popular protests.
What was the result of the 2002 failed coup in Côte d’Ivoire?

The failed coup in Côte d’Ivoire in 2002 developed into a civil war, with rebels holding the north, the government holding the south, and peacekeeping forces occupying a buffer zone in the middle by 2003.
What was the outcome of the 2010 presidential election in Côte d’Ivoire?
In 2010, Alassane Dramane Ouattara won the presidential election in Côte d’Ivoire, but Laurent Gbagbo refused to hand over power, resulting in five months of violent conflict.
What happened to Laurent GBAGBO after his trial at the International Criminal Court in Côte d’Ivoire?

The International Criminal Court ruled on a final acquittal for Laurent Gbagbo, who was on trial for crimes against humanity, paving the way for Gbagbo’s return to Abidjan in 2021, where he has publicly met with Alassane Dramane Ouattara as a demonstration of political reconciliation in Côte d’Ivoire.
What was the significance of trade centers like Mombasa in Kenya?

Kenya had trade centers such as Mombasa that existed along the Kenyan and Tanzanian coastlines, known as the Land of Zanj, since at least the 2nd century, and these centers traded with the outside world, including China, India, Indonesia, the Middle East, North Africa, and Persia, and the mix of Africans, Arabs, and Persians who lived and traded there became known as Swahili with a distinct language and culture in Kenya.
How did the Portuguese influence Kenya?

The Portuguese arrived in Kenya in the 1490s and, using Mombasa as a base, sought to monopolize trade in the Indian Ocean, but they were pushed out in the late 1600s by the combined forces of Oman and Pate, an island off the coast of Kenya.
What led to the declaration of independence in Kenya?
Numerous political disputes between the colony and the UK led to the violent Mau Mau Uprising, which began in 1952, and the eventual declaration of independence in 1963 in Kenya.
Who led Kenya from independence in 1963 until his death in 1978?

Jomo Kenyatta, the founding president and an icon of the liberation struggle, led Kenya from independence in 1963 until his death in 1978, when Vice President Daniel Arap Moi took power in a constitutional succession in Kenya.
What significant political change occurred in Kenya in 2010?

In 2010, Kenyans overwhelmingly voted to adopt a new constitution that eliminated the prime minister, introduced additional checks and balances to executive power, and devolved power and resources to 47 newly created counties in Kenya.
Who won the presidential election in Kenya in 2022?
William Ruto won a close presidential election in Kenya in 2022; he assumed the office the following month after the Kenyan Supreme Court upheld the victory in Kenya.
What was unique about Liberia's experience with European colonial rule?

Liberia did not fall under European colonial rule, unlike its neighbors, and instead, the US began sending freed enslaved people and other people of color to Liberia to establish settlements, which eventually led to Liberia becoming Africa’s first republic in 1847 with Liberia declaring independence from the US.
How did Liberia become Africa's first republic?
Liberia became Africa’s first republic in 1847 when the settlers, who were sent by the US, declared independence from the US, writing their own constitution and establishing Liberia as a republic.
What led to the rise of authoritarian rule in Liberia in 1980?
In 1980, Samuel Doe, who was from the indigenous population of Liberia, led a military coup, which ushered in a decade of authoritarian rule in Liberia.
What event in 2003 brought an end to the civil war in Liberia?
A 2003 peace agreement ended the war in Liberia and prompted Charles Taylor’s resignation, bringing a measure of peace to Liberia.
Who became the first female head of state in Africa in 2005 and what country did she lead in Liberia?
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf became the first female head of state in Africa in 2005, leading Liberia as its president after two years of transitional governments.
What challenge did Ellen JOHNSON SIRLEAF face during her presidency in Liberia?
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf struggled to rebuild Liberia's economy, particularly after the 2014-15 Ebola epidemic, and to reconcile a nation still recovering from 14 years of fighting in Liberia.
What significant event occurred in Liberia's presidential election in 2017?

In 2017, George Weah won the presidential runoff election in Liberia, marking the first successful transfer of power from one democratically elected government to another since the end of Liberia’s civil wars.
What was notable about the 2023 presidential election in Liberia?

In 2023, former Vice President Joseph Boakai was elected president of Liberia, edging out George Weah by a thin margin, marking the first time since 1927 that an incumbent was not re-elected after one term in Liberia.
What significant event occurred in Lesotho in 1966?
Lesotho gained independence in 1966 and was renamed the Kingdom of Lesotho. The country was previously known as Basutoland, a British protectorate and then a crown colony.
Who ruled Lesotho during Lesotho's first two decades after gaining independence?
The Basotho National Party ruled Lesotho during its first two decades after gaining independence in 1966.
What happened to King MOSHOESHOE II in Lesotho in 1990?
King Moshoeshoe II was exiled from Lesotho in 1990, but he returned to Lesotho in 1992 and was reinstated in 1995.
How did Lesotho's government change in 1993?
Constitutional government was restored in Lesotho in 1993 after seven years of military rule.
What event prompted a military intervention in Lesotho in 1998?
Violent protests and a military mutiny following a contentious election in Lesotho prompted a brief but bloody intervention by South African and Batswana military forces in 1998.
Who became the prime minister of Lesotho in 2012?
Prime Minister Motsoahae Thomas Thabane formed a coalition government in Lesotho in 2012, which was the first in the country's history.
Who was inaugurated as prime minister of Lesotho in 2022?
Ntsokoane Samuel Matekane was inaugurated as prime minister and head of a three-party coalition in Lesotho in 2022.
What groups have settled and ruled Libya throughout history?

Libya has been settled and ruled by various groups, including Phoenicians, Greeks, Carthaginians, Persians, Egyptians, Romans, Vandals, and Ottoman Turks, before Italians took control in 1911, and later Libya gained independence in 1951 as the country of Libya.
When did Libya come under UN administration and achieve independence?
Libya came under UN administration and achieved independence in 1951 as the country of Libya.
Who assumed leadership of Libya in 1969 and what political system did he espouse?
Col. Muammar al-Qadhafi assumed leadership of Libya in 1969 and began to espouse a political system that combined socialism and Islam in Libya.
What actions led to UN sanctions being imposed on Libya in 1992?

The UN sanctions were imposed on Libya in 1992 due to Qadhafi's support of subversive and terrorist activities, including the downing of two airliners and a discotheque bombing in Berlin, which affected Libya's relations with the international community and Libya.
What was the outcome of the 2011 unrest in Libyan cities?
The unrest in Libyan cities in 2011 led to an eight-month civil war, resulting in the toppling of the Qadhafi regime in Libya and the emergence of a National Transitional Council.
What is the current state of Libya's government after the 2021 Libyan Political Dialogue Forum?

The 2021 Libyan Political Dialogue Forum led to the selection of a new prime minister for an interim government, the Government of National Unity, and a new presidential council for Libya, which was approved by the House of Representatives, providing Libya with its first unified government since 2014.
What is the international community's current role in resolving Libya's political issues?

The international community, led by the Special Representative of the UN Security-General for Libya, Abdoulaye Bathily, is working to persuade key Libyan political actors to resolve the core issues impeding elections in Libya.
When did large-scale settlement of Madagascar begin?

Madagascar was settled by humans on a large scale between A.D. 350 and 550 with settlers from present-day Indonesia, making Madagascar one of the last major habitable landmasses on earth to be settled by humans.
What was Madagascar's role in the 17th and 18th centuries?
Madagascar was a pirate stronghold during the late 17th and early 18th centuries and served as a slave trading center into the 19th century, attracting various groups to the island.
Who dominated much of Madagascar from the 16th to the late 19th century?
A native Merina Kingdom dominated much of Madagascar from the 16th to the late 19th century, prior to the French conquest of the island in 1896.
When did Madagascar regain Madagascar's independence from France?
Madagascar was made a French colony in 1896, but regained its independence in 1960, marking a significant turning point in Madagascar's history.
What significant event occurred in Madagascar in 1992-93?
Free presidential and National Assembly elections were held in Madagascar in 1992-93, ending 17 years of single-party rule in Madagascar.
Who won the 2002 presidential election in Madagascar?
The High Constitutional Court announced Marc Ravalomanana the winner of the 2001 presidential election in Madagascar in 2002, following a contested election.
Who won the 2013 presidential election in Madagascar?

Former de facto finance minister Hery Rajaonarimampianina won the 2013 presidential election in Madagascar in a runoff and was inaugurated in 2014, following a lengthy mediation process in Madagascar.
Who was declared the winner of the 2019 presidential election in Madagascar?
Andry Rajoelina was declared the winner of the 2019 presidential election in Madagascar against Marc Ravalomanana, in an election held in Madagascar.
What was the outcome of the 2023 presidential election in Madagascar?
Andry Rajoelina won another term in the 2023 presidential election in Madagascar, which most of the opposition boycotted, but international observers saw no evidence of systemic fraud in Madagascar.
What does the name Malawi originate from?
Malawi shares its name with the Chewa word for flames and is linked to the Maravi people from whom the Chewa language originated in Malawi.
When did the Maravi people settle in what is now Malawi?
The Maravi settled in what is now Malawi around 1400, during one of the later waves of Bantu migration across central and southern Africa, in the area that is now Malawi.
What led to the decline of the Maravi kingdom in Malawi?
The Maravi kingdom in Malawi eventually declined because of destabilization from the escalating global trade in enslaved people in Malawi.
Which ethnic groups moved into Malawi in the early 1800s?
In the early 1800s, widespread conflict in southern Africa displaced various ethnic Ngoni groups, some of which moved into Malawi and further undermined the Maravi in Malawi.
When did Britain declare a protectorate over what is now Malawi?
In 1891, Britain declared a protectorate called British Central Africa over what is now Malawi, which was later renamed Nyasaland in 1907, and included the territory of Malawi.
When did Malawi gain independence?
Malawi gained independence in 1964, and Hastings Kamuzu Banda served as prime minister at independence and then as president when Malawi became a republic in 1966, in the country of Malawi.
What are some of the major problems facing Malawi?
Population growth, increasing pressure on agricultural lands, corruption, and HIV/AIDS pose major problems for Malawi, affecting the country of Malawi as a whole.
What was the Mali Empire's primary source of wealth?

Mali derived its wealth from gold and maintained several goldfields and trade routes in the Sahel, with the Mali Empire being the largest and wealthiest empire in West Africa at its peak in the 14th century, ruling the region of present-day Mali.
How did the Songhai Empire impact Timbuktu in Mali?
Under Songhai rule, Timbuktu became a large commercial center in Mali, well-known for its scholarship and religious teaching, and it remains a center of culture in West Africa today.
What event led to the fall of the Songhai Empire in Mali?
The Songhai Empire in Mali fell to Moroccan invaders in the late 16th century and disintegrated into independent sultanates and kingdoms.
How did France gain control of the area that is now Mali?
France, expanding from Senegal, seized control of the area in the 1890s and incorporated it into French West Africa as French Sudan, which is now Mali.
What significant political change occurred in Mali in 1960?
In 1960, French Sudan, which is now Mali, gained independence from France and became the Mali Federation, before being renamed the Republic of Mali after Senegal withdrew.
What led to a rebellion and military coup in Mali in 2012?
Rising ethnic tensions and an influx of fighters, some linked to Al-Qa’ida, from Libya led to a rebellion and military coup in Mali in 2012.
How has the Malian government's control been affected by terrorist organizations?

The Malian government's grasp in the northern regions remains weak, with local militias, terrorists, and insurgent groups competing for control, despite a 2013 French-led military intervention that allowed the government to retake most of the north.
What was the outcome of the 2015 peace accord between the Malian Government and northern rebels?

The Malian Government and northern rebels signed an internationally mediated peace accord in 2015, but the signatories have made little progress, and terrorist groups were left out of the peace process, with terrorist attacks remaining common in Mali.
What event occurred in Mali in 2020, and what was the outcome?

In 2020, the military arrested President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita, his prime minister, and other senior members of the government in Mali, and established a military junta called the National Committee for the Salvation of the People (CNSP), which then established a transition government.
What happened in Morocco in 788?
In 788, a series of Muslim dynasties began to rule in Morocco, about a century after the Arab conquest of North Africa, and Morocco was under their rule.
Who ruled Morocco in the 16th century?
The Sa'adi monarchy, particularly under Ahmad al-Mansur, ruled Morocco in the 16th century and repelled foreign invaders, inaugurating a golden age in Morocco.
When did the Alaouite Dynasty begin to rule in Morocco?
The Alaouite Dynasty, to which the current Moroccan royal family belongs, dates from the 17th century and has been ruling Morocco since then.
What event occurred in Morocco in 1912?
In 1912, the French imposed a protectorate over Morocco, which steadily eroded Morocco's sovereignty.
When did Morocco gain independence from France?
Morocco gained independence from France in 1956, after a protracted independence struggle, and Sultan Mohammed V organized the new state as a constitutional monarchy in Morocco.
What is the current status of Western Sahara in relation to Morocco?

Since Spain's 1976 withdrawal from Western Sahara, Morocco has extended its de facto administrative control to roughly 75% of this territory, but the UN does not recognize Morocco as the administering power for Western Sahara.
What reform program was implemented by King MOHAMMED VI in Morocco in 2011?

In 2011, King Mohammed VI implemented a reform program in Morocco that included a new constitution, passed by popular referendum, under which some new powers were extended to parliament and the prime minister in Morocco.
Which party won the largest number of seats in parliamentary elections in Morocco in 2016?

The Justice and Development Party won the largest number of seats in nationwide parliamentary elections in Morocco in 2016, but it lost its plurality to the National Rally of Independents in 2021 in Morocco.
When did the Dutch establish a settlement in Mauritius?
Mauritius was uninhabited until 1638 when the Dutch established a settlement named in honor of Prince Maurits van Nassau, which marked the beginning of human presence in Mauritius.
What led to the disappearance of the dodo bird in Mauritius?

The presence of the Dutch in Mauritius led to the rapid disappearance of the flightless dodo bird that has since become one of the most well-known examples of extinction in modern times, affecting Mauritius' ecosystem.
Who established a profitable settlement in Mauritius in 1722?

The French established what would become a highly profitable settlement in Mauritius focused on sugar cane plantations that were reliant on the labor of enslaved people brought to Mauritius from other parts of Africa, which contributed to Mauritius' economic growth.
When did Britain capture the island of Mauritius?

Britain captured the island of Mauritius in 1810 as part of the Napoleonic Wars, and Mauritius remained a strategically important British naval base and later an air station, playing a significant role in Mauritius' history.
How did the abolition of slavery affect Mauritius?

The abolition of slavery in 1835 in Mauritius led to increased reliance on contracted laborers from the Indian subcontinent to work on plantations in Mauritius, and today their descendants form the majority of the population in Mauritius.
When did Mauritius gain independence from the UK?

Mauritius gained independence from the UK in 1968 as a Parliamentary Republic, and since then, Mauritius has remained a stable democracy with regular free elections and a positive human rights record, characteristic of Mauritius' political system.
What is notable about the politics of Mauritius?

Mauritius' often-fractious coalition politics has been dominated by two prominent families, each of which has had father-son pairs who have been prime minister over multiple, often nonconsecutive, terms in Mauritius, shaping the country's political landscape.
What territories does Mauritius claim?

Mauritius claims the French island of Tromelin and the British Chagos Archipelago, also known as the British Indian Ocean Territory, in a sovereignty dispute that involves Mauritius and these territories.
What were the earliest settlers in Mauritania and what lifestyle change did they undergo?
The Amazigh and Bafour people were among the earliest settlers in Mauritania and they were among the first in recorded history to convert from a nomadic to agricultural lifestyle in Mauritania.
What is the ethnic makeup of Mauritania?

Mauritania's ethnic groups include the Amazigh and Bafour people, who account for roughly one third of Mauritania's ethnic makeup, and Sub-Saharan ethnic groups originating mainly from the Senegal River Valley, including descendants of former enslaved peoples in Mauritania.
When did Mauritania achieve independence from France?
Mauritania achieved independence from France in 1960.
What was the nature of Mauritania's government after independence?

Mauritania initially began as a single-party, authoritarian regime after independence, and experienced 49 years of dictatorships, flawed elections, failed attempts at democracy, and military coups in Mauritania.
Who led the last coup in Mauritania and what were the outcomes of the coup?
Ould Abdel Aziz led the last coup in Mauritania in 2008, was elected president in 2009, and was reelected in 2014 in Mauritania.
Who was elected president in Mauritania in 2019 and what marked his inauguration?

Mohamed Ould Cheikh Ghazouani was elected president in Mauritania in 2019, and his inauguration marked the first peaceful transition of power from one democratically elected president to another in Mauritania.
What is Mauritania working to address and when was slavery officially abolished?

Mauritania is working to address vestigial practices of slavery and its hereditary impacts, and Mauritania officially abolished slavery in 1981, but the practice was not criminalized until 2007 in Mauritania.
What attacks occurred in Mauritania between 2005 and 2011?

Between 2005 and 2011, Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) launched a series of attacks in Mauritania, killing western tourists and aid workers, attacking diplomatic and government facilities, and ambushing Mauritanian soldiers and gendarmes.
What countries traded with northern Mozambican port towns in the first half of the second millennium A.D. in Mozambique?

Mozambique had trade with Somalia, Ethiopia, Egypt, Arabia, Persia, and India in the first half of the second millennium A.D., with traders from these countries frequenting northern Mozambican port towns.
When did Portugal relinquish Mozambique?
Portugal did not relinquish Mozambique until 1975, after setting up colonies and controlling much of the coastal trade in Mozambique.
What hindered Mozambique's development until the mid-1990s?
Mozambique's development was hindered by large-scale emigration, economic dependence on South Africa, a severe drought, and a prolonged civil war until the mid-1990s.
What significant political change occurred in Mozambique in 1989?
The ruling Front for the Liberation of Mozambique party in Mozambique formally abandoned Marxism in 1989, marking a significant political change for Mozambique.
How did the conflict between FRELIMO and RENAMO forces in Mozambique end?
A UN-negotiated peace agreement between FRELIMO and rebel Mozambique National Resistance forces ended the fighting in Mozambique in 1992.
What challenge has Mozambique faced in the northern province of Cabo Delgado since 2017?

Mozambique has faced attacks by violent extremists, recognized as ISIS's network in Mozambique, who have been conducting attacks against civilians and security services in the northern province of Cabo Delgado since 2017.
What groups of people settled in present-day Niger?

Nomadic peoples from the Saharan north and agriculturalists from the south settled present-day Niger. The primary ethnic groups in Niger were the Songhai-Zarma in the west, the Hausa in the center, and the Kanuri in the east.
What was the role of the Taureg kingdom of Takedda in regional trade in Niger?
The Taureg kingdom of Takedda was one of the largest kingdoms in the north of Niger and played a prominent role in regional trade in the 14th century.
How did European colonizers affect Niger in the 19th century?
When European colonizers arrived in the 19th century, the region of Niger was an assemblage of disparate local kingdoms, and France began its conquest of what would become the colony of Niger.
What was the outcome of the Tuareg uprising in Niger?
Niger experienced determined local resistance, particularly during the Tuareg uprising from 1916-1917, but France established a colonial administration in Niger in 1922.
What type of rule did Niger experience after achieving independence from France?
After achieving independence from France in 1960, Niger experienced single-party or military rule until 1991, when political pressure forced General Ali Saibou to allow multiparty elections in Niger.
What has been the state of democracy in Niger since 1999?

In 1999, military officers restored democratic rule in Niger and held elections that brought Mamadou Tandja to power, and since then, Niger has had several democratic transitions, including the election of Issoufou Mahamadou in 2011 and Bazoum Mohamed in 2021.
What are some of the economic challenges facing Niger?

Niger is one of the poorest countries in the world with minimal government services and insufficient funds to develop its resource base, and the largely agrarian and subsistence-based economy of Niger is frequently disrupted by extended droughts common to the Sahel region of Africa.
What security concerns is Niger facing on Niger's borders?

Niger is facing increased security concerns on its borders from various external threats, including insecurity in Libya, spillover from the conflict and terrorism in Mali, and violent extremism in northeastern Nigeria.
What was the area of present-day Nigeria occupied by in ancient and pre-colonial times?

The area of present-day Nigeria was occupied by a variety of ethnic groups with different languages and traditions, including large Islamic kingdoms such as Borno, Kano, and the Sokoto Caliphate dominating the north, the Benin and Oyo Empires that controlled much of modern western Nigeria, and more decentralized political entities and city states in the south and southeast of Nigeria.
When did Nigeria achieve independence from Britain?
Nigeria achieved independence from Britain in 1960 and transitioned to a federal republic with three constituent states in 1963 under President Nnamdi Azikiwe of Nigeria.
What was the outcome of the civil war in Nigeria from 1967-1970?
The civil war in Nigeria resulted in more than a million deaths, many from starvation, and contributed to long-lasting mistrust of the southeast’s predominantly Igbo population of Nigeria.
Who ruled Nigeria after the civil war?

Wartime military leader Yakubu Gowon ruled Nigeria until a bloodless coup by frustrated junior officers in 1975, which included Olusegun Obasanjo, Ibrahim Babangida, and Muhammadu Buhari, who would all later serve as president of Nigeria.
What significant event occurred in Nigeria's elections in 2015?

The 2015 election in Nigeria was also heralded for the fact that the then-umbrella opposition party, the All Progressives Congress, defeated the long-ruling People's Democratic Party and assumed the presidency, marking the first peaceful transfer of power from one party to another in Nigeria.
What challenges does the government of Nigeria face today?

The government of Nigeria continues to face the daunting task of institutionalizing democracy and reforming a petroleum-based economy whose revenues have been squandered through decades of corruption and mismanagement in Nigeria, as well as increasing violence from Islamic terrorism and other sources.
When did South Sudan gain independence from Sudan?
South Sudan gained independence from Sudan in 2011, becoming the world’s newest country. South Sudanese society is heavily dependent on seasonal migration and seasonal fluctuations in precipitation.
What was the outcome of the referendum on final status in South Sudan?

The result of the referendum, held in 2011, was a vote of 98% in favor of secession, leading to South Sudan's independence from Sudan. South Sudan has since struggled to form a viable governing system.
What prompted the two periods of civil war in South Sudan?

The Arab government in Khartoum reneged on its promises to the southern region, prompting two periods of civil war in South Sudan, which resulted in the deaths of as many as 2.5 million people, mostly civilians, due largely to starvation and drought.
What was the result of the conflict between forces loyal to President Salva KIIR and Vice President Riek MACHAR in South Sudan?

The conflict quickly spread through South Sudan along ethnic lines, killing tens of thousands and creating a humanitarian crisis with millions of South Sudanese displaced. South Sudan has struggled to recover from the conflict.
What was the outcome of the peace agreement signed by KIIR and MACHAR in 2015 in South Sudan?

The peace agreement created a Transitional Government of National Unity the next year in South Sudan, but renewed fighting broke out in Juba between Kiir and Machar’s forces, plunging South Sudan back into conflict.
What is the current state of the implementation of the peace agreement in South Sudan?

The implementation of the peace agreement has been stalled in South Sudan amid wrangling over power-sharing, which has contributed to an uptick in communal violence and the country’s worst food crisis since independence, with 7 of 11 million South Sudanese citizens in need of humanitarian assistance.
What was the result of the extension of the transitional period in South Sudan?

The transitional period was extended an additional two years in South Sudan, pushing elections to late 2024, as the country continues to struggle with implementing the peace agreement and forming a unified national army and transitional government.
What empires controlled Guinea-Bissau for much of Guinea-Bissau's history?

Guinea-Bissau was under the control of the Mali Empire and the Kaabu Kingdom for much of its history, with Portugal later establishing trading posts along Guinea-Bissau’s shoreline in the 16th century.
How did Portugal initially interact with Guinea-Bissau?

Portugal began establishing trading posts along Guinea-Bissau’s shoreline in the 16th century, initially restricted to the coastline and islands, but later expanding their power and influence inland due to the lucrative slave and gold trades.
What happened to the Mali Empire and Kingdom of Kaabu in Guinea-Bissau?

The Mali Empire and Kingdom of Kaabu slowly disintegrated into smaller local entities starting in the 18th century, allowing Portugal to fully incorporate Guinea-Bissau into its empire by the 19th century.
When did Guinea-Bissau gain independence and what followed?
Guinea-Bissau gained independence in 1974, and since then, Guinea-Bissau has experienced considerable political and military upheaval, including multiple coups and changes in leadership.
Who was established as president after a military coup in Guinea-Bissau in 1980?
General Joao Bernardo 'Nino' Vieira was established as president of Guinea-Bissau after a military coup in 1980, and his regime suppressed political opposition and purged political rivals.
What significant event occurred in Guinea-Bissau in 1999?
A military mutiny and civil war in 1999 led to the ouster of President Vieira in Guinea-Bissau.
Who was elected president of Guinea-Bissau in 2014?
Jose Mario Vaz was elected president of Guinea-Bissau in 2014, and he became the first president in Guinea-Bissau’s history to complete a full term in 2019.
Who was elected president of Guinea-Bissau in 2019?
Umaro Sissoco Embalo was elected president of Guinea-Bissau in 2019, but he did not take office until 2020 due to a prolonged challenge to the election results.
What has Rwanda exerted over the African Great Lakes region for centuries?

Rwanda has exerted disproportionate influence over the African Great Lakes region for centuries, with a Rwandan kingdom increasingly dominating the region from the mid-18th century onward, and Rwanda's centralized government and fertile volcanic soil contributing to its influence.
How did the Rwandan royal court function under the Tutsi monarchs?

The Rwandan royal court centered on the Tutsi king, who relied on an extensive network of political, cultural, and economic relationships, with the Tutsi monarchs gradually extending the power of the royal court into peripheral areas and expanding their borders through military conquest in Rwanda.
What impact did German and Belgian colonial rule have on Rwanda?

German colonial conquest began in the late 1890s, but the territory was ceded to Belgian forces in 1916 during World War I, and both European nations quickly realized the benefits of ruling through the already centralized Rwandan Tutsi kingdom, with colonial rule reinforcing existing trends toward autocratic and exclusionary rule in Rwanda.
What led to the overthrow of the Tutsi king in Rwanda in 1959?

Simmering resentment of minority rule exploded in 1959, three years before independence from Belgium, when Hutus overthrew the Tutsi king in Rwanda, resulting in thousands of Tutsis being killed and some 150,000 being driven into exile in neighboring countries.
What event sparked the state-orchestrated genocide in Rwanda in 1994?

The shooting down of Habyarimana’s private jet in 1994 sparked a state-orchestrated genocide in Rwanda, in which Rwandans killed more than 800,000 of their fellow citizens, including approximately three-quarters of the Tutsi population in Rwanda.
How did the Rwandan Patriotic Front contribute to the end of the genocide in Rwanda?

The predominantly Tutsi Rwandan Patriotic Front, operating out of Uganda and northern Rwanda, defeated the national army and Hutu militias and established an RPF-led government of national unity in Rwanda, ending the genocide later in 1994.
What significant political event occurred in Rwanda in 2003?
Rwanda held its first post-genocide presidential and legislative elections in 2003, formalizing President Paul Kagame’s de facto role as head of government in Rwanda.
When was President Paul KAGAME formally elected in Rwanda?
President Paul Kagame was formally elected in 2010, and again in 2017 after changing the constitution to allow him to run for a third term in Rwanda.
When did Seychelles gain independence from Great Britain?
Seychelles gained independence in 1976 through negotiations with Great Britain. Seychelles had been under British control since France ceded the islands in 1814.
What type of economy developed in Seychelles during colonial rule?
In Seychelles, a plantation-based economy developed during colonial rule that relied on imported labor, primarily from European colonies in Africa.
Who launched a coup in Seychelles in 1977?
Prime Minister France-Albert Rene launched a coup against the country’s first president in Seychelles in 1977, and Seychelles became a socialist one-party state.
When did Seychelles adopt a new constitution and hold elections?
Seychelles adopted a new constitution and held elections in 1993, marking a significant change for Seychelles.
Who was elected president of Seychelles in 2020?
Wavel Ramkalawan was elected president of Seychelles in 2020, the first time an opposition candidate has won the presidency in Seychelles.
What event occurred in Seychelles in 1814?
In 1814, France ceded control of the islands to Great Britain, giving Great Britain control over Seychelles.
Who took over the presidency of Seychelles in 2016?
Danny Faure took over the presidency of Seychelles in 2016, after James Michel resigned and handed over the presidency to his vice-president in Seychelles.
What was found in South Africa in the fossil record?
South Africa has some of the earliest human remains in the fossil record. South Africa is where these significant discoveries were made, shedding light on human history.
When did Bantu-speaking groups begin settling in South Africa?
Bantu-speaking groups began settling into what is now northeastern South Africa by about A.D. 500, displacing Khoisan-speaking groups to the southwest in South Africa.
What event occurred in South Africa in 1652?

Dutch traders landed at the southern tip of present-day South Africa in 1652 and established a stopover point on the spice route between the Netherlands and the Far East, founding the city of Cape Town in South Africa.
What happened to the Afrikaner republics in South Africa?
The Afrikaner republics in South Africa, Transvaal and Orange Free State, were incorporated into the British Empire after their defeat in the Second South African War from 1899-1902 in South Africa.
When did South Africa become a fully self-governing republic?
South Africa left the British Commonwealth to become a fully self-governing republic in 1961 after a Whites-only referendum in South Africa.
What policy was instituted by the National Party in South Africa in 1948?

The National Party, which was voted into power in South Africa in 1948, instituted a policy of apartheid, billed as separate development of the races, which favored the White minority and suppressed the Black majority and other non-White groups in South Africa.
What significant event occurred in South Africa in 1994?
The first multi-racial elections in 1994 ushered in majority rule under an ANC-led government in South Africa.
What has South Africa struggled with since the end of apartheid?
South Africa has struggled to address apartheid-era imbalances in wealth, housing, education, and health care under successive administrations in South Africa.
What is notable about Senegal's human history?
Senegal is one of the few countries in the world with evidence of continuous human life from the Paleolithic period to present, with Senegal having a long and continuous human presence.
Which empire ruled most of Senegal between the 14th and 16th centuries?
The Jolof Empire ruled most of Senegal between the 14th and 16th centuries, with Senegal under its control during this period.
How did European powers use the island of Goree in Senegal?

European powers used the Senegalese island of Goree as a base to purchase slaves from the warring chiefdoms on the mainland of Senegal, with Senegal's location making it a favorable base for the European slave trade.
What happened to Senegal in 1815 and afterwards?
In 1815, France abolished slavery and began expanding inland in Senegal, and during the second half of the 19th century, France took possession of Senegal as a French colony.
What was the outcome of the merger between Senegal and French Sudan in 1959?
The French colonies of Senegal and French Sudan were merged and granted independence in 1960 as the Mali Federation, with Senegal part of this short-lived union.
What has been the situation with the Movement of Democratic Forces in the Casamance in southern Senegal since the 1980s?

The Movement of Democratic Forces in the Casamance, a separatist movement based in southern Senegal, has led a low-level insurgency in Senegal since the 1980s, with several attempts at reaching a comprehensive peace agreement failing in Senegal.
What is notable about Senegal's political stability and participation in international activities?
Senegal is one of the most stable democracies in Africa and has a long history of participating in international peacekeeping and regional mediation, with Senegal a stable democracy.
How has the presidency changed in Senegal since 2000?

In 2000, Abdoulaye Wade was elected president of Senegal and re-elected in 2007, and in 2012, Wade’s decision to run for a third presidential term sparked public backlash that led to his loss to current President Macky Sall in Senegal.
When was Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha first discovered by the Portuguese?

Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha was not discovered as a whole, but its individual islands were discovered by the Portuguese: Saint Helena in 1502, Ascension Island in 1503, and Tristan da Cunha in 1506.
What is Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha's status in the world?

Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha is a British Overseas Territory, and it is one of the most remote populated places in the world, consisting of Saint Helena, Ascension Island, and the island group of Tristan da Cunha.
What event led to the decline of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha's importance as a port of call?
The opening of the Suez Canal in 1869 led to the decline of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha's importance as a port of call.
How did the British Government improve accessibility to Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha?

The British Government committed to building an airport on Saint Helena in 2005, and after more than a decade of delays and construction, a commercial air service to South Africa via Namibia was inaugurated in 2017, serving Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha.
What is the significance of Ascension Island in Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha?

Ascension Island, part of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha, served as a provisioning station for the Royal Navy's West Africa Squadron on anti-slavery patrol, and it remains a critical refueling point in the air-bridge from the UK to the South Atlantic, hosting one of four dedicated ground antennas that assist in the operation of the Global Positioning System navigation system.
What role did Tristan da Cunha play in the British efforts to prevent Napoleon's rescue in Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha?

Tristan da Cunha, part of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha, was garrisoned by the British in 1816 to prevent any attempt to rescue Napoleon from Saint Helena, which is also part of Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha.
What is the history of population in Sierra Leone?

Sierra Leone has been continuously populated for at least 2,500 years, with the area now known as Sierra Leone being covered with dense jungle that allowed the region to remain relatively protected from invading West African empires, and Sierra Leone is home to a diverse population.
How was Islam introduced to Sierra Leone?
Traders introduced Sierra Leone to Islam, which occupies a central role in Sierra Leonean culture and history, and has had a lasting impact on Sierra Leone.
What was the role of the British in Sierra Leone's history?

The British set up a trading post near present-day Freetown in Sierra Leone in the 17th century, and later, Britain abolished the slave trade in 1807, with British ships delivering thousands of liberated Africans to Sierra Leone.
When did Sierra Leone become independent of the UK?
Sierra Leone became independent of the UK in 1961, marking a significant turning point in Sierra Leone's history.
What was the outcome of the civil war in Sierra Leone?

The civil war in Sierra Leone, launched by Sierra Leonean soldiers in 1991, caused tens of thousands of deaths and displaced more than 2 million people, about one third of Sierra Leone's population, before ending in 2002, with Sierra Leone emerging from the conflict.
What is the current state of democracy in Sierra Leone?

Since 1998, Sierra Leone has conducted democratic elections dominated by the two main political parties, the Sierra Leone People’s Party and the All People’s Congress party, with Sierra Leone holding free and fair elections, including the presidential election won by Julius Maada Bio of the Sierra Leone People’s Party in 2018 and again in June 2023, with Sierra Leone continuing to strengthen its democratic institutions.
What happened to Somalia in 1960?
In 1960, British Somaliland gained independence and joined with Italian Somaliland to form the Republic of Somalia, marking the beginning of Somalia as a unified nation.
How did Somalia function from 1960 until 1969?
Somalia functioned as a parliamentary democracy until 1969, when General Mohamed Siad Barre took control in a coup, beginning a 22-year socialist dictatorship in Somalia.
What led to the overthrow of General Mohamed SIAD Barre in Somalia?
Resistance to Siad’s socialist leadership, which was causing a rapid deterioration of Somalia, prompted allied clan militias to overthrow Siad in 1991, resulting in state collapse in Somalia.
What was the outcome of the international humanitarian mission in Somalia starting in 1993?
The international community largely withdrew from Somalia by 1995 after an incident that became known as Black Hawk Down, in which two US military helicopters were shot down in Mogadishu, Somalia.
How did Somalis in Somalia respond to the lack of international support?

Left largely to themselves, Somalis in Somalia established alternative governance structures, with some areas forming their own administrations, such as Somaliland and Puntland, while others developed localized institutions in Somalia.
What happened to the Islamic Courts Union in Somalia in 2006?

The Islamic Courts Union established order in many areas of central and southern Somalia, including Mogadishu, but was forced out when Ethiopia intervened militarily in 2006 on behalf of the Somali Transitional Federal Government in Somalia.
What is the current state of governance in Somalia?

Since 2012, Somalia has seen several interim regional administrations and three presidential elections, but significant governance and security problems remain because al-Shabaab still controls large portions of Somalia.
What ancient kingdoms existed in Sudan before the 11th century B.C.?

Sudan was the site of the Kingdom of Kerma until it was absorbed into the New Kingdom of Egypt, and later the Kingdom of Kush gained independence from Egypt, with Sudan the location of these kingdoms.
What happened to the Kingdom of Kush in Sudan?
The Kingdom of Kush in Sudan lasted in various forms until the middle of the 4th century A.D., after which the Nubians formed three Christian kingdoms of Nobatia, Makuria, and Alodia in Sudan.
How did Arab nomads influence Sudan between the 14th and 19th centuries?
Arab nomads settled much of Sudan between the 14th and 15th centuries, leading to extensive Islamization of Sudan between the 16th and 19th centuries.
What type of government was established in Sudan in 1899?
An agreement in 1899 set up a joint British-Egyptian government in Sudan, but it was effectively a British colony, with Sudan under British control.
What has dominated national politics in Sudan since gaining independence in 1956?
Military regimes favoring Islamic-oriented governments have dominated national politics in Sudan since Sudan gained independence from Anglo-Egyptian co-rule in 1956.
What was the outcome of the North/South Comprehensive Peace Agreement in 2005 for Sudan?

The final North/South Comprehensive Peace Agreement in 2005 granted the southern rebels autonomy for six years, followed by a referendum on independence for Southern Sudan, ultimately leading to South Sudan becoming independent in 2011, with Sudan and South Sudan having to normalize relations.
What conflict has Sudan faced since 2003?
Sudan has faced conflict in Darfur, Southern Kordofan, and Blue Nile starting in 2003, with Sudan the country affected by these conflicts.
Who currently serves as the de facto head of state and government of Sudan?
