General Abd-al-Fatah al-Burhan Abd-al-Rahman, the Chair of Sudan's Sovereign Council and Commander-in-Chief of the Sudanese Armed Forces, currently serves as de facto head of state and government of Sudan, presiding over a Sovereign Council consisting of military leaders, former armed opposition group representatives, and military-appointed civilians in Sudan.
What was the Togo region known as from the 16th to the 18th centuries?

The Togo region was known as 'The Slave Coast' from the 16th to the 18th centuries, as the coastal region became a major trading center for enslaved people, and this name was associated with the Togo area.
Who declared the Togo area a protectorate in 1884?
Germany declared the area a protectorate called Togoland, which included present-day Togo, in 1884, and this marked the beginning of German rule over Togo.
What happened to Togo after World War I?

After World War I, colonial rule over Togo was transferred to France, and Togo became French Togoland, which later became the independent country of Togo in 1960, with Togo gaining independence from France.
Who ruled Togo with a heavy hand for almost four decades?
Gen. Gnassingbe Eyadema ruled Togo with a heavy hand for almost four decades, after being installed as military ruler in 1967, and his rule had a significant impact on Togo.
What is the current state of the Rally of the Togolese People party in Togo?

The Rally of the Togolese People party, founded by Gen. Gnassingbe Eyadema, has been in power almost continually since 1967, with its successor, the Union for the Republic, maintaining a majority of seats in today's legislature in Togo.
Who became president of Togo after Gen. Gnassingbe EYADEMA's death in 2005?

Upon Gen. Gnassingbe Eyadema's death in 2005, the military installed his son, Faure Gnassingbe, as president of Togo, and then engineered his formal election two months later, marking the beginning of Faure Gnassingbe's rule over Togo.
What significant electoral event occurred in Togo in 2007?
Togo held its first relatively free and fair legislative elections in 2007, under the leadership of Faure Gnassingbe, and this marked an important step towards democratic reform in Togo.
What constitutional changes were made in Togo in 2019?

Constitutional changes in 2019 instituted a runoff system in presidential elections and established term limits in Togo, although these changes have done little to reduce the resentment many Togolese feel after more than 50 years of one-family rule in Togo.
When did Sao Tome and Principe achieve independence from Portugal?

Sao Tome and Principe achieved independence in 1975, after being discovered and colonized by Portugal in the late 15th century, and having a sugar-based economy that gave way to coffee and cocoa in the 19th century, all grown with African slave labor in Sao Tome and Principe.
What type of labor was used to grow crops in Sao Tome and Principe during the 19th century?

African slave labor was used to grow crops such as sugar, coffee, and cocoa in Sao Tome and Principe during the 19th century, with a form of this labor lingering into the 20th century in Sao Tome and Principe.
When did Sao Tome and Principe hold Sao Tome and Principe's first free elections?
Sao Tome and Principe held its first free elections in 1991, after democratic reforms were instituted in the late 1980s in Sao Tome and Principe.
What happened to the majority government of former Prime Minister Patrice TROVOADA in 2012 in Sao Tome and Principe?

In 2012, three opposition parties combined in a no-confidence vote to bring down the majority government of former Prime Minister Patrice Trovoada in Sao Tome and Principe, but legislative elections returned him to the office two years later in Sao Tome and Principe.
Who was elected president of Sao Tome and Principe in 2016 and 2021?
President Evaristo Carvalho was elected in 2016, and Carlos Vila Nova was elected president of Sao Tome and Principe in 2021, with both elections taking place in Sao Tome and Principe.
When did Patrice TROVOADA begin his fourth stint as prime minister of Sao Tome and Principe?
Patrice Trovoada began his fourth stint as prime minister of Sao Tome and Principe in 2022, after his party's victory in legislative elections in Sao Tome and Principe.
What empires have controlled Tunisia throughout history?

Tunisia has been controlled by many empires, including the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, Romans, Vandals, Byzantines, various Arab and Berber kingdoms, and Ottomans, which ruled Tunisia from the 16th to late-19th centuries, and Tunisia was also under French control from 1881.
When did Tunisia gain independence from France?
Tunisia was recognized as an independent state by France in 1956, after decades of agitation for independence following World War I, and Tunisia became an independent country with its own government.
Who was the first president of Tunisia and what was his political approach?

Tunisia's first president, Habib Bourguiba, established a strict one-party state in Tunisia, dominating the country for 31 years, repressing Islamic fundamentalism and establishing rights for women in Tunisia.
What led to the ousting of President Zine el Abidine BEN ALI in Tunisia?

Street protests in Tunis, Tunisia, over high unemployment, corruption, widespread poverty, and high food prices escalated into rioting, leading to the dismissal of the government and the flight of President Zine el Abidine Ben Ali from Tunisia in 2011.
How has Tunisia's government changed since the Arab Spring uprising?

Tunisia formed a national unity government after the ousting of President Ben Ali, and later held elections for a new Constituent Assembly, which drafted and ratified a new constitution in 2014, establishing a permanent government in Tunisia with parliamentary and presidential elections.
What changes were made to Tunisia's constitution in 2022?
Tunisians approved a new constitution through public referendum in 2022, expanding presidential powers in Tunisia and creating a new bicameral legislature in Tunisia.
What is notable about Tanzania's national parks and cultural heritage?

Tanzania contains some of Africa’s most iconic national parks and famous paleoanthropological sites, and its diverse cultural heritage reflects the multiple ethnolinguistic groups that live in Tanzania.
How did Tanzania's integration into trade networks affect the region?

Tanzania's long history of integration into trade networks spanning the Indian Ocean and the African interior led to the development of Swahili as a common language in much of east Africa and the introduction of Islam into the region of Tanzania.
What happened to the independent coastal trading posts in Tanzania after 1498?

A number of independent coastal and island trading posts in what is now Tanzania came under Portuguese control after 1498 when they began to take control of much of the coast and Indian Ocean trade in Tanzania.
What was the outcome of the series of local uprisings against the Portuguese in Tanzania?
The Portuguese were facing a series of local uprisings in Tanzania, and by 1700, the Sultanate of Oman had become the dominant power in the region after ousting the Portuguese.
How did Zanzibar, part of Tanzania, become a hub of Indian Ocean trade?

Zanzibar -- an archipelago off the coast that is now part of Tanzania -- became a hub of Indian Ocean trade, with Arab and Indian traders establishing and consolidating trade routes with communities in mainland Tanzania.
What was the result of the popular uprising in Zanzibar in 1964 in Tanzania?

In 1964, a popular uprising overthrew the Sultan in Zanzibar, which is part of Tanzania, and either killed or expelled many of the Arabs and Indians who had dominated the isles for more than 200 years.
When did Tanganyika, now part of Tanzania, gain independence from Great Britain?
Tanganyika, which is now part of Tanzania, gained independence from Great Britain in 1961.
What was the outcome of the combination of Tanganyika and Zanzibar in 1964 in Tanzania?
Later in 1964, Tanganyika and Zanzibar combined to form the United Republic of Tanzania, but Zanzibar retained considerable autonomy within Tanzania.
What is notable about the ethnic groups in Uganda?
Uganda has as many as 65 ethnic groups that speak languages from three of Africa’s four major linguistic families, with Uganda a country of great linguistic diversity.
How did the name of Uganda Uganda originate?
The country Uganda derives its name from the kingdom of Buganda, which was one of the large, centralized kingdoms that formed in the south due to fertile soils and regular rainfall.
What was the impact of British influence on Uganda?

Uganda was declared a British protectorate in 1894, and this influence expanded with the arrival of Christian missionaries and trade agreements, with Uganda's colonial boundaries grouping together a wide range of ethnic groups with different political systems and cultures, affecting Uganda.
What was the state of Uganda's economy and education system at independence?

Uganda gained independence in 1962 with one of the more developed economies and one of the strongest education systems in Sub-Saharan Africa, making Uganda one of the more promising newly independent countries in the region.
Who seized power in Uganda in 1971 and what were the consequences?
Idi Amin seized power in Uganda in 1971 through a military coup and led Uganda into economic ruin and rampant mass atrocities that killed as many as 500,000 civilians in Uganda.
What led to the invasion of Uganda by Tanzania in 1979?
Idi Amin’s annexation of Tanzanian territory in 1979 provoked Tanzania to invade Uganda, depose Amin, and install a coalition government in Uganda.
Who became president of Uganda in 1986 and what is he credited with?
Yoweri Museveni became president of Uganda in 1986 after his insurgency captured the capital, and Museveni is widely credited with restoring relative stability and economic growth to Uganda.
When did many of Burkina Faso's ethnic groups arrive in the region?
Many of Burkina Faso's ethnic groups arrived in the region between the 12th and 15th centuries, with the Gurma and Mossi peoples establishing several of the largest kingdoms in Burkina Faso.
What was the outcome of European competition for control of the region of Burkina Faso in the late 19th century?
France eventually conquered the area of Burkina Faso and established it as a French protectorate.
When did Burkina Faso achieve independence from France?
Burkina Faso achieved independence from France in 1960.
What was the result of Blaise Compaore's actions in 1987 in Burkina Faso?
In 1987, Blaise Compaore deposed the president of Burkina Faso, established a government, and ruled Burkina Faso for 27 years.
Who was elected president of Burkina Faso in 2015 and reelected in 2020?
Roch Marc Christian Kabore was elected president of Burkina Faso in 2015 and reelected in 2020, leading Burkina Faso until his overthrow.
What has been the impact of terrorist groups on Burkina Faso since 2016?

Terrorist groups, including groups affiliated with Al-Qa’ida and the Islamic State, began attacks in Burkina Faso in 2016, conducting attacks in the capital and displacing more than 2 million people in Burkina Faso by early 2023.
What are some of the problems faced by Burkina Faso in addition to terrorism?

In addition to terrorism, Burkina Faso faces a myriad of problems including high population growth, recurring drought, pervasive and perennial food insecurity, and limited natural resources, making it one of the world’s poorest countries, Burkina Faso.
What event occurred in Namibia in 1884?
Germany established a colony over most of the territory of Namibia in 1884. Namibia was occupied by various ethnic groups prior to this event.
How did South Africa initially occupy Namibia?
South Africa occupied the colony of Namibia, then known as German South West Africa, in 1915 during World War I, and Namibia was administered as a mandate by South Africa until after World War II.
When did the South-West Africa People's Organization launch a war of independence for Namibia?
The Marxist South-West Africa People's Organization launched a war of independence for the area that became Namibia in 1966, with the goal of gaining independence for Namibia.
When did Namibia gain independence from South Africa?
Namibia gained independence in 1990, after South Africa agreed to end its administration in accordance with a UN peace plan for the entire region of Namibia.
Which party has governed Namibia since Namibia's independence?

The South-West Africa People's Organization, or SWAPO, has governed Namibia since its independence in 1990, and although the party has dropped much of its Marxist ideology, SWAPO remains the governing party of Namibia.
Who was elected as the president of Namibia in 2014?
President Hage Geingob was elected in 2014 in a landslide victory in Namibia, replacing Hifikepunye Pohamba, who stepped down after serving two terms as the president of Namibia.
What is the location of Western Sahara?
Western Sahara is a non-self-governing territory on the northwest coast of Africa bordered by Morocco, Mauritania, and Algeria, with Western Sahara situated in this region.
What happened to Western Sahara after Spain withdrew in 1976?

After Spain withdrew from its former colony of Spanish Sahara in 1976, Morocco annexed the northern two-thirds of Western Sahara and later claimed the rest of Western Sahara in 1979, following Mauritania's withdrawal.
What is the current state of the conflict in Western Sahara?
A guerrilla war with the Polisario Front contesting Morocco's sovereignty over Western Sahara ended in a 1991 cease-fire and the establishment of a UN peacekeeping operation in Western Sahara.
What is the role of the UN in Western Sahara?
The UN sought to offer a choice to the peoples of Western Sahara between independence or integration into Morocco, with the UN establishing a peacekeeping operation in Western Sahara.
What separates the opposing forces in Western Sahara?

The approximately 1,600 km-long defensive sand berm, built by the Moroccans from 1980 to 1987 and running the length of Western Sahara, continues to separate the opposing forces, with Morocco controlling the roughly three-quarters of Western Sahara west of the berm.
What is the source of ethnic tensions in Western Sahara?
There are periodic ethnic tensions between the native Sahrawi population of Western Sahara and Moroccan immigrants in Western Sahara.
What is the current security presence in Western Sahara?
Morocco maintains a heavy security presence in Western Sahara.
When was the Swazi kingdom founded that would eventually become Eswatini?

The Swazi kingdom that would eventually become Eswatini was founded in the mid-18th century by a series of kings, including Mswati II, a 19th century ruler whose name was adopted for the country and its predominant ethnic group, in the area that is now Eswatini.
How was Eswatini administered from 1903 until Eswatini's independence?

Eswatini, then known as Swaziland, was administered as a UK high commission territory from 1903 until its independence in 1968, with the UK defining the kingdom's modern borders during the late-19th century in what is now Eswatini.
What change did King MSWATI III make to Eswatini's name in 2018 in Eswatini?
King Mswati III renamed the country from Swaziland to Eswatini in 2018 to reflect the name most commonly used by Eswatini's citizens, in Eswatini.
How did King MSWATI III respond to prodemocracy protests in 2021 in Eswatini?

In 2021, King Mswati III used security forces to suppress prodemocracy protests in Eswatini, and a national dialogue and reconciliation process agreed to in the wake of violence has not materialized in Eswatini.
What is notable about Eswatini's recognition of other countries?
Eswatini is the only country in Africa that recognizes Taiwan, making Eswatini unique in its diplomatic relations.
What is a significant challenge faced by Eswatini despite Eswatini's income classification?
Despite being classified as a lower-middle income country, Eswatini suffers from severe poverty, corruption, and high unemployment, affecting the lives of people in Eswatini.
What is Eswatini's status regarding HIV/AIDS prevalence?
Eswatini has the world's highest HIV/AIDS prevalence rate, although recent years have shown marked declines in new infections in Eswatini.
What groups settled in what is now Zambia around A.D. 300?

Bantu-speaking groups mainly from the Luba and Lunda Kingdoms in the Congo River Basin and from the Great Lakes region in East Africa settled in what is now Zambia, displacing and mixing with previous population groups in the region, including Zambia.
Which empire ruled large parts of Zambia from the 14th to 17th century?

The Mutapa Empire developed after the fall of Great Zimbabwe to the south in the 14th century and ruled the region, including large parts of Zambia, from the 14th to 17th century, before collapsing as a result of the growing slave trade and Portuguese incursions in Zambia.
How did British companies gain control of the region that is now Zambia?

In the 1880s, British companies began securing mineral and other economic concessions from local leaders in what is now Zambia, and the companies eventually claimed control of the region and incorporated it as the protectorate of Northern Rhodesia in 1911, which is now Zambia.
When did Zambia gain independence from the UK?
Zambia gained independence from the UK in 1964, under independence leader and first President Kenneth Kaunda, at which point Northern Rhodesia’s name was changed to Zambia.
What challenges did Zambia's economy face in the 1980s and 1990s?
In the 1980s and 1990s, Zambia's economy was hurt by declining copper prices, economic mismanagement, and a prolonged drought, affecting Zambia's overall economic situation.
Who won the presidential election in Zambia in 2006?
Levy Mwanawasa was reelected in 2006 in an election that was deemed free and fair in Zambia.
Who succeeded Levy MWANAWASA as president of Zambia after his death in 2008?
Upon his death in 2008, Levy Mwanawasa was succeeded by his vice president, Rupiah Banda, who won a special presidential byelection later that year in Zambia.
Who won the general elections in Zambia in 2011?
Michael Sata and the Patriotic Front (PF) won the general elections in Zambia in 2011, defeating Rupiah Banda and the MMD.
Who was elected president of Zambia in 2021?
Hakainde Hichilema was elected president of Zambia in 2021.
What indigenous people first inhabited the area that eventually became Zimbabwe?
The hunter-gatherer San people first inhabited the area that eventually became Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe was initially inhabited by these San people before other communities migrated to the area.
When did farming communities migrate to the area that is now Zimbabwe?
Farming communities migrated to the area that is now Zimbabwe around A.D. 500 during the Bantu expansion, and Shona-speaking societies began to develop in the Limpopo valley and Zimbabwean highlands.
What powerful trade-oriented Shona states succeeded the Kingdom of Mapungubwe in Zimbabwe?

A series of powerful trade-oriented Shona states succeeded the Kingdom of Mapungubwe in Zimbabwe, including the Kingdom of Zimbabwe, Kingdom of Mutapa, and the Rozwi Empire. The Rozwi Empire was one of the states that played a significant role in Zimbabwe.
Who conquered the area that is now Zimbabwe in 1838?

The Ndebele clan of Zulu King Mzilikazi eventually conquered the area that is now Zimbabwe in 1838 during the era of conflict and population displacement known as the Mfecane. Zimbabwe was conquered by the Ndebele clan during this time.
What led to the independence of Zimbabwe in 1980?

International diplomacy and an uprising by Black Zimbabweans led to biracial elections in 1979 and independence for Zimbabwe in 1980. Zimbabwe gained its independence after years of struggle and international pressure.
Who was the first prime minister and long-time ruler of Zimbabwe?

Robert Mugabe, who led the uprising and became the nation's first prime minister, was the country's only ruler from independence until 2017. Zimbabwe was ruled by Robert Mugabe for nearly four decades.
What event led to the resignation of Robert MUGABE as president of Zimbabwe in 2017?

A military intervention forced Robert Mugabe to resign as president of Zimbabwe in 2017, and Vice President Emmerson Mnangagwa became president. Zimbabwe saw a change in leadership after the military intervention.
When was the existence of Antarctica as a continent confirmed?
Antarctica was confirmed to be a continent in 1840, establishing that it was not merely a group of islands or an area of ocean, with Antarctica the continent in question.
What sparked an increase in scientific research in Antarctica?
Following World War II, Antarctica experienced an upsurge in scientific research, with several countries setting up stations, camps, and refuges to support research in Antarctica.
How do countries recognize territorial claims in Antarctica?
Most countries do not recognize the territorial claims made by some countries in Antarctica, with seven countries having made claims and two maintaining the basis for a claim in Antarctica.
What was established to form a legal framework for countries' activities in Antarctica?

An Antarctic Treaty was negotiated and signed in 1959, entering into force in 1961, to form a legal framework for countries' activities in Antarctica, without denying or recognizing existing territorial claims in Antarctica.
What protocols and conventions are relevant to governance in Antarctica?

The Environmental Protocol to the Antarctic Treaty and the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources are relevant to governance in Antarctica, with Antarctica the subject of these agreements.
What is unique about Bouvet Island's location?
Bouvet Island is recognized as the most remote island on Earth because it is furthest from any other point of land, being 1,639 km from Antarctica, making Bouvet Island the most isolated.
Who discovered Bouvet Island?
Bouvet Island was named after the French naval officer who discovered it in 1739, and later the British flag was raised on Bouvet Island in 1825.
Which country currently occupies and studies Bouvet Island?
Norway occupied Bouvet Island in 1927, and since then, Norway has run an automated meteorological station and studied foraging strategies and distribution of fur seals and penguins on Bouvet Island.
What happened to the meteorological station on Bouvet Island in 2006?
An earthquake weakened the station's foundation on Bouvet Island, causing it to be blown out to sea in a winter storm.
What did Norway establish on Bouvet Island in 2014?
Norway erected a new research station on Bouvet Island in 2014 that can hold six people for periods of two to four months, allowing for further research on Bouvet Island.
What designation did Norway give to Bouvet Island in 1971?
Norway designated Bouvet Island and the adjacent territorial waters as a nature reserve in 1971, protecting Bouvet Island's unique environment.
What happened to the Iles Eparses in 2007 in relation to the French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

In 2007, the Iles Eparses became an integral part of the French Southern and Antarctic Lands. The French Southern and Antarctic Lands now include the Iles Eparses as one of its five administrative districts, which consists of five scattered tropical islands around Madagascar.
What is the composition of the French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

The French Southern and Antarctic Lands are divided into five administrative districts, including two archipelagos, the Iles Crozet and Iles Kerguelen, a district composed of two volcanic islands, Ile Saint-Paul and Ile Amsterdam, the Iles Eparses, and the Antarctic portion, Adelie Land, which is a thin slice of the Antarctic continent claimed by the French in 1840.
What is the status of the population in the French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

The French Southern and Antarctic Lands contain no permanent inhabitants and are visited only by researchers studying the native fauna, scientists at the various scientific stations, fishermen, and military personnel.
What is the history of Ile Amsterdam in the French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

Ile Amsterdam was discovered but not named in 1522 by the Spanish, and it was claimed by France in 1843. A French meteorological station was established on the island in 1949 and is still in use. (French Southern and Antarctic Lands).
What is the history of Ile Saint-Paul in the French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

Ile Saint-Paul was claimed by France since 1893, and it was a fishing industry center from 1843 to 1914. The island also had a spiny lobster cannery established in 1928, but it went bankrupt in 1931. (French Southern and Antarctic Lands).
What is the composition of the Iles Crozet in the French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

The Iles Crozet is a large archipelago formed from the Crozet Plateau, and it is divided into two main groups: L'Occidental and L'Oriental. The French Southern and Antarctic Lands include the Iles Crozet, which were discovered and claimed by France in 1772.
What is the status of the Iles Kerguelen in the French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

The Iles Kerguelen is a group of islands in the French Southern and Antarctic Lands, discovered in 1772, and it consists of one large island and about 300 smaller islands. A permanent group of 50 to 100 scientists resides at the main base at Port-aux-Francais in the Iles Kerguelen.
What is the status of Adelie Land in the French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

Adelie Land is the Antarctic portion of the French Southern and Antarctic Lands, which is a thin slice of the Antarctic continent discovered and claimed by the French in 1840. The US Government does not recognize Adelie Land as a French dependency.
When was Heard Island discovered by American sailor John Heard in relation to Heard Island and McDonald Islands?
Heard Island and McDonald Islands include Heard Island, which was discovered by American sailor John Heard in 1853, as part of the territory that now comprises Heard Island and McDonald Islands.
What happened to the seal population on Heard Island and McDonald Islands by 1877?
By 1877, most of the seals on Heard Island and McDonald Islands were killed due to sealers harvesting elephant seal oil on the islands of Heard Island and McDonald Islands.
Who formally claimed Heard Island and McDonald Islands in 1910?
The UK formally claimed Heard Island and McDonald Islands in 1910, adding the islands to the UK's territories, which later included Heard Island and McDonald Islands being transferred to Australia.
Why did Australia close the research station on Heard Island in 1954 in the context of Heard Island and McDonald Islands?

Australia closed the research station on Heard Island in 1954, as part of the management of Heard Island and McDonald Islands, when it opened a new research station on the Antarctic continent, focusing research efforts elsewhere in relation to Heard Island and McDonald Islands.
What happened to McDonald Island in 1992 and 1996 in relation to Heard Island and McDonald Islands?

McDonald Island, part of Heard Island and McDonald Islands, became an active volcano in 1992 and doubled in size after an eruption in 1996, significantly altering the island within Heard Island and McDonald Islands.
What recognition did Heard Island and McDonald Islands receive in 1997?
Heard Island and McDonald Islands were named a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1997, recognizing the islands' unique features and biodiversity within Heard Island and McDonald Islands.
What is the primary use of Heard Island and McDonald Islands today?

Heard Island and McDonald Islands are primarily used for research, with limited fishing permitted in the surrounding waters, supporting conservation efforts in the area of Heard Island and McDonald Islands.
When was the largest island in American Samoa settled?

American Samoa's largest island, Tutuila, was settled by 1000 B.C., and the island served as a refuge for exiled chiefs and defeated warriors from the other Samoan islands, including those now part of American Samoa.
What event occurred in American Samoa in 1722?
In 1722, Dutch explorer Jacob Roggeveen was the first European to sail through the Manu’a Islands, which are now part of American Samoa.
Why did American and European traders favor the port in Apia over Pago Pago in American Samoa?
American and European traders tended to favor the port in Apia over the smaller and less-developed Pago Pago on Tutuila in American Samoa.
What was the outcome of the dispute over control of the Samoan archipelago in 1899 for American Samoa?

In 1899, Germany and the US agreed to divide the Samoan islands, and American Samoa was formed as a result, with Germany and the US dividing the islands, while the UK withdrew its claims in exchange for parts of the Solomon Islands, resulting in the current composition of American Samoa.
When was the territory of American Samoa officially named?
The territory was officially named American Samoa in 1911, and American Samoa has retained this name since then.
What significant event occurred in American Samoa in 1967?
In 1967, American Samoa adopted a constitution that provides significant protections for traditional Samoan land-tenure rules, language, and culture in American Samoa.
What is the current status of people born in American Samoa?
People born in American Samoa are US nationals rather than US citizens, and American Samoa officially remains an unorganized territory of the US.
When did Aboriginal Australians arrive in Australia?
Aboriginal Australians arrived on the continent at least 60,000 years ago and developed complex hunter-gatherer societies and oral histories in Australia.
Who were the first Europeans to land in Australia?
Dutch navigators led by Abel Tasman were the first Europeans to land in Australia in 1606, and they mapped the western and northern coasts of Australia.
What was the significance of James COOK's voyage to Australia?
In 1770, Englishman James Cook sailed to the east coast of Australia, named it New South Wales, and claimed it for Great Britain, which later led to the establishment of penal colonies in Australia.
How did European settlement affect Aboriginal Australians in Australia?

As Europeans began settling areas away from the coasts in Australia, they came into more direct contact with Aboriginal Australians, and Europeans also cleared land for agriculture, impacting Aboriginal Australians’ ways of life in Australia.
What led to the reduction of the Aboriginal Australian population in Australia?

Issues such as disease, and a policy in the 1900s that forcefully removed Aboriginal children from their parents in Australia, reduced the Aboriginal Australian population from more than 700,000 pre-European contact to a low of 74,000 in 1933 in Australia.
When did Australia become the Commonwealth of Australia?
In 1901, the colonies in Australia federated and became the Commonwealth of Australia.
What was Australia's contribution to Allied efforts during World War I?
Australia contributed more than 400,000 troops to Allied efforts during World War I.
What changes occurred in Australia's immigration policies in the 1970s?
In the 1970s, racial policies that prevented most non-Whites from immigrating to Australia were removed, greatly increasing Asian immigration to Australia.
When did British explorers first see Cartier Island and Ashmore Reef in the area around Ashmore and Cartier Islands?
British explorers were the first Europeans to see Cartier Island and Ashmore Reef in 1800 and 1811, respectively, in the area around Ashmore and Cartier Islands.
What was the outcome of the dispute between the UK and the US over access to Ashmore Reef in Ashmore and Cartier Islands?
The UK disputed US access to Ashmore Reef in Ashmore and Cartier Islands and formally annexed it in 1878.
When did Australia accept Ashmore and Cartier Islands as part of Western Australia?
Australia accepted Ashmore and Cartier Islands as part of Western Australia in 1934, after the UK transferred the islands to Australia in 1931.
How were Ashmore Reef and Cartier Island in Ashmore and Cartier Islands used during World War II?
During World War II, Cartier Island in Ashmore and Cartier Islands was used as a bombing range.
What agreement did Australia and Indonesia sign in 1974 regarding Ashmore and Cartier Islands?

Australia and Indonesia signed a memorandum of understanding in 1974 to allow Indonesian fishermen to continue fishing around Ashmore and Cartier Islands, visit the graves of past fishermen, replenish their fresh water, and shelter in the West Island Lagoon of Ashmore Reef in Ashmore and Cartier Islands.
Why did Australia declare Ashmore and Cartier Islands to be outside the Australian migration zone in 2001?

Australia declared Ashmore and Cartier Islands to be outside the Australian migration zone in 2001 because the islands were a popular first point of contact for migrants and refugees seeking to enter Australia.
When did settlers from Papua first arrive on the Solomon Islands?

The Solomon Islands were first settled by people from Papua around 30,000 years ago, and later the Solomon Islands saw the arrival of Austronesian settlers about 6,000 years ago, with the two groups mixing extensively in the Solomon Islands.
What was the outcome of the Spanish attempt to create a permanent settlement on the Solomon Islands in the late 1500s?

The Spanish attempt to create a permanent European settlement on the Solomon Islands in the late 1500s failed, and the Solomon Islands remained free of European contact until a British explorer arrived in 1767.
How did the UK and Germany divide control of the Solomon Islands in the late 19th century?

In the late 19th century, Germany declared a protectorate over the northern Solomon Islands in 1885, while the UK established a protectorate over the southern Solomon Islands in 1893, with Germany later transferring its islands to the UK in 1899, in exchange for the UK relinquishing all claims in Samoa, resulting in the UK controlling the entire Solomon Islands.
What significant event occurred on the Solomon Islands during World War II?

The Solomon Islands were invaded by Japan in 1942, and the Guadalcanal Campaign, which took place from August 1942 to February 1943, proved a turning point in the Pacific theater of WWII, with the fighting destroying large parts of the Solomon Islands.
When did the Solomon Islands gain independence?

The Solomon Islands were granted self-government in 1976 and gained independence two years later, in 1978, under Prime Minister Sir Peter Kenilorea, marking a significant milestone for the Solomon Islands.
What led to the request for international assistance by the Solomon Islands in 2003?

The Solomon Islands requested international assistance to reestablish law and order in 2003, following a period of civil unrest, including a civil war in 1999, and the subsequent failure of the government to maintain stability, which affected the Solomon Islands.
What event occurred in Honiara in 2006 in Solomon Islands?

In 2006, riots broke out in Honiara, the city of the Solomon Islands, and the city’s Chinatown was burned amid allegations that the prime minister took money from China, affecting the Solomon Islands.
What sparked rioting and looting in Honiara in 2021 in Solomon Islands?

In 2021, a small group of protestors, mostly from the island of Malaita, approached parliament to lodge a petition calling for the removal of the prime minister and more development in Malaita, and when police fired tear gas into the crowd, it sparked rioting and looting in Honiara, the city of the Solomon Islands.
When did Austronesian people settle the Northern Mariana Islands?
Austronesian people settled the Northern Mariana Islands around 1500 B.C. and became the indigenous Chamorro, with the Northern Mariana Islands being their home.
How did Spain's colonization affect the indigenous population of the Northern Mariana Islands?

Spain's brutal repression of the Chamorro, along with new diseases and intermittent warfare, reduced the indigenous population of the Northern Mariana Islands by about 90% in the 1700s, with the Northern Mariana Islands being severely impacted.
What happened to the Chamorro population of the Northern Mariana Islands during the Spanish colonization?

The Chamorro from the Northern Mariana Islands were forced to resettle on Guam by Spain, and by the time they returned to the Northern Mariana Islands, many other Micronesians had already settled on their islands.
Who administered the Northern Mariana Islands after Spain ceded Guam to the US?

The Northern Mariana Islands were sold to Germany under the German-Spanish Treaty of 1899, and Germany administered the territory from German New Guinea, with the Northern Mariana Islands being under German control.
What was the impact of Japan's administration on the Northern Mariana Islands?

Japan focused on sugar production and brought in thousands of Japanese laborers to the Northern Mariana Islands, who quickly outnumbered the Chamorro on the islands, with the Northern Mariana Islands being a major site for Japanese economic activities.
How did the US acquire control of the Northern Mariana Islands?

The US captured the Northern Mariana Islands in 1944 after the Battle of Saipan, and later administered them as part of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands, with the Northern Mariana Islands being under US administration.
What is the current status of the Northern Mariana Islands?

The Northern Mariana Islands came under US sovereignty as the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in 1986, with islanders being granted US citizenship, and the Northern Mariana Islands being a US territory.
When did the Northern Mariana Islands elect a nonvoting delegate to the US Congress?
The Northern Mariana Islands became the final US territory to elect a nonvoting delegate to the US Congress in 2009, with the Northern Mariana Islands having representation in the US Congress.
When were the Coral Sea Islands first charted?
The Coral Sea Islands were first charted in 1803. The Coral Sea Islands were too small to host permanent human habitation at that time.
What attempts were made on the Coral Sea Islands in the 1870s and 1880s?
The Coral Sea Islands saw attempts at guano mining in the 1870s and 1880s, but these were soon abandoned.
When did the Coral Sea Islands become an Australian territory?
The Coral Sea Islands became an Australian territory in 1969, with the boundaries being extended in 1997 for the Coral Sea Islands.
What kind of staff has operated on the Willis Islets since 1921 in the Coral Sea Islands?
A small meteorological staff has operated on the Willis Islets since 1921 in the Coral Sea Islands.
What features do several other islands in the Coral Sea Islands host?

Several other islands in the Coral Sea Islands host unmanned weather stations, beacons, and lighthouses, with much of the territory lying within national marine nature reserves for the Coral Sea Islands.
When did Polynesians from Tahiti first settle the Cook Islands?
Polynesians from Tahiti were probably the first people to settle Rarotonga, the largest of the Cook Islands, around A.D. 900, and over time, the Cook Islands were also settled by Samoans and Tongans.
What was the relationship like between the different islands of the Cook Islands prior to European contact?

Prior to European contact, there was considerable travel and trade between inhabitants of the different islands and atolls of the Cook Islands, but they were not united in a single political entity in the Cook Islands.
Who were the first Europeans to spot the Cook Islands?
Spanish navigators were the first Europeans to spot the northern Cook Islands in 1595, and the Cook Islands were later named after British explorer James Cook by Russian mapmakers in the 1820s.
Why did the Rarotongans of the Cook Islands ask the UK for protectorate status?
Rarotongans of the Cook Islands asked the UK for protectorate status in the 1840s and 1860s, fearing France would militarily occupy the Cook Islands as it did in Tahiti.
What is the current relationship between the Cook Islands and New Zealand?

The Cook Islands is in free association with New Zealand, which is responsible for the defense and foreign affairs of the Cook Islands, and the Cook Islands has a great deal of local autonomy and is an independent member of international organizations.
When did the Cook Islands gain self-governing status from New Zealand?

New Zealand granted the Cook Islands self-governing status in 1965, after the Cook Islands had been a protectorate since 1888, when Queen Makea Takau of Rarotonga formally petitioned for protectorate status and the UK reluctantly agreed.
What is the history of human settlement in the Federated States of Micronesia?

The first humans arrived in what is now the Federated States of Micronesia in the second millennium B.C. The different states that compose the Federated States of Micronesia, including Chuuk, Kosrae, Pohnpei, and Yap, have their own unique history and cultural traditions.
What significant event occurred in Pohnpei, Federated States of Micronesia, in the 800s A.D.?
In the 800s A.D., construction of the artificial islets at the Nan Madol complex in Pohnpei, Federated States of Micronesia, began, with the main architecture being built around 1200.
How did the society of Yap, Federated States of Micronesia, become organized?
Yap's society, in the Federated States of Micronesia, became strictly hierarchical, with chiefs receiving tributes from islands up to 1,100 km away.
What was the result of Spanish exploration in the Federated States of Micronesia?
Spain began exerting nominal, but not day-to-day, control over some of the islands in the Federated States of Micronesia, which they named the Caroline Islands, in the 1600s.
What event occurred in the Federated States of Micronesia in 1899?
In 1899, Spain sold all of the Federated States of Micronesia to Germany.
What was the outcome of World War II for the Federated States of Micronesia?
During WWII, Japan built military bases across most of the islands in the Federated States of Micronesia and headquartered their Pacific naval operations in Chuuk, but the US bombed Chuuk in 1944.
What change occurred in the administration of the Federated States of Micronesia in 1947?
In 1947, the Federated States of Micronesia came under US administration as part of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.
What significant event occurred in the Federated States of Micronesia in 1979?
In 1979, Chuuk, Kosrae, Pohnpei, and Yap in the Federated States of Micronesia ratified the FSM Constitution and declared independence.
When were the Marquesas Islands in French Polynesia first settled?
The Marquesas Islands in French Polynesia were first settled around 200 B.C. French Polynesia's Marquesas Islands have a long history, with settlement occurring around this time.
What was the significance of Raiatea in the Society Islands of French Polynesia?

Raiatea in the Society Islands of French Polynesia became a center for religion and culture, and exploration of the other islands emanated from Raiatea, leading to small permanent settlements in all the island groups of French Polynesia by 1000.
Who was the first European to see the islands of French Polynesia?
Ferdinand Magellan was the first European to see the islands of French Polynesia in 1520, marking the beginning of European exploration of French Polynesia.
How did France gain control over Tahiti and French Polynesia's possessions in French Polynesia?

King Pomare V of French Polynesia ceded Tahiti and its possessions to France in 1880, changing its status into a colony, and France then claimed the Gambier Islands and Tuamotu Archipelago, incorporating all five island groups into its establishments in Oceania, which is now part of French Polynesia.
What was the outcome of the 1958 constitutional vote in French Polynesia?
In 1958, 64% of voters in French Polynesia chose to stay part of France when they approved a new constitution, indicating a desire for French Polynesia to remain associated with France.
What was the status of French Polynesia changed to in 2003?
French Polynesia was converted into an overseas collectivity in 2003, and later renamed an overseas territory in 2004, reflecting a change in the status of French Polynesia.
Why was French Polynesia relisted on the UN List of Non-Self-Governing Territories in 2013?

French Polynesia was relisted on the UN List of Non-Self-Governing Territories in 2013, indicating that French Polynesia is still subject to French oversight and has not yet achieved full independence.
When was Guam settled by Austronesian people?
Guam was settled by Austronesian people around 1500 B.C., and these people became the indigenous Chamorro, with Guam influenced by later migrations.
How did Spain's colonization affect the indigenous population of Guam?

Spain's brutal repression of the Chamorro, along with new diseases and intermittent warfare, reduced the indigenous population of Guam from more than 100,000 to less than 5,000 by the 1700s, with Guam significantly impacted.
What role did Guam serve for Spain in the 16th century?
Guam served as a refueling stop for ships between Mexico and the Philippines, leading to Spain claiming the island in 1565, with Guam a strategic location.
What event led to the US Navy occupying Guam in 1898?
The US Navy occupied Guam during the 1898 Spanish-American War, with Guam set up with a military administration, and the US Navy opposing local control of government on Guam.
How did Japan's invasion affect Guam in 1941?
Japan invaded Guam in 1941 and instituted a repressive regime on Guam, with Guam under Japanese control until the US recapture in 1944.
What is the current status of Guam in relation to the US?

Guam is an unincorporated organized US territory, with US citizenship granted to all Chamorro, and the US military holding about 29% of Guam's land, with Guam an important location for US bases in the Pacific.
What was the outcome of the 1982 referendum on Guam's status?

In a referendum in 1982, more than 75% of voters on Guam chose closer relations with the US over independence, although no change in status was made because of disagreements on the future right of Chamorro self-determination on Guam.
When was Christmas Island named and what was the reason for Christmas Island's naming?
Christmas Island was named for the day of its rediscovery in 1643, after Europeans initially sighted it in 1615, and the name commemorates this day of rediscovery.
What led to the UK annexing Christmas Island in 1888?
The discovery of phosphate on Christmas Island in 1887 led to the UK annexing it the following year, in 1888.
Who were brought to Christmas Island to work the mines in 1898?
In 1898, 200 Chinese indentured servants were brought to Christmas Island to work the mines, along with Malays, Sikhs, and a small number of Europeans.
What happened to Christmas Island during World War II?
Japan invaded Christmas Island in 1942, but islanders sabotaged Japanese mining operations, making the mines relatively unproductive on Christmas Island.
Why was the phosphate mine on Christmas Island closed in 1987?
The phosphate mine on Christmas Island was closed in 1987 because of environmental concerns, and Australia has rejected several efforts to reopen the mine on Christmas Island.
What was built on Christmas Island in 2001 and what was Christmas Island's purpose?

In 2001, Australia declared Christmas Island to be outside the Australian migration zone and built an immigration detention center on Christmas Island, which was used to detain asylum seekers claiming refugee status on Australian territory, specifically Christmas Island.
What was the immigration detention center on Christmas Island used for in 2020?
In 2020, the immigration detention center on Christmas Island served as a coronavirus quarantine facility for Australian citizens evacuated from China, on Christmas Island.
When did voyagers from Samoa first settle on Niue?

Voyagers from Samoa first settled on Niue around A.D. 900, and Niue was heavily influenced by Samoan customs, including the formation of an island-wide elected kingship system in the early 1700s, which impacted Niue.
What was the main factor contributing to conflict on Niue?
Niue had only one reliable source of fresh water, which led to high conflict on the island, particularly among the Niuean population.
How did British explorer James Cook interact with Niue?

British explorer James Cook landed on Niue in 1774 and named it Savage Island because of the Niueans' hostility towards him, which reflected the initial interactions between Niue and foreign visitors.
What role did missionaries play in Niue's development?

Missionaries arrived in Niue in 1830 and, despite initial difficulties, eventually helped convert the Niuean population and establish the first parliament in 1849, which significantly impacted Niue's development and governance.
What is Niue's current relationship with New Zealand?

Niue is in free association with New Zealand, which is responsible for defense and foreign affairs, and although Niue became internally self-governing in 1974, New Zealand still plays a significant role in Niue's international relations.
When was Niue recognized as a sovereign and independent state by the US?
The US recognized Niue as a sovereign and independent state in September 2023, marking a significant development in Niue's international status and recognition.
When did Polynesians live on Norfolk Island?
Norfolk Island was inhabited by Polynesians between 1200 and 1500, but the remote Norfolk Island was uninhabited by the time British explorer James Cook landed on the island in 1774.
What were the outcomes of the British attempts to establish Norfolk Island as a penal colony?
The two British attempts at establishing Norfolk Island as a penal colony were ultimately abandoned, with the first attempt taking place from 1788-1814 and the second from 1825-55 on Norfolk Island.
Why were Pitcairn Islanders relocated to Norfolk Island in 1856?
Almost 200 Pitcairn Islanders were relocated to Norfolk Island in 1856 because of overcrowding on the Pitcairn Islands, and most of these Pitcairn Islanders settled permanently on Norfolk Island.
What was the impact of World War II on Norfolk Island?
During World War II, Norfolk Island was an airbase and an important refueling stop in the South Pacific, highlighting the strategic importance of Norfolk Island.
How did Norfolk Island's relationship with Australia change in 1979?
After an appeal to the UN, Australia granted limited self-government to Norfolk Island in 1979, allowing Norfolk Island to have a degree of autonomy.
What changes were made to Norfolk Island's autonomy in 2015 and 2016?
Australia abolished the Norfolk Island Legislative Assembly in 2015 and reduced Norfolk Island's autonomy in 2016, significantly impacting the governance of Norfolk Island.
What is the current state of governance on Norfolk Island?

Most services on Norfolk Island are provided by a mix of the Australian Capital Territory and the states of New South Wales and Queensland, and as of 2024, the Australian Government was working with Norfolk Island to establish a new local governing body for Norfolk Island.
When did Austronesian speakers from the Solomon Islands first settle Vanuatu?
Austronesian speakers from the Solomon Islands first settled Vanuatu around 2000 B.C. Vanuatu was initially inhabited by these speakers who migrated from the Solomon Islands.
What event occurred in Vanuatu in 1606?
In 1606, a Portuguese explorer was the first European to see Vanuatu's Banks Islands and Espiritu Santo, setting up a short-lived settlement on the latter, in Vanuatu.
How did European planters affect the population of Vanuatu in the 1860s?
European planters in Australia, Fiji, New Caledonia, and Samoa needed labor and kidnapped almost half the adult males on the islands of Vanuatu to work as indentured servants.
What agreement was made between France and the UK regarding Vanuatu in 1878?
France and the UK agreed that the New Hebrides, now known as Vanuatu, would be neutral in 1878, and later established a joint naval commission in 1887 to administer the islands of Vanuatu.
What was the result of the UK-France condominium in Vanuatu?

The UK-France condominium to jointly administer the islands of Vanuatu was created in 1906, but the arrangement was dysfunctional, and the UK used France’s initial defeat in World War II to assert greater control over Vanuatu.
How did the US presence in Vanuatu during World War II affect the island?

During World War II, the US stationed up to 50,000 soldiers in Vanuatu, and after they withdrew in 1945, they sold their equipment, leading to the rise of political and religious movements known as 'cargo cults' in Vanuatu.
When was independence granted to Vanuatu?

Independence was granted to Vanuatu in 1980 under English-speaking Prime Minister Walter Lini, after elections were held in 1974, and the UK and France agreed to move the condominium toward independence.
What was the result of the Nagriamel Movement in Vanuatu?

The Nagriamel Movement, with support from French-speaking landowners in Vanuatu, declared the island of Espiritu Santo independent from Vanuatu, but the short-lived state was dissolved 12 weeks later, and Vanuatu remained a unified nation.
What was the state of Nauru's population after the civil war in 1878?
Nauru's population was reduced by more than a third after the civil war in 1878, with Nauru severely affected by the conflict.
How did Germany annex Nauru in 1888?
Germany forcibly annexed Nauru in 1888 by holding the 12 Nauruan chiefs under house arrest until they consented to the annexation, giving Germany control over Nauru.
What was the outcome of the discovery of phosphate in Nauru in 1900?

The discovery of phosphate in Nauru in 1900 led to heavy mining, but Nauru and Nauruans earned only about one tenth of one percent of the profits from the phosphate deposits, with the majority of the profits going elsewhere.
What was the offer made by Australian Prime Minister Robert MENZIES to Nauruans in 1962?

Australian Prime Minister Robert Menzies offered to resettle all Nauruans on Curtis Island in Queensland in 1962, but Nauruans rejected the plan and opted for independence, which was achieved in 1968, allowing Nauru to self-govern.
What is the current state of the Nauru Regional Processing Center?

The Nauru Regional Processing Center, an offshore refugee detention facility, was reopened in 2012 and remains the Government of Nauru's largest source of income, with Australia agreeing to continue funding it for two years and restarting settling asylees in the center in mid-2023, supporting Nauru's economy.
When did Polynesians settle New Zealand?
New Zealand was settled by Polynesians between the late 1200s and the mid-1300s, and they called the land Aotearoa, which is now in widespread use as the local Maori name for New Zealand.
What led to intermittent fighting between different Maori tribes in New Zealand?
Competition for land and resources led to intermittent fighting between different Maori tribes in New Zealand as large game became extinct by the 1500s.
Who was the first European to see the islands of New Zealand?
Dutch explorer Abel Tasman was the first European to see the islands of New Zealand in 1642, but he left after an encounter with local Maori in New Zealand.
Why did the majority of Maori chiefs sign the Treaty of Waitangi with the British in New Zealand?
The majority of Maori chiefs signed the Treaty of Waitangi with the British in New Zealand in 1840, fearing an impending French settlement and takeover of New Zealand.
What was the outcome of the series of wars between Europeans and Maori tribes in New Zealand?
The series of wars between Europeans and various Maori tribes in New Zealand from the 1840s to the 1870s, along with disease, halved the Maori population in New Zealand.
When did New Zealand change New Zealand's status to an independent dominion?
New Zealand changed its status to an independent dominion in 1907, after initially expressing interest in joining independence talks with Australia but ultimately opting against it.
What was New Zealand's contribution to the World Wars?
New Zealand provided more than 100,000 troops during each World War, many of whom fought as part of the Australia and New Zealand Army Corps (ANZAC) in New Zealand.
What is a key challenge for New Zealand in the Pacific region?
A key challenge for New Zealand is balancing concerns over China’s growing influence in the Pacific region with its role as New Zealand's largest export destination.
Who were the first settlers of the Pitcairn Islands?
Polynesians were the first settlers on the four tiny islands that are now called the Pitcairn Islands, but all four were uninhabited by the time Europeans discovered the Pitcairn Islands in 1606.
What event led to the settlement of the Pitcairn Islands by Europeans?

The Pitcairn Islands were settled by Europeans after Fletcher Christian led a mutiny on the HMS Bounty in 1789 and landed on the Pitcairn Islands with eight other mutineers and their Tahitian companions.
When did the Pitcairn Islands become an official British colony?
The Pitcairn Islands became an official British colony in 1838, with the British governing the Pitcairn Islands as a colony.
Why were the residents of the Pitcairn Islands relocated to Norfolk Island in 1856?
The British relocated all the residents of the Pitcairn Islands to Norfolk Island in 1856 because the population of 193 was too high for the Pitcairn Islands.
What happened to the population of the Pitcairn Islands after several families returned from Norfolk Island?

After several families returned to the Pitcairn Islands in 1858 and 1864, the island's population increased to 43, and almost all of the current population of the Pitcairn Islands are descendants of these returnees.
How has the population of the Pitcairn Islands changed since Pitcairn Islands's peak in 1937?

The population of the Pitcairn Islands peaked at 233 in 1937, but has since thinned due to outmigration, primarily to New Zealand, with only two children born between 1986 and 2012 on the Pitcairn Islands.
When did humans arrive in the Palauan archipelago?
Humans arrived in the Palauan archipelago from Southeast Asia around 1000 B.C. and developed a complex, highly organized matrilineal society in Palau where high-ranking women picked the chiefs.
What was the role of Spain in Palau in the 18th and 19th centuries?
Spain gained some influence in the islands of Palau and administered them from the Philippines during the 18th and 19th centuries, with occasional visits from whalers and traders.
Who seized Palau in 1914 and what happened afterwards?
Japan seized Palau in 1914, and was later granted a League of Nations mandate to administer the islands in 1920, making Koror the capital of its South Seas Mandate in 1922 in Palau.
What significant event occurred in Palau during World War II?
The US invasion of the island of Peleliu in Palau was one of the bloodiest island fights of the Pacific War in 1944.
What is Palau's stance on nuclear issues as stated in Palau's constitution?
Palau adopted its own constitution in 1981, which stated that Palau was a nuclear-free country.
What agreement did Palau sign with the US in 1982?

Palau signed a Compact of Free Association with the US in 1982, which granted Palau financial assistance and access to many US domestic programs in exchange for exclusive US military access and defense responsibilities in Palau.
What measures has Palau taken to protect marine resources?

Palau has taken several measures to protect marine resources, including banning commercial shark fishing and creating the world’s first shark sanctuary in 2011, and expanding its fishing prohibition to include 80% of its exclusive economic zone in 2020 in Palau.
When did humans first arrive in the Marshall Islands?
Humans arrived in the Marshall Islands in the first millennium B.C. and gradually created permanent settlements on the various atolls in the Marshall Islands.
How did early inhabitants of the Marshall Islands navigate between atolls?
The early inhabitants of the Marshall Islands were skilled navigators who frequently traveled between atolls using stick charts to map the islands in the Marshall Islands.
Who formally claimed the Marshall Islands in 1592?
Spain formally claimed the Marshall Islands in 1592, which later became part of the Marshall Islands' history under Spanish claim.
What was the outcome for the Marshall Islands when Japan seized them in 1914?
Japan seized the Marshall Islands in 1914 and was later granted a League of Nations Mandate to administer the Marshall Islands in 1920.
What event led to the US capturing the Marshall Islands during World War II?
The US captured the Marshall Islands in heavy fighting during World War II, resulting in the Marshall Islands coming under US administration as part of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands.
What was the impact of nuclear tests on the population of the Marshall Islands?

Between 1946 and 1958, the US conducted 67 nuclear tests in the Marshall Islands, leading to the resettlement of populations from Bikini and Enewetak Atolls, and the evacuation of people from Ailinginae, Rongelap, and Utrik Atolls in the Marshall Islands due to nuclear fallout.
When did the Marshall Islands declare independence under President Amata Kabua?

In 1979, the Marshall Islands drafted a constitution separate from the rest of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands and declared independence under President Amata Kabua, a paramount chief of the Marshall Islands.
When did the first humans arrive in Tonga?
The first humans arrived in Tonga around 1000 B.C. Tonga's early history began with this initial settlement.
What was the role of the Tu’i Tonga in Tonga by A.D. 950?
By A.D. 950, the Tu’i Tonga, or Tongan king, had a highly centralized role in Tonga's politics, with significant influence over the islands.
What event marked the beginning of the decline of the Tongan Empire?
The Tongan Empire began to decline in the 1300s, with civil wars, a military defeat to Samoa, and internal political strife affecting Tonga.
How did the administration of Tonga change by the mid-1500s?
By the mid-1500s, day-to-day administration of Tonga was transferred to a new position occupied by ethnic Tongans, while some Tu’i Tongans were ethnic Samoan.
What significant event occurred in Tonga in 1845?
In 1845, a low-ranking chief from Ha’apai was crowned King George Tupou I, establishing the only still-extant Polynesian monarchy in Tonga.
What was the outcome of King George TUPOU I's reign for Tonga?
During King George Tupou I's reign, Tonga became a unified and independent country with a modern constitution, legal code, and administrative structure, recognizing Tonga as a sovereign nation.
What agreement did King George TUPOU II enter into with the UK in 1900 regarding Tonga?
King George Tupou II agreed to enter a protectorate agreement with the UK in 1900, which meant Tonga would have a degree of autonomy but also be subject to British influence and protection.
When did Tonga regain full control of Tonga's domestic and foreign affairs?
Tonga regained full control of its domestic and foreign affairs and became a fully independent nation within the Commonwealth in 1970, marking a significant milestone in Tonga's history.
What significant political change occurred in Tonga in 2008?
In 2008, King George Tupou V announced he was relinquishing most of his powers, leading to a shift in Tonga's governance structure and decision-making processes.
What was the outcome of the 2010 parliamentary elections in Tonga?
The 2010 Legislative Assembly was called Tonga's first democratically elected Parliament, marking a significant step towards democratization in Tonga.
Who first populated Tuvalu?

Voyagers from either Samoa or Tonga first populated Tuvalu in the first millennium A.D., and the islands provided a stepping-stone for various Polynesian communities that subsequently settled in Melanesia and Micronesia, including Tuvalu.
What was the name given to Tuvalu in 1819?
Tuvalu was named the Ellice Islands in 1819, which was a name used to refer to the islands before they became known as Tuvalu.
When did the UK declare a protectorate over Tuvalu?

The UK declared a protectorate over Tuvalu, then known as the Ellice Islands, in 1892, and later merged them with the Micronesian Gilbert Islands to form the Gilbert and Ellice Islands Protectorate, which included Tuvalu.
What event led to the transfer of administration of the colony to Funafuti in Tuvalu?

The transfer of administration of the colony to Funafuti in Tuvalu occurred in 1943, after Japan captured many of the northern Gilbert Islands during World War II, and the UK transferred the administration of the colony southward to Funafuti in Tuvalu.
When did Tuvalu gain independence?
Tuvalu gained independence in 1978, after Tuvaluans voted to secede from the colony in 1974 and were granted self-rule in 1975, marking the beginning of Tuvalu as an independent nation.
What was the outcome of the treaty of friendship between the US and Tuvalu in 1979?
The US relinquished its claims to the Tuvaluan islands in a treaty of friendship with Tuvalu in 1979, which was an important development for Tuvalu.
When did the first Austronesian settlers arrive in Samoa?
The first Austronesian settlers arrived in Samoa around 1000 B.C., and early Samoans traded and intermarried with Fijian and Tongan nobility in Samoa.
What system of titles and nobility developed in Samoa?

The fa’amatai system of titles and nobility developed in Samoa, which dominates Samoan politics to this day; all but two seats in the legislature are reserved for matai, or heads of families in Samoa.
How did European settlers and influence impact Samoa?

Christian missionaries arrived in Samoa in the 1830s and were followed by an influx of American and European settlers and influence in Samoa. By the 1880s, Germany, the UK, and the US had trading posts and claimed parts of the kingdom of Samoa.
What event occurred in Samoa in 1889?
Germany, the UK, and the US all sent warships to Apia in Samoa in 1889 and came close to conflict, but a cyclone damaged or destroyed the ships of all three navies in Samoa.
What was the outcome of the civil war in Samoa in 1894?
At the end of the civil war in 1894, Malietoa Laupepa was installed as king of Samoa, but upon his death in 1898, a second civil war over succession broke out in Samoa.
How did the Western powers affect the monarchy in Samoa?
When the war ended in 1899, the Western powers abolished the monarchy in Samoa, giving the western Samoan islands to Germany and the eastern Samoan islands to the US.
What event occurred in Samoa in 1929?
In 1929, New Zealand police shot into a crowd of peaceful Mau protestors in Samoa, killing 11, in an event known as Black Sunday in Samoa.
When did Samoa become the first Polynesian nation to reestablish Samoa's independence?
In 1962, Samoa became the first Polynesian nation to reestablish its independence as Western Samoa, but dropped the “Western” from its name in 1997, and is now known as Samoa.
When was Aruba discovered and claimed for Spain?
Aruba was discovered and claimed for Spain in 1499. Aruba was later acquired by the Dutch in 1636.
What are the main industries that have dominated Aruba's economy?
The main industries that have dominated Aruba's economy are gold mining, oil refining, and tourism, which have all played a significant role in Aruba's economic development.
What event in 1924 brought prosperity to Aruba?
The opening of an oil refinery in 1924 brought prosperity to Aruba, following a 19th-century gold rush.
When did Aruba secede from the Netherlands Antilles?
Aruba seceded from the Netherlands Antilles in 1986 and became a separate, semi-autonomous member of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, with Aruba gaining more autonomy.
What happened to Aruba's movement toward full independence in 1990?
Movement toward full independence was halted at Aruba's request in 1990, with Aruba choosing to maintain its semi-autonomous status within the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
When did the Siboney first inhabit the islands of Antigua and Barbuda?

The Siboney were the first people to inhabit the islands of Antigua and Barbuda in 2400 B.C., and later the Arawaks populated the islands when Christopher Columbus landed on his second voyage in 1493, finding Antigua and Barbuda already inhabited.
What event occurred in Antigua and Barbuda in 1493?
In 1493, Christopher Columbus landed on his second voyage, finding the Arawaks populating the islands of Antigua and Barbuda.
Who succeeded the early Spanish and French settlements in Antigua and Barbuda?
An English colony succeeded the early Spanish and French settlements in Antigua and Barbuda in 1667, establishing a new period for the islands of Antigua and Barbuda.
When was slavery abolished on the sugar plantations of Antigua in Antigua and Barbuda?
Slavery, which provided labor on the sugar plantations on Antigua, was abolished in 1834, bringing an end to the practice in Antigua and Barbuda.
What was the status of Antigua and Barbuda in 1981?
The islands of Antigua and Barbuda became an independent state within the British Commonwealth of Nations in 1981, marking a new era for Antigua and Barbuda.
How did Hurricane Irma affect the island of Barbuda in 2017 in Antigua and Barbuda?

In 2017, Hurricane Irma passed over the island of Barbuda, devastating the island of Barbuda and forcing the evacuation of the population to Antigua, with almost all of the structures on Barbuda being destroyed and the vegetation stripped, while Antigua and Barbuda's other island, Antigua, was spared the worst.
When was Anguilla first colonized by English settlers from Saint Kitts?
Anguilla was first colonized by English settlers from Saint Kitts in 1650. Anguilla has since been shaped by its early colonization.
How was Anguilla administered by Great Britain in the early 19th century?
Great Britain administered Anguilla until the early 19th century, when Anguilla was incorporated into a single British dependency along with Saint Kitts and Nevis.
What was the outcome of the attempts at separation by Anguilla from Saint Kitts and Nevis?
Several attempts at separation by Anguilla failed, but in 1971, Anguilla was finally allowed to secede.
When was Anguilla formally recognized as a separate British dependency?
Anguilla became a separate British dependency in 1980, with the arrangement being formally recognized.
What damage did Hurricane Irma cause to Anguilla in 2017?
Hurricane Irma caused extensive damage to Anguilla in 2017, particularly to communications and residential and business infrastructure on the island of Anguilla.
Who inhabited the Bahama islands when Christopher Columbus first set foot in the New World in 1492 in The Bahamas?
Lucayan Indians inhabited the Bahama islands when Christopher Columbus first set foot in the New World in 1492 in The Bahamas.
When did British settlement of the islands begin in The Bahamas?
British settlement of the islands began in 1647 in The Bahamas.
In what year did the islands become a colony in The Bahamas?
The islands became a colony in 1783 in The Bahamas.
What factors contributed to the thriving of piracy in the 17th and 18th centuries in The Bahamas?
Piracy thrived in the 17th and 18th centuries in The Bahamas because of The Bahamas' close proximity to shipping lanes.
What are the main components of The Bahamas' GDP since gaining independence from the UK in 1973?
The Bahamas has prospered through tourism, international banking, and investment management, which comprise up to 85% of GDP in The Bahamas.
Why is The Bahamas a major transshipment point for illicit trafficking to the US mainland and Europe?

The Bahamas is a major transshipment point for illicit trafficking to the US mainland and Europe because of its proximity to the US, with the nearest Bahamian landmass being only 80 km from Florida in The Bahamas.
How do US law enforcement agencies cooperate with The Bahamas?

What happened to the lighthouse on Navassa Island?

What is Navassa Island described as by a scientific expedition?
A 1998 scientific expedition to Navassa Island described Navassa Island as a 'unique preserve of Caribbean biodiversity'.
What status was given to Navassa Island in the year following the scientific expedition?
The year after the scientific expedition, Navassa Island became a National Wildlife Refuge, and annual scientific expeditions to Navassa Island have continued.
When did annual scientific expeditions to Navassa Island begin?
Annual scientific expeditions to Navassa Island have continued since Navassa Island became a National Wildlife Refuge the year after a 1998 scientific expedition to Navassa Island.
What happened to the Cayman Islands during the 18th and 19th centuries?

The British colonized the Cayman Islands during the 18th and 19th centuries, and the Cayman Islands were administered by Jamaica after 1863, with the Cayman Islands being a British colony at the time.
How were the Cayman Islands administered after 1863?
The Cayman Islands were administered by Jamaica after 1863, with the Cayman Islands being a British colony at the time, and Jamaica also being a British colony.
What change occurred in the Cayman Islands in 1959?

What was the outcome for the Cayman Islands when the Federation of the West Indies dissolved in 1962?
When the Federation of the West Indies dissolved in 1962, the Cayman Islands chose to remain a British dependency, with the Cayman Islands continuing as a British territory.
What has the Cayman Islands transformed into over time?
The Cayman Islands has transformed itself into a significant offshore financial center, with the Cayman Islands becoming a major financial hub.
What challenges did the Spanish face when attempting to colonize Costa Rica in the 16th century?
Costa Rica proved unsuccessful for the Spanish to colonize due to disease from mosquito-infested swamps, brutal heat, resistance from Indigenous populations, and pirate raids.
When was a permanent settlement established in Costa Rica?
A permanent settlement of Cartago was established in Costa Rica in 1563 in the cooler, fertile central highlands.
When did Costa Rica declare independence from Spain?
Costa Rica was one of several Central American provinces that jointly declared independence from Spain in 1821.
What happened to the United Provinces of Central America that Costa Rica joined in 1823?
The United Provinces of Central America, which Costa Rica joined, disintegrated in 1838, at which time Costa Rica proclaimed its sovereignty and independence.
Who led a coup in Costa Rica in 1917 and what was the outcome?
General Federico Tinoco Granados led a coup in Costa Rica in 1917, but the threat of US intervention pushed him to resign in 1919.
What event occurred in Costa Rica in 1948?
In 1948, landowner Jose Figueres Ferrer raised his own army and rebelled against the government of Costa Rica, leading to a brief civil war.
How has Costa Rica's economy changed over time?
Costa Rica has expanded its economy to include strong technology and tourism industries, although it still maintains a large agricultural sector.
What impact did Central American civil wars have on Costa Rica?
Costa Rica experienced destabilizing waves of refugees from Central American civil wars in the 1970s and 1980s, but peace in the region has since helped Costa Rica's economy rebound.
What happened to the native Amerindian population of Cuba after the arrival of Christopher Columbus in 1492?
The native Amerindian population of Cuba began to decline after the arrival of Christopher Columbus in 1492, as Cuba was developed as a Spanish colony during the next several centuries.

Cuba gained independence from Spain with the assistance of US intervention during the Spanish-American War in 1898, and the Treaty of Paris established Cuban independence from Spain in 1898.

Fidel Castro led a rebel army to victory in 1959, and his authoritarian rule held the subsequent regime together for nearly five decades in Cuba.

Fidel Castro handed off the presidency to his younger brother Raul Castro in 2008, and Raul Castro later handed off the presidency to Miguel Diaz-Canel Bermudez in 2018 in Cuba.
What has been a longstanding challenge for Cuba and the US?
Illicit migration of Cuban nationals to the US via maritime and overland routes has been a longstanding challenge for Cuba and the US.
What is Cuba's stance on the US embargo?
Cuba traditionally and consistently portrays the US embargo, in place since 1961, as the source of its socioeconomic difficulties in Cuba.
What was the result of the efforts to reestablish diplomatic relations between the US and Cuba?

When did Dominica become a British colony?

What was Dominica's status in 1967?
In 1967, Dominica became an associated state of the UK, with Dominica formally taking responsibility for its internal affairs, leading to Dominica gaining its independence in 1978.
Who was the first female prime minister in the Caribbean and what country did she represent in Dominica?

Mary Eugenia Charles was the first female prime minister in the Caribbean, representing Dominica, and she replaced a corrupt and tyrannical administration in Dominica, serving for the next 15 years in Dominica.
What was the impact of Hurricane Maria on Dominica in 2017?

How did the Dominican Republic gain independence from Haiti?

What happened to the Dominican Republic in 1861?
The Dominicans voluntarily returned to the Spanish Empire in 1861, but the Dominican Republic launched a war two years later, which restored independence in 1865.
Who ruled the Dominican Republic from 1930 to 1961?
The Dominican Republic was ruled by the dictatorship of Rafael Leonidas Trujillo from 1930 to 1961, during which time the Dominican Republic was under his control.
What event occurred in the Dominican Republic in 1965?

The US led an intervention in the Dominican Republic in 1965, in the midst of a civil war sparked by an uprising to restore Juan Bosch, the president who was elected in 1962 but deposed in a military coup in 1963.
Who maintained a tight grip on power in the Dominican Republic for most of the next 30 years?

When did El Salvador achieve independence from Spain?

What is a major challenge facing El Salvador today?
El Salvador is beset by one of the world's highest homicide rates and pervasive criminal gangs, posing significant challenges to the country.
How many lives were lost during the 12-year civil war in El Salvador?
The 12-year civil war in El Salvador cost about 75,000 lives in El Salvador.
What happened when Christopher Columbus landed on Grenada in 1498?

When Christopher Columbus landed on Grenada in 1498, the indigenous Carib people inhabited Grenada, but the island remained uncolonized for more than a century, with Grenada eventually settled by the French in the 17th century, and later taken by Britain in 1762, and Grenada became a British colony.
Who settled Grenada in the 17th century?
The French settled Grenada in the 17th century, established sugar estates in Grenada, and imported large numbers of African slaves to Grenada.
What was the main export crop of Grenada in the 20th century?
