When did Britain give Grenada autonomy over Grenada's internal affairs?

What was the outcome of the US-led intervention in Grenada in 1983?

What civilization flourished in Guatemala during the first millennium A.D.?
The Maya civilization flourished in Guatemala and surrounding regions during the first millennium A.D.

What type of governments did Guatemala experience during the second half of the 20th century?

How long did the guerrilla war in Guatemala last?

When did the government of Guatemala sign a peace agreement to end the internal conflict?
The government of Guatemala signed a peace agreement formally ending the internal conflict in 1996.
What happened to the native Taino in Haiti after Christopher Columbus landed in 1492?
The native Taino who inhabited the island of Hispaniola when Christopher Columbus first landed in 1492 were virtually wiped out by Spanish settlers within 25 years in Haiti.

What was the outcome of the US occupation of Haiti from 1915 to 1934?

What natural disasters has Haiti been plagued by?

Haiti has been plagued by natural disasters, including a major 7.0 magnitude earthquake in 2010 that killed an estimated 300,000 people, and a 7.2 magnitude earthquake in 2021 that caused over 2,000 deaths in Haiti.
When did Honduras become an independent nation?
Honduras became an independent nation in 1821, after being part of Spain's vast empire in the New World.
What type of government came to power in Honduras in 1982?

What role did Honduras play in relation to the anti-Sandinista contras in the 1980s?

How did Honduras support the Salvadoran Government forces in the 1980s?

How has the economy of Honduras performed since Hurricane Mitch?
Since Hurricane Mitch, the economy of Honduras has slowly rebounded, despite COVID-19 and severe storm-related setbacks in 2020 and 2021.
When did Europeans first see Jamaica?
Jamaica was first seen by Europeans when Christopher Columbus arrived in 1494, and the Spanish settled the island early in the 16th century in Jamaica.
What happened to the Native Taino in Jamaica?
The Native Taino, who had inhabited Jamaica for centuries, were gradually exterminated and replaced with African slaves in Jamaica.

England seized the island of Jamaica in 1655 and established a plantation economy based on sugar, cocoa, and coffee in Jamaica.
What was the result of the abolition of slavery in 1834 for Jamaica?
The abolition of slavery in 1834 freed a quarter-million slaves in Jamaica, many of whom became small farmers in Jamaica.

What challenges does the government of Jamaica face today?

When did English and Irish colonists from St. Kitts first settle on Montserrat?

The first African slaves arrived on Montserrat three decades after the initial settlement in 1632, which would be in the 1660s; Montserrat received its first African slaves at this time.
Who fought for possession of Montserrat in the 18th century?

What happened to Montserrat's sugar plantation economy in the mid-19th century?

When was the Pacific coast of Nicaragua settled as a Spanish colony?

What has happened to democratic institutions in Nicaragua under the ORTEGA regime?

How has the Nicaraguan government treated opposition candidates and civil society organizations?

What was the outcome of the 2022 municipal elections in Nicaragua?

When did Panama break with Spain?

What happened to Panama after the Republic of Gran Colombia dissolved?
When the union dissolved in 1830, Panama remained part of Colombia.
How did Panama gain independence from Colombia?

Who built the Panama Canal and when?
The US Army Corps of Engineers built the Panama Canal in Panama between 1904 and 1914.
When was the Panama Canal transferred to Panama?

What significant project was carried out in Panama between 2007 and 2016?
An ambitious expansion project to more than double the Canal's capacity by allowing for more Canal transits and larger ships was carried out in Panama between 2007 and 2016.
When did the British and French begin settlement in Saint Kitts and Nevis?

The British and French began settlement in Saint Kitts and Nevis in 1623, with Carib Indians occupying the islands for hundreds of years before that, and Saint Kitts became the premier base for British and French expansion into the Caribbean.
What was the result of the sugar trade for Saint Kitts in Saint Kitts and Nevis?

The sugar trade made Saint Kitts the richest British Crown Colony per capita in the Caribbean at the turn of the 18th century, with Saint Kitts being a major beneficiary of this trade. (Saint Kitts and Nevis).
How were Saint Kitts and Nevis governed until the late-19th century?

Saint Kitts and Nevis were viewed and governed as different states until the late-19th century, with the British later forcibly unifying them along with the island of Anguilla, and Saint Kitts and Nevis being separate entities for a long time.
What was the status of Saint Christopher-Nevis-Anguilla in 1967 in Saint Kitts and Nevis?

When did Saint Kitts and Nevis achieve independence?

What was the outcome of the 1998 referendum on Nevis in Saint Kitts and Nevis?

What was the contest between England and France over Saint Lucia about?

When was slavery abolished on the plantations of Saint Lucia?

What was the status of Saint Lucia in 1967?

When did Saint Lucia gain full independence?
Saint Lucia gained full independence in 1979, after being part of the British Windward Islands colony and later having internal self-government as a member of the West Indies Associated States.
What was the main industry of Saint Lucia after the abolition of slavery?
After the abolition of slavery, Saint Lucia remained dedicated to producing tropical commodity crops, and the country remained an agricultural island.
When was Saint Barthelemy first settled by the French?
Saint Barthelemy was first settled by the French in 1648, after being named by Christopher Columbus in 1493 for his brother Bartolomeo.
What happened to Saint Barthelemy in 1784?

Who repurchased Saint Barthelemy in 1877?

What status did Saint Barthelemy gain in 2012?

What natural disaster hit Saint Barthelemy in 2017?

What was the initial colonization of Trinidad and Tobago by?

When did Trinidad and Tobago come under British control?
Trinidad and Tobago came under British control in the early 19th century.

The emancipation of enslaved people in 1834 disrupted Trinidad and Tobago's sugar industry.
What group of workers arrived in Trinidad and Tobago between 1845 and 1917?

When did Trinidad and Tobago attain independence?
Trinidad and Tobago attained independence in 1962.
What is the main reason for Trinidad and Tobago's prosperity?

What challenge is the government of Trinidad and Tobago currently facing?

What was the status of the Turks and Caicos Islands in relation to Jamaica until 1962?

Who oversaw the affairs of the Turks and Caicos Islands from 1965 to 1973?

What change occurred in the governance of the Turks and Caicos Islands in 1973?

What was the planned status of the Turks and Caicos Islands for 1982?

What is the current status of the Turks and Caicos Islands?

What natural disaster affected Grand Turk Island in 2017 in Turks and Caicos Islands?

What happened to the original Arawak Indian settlers of Curacao in the 16th century?

Who seized Curacao from the Spanish in 1634?

How was the economy of Curacao affected by the abolition of slavery in 1863?
Curacao was hard hit economically when the Dutch abolished slavery in 1863, as the island was once the center of the Caribbean slave trade, and this significantly impacted Curacao's economy.
What event in the early 20th century helped restore prosperity to Curacao?

What was the outcome of the referenda held in Curacao in 2005 and 2009?
The citizens of Curacao voted to become a self-governing country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands in referenda held in 2005 and 2009, which would affect Curacao's status within the kingdom.
What change occurred in Curacao's status in 2010?

In 2010, Curacao became a self-governing country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands, with the change in status becoming effective with the dissolution of the Netherlands Antilles, which included Curacao.
When did colonization occur on Saint Vincent and the Grenadines?

Colonization on Saint Vincent and the Grenadines occurred in 1719, after resistance from native Caribs was overcome. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines was then a prized location for the British due to its fertile soil. The fertile soil of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines allowed for thriving plantations.
What was the main reason the British prized Saint Vincent and the Grenadines?

The British prized Saint Vincent and the Grenadines because of its fertile soil, which allowed for thriving slave-run plantations of sugar, coffee, indigo, tobacco, cotton, and cocoa. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines had fertile soil that supported various crops.
What happened to slavery in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines in 1834?

In 1834, the British abolished slavery in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines. This led to a labor shortage, which was later eased by immigration of indentured servants and subsequent immigrant waves from Portugal and East India to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines.
What was the state of the economy of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines until the early 1900s?

The economy of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines remained stagnant until the early 1900s due to depressed world sugar prices. This affected both former slaves and immigrant agricultural workers in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, who faced harsh conditions.
When was autonomy granted to Saint Vincent and the Grenadines?

What is the primary sector of the economy of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines?
The Vincentian economy is primarily agricultural, unlike most of its tourism-dependent neighbors. Saint Vincent and the Grenadines relies heavily on agriculture.
What event occurred in 2021 in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines?

Who were the first inhabitants of the British Virgin Islands?

When were the British Virgin Islands annexed by the English?
The British Virgin Islands were annexed by the English in 1672, after being settled by the Dutch in 1648.
What was the status of the British Virgin Islands from 1872 to 1960?

When were the British Virgin Islands granted autonomy?
The British Virgin Islands were granted autonomy in 1967.
How does the economy of the British Virgin Islands relate to the US Virgin Islands?

What is the legal currency of the British Virgin Islands?
The US dollar is the legal currency of the British Virgin Islands.
What was the impact of Hurricane Irma on the British Virgin Islands in 2017?

What event led to the economic decline of the Danish holdings in the Virgin Islands?

The abolition of slavery in 1848 led to the economic decline of the Danish holdings in the Virgin Islands, as the economy was driven by sugarcane produced by African slave labor, and the Virgin Islands were significantly affected by this change.

What was the main driver of the economy in the Virgin Islands during the 18th and early 19th centuries?

Which hurricanes inflicted damage on the Virgin Islands in 2017?

What was the impact of Hurricane Irma on the northern Virgin Islands?

What is the origin of ethnic Kazakhs in Kazakhstan?
Kazakhstan's ethnic Kazakhs derive from a mix of Turkic nomadic tribes that migrated to the region in the 15th century. Kazakhstan was eventually shaped by these tribes.
How did Kazakhstan become a Soviet Republic?
Kazakhstan became a Soviet Republic in 1925, after the Russian Empire conquered the Kazakh steppe in the 18th and 19th centuries.
What was the impact of forced agricultural collectivization on Kazakhstan?
Forced agricultural collectivization in Kazakhstan led to repression and starvation, resulting in more than a million deaths in the early 1930s, affecting Kazakhstan's population.
What demographic changes occurred in Kazakhstan after independence?
