The Bailiwick of Jersey, including Jersey, is a British Crown dependency, which means that Jersey is not part of the UK but is rather a self-governing possession of the British Crown, with Jersey having its own governance.
What is the UK's role in Jersey's defense and international representation?
The UK Government is constitutionally responsible for the defense and international representation of Jersey, as Jersey is a British Crown dependency.
When was Jan Mayen discovered by a Dutch whaling captain?
Jan Mayen was discovered by a Dutch whaling captain in 1614, although earlier claims are inconclusive.
What type of visitors did Jan Mayen have over the centuries?
Jan Mayen was visited only occasionally by seal hunters and trappers over the centuries.
When did Jan Mayen come under Norwegian sovereignty?
Jan Mayen came under Norwegian sovereignty in 1929.
What notable geological feature is located on Jan Mayen?
Jan Mayen is home to the Beerenberg volcano, the northernmost active volcano on earth, which resumed activity in 1970 and had its most recent eruption in 1985.
When did the Beerenberg volcano on Jan Mayen resume activity?
The Beerenberg volcano on Jan Mayen resumed activity in 1970, with the most recent eruption occurring in 1985.
When did the Ottoman Empire take control of Kosovo?
The Ottoman Empire took control of Kosovo in 1389 after defeating Serbian forces, and large numbers of Turks and Albanians moved to the region of Kosovo.
What happened to the ethnic composition of Kosovo by the end of the 19th century?
By the end of the 19th century, Albanians had replaced Serbs as the majority ethnic group in Kosovo, with Albanians and Turks having moved to the region of Kosovo.
How did Serbia reacquire control of Kosovo?
Serbia reacquired control of Kosovo during the First Balkan War of 1912, and Kosovo became an autonomous province of Serbia in the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
What led to the insurgency in Kosovo?
Increasing Albanian nationalism in Kosovo in the 1980s led to riots and calls for Kosovo's independence, but Belgrade revoked Kosovo's autonomous status, leading to an insurgency in Kosovo.
What was the result of the NATO military operation in Kosovo in 1999?

The NATO military operation in Kosovo began in March 1999 and forced Belgrade to withdraw its forces from Kosovo, after which the UN Security Council placed Kosovo under the temporary control of the UN Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo.
When did the Kosovo Assembly declare Kosovo independent?
The Kosovo Assembly declared Kosovo independent on 17 February 2008, although Serbia continues to reject Kosovo's independence.
What is Kosovo seeking in terms of international membership?
Kosovo is seeking UN and NATO memberships, and in 2022, Kosovo formally applied for membership in the EU, which is contingent on fulfillment of accession criteria, and the Council of Europe.
What happened to Latvia after World War I?

A Latvian republic emerged following World War I, but Latvia was later annexed by the USSR in 1940, an action never recognized by the US and many other countries, including the fact that Latvia was formed from several eastern Baltic tribes that merged in medieval times to form the ethnic core of the Latvian people, and the region was previously controlled by Germans, Poles, Swedes, and finally Russians, before the Latvian republic was established.
When did Latvia reestablish Latvia's independence?
Latvia reestablished its independence in 1991 after the breakup of the Soviet Union, with Latvia the country that emerged from the USSR's control.
What is the status of the Russian minority in Latvia?
The status of the Russian minority, which makes up some 25% of Latvia's population, remains of concern to Moscow, in Latvia.
When did Latvia join NATO and the EU?
Latvia joined both NATO and the EU in 2004, as part of its integration into European and international organizations, with Latvia the country that joined.

Latvia joined the euro zone in 2014, as part of its continued integration into European economic organizations, with Latvia adopting the euro as its currency.
When did Latvia join the OECD?
Latvia joined the OECD in 2016, as part of its efforts to integrate into international economic organizations, with Latvia the country that became a member of the OECD.
When did Lithuania become the largest state in Europe?

Lithuania was the largest state in Europe by the end of the 14th century, after extending its territory through alliances and conquest to include most of present-day Belarus and Ukraine, with Lithuania united under Mindaugas in 1236.
What was the result of the alliance between Lithuania and Poland in 1386?

The alliance between Lithuania and Poland in 1386 led the two countries into a union through a common ruler, with Lithuania and Poland formally uniting into a single dual state, the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, in 1569.
When did Lithuania regain Lithuania's independence after being annexed by the USSR?

Lithuania regained its independence after World War I, but the USSR annexed it in 1940, and Lithuania became the first of the Soviet republics to declare its independence in 1990, with Moscow recognizing this proclamation in 1991, and the last Russian troops withdrawing in 1993, from Lithuania.
What international organizations has Lithuania joined since Lithuania's independence?

Lithuania joined both NATO and the EU in 2004, and subsequently joined the euro zone in 2015, and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in 2018, with Lithuania restructuring its economy for integration into West European institutions.
When was Lithuania united under Mindaugas?

Lithuania was united under Mindaugas in 1236, and over the next century, Lithuania extended its territory through alliances and conquest to include most of present-day Belarus and Ukraine, with Lithuania becoming a major power in the region.
What 9th century state did Slovakia trace Slovakia's roots to?
Slovakia traces its roots to the 9th century state of Great Moravia, which was an early foundation for the country of Slovakia.
What happened to Slovakia after the formation of the dual Austro-Hungarian monarchy in 1867?

After the formation of the dual Austro-Hungarian monarchy in 1867, Slovakia became subject to language and education policies favoring the use of Hungarian, known as Magyarization, which led to a public backlash that boosted Slovak nationalism and strengthened Slovak cultural ties with the Czechs in Slovakia.
What event led to the formation of the Slovak Republic in 1939 in Slovakia?

What was the outcome of the Warsaw Pact troops' invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 for Slovakia?

When did Slovakia join NATO and the EU?
Slovakia joined both NATO and the EU in 2004, marking significant steps in the country of Slovakia's integration into European and international organizations.
What was the result of the Velvet Revolution for Slovakia?

The peaceful Velvet Revolution swept the Communist Party from power at the end of 1989, inaugurating a return to democratic rule and a market economy in Slovakia, which would eventually lead to the country of Slovakia's independence.
What was the outcome of the 'velvet divorce' for Slovakia?

When was the Principality of Liechtenstein established within the Holy Roman Empire?
The Principality of Liechtenstein was established within the Holy Roman Empire in 1719. Liechtenstein became a part of this empire during that time.
What was the status of Liechtenstein after the Napoleonic Wars?
After the Napoleonic Wars, Liechtenstein became a sovereign state in 1806 and Liechtenstein joined the German Confederation in 1815.

Liechtenstein became fully independent in 1866 when the German Confederation dissolved, marking a significant point for Liechtenstein.

When was Luxembourg founded?

When did a large portion of present-day Moldova become a province of the Russian Empire?

A large portion of present-day Moldovan territory became a province of the Russian Empire in 1812, with Moldova part of this empire at that time. Moldova was then unified with Romania in 1918. Moldova was later incorporated into the Soviet Union at the close of World War II.
What is the current status of Russian forces in Moldova?
Russian forces have remained on Moldovan territory east of the Nistru River in the breakaway region of Transnistria, with Moldova having been independent from the Soviet Union since 1991.
What event ended the Communist Party rule in Moldova in 2009?

Years of Communist Party rule in Moldova from 2001 to 2009 ultimately ended with election-related violent protests and a rerun of parliamentary elections in 2009, which led to a change in the government of Moldova.
Who won the presidency in Moldova in 2016?

When did Montenegro begin to be referred to as the Black Mountain or Crna Gora?
The use of the name Crna Gora or Black Mountain, referring to Montenegro, began in the 13th century in reference to a highland region in the Serbian province of Zeta, which is now part of Montenegro.
What type of government did Montenegro have under Ottoman control?

When did Montenegro gain recognition as an independent sovereign principality?

In 1918, Montenegro was absorbed by the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes, which later became the Kingdom of Yugoslavia in 1929, and Montenegro was part of this kingdom.
When did Montenegro join the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia?

The Genoese built a fortress on the site of present-day Monaco in 1215, which is now part of Monaco.
When did the Grimaldi family first seize control of Monaco?
The Grimaldi family first seized control of Monaco in 1297, but Monaco was not permanently secured by the family until later.

The Grimaldi family was able to permanently secure its holding of Monaco in 1419, solidifying Monaco's position under the family's rule.

Economic development was spurred in Monaco in the late 19th century with a railroad linkup to France and the opening of a casino in Monaco.
What has made Monaco world-famous as a tourist and recreation center?
Monaco's mild climate, coastal Mediterranean scenery, and gambling facilities have made Monaco world-famous as a tourist and recreation center.
What is notable about Malta's megalithic sites?
Malta boasts some of the oldest megalithic sites in the world, with a civilization that dates back thousands of years, and Malta’s islands have long served as a strategic military asset.

When did Malta gain Malta's independence from Britain?

How did Malta support the UK during world wars?

When did the Netherlands declare Netherlands's independence from Spain?

Netherlands also saw the larger islands of Sint Maarten and Curacao join the Netherlands and Aruba as constituent countries forming the Kingdom of the Netherlands.

Why did Norway reject joining the EU?

When did Poland's history as a state begin?
Poland's history as a state began near the middle of the 10th century. Poland was a newly formed state at this time.
What happened to Poland during the 18th century?

When did Poland regain Poland's independence?

The monarchy in Serbia remained in power until 1945, when the communist Partisans headed by Josip Broz took control of the newly created Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, which included Serbia.
Who became president of the Republic of Serbia in 1989?
Slobodan Milosevic became president of the Republic of Serbia in 1989, and his calls for Serbian domination led to the violent breakup of Yugoslavia along ethnic lines, affecting Serbia.
What was the outcome of the ethnic Albanian insurgency in Kosovo for Serbia?

How has Serbia's relationship with Kosovo evolved?

What was the result of Montenegro's secession for Serbia?

The Treaty of Paris in 1856 secured the autonomy of the principalities of Wallachia and Moldavia in Romania, which were for centuries under the control of the Turkish Ottoman Empire.
When and how was Romania formally united?
Romania was formally united in 1862 under the new name of Romania, after being de facto linked in 1859.
What was the outcome for Romania after joining the Allied Powers in World War I?

What alliance did Romania join in 1940 and what was the consequence?
Romania allied with the Axis powers in 1940 and subsequently participated in the 1941 German invasion of the USSR, which led to Romania being overrun by the Soviets three years later.
What led to the formation of a communist people's republic in Romania?
The post-war Soviet occupation of Romania led to the formation of a communist people's republic in 1947 and the abdication of the king in Romania.
Who ruled Romania from 1965 and what characterized his rule?
Nicolae Ceausescu ruled Romania from 1965, and his rule became increasingly oppressive and draconian through the 1980s, characterized by a Securitate police state in Romania.
What significant events occurred in Romania in 1989 and 1996?

What international organizations has Romania joined since 2000?

What empire did Slovenia belong to before World War I?

What was Slovenia's status after World War II?
After World War II, Slovenia joined other republics as one of the constituent republics in the new Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. Slovenia was one of the republics in this new federation.
How did Serbia respond to Slovenia's referendum on independence in 1990?

When did Slovenia join NATO and the EU?
Slovenia acceded to both NATO and the EU in the spring of 2004. Slovenia joined these organizations as part of its integration into European and international structures.
What other international organizations did Slovenia join in 2007?

What is San Marino's claim to fame in terms of San Marino's republic status?
San Marino claims to be the world's oldest republic, founded by a Christian stonemason named Marinus in A.D. 301, and is located in San Marino.
Is San Marino a member of the European Union?
San Marino is not a member of the European Union, but San Marino's foreign policy is aligned with that of the EU.
What agreement is San Marino currently negotiating with the European Union?

What happened to Spain's world empire in the 16th and 17th centuries?

How did Spain's economy change after joining the EU in 1986?
After Spain joined the EU in 1986, the country experienced rapid economic modernization, giving Spain a dynamic and rapidly growing economy.
What is the current state of Spain's economy?

What challenge is Spain currently facing due to the Catalonia region?

What was Sweden's policy regarding military involvement during the 17th century and beyond?

How did Sweden remain involved in international conflicts without taking sides?
Stockholm preserved an armed neutrality in both World Wars, allowing Sweden to remain involved without taking sides.
What economic system has Sweden successfully implemented?
Sweden has pursued a successful economic formula consisting of a capitalist system intermixed with substantial welfare elements, which has contributed to its economic success.

How has the population of Sweden changed in terms of foreign-born residents?

When was the Swiss Confederation founded in Switzerland?
The Swiss Confederation was founded in 1291 as a defensive alliance among three cantons in Switzerland.
What significant event occurred in Switzerland in 1499?
Switzerland secured its independence from the Holy Roman Empire in 1499.
How did the constitution of 1848 impact the government of Switzerland?
A constitution of 1848, which was modified in 1874, replaced the confederation with a centralized federal government in Switzerland.
Was Switzerland involved in either World War?
Switzerland was not involved in either World War, with the major European powers honoring Switzerland's sovereignty and neutrality.
When did Switzerland officially become a UN member?

Switzerland did not officially become a UN member until 2002, although the country remains active in many UN and international organizations and retains a strong commitment to neutrality in Switzerland.
When was the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland created?

The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland was created when the Kingdoms of England and Scotland were joined under the 1707 Acts of Union, with the island of Ireland incorporated under the 1800 Acts of Union, and Wales having been part of the Kingdom of England since the 16th century, thus forming the United Kingdom.
What role has the United Kingdom historically played in global affairs?

The United Kingdom has historically played a leading role in developing parliamentary democracy and in advancing literature and science, and as one of five permanent members of the UN Security Council and a founding member of NATO and the Commonwealth of Nations, the United Kingdom pursues a global approach to foreign policy.
How did the British Empire expand and decline in United Kingdom?

The 18th and 19th centuries saw the rapid expansion of the British Empire, despite the loss of the Thirteen Colonies, and at its zenith in the early 20th century, the British Empire stretched over one fourth of the earth's surface, but the first half of the 20th century saw two World Wars seriously deplete the United Kingdom's strength and the Irish Republic withdraw from the union, leading to the dismantling of the Empire in the second half of the 20th century.
What significant event occurred in the United Kingdom in 2016?

In 2016, United Kingdom citizens voted by 52 to 48 percent to leave the European Union, motivated in part by frustration at a remote bureaucracy in Brussels and massive migration into the United Kingdom.
What was the outcome of the United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union?

On 31 January 2020, the United Kingdom became the only country to depart the European Union, a move known as 'Brexit', after prolonged negotiations on EU-United Kingdom economic and security relationships.
What institutions were established in the United Kingdom in 1998?
The devolved Scottish Parliament, the National Assembly for Wales, and the Northern Ireland Assembly were established in 1998 in the United Kingdom.
What was Ukraine's role in the first eastern Slavic state?

Ukraine was the center of the first eastern Slavic state, Kyivan Rus, which was the largest and most powerful state in Europe during the 10th and 11th centuries, and the cultural and religious legacy of Kyivan Rus laid the foundation for Ukrainian nationalism in Ukraine.
How did Ukraine achieve independence after czarist Russia collapsed?
After czarist Russia collapsed in 1917, Ukraine achieved a short-lived period of independence from 1917 to 1920, but the country was later reconquered and endured Soviet rule in Ukraine.
What was the impact of the Chernobyl disaster on Ukraine?

In 1986, a sudden power surge during a reactor-systems test at Ukraine's Chernobyl power station triggered the worst nuclear disaster in history, releasing massive amounts of radioactive material in Ukraine.
How did Ukraine vote in 1991 when the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics dissolved?
Ukraine overwhelmingly voted for independence in 1991 as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics dissolved, paving the way for a new era in Ukraine.
What was the outcome of the 'Orange Revolution' in Ukraine?

The 'Orange Revolution' in Ukraine forced the authorities to overturn a presidential election and allow a new internationally monitored vote that swept into power a reformist slate under Viktor Yushchenko in Ukraine.
How has Russia's invasion affected Ukraine?

Russia's invasion of Ukraine has resulted in substantial human suffering, with over 14,000 civilians killed or wounded, and over six million Ukrainian refugees recorded globally, making it Europe's largest refugee crisis since World War II in Ukraine.
What is President ZELENSKYY's focus for Ukraine?

President Zelenskyy has focused on boosting Ukrainian identity to unite the country behind the goals of ending the war through reclaiming territory and advancing Ukraine's candidacy for EU membership in Ukraine.
What role did popes have in the Italian peninsula for over a thousand years in the Holy See in Holy See (Vatican City)?
In the Holy See, popes in their secular role ruled portions of the Italian peninsula for more than a thousand years until the mid-19th century. (Holy See (Vatican City)).
How did the establishment of the Kingdom of Italy affect the Holy See's holdings in Holy See (Vatican City)?

The Holy See's holdings were seized by the newly established Kingdom of Italy, which took many of the Papal States in the mid-19th century, and in 1870, Rome itself was annexed, further circumscribing the pope's holdings in the Holy See. (Holy See (Vatican City)).
What was the outcome of the disputes between Italy and the Holy See in 1929 in Holy See (Vatican City)?

The disputes between Italy and the Holy See were resolved in 1929 by three Lateran Treaties, which established the independent state of Vatican City, which is the sovereign territory of the Holy See, and granted Roman Catholicism special status in Italy. (Holy See (Vatican City)).
What changes were made to the treaty provisions between the Holy See and Italy in 1984 in Holy See (Vatican City)?

In 1984, a concordat between the Holy See and Italy modified some of the earlier treaty provisions, including the primacy of Roman Catholicism as the Italian state religion, affecting the relationship between the Holy See and Italy. (Holy See (Vatican City)).
What are some of the present concerns of the Holy See in Holy See (Vatican City)?

The Holy See is concerned about issues such as religious freedom, threats against minority Christian communities, the plight of refugees and migrants, climate change, and conflict, among others, affecting the Holy See's global interests. (Holy See (Vatican City)).
How many people worldwide profess Catholicism, which is associated with the Holy See in Holy See (Vatican City)?
About 1.3 billion people worldwide profess Catholicism, the world's largest Christian faith, which is closely tied to the Holy See. (Holy See (Vatican City)).
What event occurred in 1971 in the United Arab Emirates?
In 1971, six of the Trucial States -- Abu Dhabi, 'Ajman, Al Fujayrah, Ash Shariqah, Dubayy, and Umm al Qaywayn -- merged to form the United Arab Emirates (UAE).
How did the United Arab Emirates' economy perform for over three decades?
For more than three decades, oil and global finance drove the United Arab Emirates' economy, with the UAE's per-capita GDP being on par with those of leading West European nations.
What challenges did the United Arab Emirates face in 2008-09?
The United Arab Emirates was hit especially hard by the confluence of falling oil prices, collapsing real estate prices, and the international banking crisis in 2008-09.
Why did the United Arab Emirates not experience the 'Arab Spring' unrest?

The United Arab Emirates did not experience the 'Arab Spring' unrest partly because of the government's multi-year, $1.6-billion infrastructure investment plan for the poorer northern emirates, and its aggressive pursuit of advocates for political reform.
What was the United Arab Emirates' role in regional affairs in recent years?

The United Arab Emirates has played a growing role in regional affairs, donating billions of dollars in economic aid to help stabilize Egypt, and participating as a key partner in a Saudi-led military campaign in Yemen.
What significant agreement did the United Arab Emirates sign in 2020?

The United Arab Emirates and Bahrain signed a peace agreement, the Abraham Accords, with Israel in 2020, brokered by the US, making the United Arab Emirates the third Middle Eastern country, along with Egypt and Jordan, to recognize Israel, with Bahrain being the fourth.
What was the status of Azerbaijan after the collapse of the Russian Empire?

Azerbaijan was briefly independent from 1918 to 1920 following the collapse of the Russian Empire, before being incorporated into the Soviet Union for seven decades, with Azerbaijan a secular nation with a majority-Turkic and majority-Shia Muslim population.
What conflict did Azerbaijan and Armenia fight over starting in 1988?

Azerbaijan and Armenia fought over the Nagorno-Karabakh region, which was populated largely by ethnic Armenians but incorporated into Soviet Azerbaijan as an autonomous oblast in the early 1920s, with Azerbaijan seeking to maintain control over the region.
What was the outcome of the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh by 1994 in Azerbaijan?

By the time a ceasefire took effect in 1994, separatists with Armenian support controlled Nagorno-Karabakh and seven surrounding Azerbaijani territories, with Azerbaijan losing control over these areas.
What actions did Azerbaijan take in 2020 regarding the Nagorno-Karabakh region?

Azerbaijan tried to win back the territories it had lost in the 1990s, resulting in significant Azerbaijani gains, and Armenia returned the southern part of Nagorno-Karabakh and the surrounding territories to Azerbaijan.
What has been the impact of corruption on Azerbaijan's economy?

Corruption remains a burden on Azerbaijan's economy, despite the country significantly reducing the poverty rate and directing some revenue from its oil and gas production to develop Azerbaijan's infrastructure.
Who has been in leadership of Azerbaijan since 1993?
The country’s leadership has remained in the Aliyev family since Heydar Aliyev became president of Azerbaijan during the first Nagorno-Karabakh War in 1993.
When did Armenia adopt Christianity as Armenia's official religion?

Armenia adopted Christianity as its official religion in the early 4th century, making it the first state to formally do so. Armenia has existed as a political entity for centuries. Armenia prides itself on this aspect of its history.
What was the outcome for Armenia's Armenian subjects during World War I under the Ottoman Empire?

The Ottoman Empire instituted a policy of forced resettlement that, coupled with other harsh practices targeting its Armenian subjects, resulted in at least 1 million deaths in Armenia; these actions have been widely recognized as constituting genocide.
When did Armenia declare Armenia's independence and what was the consequence?

Armenia declared its independence in 1918 in the wake of the Bolshevik Revolution in Russia, but Armenia was conquered by the Soviet Red Army in 1920. Armenia, along with Azerbaijan and Georgia, was initially incorporated into the USSR as part of the Transcaucasian Federated Soviet Socialist Republic.
What is the status of the Nagorno-Karabakh region and Armenia's relation to Armenia?

The Nagorno-Karabakh region historically had a mixed Armenian and Azerbaijani population, although ethnic Armenians have constituted the majority since the late 19th century in Armenia's neighboring region. In 1921, Moscow placed Nagorno-Karabakh within Soviet Azerbaijan as an autonomous oblast, which led to a longstanding conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan.
What was the result of the 2020 military conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan over Nagorno-Karabakh?

Armenia lost control over much of the territory it had previously captured, returning the southern part of Nagorno-Karabakh and the territories around it to Azerbaijan. Armenia and Azerbaijan engaged in a second military conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh in 2020.
Why does Armenia have closed borders with Turkey and Azerbaijan?

Turkey closed its border with Armenia in 1993 in support of Azerbaijan during the first period of conflict with Armenia. Armenia also has a closed border with Azerbaijan due to their longstanding conflict, leaving Armenia with closed borders both in the west and east.
What economic unions and agreements has Armenia joined or signed?
In 2015, Armenia joined the Eurasian Economic Union alongside Russia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyzstan. In 2017, Armenia signed a Comprehensive and Enhanced Partnership Agreement with the EU.
When did the Sunni AL-KHALIFA family take power in Bahrain?
The Sunni Al-Khalifa family took power in Bahrain in 1783, and Bahrain has since been ruled by this family.
What was the result of Bahrain entering into a series of treaties with the UK during the 19th century?
Bahrain entered into a series of treaties with the UK during the 19th century that made Bahrain a British protectorate, with Bahrain ultimately attaining its independence in 1971.
What steps has Bahrain taken to diversify Bahrain's economy?

Bahrain has taken steps to diversify its economy by developing petroleum processing and refining, aluminum production, and hospitality and retail sectors, as its oil production and reserves have been declining since 1970.
What is Bahrain's goal in the banking sector?
Bahrain has endeavored to become a leading regional banking center, especially with respect to Islamic finance, in Bahrain.
How does Bahrain's foreign policy typically align?
Bahrain's foreign policy activities usually fall in line with Saudi Arabia and the UAE, due to Bahrain's small size, central location among Gulf countries, and economic dependence on Saudi Arabia.
What was the Bahraini Government's response to pro-democracy protests in 2011?

The Bahraini Government responded to pro-democracy and reform protests in Bahrain with police and military action, including deploying Gulf Cooperation Council security forces, amid Arab uprisings elsewhere in the region.
What agreement did Bahrain sign with Israel in 2020?
Bahrain signed the US-brokered Abraham Accords with Israel in 2020, marking a significant development in Bahrain's foreign relations.
What agreement did Bahrain sign with the United States in 2023?

Bahrain signed the Comprehensive Security Integration and Prosperity Agreement with the United States in 2023 to enhance cooperation across a wide range of areas, from defense and security to emerging technology, trade, and investment in Bahrain.
What ancient kingdoms were located in the region of present-day Georgia?
The region of present-day Georgia once contained the ancient kingdoms of Colchis, known as Egrisi locally, and Kartli-Iberia, which were part of Georgia's early history.
When did Christianity become the state religion in Georgia?
Christianity became the state religion in Georgia in the 330s, which had a significant impact on the country.
What event cut short the Georgian golden age in the 13th century?
The Mongols invaded Georgia in 1236, cutting short the Georgian golden age that occurred from the 11th to the 13th centuries in Georgia.
When was Georgia absorbed into the Russian Empire?
Georgia was absorbed into the Russian Empire in the 19th century, which significantly influenced Georgia's development.
How long was Georgia independent after the Russian revolution?
Georgia was independent for three years, from 1918 to 1921, following the Russian revolution, before being forcibly incorporated into the USSR, which affected Georgia.
What led to the resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze in Georgia in 2003?

Mounting public discontent over rampant corruption, ineffective government services, and a government attempt to manipulate parliamentary elections in Georgia touched off widespread protests that led to the resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze, who had been president of Georgia since 1995.
What was the outcome of the 2008 conflict between Russia and Georgia?

The five-day conflict between Russia and Georgia in August 2008 resulted in Russia invading large portions of Georgian territory, and Russia initially pledged to pull back from most Georgian territory but then unilaterally recognized the independence of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, which are regions in Georgia.
What are Georgia's top foreign policy goals?

Joining the EU and NATO are among Georgia's top foreign policy goals, and Georgia applied for EU membership in 2022, becoming a candidate country in December 2023, which reflects Georgia's desire for integration with the West.
What trade agreement does Georgia have with the EU?
Georgia and the EU have a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement, which has facilitated trade between Georgia and the EU.
What has been the de facto governing authority of the Gaza Strip since 2007 in Gaza, Gaza Strip?

The Gaza Strip has been under the de facto governing authority of the Islamic Resistance Movement, also known as HAMAS, since 2007, and the Gaza Strip has faced years of conflict, poverty, and humanitarian crises under HAMAS's governance. (Gaza, Gaza Strip).
When did the Gaza Strip fall to British forces in Gaza, Gaza Strip?

The Gaza Strip fell to British forces during World War I, becoming a part of the British Mandate of Palestine, which marked a significant change in the governance of the Gaza Strip. (Gaza, Gaza Strip).
Who administered the Gaza Strip following the 1948 Arab-Israeli War in Gaza, Gaza Strip?

Following the 1948 Arab-Israeli War, Egypt administered the newly formed Gaza Strip, which was later captured by Israel in the Six-Day War in 1967, and the Gaza Strip has been a point of contention between Egypt, Israel, and the Palestinian Authority. (Gaza, Gaza Strip).
What was the outcome of the 2006 Palestinian Legislative Council election in the Gaza Strip in Gaza, Gaza Strip?

In 2006, HAMAS won a majority in the Palestinian Legislative Council election in the Gaza Strip, which led to a significant shift in the political landscape of the Gaza Strip and ultimately resulted in HAMAS's violent seizure of all PA military and governmental institutions in the Gaza Strip in 2007. (Gaza, Gaza Strip).
How has Israel controlled the Gaza Strip since Gaza, Gaza Strip's unilateral withdrawal in 2005?

Although Israel unilaterally withdrew all of its settlers and soldiers and dismantled its military facilities in the Gaza Strip in 2005, Israel continues to control the Gaza Strip’s land borders, maritime territorial waters, cyberspace, telecommunications, and airspace, which has significantly impacted the Gaza Strip's economy and daily life. (Gaza, Gaza Strip).
What sparked the 11-day conflict in the Gaza Strip in 2021 in Gaza, Gaza Strip?

In 2021, HAMAS launched rockets into Israel, sparking an 11-day conflict that also involved other Gaza-based militant groups, and the conflict was eventually brought to an end through ceasefires negotiated by Egypt, Qatar, and the UN Special Coordinator for the Middle East Peace Process. (Gaza, Gaza Strip).
What type of demonstrations has HAMAS coordinated along the Gaza-Israel security fence since 2018 in Gaza, Gaza Strip?

Since 2018, HAMAS has coordinated demonstrations along the Gaza-Israel security fence, which have periodically escalated into exchanges of projectiles and air strikes between Palestinian militants in the Gaza Strip and the Israel Defense Forces. (Gaza, Gaza Strip).
What was the nature of the attack launched by HAMAS militants inside the Gaza Strip on 7 October 2023 in Gaza, Gaza Strip?

On 7 October 2023, HAMAS militants inside the Gaza Strip launched a combined unguided rocket and ground attack into Israel, which included thousands of terrorists infiltrating Israel by land, sea, and air via paragliders, and resulted in massacres, murders, and kidnappings of civilians. (Gaza, Gaza Strip).
What significant event occurred in Iran in 1979?

Iran became an Islamic republic in 1979 after the ruling monarchy was overthrown and Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi was forced into exile, with conservative clerical forces led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini establishing a theocratic system of government in Iran.
How did US-Iran relations become strained in the past?

US-Iran relations became strained when Iranian students seized the US Embassy in Tehran in November 1979 and held embassy personnel hostage until mid-January 1981, leading the US to cut off diplomatic relations with Iran in April 1980, and Iran has been designated a state sponsor of terrorism since 1984.
What was the outcome of the war between Iran and Iraq?
From 1980 to 1988, Iran fought a bloody, indecisive war with Iraq that eventually expanded into the Persian Gulf and led to clashes between US Navy and Iranian military forces in Iran.
What changes occurred in Iran's government after the election of Mohammad KHATAMI?

After the election of reformer Hojjat ol-Eslam Mohammad Khatami as president in 1997, a political reform campaign in response to popular dissatisfaction was initiated in Iran, but conservative politicians blocked reform measures while increasing repression in Iran.
How has Iran's foreign policy changed under President Ebrahim RAISI?

As president, Raisi has concentrated on deepening Iran's foreign relations with anti-US states -- particularly China and Russia -- to weather US sanctions and diplomatic pressure in Iran, while supporting negotiations to restore a nuclear deal that began in 2021 in Iran.
What sparked nationwide protests in Iran in 2019 and 2022?

In 2019, Tehran's sudden decision to increase the gasoline price sparked nationwide protests in Iran, which the regime violently suppressed, and in 2022, the death of a Kurdish Iranian woman, Mahsa Amini, in morality police custody led to nationwide protests in Iran that persisted for over three months.
What international measures have been imposed on Iran?

Iran continues to be subject to a range of international sanctions and export controls because of its involvement in terrorism, weapons proliferation, human rights abuses, and concerns over the nature of its nuclear program in Iran, with the EU and the UK maintaining nuclear-proliferation-related measures on Iran.
When was the State of Israel established?

The State of Israel was established in 1948, after the UN General Assembly proposed partitioning the British Mandate for Palestine into an Arab and Jewish state in 1947, which the Jews accepted but the local Arabs and Arab states rejected, leading to a war.
What was the outcome of the 1947-1949 war for Israel?
Israel was victorious in the 1947-1949 war that followed the UN proposal and the British withdrawal, with the Arabs being subsequently defeated.
What significant economic transformation has Israel undergone in the last 30 years?

Israel's economy has undergone a dramatic transformation in the last 30 years, led by cutting-edge high-tech sectors, with offshore gas discoveries in the Mediterranean placing Israel at the center of a potential regional natural gas market.
How has Israel's relationship with Israel's Arab neighbors evolved over time?

Israel and its Arab neighbors fought wars in 1956, 1967, and 1973, but Israel signed peace treaties with Egypt in 1979 and Jordan in 1994, and more recently, Israel signed the US-brokered normalization agreements with Bahrain, the UAE, and Morocco in 2020 and reached an agreement with Sudan in 2021.
What is the current status of Israel's administration of the West Bank and Gaza Strip?

Israel took control of the West Bank, the eastern part of Jerusalem, the Gaza Strip, the Sinai Peninsula, and the Golan Heights in the course of the 1967 war, and although it ceded the Sinai back to Egypt in the 1979-1982 period, Israel has continued to administer the other territories through military authorities, with Israel withdrawing from Gaza in 2005.
What recent conflict has Israel been involved in?

Israel has been involved in a conflict with Hamas, with Hamas militants launching a combined unguided rocket and ground terrorist attack from Gaza into southern Israel on 7 October 2023, prompting Israel's Air Force to launch air strikes inside Gaza and initiate a sustained air campaign against Hamas targets across the Gaza Strip.
How has Israel's immigration policy contributed to Israel's population growth?

Israel has seen rapid population growth, primarily due to Jewish refugee migration from Europe and the Middle East, with immigration to Israel continuing, and more than 44,000 estimated new immigrants, mostly Jewish, in the first 11 months of 2023.
What was Iraq's status after World War I?
Iraq was occupied by the United Kingdom during World War I and was declared a League of Nations mandate under UK administration in 1920, with Iraq under UK administration.
When did Iraq attain Iraq's independence as a kingdom?
Iraq attained its independence as a kingdom in 1932, marking a significant milestone for Iraq.
What led to the war between Iraq and Iran from 1980 to 1988?
Territorial disputes led to an inconclusive and costly war between Iraq and Iran from 1980 to 1988, involving the two countries.
What was the outcome of the Gulf War of 1991 for Iraq?
Iraq was expelled by US-led UN coalition forces during the two-month-long Gulf War of 1991, resulting in Iraq's expulsion from Kuwait.
What was the result of the Second Gulf War in 2003 for Iraq?
US-led forces ousted the Saddam regime in Iraq in 2003, leading to a change in Iraq's government.
What significant political development occurred in Iraq in 2005?

In 2005, Iraqis approved a constitution in a national referendum and elected a 275-member Council of Representatives, marking a transition to Iraq's first constitutional government in nearly a half-century, with Iraq establishing its government.
What is the status of the Kurdistan Regional Government in Iraq?

Iraq's constitution established the Kurdistan Regional Government, a semi-autonomous region that administers the governorates of Erbil, Dahuk, and As Sulaymaniyah in Iraq, with the KRG being part of Iraq.
How has Iraq addressed the issue of provincial councils since 2013?

Iraq has repeatedly postponed elections for provincial councils, last held in 2013, and since 2019, the prime minister of Iraq has had the authority to appoint governors rather than provincial councils in Iraq.
What happened to Jordan after World War I and the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire?

After World War I and the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire, the League of Nations awarded Britain the mandate to govern much of the Middle East, which included Jordan. Britain demarcated from Palestine a semi-autonomous region of Transjordan, which is now Jordan, and recognized Abdallah I from the Hashemite family as Jordan's first leader.
How did Jordan gain Jordan's independence?
Jordan gained its independence in 1946 and thereafter became the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. The country has had four kings, with King Hussein being one of the long-time rulers of Jordan.
What was the outcome of the 1967 Six-Day War for Jordan?

In 1967, Jordan lost the West Bank and East Jerusalem to Israel in the Six-Day War, but Jordan retained administrative claims to the West Bank until 1988, when King Hussein permanently relinquished Jordanian claims to the West Bank in favor of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO).
What is Jordan's role in administering the Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem?

Jordanian kings continue to claim custodianship of the Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem by virtue of their Hashemite heritage as descendants of the Prophet Mohammad and agreements with Israel and Jerusalem-based religious and Palestinian leaders. Jordan's special role in administering the Muslim holy shrines in Jerusalem was reaffirmed in the Jordan-Israel peace treaty.
Who succeeded King HUSSEIN as the ruler of Jordan?

King Hussein died in 1999 and was succeeded by his eldest son, King Abdallah II, who has been contending with various challenges, including the Arab Spring influx of refugees from neighboring states and the COVID-19 pandemic, during his reign in Jordan.
What is Jordan's claim to custodianship of the Christian sites in Jerusalem based on?

Jordanian kings claim custodianship of the Christian sites in Jerusalem on the basis of the 7th-century Pact of Omar, when the Muslim leader, after conquering Jerusalem, agreed to permit Christian worship, which applies to Jordan as part of its heritage.
What challenges has King ABDALLAH II faced during his reign in Jordan?

During his reign, King Abdallah II has contended with a series of challenges, including the Arab Spring influx of refugees from neighboring states, the COVID-19 pandemic, the effects of the war in Ukraine, a perennially weak economy, and the Israel-HAMAS conflict that began in October 2023, in Jordan.
What dynasty has ruled Kuwait since the 18th century?

Kuwait has been ruled by the Al-Sabah dynasty since the 18th century, with the Al-Sabah dynasty playing a significant role in the country's history and development, including Kuwait's relationship with Britain and its path to independence.
How did Kuwait attain Kuwait's independence from Britain?

Kuwait attained its independence in 1961, after Amir Mubarak Al-Sabah had ceded foreign and defense responsibility to Britain in 1899 due to the threat of Ottoman invasion, and Kuwait finally regained control over its foreign and defense affairs.
What event occurred in Kuwait in 1990?
Iraq attacked and overran Kuwait in 1990, prompting a US-led UN coalition to intervene on behalf of Kuwait, which was eventually liberated in 1991.
How did the US-led UN coalition liberate Kuwait?
Kuwait was liberated in four days after a US-led UN coalition began a ground assault in 1991, following several weeks of aerial bombardment, and Kuwait was finally freed from Iraqi occupation.
What prompted protests by stateless Arabs known as Bidoon in Kuwait in 2010-11?

Stateless Arabs known as Bidoon in Kuwait staged small protests demanding citizenship, jobs, and other benefits available to Kuwaiti nationals amid the 2010-11 uprisings and protests across the Arab world, with Kuwait one of the countries affected by these regional protests.
What was the outcome of the 2012 legislative elections in Kuwait?

An opposition coalition of Sunni Islamists, tribal populists, and some liberals largely boycotted the legislative elections in 2012, which ushered in a legislature more amenable to the government's agenda in Kuwait, leading to a shift in the country's political landscape.
What initiative was launched by the current Amir of Kuwait in 2021?

The current Amir of Kuwait launched a 'National Dialogue' in 2021, meant to resolve political gridlock in Kuwait, and as part of this initiative, the Amir pardoned several opposition figures who had been living in exile and they returned to Kuwait.
What is the historical background of Lebanon's cultural and religious diversity?

Lebanon is rich in cultural and religious diversity as a result of its location at the crossroads of three continents, and the area that is modern-day Lebanon was subject to various foreign conquerors for much of its history, including the Romans, Arabs, and Ottomans, which contributed to Lebanon's cultural and religious diversity.
How did Lebanon gain independence?
Lebanon gained independence in 1943, after France acquired a mandate over the northern portion of the former Ottoman Empire province of Syria and demarcated the region of Lebanon in 1920.
What was the impact of the 1975-90 civil war on Lebanon?

Lebanon's 1975-90 civil war resulted in an estimated 120,000 fatalities and was followed by years of social and political instability, with sectarianism remaining a key element of Lebanese political life, affecting Lebanon significantly.
How has Syria influenced Lebanon's policies?

Neighboring Syria influenced Lebanon's foreign and domestic policies while its military occupied Lebanon from 1976 until 2005, but Syria's influence over Lebanon diminished significantly after 2005, and Lebanon was affected by this occupation.
What has been the impact of the Syrian conflict on Lebanon?
Over 1.5 million Syrian refugees fled to Lebanon after the start of the Syrian conflict in 2011, which has put a strain on Lebanon's resources and affected the country.
What is the current state of Lebanon's economy?

Lebanon's prosperity has significantly diminished since the beginning of the country's economic crisis in 2019, which has crippled Lebanon's economy, shut down its previously lucrative banking sector, reduced the value of its currency, and caused many Lebanese to emigrate in search of better prospects.
What has contributed to the prosperity of Oman's inhabitants?
The inhabitants of Oman have long prospered from Indian Ocean trade. Oman's strategic location has allowed the country to benefit from this trade.
How did Oman's relationship with Britain evolve over time?

Oman's dependence on British political and military advisors increased over time, although Oman never became a British colony. The nascent sultanate in Muscat signed the first in a series of friendship treaties with Britain in the late 18th century.
What changes did QABOOS bin Said Al Said introduce in Oman after taking power in 1970?

Qaboos bin Said Al Said introduced an extensive modernization program in Oman, opening the country to the outside world. Oman, under his rule, prioritized strategic ties to the UK and US, and maintained good relations with its neighbors.
How did Oman respond to the popular uprisings in the Middle East and North Africa in 2011?

In response to the demonstrations in Oman, Qaboos implemented economic and political reforms, granting Oman's legislative body more power and authorizing direct elections for its lower house. Oman also increased unemployment benefits and issued a royal directive for job creation.
What steps did Oman take to decentralize authority and increase citizen participation in governance?

Oman successfully conducted its first municipal council elections in 2012 as part of the government's efforts to decentralize authority and allow greater citizen participation in local governance. This was a significant step for Oman.
What happened to QABOOS bin Said Al Said and who succeeded him in Oman?
Qaboos bin Said Al Said, Oman's longest reigning monarch, died in 2020. His cousin, Haytham bin Tariq Al Said, was sworn in as Oman's new sultan the same day.
What family has ruled Qatar since the mid-1800s?
Qatar has been ruled by the Al Thani family since the mid-1800s, transforming Qatar from a poor British protectorate into an independent state with significant hydrocarbon revenues.
How did Qatar's former Amir HAMAD bin Khalifa Al Thani come to power?
Qatar's former Amir Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani came to power in a bloodless coup in 1995, overthrowing his father and ushering in wide-sweeping political and media reforms in Qatar.
What is notable about Qatar's economic status by 2007?
By 2007, Qatar's capital Doha had attained the highest per capita income in the world, due in part to Qatar's significant hydrocarbon revenues.
Why did Qatar not experience domestic unrest in 2011?
Qatar did not experience domestic unrest or violence in 2011, due in part to its immense wealth and patronage network, which helped to maintain stability in Qatar.
Who is the current Amir of Qatar and what is he known for?

The current Amir of Qatar is Tamim bin Hamad, who is popular with the Qatari public for his role in shepherding Qatar through an economic embargo and for his efforts to improve Qatar's healthcare and education systems.
What notable international sporting event did Qatar host in 2022?
Qatar became the first country in the Arab world to host the FIFA Men’s World Cup in 2022, with Qatar's infrastructure being expanded in anticipation of the event.
How have Qatar's relations with other regional countries changed over time?

Qatar's relations with Bahrain, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE have undergone significant changes, including a temporary recall of ambassadors in 2014, a brief warming of relations, and a subsequent cutting of diplomatic and economic ties in 2017, before being restored in 2021, with Qatar and these countries signing a declaration at the Gulf Cooperation Council Summit in Al Ula, Saudi Arabia.
What is the significance of Saudi Arabia in the Islamic world?
Saudi Arabia is the birthplace of Islam and home to Islam's two holiest shrines in Mecca and Medina, with the king holding the official title of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques in Saudi Arabia.
Who founded the modern Saudi state and when in Saudi Arabia?
Abd Al-Aziz bin Abd al-Rahman Al Saud, also known as Ibn Saud, founded the modern Saudi state in 1932 after a 30-year campaign to unify most of the Arabian Peninsula in Saudi Arabia.
How did Saudi Arabia respond to the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq in 1990?
Saudi Arabia took in the Kuwaiti royal family and 400,000 refugees, and allowed Western and Arab troops to deploy on its soil to liberate Kuwait the following year in Saudi Arabia.
What reforms did King ABDALLAH bin Abd al-Aziz Al Saud implement in Saudi Arabia from 2005 to 2015?

King Abdallah bin Abd al-Aziz Al Saud incrementally modernized Saudi Arabia through a series of social and economic initiatives, including expanding employment and social opportunities for women, attracting foreign investment, and increasing the private sector's role in the economy of Saudi Arabia.
What was the outcome of the 2011 Arab Spring protests in Saudi Arabia?

Saudi Arabia saw some protests during the 2011 Arab Spring, but not the level of bloodshed seen in protests elsewhere in the region, as Riyadh took a cautious but firm approach in Saudi Arabia, arresting and quickly releasing some protesters.
What economic reforms has the government of Saudi Arabia pursued since 2005?

The government of Saudi Arabia continues to pursue economic reform and diversification, particularly since Saudi Arabia's accession to the WTO in 2005, and promotes foreign investment in Saudi Arabia.
What is the significance of Vision 2030 in Saudi Arabia?
The Saudi Government announced broad socio-economic reforms known as Vision 2030 in 2016, aiming to diversify the economy of Saudi Arabia and reduce its dependence on oil.
What is Saudi Arabia's position in the global oil market as of 2020?
Saudi Arabia remains a leading producer of oil and natural gas and holds about 17% of the world's proven oil reserves as of 2020 in Saudi Arabia.
What happened to Syria after World War I?
After World War I, France acquired a mandate over the northern portion of the former Ottoman Empire province of Syria, and the French administered the area until granting Syria independence in 1946.
When did Syria unite with Egypt to form the United Arab Republic?
Syria united with Egypt in 1958 to form the United Arab Republic, but the two entities separated in 1961, and the Syrian Arab Republic was reestablished.
What was the outcome of the 1967 Arab-Israeli War for Syria?
