Who was named king of Bhutan in 1907?

Ugyen Wangchuck, who had served as the de facto ruler of an increasingly unified Bhutan, was named king of Bhutan in 1907, with Bhutan having improved relations with the British toward the end of the 19th century.
What was agreed upon in the treaty signed between Bhutan and Britain in 1910?

The treaty signed between Bhutan and Britain in 1910 stated that the British agreed not to interfere in Bhutanese internal affairs, and Bhutan allowed Britain to direct its foreign affairs, with Bhutan subject to this arrangement.
What was the outcome of the Indo-Bhutanese Treaty of Friendship signed in 1949?

The Indo-Bhutanese Treaty of Friendship returned to Bhutan a small piece of the territory annexed by the British, formalized the annual subsidies Bhutan received, and defined India's responsibilities in defense and foreign relations concerning Bhutan.
When did Bhutan join the UN?
Bhutan joined the UN in 1971, under a succession of modernizing monarchs beginning in the 1950s, with Bhutan continuing its engagement beyond its borders.
What significant event occurred in Bhutan in 2005?

In 2005, King Jigme Singye Wangchuck of Bhutan unveiled the draft of Bhutan's first constitution, which introduced major democratic reforms, and held a national referendum for its approval, with Bhutan implementing these reforms.
What was the result of the parliamentary election in Bhutan in 2013?
Bhutan experienced a peaceful turnover of power following a parliamentary election in 2013, which resulted in the defeat of the incumbent party, with Bhutan having a change in government.
What is the current status of the ethnic Nepali refugees who fled Bhutan in the 1990s?
Of the more than 100,000 ethnic Nepali refugees who fled or were forced out of Bhutan in the 1990s, about 6,500 remain displaced in Nepal, with Bhutan the country of origin for these refugees.
When did the first Sinhalese arrive in Sri Lanka?
The first Sinhalese arrived in Sri Lanka late in the 6th century B.C., probably from northern India, and established themselves in Sri Lanka.
How was Buddhism introduced in Sri Lanka?
Buddhism was introduced in Sri Lanka circa 250 B.C.
What foreign powers controlled the coastal areas of Sri Lanka in the 16th and 17th centuries?
The Portuguese controlled the coastal areas of Sri Lanka in the 16th century, followed by the Dutch in the 17th century, with both powers exerting control over Sri Lanka's coastal regions.
When did Sri Lanka become independent and what was Sri Lanka's name at the time?
Sri Lanka, then known as Ceylon, became independent in 1948, and the name was later changed to Sri Lanka in 1972, with Sri Lanka the official name since then.
What led to the war between the government and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in Sri Lanka?

Prevailing tensions between the Sinhalese majority and Tamil separatists in Sri Lanka erupted into war in 1983, with the conflict involving the government and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in Sri Lanka.
Who defeated the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in Sri Lanka?
The government of Sri Lanka defeated the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in 2009, bringing an end to the conflict in Sri Lanka.
What significant event occurred in Sri Lanka in 2015?

In 2015, a new coalition government headed by President Maithripala Sirisena of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe of the United National Party came to power in Sri Lanka with pledges to advance economic, political, and judicial reforms in Sri Lanka.
Who won the presidential election in Sri Lanka in 2019?
Gotabaya Rajapaksa won the presidential election in Sri Lanka in 2019 and appointed his brother Mahinda prime minister of Sri Lanka.
What civilization flourished in northwestern India during the 3rd and 2nd millennia B.C.?
The Indus Valley civilization flourished in northwestern India during the 3rd and 2nd millennia B.C. and was one of the world's oldest civilizations, extending into northwestern India.
How did the classical Indian culture emerge in India?
India's classical Indian culture was created by the merger of Aryan tribes from the northwest with the earlier Dravidian inhabitants of India.
Which empire united much of South Asia, including India, in the 4th and 3rd centuries B.C.?
The Maurya Empire, which reached its zenith under Ashoka, united much of South Asia, including India, in the 4th and 3rd centuries B.C.
What significant event occurred in India in 1947?
India gained independence in 1947 after years of nonviolent resistance to British rule, led by Mohandas Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru.
What has contributed to India's emergence as a regional and global power?
India's economic growth after economic reforms in 1991, a massive youth population, and a strategic geographic location have contributed to India's emergence as a regional and global power.
What challenges does India still face despite India's emergence as a global power?

India still faces pressing problems such as extensive poverty, widespread corruption, and environmental degradation, and its restrictive business climate challenges economic growth expectations in India.
How did the British Indian Army contribute to World Wars?
The British Indian Army played a vital role in both World Wars, with India the dominant political power on the subcontinent under Great Britain's rule.
What was the outcome of the partition of the subcontinent into two separate states, India and Pakistan?

The partition of the subcontinent into two separate states, India and Pakistan, resulted in large-scale communal violence before and after the partition, and the neighboring countries have fought three wars since India's independence.
When did the Maldives become a British protectorate?
The Maldives became a British protectorate in 1887, and later became a republic in 1968, three years after independence, with the Maldives being the country that underwent this transformation.
What significant political change occurred in the Maldives in 2005?

In 2005, the Maldives saw the legalization of political parties, marking a key step in the country's liberalization and democratic reforms, with the Maldives being the country that legalized political parties.
Who won the first-ever presidential elections under a multi-candidate, multi-party system in the Maldives in 2008?

Mohamed Nasheed, a political activist, won the first-ever presidential elections under a multi-candidate, multi-party system in the Maldives in 2008, defeating President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom, with the Maldives being the country that held these elections.
What event led to the resignation of President Mohamed NASHEED in the Maldives in 2012?

In 2012, President Mohamed Nasheed resigned after several weeks of street protests in response to a top judge's arrest in the Maldives, with the Maldives being the country where these protests took place.
Who won the presidential election in the Maldives in 2013?

Abdulla Yameen Abdul Gayoom won the presidency in the Maldives in 2013, after running against Mohamed Nasheed and Mohammed Waheed Hassan Maniku, with the Maldives being the country that held these elections.
Who won the presidential election in the Maldives in 2018?
Ibrahim Mohamed Solih won the presidential election in the Maldives in 2018, defeating incumbent President Abdulla Yameen Abdul Gayoom, with the Maldives being the country that held these elections.
What was the outcome of the 2023 democratic election in the Maldives?

The winner of the 2023 democratic election in the Maldives was Male City Mayor Dr. Mohamed Muizzu, who campaigned on a platform of Maldivian sovereignty and represented a joint Progressive Party of Maldives and People's National Congress (PPM/Pnc) coalition, with the Maldives being the country that held these elections.
What happened to Nepal's independence after the Anglo-Nepalese War of 1814-16?
Nepal retained its independence after the Anglo-Nepalese War of 1814-16, and the subsequent peace treaty laid the foundations for two centuries of amicable relations between Britain and Nepal.
What system of government was instituted in Nepal in 1951?
In 1951, the Nepali monarch ended the century-old system of hereditary rule and instituted a cabinet system that brought political parties into the government of Nepal.
What led to the establishment of a multiparty democracy in Nepal?
The establishment of a multiparty democracy within the framework of a constitutional monarchy in Nepal was reinstated in 1990.
What broke out in Nepal in 1996?
A Maoist-led insurgency broke out in Nepal in 1996, leading to a 10-year civil war between Maoist and government forces of Nepal.
What was declared by the newly formed Constituent Assembly in Nepal in 2008?
The newly formed Constituent Assembly in Nepal declared Nepal a federal democratic republic, abolished the monarchy, and elected the country's first president.
When did Nepal's new constitution come into effect?
Nepal's new constitution came into effect in 2015, at which point the Constituent Assembly became the Parliament of Nepal.
What happened to the opposition-supported NC leader Sher Bahadur DEUBA in 2021 in Nepal?
The opposition-supported NC leader Sher Bahadur Deuba was named prime minister of Nepal in 2021, after Oli's efforts to dissolve parliament and hold elections were declared unconstitutional.
What was the outcome of the parliamentary elections in Nepal in 2022?
The NC won a majority of seats in the parliamentary elections in Nepal in 2022.
What ancient civilization spread over much of modern-day Pakistan?

The Indus Valley civilization, one of the oldest in the world, spread over much of modern-day Pakistan,dating back at least 5,000 years, and elements of this culture later interacted with migrating Indo-Aryan peoples in Pakistan.
Which empires and groups invaded Pakistan in subsequent centuries?

Pakistan underwent successive invasions from the Persians, Greeks, Scythians, Arabs, Afghans, and Turks, who brought significant changes to the region, including the introduction of Islam to Pakistan.
What was the outcome of the partition of British India in 1947 for Pakistan?
The partition of British India in 1947 resulted in the creation of the Muslim state of Pakistan, with West and East sections, which later created lasting tension between Pakistan India.
What has been a major point of conflict between Pakistan and India?

Pakistan and India have fought wars and a limited conflict over the Kashmir territory, a dispute that continues to this day, with Pakistan and India having fought two wars and a limited conflict in 1947-48, 1965, and 1999 respectively.
How did East Pakistan become a separate nation?

East Pakistan became the separate nation of Bangladesh in 1971, fter a war in 1971 in which India assisted an indigenous movement reacting to Bengali marginalization in Pakistani politics, resulting in the separation of Bangladesh from Pakistan.
Why did Pakistan conduct nuclear weapons testing in 1998?
Pakistan conducted nuclear tests in 1998 in response to Indian nuclear weapons testing earlier that year.
What kind of conflict has Pakistan been engaged in for decades?

Pakistan has been engaged in a decades-long armed conflict with militant groups, including groups such as the Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan and other militant networks that target government institutions and civilians in Pakistan.
When did humans first settle in New Caledonia?
The first humans settled in New Caledonia around 1600 B.C., marking the beginning of human presence on the island.
Who were the Lapita people in New Caledonia?
The Lapita were skilled navigators who settled early in New Caledonia, and their distinctive pottery has helped scholars trace human expansion across the Pacific.
How did the Kanak ethnic group originate in New Caledonia?
The Kanak ethnic group emerged in New Caledonia through intermarriage between the Lapita and successive waves of migrants from other islands in Melanesia.
Who was the first European to visit New Caledonia and when did this occur?
British explorer James Cook was the first European to visit New Caledonia in 1774, and he gave the island a Latin name referencing Scotland.
When did France annex New Caledonia and for what purpose?
France annexed New Caledonia in 1853 to prevent any British attempt to claim the island.
Why did France establish a penal colony in New Caledonia?
France declared New Caledonia a penal colony in 1864 and sent more than 20,000 prisoners there over the following decades.
What role did nickel play in the colonial economy of New Caledonia?
Nickel was discovered in New Caledonia in 1864, and French prisoners and imported labor were directed to mine it while Kanaks were excluded from the most profitable sectors.
What resistance did the Kanaks mount against French rule in New Caledonia?
In 1878, High Chief Atai led a rebellion against French rule in New Caledonia, followed by smaller uprisings and a major revolt in 1917 that colonial authorities suppressed.
What role did New Caledonia play during World War II?
During World War II, New Caledonia became an important Allied base, and the United States moved its South Pacific headquarters to the island in 1942.
What political changes occurred in New Caledonia after World War II?
After World War II, France made New Caledonia an overseas territory and granted French citizenship to all inhabitants in 1953, allowing Kanaks to leave reservations.
How did the independence movement develop in New Caledonia after the 1950s?
Kanak nationalism emerged in the 1950s, intensified in the 1970s due to renewed nickel mining and European migration, and led to violence in the 1980s.
What agreements shaped New Caledonia’s path toward potential independence?
The Matignon Accords of 1988 established a transition period, and the Noumea Accord of 1998 transferred increasing governing powers from France to New Caledonia and scheduled independence referenda.
What were the results of the independence referenda held in New Caledonia?
Voters in New Caledonia rejected independence in referenda held in 2018, 2020, and 2021, though the 2021 vote was contested due to a boycott by key Kanak groups.
What is the current political situation regarding New Caledonia’s status?
Pro-independence parties later gained a majority in the New Caledonian Government, and France and New Caledonia remain in negotiations over the territory’s future status.
Which medieval states existed in the area of present-day Djibouti?
Present-day Djibouti was the site of the medieval Ifat and Adal Sultanates.
How did France establish colonial control over Djibouti?

In the late 19th century, Afar sultans signed treaties with France that allowed the establishment of the colony of French Somaliland in 1862, followed by additional treaties with ethnic Somalis in 1885.
What ethnic tensions developed during French rule in Djibouti?
Tensions grew between ethnic Afar and Somali populations in Djibouti as Somalis perceived that French authorities favored the Afar and granted them disproportionate influence in local governance.
What choice was offered in the 1958 referendum in French Somaliland?
In 1958, residents of French Somaliland were given the option to either maintain their association with France or join neighboring Somalia as it moved toward independence.
Why did ethnic Somalis protest the 1958 referendum in Djibouti?
Ethnic Somalis protested the 1958 referendum because many were not recognized as residents by French authorities, which gave the Afar population outsized influence in the vote.
Why was the territory renamed the French Territory of the Afars and the Issas in 1967?
After a second referendum in 1967, France renamed the territory to emphasize ties with the ethnic Afar and to downplay the political role of ethnic Somalis in Djibouti.
How did Djibouti achieve independence?
A referendum in 1977 established Djibouti as an independent nation and granted ethnic Somalis Djiboutian nationality, formally rebalancing political power between ethnic groups.
Who was Djibouti’s first president after independence?
Hassan Gouled Aptidon, an ethnic Somali leader, became Djibouti’s first president and governed the country as an authoritarian one-party state until 1999.
What caused the civil conflict in Djibouti during the 1990s?
Civil war in Djibouti during the 1990s resulted from unrest between the Afar minority and the Somali majority and ended with a peace accord in 2001.
Who has led Djibouti since 1999 and how has power been maintained?
Ismail Omar Guelleh became president of Djibouti in 1999 and extended his rule through reelections and a constitutional amendment that enabled multiple additional terms.
Why is Djibouti considered strategically important?
Djibouti occupies a strategic location at the junction of the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden, and its ports handle most of Ethiopia’s trade and global transshipment traffic.
Which foreign countries maintain a military presence in Djibouti?
France, the United States, Japan, Italy, Germany, Spain, and China all maintain a military presence in Djibouti.
Who inhabited the mainland region of Equatorial Guinea before Bantu migrations?
Before the migration of Bantu-speaking groups, the mainland region of Equatorial Guinea was most likely predominantly inhabited by Pygmy ethnic groups.
When was Bioko Island first occupied in Equatorial Guinea?
Bioko Island, the largest inhabited island of Equatorial Guinea and the location of the capital Malabo, has been occupied since at least 1000 B.C.
When did Portuguese explorers arrive in Equatorial Guinea?
Portuguese explorers landed on Bioko Island in the early 1470s and soon established control over the island and other parts of present-day Equatorial Guinea.
How did Spain gain colonial control over Equatorial Guinea?
Spain gained control of Equatorial Guinea in 1778 when Portugal ceded its colonial possessions in the region under the Treaty of El Pardo.
How did the borders of modern Equatorial Guinea develop under colonial rule?
The borders of modern Equatorial Guinea evolved between 1778 and 1968 while the territory remained under European colonial administration.
When did Equatorial Guinea gain independence and who became its first president?
Equatorial Guinea gained independence from Spain in 1968 and elected Francisco Macias Nguema as its first president.
What characterized Francisco Macias Nguema’s rule in Equatorial Guinea?
Francisco Macias Nguema consolidated power and ruled Equatorial Guinea brutally for more than a decade, during which mass repression, purges, and killings occurred.
What impact did Macias Nguema’s regime have on Equatorial Guinea’s population?
Under Francisco Macias Nguema’s rule, estimates indicate that up to one-third of Equatorial Guinea’s population was either killed or forced into exile.
How did Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo come to power in Equatorial Guinea?
In 1979, Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo, then a senior military officer, overthrew Francisco Macias Nguema in a violent coup in Equatorial Guinea.
How has political power been exercised in Equatorial Guinea under Obiang?
Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo has ruled Equatorial Guinea since 1979, winning several non-competitive elections and maintaining near-total control over the political system.
What caused economic growth in Equatorial Guinea in the early 21st century?
Equatorial Guinea experienced rapid economic growth in the early 21st century following the discovery of large offshore oil reserves in 1996.
How did oil production affect Equatorial Guinea’s economy?
Oil production in Equatorial Guinea peaked in 2004, generating large government revenues that funded infrastructure development, though production has declined since.
Why have living standards not improved significantly in Equatorial Guinea despite oil wealth?
Systemic corruption in Equatorial Guinea has limited socio-economic development, resulting in only modest improvements in living standards despite substantial oil revenues.
What economic goals does Equatorial Guinea pursue today?
Equatorial Guinea seeks to diversify its economy, attract foreign investment, and play a greater role in regional and international affairs.
Who discovered the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and when?
British sea captain William Keeling discovered the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in 1609.
How did the Cocos (Keeling) Islands get their name?
The Cocos (Keeling) Islands were named for their coconut trees in 1622, and some maps later referred to them as the Keeling Islands.
Who established the first permanent settlement on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands?
The first permanent settlement on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands was established in the 1820s after John Clunies-Ross landed on the islands in 1825.
How did the Clunies-Ross family come to rule the Cocos (Keeling) Islands?
By the 1830s, the Clunies-Ross family had established themselves as the leaders of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and ruled them in a feudal style.
When did the United Kingdom annex the Cocos (Keeling) Islands?
The United Kingdom annexed the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in 1857.
How were the Cocos (Keeling) Islands administered under British rule?
The United Kingdom administered the Cocos (Keeling) Islands from Ceylon after 1878 and from Singapore after 1886.
What role did the Cocos (Keeling) Islands play during the World Wars?
The Cocos (Keeling) Islands hosted a cable relaying station and were attacked by German forces in World War I and by Japanese forces in World War II.
When were the Cocos (Keeling) Islands transferred to Australia?
The United Kingdom transferred the Cocos (Keeling) Islands to Australia in 1955.
How did Clunies-Ross family rule on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands end?
In 1978, Australia purchased all land held by the Clunies-Ross family, ending their control over the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.
What was the outcome of the 1984 referendum in the Cocos (Keeling) Islands?
In a 1984 referendum, most residents of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands voted to integrate with Australia.
What legal system applies to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands today?
Western Australian laws have applied to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands since 1992.
Who were the earliest settlers of Fiji?
Austronesians settled Fiji around 1000 B.C., followed by waves of Melanesian settlers beginning around the first century A.D.
What external influences shaped early Fijian society?
Fiji traded with Polynesian societies in Samoa and Tonga, and by about 900 much of Fiji was within the Tu’i Tongan Empire’s sphere of influence.
When did European contact with Fiji begin?
The first European sighting of Fiji occurred in 1643, and by the 1800s European traders, missionaries, and whalers frequented the islands.
How did Seru Epenisa Cakobau attempt to unify Fiji?
In 1865, Seru Epenisa Cakobau helped form the Confederacy of Independent Kingdoms of Viti and later established the Kingdom of Fiji in 1871.
Why did Fiji become a British colony?
Seru Epenisa Cakobau ceded Fiji to the United Kingdom in 1874 due to economic instability and fears of takeover by another foreign power.
How did British colonial rule change Fiji’s population?
British authorities brought more than 60,000 Indian indentured laborers to Fiji to work on plantations, many of whom remained after their contracts ended.
How was Fijian society structured in the early 20th century?
By the early 1900s, Fiji was divided along ethnic lines, with iTaukei, Europeans, and Indo-Fijians living separately and maintaining distinct traditions.
When did Fiji gain independence and under what political arrangement?
Fiji gained independence in 1970 under a system that allocated parliamentary seats by ethnic group.
How did political instability affect Fiji after independence?
Coups in 1987 led to a constitution that favored iTaukei political control, prompting significant emigration by Indo-Fijians.
What constitutional changes occurred in Fiji during the late 1990s?
A revised constitution in 1997 created a more equitable political system and led to the election of Fiji’s first Indo-Fijian prime minister in 1999.
How did the 2006 coup reshape Fiji’s government?
In 2006, Josaia Voreqe Bainimarama led a coup, later appointing himself prime minister and retaining power after elections in 2014 and 2018.
Who became prime minister of Fiji after the 2022 elections?
Following the 2022 elections, Sitiveni Ligamamada Rabuka became prime minister of Fiji after narrowly winning parliamentary support.
What island groups make up Kiribati?
Kiribati is composed of three island groups: the Gilbert Islands, the Line Islands, and the Phoenix Islands.
When did the first human settlers arrive in the Gilbert Islands of Kiribati?
The first Austronesian voyagers arrived in the Gilbert Islands of Kiribati as early as 3000 B.C., though widespread settlement began around A.D. 200 by Micronesians.
How did Polynesian and Melanesian influences reach the Gilbert Islands of Kiribati?
Around 1300, Samoans and Tongans invaded the southern Gilbert Islands of Kiribati, and later Fijian arrivals introduced Melanesian cultural elements.
How did Gilbertese culture develop in Kiribati?
Extensive intermarriage among Micronesian, Polynesian, and Melanesian peoples led to the development of Gilbertese cultural traditions in Kiribati before European contact.
What was the settlement history of the Phoenix and Line Islands in Kiribati?
The Phoenix and Line Islands of Kiribati were visited by Melanesian and Polynesian peoples but were uninhabited by the time of European contact due to their isolation and limited resources.
When did sustained European contact begin in Kiribati?
Kiribati experienced sustained European contact by the 1760s, and all three island groups were named and charted by 1826.
Why did the United Kingdom establish a protectorate over Kiribati?
The United Kingdom declared a protectorate over the Gilbert and nearby Ellice Islands in 1892 to counter growing United States influence in Kiribati.
How did British colonial administration expand in Kiribati?
Phosphate-rich Banaba Island was annexed in 1900, the protectorate became a colony in 1916, and additional Line and Phoenix Islands were incorporated between 1916 and 1937.
What role did Kiribati play during World War II?
During World War II, islands of Kiribati were occupied by Japanese forces and later recaptured by United States amphibious assaults.
How did Kiribati achieve independence?
The Gilbert Islands became fully self-governing in 1977 and gained independence in 1979 under the name Kiribati.
What international agreement affected Kiribati in 1979?
In 1979, the United States relinquished all territorial claims to the Phoenix and Line Islands in a treaty of friendship with Kiribati.
Why did Kiribati purchase land in Fiji in 2012?
In 2012, Kiribati purchased land in Fiji to provide a potential resettlement option for its population due to the long-term threat of climate change.
What islands make up Tokelau?
Tokelau consists of three atolls: Fakaofo, Atafu, and Nukunonu.
When was Tokelau first settled?
Tokelau was first settled by Polynesians around A.D. 1000.
How was political authority organized in early Tokelau?
Although the atolls operated independently, Fakaofo Atoll eventually asserted dominance over the other atolls in Tokelau.
When did Europeans first encounter Tokelau?
British explorers first sighted the atolls of Tokelau in 1765 and 1791.
What impact did missionaries have on Tokelau in the 19th century?
Catholic and Protestant missionaries arrived in Tokelau in the 1840s and converted the populations of the atolls they visited.
How did slave raiding and disease affect Tokelau in the 19th century?
In 1863, Peruvian slave raiders abducted many Tokelauans, and disease outbreaks reduced the population to about 200.
How did governance evolve in Tokelau during the colonial period?
Local governance in Tokelau shifted to a Council of Elders system, which continues to function in Tokelau today.
When did Tokelau become a British protectorate?
Tokelau became a British protectorate in 1889.
How did Tokelau come under New Zealand administration?
In 1925, the United Kingdom placed Tokelau under New Zealand administration.
What was the significance of the Tokelau Islands Act of 1948?
The Tokelau Islands Act of 1948 transferred sovereignty from the United Kingdom to New Zealand and granted New Zealand citizenship to Tokelauans.
What territorial agreement was reached between Tokelau and the United States in 1979?
In 1979, the United States relinquished its claim to Tokelau, and Tokelau relinquished its claim to Swains Island.
What were the outcomes of Tokelau’s self-governance referendums?
Tokelau held referendums in 2006 and 2007 in which over 60% supported free association with New Zealand, but the measures failed to reach the required two-thirds majority.
When did the United States take possession of Baker Island?
The United States took possession of Baker Island in 1857.
What economic activity took place on Baker Island in the 19th century?
During the second half of the 19th century, United States and British companies mined guano deposits on Baker Island.
What happened to settlement attempts on Baker Island in the 20th century?
A short-lived colonization attempt on Baker Island began in 1935 but was disrupted by World War II, after which the island was abandoned.
When was Baker Island designated a National Wildlife Refuge?
Baker Island was declared a United States National Wildlife Refuge in 1974.
When was Howland Island claimed by the United States?
The United States officially claimed Howland Island in 1857.
What activities took place on Howland Island in the late 19th century?
United States and British companies mined guano on Howland Island until about 1890.
What is the historical significance of Earhart Light on Howland Island?
Earhart Light on Howland Island was partially destroyed during World War II, later rebuilt, and named in memory of aviator Amelia Earhart.
How did Jarvis Island change hands during the 19th and early 20th centuries?
Jarvis Island was discovered by the British in 1821, annexed by the United States in 1858, later claimed by the United Kingdom in 1889, and reclaimed by the United States in 1935.
Why was Jarvis Island abandoned in the 19th century?
Jarvis Island was abandoned in 1879 after its guano deposits were exhausted.
Which powers claimed Johnston Atoll in the 19th century?
Both the United States and the Kingdom of Hawaii annexed Johnston Atoll in 1858.
How was Johnston Atoll used by the United States military?
Johnston Atoll was used for high-altitude nuclear testing in the 1950s and 1960s and later served as a chemical weapons storage and disposal site until 2000.
When did the United States annex Kingman Reef?
The United States annexed Kingman Reef in 1922.
What was Kingman Reef used for during the 1930s?
During the late 1930s, Kingman Reef served as a way station for flying boats traveling between Hawaii and American Samoa.
Why are the Midway Islands historically significant?
The Midway Islands were the site of a decisive United States naval victory over Japan in 1942, marking a major turning point in World War II.
How were the Midway Islands used after World War II?
After World War II, the Midway Islands continued to serve as a United States naval station until 1993.
How did Palmyra Atoll become separated from the state of Hawaii?
Palmyra Atoll was excluded from the Hawaii Statehood Act of 1959 and remained under United States federal jurisdiction.
When did the first settlers arrive in Wallis and Futuna?
The first settlers arrived on Wallis and Futuna around 800 B.C.
How did Tongan influence shape Wallis Island?
Around A.D. 1500, Tongans invaded Wallis Island and established a chiefdom system modeled on Tonga’s hierarchical structure.
Who settled Futuna Island after failed Tongan attempts?
Samoans settled Futuna Island in the 1600s after repeated failed Tongan settlement attempts.
When did Europeans first encounter Wallis and Futuna?
Dutch explorers first encountered Wallis and Futuna in 1616, followed later by British explorer Samuel Wallis in 1767.
How did Christianity spread in Wallis and Futuna?
French Catholic missionaries arrived in Wallis and Futuna in 1837 and converted most of the population by 1846.
Why did Wallis and Futuna seek French protection?
Missionaries and King Lavelua of Uvea requested French protection in 1842 following a local rebellion in Wallis and Futuna.
When was the French protectorate over Wallis and Futuna formally established?
The French protectorate over Wallis and Futuna was formally ratified in 1887.
How did Wallis and Futuna’s political status change during World War II?
Wallis and Futuna sided with the Vichy regime during World War II until Free French and United States forces arrived in 1942.
When did Wallis and Futuna separate from New Caledonia?
In 1959, residents of Wallis and Futuna voted to separate from New Caledonia, becoming a French overseas territory in 1961.
What is the current political status of Wallis and Futuna?
Wallis and Futuna became a French overseas collectivity in 2003.
When did Wallis and Futuna join the Pacific Islands Forum?
Wallis and Futuna joined the Pacific Islands Forum as an associate member in 2018.
Who were the earliest known visitors to Wake Island?
Early Micronesian and Polynesian peoples probably visited Wake Island, and oral traditions describe periodic voyages from the Marshall Islands.
When did Europeans first encounter Wake Island?
Wake Island was first sighted by Spanish explorer Alvaro de Mendana de Neyra in 1568.
Was Wake Island inhabited at the time of European contact?
Wake Island was uninhabited when first seen by Europeans in the 16th and 18th centuries.
Why did the United States annex Wake Island in 1899?
The United States annexed Wake Island in 1899 to use it as a cable and refueling station for Hawaii, the Philippines, and Guam.
How was Wake Island used during the 1930s?
In the 1930s, Pan American Airways built facilities on Wake Island to serve as a stopover for trans-Pacific flights between the United States and China.
What role did Wake Island play during World War II?
In 1941, the United States installed military assets on Wake Island, which was later captured by Japan and held until the end of World War II.
How was Wake Island used after World War II?
After World War II, commercial airlines resumed using Wake Island as a refueling stop beginning in 1946.
What territorial claim did the Marshall Islands make regarding Wake Island?
In 1973, the Marshall Islands claimed Wake Island based on oral traditions, although the United States did not recognize the claim.
Why did the United States restrict access to Wake Island in the 1970s?
In 1974, the United States military took exclusive control of Wake Island’s airstrip and restricted civilian access.
How has Wake Island been used since the late 20th century?
Since the 1970s, Wake Island has been used for missile defense testing by the United States.
What conservation status was granted to Wake Island in 2009?
In 2009, Wake Island was included in the Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument.
Who first settled Barbados?
Barbados was first settled by the British in 1627.
What labor system supported early plantation agriculture in Barbados?
Enslaved Africans worked on sugar plantations that supported Barbados’s early plantation economy.
How did Barbados’s role in the sugar industry change over time?
By 1720, Barbados was no longer dominant in the Caribbean sugar industry, having been surpassed by Jamaica and the Leeward Islands.
When was slavery abolished in Barbados?
Slavery was abolished in Barbados in 1834.
What industries shaped Barbados’s economy during the 20th century?
Throughout much of the 20th century, Barbados’s economy relied heavily on sugar, rum, and molasses production.
When did Barbados gain independence from the United Kingdom?
Barbados gained independence from the United Kingdom in 1966.
What economic changes occurred in Barbados during the 1990s?
In the 1990s, tourism and manufacturing surpassed sugar production in economic importance in Barbados.
When did Barbados become a republic?
Barbados became a republic in 2021.
Who became the first president of Barbados?
Sandra Mason became the first president of Barbados after the country transitioned to a republic.
What civilizations existed in Belize before European contact?
Belize was home to several Mayan city-states that flourished until their decline at the end of the first millennium A.D.
Which European powers competed for control of Belize in the colonial period?
During the 17th and 18th centuries, Britain and Spain disputed control over the territory that is now Belize.
When did Belize formally become a British colony?
Belize formally became a British colony in 1862 under the name British Honduras.
Why was Belize’s independence delayed?
Belize’s independence was delayed due to territorial disputes between the United Kingdom and Guatemala.
When did Belize gain independence?
Belize gained independence in 1981 after prolonged diplomatic negotiations related to territorial claims.
How did Guatemala respond to Belize’s independence?
Guatemala refused to recognize Belize as an independent nation until 1992.
What unresolved issue remains between Belize and Guatemala?
Belize and Guatemala continue to have an unresolved border dispute stemming from historical territorial claims.
Who first claimed the island that includes Sint Maarten and when?
Christopher Columbus claimed the island that includes Sint Maarten for Spain in 1493.
Which European power first occupied Sint Maarten and for what purpose?
The Dutch occupied Sint Maarten in 1631 to exploit the island’s salt deposits.
How did control of Sint Maarten shift during the 17th century?
Spain retook Sint Maarten in 1633, but later relinquished the island in 1648 when it was divided between the Dutch and the French.
How was the island divided between the Dutch and French territories?
After repeated border changes over two centuries, the Dutch retained about 39% of the island, which became Sint Maarten.
How did plantation agriculture affect Sint Maarten during the colonial period?
Cotton, tobacco, and sugar plantations expanded African slavery on Sint Maarten during the 18th and 19th centuries.
When was slavery abolished in Sint Maarten?
Slavery was abolished in Sint Maarten in 1863.
How did Sint Maarten’s economy change in the 20th century?
Sint Maarten’s economy declined until 1939, when it became a free port, followed by rapid tourism growth beginning in the 1950s.
What was Sint Maarten’s political status within the Kingdom of the Netherlands before 2010?
In 1954, Sint Maarten became part of the Netherlands Antilles within the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
When did Sint Maarten become a self-governing country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands?
Sint Maarten became a self-governing country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands in 2010 after a 2000 referendum.
What impact did Hurricane Irma have on Sint Maarten in 2017?
In 2017, Hurricane Irma caused extensive damage in Sint Maarten, with the United Nations estimating that about 90% of buildings were damaged or destroyed.
Who first claimed Saint Martin for Europe and when?
Christopher Columbus claimed Saint Martin for Spain in 1493 and named it after the feast day of St. Martin of Tours.
Which European powers competed for control of Saint Martin in the 17th century?
The Dutch and Spanish competed for control of Saint Martin until Spain relinquished the island to France and the Netherlands in 1648.
How was Saint Martin divided between France and the Netherlands?
After the 1648 division, France eventually retained about 61% of Saint Martin following centuries of fluctuating borders.
How did slavery develop on Saint Martin?
The cultivation of sugarcane introduced African slavery to Saint Martin in the late 18th century.
When was slavery abolished in Saint Martin?
Slavery was abolished in Saint Martin in 1848.
How did Saint Martin’s economy change during the 20th century?
Saint Martin became a free port in 1939, and tourism expanded significantly during the 1970s and 1980s.
How did Saint Martin’s political status change in the early 21st century?
In 2007, Saint Martin became a French overseas collectivity after voting in 2003 to separate from Guadeloupe.
How did events in 2010 affect the island shared with Saint Martin?
In 2010, the southern portion of the island became Sint Maarten, a self-governing country within the Kingdom of the Netherlands, while Saint Martin remained a French collectivity.
What impact did Hurricane Irma have on Saint Martin in 2017?
Hurricane Irma caused widespread destruction in Saint Martin in 2017, with the United Nations estimating that about 90% of buildings were damaged or destroyed.
Who inhabited Puerto Rico before European contact?
Puerto Rico was populated for centuries by aboriginal peoples before European contact.
When and by whom was Puerto Rico claimed for Spain?
Puerto Rico was claimed by the Spanish Crown in 1493 following Christopher Columbus’s second voyage to the Americas.
How did Spanish colonial rule affect Puerto Rico?
During roughly 400 years of Spanish colonial rule, Puerto Rico’s indigenous population was nearly exterminated and African slave labor was introduced.
How did Puerto Rico become a territory of the United States?
Puerto Rico was ceded to the United States in 1898 as a result of the Spanish-American War.
When were Puerto Ricans granted United States citizenship?
Puerto Ricans were granted United States citizenship in 1917.
When did Puerto Rico begin electing its own governors?
Puerto Rico has had popularly elected governors since 1948.
What political change occurred in Puerto Rico in 1952?
In 1952, Puerto Rico enacted a constitution that provided for internal self-government.
What were the outcomes of Puerto Rico’s political status plebiscites before 2012?
In plebiscites held in 1967, 1993, and 1998, voters in Puerto Rico chose not to alter the island’s existing political status with the United States.
What did the 2012 and 2020 referendums indicate about Puerto Rico’s political status?
The 2012 vote left open the possibility of statehood, and a 2020 referendum showed a narrow preference for Puerto Rico to become a U.S. state.
What major event affected Puerto Rico in 2017?
In 2017, Hurricane Maria struck Puerto Rico and caused damage estimated in the tens of billions of dollars.
When did the Russian Empire annex Kyrgyzstan?
The Russian Empire annexed most of the territory of present-day Kyrgyzstan in 1876.
What happened during the Kyrgyz revolt of 1916?
In 1916, the Kyrgyz staged a major revolt against the Tsarist Empire, during which almost one-sixth of the Kyrgyz population was killed.
When did Kyrgyzstan become a Soviet republic?
Kyrgyzstan became a Soviet republic in 1926.
When did Kyrgyzstan gain independence?
Kyrgyzstan gained independence in 1991 following the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
What political events occurred in Kyrgyzstan in 2005 and 2010?
Nationwide demonstrations in Kyrgyzstan in 2005 and 2010 led to the removal of the country’s first two presidents, Askar Akaev and Kurmanbek Bakiev.
Who became president of Kyrgyzstan in 2011?
Almazbek Atambaev was sworn in as president of Kyrgyzstan in 2011.
Why was the 2017 presidential transition in Kyrgyzstan significant?
In 2017, Almazbek Atambaev became the first president of Kyrgyzstan to complete a full term and voluntarily step down in accordance with constitutional limits.
What led to political change in Kyrgyzstan in 2020?
Protests against parliamentary election results in 2020 led to the resignation of President Sooronbay Jeenbekov and the rise of Sadyr Japarov as acting president of Kyrgyzstan.
What political changes were approved in Kyrgyzstan in 2021?
In 2021, voters in Kyrgyzstan elected Sadyr Japarov as president and approved constitutional changes that shifted the country from a parliamentary to a presidential system.
What ongoing challenges does Kyrgyzstan face?
Kyrgyzstan continues to face challenges related to democratization, corruption, regional relations, climate vulnerabilities, border security, and potential terrorist threats.
When does China’s recorded civilization begin?
China’s recorded civilization dates to at least the 13th century B.C., beginning under the Shang Dynasty and followed by the Zhou Dynasty.
Which dynasties ruled China before the imperial era?
Before the imperial era, China was ruled by the Shang Dynasty until 1046 B.C. and the Zhou Dynasty from 1046 to 221 B.C.
When did the imperial era of China begin and end?
China’s imperial era began in 221 B.C. under the Qin Dynasty and ended in 1912 with the fall of the Qing Dynasty.
What conditions weakened the Qing Dynasty in the 19th century?
In the 19th century, the Qing Dynasty weakened due to territorial overextension, insolvency, civil war, imperialism, military defeats, and foreign expropriation of ports and infrastructure in China.
What political change followed the Revolution of 1911 in China?
Following the Revolution of 1911, China became a republic under Sun Yat-sen and the Kuomintang Party.
Why was early republican China politically unstable?
Early republican China was marked by internal division, warlordism, and continued foreign intervention.
What conflict emerged in China during the late 1920s?
In the late 1920s, a civil war erupted in China between the Kuomintang-led government under Chiang Kai-shek and the Chinese Communist Party.
How did Japan’s invasion affect China between 1937 and 1945?
Japan’s full-scale invasion of China in 1937 led to eight years of warfare that devastated the country and caused up to 20 million deaths by 1945.
How did the Chinese Civil War conclude?
The Chinese Civil War ended in 1949 with a victory by the Chinese Communist Party under Mao Zedong.
What political system was established in China after 1949?
After 1949, Mao Zedong and the Chinese Communist Party established an autocratic socialist system in China.
Which Mao-era campaigns had severe consequences in China?
The Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution in China caused widespread disruption and resulted in the deaths of millions of people.
When did China begin market-oriented reforms?
China began market-oriented economic reforms in 1978 under leaders such as Deng Xiaoping, while maintaining Chinese Communist Party rule.
How did economic reforms change China’s economy?
Following economic reforms, China experienced rapid growth, lifted hundreds of millions out of poverty, and became the world’s second-largest economy by 2011.
How has China expanded its global influence in recent decades?
Over the past decade, China has expanded its global influence through military deployments, participation in international organizations, and the Belt and Road Initiative launched in 2013.
What political changes occurred under Xi Jinping?
Xi Jinping assumed top leadership positions in China between 2012 and 2013, and in 2018 presidential term limits were abolished, allowing him to secure a third term in 2023.
How did the United Kingdom first acquire Hong Kong?
The United Kingdom seized Hong Kong in 1841, and China formally ceded Hong Kong to the UK in 1842 at the end of the First Opium War.
How did British control over Hong Kong expand in the 19th century?
British control over Hong Kong expanded when the Kowloon Peninsula was added in 1860 after the Second Opium War and the New Territories were leased to the UK for 99 years in 1898.
What agreement determined Hong Kong’s return to China?
The 1984 UK-China agreement determined that Hong Kong would be returned to China and become a Special Administrative Region of the People’s Republic of China in 1997.
What political system was promised to Hong Kong after 1997?
After 1997, Hong Kong was promised a "one country, two systems" arrangement that guaranteed a high degree of autonomy except in foreign and defense affairs.
How did Hong Kong perform economically after the 1997 handover?
After the 1997 handover, Hong Kong continued to thrive as an international financial center.
What factors led to major unrest in Hong Kong during the 2010s?
Growing Chinese political influence and dissatisfaction with the Hong Kong Government led to widespread unrest, including large pro-democracy demonstrations in Hong Kong in 2019.
What triggered the large-scale protests in Hong Kong in 2019?
The 2019 protests in Hong Kong were triggered by an attempt by the Hong Kong Government to revise a local ordinance to allow extraditions to mainland China.
How did authorities respond to protests in Hong Kong after 2019?
Following the protests, the Hong Kong Government and the Chinese Government reduced Hong Kong’s autonomy and imposed new restrictions on civil and political rights.
What actions were taken against political opposition in Hong Kong?
Authorities in Hong Kong arrested democratic lawmakers and political figures, while others fled abroad, and numerous civil society organizations and independent media outlets were shut down.
How was Hong Kong’s electoral system changed in 2021?
In 2021, Beijing imposed a more restrictive electoral system in Hong Kong, restructuring the Legislative Council and limiting candidates to those approved by the government.
What was the outcome of the 2021 Legislative Council election in Hong Kong?
The changes to Hong Kong’s electoral system ensured that nearly all seats in the 2021 Legislative Council election were won by pro-establishment candidates.
What legal change was enacted in Hong Kong in 2024?
In 2024, Hong Kong’s Legislative Council passed a new national security law under Article 23 of the Basic Law, further expanding government powers to curb dissent.
What were the earliest kingdoms on the Korean Peninsula before unification?
The earliest recorded kingdom on the Korean Peninsula was Choson, dating to approximately 2300 B.C., followed by the kingdoms of Kogoryo, Baekche, and Silla in what is now South Korea.
Which kingdom first unified most of the Korean Peninsula?
Silla unified most of the Korean Peninsula in 688 after allying with China, creating the first unified Korean state that included much of present-day South Korea.
Which dynasties ruled Korea after the fall of Silla?
After Silla collapsed in the 9th century, Korea was ruled by the Koryo Dynasty from 918 to 1392 and the Joseon Dynasty from 1392 to 1910, shaping the historical foundations of South Korea.
How did imperial rivalries affect Korea in the late 19th and early 20th centuries?
In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Korea became the focus of rivalry among Chinese, Japanese, and Russian empires, contributing to instability in what is now South Korea.
When and how did Japan annex Korea?
After the Sino-Japanese War and Russo-Japanese War, Japan formally annexed Korea in 1910, beginning colonial rule over the territory that includes modern South Korea.
How did South Korea emerge after World War II?
After Japan’s surrender in 1945, a US-supported democratic government known as the Republic of Korea was established in the southern half of the Korean Peninsula, forming South Korea.
What role did South Korea play in the Korean War?
During the Korean War from 1950 to 1953, South Korea was defended by US and UN forces against a North Korean invasion supported by China and the Soviet Union.
How was the division between North and South Korea formalized?
Following the 1953 armistice that ended active fighting in the Korean War, South Korea and North Korea were separated by a demilitarized zone.
Who were the early leaders of South Korea after independence?
Syngman Rhee served as South Korea’s first president from 1948 to 1960, followed by Park Chung-hee, who came to power in a 1961 coup.
How did South Korea’s economy change under Park Chung-hee?
During Park Chung-hee’s rule from 1961 to 1979, South Korea experienced rapid economic growth, with per capita income rising to roughly 17 times that of North Korea by 1979.
When did South Korea transition toward democratic governance?
South Korea began its democratic transition with its first free presidential election in 1987 under a revised constitution.
Who was the first civilian president of South Korea’s democratic era?
Kim Young-sam became the first civilian president of South Korea’s new democratic era in 1993.
Why did President Kim Dae-jung receive the Nobel Peace Prize?
President Kim Dae-jung received the Nobel Peace Prize in 2000 for his contributions to democracy in South Korea and his Sunshine Policy toward North Korea.
What political crisis occurred during Park Geun-hye’s presidency?
In 2016, South Korea’s National Assembly impeached President Park Geun-hye over a corruption and influence-peddling scandal.
Who became president of South Korea after the 2017 election?
Moon Jae-in won South Korea’s 2017 presidential election following the impeachment of Park Geun-hye.
Who won South Korea’s 2022 presidential election?
Yoon Suk Yeol won South Korea’s 2022 presidential election by the narrowest margin in the country’s history.
How have relations between South Korea and North Korea evolved in recent years?

Relations between South Korea and North Korea have remained tense, despite brief diplomatic engagement in 2018 and 2019, and deteriorated further in 2024 when North Korea ended all economic cooperation with South Korea.
What early nomadic empires ruled the territory of modern Mongolia?
The territory of modern Mongolia was ruled by several nomadic empires, beginning with the Xiongnu in the 4th century B.C.
Who unified the Mongol tribes in the early 13th century?
Temüjin, later known as Genghis Khan, unified the Mongol tribes in the early 1200s, laying the foundation for the Mongol Empire in Mongolia.
How large was the Mongol Empire at its height?
By the time of Genghis Khan’s death in 1227, the Mongol Empire extended across much of Eurasia, making it one of the largest empires in history and centered in Mongolia.
How did Genghis Khan’s successors expand the Mongol Empire?
Successors of Genghis Khan, including Ögödei and Khubilai Khan, expanded the Mongol Empire into Eastern Europe, the Middle East, and China, where the Yuan Dynasty was established.
What caused the decline of the Mongol Empire?
The Mongol Empire fragmented in the 14th century after failed invasions of regions such as Japan and Java, leading to its eventual decline.
When did Mongolia fall under Qing Dynasty rule?
Mongolia came under the control of the Manchu-led Qing Dynasty in the 17th century.
How did Mongolia gain independence in the early 20th century?
After the collapse of Qing rule in 1911, Mongolia declared independence and secured it in 1921 with support from the Soviet Union.
What political system did Mongolia adopt in 1924?
In 1924, Mongolia became a socialist state known as the Mongolian People’s Republic.
What was Mongolia’s relationship with the Soviet Union during the Cold War?
Until 1989, Mongolia functioned as a Soviet satellite state, relying heavily on Soviet economic, military, and political support.
When did Mongolia transition to democracy?
Mongolia peacefully transitioned to a democratic system in 1990 following the collapse of communist rule.
What constitutional changes occurred in Mongolia in the early 1990s?
In 1992, Mongolia adopted a new constitution that established a democratic political system and a free-market economy.
Which political parties have dominated Mongolia’s democratic era?
Since democratization, Mongolia’s political system has been dominated by competition between the Mongolian People’s Party and the Democratic Party.
What political shift occurred in Mongolia between 2020 and 2021?
Between 2020 and 2021, the Mongolian People’s Party consolidated power by winning a parliamentary supermajority and the presidency.
Who won Mongolia’s 2021 presidential election?
Ukhnaagiin Khurelsukh won Mongolia’s June 2021 presidential election as the candidate of the Mongolian People’s Party.
How does Mongolia balance its foreign relations?
Mongolia balances its foreign relations by maintaining ties with Russia and China while also engaging with partners such as Japan, South Korea, and the United States.
What are the Spratly Islands and why are they significant?
The Spratly Islands consist of more than 100 small islands and reefs surrounded by rich fishing grounds and potentially significant oil and gas deposits in the South China Sea.
Which countries claim sovereignty over the Spratly Islands?
China, Taiwan, and Vietnam claim the Spratly Islands in their entirety, while Malaysia and the Philippines claim portions of the Spratly Islands.
How many features in the Spratly Islands are currently occupied?
Around 70 disputed islets and reefs in the Spratly Islands are occupied by China, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam.
What is Brunei’s position regarding the Spratly Islands?
Since 1985, Brunei has claimed a continental shelf and exclusive economic zone overlapping a southern reef in the Spratly Islands but has not made a formal territorial claim to the reef itself.
When did North Macedonia gain independence from Yugoslavia?
North Macedonia gained independence peacefully from Yugoslavia in 1991 under the name Macedonia.
Why did Greece oppose the name Macedonia?
Greece objected to the name Macedonia because it believed the name implied territorial claims over the Greek region of Macedonia.
Under what name was North Macedonia admitted to the United Nations?
North Macedonia was admitted to the United Nations in 1993 under the provisional name The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
How did relations between North Macedonia and Greece evolve in the 1990s?
In 1995, Greece lifted a trade embargo on North Macedonia and both countries agreed to normalize relations, although the name dispute remained unresolved.
What conflict occurred in North Macedonia in 2001?
In 2001, ethnic Albanian grievances in North Macedonia escalated into an armed conflict that was resolved through the Ohrid Framework Agreement.
What was the Ohrid Framework Agreement?
The Ohrid Framework Agreement ended the 2001 conflict in North Macedonia and established constitutional and legal reforms that enhanced minority rights.
What changes occurred to language policy in North Macedonia in 2018?
In 2018, North Macedonia adopted a law that made Albanian an official language at the national level while retaining Macedonian as the sole official language in international relations.
What was the Prespa Agreement and when did it take effect?
The Prespa Agreement was signed in 2018 between Macedonia and Greece and entered into force on 12 February 2019, officially renaming the country North Macedonia.
When did North Macedonia join NATO?
North Macedonia joined NATO in 2020 after amending its constitution in accordance with the Prespa Agreement.
When did North Macedonia begin European Union accession talks?
North Macedonia opened European Union accession talks in 2022 following the resolution of a veto by Bulgaria.
What political crisis affected North Macedonia after the 2014 elections?
The 2014 legislative and presidential elections in North Macedonia triggered a political crisis that escalated in 2015 amid revelations of alleged government corruption and abuse.
What ongoing challenges does North Macedonia face today?
North Macedonia continues to face challenges including democratic reform, economic development, and combating organized crime and corruption.
When may Norse explorers have first discovered Svalbard?
Norse explorers may have first discovered the Svalbard archipelago in the 12th century.
What role did Svalbard play during the 17th and 18th centuries?
During the 17th and 18th centuries, Svalbard served as an international base for whaling operations.
When was Norway’s sovereignty over Svalbard recognized?
Norway’s sovereignty over Svalbard was internationally recognized by treaty in 1920.
When did Norway formally assume control of Svalbard?
Norway formally assumed control of Svalbard five years after the 1920 treaty, taking over the territory in 1925.
When did coal mining begin in Svalbard?
Coal mining in Svalbard began in the 20th century and continues today.
Which countries continue mining operations in Svalbard?
Coal mining in Svalbard is still carried out by both a Norwegian company and a Russian company.
How did Clipperton Island get its name?
Clipperton Island was named after John Clipperton, an English pirate who was rumored to have used the atoll as a hideout in the early 18th century.
When was Clipperton Island annexed by France?
France annexed Clipperton Island in 1855.
Which other countries claimed Clipperton Island in the late 19th century?
In addition to France, Clipperton Island was claimed by the United States and seized by Mexico in 1897.
How was sovereignty over Clipperton Island ultimately decided?
An international arbitration awarded Clipperton Island to France in 1931.
When did France take possession of Clipperton Island following arbitration?
France formally took possession of Clipperton Island in 1935 after the arbitration decision.
When did Argentina declare independence from Spain?
Argentina declared independence from Spain in 1816 as part of the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata.
How did Argentina emerge as a separate state after independence?
After Bolivia, Paraguay, and Uruguay separated from the United Provinces of the Río de la Plata, the remaining territory became Argentina.
How did European immigration shape Argentina between the 19th and 20th centuries?
Between 1860 and 1930, large numbers of European immigrants, mainly from Italy and Spain, significantly shaped Argentina’s population and culture.
What characterized Argentina’s political history before the mid-20th century?
Until the mid-20th century, Argentina’s history was marked by recurring political instability and conflict between civilian governments and the military.
Who was Juan Domingo Perón and why was he significant?
Juan Domingo Perón was a former president of Argentina and founder of the Peronist movement, serving three non-consecutive terms after World War II until his death in 1974.
How did military rule return to Argentina in the 1970s?
Military interference during the Perón era culminated in a military junta seizing power in Argentina in 1976.
What happened during the 1982 Falklands War?
In 1982, Argentina’s military junta unsuccessfully attempted to seize the Falkland Islands from the United Kingdom.
When was democracy restored in Argentina?
Democracy was restored in Argentina in 1983 following the collapse of the military regime.
What crisis challenged Argentina’s democracy in the early 2000s?
A severe economic crisis in 2001–02 triggered violent protests in Argentina and led to the resignation of several presidents.
Who governed Argentina during the period from 2003 to 2015?
Argentina was governed by Peronist presidents Néstor Kirchner from 2003 to 2007 and Cristina Fernández de Kirchner from 2007 to 2015.
How did Argentina’s economy change after 2011?
After several years of strong growth from 2003 to 2011, Argentina experienced fiscal deterioration, economic stagnation, and increased isolation.
What political shift occurred in Argentina after 2015?
Argentina underwent a period of economic reform and international reintegration under President Mauricio Macri from 2015 to 2019.
What led to the return of a Peronist government in 2019?
Economic recession and dissatisfaction with Macri’s policies led to the election of a Peronist government in 2019 headed by President Alberto Fernández.
What factors influenced Argentina’s 2023 presidential election?
High public debt, inflation, and ongoing monetary problems contributed to the 2023 election outcome in Argentina, which resulted in the election of Javier Milei.
Where are South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands located?
South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands are located approximately 1,000 kilometers east of the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic Ocean.
When did British administration of South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands begin?
South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands have been under British administration since 1908.
When were South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands occupied by Argentina?
Argentina briefly occupied South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands in 1982 during the Falklands conflict.
What was the historical role of Grytviken on South Georgia?
Grytviken on South Georgia served as a major whaling station during the 19th and early 20th centuries.
Why is Ernest Shackleton associated with South Georgia?
Explorer Ernest Shackleton stopped at South Georgia in 1914 and later returned in 1916 to organize the rescue of his stranded crew; he died in 1922 and is buried at Grytviken.
What is the current use of the Grytviken station?
Today, the former whaling station at Grytviken houses scientists from the British Antarctic Survey.
What maritime protection measures were taken by the United Kingdom in 1993?
In 1993, the United Kingdom extended the exclusive fishing zone around South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands from 12 nautical miles to 200 nautical miles.
What was the historical significance of the delta region that became Bangladesh?
The delta region at the confluence of the Ganges and Brahmaputra river systems, now known as Bangladesh, was a loosely incorporated outpost of various empires during much of the first millennium A.D.
When did Islam begin spreading in the region of present-day Bangladesh?
Muslim settlement and conversion in the region of present-day Bangladesh began in the 10th century, largely through Arab and Persian traders and preachers.
When did Europeans establish trading posts in Bangladesh?
European powers established trading posts in the region that is now Bangladesh during the 16th century.
How did Bangladesh become part of British India?
The region known as Bengal, including what is now Bangladesh, became part of British India during the colonial period.
What was the status of Bangladesh after the 1947 partition of India?
After the partition of India in 1947, the Muslim-majority eastern region of Bengal became East Pakistan, which later became Bangladesh.
What caused the Bengali independence movement?
Calls for greater autonomy and growing political and economic tensions between East and West Pakistan led to a Bengali independence movement in what is now Bangladesh.
How did Bangladesh achieve independence in 1971?
Bangladesh achieved independence in 1971 after a war led by the Awami League and supported by India, resulting in the creation of an independent state.
What political changes occurred in Bangladesh after independence?
Following independence, the Awami League government in Bangladesh was overthrown by the military in 1975, beginning a period of coups and military-backed rule.
When was the Bangladesh Nationalist Party formed and how did it come to power?
The Bangladesh Nationalist Party was created after a military-backed government took power in 1979 following a series of coups in Bangladesh.
When did democratic elections resume in Bangladesh?
Democratic elections resumed in Bangladesh in 1991 after years of military-backed governance.
How did political power shift in Bangladesh between 1991 and 2008?
From 1991 to 2008, political power in Bangladesh alternated mainly between the Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, with a brief military-backed caretaker government in 2007.
When did Bangladesh return to fully democratic rule?
Bangladesh returned to fully democratic rule in 2008 with the election of the Awami League government led by Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.
When was the British Indian Ocean Territory established?
The British Indian Ocean Territory was established as an overseas territory of the United Kingdom in 1965.
How did the composition of the British Indian Ocean Territory change after 1976?
After some islands were transferred to the Seychelles following its independence in 1976, the British Indian Ocean Territory consisted of the six main island groups of the Chagos Archipelago.
Which island in the British Indian Ocean Territory is inhabited?
Diego Garcia is the only inhabited island in the British Indian Ocean Territory.
What occurred to the Chagossian population between 1967 and 1973?
Between 1967 and 1973, the agricultural workers living in the British Indian Ocean Territory were relocated, primarily to Mauritius and the Seychelles.
What legal actions did Chagossians pursue regarding the British Indian Ocean Territory?
Beginning in 1998, displaced Chagossians pursued lawsuits against the British Government seeking compensation and the right to return to the British Indian Ocean Territory.
What was the outcome of UK court rulings on the Chagossians’ right of return?

Although lower courts initially ruled in favor of the Chagossians, the UK House of Lords overturned those decisions in 2008, ruling that there was no right of return to the British Indian Ocean Territory.
What international rulings affected the status of the British Indian Ocean Territory?
In 2015 and 2019, international legal bodies ruled that aspects of the United Kingdom’s administration of the British Indian Ocean Territory were inconsistent with international law.
What agreement was signed regarding the future of the British Indian Ocean Territory in 2025?

In May 2025, the United Kingdom and Mauritius signed an agreement providing for the transfer of sovereignty of the British Indian Ocean Territory to Mauritius while allowing the UK to lease Diego Garcia for 99 years.
When did Algeria gain independence?
Algeria gained independence from France on 5 July 1962.
When did Angola gain independence?
Angola gained independence from Portugal on 11 November 1975.
When did Botswana gain independence?
Botswana gained independence from the United Kingdom on 30 September 1966.
When did Benin gain independence?
Benin gained independence from France on 1 August 1960.
When did Burundi gain independence?
Burundi gained independence on 1 July 1962 from United Nations trusteeship under Belgian administration
When did Chad gain independence?
Chad gained independence from France on 11 August 1960.
When did Democratic Republic of the Congo gain independence?
The Democratic Republic of the Congo gained independence from Belgium on 30 June 1960.
When did Cameroon gain independence?
Cameroon gained independence from French-administered United Nations trusteeship on 1 January 1960.
When did Comoros gain independence?
Comoros gained independence from France on 6 July 1975.
When did Central African Republic gain independence?
The Central African Republic gained independence from France on 13 August 1960.
When did Cabo Verde gain independence?
Cabo Verde gained independence from Portugal on 5 July 1975.
When did Djibouti gain independence?
Djibouti gained independence from France on 27 June 1977.
When did Egypt gain independence?

Egypt gained independence on 28 February 1922 from United Kingdom protectorate status, and the military-led revolution that began on 23 July 1952 led to a republic being declared on 18 June 1953 and all British troops withdrawn on 18 June 1956.
When did Equatorial Guinea gain independence?
Equatorial Guinea gained independence from Spain on 12 October 1968.
When did Eritrea gain independence?
Eritrea gained independence from Ethiopia on 24 May 1993.
When did Ethiopia gain independence?

Ethiopia is the oldest independent country in Africa and one of the oldest in the world, with its independence tracing back at least 2,000 years to the Aksumite Kingdom, which appeared in the first century B.C.
When did Gambia gain independence?
